title: Happy Families Are All Alike
description: ST. LOUISIn olden days two lovers, when they died, in honor of the love they had for one another were often buried together. Nowadays, instead, they marry. Children, cars, and houses stand above them, mark their place, for there they lie, beneath six feet of mortgage and insurance, locked in an eternal institutional embrace, their shrouds the slick white silk of shared experience.

title: San Francisco Votes Tomorrow On Hotly Contested Charter Issues
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31Still hoping to sway a huge bloc of undecided and confused voters in a special election Tuesday, thousands of volunteers began ringing doorbells in the city yesterday morning, urging people to support or oppose changes in the city charter.

title: Dividend Meetings
Jury Focuses on State Court Aide In Its Investigation of CaseFixing
description: A date book found in the desk of a State Supreme Court law assistant when he was arrested in a bribery case is at the center of a grand jury investigation into possible favors and fixes in the court.

title: Caramoor: `Lucretia Is Sung
description: The Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N. Y., has been honoring the memory of Benjamin Britten this summer, and on Friday night it gave the second of two performances of the late English composer's The Rape of Lucretia.

title: Brazilian Government Criticized for Decision To Provide Birth Pills
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 (AP)A Government decision to provide birth control pills free to women whose lives might be imperiled by pregnancy has provoked an emotional debate in this over whelmingly Roman Catholic nation.

title: Padres
description: All thumbs and erratic arms, the San Diego Padres committed six errors yesterday and presented five gift runs that helped the Mets score a 109 victory at Shea Stadium before 13,386 paid fans, plus 15,000 city firemen and their families.

title: Argentine Army Reports Freeing Kidnapped Man After ShootOut
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 31 (AP)Six leftist terrorists were killed in a shootout with security forces Saturday night and a businessman who had been kidnapped by the terrorists was freed, the army said today.

title: Sanjay Gandhi Says His Phone Is Tapped and Mail Is Opened
description: NEW DELHI, July 31 (Reuters)Sanjay Gandhi, the controversial son of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, says he is under constant surveillance, with his telephone tapped and his mail opened.

title: France Seeking Wider Influence Among Africans
description: PARIS, July 30France has evolved a broad African policy that has as its longterm goal the extension of France's special relationship with its former African colonies to each of the countries of the continent.

title: Advertising
description: The popcorn business is in for a shakeup. HuntWesson Foods Inc.. a giant food marketer that has acquired a popcorn company, plans to spend $6 million, for advertising in a category whose total annual spending has been only about 3500.000.

title: Firefighters in Canton, Ohio
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 31 (UPI)Striking firefighters in this northeastern Ohio city of 100,000 people returned to work today while contract negotiations with the city continued.

title: Music: Weekend of Beethoven
description: LENOX, Mass., July 31Tangle. wood's annual Beethoven Areekend was entrusted this year to Klaus Tennstedt, the East German conductor who has attracted a cult with the Boston Symphony both at home and here in the Berkshires. The three concerts attracted 35,685 people, and,they found Mr. Tennstedt at his best to be a superb Beethoven conductor, if perhaps a slightly erractic one.

title: Soccer
description: NORTH AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Expanding Plants Face Pollution Tradeoffs
description: HOUSTON, July 31Harry Birdwell, manager of the Oklahoma City Chamber of Commerce, was ecstatic last year when the General Motors Corporation announced plans to build a big automobile assembly plant in his city because would create 5,000 jobs and bring a badly needed economic lift.

title: $11 MILLION AT STAKE IN U.S. DENIAL TO CITY OF DISASTER STATUS
description: A Carter Administration decision to deny disaster status for New York City because of the July 1314 blackout basically means rejection of the city's bid for Federal reimbursement for $11.7 million in overtime for the Police Department and others.

title: Martin Epstein Marries Marsha Lynn Halperin
description: Marsha Lynn Halperin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Halperin of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Martin Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. lark Enstein of New York.

title: Cry for Help Wakes Up a Brooklyn Neighborhood
description: His voice was sort of high, like a little boy's voice, and .he was screaming, Help me! Don't let me die!  a 32yearold Brooklyn housewife recalled yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: Prospects were brightened for Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's Middle East mission this week with the statement by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that he was optimistic about retonvening a peace conference. There were alternatives to having the Palestine Liberation Organization represented in Geneva, Mr. Sadat said in a television interview taped last week. Israel's ,opposition to the P.L.O.'s participation in the conference has been a main obstacle to getting it started. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Insurance Giant Acts to End Mandatory Retirement at 65
description: While Congress considers abolishing mandatory retirement at age 65, a big Connecticut insurance concern has already acted on this issue.

title: Robert Boyle Marries Miss Belous, Teacher
description: Kathryn Ivanovna Belous. who teaches French, Russian and German, was married yesterday to Robert H. Boyle of Croton, N.Y., a conservationist and senior writer for Sports Illustrated. The Right Rev. Archimandrite Victoran performed the ceremony in the St. Sergius Russian Orthodox Church in Exile at the Tolstoy Foundation Farm in Valley Cottage, N.Y.

title: Some School Districts in the State Weigh Shift to Regional System
description: WOODRIDGE, July 31Declining enrollment and rising costs are forcing smaller public school districts in New Jersey to consider mergers to form regional systems.

title: O'Dwyer and 4 Rivals Seek Donations In the Race for City Council President
description: Paul O'Dwyer was served watery scrambled eggs and a lump of hashedbrown potatoes for breakfast recently in the meeting room of a West Side motel. He ignored the food, but savored the promises of campaign contributions in his race for reelection to City Council President from dozens of labor leaders at surrounding tables.

title: Iranians Are Canceling Purchase Of U.S. Airborne Radar System
description: TEHERAN, July 31 (UPI)Iran indicated today that it was withdrawing its request to buy an advanced airborne radar system from the United States, apparently in anger over a delay in Congressional approval of the $1.2 billion sale.

title: 150 U.S. Sailors Fight Capri Fire
description: CAPRI, Italy, July 31 (UPI)More tnan 150 United States Navy men from the carrier Independence gave up their shore leave today to help firemen extinguish a major brush fire on this Mediterranean resort island. The American sailors joined hundreds of foreign tourists who dug ditches and cleared a buffer zone along 1,932foot Mount Solaro, where the blaze began Friday night.

title: .44 Killer Wounds 12th and 13th Victims
description: With massive police patrols focused elsewhere in the city, the killer who calls himself Son of Sam shot and critically wounded a young couple early yesterday as they sat in a car parked on the Brooklyn waterfront a mile south of the glittering lights of the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge.

title: PROF, HOLLOWAY DIES; WHITMAN BIOGRAPHER
description: Emory Holloway, a Pulitzer Prizewinning biographer of Walt Whitman who was one of the original members of the Queens College faculty in 1937, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital, Bethlehem, Pa., at 92 years of age. A resident of Brooklyn until a few months ago, he was living with his son in Coopersburg, Pa.

title: Pakistani Regime Seeks Party Consensus on Vote
description: RAWALPINDI, PakistanA timetable for Pakistan's political future has begun to emerge. It calls for elections in midOctober, but only if a series of bottlenecks can be removed. Failure to eliminate any one of them could result in postponement or cancellation of the balloting.

title: Commodities
description: Commodity futures markets have always thrived during times of uncertainty over supplydemand and prices. Today, this uncertainty involves a basic commoditymoney. More specifically, the value of the dollar.

title: Mets
Israeli Cabinet Approves Budget That Reduces Arms Spending 6%
description: JERUSALEM, July 31 (AP)The Israeli Cabinet approved a $12.7 , billion budget for the 1977 fiscal year today that would reduce military spending by 6 percent and is designed to reduce Israel's 38percent inflation rate.

title: GIVE A HAPPY TIME. VIA FRESH AIR FUND.
description: GIVE A HAPPY TIME. VIA FRESH AIR FUND.

title: Grandstand Collapses in France
description: NIMES, France, July 31 (AP)An wooden grandstand at a small bullfight arena near this southern French city collapsed today, injuring about 40 spectators in a 10foot fall, the police said. None of the injured was reported in serious condition.

title: Pupils Learn the 3R's: Rumbling, Rattling and Roaring
description: A speaker on the dangers of noise was forced to confront the enemy head on during a talk to schoolchildren recently:  she had hardly begun her talk when her words were drowned out by the roar of an elevated train.

title: Flow Green Is My Valley, Britain's Miners Now Say
description: WIGAN, EnglandThe coal miner has never been a glamorous figure. George Orwell called him a grimy caryatid upon whose shoulders nearly everything that is not grimy is supported. But, important as he may be, the miner has never before aroused much envy.

title: Yankees'. Box. Score
Watching the Nuclear Watchmen
description: The Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works is scheduled to meet today to consider President Carter's three nominations to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the agency that oversees the safety of nuclear power plants and the export of nuclear materials that might be fashioned into bombs. Public affairs groups have attacked two of the nominees for their supposed pronuclear bias. But quite apart from the qualifications of the nominees, the process by which they were chosen raises disturbing questions about the Carter Administration's commitment to a safe nuclear policy.

title: Bank Is Taking Unusual Action In Issuing Stock
description: It has been a long time since the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation or its predecessors journeyed to the market to raise funds through a common stock issue 27 years, in fact.

title: Job Gains Made By the Retarded
description: A national campaign to find jobs for the mentally retarded is gaining momen tum.

title: Article  No Title
Upstate Crash Kills Tockev
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., July 31 (UPI)A jockey at Finger Lakes Race Track was killed in a onecar accident earl today near here, Ontario County she'', iff's deputies said. Deputies slid a car driven by John Ciccone, 27 years old, of Churchville, N.Y., went out of control on Route 21 and struck a tree.

title: Mike, a Boxer, Captures 4th Best in Show
description: BETHANY, Conn., July 31Ch. Salgray's Market Wise, a striking deep red fawn boxer with white markings owned by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Hamilburg of Brookline, Mass., took his fourth bestinshow award and second in two days today at the Elm City Kennel Club's 67th allbreed, dog show at Bethany Airport. There were 1,379 dogs in competition.

title: Former U.S. Aide Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)William D. Morgan, a former assistant. United States Attorney in Scranton, Pa., was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of fraudulently using the mails and submitting false property re,ports. Mr. Morgan, who served in the Unite States attorney's office from 1956  to 1961, is the developer of Thornhurst Lake Estates, a recreational homesite in the Pocono mountains.

title: Crime Group Leader Said to Rule Many Bar Businesses in Midtown
description: The control and much of the profits of the multimilliondollar bar business in midtown Manhattan has been taken over by an organizedcrime group led by Matthew Ianniello, confidential law enforcement records show.

title: Employees May Buy. Humphrey Browning
description: The longawaited word on the acquisition of Humphrey Browning MacDougall by Compton Advertising, New York, came Friday: The deal is apparently off.

title: Meadowlands
RESIDENTS IN STATE FAVOR NEWSPAPERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 31Newspapers predominate over radio and television as a source of news for most New Jerseyans, according to the eighth and final poll on New Jersey Images by the Eagleton Institute of Politics.

description: At 2:50 yesterday morning, Deputy, Inspector Timothy Dowd, the head of the homicide force hunting for the killer who calls himself the Son of Sam, heard the first report over the special police radio frequency: Shots fired in Bath Beach. Brooklyn.

title: United States Policy: Between the Two Chinas
description: WASHINGTONThere is now a renewed pressure on the Carter Administration to accept Peking's conditions for the establishment of full diplomatic relations. In essence, these are that we abandon all diplomatic ties with the Government in Taiwan, and that we repudiate the defense treaty that remains the island's guarantee against an invasion from the mainland. The euphemistic code word is normalization.

title: Dr. Richards Crushes Donna Lies In Jersey Tennis Opener, 61, 61
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 31Renee Richards was not overly impressive today, but she did not have to be. She easily won her singles match as play started in the $85,000 Mutual Benefit Life open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Republican Charles Percy, ranking Republican on the millionaire's committee, solemnly agreed. President Carter reaffirmed his faith in his old friend's impeccable integrity.

description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said in an interview televised here today that he would send a note to the Soviet Union about the activities of a Russian warship during recent clashes with Libya.

description: MONMOUTH BEACH, July 31Owners of highrise condominium complexes along the northern part of the shore report that sales are slowly picking up after several seasons of stagnation.

description: Although Congress seems sympathetic toward the idea of abolishing mandatory retirement at age 65, businessmen have given this traditional practice a rousing endorsement. In a survey of executives released last week, 65 percent of the respondents said they still favored compulsory retirement at age 65.

title: Red Sox Set Back Angels, 1 to 0, and Also Top Orioles, .574 to .573
description: Last Tuesday the Boston Red Sox needed some pitching help badly and called up 22yearold Don Aase, a 6foot 3inch righthander, from Pawtucket of the International League. title: DRUMMOND F. MAXWELL
description: Drummond F. Maxwell, president and chairman of the board of the Fort Lee (N.J.) Finance Company died Saturday at his home at 38 Fourth Avenue in Nyack, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

description: COWES, England, July 31 (UPI) The United States, led by Charles Kirsch's sloop, Scaramouche, from Wilmington, N.C., swept into the lead in the Admiral's Cup today after the second race of the fiverace series.

description: MOSCOW, July 31 (Reuters)A Soviet commentator accused the United States and other Western nations today of waging psychological war on the Communist world.

title: Nigerian Official Discusses Limits Of New Press Agency's Freedom
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 31 (Agence France  Presse) Nigeria's Information Commissioner says his Government does not intend to restrict the national press agency that is scheduled to start operating next October, :Jut adds that the agency will never be allowed to operate in a way that would jeopardize Government aims and objectives.

title: New Rochelle Police Find No Evidence Cowan Threatened Woman With a Gun
description: A New Rochelle police report has found no evidence that Frederick W. Cowan, the avowed Nazi who killed six people last February, brandished the murder weapon when he confronted a 26yearold woman on his street in 1975 and threatened to kill her.

description: James B. Skidmore, the former Mayor of the Village of East Hampton, L. I., died Saturday after a long illness at his home at 35 Dunemere Lane in East Hampton. He was 77 years old.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31Who Cares? was New York City Ballet's only humalong ballet until the appearance of the deliriously successful Vienna Waltzes this spring. On the last day of its now traditional Saratoga Performing Arts Center season, the company presented both ballets, the first in the afternoon and the second for its closing evening performance. Audiences could be heard softly echoing their tuneful cadences on both occasions.

description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)President Carter taught his Bible class today and warned the students and fellow worshippers not to substitute a nation or a flag or a way of life or government for God.

Trial of Honolulu Mayor Charged With Soliciting Bribe to Begin Today
description: HONOLULU. July 31Mayor Frank F. Fasi, 57yearold Connecticutborn Democrat who has been in Hawaiian politics more than a Quarter century, goes on trial in Circuit Court tomorrow on a charge of soliciting a $500,000 bribe from Hal J. Hansen, a developer who. was awarded the contract for a $50 million downtown Honolulu condominium.

title: `Working for Love of the Law
description: When John Francis Dooling Jr. was a partner in the worldly Wall Street law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, in the 1940's, a rare quality about him caught the eye of Louis Auchincloss, a perceptive colleague who went on Man in the news to fame as a novelist. The success ethic and money absolutely didn't exist for the him, Mr. Auchincloss re called last week. I'm sure he was well compensated, and he had a great many children to educate, but there was less personal ambition behind his drive than I've seen in almost any other lawyer; with him, it was a case of working for the love of the law.

title: Level of Okefenokee Swamp Falls, Posing Danger of Fire
description: WAYCROSS, Ga., July 30The Okefe nokee Swamp, which has its northern most entrance here at the edge of this south Georgia town, derives its name from a Seminole word meaning, poetical ly, Land of the Trembling Earth.

description: DULUTH, Minn., Monday, Aug. 1 (AP) About 20.000 United Steelworkers in northern Minnesota and Upper Michigan walked off the job at midnight in the first strike in the basic steel industry since 1959.

title: Top Spanish Red in Rumania
description: VIENNA, July 31 (Reuters)President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today received the Spanish Communist Party leader, Santiago Carrillo, who arrived in Rumania yesterday on a previously unannounced visit, the Rumanian press agency Agerpres reported. Mr. Carrillo, head of one of the main independentleaning Eurocommunist parties of Western Europe, was invited to Bucharest by President Ceausescu personally, the agency said.

The Clamshell Alliance is sponsoring the vigil to protest the reinstatement cf the plant's construction permit by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's appeals hoard.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: MILANThere are several food shops in this world that I hold in high esteem or, to put it another way, cherish. I would be hard pressed, for example, to visit London without stopping by Harrod's; to go to Paris without spending an hour or so at Fauchon; and in Milan I would no more miss a trip to Peck's than I would at least a glance at the Duomo and La Scala. We have noted before that. Peck's is a living food museum and is situated on one of the most interesting food thoroughfares in the world. Peck is an odd name for an Italian landmark, and it came about because the founder of the shop was a Czechoslovak named Franz Peck. He opened his place in 1892, and it still stands at No. 9 Via

title: Tending a Killer Crop
description: For more than a decade, the Federal Government has been in the anomalous position of discouraging cigarette smoking while encouraging the growing of tobacco for cigarettes. Since 1970, the Surgeon General's conclusion that smoking is harmful has been imprinted on every package of cigarettes and on every advertisementand the Federal Trade Commission has now recommended that the wording be strengthened to state flatly that smoking cigarettes may result in death. And yet the Government maintains an extensive program of price supports for tobacco, currently tying up about $647 million in price stabilization loans, and costing around $10.5 million a year to administer. But it is not the cost that is most troubling; the Commodity Credit Corporation has lost only $57 million to defaults in the 43 years of the program's existence. The troubling fact is that such a program of making loans, accepting the tobacco as collateral, and processing and storing the leaf for years should continue to exist at all.

title: Chess:

title: Argentine Puzzle: Agriculture or Industry?

title: 'Outrageous!' Film Merely Insidious
description: "Outrageous!" tells two stories, only vaguely connected, one about a schizophrenic girl and the other about a homosexual hairdresser. Liza, the girl, has recently escaped from a mental hospital and moved into Robin's apartment, where she chatters hysterically about how, because she is the one who was born dead, the bone-crushers are going to come and grind her bones to powder.Robin isn't much more lucid himself. One evening, after a hard day at the salon, he complains that "these women here, they live life like it's a can of Coke and they're afraid to drink it too fast or it'll all be gone. Life isn't a can of Coke.""Outrageous!" is entirely sympathetic to these characters, trying to show how the rest of the world misunderstands them and why their wackiness makes them wonderful. Unfortunately, the movie winds up exploiting them in an insidious and very unpleasant way. Robin and Liza seem to define themselves through their ability to shock or at least unsettle those around them. The camera, in attempting to play along with this, merely ogles them, accentuating their freakishness without offering much insight into why, for each of them, flamboyance is so desperately important.It could be argued that "Outrageous!," a low-budget Canadian production set mostly in Toronto, presents a no-holds-barred look at a certain stratum of homosexual culture and is thus noteworthy for its verisimilitude. But a film in which nobody ever seems to stop screaming unwittingly enforces stereotypes as dangerous as those favored by Anita Bryant.Craig Russell and Hollis Mc-Laren are more than convincing as Robin and Liza, but they're a little hard to watch; Miss McLaren, in particular, is either a brilliantly skittish performer or an authentic nervous wreck. Much of the film is devoted to showcasing Mr. Russell's talents as a female impersonator, because he eventually hangs up his blow dryer ("I'm sick of doing everyone else's head!") to seek his fortune in Manhattan's homosexual nightclubs.

description: AIRBORNE THROW: Angels shortstop, Rance Mulliniks, leaps over Cliff Johnson of the Yankees as he throws to first for double play on Graig Nettles hit in second inning last night on Ccast.

title: In Brooklyn, Neighbors Talk of Vengeance
description: Everywhere in Brooklyn yesterday people were talking about Son of Sam. They were trying to guess where he might strike next and how he had been living and keeping himself inconspicuous. And they were telling one another about the punishment he deserved, the way he should be made to suffer if he was cantered_

title: Venezuelan Oil Output Up 3%
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 1 (UPI)Venezuelan oil production rose 3 percent during the first half of 1977 to an average of 2.3 million barrels a day, the Energy Ministry said today. Average production for the first six months of the year was up 66,000 barrels a day from the 2.2 millionbarreladay average in the 1976 period.

title: ALBANY DEMOCRATS CALL FOR P.S.C. SPLIT
description: ALBANY, Aug. 1Alleging that consumers of New York State are not adequately represented by the Public Service Commission, a report from the State Senate's Democratic minority recommended today that most of the commission's consumeradvocate functions be shifted to a separate, independent agency.

title: Victoria Falls Reported Shelled
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 1 (Reuters) Black guerrillas fired rockets during the night at a motel at the Rhodesia tourist resort at Victoria Falls, but no one was injured, the resort's manager said today. The attack was definitely staged from  within Rhodesia, the manager, Freddy Pacella, said.

title: Barzilauskas Seen Returning to Old Form on Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 1Just for fun, Carl Barzilauskas once bit into the sleeve of his jacket and tore it off at the shoulder with his teeth.

title: 2 MORE AIRLINES ASK TO CUT EUROPE FARE
description: Two more carriers, Trans World Airlines and Trans International Airlines, yesterday joined in the intensifying competition to offer lower fares to Europe

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Aug. (AP)Thai authorities said early today that Cambodian troops had attacked two Tliai border villages, killing at least 16 people and setting fire to some buildings.

title: Despite Falling Output, British Coal's Future Looks Bright
description: WIGAN, EnglandBritain nationalized its coal mines 30 years ego. Since then, the mines have become safer and more pleasant for the men who work underground. But they give headaches to the state managers who replaced the private owners.

title: Archbishop Lucey, Assisted Poor
description: Former Archbishop Robert E. Lucey of San Antonio, who won a national reputation as a champion of civil rights and social justice, died in San Antonio yesterday after a long illness. He was 68 years

title: Navy Reviving the BellBattorns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)The Navy announced today that it was returning the traditional uniform of bellbottomed trousers and white caps to its lower enlisted ranks.

title: Gives His Approval to 5Year Series of Contracts
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 1It wasn't the money that had kept .him away, Brad Van Pelt said today as he finally agreed to rejoin the Giants after becoming a free agent last season.

title: Advertising
description: Among the advertising agencies that have submitted proposals in the hope of winning the recruiting account of the Army and Air Force National Guard is Grey Advertising, one of the country's largest agencies and one that is committed to getting Government work.

title: Notes on People
description: Steven Clark Rockefeller, a son of Nelson A. Rockefeller and Mary Rockefeller, was married Saturday to Doris Selene Liles, a family spokesman said yesterday. Mr. Rockefeller made headlines in 1959 when he married Anne Marie Rasmussen, a Norwegian who had worked in the Rockefeller household as a maid. The couple were later divorced. The new Mrs. Rockefeller, also previously married, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Liles, of Chesapeake, Va. Like Mr. Rockefeller, slie holds a Master of Divinity degree from Union Theological Seminary. She teaches at the State University of New York t Plattsburgh and he teaches at Middlebury College in Vermont. The wedding took place outdoors on the Rockefeller estate at Pocantico Hills, N.Y. The sma Ilceremony was attended by members of the families and friends.

title: STEEL OUTPUT IN WEEK UP AFTER 8 STRAIGHT DROPS
description: Steel production showed a slight increase, of 0.4 percent, for the week ended July 30 over the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Withdrawal Symptoms in Korea
description: So the South Koreans will begin to kick their American habit. That is the significance of the phased withdrawal of United States ground troops agreed to last week in Seoul. But it won't be cold turkey: When the 27,0.00 ground troops depart, Air Force units (8.000 strong) and logistics specialists (6,000 men ) will be left behind.

title: Capital's Legendary Bachelor Introduces Bride to Friends
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Representative John Brademas, Washington's reigning bachelor for the past 20 years, invited 1,100 friends to meet his bride of three weeks, the former Mary Ellen Briggs, at a garden party in Georgetown's Dumbarton Oaks yesterday afternoon.

title: Pork Bellies Futures Fall Limit; Corn Recovers to Close up 1/2 Cent
description: Prices of frozen pork bellies futures dropped the daily limit of 2 cents a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and set new contract lows in the process.

title: Antinuclear Movement Growing in West Europe
description: PARIS, Aug. IAlthough later in gettings started than in the United States, public opposition to nuclear energy in Western Europe has emerged as a powerful movement cutting across national boundaries, forcing governments to curtail development and compelling political parties to engage is debates on energy programs.

title: Clarence W. Benedict, 74; U.S. Golf Association ExPresident
description: Clarence W. Benedict, president of the United States Golf Association in 1964 and 1965, died Sunday while visiting Nantucket, Mass. A former resident of Armonk, N.Y., he had been living in Stuart, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A music hall owner held a neighbor hostage at knifepoint here yesterday for an hour because of a contractual dispute with a music group, and then released her unharmed. He was arrested and committed to Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital for 15 days of observation.

title: WALTER MYERS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 1 (UPI)Walter Myers, 75 years old, a veteran official of the Indianapolis 500 auto race, died yesterday. Mr. Myers, a native of Evansville, Ind., was chief observer for many years at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He also served as a steward and once was a riding mechanic.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES LIMIT ON BUSING ORDERS
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. I (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill that would limit the extent to which the Federal courts could order busing to desegregate schools.

title: First Big Strike In 18 Years Idles Some Steel Locals
description: The first major strike in the steel industry in 18 years closed iron ore mines and processing plants yesterday across northern Minnesota and Michigan, the heart of the ore country.

title: Byrne and Bateman Lay Groundwork for Fall Campaign
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1The campaign for Governor will become New Jersey's most visible road show after Labor Day, but groundwork being laid now could have a greater effect on the election than all the campaign rhetoric in the fall. Gov

title: Shutting Off Soviet Earphones
description: U an American President were to discover that the Soviet Union was systematically intercepting the telephone calls of millions of Americans. surely it would be good policy and good politics for him to tell the Russians sternly to remove their eavesdropping equipment and maybe even to order a few Soviet diplomats out of the country.

title: Books of The Times
description: Me Silent Bomb: A Guide to the Nuclear Energy Controversy displays on its dustlacket a photograph of mushroom cloud, along with a headline that reads: A nuclear plant accident could kill 50,000 people, damage 617 billion worth of property over a 600,000 square mile area, inflict an untold number of injuries and genetic mutationsit could happen today! The editor of the book is Peter Faulkner, a nuclear consultant with the proenvironment lobbying Friends of the Earth who in 1974 was fired from his job as a systems application engineer for the Nuclear Services Corporittion after testifying before a Senate committee about alleged widespread mismanagement in the nuclear industry. Its foreword was written by Paul R. Ehrlich, author of The Population Bomb and The End of Affluence, among other books, and the founder and president of Zero Population Growth. Its opening section is called Maximum Incredible Accident and features a blowbyblow account of a 1975 incident at the Browns Ferry nuclear plant in Alabama that is widely regarded to have been about the closest we have yet come to a meltdown

title: SENATE AGAIN BALKS AT STOPPING DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. I=The Senate today refused again to cut off debate against legislation providing public financing for Senate elections.

title: TV: For Friends ofJack Benny
description: It is a wonderful feeling to run across an old friend, one whom you haven't seen in years, and to find him looking great, just as he ,a1Vrays did. Thanks to television tape, this is the treat that CBS is giving to friends of Jack Benny, which must surely include most of the nation.

title: Artist to Get $50,000 Prize
description: The Belgian artist Pierre Alechinsky has been chosen as the first winner of the $50,000 Andrew W. Mellon prize for artists, established by the Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh.

title: Meadowlands Results
ANDERSON, CLAYTON CUTS BID ON GERBER BY $3 A SHARE, TO $37
description: In a move described by financial analysts as unprecedented and very smart, Anderson, Clayton & Company Inc. of Houston yesterday reduced the price of its proposed tender offer for shares bf Gerber Products Company to $37 from S40 a share.

title: CARTER DRAWS LINE IN TALKS ON CANAL
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 1  President Carter has warned the Panamanian Chief of Government to expect no further major concessions from the United States in the negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: Rainstorms Disrupt Utilities and Traffic
description: Thunderstorms with heavy rain squalls and salvos of lightning danced over the New York metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, slowing homebound traffic and knocking out electric power briefly in nearly 17,000 homes and businesses in parts of the city and suburbs.

title: Pro Transactions
Glory (?)
description: PIUSFIELD, Mass.A woman from a new women's magazine that is not feminist, but, instead, serious called me the other day. Like the long col tunn of journalists who have interviewed me since December when was named one of the first women Rhodes Scholars, she wanted to know two things: how it felt to be in the first group of women to be able to be chosen Rhodes Scholars, and if in the competition for the scholarship I felt I was discriminated against because am a woman. My answers to these questions, whatever they were, were inadequate. Finally, I have a response.

title: Youngblood's Single in 12th Is Winner
description: Dust off that word, amazin'. The Mets are starting to look like that unlikely bunch who surprised the baseball world in 1969 by capturing a World Series.

title: Immigrants From India Find Problems in America
description: Many of the thousands of immigrants from India who have settled in the United States in the last decade are discovering that their new lives are not nearly so problemfree as they had expected.

title: Leasing in Bayonne Approved
description: Congress has approved the commercial leasing of 42 acres of land and facilities at the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, Representative Joseph A. LeFante, Democrat of Bayonne in the 14th Congressional District, announced yesterday.

title: Major League Scores
Cautious Vance Begins Talks With a Confident Sadat
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 1Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and President Anwar elSadat opened discussions tonight on overcoming the remaining obstacles to convening a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Egyptian leader expressing new confidence about the outcome.

title: Was Beats Dibbs in Final
description: LOUISVILLE Ky., Aug. .1 (UPI) Argentina's Guillermo Vilas won his third straight tournament, defeating Eddie Dibbs of Miami Beach tonight, 16, 60, 61, and capturing the $125,000 Louisville International.

title: Jones &
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (UPI)  All elected officers of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation and about 350 top management employees in the company's basic steel eastern division took 10 percent pay cut today because of low profits.

title: State Calls 77 Worst Year for Forest Fires Since 1963
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1A state division fire warden, Joseph R. Hughes, said today that more than 2,000 forest fires this year had destroyed more than 40,000 acres of woodlands, making it the worst year for forest fires since 1963.

title: A BLACK REPORTED KILLED IN NEW SOWETO OUTBREAK
description: JOIJANNESBURG, Aug. 1 (UPI)Police officers in the black township of Soweto killed one black youth and wounded second today in battles with protesters who stoned cars, the South African Broadcasting Corporation reported.

title: Business Records
STANLEY SOLON
description: Stanley Solon, founder and president of Meredith Galleries, 214 East 57th Street, specialists in the sale of art, fine furniture., and estates, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 180 East 79th Street, and was 75 years old. He was a trustee of the Towne Club of New York.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that there may be a new disagreement brewing on taxe3 between the Carter Administration and Arthur F. Burns, chairman of Federal Reserve. Page 41.

title: Briarcliff College Ordered Closed; Fails to Meet Conditions of Merger
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 1Briarcliff College has failed in its last desperate bid to stay alive. The state's Board of Regents approved an order Friday closing the 75yearold college for women.

title: Court Finds Boe Violated CableTelevision Pact
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 1 (UPI)A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that Roy Boe, principal owner of the New York Nets basketball team and the New York Islanders hockey team, had violated a contract that gave Long Island Cablevision exclusive cabletelevision rights to the teams games.

title: NEW YORK IS LOWEST INYOUTHEMPLOYMENT
description: New York City has the highest rate of youth unemployment among 11 major American cities, according to a new Federal report that counts everyone of working age, not just those who are looking for jobs.

title: State Inquiry to Call the Leaders Of Sex Businesses in New York
description: The managers of many midtown Manhattan sexindustry establishments and the landlords, lawyers  and architects connected with these places will be subpoenaed soon to testify before a legisladye committee investigating pornography and prostitution, state and city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Bridge  * NassauSuffolk Play Yields 2 Sets of Open Pairs Winners.
description: The NassauSuffolk Regional, held last weekend at .the ,Nassau Coliseum, Heampstead, L. I., produced two sets of open pairs winners, for the first time at a regional tournament: Joel Friedberg of New York and Saul Gross of Philadelphia, and David Berkowitz of Brooklyn and Harry Stappenbeck of Uniondale,. L. I.

title: MOSCOW PROMISES VISAS TO SAKHAROV RELATIVES
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (UPI)The stepdaughter and soninlaw of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and civil rights advocate, have received permission to emigrate with their two young children, the family said today.

title: Coercion Claimed as Georgia Trial of 5 Blacks Opens
description: DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 1A former captain with the Dawson police force said today that he was present when another officer jammed a pistol between the eyes of a black teenage murder suspect, cocked it and repeatedly ordered the nigger to confess.

title: Tennis
description: EASTERN SENIORS CHAMPIONSHIP Singles Final

title: LAUGHING GAS GIVEN PATIENTS BY ACCIDENT
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. (UPI)Emergency room patients at a Montgomery County osteopathic hospital were accidentally given laughing gas instead of oxygen for more than five months, hospital and Pennsylvania Health Department officials said today.

title: Court Stays a Fine for Rio Algom To Allow Study of Uranium Cartel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1A uranium company and its president, which was fined $10.000 a day Friday for willful civil contempt of .court, was granted stay until next Monday.

title: Joseph Durso
description: LOS ANGELES. Aug. 1Out here in the Golden West where..Toe Namath is already hogging headlines, the Oakland Raiders are kings of the football world, the Portland Trail Blazers are kings of the basketball world and the Los Angeles Dodgers seem well on their way to becoming kings of the baseball world.

title: Italy Clinches Series
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 1 (AP)Corrado Barazzutti beat Manuel Oran tes, 75, 745, 61 today and helped Italy to a 32 victory over Spain in the European Zone B final of the Davis Cup tennis tournament.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: The Unipedal Mystery
description: Why does the washing machine take two socks and give back only one? Various theories have been advanced over the years, as, for example, that the washing machine eats one of the socks. Arlberg's brilliant monograph, The Dynamics of Laundry, demolished this theory with laboratory evidence.

title: June Spending for Construction Showed Rise of 0.4% Over May
description: Construction spending rose 0.4 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of S171 billion, up from $170.4 billion in May, according to the Commerce Department.

title: Bad Company Good in Its Idiom
description: It will be intresting to see what becomes or Bad Company, the British rock quartet that played a soldout concert Sunday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Cauthen Unhurt in Spill at Spa Opener
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1Steve Cauthen refused to let a spill interrupt his celebrity's return to Saratoga today as the upstate track began its 109th meeting of thoroughbred racing before a record openingday crowd of 20,012.

title: House Begins a Week of Debate On President's Energy Program
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The House today began a week of debate on President Carters sweeping energy program amid increasing signs that the program would emerge from the chamber virtually intact.

title: Francis Gary Powers, U2 Pilot, I,. Dies in a California Copter Crash
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1Francis Gary Powers, whose U2 espionage flight over the Soviet Union touched off a crisis in SovietAmerican relations 17 years ago, was killed today in the crash of a helicopter he piloted as a reporter for a Los Angeles television station.

title: Rainstorms Disrupt Utilities and Traffic
description: Thunderstorms with heavy rain squalls and salvos of lightning danced over the Ne,v York metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, slowing homebound traffic and knocking out electric power briefly in nearly 17.000 homes and busihesses in parts of the city and suburbs.

title: NeW Tournament Scheduled
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (UPI)A new men's professional tennis tournament, wLich will offer at least $100.000 in prize money, will be staged at the Los Angeles Tennis Club Sept. 1626.

title: Atlantic City Takeover Approved
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1 (AP)The New Jersey Racing Commission approved today a plan to let the state's Sports and Exposition Authority take over the Atlantic City Racing Association's thoroughbred racing in August.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: District Attorney Carl Vergari of Westchester County diced the state's highest court for permission to appeal an Appellate Division riling that reversed the conviction of Peter J. Leonard, the 25yearold man charged with murder for setting the fire that killed 24 persons in a singles bar in June 1974. .

title: KLEIN OPPOSES LILCO . ON NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Aug. 1Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein today announced his opposition to the construction of two nuclearpower plants in the East End, asserting that the Long Island Lighting Company had not shown that the plants were necessary to serve the needs of the area.

title: Llewellyn Is Hopeful Of Taking U.S. Post
description: J. Bruce Llewellyn, who runs one of the nation's largest blackowned businesses, said yesterday that he might stilt be able to accept an offer of a high post with the Government if he was able to square ;away in a reasonable time his food stores that were ravaged by looters during the blackout.

title: ExRep. Garmatz Indicted in Gratuities Plot
description: Edward A. Garmatz, a former Representative from Maryland, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on a charge of having conspired to receive $15,000 in unlawful gratuities from two shipping companies while he was chair. man of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee in the early 1970's.

title: About New York
description: Of all the things that draw men to Manhattanthe fulfillment of ambition, the pursuit of excitement, gold and gloryyou would imagine the quest for serenity, even Nirvana, to rank low on the list of lures. Yet, this ineffable state, or the desire to teach others how to achieve it, is what has taken Fa Yun, a Buddhist monk, from Asia, to a temple, one flight up, on Division Street.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: RESULTS

title: CAR OUTPUT FOB JULY UP 24.4% FROM 1976 MONTH
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1The American auto industry built 661,278 cars last month, up 24.4 percent from 531,441 in July 1976, according to reports released today by the four major auto makers.

title: Guerrilla Unit in Lusaka Bombed
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 1 (AP)Two explosions over the weekend demolished the Lusaka headquarters of the ZiMbabwe African People's Union, a Rhodesian black nationalist group, Zambian officials reported today. The Home Affairs Minister, Aaron Milner, said there were no casualties when bombs, in quick succession, went off at 4:45 A.M. yesterday.

title: Mrs. Arness's Death Accidental
description: MALIBU, Calif., Aug. 1 (UPI)The death of Virginia Arness, former wife of James Arness, star of the television series Gunsmoke has been ruled an accidental overdose of sleeping pills. The coroner's office said yesterday that Mrs. Ainess, 56 years old, was found dead in  her beach home Friday. The Arnesses had been divorced since 1963. The couple's 24yearold. daughter, Jenny, took her own life in May 1975 with an overdose of sleeping pills.

title: Around the Nation
description: Range and timber fires were threatening villages in Alaska yesterday, but firefighters in Maine, California and Washington said they had contained most of the forest fires in their states.

title: President to Appoint Mrs. Karmel to S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  President Carter, as expected, announced today he would nominate Roberta, S. Karmel, a New York lawyer, to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 3Aides of Johnson Say He Had No Part In an Alleged Fraud
description: AUSTIN. Tex., Aug. 1 (AP)Three close associates of Lyndon B. Johnson in the 1948 United States senatorial election said today that they were certain Mr. Johnson had had no part in alleged vote fraud.

title: Seymour Rabinitzky, Chief Clerk Of Housing Court, Leader in Field
description: Seymour Rabinitzky, chief clerk of the housing court of the New York City Civil Court, died of cancer on Sunday in MemorialSloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 575 Grand Street.

title: Youths Drinking at Night in Clifftop Park Vex Police
description: ALPINE, Aug. IThe fatal plunge of a 17yearold girl after she drank wine at the edge of the Palisades here Saturday night has accentuated the increasing problems the police face with youths consuming liquor after dark in the clifftop park and its boat basins far below on the western shore of the Hudson River, officials said today.

title: Audit on Docks Finds Lockheed Didn't Overbill
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1Escalating its feud with the Federal Renegotiation Board, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation asserted today that a review of its records by outside auditors had found no evidence that the company had billed the Pentagon for millions of dollars worth of excess steel for a fleet of amphibious docks.

title: W.H.A. Officials to Meet On Applications to N.H.L.
description: A meeting of the World Hockey Association's board of trustees on Thursday in Montreal will determine which franchises will apply for membership in the National Hockey League.

title: Abuse of Carriage and Other Rental Horses Is Alleged
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals criticized New York City and drivers of horsedrawn carriages yesterday over the alleged mistreatment of horses.

title: Guider
description: GO AND TOUCH Heartening news from the Metropolitan Museum is the opening today of an exhibitionworkshop program for visually handicapped and blind persons. Designed primarily to bring the visual arts within the reach and experience of these visitors, the program, called Shape and Form: A Tactile Exploration, is free to the general public, although appointments must be made through the museum's Public Education Department, at 8795500, Ext. 306.

title: The New York Times/D. Gorton
Dividends
Police Urge Patience For .44 Killer Calls
description: The Police Department last night asked those with information about the .44caliber killer case to be patient if they cannot get through right away to the special number8440999that has been established to receive confidential information from the public.

title: The New York Times/D. Gorlon
Claim in .44 Killer Case Approved
description: The New York State Crime Victims Compensation Board yesterday approved the first of six claims for financial aid filed by the victims and survivors of Son of Sam, the .44caliberrevolver killer.

title: Aluminum Siding on Old Buildings Stirs LID is pute
description: SAG'HARBOR, have, L.I.  "I have no use for modern materials on historic buildings, said Otto Fenn, an antiques dealer in this old East End village, referring to the shiny, %new aluminum siding being put in the 1835 building of the Methodist Church here.

title: SECURITY INCREASED FOR GERMAN LEADERS
description: BONN, Aug. 1Protection for West Germans prominent in politics, the ju'diciary and quietly today following the killing Saturday reinforced of Jurgen Ponto, an influential banker, by two women and a man in Mr. Ponto's home near Frankfurt.

title: Events Today
Caroline Stoll Wins 12 Straight Games and Easily Gains in Jersey Tennis
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 1Caroline Stoll of Livingston, N. J., 6yearold hoping to earn a spot on the major women's tennis circuit next year, made an impressive debut in the S85,000 Mutual Benefit Life tournament today. She won a firstround match without losing a game at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Mayor Endorses Inquiry on Police In New Rochelle
description: Mayor Vincent R. Rippe of New Rochelle yesterday promised to support a judicial inquiry into charges that the police had failed to investigate actively a 1975 complaint by a young woman who asserted that Frederick W. Cowan, the neoNazi sniper who gunned down six people last February, had threatened to kill her.

title: 2 Dolphins on Waivers
description: MIAMI, Aug. 1 (AP)Randy Crowder and Don Reese, awaiting trial on drug charges, were placed on waivers today by the Miami Dolphins. The National Football League club had until 4 P.M. today to decide what to do with the two veteran defensive linemen, suspended May 6 pending the outcome of charges that they tried to sell one pound of cocaine to Miami undercover agents.

title: Dr. Richards Plans to Sue To Enter Open
description: Dr. Renee Richards will take legal action in an attempt to play the United States Open tennis championships later this month, it was learned yesterday.

title: Associated Press
HAMILTON COCHRAN
description: Hamilton Cochran, author, historian and an automotive marketing manager for the old Saturday Evening Post, died Wednesday in an Upland, Pa., hospital. He was 78 years old, and lived in Wallingford, Pa.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP)Israeli security agents frequently use torture to extract confessions from Arah prisoners from the West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip, a group of American lawyers who toured the Israelioccupied territories said today.

title: WOMAN VICTIM DIES AS OVER 300 OFFICERS HUNT FOR .44 GUNMAN
description: Stacy Moskowitz died in Kings County Hospital Center late yesterday, 38 hours after she and a 20yearold male companion were shot early Sunday by the socalled .44caliber revolver killer who has adopted the name Son of Sam.

title: Evicted Volunteer Adult School Seeks Roomy, RentFree Home
description: There was dancing to Haitian and Calypso music as some 300 students and graduates, along with present and former teachers, gathered for the last time in a New York University dormitory in the spacious quarters of the Volunteers School for Adults. But the mood last Saturday night was not entirely carefree.

title: REPUBLICANS ATTACK CARGO PREFERENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Accusing President Carter of making a blatant political payoff to the maritime unions, three Republican leaders today called for a full Congressional investigation of the Administration's support of cargo preference legislation currently pending on Capitol Hill.

title: People in Sports
description: That's what Bill Banks, King's local attorney in Knoxville, Tenn., told judge Harold Wimberly after King was cleared yesterday of burglary charges and received suspended sentences for possession of marijuana and resisting arrest, both misdemeanors. The judge sentenced the Nets No. 1 draft choice to 60 days and fined him 350 on each of the last two charges, but the sentences were suspended upon payment of fines and court costs.

title: Louvre Mounts Three Exhibitions That Show Its Approach to Future
description: PARISThe world's largest museum ??edto be, not so long ago, one of the most routine. Today, the Louvre has ceased being a petrified repository for past grandeur. Most of the action is concentrated, rightly enough, in the

title: Oval Office Intruder Asks Carter for Directions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Jimmy . Carter, who said last year that he would fight to avoid being isolated in his White House office, recently found a stranger opening his veranda door to ask directions to the office of a political underling. As a result, an embarrassed Secret Service said today it was reviewing security arrangements involving visitors to the White House.

title: DEATH
Old and New Combine For Blue Jays
description: In the first year of their existence the Toronto Blue Jays are manned, un derstandably, by the very young and the very old. The team with the worst record in major league baseball is made up of raw youngsters and oldtimers who have seen better days.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Four companies and two executives charged with an alleged pricefixing scheme in the resin industry denied the charges yesterday at an arraignment in Federal District Court in Louisville, Ky. The defendants were indicted by a Federal grand jury on Friday.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The penny postcard, fivecent cigar and dime novel are long since extinct and now the tencent phone call is an endangered species. The word from Miami is that, next month, pay calls there will cost a quarter. They already cost 15 cents in Washington, D.C., and for other cities the handwriting on the wall seems as obvious as that on the phonebooth door ("For a good time, call Mona . . .") Has it really been that long since people said, seriously, It's your nickel"? Still, this is not the time to plead the cause of the dime phone call, for there is something in even greater jeopardy. Let us rise to the defense of the penny.

title: No
description: MORGANTON, N.C. .I fear that my former colleagues in the United States Congress, eager to rid politics of the last remnants of Watergatetype scandals, may be close to damaging The very institution they hope to strengthen.

title: FrostPlans 5th In Nixon Series
description: A fifth David Frost interview with former President Richard M. Nixon, augmenting the four that were televised on a special network of 155 stations in May, has been put into the syndication market by Mr. Frost and ..his distributor. Syndicast Services.

title: Alfred Lunt's Condition
description: GENESEE DEPOT, Wis., Aug. 1 (AP)Actor Alfred Lunt, one of America's great stage stars, was reported as in critical condition today, following cancer surgery at a Chicago hospital.

title: Free Bus Service Is a Boon for the Elderly
description: If it were not for a program called Easy Ride, Eva Denenberg, who is 79 years old, said she would have spent yesterday in bed listening to the radio. Instead she was driven by bus to a lunch program for the elderly, and on this particular day she was escorted there by Senator Jacob K. Javits, on hand to call attention to the bus service.

title: Tennis
description: AT NORTH CONWAY, N. H.

title: Primary Roundup
description: Herman Badillo said his master plan for the final full month of. New York City's primary campaign was to erode the votes of Bella Abzug and Ed Koch.

title: s at Korean DMZ Voice Mixed Feelings About Pullout
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 1The rice paddies are parched now beside the demilitarized zone. At midafternoon the throbbing sun leaves the American soldiers weary and idly playing cards beneath dusty canvas tents.

title: D. &
description: The board of the Delaware & Hudson Railway Company moved yesterday to avert yet another bankruptcy of a Northeast railroad, replacing Carl B. Sterzing Jr. as the president of the ailing subsidiary of the Norfolk & Western Railway System, apparently in an effort to clear the way for a $2 million loan.

title: Hollywood Tackles Vietnam War
description: LOS ANGELESFour years after our troops left Vietnam, and al most 20 years after they went there, Hollywood appears at last ready to come to grips with the Vietnam War. At least six pictures are being prepared these days in which the war, or its victims and veterans, will be placed under the thicroscope of moviemakers.

title: The Limits of Loyal Dissent
description: The questions raised recently, when some 25 Carter appointees met to protest the President's views on abortion, are hardly limited to abortion. To a country much torn in recent years by dissent; and to a President who campaigned on a pledge for open government, a far broader question is exposed: how much internal dissent canAnd shouldan Administration tolerate?

title: A Lean and Hungry Zero Mostel Starting Rehearsals for Arnold Wesker Merchant
description: If Zero Mostel has any qualms about moving from the role of the indomitable Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof to that of Shylock in The Merchant, he gave no indication yesterday as the new Arnold Wesker play became the first of the season to begin rehearsals.

title: JAWORSKI REQUESTS A KOREAN DOCUMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Leon Jaworski, the new special counsel in the House ethics committee's investigation of alleged Korean influence peddling, has written to the Justice Department asking for a previously undisclosed document that reportedly lists Congressmen who received Korean donations, informed sources said.

title: Personal Health
description: THE DOCTOR'S VOICE was stern: You're 20 pounds overweight, your blood pressure is too high and so is your cholesterol level. Your weekend golf game hardly counts as exercise, and the two packs of cigarettes a dayI guess don't need to tell you about that.

title: Vegetable Garden Yields New Hopes for Alcoholics
description: ENGLEWOOD, Aug. 2The late morning sun was high and hot as the four men bent over hoes and potato forks and dug at weeds deeply rooted at the edge of their two small vegetable gardens.

title: Wildcat Strikes by Miners Spread Amid Fears of Dwindling Benefits
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 2Wildcat strikes by about 60,000 members of the United Mine Workers union have spread to three states, reflecting many miners fears that their medical and pension funds are disappearing and concern that the union leadership is floundering instead of fighting for them.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOME YUGOSLAV intellectuals, as well as foreign historians and other scholars who study Yugoslavia's tortured past and ponder its uncertain future, foresee after the passing of 85yearold Marshal Tito a hardeyed reappraisal of the heroic legends and mythology surrounding the World War II Partisan forces. In Wartime, Milovan Djilasthe senior dissident of the postwar Communist movementhas begun the reappraisal.

title: Poor Hatch Closures. Blamed in a Sinking
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (AP)A Coast Guard board of inquiry released a report today blaming ineffective hatch closures for the sinking of the ore carrier Edmund Fitzgerald, which disappeared in a Lake Superior storm Nov. 10, 1975. All 29 crewmen aboard died in the sinking.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2With nearly half the votes counted shortly after 10 P.M. Pacific time, it appeared that two propositions to change this city's election laws were heading for defeat.

title: Prisoners Say They Were Offered Parole to Spy on 5 is Murder Case
description: DAWSON, GA., Aug. 2Two black prison inmates testified in the firstdegree murder trial of the Dawson Five today that they had been offered early parole in exchange for spying on and trumping un testimony against the five.

title: U.S. Commander Says Seoul Needs Big Arms Buildup
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 2The commander of United States forces in Korea said today that the South Korean armed forces needed a major inflt4 of weapons and equipment over the next few years to match North Korean strength.

title: 4 AGENCIES PLAN SYSTEM OF SHARING INFORMATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)Four Federal agencies charged with protecting the public from manmade hazards announced today an unusual agreement to exchange information and perhaps personnel.

title: T. Louis Bacchiani, 68, Directed Mental Clinics in Suffolk County
description: Dr. T. Louis Bacchiani, a former director of outpatient clinics for the Suffolk County Mental Health Board and a psychiatrist in private practice, died Monday of cancer at the Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 29Policemen and other agents of the Government of President Park Chung Hee have begun applying intense psychological and physical pressures to imprisoned dissidents in recent days to get them to sign statements of repentance for their opposition and political crimes.

title: Books: Food First
description: DURING THE FAMINE of 1974, we are told here, the African republic of Mali increased its exports of peanuts. In Bangladesh, thousands of tons of donated rice rotted because the poor couldn't afford to buy it. The underfed countries of Latin America and Africa were plahting more and more of their best land in cash crops for export to the overfed markets of North America and Europe.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Congressional leaders, threatening to postpone a vacation set to begin on Saturday, pressed a HouseSenate conference committee today to break a deadlock on pollution standards that would permit the manufacture of 1978 model cars.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission today obtained a preliminary injunction against the Falstaff Brewing Corporation, prohibiting it from making false or misleading reports or proxy statements.

title: Former Attica. Prosecutor Angered by Official CoverUp

description: HOLMDEL, N.J.A sure sign of the pickup in homebuilding activity this year is that new people are getting into the business.

title: That Rarity, A Woman Director
description: WHEN An Almost Perfect Person opens on Broadway in the fall, it will represent Zoe Caldwell's directing debut. That in itself is a theatrical event because women directors are an even rarer species than women playwrights or producers. Coincidentally, most of the principals involved in An Almost Perfect Person are women. The star is Colleen Dewhurst (as a change of pace, she is doing a light comedy); the author, Judith A. Ross, and the coproducer, Burry Fredrik.

title: The U.N. Today
Carter Names Envoy to Two Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (Reuters)President Carter today nominated Edward Marks, a senior State Department official, as the new United. States Ambassador to GuineaBissau and also to Cape Verde. The 43yearold Mr. Marks is alternate director of the State Department's Office of Central American Affairs. His nomination is subject to Senate confirmation.

title: Two Junior Shooters Excel
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 2 (AP),Two junior skeet shooters matched world records today in, the 28gauge competition, scoring 96 of a possible 100. J. C. Martin 4th of Laredo, Tex., who won the subjunior division, and Susan Ponger of Punta Gorda, Fla., who won ;the junior ladies division, hit all but four shots in the preliminary competition.

title: 2 Die, 12 Hurt in Blast at Chemical Plant in Paterson
description: PATERSON, Aug. 2A chemical mixing vat exploded at a dye factory in the historic Old Mill section of Paterson today, killing two workers and injuring 12 others, two of them critically.

title: JUDGE BARS JOB NEED TO GET HOME RELIEF
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Buffalo yesterday enjoined New York State from enforcing a new requirement that some welfare recipients work in public jobs three days a week or lose their leaefits.

title: TEAMSTER INFORMANT DRAWING SKEPTICISM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The informant who has alleged that Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, paid the Administration of former President Richard M. Nixon $1 million for barring James R. Hoffa from union activities is a man Federal investigators have described in the past as having a spotty record for reliability.

description: CANTERBURY, N.H., Aug. 2 (AP)Sister Gladys Miriam Wall, one of four remaining members of the Canterbury Shakers religious community, died yesterday. She was 81 years old.

description: POETRETTA TERME, Italy, Aug. 2 (AP) Gen. Giuseppe Castellano, who signed the Italian armistice with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1943, died in this small Apennine mountain resort here Sunday. He was 84.

description: Jeanette Hooker Payne, the wife of Samuel B. Payne, former president of Morgan Stanley & Company, the Wall Street concern, died last Thursday in Greenfield, Mass. She was 64 years old.

title: New York Among 3 U.S. Cities Still in Running for 84 Olympics
description: The search for the American choice to be the host city for the 1984 Summer Olympics has been narrowed to New York, Los Angeles and New Orleans, and a decision will be made on Sept. 25.

description: Things are happening in this long, hot summer.

description: Outgoing

title: Thomas Rivers, 85, Who Started The World
description: Thomas E. Rivers, founder and director general of the World Leisure and Recreation Association here, died early yesterday in his home, 135 Millard Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y., after a short illness. His age was 85.

title: I .B.M. Acts to Curb Speculative Orders
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has begun telling customers of their assigned delivery positions for a new type of computer, called the 3033, that drew a flurry of speculative orders after plans to market it were announced in March.

title: Britain Blunt About Its Diplomats
description: LONDON, Aug. 2A drastic reorganization of Britain's Foreign Office and Diplomatic Service in line with the country's declining influence in the world was recommended today by the Cabinet's think tank.the Central Policy Review Staff.

title: CARTER SEEKS TO END MARIJUANA PENALTY FOR SMALL AMOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  President Carter asked Congress today to abolish all Federal criminal penalties for the possession of small amounts of marijuana.

title: Cotton Dunn Takes Lead
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug 2 (AP)Cotton ,Dunn fired an evenpar 70 today to take a twostroke lead after the second round of the $6,500 Rhode Island open golf championship at Metacomet Country Club. The former touring pro from Salem, Mass., got three birdies on the 6,553yeard course for a 36hole total of 139. Two stroked back were Mike Caporale of Springfield, Mass., and Charlie Volpone of Concord, Mass.

title: Hilmer Lodge, 63, Track Coach And Founder of Coast Relays
description: PALA, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP)  Hilmer Lodge, an influential figure in United States track and field for the last three decades, died today at his home, a family spokesman said. He was 63 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Senate killed today a proposal for public financing of Senate election campaigns, handing President Carter another major setback of his package of electionlaw changes.

title: The Flea Market: A Weekend Hobby For Fun and Profit
description: AT 6 o'clock on Sunday morning. Bennett and Geraldine Hirsch pulled out of their Yorktown Heights driveway on their way to Pearl River, N. Y. Their car was loaded with bubble gum machines, copper planters, turnofthecentury pocket watches, and a number of other oddly diverse items for sale. Pearl River is the site of. one of the two flea markets they traveled to this month. Like an increasing number of other professionals and highlevel executives, Dr. Hirsch, who practices dentistry in Westchester, has become a weekend antiques dealer.

title: Anonymous Friend's Ad Seeks to Aid Robbed Jeweler
description: NORTHPORT, LI., Aug. 2An anonymous donor has taken an advertisement in a local shopper newspaper asking that people do their Christmas shopping nowby buying gifts from a jewelry store that suffered a $200,000 loss in a holdup last month.

Market Place

The Crane Company did it two years ago.

title: CHARLES ALBERT GRACE, 69, RETIRED BANK OFFICER
description: Charles Albert Grace, who retired in 1973 as a senior vice president of the National Bank of North America, 44 Wall Street, died Monday night at his home, 17240 82d Avenue, Jamaica Estates, Queens. He was 69.

description: ENGLEWOOD, Aug. 2The rupture b?. a third major water main in five dayr forced the Hackensack Water Company today to urge all its customers in 60 con, munities in North Jersey to begin geneir al and drastic water conservation.

title: Financier Arraigned in California On Investment Fraud Charge
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (UPI)Barry Marlin, a financier, was arraigned here yesterday on 24 counts of fraud stemming from an alleged scheme to bilk hundreds of United Airlines pilots out of $12 million through a series of financial investments.

title: Cellar Suggestions at Under $3 a Bottle
description: BY HIS OWN admission, Mr. Edwards is a pessimist. But jug zinfandel? Has it came to that? He's right, of course. Prices are going up again. But that's no reason to go thirsty. Here are a few suggestions for himand for anyone else who'd like to stock a few things away, not for aging or as a hedge against inflation. but lust to have around.

title: WIDOW, 28 IS ACCUSED OF MURDERING DOCTOR
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 2The 28yearold wife of a prominent White Plains physician who reported him a suicide in their Mount Pleasant condominium last September was indicted today, accused of murdering him.

title: Public Found Against Welfare Idea But in Favor of What Programs Do
description: When President Carter unveils his plan to revise the national welfare system, he will do so against the backdrop of an American public that is deeply antagonistic to the concept of public welfare yet strongly supports what welfare programs do.

title: Bringing the Best to the Most
description: The search for a new head of the National Endowment for the Humanities, which covered seven months and scores of candidates, has ended with the President's selection of Joseph Duffey. Unlike most of those who were considered, Mr. Duffey, a former chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, boasts no. impressive scholarly credentials; he owes his new post not to his modest career in Academe but to his efforts in behalf of Jimmy Carter during the 1976 campaign.

title: The Death of a Pilot
description: We first heard the name Francis Gary Powers in United States Government lie. On a day in May 1960, he was identified as the civilian pilot of an unarmed, spaceagency weather plane that lost its way while photographing clouds over Turkey and allegedly strayed over Soviet terrain. When the Russians revealed that they'd shot him down, a wave of innocent indignation swept our land. How could we ever get along with these barbarians who shoot first and complain later?

title: Mr. Carter's Balance Sheet
description: WASHINGTONHere it is August, over six months since Jimmy Carter strolled into the White House, and he hasn't even solved the problems of inflation and unemployment, or tamed the Russians or brought peace to the Middle East.

title: PORT AUTHORITY SAYS TRIPS COST $724,200
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has put the estimated total cost of more than six years of expensepaid international travel by officials and staff members and their wives at $724,200 a figure termed amazingly low by the New York State Assemblyman investigating the trips.

Wallace .circulated in the offices of newspapers, wire services and radio and television stations. A spokesman for Mr. Wallace said there's nothing to the papers. which maintain that with Mr. Wallace and his wife, Cornelia, there exists such a complete incompatibility of temperament that the parties can no longer live together.

description: BATON ROUGB, La Aug. 2 (UPI)Linda Nell Lawrence a 30yearold police officer, was shot to death yesterday with her won while struggling with a man who allegedly wee stabbing her partner. She was the first female police. officer killed on ditty, in Baton Rouge. Her male partner, stabbed in the hick and shouldder, killed her alleged assailant. The dead man was identified as John James Mullery. 42 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission filed suit today seeking enforcement of 28 subpoenas for documents from the tobacco industry. The documents are wanted in the agency's investigation into cigarette advertising and other promotional practices.

Mr. Foster's band, which he calls the Loud Minority, comes to the Vanguard after a long run of Monday nights at Ali's Alley, an opportuni ty for steady work that, shows in its Performance at the Vanguard.

Reduced profits of the ntercity passenger bus operations have also lowered earnings since the June Quarter of 1976, the company said.

When Mrs. Shirley Ritter hangs her sign in the window of her house at 222 Academy Street in downtown Trenton, the neighbors come running. Sometimes the people are here paying for the food before I get it ready, Mrs. Ritter said, So I say, oh Lord, I've got to take the sign out of the window quick.

Before curtain time at Same Time, Next Year at the Atkinson Theater on West 47th Street you can attend a theaterlobby party, inspect display of dogs being offered for adoption, enjoy free refreshments and meet the show's two stars.

title: Deaths at Pennsylvania Hospital Laid to Mixup in Labeling Gases
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 2The apparent switching of labels on oxygen and nitrous oxide outlets in a hospital emergency room was responsible for several deaths, the administrator of the hospital said today.

Something also whispered damp, decay, the beginning of the end, but the housebolder's dread of suburban blight faded away before the enthusiast's wild surmisewas this, at last, the great good place?

title: Acquisition of the Hempstead Bank By United Bank Approved by State
description: The New York State Banking Department approved yesterday the acquisition of the Hempstead Bank by the United Bank Corporation of Albany. Approval by Federal regulatory authorities is needed to complete the takeover.

title: Woman Is Held, Another Charged In Killing of West German Banker

title: U.S. Won't Recognize Boundary
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)The United States said today it did not ecognize the right of any nation to curtail freedom of navigation and overflight more than 12 miles off its shores.

title: THE REV. JAMES H. DOLAN
description: WESTON, Mass., Aug. 2 (AP)The Rev. James H. Dolan, president and rector of Boston College from 1925 to 1932, died yesterday at Campion Center. He was 92 years old.

title: ExChief of Staff Rehabilitated In Peking After 10Year Absence
description: PEKING, Aug. 2 (Reuters)Huang Kecheng, a former army chief of staff, has been quietly rehabilitated after more than 10 years in political disgrace.

title: House Votes to Bar Abortion Aid For Victims of Rape and. Incest
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The House voted tonight to bar Federal Medicaid funds for abortion except when a mother's life is endangered, rejecting appeals to add further exceptions for rape, incest or potentially crippling medical conditions.

title: Russian Trawler Rescues 1 of 2 In SmallPlane Crash in Atlantic
description: CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP)A Russian trawler rescued one of two persons aboard a small engine plane that plunged into the Atlantic Ocean about 90 miles southeast of here today, Coast Guard officials said.

title: The Matchmakers
description: It is an odd world when a ruler's decision to allow handful of young women to leave their country in search of husbands should require a highlevel diplomatic initiative, and that the circumstanceshould merit commendation. The women in question are members of Syria's tiny surviving Jewish community. They cannot find husbands at home because eligible Jewish men hope escape to Israel and dare not encumber themselves with family responsibilities.

title: Music: NRBQ Plays Kinetic Rock
description: NRBQ, which stands for New Rhythm and Blues Quartet, has been around since the late 1960's, when its performances were a pleasant anomaly on the psychedelicized New York concert. scene. Now the group is based upstate, has undergone a number of personnel shifts and is without a major recording contract. But that didn't stop it from headlining at the Bottom Line Monday night and last night, and it didn't prevent an rnthmiastic cult following from nearly filling the place and from cheerins the hand on Celiriousiy.

title: Woman Loses Pittsburgh U. Suit
description: PITTSBURGH. Aug. 2A Federal Distrie judge ruled today against s woman biochemist at the University of Pittsburgh who contended that she had been denied university tenure because of her sex.

Kingman is working without a contract, and the Padres have chosen to keep the powerhitting player in the dark concerning his future. with the club.
