It just sat there, all 100 min tons of it, too large to list, behind a rock dike at Pier J, full of hotel rooms, shops, restaurants, nightclubs, bars and a museum in which JacquesYves Cousteau was trying one more time to make the sea cute.

Goldin, charges that New York City's emergency repair program for rundown housing is riddled with mismanagement and ineptness by city agencies and with excessive charges And poor work by contractors, causing a loss of half the $7.5 million spent on the program last year.

And he made an arrangement with the company to pay royalties on the sale of the 4,900 shirts it had produced to Georgette Magritte, the artist's widow.

The strike had left more than 2,000 unburied bodies in Chicago area storage facilities. Spokesmen for burial vault manufacturers and the funeral industry have estimated that it will take at least two weeks to bury the dead.

President Carter has already substantially settled amnesty with his pardon for evaders: one A down.

description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)An estate of $81.3 million was left by Philip K. Wrigley, the chewing gum executive and Chicago Cubs owner, at his death last April 12, a court inventory showed today. The inventory was the, first detailed listing of items in the estate, previously estimated at being worth between $60 million and $100 million. It contained $81 million in personal property and $300,000 in real estate.

title: 12 Reporters Cleared in Protest
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 3 (AP)A dozen reporters arrested in an antinuclear demonstration at the Seabrook nuclear power plant construction site last May have been cleared of criminal tresspassing charges. Judge William O'Neil of District Court here dismissed the charges yesterday, saying it was evident that the reporters were on the site as members of the news media, and not as demonstrators. The reporters were among 1,414 persons arrested during a weekend occupation of the Seabrook site.

title: Powers Burial in Arlington
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (UPI)Francis Gary Powers, the U2 spy plane pilot who was killed Monday in the crash of his trafficreporting helicopter, will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery. A spokesman for telvision station KNBC, for which Mr. Powers flew traffic and aerial news missions, said the Secretaiy of the Army had asked th, Powers family that the pilot be honored by burial in a site reserved for those who lost their lives in the service of the United States.

description: The high point in the backgammon year was the recently completed Philip Morris International European Backgammon Championship at Monte Carlo. It drew the strongest competitors from all over the world, including former French tennis star JeanNol Grinda. Known as France's leading backgammon player, he proved his ability once again. title: Governor of Puerto Rico Assails Terrorist Group As Fanatics and Maniacs
description: Denouncing yesterday's terrorist bombings as the word of fanatics and maniacs who are betraying the people of Puerto Rico, the Commonwealth's Governor, Carlos Romero Barcelo, urged the American people not to be taken in by these enemies of Puerto Rico.

title: Film: 'Herbie' in Neutral
description: HERBIE, the 1963 Volkswagen Beetle with a mindand heartof his own and the power to cloud juvenile minds, is back again.This time, the little car that became a box-office star in "The Love Bug" in 1969 and demonstrated continuing popularity in "Herbie Rides Again" (1974) is off to the races in Europe. The latest vehicle for the vehicle is "Herbie Goes to Monte Carlo," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.Herbie, already the under-Beetle in a race from Paris to Monaco against more dazzling looking cars and more dashing crews than folksy Dean Jones and pop-eyed Don Knotts, faces a couple of additional complications: a $6 million diamond dropped in his gas tank by jewel thieves led by a crooked police inspector; and falling in love with a powder blue Lancia that is one of his rivals in the race.Does Herbie win? Does Herbie help foil the jewel thieves? Does true love triumph?Countless people will probably pay to find out the answers despite special effects in which the actors appear repeatedly in black outline and occasionally distorted perspective; and an assortment of tricks (rearing up on hind wheels, blushing and blinking his lights) that possesses a somewhat limited power to captivate.Reluctant adults marched off to "Herbie" by tiny press gangs may take what consolation they can from the scenery, featuring France and Monaco.

title: Philharmonic Fills Meadow
description: THE SHEEP MEADOW in Ceritral Park is more than a half mile long and covers 16 acres. To see it filled with people, up to 150,000 by some estimates, seated on the ground and quietly listening to a symphonic concert is at once breathtaking and satisfying. Thic hanpened at the New York Philharmonic's opening program of its summer series in the parksTuesday night. As Martin E. Segal, chairman of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, put it, Outsiders should see how beautifully civil large American crowds can be.

title: CocaCola's SecondQuarter Net Climbed 12.9% to $95.9 Million
description: The CocaCola Company, the world's largest maker of soft drinks, reported a secondquarter net profit of $95.9 million, or 79 cents a share, up 12.9 percent from $85.5 million, or 70 cents a share, a year ago. This lifted the halfyear net by 11.9 percent to $161.6 million, or $1.32 a share, from $144.5 million, or $1.18 a share, for the first six months of 1976.

title: Associated Press
description: HOUSTON SHIP FIRE: Smoke billowing from portholes of the Philippine Corregidor Tuesday as Houston firemen. fought blaze. Fire was contained to the living quarters and bridge of the ship. One person was reported injured.

title: Market Place
description: Investors who are wondering whether the California savings and loan stocks can be cheap after 12month gains of more than 50 percent and the highest prices for the group since February 1973 will get an affirmative answer from some bullish Wall Street houses.

title: Books: A Lose
description: NOT JUST another addition to the iconography of New York, The Way It Was unfolds New York as it appeared to tne wood engravers for the popular press of the late 19th century. This was the heyday of wood engraving, with its characteristic sharp, crisp quality. Metal halftones, which were in general use by 1890, ended an era, in which artists of such stature as Homer, de Thulstrup, Frenzeny. Sloan, Gibson, Graham and Henri executed striking, realistic woodcuts for Leslie's, Harper's Weekly and, the newspapers.

title: Giants Still Lack Top Passer
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3The Giants still do not have a No. 1 quarterback.

title: 40Th2y Period of Mourning Is Started for Archbishop Makarios
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 3 (AP)Greek Cypriots began 40 days of mourning for the President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios, who died early today. Turkish Cypriots immediately stepped up their demands for autonomy.

title: C.I.A. DIRECTOR GIVEN WIDE BUDGET POWER IN CARTER PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  President Carter has decided to give Adm. Stansfield Turner more authority than any other Director of Central Intelligence in history by granting him explicit control over,the entire natiohal intelligence budget, including funding of the Defense Department's National Security Agency and the National Reconnaissance Office.

title: Toyota. Says Port Authority Trips Didn't Produce Port Newark Plan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3  The decision by Japan's Toyota Motor Company to lease a 30acre site at Port Newark, a decision cited by officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as proof of the value of their expensive lobbying trips overseas, had nothing to do with the recent visits here by authority executives, Toyota officials said today.

title: President, Signs StripMining Bill, But Cites Defects
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  President Carter climaxed a 10year struggle over the strip mining of coal by signing into law today the first uniform Federal controls on strip mining, until now a prerogative of coalstate governments often dominated by mining interests.

title: Calendar of Events
description: The Reformed Church, 92 Huguenot Street, New Paltz, N.Y. Heritage Day will be celebrated in New Pelts on Saturday, rain or shine from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: 44Caliber Killer's 6th Death Victim Buried in Rain In Jersey Cemetery by a Grieving Moskowitz Family
description: Stacy Moskowitz was buried yesterday in the muddy ground of a Jewish cemetery in New Jersey following wracking earlymorning funeral in a Flatbush Avenue chapel in Brooklyn.

title: Notes on People
description: The former President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico, who presented his credentials as Ambassador to Spain only two weeks ago, resigned suddenly yesterday for health reasons  His appointment to Madrid led to the resignation of Carlos Fuentes as Mexican Ambassador to France. Mr. Fuentes said he was protesting the repression of student riots in Mexico City in 1968. when Mr. Diaz Ordaz was president. In Madrid yesterday, a Mexican Embassy official said the Ambassador was leaving his post strictly due to eye trouble.

title: ABC Sees No End Soon to Long Strike
description: ABC's drive to improve its competitive position in television mews is cited by network officials as the underlying reason for its inability to reach an agreement with the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians on a new fouryear labor contract.

title: Cyprus After Makarios
description: The death of Michael Christodouros Mouskoswho took the name Makarios (Blessed) when he became a monkmay open doors to a settlement of the Cyprus problem. The tragedy of Archbishop Makarios was that he never became more than the head of a Greekbased church and the leader of the halfmillion Greeks on Cyprus, even while he headed a government ostensibly representing the island's 100,000 Turks as well. Many leaders of newly independent states (Cyprus won independence from Britain in 1960) have never transcended their own ethnic communities, and have simply repressed minorities. But in Cyprus, the Turkish minority had at their backs a powerful mother country only 40 miles away.

title: U.S. BLACKOUT REPORT IS CRITICAL OF CON ED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Federal Power Commission says that Consolidated Edison was not only illprepared for the emergency that led to the New. York blackout on July 1314, but also feed to act promptly when there was still time, to avoid a complete power failure.

title: Soviet Concessions To West Reported At Belgrade Talks
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3The Soviet Union offered concessions today at the preliminary phase of the Belgrade conference on EastWest cooperation, which has been deadlocked for weeks. The concessions are expected to clear the way for the main meeting to begin here Sent. 27.

title: Johnson Memo Denies Charges Of Vote Fraud
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 3In the draft of a Statement never before released, Lyndon 13. Johnson denied attending a meeting at which a Texas political leader allegedly proposed altering vote totals to insure Mr. Johnson's victory in the 1948 runoff or the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate. The text was among papers made public today at the Johnson Library here.

title: Sussex Is Split Over Its Future as a Resort
description: MCAFEE, Aug. 3Susscx County. a bucolic area of 526 square miles in the northwtst corner of New Strsey, is in the midst of a conflict between busintss inaerests who would like to see it become a yearround resort area and residents who weant it to stay as it is.

title: F .B.I. Files Disclose 50s Tie to A.C.L.U.
description: For about seven years in the 1950's a number of officials of the American Civil Liberties Union gave the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a continuing basis information about the organization, its activities and some of its memberk, according to materials obtained from the bureau's files.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart, Mostly Successful
description: IN AN IDEAL world, there would be no chamber music played except in modestly proportioned spaces that could be reasonably identified as chambers, and by musicians of old and close acquaintance. Dream away, idealists. Avery Fisher Hall stretches the notion of the chamber rather far, even though its sound nowadays does make music far more immediate and pleasant than in the past, before last year's acoustical remodeling. And the nature of a concentrated series such as the Mostly Mozart Festival virtually insures that some performers will be acquaintances rather than intimates.

title: Growth in Economy And Dip in Jobless Forecast for U. S.
description: PARIS, Aug. 3 (UPI)The United States economy will continue to grow during the next 12 months and unemployment will drop, but inflation could be a problem, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Israelis Embrace Sadat Proposal But Doubt Syrians Will Accept It
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3Prime Minister Menahem Begin toaay endorsed the proposal by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Secretary Cyrus R. Vance that Arab and Israeli foreign ministers meet in the United States next month.

title: Greek Cypriots Lose Leader at a Time of High Economic Hopes and Low Political Ones
description: ATHENS, Aug. 3Archbishop Makarios died at a moment when economic prospects were very bright, and political prospects very gloomy, for the Greek Cypriot community he led for 27 years.

title: Ecologist Cites Optimistic U.S. Study of Solar Power
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3The Federal Government has found that electricity can be produced by solar power on a competitive basis with other forms of generating electricity in less than a decade, Barry Commoner, the ecologist, said here today.

title: Associated Press Manuel Orantes of Spain returning ball to John Bartlett of Australia, in the first round of Volvo international tennis tournament at North Conway, N.H. Orantes won the match, 61, 61.
Diffusion of Economic Power
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The diffusion of economic power has become one of the characteristics of the Carter Administration befitting the style of a President who listens to everything and everybody and then often unpredictably makes up his own mind at the last minute. Presider Gerald R. Ford used Secretary William E. Simon as the chief economic spokesman. Though on some foreign economic policy issues Mr. Simon clashed with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, the Treasury Secretary retained the authority of first among equals on virtually all domestic issues.

title: Planners Study Pay TV Proposal For Parts of Queens and Bronx
description: An application to provide pay television onlywithout full cable serviceto parts of Queens and most of the Bronx occupied the bulk of a crowded calendar before the City Planning Commission yesterday.

title: Foreign Yachts Begin America's Cup Challenge
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3America's Cup yachting resumes tomorrow with the foreign yachts battling each other and the elements on Rhode Island Sound. The four foreign entrants will begin a month of racing to determine which is best qualified to try to wrest the 126yearold Cup from the Americans in September.

title: Carter Set to Give Welfare Plan To Congress Despite Delay Pleas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  President Carter said today that he would send Congress on Friday his plan for revising the nation's welfare system despite the recommendation of two Congressional committee chairmen that he postpone its submission.

title: DEREGULATION ISSUE IS DEFEATED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 3In one of the most critical legislative battles of the year, the House of Representatives turned back today, 227 to 199. a determined effort to deregulate the price of newly produced natural gas.

title: 9 Workers Sue for $18 Million
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (UPI)Nine former employees of Robbie Brooks Inc.. have filed an $18 million Federal court suit charging that the company practiced racial discrimination against them. The suit charges that the company refused to transfer them from the old Kelley Avenue center, which was closed in 1976, to a new warehouse distribution center in Solon because they were black. They asked $1 million apiece from the company and from Local 29 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which, they said, failed, to, help them.

title: Plane Wreck Eludes Navy Men
description: AGANA, Guam, Aug. 3 (Reuters)United States Navy rescuers, hampered by rough seas and submerged World War II wreckage, have failed to locate a plane packed with secret equipment that crashed near Wake Island in June, a Navy spokesman said here today. He said the Navy EC130, which carried equipment to send messages to nuclear submarines, was believed to be under 1,800 feet of water.

title: Chief Xerox Officer Quits to Take Top International Harvester Post
description: Archie R. McCardell, the 50yearold president and chief operating officer of the Xerox Corporation, yesterday was named to the same post at the International Harvester Company.

title: World Team Tennis
Kidnapped Italian Is Freed
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 3 (Reuters)Kidnappers today released a 59yearold industrialist, Giuseppe Scalad, who was abducted near here almost three months ago, the police said. Mr. Scalari, who runs a pharmaceutical business, was seized by four masked gunmen on May 16. He was released on the outskirts of Milan after his family paid a ransom, the police said.

title: Brzezinski Assures Bonn on U.S. Strategy in a Ward
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3In a hypothet ical Soviet surprise attack, the UnitedStates is contemplating a strategic plan that calls for strikes against Soviet assets outside Europe to force Moscow to surrender any territorial gains in West Germany, a senior White House official said today.

title: Union Leader Says Steel Strike Should Be Settled at Local Level
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Lloyd McBride, the new president of theUni ted Steelworkers of America, said today that the steelworkers strike in seven states should properly be settled at the local level.

title: Most Stay Calm As Evacuations Halt Workday
description: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers, obliged to leave their offices abruptly yesterday morning, did so with dispatch, calm and even touches of good humor.

title: U.S. Auto Sales Show Increases; Imports Still Up
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3Domestic automobile sales during the final 10day period of July rose 6 percent above sales for the same period a year ago, the major automobile producers reported here today.

title: Advertising.
description: A MiIgram supermarket in a small shopping complex in a middleclass neighborhood of Kansas City, Mo., is well on its way to becoming a historic site in the annals of marketing research.

title: Three Labor and Business Laws Signed by Carey
description: ALBANY, Aug. 3Governor Carey today signed into law three measures intended to improve conditions for labor and business in New York State, pro, claiming the legislation one of the highlights of the 1977 Legislature.

title: Lazard's Robert Price On Lane Bryant Board
description: In a move described as laying the ground for faster growth, Lane Bryant Inc., a national chain of women's clothing stores, yesterday elected an investment banker, Robert Price of Lazard Freres & Company to its board of directors.

title: Computer Linked to Alleged Korean Thefts
description: An organized ring of South Koreans, with American help, systematically exploited a United States computer to steal up to $17 million a year in American food, uniforms, vehicle patis, gasoline and other goods from Army installations in Korea during the early 1970's, according to a retired Army lieutenant colonel who served there as a nrovos! marshal.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 3 (UPI)Somaha's radio station said today that Somali guerrillas had launched an offensive against Ethiopia's last line of defense in the Ogaden region, attacking the military headquarters and major airstrip at Diredawa.

title: U.S.Korean Textiles Talks Falter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)The United StateS and South Korea have so far failed to reach a new textiles agreement and a further round of negotiations is expected in Washington or Seoul at the end of this month, United States Administration sources said today. The two sides end a current round of discussions here tomorrow. The sources described the sessions as very friendly and stressed that both sides want a new agreement to replace the current threeyear accord, which expires on Sept. 30.

title: Broadway Limited 5 Hours Late
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)The Broadway Limited from New York to Chicago was at least five hours late today because of equipment breakdowns in Pennsylvania, an Amtrak spokesman said. He said the train was delayed 61 minutes inAltoona when the locomotive stalled. It:was replaced by a Conrail freight locomotive that became inoperable for 90 minutes when it blew a blower fan at Paoli.

description: Tinton, Aug. 3The rate increases granted, earlier this week to automobile insurance compan'es covering 1.6 million driyers, the first in almbst a year, may sooniba followed by others.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)  The Army ordered an audit of recruiting records across the country today as result of a scheme in a New York recruiting office to inflate enlistment totals with Phantom recruits.

title: Carter Will Ask Tanzania Leader, Here for Talks for Help on Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  President Carter will make a major effort tomorrow and Friday to obtain the cooperation of President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania for United States and allied proposals to advance peaceful solutions for Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa, Administration officials said today.

title: Soviet Lofts Rats in Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (AP)The Soviet Union has launched a satellite tarrying rats that will be put through various biological experiments as part of a joint program with the United States, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. Tass said the test animals, as well as various other biological objects, were put into orbit today aboard the satellite Cosmos 936. The announcement said the rats, offspring of animals orbited i nan earlier experiment, would be studied for the effects of weightlesness on cellular processes.

description: The only fatality in yesterday's midtown bombings was sitting with his partner at the Mobil Oil Corporation's personnel office on the ground floor at 150 East 42d Street when a bomb exploded.

title: Man Is Killed and Woman Injured Sleeping on Denver Church Lawn
description: DENVER, Aug. 3 (AP)A 27yearold man was bludgeoned to death and a 19yearold woman companion was injured seriously as they slept early today on a lawn outside St. Andrew's Episcopal Church near downtown Denver, the police said.

description: VIENNA, Aug. 3 (AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may drop the dollar as the currency of the oil trade if the dollar decline becomes critical, a top Iranian official said today.

title: Newly Paved Street Being Repaved. at U.S. Expense
description: The hum of traffic gliding smoothly up and down treelined West End Avenue in the 70's has been drowned out for the last few weeks by street noisesidewalks and curbs are being torn up and replaced. Soon the street itself, repaved only last year, will be ripped out and rebuilt.

title: Bridge:
description: Many of the conventions favored by modern tournament players result in the contract being played wrong way up, with long trumps in the dummy and short trumps in the closed hand., On the diagramed deal from the last Blue Ribbon pair championship played in Pittsburgh, South found himself playing upside down, and when the hand was over did not know whether he was on his head or his heels.

title: Escaped Baboon Slain With Dart After 8Hour Chase at Newark
description: NEWANG, Aug. 3 (UPP)a habon was destroyed with a tranquilizer dart yesterday after escaping from a crate at. L Newark International Airport and running loose for eight hours.

title: WEAKENED ELECTIONS BILL IS VOTED BY SENATE, 881
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)  The Senate tonight approved Federal election law legislation stripped of most of its reform items, including a provision backed by the Carter Administration for public financing of Senate campaigns. The vote was 88 to 1, with Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, voting against the bill.

title: Alfred Lunt, a Star of Broadway For Third of Century, Dies at 84
description: Alfred Lunt, who with hig wife, Lynn Fontanne, reigned for nearly 40 years as the leading couple of the American stage, died early yesterday in a Chicago hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: ChineseJapanese Trade Off
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3 (UPI)Twoway trade between Japan and China totaled $1.5 billion in the JanuaryJune period of this year, down 10.8 percent from the corresponding period of last year, a private trade association reported today. The Association for the Promotion of International Trade put Japan's exports to China at $792 million, down 26.6 percent from the yearbefore level, and its imports from China at $708 million, up 17.6 percent.

title: Many Trends, One Singer
description: JIMMY BUFFETT, who appeared on Tuesday at the Dr. Pepper Music Festival in Central Park (the concert had been scheduled for Monday, but was rained out), combines serveral divergent trends in presentday popular music in a most engaging way. He can be a jolly, rowdy, good old boy (he comes from Alabama, after all, and several of his most popular songs glorify alcohol in a manner akin to Ray Davies of the Kinks). He can write smoothly flowing country ballads. He has a lively sense of humor. And he has a sensitivity usually reserved for that awkward hybrid, the singersongwriter.

title: Striking Brazilian Students March
description: BRASILIA, Brazil, Aug. 3 (AP)More than 400 striking University of Brasilia students, prevented from protesting on campus by the presence of military police, demonstrated at the nation's Congress today. They raised their fists and sang the national anthem in a spacious lobby dividing the two chambers of the Congress. The demonstration coincided with the opening of political debate after a monthlong recess.

title: Film: Squid Pro Quo
description: BACK IN THE days before Bruce the shark and Orca the killer whale, people who were foolhardy enough to venture near salt water in adventure moviesespecially those set in the South Seaswere likely to find themselves in the toils of a giant octopus.Well, it's back to those thrilling days of yesteryear in "Tentacles," the all-too-familiar giant octopus movie that opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.This one isn't set in the South Seas. Influenced by "Jaws," and up-to-date in its use of this summer's fad mammal, the killer whale, "Tentacles" is set on the California coast, where underwater radio waves of illegal frequency, authorized by a corrupt executive of a construction company, rile a giant octopus.Among the dozen or so victims are a baby, a boatyard worker, a very fat man and the wife of the oceanographer who ultimately solves the mystery of the deaths and settles the monster's hash with the aid of a pair of killer whales.John Huston plays the nosey reporter; Claude Akins is the local lawman who wants to keep the lid on the strange doings. Henry Fonda turns up as the industrialist initially unaware of the use of the illegal radio frequencies by his aide, Cesare Danova. Shelley Winters plays the blowsy sister of the reporter and the mother of a young boy imperiled by the monster during a children's sailboat race; and, in a generally unelectrifying cast, Bo Hopkins takes honors for torpidity with his depiction of the oceanographer.People who are immune to atrocious acting in minor roles; to occasionally poor dubbing; to a totally unoriginal story; to the sort of sloppiness that allows at least one reference to the octopus as a squid; and to a climactic sequence that looks like feeding time at the aquarium when it is at all intelligible, will cull the exceedingly minor rewards of "Tentacles" from some realistic underwater photography, a nicely manipulative opening sequence in which the baby vanishes; and the bobbing corpse gimmick that was more shocking than anything else in "Jaws."The PG (Parental Guidance Suggested) rating of "Tentacles" is probably attributed to its one scary sequence, involving a corpse, and to the high death toll.

title: BONN CABINET MEETS TO DEAL WITH TERROR
description: BONN, Aug. 3The Cabinet, in a long meeting today, discussed anarchist terrorism and reaffirmed its determination to strengthen the criminal arm of the federal police to curb the surge of violence.

title: Movies: Pryor Is Serious (and Fine)
description: RICHARD PRYOR isn't very funny in "Greased Lightning," and if you don't think that sounds like an accomplishment, well, think again. Mr. Pryor has a gift for being almost effortlessly amusing, so much so that movie audiences often burst put laughing at the mere sight of him. The first few minutes of "Greased Lightning" are a little dicey for that reason, until it becomes clear that Mr. Pryor is out to give a coolly sustained dramatic performance, even a rather subtle one. After that, it's smooth sailing all the way."Greased Lightning" is a winning biography of Wendell Scott, the first black stock-car racing champion. Mr. Scott started out driving a taxi after World War II, learned his craft by briefly running moonshine in the backwoods of Virginia. By the mid-1960's he was a veteran driver who had won his battles with those white racetrack owners and law officers who once hoped to cramp his style.The film notes this passage of time inexpensively, mostly through everchanging car models and different amounts of talcum powder in Mr. Pryor's hair. But it lavishes a great deal of energy upon tracing Mr. Scott's evolution from a secretive figure, both frightened and exhilarated by his own ambitions, to a hero a little saddened by the fact that his triumphs are mostly behind him. Mr. Pryor is especially successful in presenting Mr. Scott as a man who guards his energy and intelligence carefully, betraying very little to his enemies and saving a great deal for the moments that matter.Michael Schultz, the erratic and innovative black director responsible for both the verisimilitude of "Cooley High" and the jive of "Car Wash" is this time at his most quietly telling, as he incorporates a warm sense of Mr. Scott's family ties into a broader, slightly harsher portrait of the era in which he came to maturity. The film perceives a symbiotic relationship between black and white cultures of the day, and it presents racism almost matter-of-factly, as a by-product of cross-cultural confusion.In one scene, Mr. Scott became so furious that he calls a white man a "nigger." Beau Bridges, as a white driver who taunts Mr. Scott at their first meeting, is shown to be an all-around sorehead who uses racism as a convenient outlet for his otherwise-undirected rage. He and Mr. Scott soon become fast friends, the early trouble between them apparently forgotten. In one of the film's most crowd-pleasing episodes, they use a steak dinner and a Confederate flag to hold at bay a restaurant full of white patrons, who clearly find Mr. Bridges' character the more dangerous and unsavory of the two.Mr. Bridges has been giving all the right performances in all the wrong movies lately, but this time he comes into his own; his performance here, which recalls his brother Jeff's in another movie about a racing driver, "The Last American Hero," has a crackling vitality, especially when he banters with Mr. Pryor. Mr. Schultz has taken chances in his casting, with performers ranging from Julian Bond to Richie Havens, but everyone does.Cleavon Little is especially effective as Mr. Scott's friend and confidant. Pam Grier, as Mr. Scott's preternaturally patient wife, manages at times to make herself seem almost inconspicuous, which constitutes a triumph of willpower over natural assets even more impressive than that of her costar."Greased Lightning" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), partly because of the words that are tossed around when tempers flare, and partly because of the sweet, low-key sexual chemistry that seems to exist between Mr. Pryor and Miss Grier.

title: Screen: Charlie Brown as Before
description: RACE FOR YOUR LIFE, Charlie Brown" packs the "Peanuts" gang off to a summer camp that doesn't require counselors, because the kids come equipped with adults-sized neuroses of their own. Sally moons over Linus, Peppermint Patty rigs all the bunk elections and Charlie Brown worries about whether he has leadership qualities, especially after one of the local bullies declares that "that round-headed kid is a joke." Snoopy, ever the scene-stealer, races across the desert on a souped-up cycle, "Easy Rider"-style, in short, everyone is up to his or her perennially adorable old tricks.This is the third of the Charlie Brown features (there have also been 16 television specials, and a 17th is in progress), but the animated "Peanuts," as directed by Bill Melendez, isn't that much of a departure from Charles M. Schulz's 25-year-old comic strip. The film runs an hour and quarter and has a rambling plot about a regatta, but it seems less like a continuous story than a series of droll blackout sketches, many of them ending with the obligatory "Good Grief!"The animation is as purposefully spare as the format, often seeming even more two-dimensional than Mr. Schulz's newspaper drawings. The net effect is that of having read the comic strip for an unusually long spell, which can amount to either a delightful experience or a pleasant but slightly wearing one, depending upon the intensity of one's fascination with the basic "Peanuts" mystique.

title: Art: Stretching the Limits of Drawing
description: A BOUT the art of drawing, there is nowadays so much disagreement among artists and critics and virtually everyone else concerned with the visual artsthat one has reason at times to wonder if the, very word drawing has not outlived its usefulness. What does it mean today? The only accurate answer seems to be: everything, and nothing at all. Once the most conservative of the visual arts, the medium to which even the most diehard vanguard innovators returned in order to refresh their vision of the observable world, it is not as open and undefined as the universe of noises that are sometimes alleged to constitute musical sounds. The art of drawingas many artists now see ithas become an art without limits of any kind.

title: New Jersey. Briefs
description: The Hackensack Water Company yesterday lifted its call to 160,000 customers in Bergen and Hudson Counties for water conservation.

title: JULIAN RUIZ, ESTRANGED FROM DOLORES IBARURRI
description: BILBAO, Spain, Aug. 4 (AP)Julian Ruiz, estranged husband of. Spain's celebrated Communist leader Dolores Ibarurri, or La Pasionaria, died today at a hospital in this northern Spanish city, doctors said. He was 84 years old.

title: Topics
description: For years, St. Wapniacl was the patron saint of school children across the country. That name, they had learned, could servewith the least bit of explicationas an acronymic guide to the names of the departments in the President's Cabinet, as well as their order of creation. That is:

title: Swedes Finally Feel World Economic Pinch
description: STOCKHOLMThe worldwide economic slowdown is finally catching up with Sweden, long thought of as showcase, for European socialism.

title: MONEY SUPPLY DOWN IN WEEK OF JULY 27
description: $1.5 Billion Drop to $327.5 Billion Followed $5 Billion Advance in Prior 7 Days, Fed Says

title: SOWETO POLICE FIGHT YOUTHS FOR 4TH DAY
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 4 (AP)Violence erupted today between policemen and young blacks for the fourth straight day in Soweto township. The police hunted for youths house by house in parts, of the black community near Johannesburg.

title: PARENTS /CHILDREN
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.The long goodbye must have been easier in years past.

title: President Seeks Legalized Status For Many Aliens,
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 President Carter asked Congress today to provide Iegal status for millions of aliens whose presence in the United States violates current immigration statutes.

title: The Day Bird
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival Mobile Theater is ready for its 22performance, fiveborough tour of city parks. The season opens on the East River Park athletic field at Sixth Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The generator truck hums, providing power for the outdoor theater's light and sound. The bleachers are erected. The trailer trucks that are dressing rooms and control booth are in place. Actors and musicians are on the stage.

title: Events and Openings
136 Policemen Will Be Rehired To Aid Hunt for .44Caliber Killer
description: With 300 New York City police officers assigned to the hunt for the .44caliber killer, and 75 more on an expanded search for terrorist bombers, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that 136 laidoff police officers would be rehired today, and more later this month.

title: Plan for French Guiana Called Failure for Luring Only 30 Settlers to Colony
description: PARIS, Aug. 4 (AP)A twoyearold French Government plan to send 30,000 settlers to develop French Guiana has been termed a failure because only about 30 colonists have arrived in France's last. colony on the South American mainland.

title: Greek Cypriot Party Chiefs Meet on Isle's Future
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 4 (AP)The leaders of the four major Greek Cypriot political parties, including the acting President, Spiros Kyprianou, met today to discuss the future of this divided island in the aftermath of President Makarios's death.

title: House Rejects Efforts to Raise Tax on Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The House resoundingly defeated today two proposals to increase the Federal gasoline tax but put off a final vote on President Carter's energy package.

title: Van Muraskin Is Medalist In Met Amateui With 142
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 4Century Country Club's magnificent golf course has weathered the drought and remains a lush green on fairways and putting surfaces. For Dave Van Muraskin, it was just right today.

title: U.S. Sells Billion in Bonds at Average Rate of 7.72%
description: The Treasury yesterday sold $1 billion of longterm bonds at an average interest rate of 7.72 percent, a sale that completed its $6.25 billion August refinancing effort.

title: Market Place
description: The current market weakness that has carried leading stock averages down more than 5 percent in two and a half weeks has had almost no effect on the JohnsManville Company, the nation's largest producer of asbestos fibers.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company, the embattled beer producer, has been informed that a Federal attorney will probably seek indictments against the company, and that the Internal Revenue Service has recommended that the brewer be prosecuted for filing false tax returns from 1972 through 1975. The information was disclosed in material the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Hsinhua/Associated Press

title: U.S. Aides Meet With Spanish Reds
description: MADRID, Aug. 4Quietly ending boycott, American officials had their first formal meeting last week with a member of the Spanish Communist Party, accord ing to informants involved in the luncheon gathering.

title: House Proposal Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Senate refused again tonight to accept the wording of a House proposal banning Federal spending for abortions except to save the life of the mother for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: Elder Posts 64 and Takes Shot Lead in Hartford Golf
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 4 (AP) Lee Elder, capitalizing on a putting tip from his wife, splashed 10 threes across his card today on the way to a sevenunderpar 64 and a onestroke lead in the first round of the $210,000 Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open golf tournament. Austin, had a 75, to be tied for third spot with Nancy Lopez at 143. Sandra

title: Conrail Narrows 3Month Deficit to $27.6 Million
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the Governmentchartered successor to six bankrupt Northeastern railroads, yesterday reported a loss of $27.6 million for the second quarter. This was 19.7 percent less than the $34.4 million loss in the yearearlier quarter, which was the railroad's first quarter of operation.

title: A Rare Appearance For Harlem Dancers
description: This weekend may well be the last chance for New Yorkers to see the vibrant Dance Theater of Harlem in Manhattan for at least a year.

title: Restaurants
At G.M.'s Plant in Quebec, The Accent Is on Francais
description: STE. THERESE, Aug. 4in Quebec, being a good corporate citizen these days means using French and French speakers as much as possitionalistic rush to make Quebec as French as the rest of Canada is English, the sprawling assembly plant that the General Motors Corporation maintains in this little town about 20 miles north of Montreal is becoming more French all the time, and even the world's largest automobile manufacturer is finding there are things it cannot accomplish.

title: CONGRESS CONFEREES SET SUGAR SUPPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4House and Senate conferees agreed today on new price support program for sugar that would benefit producers but would cost consumers and big industrial users between $440 million and $660 million a year.

title: PARKING BUREAU PLANS  TO IMMOBILIZE SCOFFLAWS
description: In an effort to curb scofflaws, the Parking Violations Bureau plans to begin next week immobilizing the vehicles of motorists who repeatedly violate parking laws, according to Harry W. Voccola, the director of the bureau.

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: ROCKWELL OFFICERS SOLD SOME SHARES BEFORE BI DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Two top officials of the Rockwell International Corporation, builder of the controversial B1 bomber, sold holdings of company stock worth more than $1.2 million just 10 days before President Carter canceled the planeproduction program on June 30, it was learned from Federal records today.

title: Two Die in Boarding House Fire, Possibly Set in Wake of a Quarrel
description: MIAMI, Aug. 4 (AP)Two men burned to death early today in a boarding house fire set by an arsonist who may have been quarreling with someone who lived in the building, the police said.

title: Kidnapped Student in Guatemala Found Dead Amid Torture Signs
description: GUATEMALA, Aug. 4 (Reuters)A 22yearold student, whose kidnapping week ago sparked student demonstrations here, was found dead today with signs he had been tortured.

title: Advertising
description: The average New York thoroughbred racing fan has a middle income and is 49 years old or older, and not too much more is known about him. Yes, he tends to be male.

title: KEY HOFFA CASE WITNESS FACES RETRIAL IN JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Ralph Picardo, the New Jersey trucking company owner who has been the Government's key witness in the investigation into the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, the former teamsters union president, will get a new trial in the New Jersey murder case in which he was convicted two years ago.

title: 8,000 Pounds of Atom Materials Unadcounted For by Plants in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Federal Government said today that nuclear facilities in the United States were unable to trace more than 8,000 pounds of highly enriched uranium and plutonium as of last September but that there was no evidence that the material had been stolen.

description: StageStruck

title: Bateman Eichler Planning to Sell  Vernitron and Frigitronics Stock
description: Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., the beleaguered Los Angelesbased brokerage house with heavy positions in the Vernitron Corporation and the Frigitonics Corporation, took steps yesterday to sell some of these holdings. Stocks of the two companies have recently declined sharply in price.

description: Friday, August 3, 1977

title: The New American Patriotism
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Director of Central Intelligence used an intriguing rationale yesterday in assuring Congress that Americans need not fear future attempts by his agency to boggle their minds in secret drug experiments. These days, Adm. Stansfield Turner testified, there would be

title: Primary Roundup
description: Bringing the 1984 summer Olympics to New York City would be a joke, Representative Herman Badillo said yesterday.

title: This Concert Series Is a Landmark Event
description: Five years ago, n young concert pianist named Francis Heilbut was thinking about the problem he and other rising musicians had in finding places to play. Looking around New York City he became aware of a number of possible small auditoriums, halls and large rooms that could be used for public functions. They were in buildings that had been designated American landmarks and came under the jurisdiction of the Federal Government's Department of the Interior  the National Park Service. to be precise.

title: Dollar Gains After 2Day Decline
description: The dollar ended a twoday slide yesterday with gains against most currencies on the world money markets, The Associated Press reported. Observers were at a loss, however, to explain the rise in the dollar's value.

title: CARTER DELAYS PLAN ON WELFARE SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Carter Administration, wary of political criticism of its plan to revise the nation's welfare system, has decided to withhold public disclosure of the plan until after the House of Representatives completes action this week on the President's energy legislation.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Skies will be hazy to partly sunny over the Northeast today. Scattered showers and thunderstorms are likely from the South Atlantic Stats to eastern Texas; across the Ohio Valley, the lower and upper lake region and the middle Mississippi Valley; in the Central Plains States, central Rocikes and Montana. Isolated showers are possible in portions of the northern and central

title: Monmouth
description: RESULTS

title: Senators Still Pay Female Aides Less
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)The median salary that United States Senators pay women employees is 56 percent of the median salary paid to male employees, a wider gap than three years ago, according to a new survey.

title: Bridge:; Books Short on Pages, L?? On Price, Offer Valuable Tips
description: Those who like books of unusually high quality at unusually high prices will welcome the two most recent volumes in the Master Bridge Series, published here by Frederick Fell. They are Snares and Swindles in Bridge and Elimination Play in Bridge by Terence Reese and Roger Trezel.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 5, 1977

title: Broadway
description: Hit the Deck to Be Overhauled Before Voyage to New York

title: Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 4 (AP)Three metropolitan areas were dropped in July from the Government's list of areas with substantial unemployment rates, the Labor Department said today. They were DenverBoulder, Colo., and two in Pennsylvania, Altoona and AllentownBethlehemEaston. This reduced to 91 the number of areas on the list.

title: It Doesn't Pay to Work Harder
description: STOCKHOLMThe lack of incentive to earn more under Sweden's high tax rates and generous socialsecurity arrangements is vividly illustrated by new study prepared by the Central Statistical Office at the request of the Employers Association. It shows that family with two or more children and with one working parent can only marginally improve its standard of living no matter how much family income is increased.

title: Minister Admits Stealing Books; Gets a Sentence of 2 to 5 Years
description: GILMER, Tex., Aug. 4 (AP)A Baptist minister charged with stealing rare books and documents from 100 libraries, museums and book stores in Texas and Oklahoma pleaded guilty to a theft charge today.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Records Show C.I.A. Tested LSD on Sex Psychopaths
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Some 142 sexual psychopaths at the Iona State Hospital in Michigan were given LSD and a marijuana derivative to see whether the substances would unlock their most secret thoughts in an experiment sponsored by the Central Intelligence Agency, according to documents reviewed today..

title: Art: Friends at Whitney Show 20thCenturyWorks
description: The painter Ad Reinhardt summed up one point of view in this matter when he said of the Whitney Annual of 1950. Have you ever seen a crosssection show that made any sense? Everything is treated as if it were the same thing. Is it all the same thing? Hey!

title: Seeking New Customers for Gas Incredible
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4The chairman of aspecial State Senate committee investigating supplies of natural gas said today that be found it Incredible that the state's public utilities were seeking new gas customers after last winter's fuel shortage, which shut down scores of New Jersey industries and cost 45,000 jobs and $10 million in wages.

title: France Set to Join 2Year Study To Devise New Atom Safeguards
description: PARIS, Aug. 4The French Government said today that it would take part in an attempt to work out a new international code of safeguards against the spread of nuclear weapons, first proposed by President Carter.

title: Diary of a Discerning Macy Shopper
description: An earlier article In this space told you how Jill, my best friend's daughter, got married last May and moved into a splendid loft. She has just announced that they're planning their first big bash. Would I mind lending her some, china and glassware? Jeff, her husband, is thinking of setting up bridge tables with checkered table cloths and candles in Chianti bottles  the bistro touch, you know. Heavens! That idea is as dated as Aunt Minnie's bouffant hairdo. We all entertained like that when WE were young. I will gladly lend her anything she needs, I tell her, but isn't she aware of the fabulous paper stuff that's around? It's not just practical .(no dishwashing!), but utterly chic, and perfect for contemporary rooms like theirs.

title: Publishing: For Sacco and Vanzetti
description: ON AUG. 23, Katherine Anne Porter's The NeverEnding Wrong will be published. Why that day? Because on Aug. 23, just 50 years ago, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were executed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Miss Porter was there.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: CHAIN STORE SALES UP 87% TO 21% FOR JULY
description: The country's major chain Store organization& chalked up impressive sales gains in July with increases ranging from 8.7 percent to more than 21 percent over the level of July 1976.

title: Buddy Tate, the Traveling Saxophone Man, Stops Over
description: Buddy Tate, the tenor saxophonist from Texas, whose urgent, billowing sound has been one of the more distinctive colors on the jazz palette since the time he joined Count Basie's orchestra almost 40 years aso, seems to be everywhere with everybody these days.

title: CORNELIUS E. O'CONNOR JR.
description: Cornelius Edward O'Connor Jr., founder and president of Capital Overseas Real Estate in New York City and former vice president and assistant to the president of the Diamond Match Company, died yesterday in his summer home on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Hair'In Case You Missed It
description: Nothing quite captured the essence of the youthful 1960'swith its mixture of anger and love, cynicism and hopelike the musical Hair.

title: Phils Inch to 21 Victory and Within HalfGame of Top
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, who went through the rigors of a pennant race last year, turned the screw a little tighter yesterday on the Chicago Cubs, who hadn't been contenders in recent years. The Phils did it by beating San Diego, 21, in 10 Innings.

title: An Owner of the Mots Packs It In
description: G. Herbert Walker Jr one of the original owners of the New York Mets, has quietly sold his . stock in the club and resigned as executive vice president and treasurer and a member of the board. Staying clear of any public laundering of linen, he gave health considerations as his reason for pulling out but there is no escaping the conclusion that the unpleasantness surrounding the de parture of Tom Seaver was a contributing factor. Well, said Mrs. Walker when that was suggested, he's very foRd

title: NYERERE IS CALLED HOPEFUL ON RHODESIA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Whit House said today that President Cartel and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanza nia believe a transition to majority rule in Rhodesia is possible without an esca. lation to massive bloodshed and civi war.

title: ANTIBOMB MEASURES ARE NOT FOOLPROOF
description: Many antibomb procedures have been adopted to protect office buildings in New York and other cities, but none of them are foolproof, a number of owners and managers of such buildings said yesterday.

title: Joe McDonald Has a Farm And Likes It
description: Last May 25 the Mets played their annual game against their Tidewater farm club and won easily. Afterward, some of the Met players said they were appalled at the lack of talent on the club that was supposed to feed the Mets for the future.

title: Jazz: Shaw Rides the Rhythm
description: WOODY SHAW'S sevenpiece Concert Ensemble, which the jazz trumpeter fliigelhorn player has been nursing along for three months, is already playing with the mutual responsiveness and confidence of a group that has found a clear sense of direction. The key to this unusually quick development is a brilliant rhythm section that provides a secure and buoyant foundation for the four horns in the front line.

title: Stewart Coach of Kings
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP)Ron Stewart was named coach the Los Angeles Kings today, becoming the second new coach in two days in the National Hockey League. Marcel Pronovost was appointed coach of the Buffalo Sabres yesterday.

title: Eunice Shriver Is Hospitalized
description: BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 4 (AP)Eunice Kennedy Shriver, wife of Sargent Shriver, the former VicePresidential candidate, and sister of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has entered Massachusetts General Hospital, a spokesman said today. He said that Mrs. Shriver, 54 years old, was undergoing diagnostic tests and was under observation, but other details were not available.

title: Ballet: At Columbia
description: HERE ARE sorrows as well as pleasures to be garnered from the Dance Theater of Harlem's summer community dance series at the Wollman Auditorium on the Columbia University campus. The sorrows are all too easily spelled out. These two weeks of performances  an abbreviated season necessitated by financial difficultiesthat end this weekend with. Sunday's matinee, are the only opportunity New York has had to see the Harlem company in more than a year.

title: CALIFANO THEN ACTS TO BAR AID Court in Brooklyn Rules After Determining That the Law Was Not Proved Vague
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn yesterday withdrew his order requiring Federal reimbursement for elective abortions for the poor, and Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, acted immediately to ban all Federal subsidies for abortions except when a woman's life was in daneer.

title: Puerto Rican Arrested After Tip, But No Charge in Bombings Is Filed
description: The police announced yesterday that they had arrested a 27yearold Puerto Rican in the Bronx after an anonymous caller told them the man was connected with the terrorist bombings in midtown Manhattan on Wednesday in which one person died and seven others were iniured.

title: Chinatown Rolls Out The Welcome Mat
description: Chinatown is a yearround festival, particularly for those who go there to eat. But every summer, at least the last halfdozen, Chinatown demonstrates to the world that its cultural perimeters extend far beyond the radius of a chonstick.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN AN EXTRAORDINARY poem of some years back, Richard Eberhart compared cancer cells Sinister shapes with menacing attitudes, a virulent laughing gang, Lethal, sparkling and irregular stars  to art itself, like the artist's mind,/ Powerful shaker, and the taker of new forms. Exuberant, malign, vivid, rioting, cancer and art both had something to say about The murderous design of the universe. The poet had been looking at a picture of the cells. He concluded:

title: New Face: Beauty and the Beasts
description: Barbara Carrera is beautiful in an almost unearthly way, and that is what one remembers most after seeing her in The Island of Dr. Moreau, the horror movie now playing in several theaters around town. But like many beautiful woman In Hollywood before her, Miss Carrera would rather be taken seriously as a sensitive actress.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE LIFTS ORDER REQUIRING U.S. TO PAY FOR ABORTIONS
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn yesterday withdrew his order requiring Fedreal reimbursement for elective abortions for the poor, and. Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, acted immediately to ban all Federal subsidies for abortions except when a wbman's life was in danger.

title: At the Hollis Discussion Club, There's No Subject That's Sacred
description: The most remarkable thing about the Hollis Discussion Club may not be that Herb Coddington and Russell Marks are still on speaking terms after 35 years of biweekly discourse and debate, but that the two men ever found anything to say to each other in the first place.

title: An Editorial in The New York Amsterdam News, and a Reply
description: When the lights went out the evening of July 13, bringing blackness to the entire city, suddenly many things became illuminated.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: About Real Estate
description: Over the years, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals has grown accustomed to attacks by planners for its role in the zoning process. As the body with authority to grant exceptions to zoning and building laws, it has been criticized as too lenient in giving such variances. Planning officials, especially those in the administration of former Mayor John V. Lindsay, sought to curb the board's diseretionary authority.

title: New Kind of Albany Bureaucrat
description: Robert James Morgado, who was appointed yesterday to the top staff position in the Carey administration, the secretary to the Governor, arrived there by an unlikely route.

title: Aussie Yachts Capture First 2 CuP Trial Races
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4The Swedes and the French were hammered by the Australians today as the competition began to determine which of four yachts should challenge the Americans for the Amtrica's Cup next month. The Australian yachts, called Gretel H and Australia, von two races each, while France I and Sverige both lost twice.

title: DOROTHY LYNCH
description: Dorothy Lynch, wife of Eugene M. Lynch, a pressman at The New York Times, died Tuesday in the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., after a long illness. She lived at 70 Manchester Road, East chester, N.Y., and was 65 years old. Besides her husband, she is survived by a daughter, Dorothy Jean Lynch.

title: Beame Aides Join in Parking Talks With U.S. and Environmentalists
description: For the first time since the dispute over the New York City parking ban flared earlier this year, the Beame administration has joined with Federal officials and environmentalists to seek a compromise that might avoid widespread curtailment of private automobiles in Manhattan.

title: Control C.I.A., Not Behavior
description: So we must add repugnant medical experimentation to the list of horror stories emerging from the Central Intelligence Agency. It was no secret that the agency once hunted desperately for means to control human behavior, but the pertinent records were believed destroyed. Now, thanks to persistent critics and a diligent search by one agency employee, a batch of records has been found and, in edited form, released. Other evidence has come from an investigation by reporters of The Times and testimony by the C.I.A. director, Stansfield Turner.

title: Bergen County Jail, Condemned as Unfit, Is Closed
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 4The Bergen County Jail, which was condemned by a study commission a year ago as unfit for human habitation, was permanently closed today by Sheriff Joseph F. Job.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: DAILY CRUDE IMPORTS UP TO 6.9 MILLION BARRELS
description: Crude oil imports for the week ending July 29 were up slightly, from the preceding week, to 6.9 million barrels a day from 6.4 million barrels a day, according to the latest weekly supply figures by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Political Campaign Contribution Curb Changes Influence Game
description: The $600 limit on individual campaign contributions has taken much of the fun out of reading campaign financing reports on the race for Governor. It was once a game trying to predict which architectural or construction

title: Marion C. McCarroll, ExColumnist
description: Marion Clyde McCarroll, who for 21 years wrote the nationally syndicated King Features column Advice to the Lovelorn under the name Beatrice Fairfax, died Monday in the Allendale Nursing Home, Allendale, N.J., where she had lived since 1970. She was 84 years old, and had formerly resided in Manhattan and in Ridgewood. N.J.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Federal Government said today that nuclear facilities in the United States were unable to trace more than 8,000 pounds of highly enriched uranium and plutonium as of last September but that there was no evidence that the material had been stolen.

title: Galanos Waves The Flag
description: James Galanos struck a blow for American fashion this week. With a giant creative leap, he made expensive clothes look fashionable, soft and relaxed. He introduced a strong sportswear look in his daytime clothes and pulled out all the stops for evening, using fabrics of infinite luxury.

title: Mimi Sheraton
description: Two on the West Side Of the Isle

title: New Agencies Set For Gillette Brands
description: Brands from the Gillette Personal Care Division with total advertising billings estimated at more than $7 million are being moved out of GreyNorth, Chicago, and spread among three agencies: J. Waller Thompson, Chicago, and Marschalk and Advertising to Women, both in New York.

title: Carey Signs ChildCustody Accord
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Governor Carey today announced that he had signed a measure intended to discourage a parent who loses a custody case in New York from seizing the child in an effort to gain custody elsewhere.

title: Major League Box Scores
Lawyers Explore Advertising, but Cautiously
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4  Lawyers around the country have begun slowly and cautiously testing the uncharted waters of advertising since the Supreme Court ruled in June that, for the first time in 69 years, they could publicize their services and probable fees.

title: Books: Causes and Cases
description: In Final Argument, the last chap. ter of Charles Garry's autobiography he says, From the preceeding as counts, it is evident that real justice i5 not easily obtainable in this country.

title: More Jobs for Youths Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that he had asked President Carter to increase the Federal youth employment program to allow New York City 25,000 jobs. The President is scheduled to sign the $1.5 billion Youth Employment Act tomorrow, which will include money for 15,000 to 20,000 jobs in New York State, of which more than 5,000 will be in New York City, the Senator said, Nationally, the act will provide for 200,000 jobs. Senator Javits linked the recent looting in New York City to a situation of an overwhelming number of young people with idle hands.

title: The Illegal Alien Tangle
description: WASHINGTONThe Carter Administration has finally produced a compromise plan to stem the flow of illegal aliens into the United States, but it lacks the two elements essential to an effective solution to this increasingly serious problem.

title: Cost of Office Building Evacuations Estimated at Millions in Lost Time
description: The mass evacuation of more than dozen skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan as a result of terrorist's bomb threats Will apparently cost millions of dollars in lost worker time, overtime payments, added security expenses and forfeited commissions and profits.

title: Atom Defense a Big Issue for French Leftist Alliance
description: PARIS, July 31France's nuclear defense policy has become the central issue in the current effort of Socialists and Communists to renew the electoral alliance that has led them to the brink of Dower.

title: The Bells Are Ringing on Riverside Dr.
description: Almost since the beginning of recorded time, bells have held a mystical fascination for humankind. At times the bearers of good tidings, at other times the harbingers of bad news, bells have tolled themselves firmly into the fabric of our lives.

title: Chief Detective Asks Reporters to Stop Going After Witnesses to .44 Slayings
description: Chief of Detectives John L. Keenan appealed to reporters yesterday to stop tracking down witnesses in the .44caliber killings and to let the police interview such people.

title: Article 3  No Title
Arledge Is Bullish On News
description: IN THE TWO months since he became president of ABC News and Sports, Boone Arledge has been on a hiring spree to strengthen the organization for a new assault on the ratings of the dominant news networks. CBS and NBC.

title: Notes on People
description: Break a leg is, in the theater, one performer's way of wishing good luck to another. Alas, Mary Martin almost took the advice literally in Knoxville, where she has been rehearsing the preBroadway tryout of a new comedy, Do You Turn Somersaults? The 63yearold actress was onstage when she tore some knee ligaments Tuesday, but the next day she was back at work with her costar, Anthony Quayle. The orthopedist who put her knee in a cast said Miss Martin should be recovered in about 10 days, but when the play opens in Knoxville tomorrow night she will be seen hobbling about. That's O.K., though; she appears as a patient in a sanitarium.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: LONG ISLAND reaches out into the Atlantic Ocean and forms a land mass that many liken to the claw of a lobster. But the two ends of that single clawthe North Fork and the South Forkare as different from one another as are the green country and the sandy beach.
