title: MORITZ MITZENHEIM, 85, EAST GERMAN CHURCHMAN
description: EISENACH, East Germany, Aug. 4 (Reuters)The former chairman of the East German Evangelical Church Conference, the Rev. Moritz Mitzenheim, died here today shortly before his 86th birthday, church officials said.

title: Financial Area to Get a New Park
description: New York City's financial district will have a new vestpocket park in November with Callery pear trees, big comfortable wooden benches and sculptures by Louise Nevelson.

title: Dow Advances by 2.17 to 888.17; Oil Issues Lead Broad List Higher
description: The beleaguered stock market finally showed a touch of bouyancy yesterday as oil shares and a broad list of issues moved higher.

title: Court Rules Arrests Of War Protesters In 71 Was Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that antiwar demonstrators were arrested illegally here in 1971, but that a $12 million damage award to the protesters was excessive.

title: With the Meadowlands Season Concluded, Freehold HarnessTrack EnjoysModest Gains
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 4Only three days after a greatly successful meeting ended at the upstate Meadowlands, business at this historic downstate harnesshorse center is showing an increase.

title: Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Puerto Rican Arrested After Tip, But No Charge in Bombings Is Filed
description: The police announced yesterday that they had arrested a 27yearold Puerto Rican in the Bronx after an anonymous caller told them the man was connected with the terrorist bombings in midtown Manhattan on Wednesday in which one person died and seven others were injured.

title: Inventor Suing Presley Companies For Statements on Energy Process
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4  Sam Leslie Leach, a Los Angeles inventor who has patented what he asserts is a method to derive inexpensive energy from ordinary water, filed suit today against the Presley Companies, a Newport Beach, Calif. homebuilder that owns certain rights to the process.

title: NINE PENALIZED BY S.E.C. IN AMEX OPTIONS CASE
description: Nine individuals from four American Stock Exchange member firms have been named by the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with optionstrading charges dating back more than a year. Suspensions have been ordered for seven of the individuals and the other two have been censured.

title: Pole Spot to Parsons; Miss Guthrie Sets Mark
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 4 (AP)Benny Parsons won the pole position today for Sunday's $200,000 Talladega 500 Grand National stock car race. Driving a Chevrolet, he recorded a time of 192.684 miles an hour.

title: Deaths
description: BIDERMANHenry, Age 79. of 8818 West McNab Road, Tamarac, Fla., passed away August 4 at the Florida Medical Center. He came here 2 yrs. CIO from Brooklyn. He is survived by his wife Frieda, 2 sisters, Mrs. Sadie Topper of Palm Springs, Calif and Mrs. Goldie Heiberg of West Palm Beach, Fla. Private services will be hold Sunday. For further information contact the Mason Funeral Home, Tamarac, Fla.

title: Canadian Economic Growth in 1978 To Accelerate After Failing in 77
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Canadian economy will fail to attain Its potential growth in 1977, but all provinces will enjoy an accelerated pace of economic growth next year, the Conference Board in Canada said today.

title: Beame Says That 75% of Stores Looted in Blackout Have Reopened
description: Almost 75 percent of the estimated 2,000 stores that were looted or vandalized during the recent blackout have reopened for business, many at the same soot, Mayor Beame reported yesterday.

title: Looking at Nature Enriched by Design
description: Louise Lasser, Henry James and Philip Johnson all agree on at least one thing: Central Park is among New York City's prime natural resources. The park, covering 5 percent of Manhattan's surface, offers a trip to the country, to the great outdoors, that is just across the street. Breathtaking vistas and a sense of freedom greet the stroller fresh from the city's asphalt. Few skylines compare with the sight of the buildings on Central Park South that seemingly rise out of the park's trees as one stands in the Sheep Meadow

title: Mexican Police Raid Rights Group
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4Just hours after breaking a twoweek strike of academic and administrative staff at the National University last month, Mexican policemen raided and closed a churchrelated information center here dedicated to defending human riehts.

title: Giants Select Shaw for Opener
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4While Coach John McVay was finally announcing today that Dennis Shaw would be the starting quarterback for the Giants preseason opener Saturday night, Shaw was doing his laundry.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan directed that the owner or the state's largest nursing home, Charles E. Sigety, be taken into custody next Tuesday and kept in jail until he complied with a subpoena to produce books and records for 1970 and 1971.

title: Stage: Otherwise Discomfited
description: SIMON HENCH, the central figure in Simon Gray's Otherwise Engaged, has precisely compartmentalized his life and rationed his emotionsetting a specific afternoon aside for listening to Wagner and having an office romance with the same cool circumspection that he sips his customary third of a bottle of wine with dinner. Less a dramatic character than a carefully composed attitudea demeanorhe wears a donotdisturb sign on his heart. But soon his apartment is a swinging door of other people's problems, which he disdains with serene detachment. They act; he reacts.

title: Police Evict Elderly Tenants of San Francisco Hotel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4Hundreds of policemen, some on horseback and swinging nightsticks, pushed through more than 2,000 protesters here before dawn today to evict elderly tenants from a downtown hotel.

title: In Memoriam
description: SPIEREGENRa?. July 5, 1977. In loving memory. Never to be forgotten. MACK J. POPOLOW.

title: The Museums
description: For the contemplative, or those seeking escape from a sudden summer shower, there is a host of museums bordering Central Park.

title: Congress Approves CleanAir Bill Signaling GoAhead on 1978 Autos
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)Congress gave auto makers the goahead tonight to begin manufacturing 1978model cars without fitting them with advanced new pollutioncontrol devices.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday. Aug. 4. 1977

title: New York Welfare Rolls Drop 3.5%
description: The number of people collecting welfare in New York City fell by 36,119 in the year ended June 30 to 966,728, which was the lowest monthly total in nearly three years, the Human Resources Administrator, J. Henry Smith, announced yesterday.

title: Management
description: A Governmentfinanced organization the Institute for New Enterprise Development  helps dreamers who have sound ideas. Daniel M. Lopez, Chicagoan of MexicanAmerican parentage, is just such a person.

title: Liberals
description: In a reprise of the intense struggle over the Liberal Party mayoral nomination, the Liberals state chairman charged yesterday that State Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Republican mayoral hopeful, was harassing and intimidating Liberal Party members in an effort to Invalidate the party's support of Mario M. Cuomo, one of the Democratic mayoral contenders.

title: ALICE CADDY BURMAN, 80; ARTIST, BOOK ILLUSTRATOR
description: Alice Caddy Burman, artist and illustrator of a series of popular books by her husband, Ben Lucien Burman, died Wednesday night in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. She was 80 years old and lived at 24 Fifth Avenue.

title: New Face: Sandy Faison
description: Every night after the curtain comes down on the hit musical Annie, brownhaired woman in a sweatshirt, smelly sneakers and Levi's hops into a Volkswagen and drives off to Brooklyn Heights. Sometimes the crowds at the stage door ask if she's a dancer in the show, but usually they ignore her. They never mistake her for Grace Farrell, Daddy Warbucks's coolly elegant, blond, colorcoordinated secretary.

title: Film: The 'Madcap' Family Plotters
description: THE GREAT MADCAP" is an atypically sunny, relatively slight Luis Buuel film, made in Mexico in 1949 but only now enjoying its first New York theatrical run at the Jean Renoir Cinema, which will be the local host of premieres of three more Buuel films in weeks to come.The title refers to a Mexican millionaire who begins drowning his sorrow after his wife's death and, as the film opens, has just spent a night in the cooler, cheek by jowl with a bunch of friendly bums. He fits in quite nicely, which is convenient, because the millionaire's good-for-nothing family is hatching a plot that will leave him in rags for real.It seems that the familya socialite daughter, playboy son, snooty brother and hypochondriac sister-in-lawhas decided that the only way to keep everybody's favorite moneybags sober is to convince him that he has already squandered his fortune. The relatives forsake their hacienda to rent a shabby apartment and don very neat work clothes, in an effort to convince him that times are rough. Their ruse doesn't workand why should it? They still sneak cream puffs when the old man isn't looking.But the millionaire comes up with a scheme of his own, and it's a wonderful success: He convinces the others that they really are poor and, as if by magic, these freeloaders learn to support themselves. Pretty soon everyone is back home in the mansion, where the snooty brother mends gilt furniture and the sister-in-law bakes bread. The lazy son decides to go back to college, and the daughter breaks off with a gigolo to marry a diligent poor boy she met in the slums. Through it all, the millionaire beams wisely. Everybody lives more than happily ever after.This story, based on a comedy by Adolfo Torrado, would have amounted only to the airiest of fluff had not Buuel taken merry advantage of the plot's several layers of deceit. The film, which has an exaggerated visual elegance to match its characters' fine manners, contains several delightful episodes in which the family's cordiality, never worth much in the first place, is worn even thinner than usual by everyone's complete uncertainty about just what everyone else is up to. But, Buuel being Buuel, politesse easily prevails at the expense of reason.

title: Coal Union Hospitals Floundering Amid Spreading Strike by Miners
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Complications continued to spread today from the siKweekold wildcat strike of coal miners, by the latest count swollen to 70,000 men, or onethird of the active membership of the United Mine Workers.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Performances of Hair are tonight and 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8, Sunday at 3 and 8. Previews continue until Sept. 14, Tuesdays through Saturdays at 8, matinees Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2, Sundays at 3. Tickets, Tuesdays through Fridays and all matinees $8, $12.50 and $16.50; Saturday evenings, $10, $15 and $20. At the Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street (JU 25340).

title: Raymond Lee Concern Accused In Ruling by F.T.C. Law Judge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)An initial decision from a Federal Trade Commission judge has ruled that the Raymond Lee Organization, an ideapromotion company, has misrepresented the nature and value of its services, the agency announced today.

title: Carey Seeks Carter Meeting
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Governor Carey said today that he had formally requested personal meeting with President Carter to appeal the President's rejection of New York's application for disaster status to aid in recovery from the blackout..

title: Lawyers Explore Advertising, but Cautiously
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 Lawyers around the country have begun slowly and cautiously testing the uncharted waters of advertising since the Supreme Court ruled in June that, for the first time in 69 years, they could publicize their services and nrobable fees.

title: Physicists at Illinois Lab Think They Have Found a New Quark
description: An ephemeral particle 10 times heavier than the proton and neutron of the atomic nucleus, heaviest of the stable particles, appears to have been discovered, suggesting the existence of six rather than four quarks as basic building blocks of matter.

title: A.C.L.U. Aides Fear Effects of Former F.B.I. Ties
description: A number of officials of the American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday they feared that disclosures that some of the group's leaders fed information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the 1950's might have an adverse effect on their organization, whose membership and income have recently been declining. same time might make it a more forceful organization.

title: The Pop Life
description: YES is much with us this week. The first album by the British progressive rock quintet in two and a half years, Going for the One, is barreling up toward the No. 1 spot on the album charts only two weeks after its release (although whether it can displace the tenacious Fleetwood Mac Rumours album remains very much to be seen). And the group is scheduled for Madison Square Garden for three shows tonight through Sunday.

title: At the Movies
description: NOWADAYS, a good movie about a boy and his horse is hard to find. Which is why comes as a jolt to hear that the Godfather s Om Francis Ford Coppola is producing The Black Stallion, based on a childhood favorite story by William Farley. What's more, Mr. Coppola and his director, Carroll Ballard, have come up with the ideal star for their film. His name is Mickey Rooney.

title: Surviving Measure for Measure When the Metric System Arrives
description: It's going to make confusion, said Geoffrey Beene, the designer. I assume it initially will be a nightmare, said Dr. Sanford Siegal, the expert on weight control. There's a reservoir of opposition, said Nathan L. Friedman, an executive of the United States Metric Association.

title: F.P.C.BLACKOUT STUDY DENOUNCED BY CON ED
description: The president of the Consolidated Edison Company, Arthur Hauspurg, yesterday denounced a Federal Power Commission report critical of obvious flaws in the reliability of the utility's electrical system and attacked what he termed inaccurate statements and unsupported conclusions.

title: Young, on Eve of Trip, Says Aim Is Overall Policy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4Andrew Young, who is undertaking a 10country Caribbean mission for the President, says the Carter Administration is seeking an overall Caribbean policy for the region, which in past years has been neglected or taken for granted.

title: PENTAGON INVESTIGATING KOREAN THEFT CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters)The Defense Department said today it was investigating allegations that American and Korean military personnel in South Korea have peen stealing up to $17 million a year of United States equipment.

title: New Leaders of Port Authority Introduce Antijunket Travel Plan
description: The new leadership of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced a new travel policy yesterday designed to eliminate many of the practices that have provoked inVestigations into alleged expenseaccount abuses and possible evasion of taxes.

title: Holtzman, the Designated Sitter, Makes His Stand
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 4Ken Holtzman laughed. One does not often see Ken Holtzman laugh. At this moment, though, he could have fallen off the bench laughing. It is that funny.

title: Carter Asks More E.P.A. Money
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)President Carter asked Congress today to add $69 million to the budget for the fiscal year 1978 for the Environmental Protection Agency. The money would be used to complete waste treatment management planning programs.

title: U.S. SPENDING SHORTFALL UP TO OVER $9 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Bert Lance, director of the Office of Management and Budget, reported today another rise in the shortfall in Federal spendingthe inability of Federal agencies and states to spend as much Federal money as budgeted.

title: Carey Names Morgado. Secretary In Face of Opposition From Gribetz
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Robert J. Morgado, who rose quietly and quickly through the ranks of state government to become Governor Carey's director of state operations, today was named secretary to the Governor, the most powerful staff post in the Carey administration. He will succeed David W. Burke, who has accepted a job as vice president of ABC News and Sports.

title: Student, 22, Surrenders to the Nassau Police in Bank Murder Case
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 4A 22yearold student at the New York Institute of Technology surrendered to the Nassau County police today in connection with the murder of a 42yearold woman teller during the holdup of a bank in Greenvale last week.

title: Sports Today
Pedaling on Country Lanes
description: Some urban fantasies die hard, and among the most persistent of them is the vision of getting away from it all. Many New Yorkers cherish the idea of the rural bicycle trip. Settling for Central Park on the odd Sunday, they dream of coursing down sunny, sleepy lanes in a restorative silence, the wind ruffling their hair, with a hot bath at the end of the ride and drinks with congenial but undemanding friends.

title: At the Hollis Discussion Club, There's No Subject That's Sacred
description: The most remarkable thing about the Hollis Discussion Club may not be that Herb Coddington and Russell Marks are still on speaking terms after 35 years of biweekly discourse and debate, but that the two men ever found anything to say to each other in the first place.

title: President Seeks Legalized Status For Many Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  President Carter asked Congress today to provide legal status for millions of aliens whose presence in the United States violates current immigration statutes.

title: What a Summer Wins at Spa
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4What a Summer, favored at 85 and topweighted with 125 pounds, easily won the $25,000 feature race, handicap for fillies and mares, at the Saratoga track today. Artfully was second, 3 lengths behind.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Aug. 4, 1977

title: Suspicious Fire Disrupts Hospital
description: A suspicious threealarm tire in locked storage room poured heavy smoke through Lincoln Medical Center in the South Bronx last, night, prompting hospital officials to move 20 infants and dozen adult patients in pediatrics and surgical wards.

title: League Leaders
Roosevelt Raceway Drivers
description: RESULTS

title: Mexico Plans Large Sales Of Gas toU.S. Consortium
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4 (AP)Mexico has signed a letter of intent to sell large quantities of natural gas to a consortium of six United States companies, it was announced yesterday. The accord should eventually help relieve winter gas shortages in the United States.

title: F.P.C. BLACKOUT STUDY DENOUNCED BY CON ED
description: The president of the Consolidated Edison Company, Arthur Hauspurg, yesterday denounced a Federal Power Commission report critical of obvious flaws in the reliability of the utility's electrical system and attacked what he termed inaccurate statements and unsupported conclusions.

description: LONDON, Aug. 4  A major British campaign to promote a less hazardous cigarette containing cellulose seems to be failing.

title: Antiques
description: SUMMER IS the busiest season for two of the country's top specialists in furniture repair and restorationOxford Antique Restorers Ltd., a subsidiary of Stair & Company Inc.; 59 East 57th Street, and Sack Conservation Company Inc., division of Israel Sack Inc., 15 East 57th Street

title: JAPANESE PREPARING PLAN TO CUT HOLDINGS OF FOREIGN RESERVES
description: TOKYO, Aug. 4Japan's Ministry of Finance and other Government bureaus, under instructions from Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda, are drawing up plans to reduce that country's foreign exchange holdings, which have been spiraling since the beginning of this year.

title: Rice Designated Leader
description: Boston's time Rice continues to lead American League designated hitters according to figures released yesterday. Rice is hitting .321 and has 29 home runs and 61 runs batted in as a dh. Hal McRae of Kansas City is hitting .308 and Ron Fairly of Toronto is at .304.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Touch Of Poignancy for Rhodesians
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 31In the apprehensive lives of white Rhodesians, there are few more poignant occasions than an auction. Under Government controls that permit emigrants to take their wealth in kind, but not in cash, an unseemly scramble has developed for jewelry and antiques, raising prices to levels that would make dealers in London and New York scratch their heads in envy.

title: Fluke and Blues Dominate Catches in Nearby Waters
description: AREA AAround Margate, N.J., fishing is still good for blues and excellent for flounder in the back bays and inlets. Robert Corkhill of Ventnor, N.J., had a big day Wednesday, hauling in 20 flounder 12 blues and 16 weakfish off Great Egg Inlet. Flounder have been most abundants between Buoys C and D while the blues have been found mostly in 60 to 70 feet of water. Weakfish in the 3 to 5 pounds range have been caught in good numbers off Ocean City. Fishing for weaks has been partitularly good at night in areas where there are lights near the water. Blues in the 8 to 15 pound range are abundant on Barnegat Ridge. In Barnegat Inlet, a few fluke up to 8 pounds have been responding to snappers.

title: 3 IN ARAB BAND SLAIN IN THE JORDAN VALLEY
description: TEL AVIV, Aug 4Israeli forces killed three Arab guerrillas and took two prisoners today, destroying a band that paralyzed life in Jordan Valley settlements for several hours, military headquarters here said.

title: Group With Korea Ties Is Linked To Bid to Stop Nixon Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4A House subcommittee reported today that an organization with operational ties to the Korean Central Intelligence Agency and under the aegis of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon had tried to stop the impending impeachment of President Nixon.

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros
description: CARIBBEAN DANCE: Students in the Caribbean Community Program at the Museum of Natural History performed yesterday for Haitian youngsters who live in the city. The modern and folk dances and the adaptations of dances performed at voodoo ceremonies seemed to entrance the young girl at right.

title: U.S. Campaign Encourages Women to Own Businesses
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)A national campaign to encourage women's ownership of businesses through programs of the Small Business Administration has been announced by the White House.

title: Personal Investing
description: Two of the Value Line's mutual funds are not for the fainthearted. But right now, thanks to investor interest in second tier stocks that they hold, Leveraged Growth Investors and the Special Situations Fund are at the top of the performance heap. Their recent gains in net asset value still leave them below their levels of a few years back. Page 27.

title: Miss Engst Wed to Judge Charles Mullen Jr.
description: Barbara Head Engst, daughter of Mrs. Clarence Chaddock Head of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Head of Ithaca, N.Y., and Sarasota. was married in Scranton, Pa., yesterday to Charles .Tames Mullen Jr. of Cortland, N.Y., who serves as Cortland County Judge, Surrogate, and as a Judge of Ihe Family Court of the State of New York.

title: PattiAnn McKenna Married To Ens. Arthur Stephen Olsen
description: St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syosset, LI., was the setting last evening for the marriage of PattiAnn McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. McKenna of Syosset, to Ens. Arthur Stephen Olsen, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Olsen of Farmingdale, L.I. The Rev. Harry J. Palmer performed the ceremony.

title: The New York Times/Mlko The Rev. Frederick D. Kirkpatrick singing folk songs prior to a seminar at conference in Atlanta
Carter News Parley On 3 Networks Today
description: President Carter's news conference today will be televised by the CBS, NBC and ABC network, and their local stations, Channels 2, 4 and 7, starting at 10 A.M. The following radio stations have also scheduled live broadcasts: WCBSAM, WINS, WNBC and WNYCAM.

title: Carter Still Looks to Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)President Carter said today that despite Syria's rejection of American proposals fcr Middle East peace talks a conference in Geneva later this year was probable. Asked whether he thought Palestinians would be represented at the talks, Mr. Carter said, I'll wait until later to make judgment.

title: 5 Southeast Asian Nations Agree On Economic Cooperation in Area
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia. Aug. 5The leaders of the five nonCommunist countries of Southeast Asia concluded their twoday conference today with series of economic agreements and broad communique pledging renewed efforts to create a strong, viable and cohesive regional organization.

title: Regalado Leads on63 for 130
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 5 (AP) Victor Regalado of Mexico, the last man on the course, birdied the final hole in neardarkness today carded secondround 63 and grabbed the lead at the halfway point of the $210,000 Greater Hartford open golf tournament.

title: Shipping/Mails
Bride of Geoffrey Baker
description: The bride, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marion G. Donaldson of Scottsdale, Ariz., will retain her own name. She was graduated from the University of Arizona and received an M.A. degree from the University of Massachusetts. Her previous marriage ended in diverce. Her father is a, retired superintendent of schools in the Phoenix area.

title: Court Voids 2 Life Terms Imposed Under New York State Drug Laws
description: Sentences of up to life in prison for two women convicted under New York State's drug laws were declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal judge who said the sentences were disproportionately severe for relatively minor offenses.

title: Notes on People
description: Fan YuanYen, the MIG19 pilot who defected from the Chinese Air Force to Taiwan last month, has turned down an invitation to visit the United States. Eight conservative Congressmen extended the invitation, but Mr. Fan turned it down for fear of embarassing the United States Government before Secretary State Cyrus R. Vance visits Peking later this month. If I visit the United States at this juncture it might add some difficulty to the U.S. Government and it might not be welcomed, he wrote the Congressmen, all members of the American Conservative Union. Mr. Yen has also written Mr. Vance asking for help in getting his wife and three children out of mainland China.

title: SovietI.T.T. Phone Pact
description: Soviet businessmen will be using an American telephone system to help them make calls from Moscow's World Trade Center under an agreement announced yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. I.T.T. said its North American Telecommunications subsidiary would install by early 1980 a 2,650line telephone switching system to serve hotel rooms, offices and stores in the trade center.

title: Agenda Compromise Ends Preparatory Conference For EastWest Meeting
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5The preparatory phase of the Belgrade conference on European security ended today with the adoption of a compromise agenda for the main meeting this fall.

title: The Power Outage
description: 1 The thing which I'm telling you no one enjoys being equal.

title: Books of The Times
description: Of the scores of reform movements that flourished in the United States in the last half of the 19th century, few generated the passion and the moral fervor of sex reform. Its explicit history, peopled with men and women of high purpose and fought around issues fundamental to an enlightened society, has lain neglected for almost 100 years, so that Hal D. Sears's The Sex Radicals is a pathfinding study of great interest and significance.

title: Cookindustries Reports $53 Million Loss in Quarter
description: Cook Industries Inc.. one of the nation's largest grain and cotton conglomerates, continued to suffer severe reverses in its financial position, yesterday reporting loss of $53 million for its fourth fiscal quarter ended May 31, in contrast to profit of $20.2 million, or $5.41 a share, cleared in the final quarter of its preceding fiscal year.

title: People and Business
description: Challenges for Kelly as Esmark Names Him Its Chief Executive

title: LORD ADRIAN, 81,DIES; NOTED PHYSIOLOGIST
description: LONDON, Aug. 5Lord Adrian of Cambridge, one of the world's ranking physiologists and a senior figure in Britain's scientific community for more than four decades, died last night. He was 87 years old.

title: Sports Today
About New York
description: What can you give to the man who has nothing? What can you promise the woman who has had dreams, her dreams, shattered in one night of passion, none of it hers? How can you put someone together again after he has fallen off the wall?

title: Governor Signs Package of Bills Aimed at Better. AdultHome Care
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5Governor Carey has signed a package of bills intended to improve conditions in private, profitmaking homes for adults, his office announced today.

title: Jamaica at a Glance
description: GeographyJamaica is a 4,400square mile island in the heart of the Caribbean. Kingston, the capital, is 90 miles south of Cuba and 100 miles west of Haiti. Largely a limestone plateau, the island has volcanic hills, with Blue Mountain on the eastern end reaching 7,400 feet. Rainfall is heavy along this mountainous region, where there are extensive timber reserves. The plateau is a rugged area deeply dissected by streams and undermined by subterranean rivers. The plateau rises abruptly from the ocean, but generally there is a narrow coastal band widened by broad river valleys.

title: Vance in Jordan, Still Talking of a Geneva Conference
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 5Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance brought his Middle East mission to Jordan today, still publicly holding out the hope that a Geneva peace conference could eventually be convened despite the apparent collapse of the idea of a preliminary meeting of Arab and Israeli foreign ministers.

title: Dividends
New Jersey No. I in Blueberries; Demand Spurs More Cultivation
description: MARMORA, Aug. 5Despite weather problems that reduced its crop, New Jersey has vaulted past Michigan this summer to become the nation's No. 1 blueberry producer, Philip G. Sheridan, executive secretary of the North American Blueberry Council, said today.

title: Village Light Opera, Londoners Stage Lively Fantasy Pinafore
description: Last summer, New York's Village Light Opera Group visited London to perform a Wild West version of Gilbert and Sullivan's Trial by Jury and pool talents with its opposite number, community theater organization called the Philbeach Society of London, in ptoduction of The Pirates of Penzance. The joint venture, dubbed BALOE (British/American Light Opera Exchange), proved to be so successful that this year the Philbeachers came to New York to collaborate with the Village Light Opera Thursday and Friday nights at New York Community College in Brooklyn.

title: Article 3  No Title
Patents
description: WASHINGTON  An electronically controlled intravenous infusion system for use in hospitals can be adjusted to deliver from 1 to 99 drops a minute into a patient's veins. The instrument, which monitors the flow, gives visual and audible alarms if it is slowed by such things as pinched tubing or an empty fluid container.

title: Unueilings
description: HAMMERIrving. A monument will be unveiled on Sunday August 7 at Beth David Cemefory, Elmont, Long Island, at 11:30 A.M. Section A, Block 6, Sinai Ave. In memory of our beloved Irving Hammer, Husband and Father.

title: Sky Over Oshkosh Given a New Look By Airplane Buffs
description: OSHKOSH, Wis., Aug. 5Hundreds of oddlooking objects have been hovering over this northeastern Wisconsin City for nearly a week, stirring excitement and curiosity and swelling the normal population of 55,000 to more than 100,000.

title: Kathryn Faie Donaldson
description: Kathryn Faie Donaldson, a research analyst with the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, and Geoffrey Burnett Baker, legislative assistant to Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, were married yesterday afternoon at the summer home on Clark's Island, Mass., of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Baker of Greenwich, Conn., and Duxbury, Mass.

title: In Memoriam
description: COOPERSamuel (Butchlet). It's not the same world without you. We love You and miss you desperately.

title: Carter Plan Giving New York State $400 Million More in Welfare Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Under the welfare program to be proposed tomorrow by President Carter, New York State would receive well over $400 million in additional funds, members of the state's Congressional delegation reported today.

title: PRESIDENT'S PROGRAM TO CONSERVE ENERGY WINS HOUSE PASSAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5After a week of intensive debate, the House today passed energy taxes and regulatory measures designed to reduce the nation's reliance on natural gas and imported cii, leaving President Carter's sweeping package largely intact.

title: Unemployment Declines to 6.9%; Labor Picture Called Lackluster
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Government reported today that the national unemployment rate fell in July, returning to the May level, but that employment failed to rise for the first time in nine months.

title: The Great Ship Robbery
description: Shipping lobbyists helped elect Jimmy Carter, raising over $150,000 for his campaign. Now they have asked for and received a little help from their friend. The White House has chosen to support cargo preference legislation, a new way for ship owners and the maritime unions to get rich at public expense.

title: A Mountaineer's Protest Dramatized StripMine Fight
description: PIKESVILLE, Ky.Ten years ago this summer Jink Ray, as mildmannered a Godfearing mountain man as you could find here in the Appalachian highlands, heard a strip miner's bulldozer coming around the noint.

title: Dollar Gains a Little in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5 (AP)The dollar made a slight gain in moderate trading on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today to close at 265.95 yen, compared with yesterday's 265.525 yen.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY 8E TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 I UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500; SUFFOLK I CO. (5I6) 669.I000; CONNECTICUT (203) 348.7747.

title: Senate Bill Assigns U . S . More Authority MBank Supervision
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)The Senate passed a bill today designed to strengthen Federal supervisory authority over banks and other financial institutions.

title: TOKEN DAMAGES AWARDED TO HALPERIN FOR WIRETAP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)A Federal district judge today awarded token damages of $1$4 to a former member of Richard M. Nixon's national security staff for wiretaps placed in his home in White House attempt to discover the source of information disclosed to newspapers.

title: Tanker Docks North of Seattle With Alaska Pipeline's First Oil
description: CHERRY POINT, Wash., Aug. 5The first oil from Alaska's North Slope arrived here today, commencing deliveries of crude from the transAlaska pipeline. The deliveries are expected to temporarily ease, but not reverse, the nation's growing dependence on imported oil.

title: With the 60's Boom Over, Italian Fashion Industry Faces Decline
description: ROMEBeset by mounting labor and production costs, growing fear of crime among its clientele, and little sympathy from political sectors, the Italian fashion industry is in trouble.

title: DOMESTIC AUTO OUTPUT DECLINED 23.4% IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5Model changeover shutdowns cIropped domestic car production 23.4 percent this week, according to Wards Automotive Report.

title: ExPolice Captain Enters Guilty Plea To . Perjury Count
description: Daniel Tange, a retired New York City Police Department captain, pleaded guilty yesterday to perjury in connection with his sworn statements regarding a bribery investigation that had been conducted by John F, Keenan, the special state anticorruption prosecutor.

title: TELEPHONE WORKERS REJECT BELL OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The major telephone workers union rejected today a contract proposal from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: OXYGEN LEVEL DROPS AT 3 SITES OFFSHORE
description: SANDY HOOK, Aug. 5The oxygen content near the sea bottom at three points off the Jersey coast has dropped in recent days, but Federal and state officials monitoring the depletion said today that they were not yet alarmed that repetition of last summer's massive fish kill was developing.

title: BRONX YOUTH, 19, SLAIN; WOMAN SUSPECT ARRESTED
description: A 19yearold Bronx youth was shot to death yesterday and authorities were holding a woman suspect who asserted that he had been one of three men who raped her last Tuesday, the police reported.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP)An agreement to test methods of moving urban black families to the suburbs was announced today in a case in which the United States Supreme Court told Federal officials to find a way to remedy housing segregation here.

title: Carter Signs a $1 Billion Bill to Help Jobless Youths
description: WASHLNGTON. Aug. 5 President Carter signed today a bill meant to ease the plight of unemployed youths and said that the legislation showed the concern of his Administration and of Congress to help the poor and the blacks.

title: CANCELLATION OF BI IS CRITICIZED BY GAO.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5By canceling contracts on the B1 bomber and the Minuteman III missile before notifying Congress, the Carter Administration violated at least the spirit of the Budget Control and Impoundment Act of 1974, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: K.C.I.A. Said to Have List of Gifts to Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5A former associate of Park Tong Sun hai testified that the Korean businessman submitted to the Korean Central Intelligence Agency written reports of his cash gifts to American congressmen, according to Congressional sources.

title: Vilas, McEnroe Advance
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5Guillermo Vilas, getting a second wind and a dry racquet after a torturously long second set, rallied to beat Peter Fleming, 61, 67. 61, today and move into the quarterfinals of the $85,000 Mutual Benefit Life open tournament at the Orange Lawn, Tennis Club.

title: Major League Box Scores
DOLLAR WEAK AGAIN IN EUROPEAN TRADING
description: LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP)The dollar declined in relation to most European currencies today, ending a week marked by an upanddown performance in a slow but nervous market.

title: George Rosen, 67; Medical Historian Was Yale Professor
description: Dr. George Rosen, a medical historian and former director of health education for the New York City Department of Health, died on July 28 at the age of 67 in Oxford, England.

title: Warm Breeze Is Syndicated
description: Warm Breeze, the fastest harness horse under race conditions in the 171year history of the sport, has been syndicated and will begin stallion service in 1978, the United States Trotting Association was told Friday.

title: Dance Asylum Shows Value Of Collective Experimentation
description: A fairly new idea in danceprobably, at least in effect, the now venerable Dance Theater Workshop was the granddaddy of them allis the dance collective. This is simply a group of dancers and choreographers gathered together under one name and usually one roof, who experiment on one another, with one another and for one another. They are their own raw material, their own first critics and their own best friends.

title: Lebanese Christian Sees Border Battle Worsening
description: METULLA, Israel, Aug. 5A Lebanese major, Saad Haddad, crossed the border this morning after a night of heavy fighting between his almost encircled forces of Christian villagers and Palestinian troops on neighboring hills.

title: TERRORIST VICTIM BURIED: Ines Ponto being escorted to her seat by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, left, and President Walter Scheel at funeral for her husband,
description: United Press International

title: ExEmployee Of Penney Gets Jail and Fine
description: Andrew Tsanas, a discharged employee of the J. C. Penney Company, was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $15,000 yesterday following his conviction in Brooklyn Federal Court on charges of failing to report to the Internal Revenue Service $1.4 million in kickbacks on which a tax of $880,000 was evaded.

title: Soybeans Mixed
description: Soybeans Mixed; Grains Move Up

title: Dig They Must for a StillGrowing Brasilia
description: BRASILIAThis isolated capital of barren glass and concrete beauty, ideal climate and sunsets so pure and spectacular as to remind one of those seen by the astronauts from the moon has completed 17 years and become unquestionably mature as an administrative center. Yet, like the child that grows too big fast, Brasilia, which now has a population estimated at one million, remains an adolescent in search of a personality. But it keeps growing. So much so, that construction remains the leading nonGovernment industry, employing about 300,000 workers.

title: A Sitting Duck in NoMan's Land
description: The demonstrators marched in a long, orderly circle in front of the building at. 51 East 42d Street. They carried signs and chanted slogans that have become battle cries from England to California: Sports yes, apartheid no, tennis and South Africa have got to go! Many faces in the crowd were young, perhaps refugees from other movements. But Percy Sutton, the Manhattan borough president and New York City mayoral candidate, was a familiar figure as he walked with William Booth, the New York

title: Letters
description: Of Abortion, Medicaid and Carter's Stand

title: ANDREW YOUNG OPENS JAUNTY JAMAICA VISIT
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 5Andrew Young began a 10day Caribbean visit with a buoyant start here today, expressing optimism about imminent agreement on a Panama Canal treaty and saying that 'we may really have turned the corner on southern African issues.

title: For the IRT, a Special Delivery..
description: Robert Higgins became ill while a student at the Transit Police Academy watching a required film on how to deliver a baby.

title: Beaumont May Be Shut 2 Years
description: The Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center may be shut down for as long as one or two years after The Cherry Orchard ends its run there tomorrow afternoon, John W. Mazzola, the center's president, said yesterday. The New York Shakespeare Festival's production of the Chekhov play is closing more than four weeks earlier than anticipated; when it began its run last June 28, the center's management had hoped it would last into the fall.

title: FREDERICK W. RITTER SR.
description: Frederick W. Ritter Sr., a lawyer, died Wednesday at his home, 14 Melrose Lane, Douglaston, Queens. His age was 90.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROOTS AND TOOTS August is music month at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, with a free series of four outdoor concerts by the Bronx Arts Ensemble on Saturdays, starting today, and a special evening program on Aug. 17 by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Erich Leinsdorf.

title: Siderowf Ousted Early in Met Golf
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 5Dick Siderowf was named to the United States Walker Cup team for the third time Just two weeks ago. The 39Yearold golfer front Westport, Conn., already has two British Amateur chainpionships to his credit. And here he was today on his home course in the first matchplay round of the 75th Metropolitan amateur championship at Century Country Club, seeking his fifth title in the event.

title: Brats
Myths
description: The once rather daring combinations of dance, declaimed words and improvisational music have fallen on hard times. These experimental works which had, at least, the advantage of novelty must now stand or fall on their intrinsic merits. Against such a standard, Myths, seen Thursday evening at 61 Crosby Street, was a poor entry in a flagging field.

title: Rally in 8th Sinks Giants at Shea
description: The New York Mets, the giddiest lastplace team in baseball, treated themselves to more of their newly found joy of rebuilding at Shea Stadium_ last night when they concocted one run: in the last half of the eighth inning and defeated the San Francisco Giants,. 32.

title: Black Women Make Up A New Sophistication, A Look of Their Own
description: The 40 women gathered on Macy's second floor silently nodded in agreement. They sat up straighter, patted their hairdos and smiled when Susan Talyor, an editor of Essence magazine, said in her opening remarks: We are Sheba's daughters, Cleopatra's sisters. We were the first to adorn and oil our bodies, we developed the art of makeup. From nature, we extracted and refined the elements needed for our costmetic ritual.

title: Prysock Brothers Sound the Blues
description: Arthur Prysock, the singer, and his brother, Red Prysock, the tenor saxophonist, are both veterans of rhythmandblues circuits of the 1940's and 50's who are still holding closely to the basis of their original success, even in as distinctly a nonrhythmandblues setting as Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11 th Street, where they conclude their appearance tonight.

title: Economist Says No U.S. Area Is in Deep Trouble
description: None of the nation's regions is in deep economic trouble, the smaller metropolitan areas will have the largest inmigration and growth in the near future and the massive movement of people that shaped much of the nation's history has come to an end.

title: Senator and the Prince: The Odd Couple
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5A tale of an Arabian night involved what might have been an unlikely pair not too long ago. In a guess who's coming to dinner? setting, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, Prince Saud alFaisal, invited Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York, a leading spokesman for the American Jewish community, to dine on Arabian delicacies at Jidda on the shores of the Red Sea.

title: Court Voids 2 Life Terms. Imposed Under New York State Drug Laws
description: Sentences of up to life in prison for two women convicted under New York State's drug laws were declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal judge who said the sentences were disproportionately severe for relatively minor offenses.

title: CBSTV Advances Fall Premieres in Ratings Battle
description: CBSTV has advanced the premieres of several of its new series and has mounted a schedule of movies, pilots and specials to counter the efforts of ABC and NBC to gain a headstart on the fall television season.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARKS, Cunningham Park, Queens, 8:30.

title: COMPETITION HAILED ON HEALTHCARE COST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5When doctors organize a health maintenance organization, other physicians in the community seldom fight the competition by cutting fees but they do react in other ways that may help to control rising healthcare costs, according to a Federal study published today.

title: Personal Investing
description: Value Line Leveraged Growth Investors and the Value Line Special Situations Fund are not for the fainthearted. They are two of the most volatile openend investment companies in the business, and they have really had their ups and downs.

title: Somalis Urge Ethiopians to Oust Mengistu's Military
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 5 (UPI)Somalia said today that the wars of secession in southeast and northern Ethiopia would end only with the total independence of those areas and it urged the Ethiopian people to overthrow the murderous military regime of Mengistu Haile Mariam.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority announced yesterday that it had agreed to accept a $2.25 million settlement from the Island Creek Coal Company for what the Federal utility says was inferior coal delivered to its power plants.

title: Sky Over Oshkosh Given a New Look By Airplane Buffs
description: OSHKOSH, Wis., Aug. 5Hundreds of oddlooking objects have been hovering over this northeastern Wisconsin city for nearly a week, stirring excitement and curiosity and swelling the normal population of 55,000 to more than 100,000.

title: OBSERVER
Mount Etna Spouts Hot Lava
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Aug. 5 (AP)Mount Etna overflowed with hot lava again today after a 10day pause. Officials said one flow was headed toward Randazzo, a city of 14,000 about 20 miles to the north, but added that there was no immediate danger to populated or cultivated areas.

title: Hopes Rise on Canal Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Carter Administration's hopes for early conclusion of a new Panama Canal treaty, one of the President's highest priorities in foreign policy, mounted dramatically today as word spread about a speech made in Colombia by Panama's Chief of Government.

title: Carter's Gain At the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  After the prickly mood of confrontation with Capitol Hill through most of the spring, President Carter has now established more workable giveandtake relation ship with Congress as its members head home for the summer recess. The price of such an arrangement has been a recent willingness to accept compromises on the farm bill, water projects and domestic spending and to trim his sights on other issues. But this has produced successes that he needed and broken him out of the earlier logjam with the legislature.

title: LEONARD A. ASTLEYBELL, A FORMER OIL EXECUTIVE
description: Leonard A. AstleyBell, former president and a director of the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation and Shell Caribbean Petroleum, died yesterday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Sharon and in Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Doctors at the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey are seeking people who have undergone Xray or radium treatment for ear, nose and throat ailments to determine if they ran a higher risk of developing cancer, Dr. Myron J, Shapiro, acting chairman of the division of otolaryngology, said yesterday.

title: Farber Ruled Off G.O.P. Ballot in Mayoral Primary
description: The New Ycrk City Board of Elec.:Ions ruled yesterday that Barry Farber must be removed from the Republican primary for Mayor because he did not have enough valid signatures on his qualifying petitions.

title: Jesse Colin Young: Diverse Songs
description: In the five years since the dissolution of the Youngbloods, Jesse Colin Young has established a firm niche for himself in the world of popular music. He is a respected, diverse singersongwriter with a loyal, affectionate yet contained audiencecontained both in its numbers and in its enthusiasm. In fact, Mr. Young, who appeared Thursday night for a rainpostponed Dr. Pepper Music Festival date in Central Park, attracts just the sort of polite crowd that New York City officials must have envisaged when they purged the Wollman Rink site of hardrock acts.

title: Isidor Schneider, 80, Poet, Critic And Novelist With Leftist Themes
description: Isidor Schneider, a leading leftwing novelist and poet in New York's literary scene in the 1920's, 30's and 40's, died Wednesday in a Manhattan nursing home. He was 80 years old and had lived at 35 West 92d Street.

title: A Long Lost Cause
description: PARISIf Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith were not so addicted to believing everything he says, he would long since have realized that the cause of white supremacy in his unfortunate country has been doomed for many years. He would also have curbed that petrified instinct which has featured his policy since U.D.I. (unilateral declaration of independence) in 1965.

title: Army Blue Team Takes 7th National Pistol Title
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 5 (UPI)The United States Army Blue pistol squad won the national Trophy team championship today for the seventh consecutive year with a fourman score,. of 1,126 points. Second place went to the Marine Corps Scarlet entry with 1,124 points.

title: Connors Upset by Solomon
description: NORTH CONWAY. N.H.. Aug. 5 (AP) Fifthseeded Harold Solomon powered his way to an upset victory today over topseeded Jimmy Connors, ousting him in a quarterfinal match of the $125,000 Volvo International. The scores were 16, 64, 6I.

title: Early Rise in Stock Prices Is Pared And Dow Ends With Gain of 0.52
description: Stock prices moved higher early yesterday in response to favorable news developments, but Wall Street's latest version of a minirally faltered before the closing bell.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: ExTeacher, 82, Is Slain In Her Home in Elmhurst Apparently by a Burglat
description: An 82yearold retired elementary. school teacher was found strangled in her Queens home yesterday, apparently the victim of a burglar. She had lived in the house since 1907, when it was built. by her grandfather at 42.35 Ithaca Street in Elmhurst.

title: POLICE TO RESTRICT PARKING BY COUPLES
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday ordered the police to chase away couples parked in isolated areas of the city and to record the licenseplate numbers of their cars as long as the 44caliber killer case remains open.

title: MUSEUM TOWER PLAN RUNS INTO OBSTACLES
description: A luxury apartment tower that has been proposed to rise over an expanded Museum of Mctdern Art on 53d Street west of Fifth Avenue is running intolncreased ormosition.

title: Codd Says There Are No Suspects In Office Bombings Despite Arrest
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that the police had no suspects in the investigation of last Wednesday's terrorist bombings in midtown Manhattan. One person died and seven were injured in the two Incidents.

title: HighCourt Silence
description: Back in the days before John Marshall, each Justice of the United States Supreme Court expressed his individual opinion in each case (following the English practice); the tradition was abandoned, in part because Chief Justice Marshall felt that it defeated the great purpose of lawto enunciate clear and abiding principles.

title: Justice Criticizes City
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5In turning down New York City's application for a stay in the enforcement of pollutioncontrol measures, Justice Marshall criticized the city today for what he called a lack of dispatch in pressing its case.

title: Jets, Still Without a Touchdown, Lose to Eagles, 213
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, NJ., Aug 5After discovering they're not ready for the hall of fame, the New York Jets learned tonight they're not prepared for offBroadway, either.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: ROCKWELL CHAIRMAN DENIES PRIOR WORD OF B1 CANCELLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation denied today that he had any advance knowledge of President Carter's decision to kill the B1 bomber program before he sold more than $1 million of personal stock in the company.

title: Torrijos Seeks Support
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 5Panama's Chief of Government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, today sought the backing of five leaders of neighboring countries for a new Canal treaty with the United States.

title: Carter Is Optimistic After Talks On Southern Africa With Nyerere
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 President Carter said today that he and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania had reached almost complete agreement about the diplomatic course to be followed in trying to bring majority rule and legal independence to Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa. or Namibia.

title: Pessimism in Middle East
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Aug 5Middle East hopes sank today after Syria announced its rejection of the proposed formation of a working group of Arab and Israeli foreign ministers under American auspices to break the ArabIsraeli deadlock.

title: The Senator and the Prince: An Odd Couple
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5A tale of an Arabian night involved what might have been an unlikely pair not too long ago. In a guess who's coming to dinner? setting, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, Prince Saud alFaisal, invited Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York, a leading spokesman for the American Jewish community, to dine on Arabian delicacies at Jidda on the shores of the Red Sea.

title: Phils Unseat Cubs by Routing Dodgers
description: The long fall from grace that began for the Chicago Cubs on May 27 ended last night. The tenants of Wrigley Field lost to San Diego yesterday and slipped to second place in the National League East, when the Philadelphia Phillies reached the first position by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 83, in a night game at Veterans Stadium.

title: Primary Roundup
description: Representative Edward I. Koch, one of the candidates for mayor, and Albert Shankfir, president of the United Fed eration of Teachers, exchanged charges and figures yesterday after Mr. Shanher called nn Mr. Koch to withdraw an offensive advertisment on teachers.

title: Robert Hall Auction Realizes $35 Million
description: A fourday auction of the $110million in inventories of the defunct 367store Robert Hall retail chain, concluded yesterday at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden, brought in nearly $35 million, or about 32 cents on the dollar.

title: Brooklyn Fire's Refugees Struggling Back
description: At the Martinique Hotel in midtown Manhattan, Maria Jiminez sat in a dimly lighted room studying a lease she had signed that day for a new apartment for herself and her two children.

title: BERME, U.S. REACH AN UNDERSTANDING ON A PARKING BAN
description: Mayor Beame's administration, Federal officials and environmentalists  who have beenfeuding for months over a proposed Manhattan parking banreached what they said was a broad understanding yesterday, and a Federal judge gave them two more weeks to work out details of a comprehensive plan to reduce air pollution from traffic.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: PIPELINE OIL ARRIVES: The tanker Arco Juneau, carrying the first shipment of crude oil from the wells of Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's arctic coast, is brought into

title: The Standings
description: Saturday, August 6, 1977

title: More West Bank Sites Are Planned by Israelis, Visiting Settlers Report
description: Two militant Israeli settlers on the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan River held a news conference in New York yesterday to announce plans for 12 more Jewish settlements in the disputed territory.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Aug. 5, 1977

title: Measuring the Olympic Hurdles
description: Only hours before the deadline, Mayor Beanie entered New York City in the competition of American cities that wish to play host to the 1984 summer Olympics. This may be a contest worth losing, because the party will cost at least a quarter of a billion dollars. No American city seems to have that kind of money to spare. Still, if Congress would underwrite the affair, as the Mayor suggested, New York could surely provide a glamorous setting and an enthusiastic welcome.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, Aug. 5, 1977

title: Visa, Master Charge Squabbling Over Banks
description: The nation's two bank credit card systems, Visa and Master Charge, are squabbling.

title: 2 Wild Pitch Help Mariners Win, 53
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 5The Yankees, who didn't have much success playing in the proximity of Disneyland earlier this week, had trouble again tonight playing indoor baseball.

title: Some Black Church Leaders Plan Drive to Help Poor
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 5Leaders of a number of black churches around the country, spurred in part by the rising influence of young, politically oriented ministers, are seeking to open a drive to increase goods, services and human rights for the poor.

title: BEAME, U.S REACH AN UNDERSTANDING ON A PARKING BAN
description: Mayor Beame's administration, Federal officials and environmentalists  who have been feuding for months over a proposed Manhattan parking banreached what they said was a broad understanding yesterday, and a Federal judge gave them two more weeks to work out details of a comprehensive plan to reduce air pollution from traffic.

title: POLICE TO RESTRICT PARKING BY COUPLES
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the police to chase away couples parked in isolated areas of the city and to record the licenseplate numbers in an effort to prevent further shootings by the 44caliber killer.

title: People in Sports
description: Leo Boivin returned as coach of the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League yesterday, and the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association made it official that Lowell (Cotton) Fitzsimmons is their new coach. Some of the things the two men said upon assuming their posts tended to reinforce the feeling that a coach is a coach is a coach, no matter what the sport.

title: Giants Begin Exhibitions Tonight Against Patriots
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 5Now it begins, what the National Football League calls its preseason, what most fans call exhibition games and what Coach John McVay of the Giants calls competition in the finest sense, capitalism at its best: survival of the fittest.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 489,394 Abortions

title: Pueblo Dog Linked to China Wolf
description: The dogs that yelped and skulked around early Pueblo Indian settlements in the American Southwest, the first domesticated animals in the New World, may have been the descendents of the Chinese wolf that migrated into North America with the first people to reach this continent.

title: Silver Series Heads Field
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5  A remarkable 3yearold gray colt whose dam was sold unraced in 1970 for only $1,600 is expected to be the top choice in tomorrow afternoon's $100,000 added Monmouth Invitational Handicap.

title: HOPE FADES FOR 150 MINERS IN MOZAMBIQUE EXPLOSION
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Aug. 5 (Reuters)  Rescuers have recovered the bodies of six of about 150 coal miners buried in an underground explosion in northern Mozambique, it was reported today, and hopes were fading for finding any survivors.

title: Quandary on Gas Supply
description: TRENTON, Aug. 5New Jersey's consumers of natural gasmore than 1.5 million homes, commercial establishments and industrial plants  remained in quandary today about the future of their fuel supplies if faced with another winter as severely cold as that of last year. The consensus of state legislative investigators and representatives of natural gas suppliers appeared to be that while homeowners might be asked again to lower their thermostats in the interest of energy conservation, essential services in commerce and industry would be able to be maintained without major interruptions. But nobody seemed quite sure.

title: Belgrade Parley: Few Hopes
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5Satisfied with having at least disposed of the mountain of procedural obstacles they themselves created during the past two months, delegates of 34 nations and the Vatican have declared themselves ready

title: Radio
description: Music

title: BusyBusy Busy BusyBusy
description: LONDONLike many working wives and mothers, I often wonder how women who stay at home all day manage to fill in their time. I don't, of course, mean mothers of small children; I can remember all too well how the time used to disappear in those days, between the washing machine, the ducks in the park, the endless clearing up of endless piles of plastic toys; I can remember the constant craving for sleep, the interrupted nights, the dazed stagger to the shops in the morning.

title: U.S. Has MillionDollar Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)The Government said today that it had one million 19th century silver dollars packaged as Bicentennial mementos and wanted to sell them to the public. But there is a problem.

title: Mets
Senate Removes Restrictions on World Bank Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPi)The Senate adopted a $7.1 billion foreign aid bill today after removing a restriction that would have barred World Bank loans to Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Uganda. The Senate also restored an overall 5 percent cut imposed by the House.

title: Broadway Darkens Briefly for Lunt
description: Lights went out on marquees on Broadway theaters at 7:55 P.M. yester .day in honor of the actor Alfred Lunt, who died Wednesday at the age of 84. At that time, a group of producers, actors and friends, including Helen Hayes and Lillian Gish, gathered in front of the LuntFontanne Theater on 46th Street to pay their respects.

title: PRESIDENTS PROGRAM TO CONSERVE ENERGY WINS HOUSE PASSAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5After a week of intensive debate, the House today passed energy taxes and regulatory measures designed to reduce the nation's reliance on natural gas and imported oil, leaving President Carter's sweeping package largely intact.

title: BABCOCK PERSUADES OHIO COURT TO DELAY BID BY TECHNOLOGIES
description: In the latest skirmish of the battle to block the United Technologies Corporation from taking over Babcock & Wilcox, lawyers for Babcock succeeded yesterday in getting the Court of Common Pleas in Columbus, Ohio, to suspend a June 3 order by the Ohio Securities commissioner that permitted United to proceed with its tender offer.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Events/Sports
Vatican Says Man With Vasectomy May Enter Into a Valid Marriage
description: ROME, Aug. 5 (AP)  The Vatican declared today that men who have had vasectomies can enter valid marriages.

title: Judy Clark Wins Golf
description: METUCHEN, N. J., Aug. 5Judy Clark of Holly Hills captured the New Jersey women's amateur championship today with an 8 and 7 victory over Sybil Whitman of Mountain Ridge at the Metuchen Golf and Country Club. Mrs. Clark lost the first hole of the day to a birdie, but took command on the next hole and had a 4up lead after nine.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Ten New Jersey residents have been indicted on charges of running a $2.5millionayear gambling ring in central Jersey, Robert J. Del Tufo, the Criminal Justice Director, announced yesterday.

title: Ticket Holders Sought
description: Two holders of winning tickets that will expire within two months are being sought by the New Jersey lottery.

title: A Special Delivery On Northbound IRT
description: Rober Higgins became ill while a student at the Transit Police Academy watching a required film on how to deliver a baby.

title: ANTICASTRO NEWSPAPER IN SAN JUAN IS BOMBED
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 5A bomb early this morning damaged a weekly newspaper published by Cuban exiles steadfastly opposed to the regime of Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba.

title: Israelis Withhold Comment
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3Israel today refrained from commenting on Syria's rejection of the Vance proposal.

title: Carter Signs Military Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)President Carter today signed a $3.2 billion military foreign aid bill but expressed deep reservations over the constitutionality of provisions that permit Congress to veto presidential arms decisions.

title: Assessing Arms Sales: Four Cases
description: The prospective sale of American arms to Somalia, the Sudan, Egypt and Saudi Arabia dramatizes the United States growing involvement in the region around the Red Sea. It also raises some questions about the resolve of the Carter Administration to limit future weapons exports in general. All four of the proposed sales were justified by legitimate foreign policy concerns, but two do not seem to be in the nation's best interest. They are best considered separately.

title: LANCE IS QUESTIONED ON SECRET LOAN MEMO
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 5The Comptroller of the Currency questioned Bert Lance today about a secret memorandum that seemed to tie Mr. Lance's $2.6 million personal loan from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company to the opening of an arrangement between that bank and the National Bank of Georgia, which Mr. Lance formerly headed.

title: U.S. Panel on Helsinki Agreement Is Critical of Soviet Bloc on Rights

title: Carter's Gain At the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  After the prickly mood of confrontation with Cap; itol Hill through most of the spring, President Carter has now established a more workable giveandtake relation ship with Congress as its News members head home for the summer recess. The price of Analysis such an arrangement has been a recent willingness to accept compromises on the farm bill, water projects and domestic spending and to trim his sights on other issues. But this has produced successes that he needed and broken him out of the earlier logjam with the legislature.

title: Major Elements of HousePassed Bill on Energy Taxes and Regulations
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 5Following are the major provisions of the Carter energy package which faces Senate action after Labor Day, as approved this afternoon by the House of Representatives:

title: C'est la Vie: French Boat Just Misses
description: NEWPORT, R.L, Aug. 5Baron Marcel Bich, the 64yearold Frenchman who for seven years at considerable expense and effort has been in pursuit of the America's Cup without any success whatsoever, came close to a small reward today. The Baron's vessel, France I, held the lead against the Swedish yacht, Sverige, for all but the last half mile of a 13.5mile course, only to lose out at the end by 42 seconds.

title: Yankees
Untitled String Group Excels At the Mostly Mozart Festival
description: String quartets are made, not born, and the Mostly Mozart Festival had the makings of a firstrank one onstage at Avery Fiche.r Hall Thursday night. The four players, all artistmembers of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center or regular guests with that esteemed group, functioned without a name but with the kind of corporate finesse and interplay that one associates with longestablished string quartets of international reputation.

title: 'March or Die' Ambles Off to a Bloody Ending
description: Because he has almost nothing to say, and especially because he always seems to be winking at the camera, spaghetti-western star Terence Hill is the only truly lively figure in "March Or Die." No one else in the film's peculiarly listless all-star cast has much to say eitherbut none of these others has the good grace to keep still.Take Gene Hackman, for instance, as a Foreign Legion major who has clearly been out in the hot sun too long; Mr. Hackman is forever muttering about "the trenches," and the horrors he has seen while fighting in them. Catherine Deneuve, as a gorgeous (though slightly less gorgeous than usual) widow, likes to rattle on about amour and archeology, the latter also being a pet subject of Max Von Sydow's (he plays a scientist out on a dig). "March Or Die" is an extraordinarily wooden movie that, while ostensibly being about the futility of battle, actually has more to do with the futility of making movies about that futility.Dick Richards, who also directed "Farewell, My Lovely," has a good eye for eccentric faces and backgrounds: he comes up with a few memorable human tableaux here, as when a bunch of legionnaires stand quietly in a sepia-toned glow, listening to a pianist play "Plaisir D'Amour." Unfortunately, Mr. Richards's talents are ill-suited to his material here, and the static quality of the film's better movements only calls attention to the inadequacy of its action sequences.The story is complicated, comprising a dewy-eyed love affair between Miss Deneuve and Mr. Hill, an apparent one-nighter between Miss Deneuve and Mr. Hackman, a variety of lost souls who have come to the desert to forget their grubby pasts, a Legion assignment to protect Mr. Von Sydow as he excavates a priceless tomb, and the Arabs' indignation at these intruders and their grave-robbing. Although a few of these subplots may have a romantic ring to them, the movie's general tone is as hard-boiled as its title.Blood is shed messily and often, and many vignettes are designed to illustrate what a he-man a true legionnaire must be. One particular episode, which culminates in a weakling legionnaire's suicide after the others find out he has been impotent with a whore, is aimed strictly at the sort of filmgoer who eats carpet tacks for breakfast."March Or Die" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), and for good reason; it contains some extremely gruesome scenes of mutilation that may well bother small children.

title: Carter TellsWage Council To Study Steel Price Rises
description: WARNER ROBINS AIR FORCE BASE, Ga., Aug. 5 (AP)President Carter today ordered a Federal study of steel price increases and told the Pentagon and the Government's chief purchasing agency to make sure they buy the lowestpriced steel available.

Created after wide criticism of some activities of the Central Intelligeace Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the committee is charged with studying the operations of all Goverkunent intelligence agencies.

Manson Family, reported today that they were dedalocked but the judge ordered them to continue to try to reach a verdict. They have been deliberating almost a month since getting the case on July R. Miss Van Houten was charged with the August 1969 murders of Rosemary and Leno La Bianca the night after actress Sharton Tate and others were killed at her home.

title: IN BRIEF
description: THE NATIONAL ENERGY BILL proposed by President Carter was passed by the House after a week of intense debate. The package contains a crude oil equalization tax, a levy on industrial use of oil and natural gas, national standards for utility rates, taxation of gasguzzling can and a naturalgas pricing plan, despite intense lobbying to deregulate gas prices. The energy bill was passed the day after the Congress voted to set up a Department of Energy and confirmed James R. Schlesinger, President Carter's nominee, as Secretary of Energy.... Costly farm price supports of $2.90 for a bushel of wheat this year and $3.05 for a bushel in 1978 were approved by House and Senate conferees.

title: Psychopaths Are Harder to Find than Other Criminals
description: The largest manhunt in New York City's history has been mobilized to track the psychopathic killer known as the Son of Sam. And after nearly six months of,roundtheclock police effort, clues are still meager.

description: FIVEHUNDRED disadvantaged New York youngsters between the ages of 5 and 16 are spending two weeks across the Hudson this summer as guests in New Jersey homes. This is twice as many as last year.

title: In Love With Severity
description: TEN years ago, J. V. Cunningham described himself as a renegade Irish Catholic from the plains of Montana, upper lower class, a onetime scholar in Latin and in the English Renaissance. Twentyfive years ago, he called himself simply a Catholic bx tradition, training, and deep feeling. Further back still, he wrote a poem, Timor Dei,  to reflect upon lost beatitude and the still untranscended fear of God. I have no special information on these matters, apart from reasonable inferences culled from Cunningham's poems and essays. Evidence drawn from those sources would suggest that Cunningham rejected Catholicism because in this time it had lapsed from an original severity. Most people who abandon their Catholicism give it up because it is too hard, its morality is too strict. I suspect that this was not Cunningham's reason, but that he ceased to regard a church which no longer took seriously and strictly the Summa of Aquinas. Cunningham, a passionate man, maintains an intellectual life which is chiefly animated by the scruple attendant upon reason, mind, and truth. He loves severity of mind as other people love indulgence of body.

title: GARDENING

Robert Rutman and the four musicians who make up his U.S. SteelCello Ensemble, which performed in the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden on Friday. do not just play steel instruments, they make the cold steel characterization inescapable by performing in olivegreen Army fatigues.

The bill also provides $20.5 million in supplemental funding for the current fiscal year to cover the coat of the March 1 executive pay rise.

title: Burial for Gary Powers Tomorrow
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 (AP)Francis Gary Powers, the former U2 spy pilot, will be buried Monday with military honors in Arlington National Cemetery. Mr. Powers, 47 years old, died earlier this week in a crash of his television news helicopter. His body was reportedlyflown yesterday to Washington's Dulles Airport. Mr. Powers was the central figure in an international incident in 1960 when the U2 spy plane he was flying for the Central Intelligence Agency was shot down over the Soviet Union. He was released in 1962 in exchange for a Soviet spy, Col. Rudolf Abel.

title: TV VIEW
description: The guide at the Smithsonian Institution followed the visitor's inquiring finger. There, amid serried rows of campaign buttons, part of an exhibit on American political history, was one with the motto McKay for Senator emblazoned over what was unmistakably a picture of Robert Redford, the actor. The guide blanched in realization that a makebelieve candidate had somehow found a niche in this shrine along with Wilson. Rockefeller and Kennedy.
