title: They're Casting Light on Sun Power
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS LIKE worshipers from an earlier time, Jerry Woodall and Harry Hovel are sunstruck. The two scientists, who have been conducting solarenergy research at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center here, recently announced the development of a highly efficient solar cell, which could have an important impact on the nation's energy industries.

title: The Nation
description: There was much solemn nodding of agreement 3 months ago, when President Carter invoked the moral equivalent of war in presenting his energy program to Congress. Winning public support, and by the deadline of Congressional recess, meant steering the plan through the shoals of yawning apathy and hard opposition. Two previous Administrations had foundered; the Senate remains a serious obstacle. But last week, despite some earlier errors in political maneuvering, the energy program was adopted by the support, and by the deadline of ConHouse largely. intact. It passed, by 244 to 177, the President's package or measures to reduce consumption and created a new Department of Energy.

title: A Walk Right In Home for the Arts on Riverhead, L.I.'s, Main Street
description: RIVERHEAD, LLThe first day the East End Arts Center opened its doors on Main Street here, a youngster in shorts, his bare feet displaying the remnants of a trip to the beach, wandered in to take a look at the paintings hanging in the parlor gallery.

title: More Than a Doctor's Office
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C. Frank Gordy, his wife Ruth and their three daughters left home early one recent morning for a boating excursion on a lake near their home in Walkertown, a small community about 12 miles north of here.

title: IN AMERICA
description: ANDERSON, S. C. The sleek, silvery Thunderbird Randy Tate bought after his one season as a bigleague pitcher is depreciated now by two years and 39,000 miles but remains his most valuable possession. When he hitched it to a trailer containing the rest of his worldly goods and drove with his wife and daughter away from Lynchburg, Va., he was heading back into the world from which his erratic fast ball had lifted him  a world where a man chooses between driving a truck and working in a tire factory. At 24, the promise of his youth and strength seemed suddenly spent.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Rattling in a cab down lower Broadway during the recent New York power failure, I felt a surge of exhilaration, thanks to Adrian Berry. It was as if I were one of his interstellar astronauts hurtling through a black hole to the other side of the galaxy. Actually, we only got as far as Brooklyn Heights, with something less than the instantaneous speed that Berry's space pioneers are supposed to achieve on their daring mission to colonize other solar systems. But even if Berry's ingenious scheme turns out to be only science fiction, he has worked out a highly plausible and gripping scenario for spreading human civilization across immense distances.

title: Socialist Irrealism
description: LETS hear it for transcendentalism! That neglected strain of philosophy dealing with things above and independent of the material universe. Pavel Kohout wrote a comic novel about it, literally, in 1970. His is the ingenious tale of a genius, Adam Juracek, who not only defies Newton's law of gravity, but actually breaks it, rising at will to assorted ceilings in his native western Bohemia. His hero, a professor of drawing and physical education at the pedagogical institute in K. (probably Karlovy Vary) thus transcends the grubbing, beerswilling, backstabbing, cornercutting earthly pursuits of his fellow Czechs, attaining, for a few moments, angelic purity. This is Kohout's parable for the Prague spring of 1968with Adam Juracek as a kind of anagram for Alexander Dubcek who, in a flight of transcendentalism, proclaimed that as head of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia he would attempt to create socialism with a human face. There was something magnificently inspiring about that illfated venture, as almost any foreigner who was in Prague in those heavy days can attest. It was replete with comic touches, too.

title: Not Always Adversaries
description: THE stunning indictment of Edwin M. Schwenk, the former Suffolk County Republican chairman, on embezzlement charges has focused attention on the often loose handling of political party funds and the frequently unseemly close relations between Democratic and Republican party leaders who are supposed to be adversaries.

title: Robert E. Davis Weds Constance Canning, Senior Accountant
description: Constance Jean Canning, a senior accountant with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, was married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn., to Robert Ernest Davis, a staff analyst with the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York. The Rev. William F. Carey performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CRIME
description: We have had a lot of tough operatives in our day, but James Mitchell's Callan makes most of them, from James Bond on, look like prepschool classics teachers. Callan, who is a British intelligence agent licensed to kill, is so lethal that a glance from him makes the strongest men quail. He is the most ruthless of the ruthless, with a programmed inner intensity that transmits itself in quantum waves. He first came on the scene in 1971, when A Red File for Callan was published. At that time, as now, he had left the service, but nobody can ever really retire when the head of the section needs something particularly difficult done. One obeys. For if he doesn't, the red file is permanently closed. The alternative to duty is death.

title: MICHAEL M. SMITH
description: Michael M. Smith, an executive of the National Bank of North America who had been long active in the Department of the New York Jewish War Veterans, died Friday in Merrick, L. I. He was 58 years old.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Until this year, crosshanded putting had always been considered a last resort. But now there is a crosshandedputting craze on the tour of the Professional Golfers' Association, and it is gaining converts almost by the day. Suddenly no one is laughing at what the pros used to call the giveup grip.

By May, production at the Belarus tractor complex in Minsk was reported at 300 tractors a day. Plant officials said they had started to get letters from satisfied American customers.

title: Unpaid Army Fights for Greener Acres
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP THE typical member of a municipal environmental commission in New Jersey is someone who started out by loving trees and birds and wanting to protect them, and now wonders why his free time is spent poring over engineering manuals for sewagetreatment systems. An unpaid spokesman for the environment, he draws the ire of wouldbe landsellers, developers, proponents of highdensity housing, industrial polluters, truckers who drive through his town with dirty exhausts and homeowners who want to burn leaves. His conversation is peppered with abbreviations such as ANJEC, N.R.I., E.P.A., D.E.P. and D.O.T.

description: A small electrical fire forced Bloomingdale's to delay opening its Manhattan store for several hours yesterday.

title: Oh Hits 744th Home Run As Chunichi Giants Win
description: KAWASAKI Japan, Aug. 6 (UPI)Sadaharu Oh belted his 28th homer of the season today and gave the Yomiuri Giants a 65 victory over the Taiyo Whales. It was Oh's 744th care homer. In other Japanese baseball action, the Hanshin Tigers beat the Chunichi Dragons, 108; the Hiroshima Toyo Carp beat the Yakult swallws, 125; the defending champions, the Hankyu Braves, defeated the Kantetsu Buffaloes, 51; the Nankai Hawks defeated the Crown Lighter Lions, 92; and the Nippon Ham Fighters battled to a 55 tie with the Lotte Orions.

title: PANEL REPORTED CLEARING HATFIELD ON OREGON LOAN

title: Near East and Far West
description: IENJOYED this epic hashish dream by the author of Quin's Shanghai Circus. It is droll and moving and easy to read. Whittemore weaves into Sinai Tapestry the strange fortunes of a number of characters. Some are exiles wandering around in the Holy. Land looking for some greater Truth; others, already long inhabitants of that warwretched part of the earth, know that the Truth is infinite and confusing and senseless. Haj Harun, for one, has lived through several thousand years of history, his memory slipping as he said and the years all sliding together, pumping his arms in circles and sadly admitting he just couldn't be sure, just couldn't say, the past was too confusing. Then there's a hermit from Albania (Skander Bey, or Skanderberg Wallenstein) who discovers the real Bible in Sinai, a terrible heretical mass of contradictions told by a blind man and transcribed by an idiot (Haj Harun), and who forges the Gutenberg Bible to correct this aberration.

White walls and wood paneling, sparsely adorned with a few copper pots and a gilded wall sculpture, provide an attractively restrained setting in the Lshaped dining room. It only lacked touches of fresh flowers. There are also a few tables in the bar area.

title: GARDENING

To others, its Jack of autumn color, early leaf drop and winter coarseness are appalling when used in the Long Island landscape. Since the existence of this tree is threatened by the disease mimosa wilt, neither of these opinions carnes much relevance.
