title: LETTERS
description: Dean Robert Brustein (Can the Show Go On? July 10) has done a remarkable job of analyzing and documenting the problems threatening the survival of America's cultural life. The National Council for Arts and Education feels strongly that we have discovered in the arts and education bill, H.R. 1042, the most realistic path toward solution of these dire problems. This legislation, introduced into Congress by Representative Fred Richmond of Brooklyn, would provide space on Form 1040 to check off a voluntary, taxdeductible contribution to the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities.

title: Sverige of Sweden Outsails Gretel After Losing to Australia
description: NEWPORT, R.I, Aug. 6Several dozen seagulls riding at anchor near the first windward mark were waiting for Sverige today when she rounded it more than a minute ahead of Gretel II.

title: 913 Pages of Delight
description: EDWARD FREDERIC BENSON died in 1940 at the age of 72, having published some 80 bookslight fiction and historical biographiesnearty all of which are now out of print. He came from a highly literary family, son of an Archbishop of Canterbury and brother of A. C. Benson, the essayist and Robert Hugh Benson, who chiefly remembered for Come Rack! Come Rope!, a bloodcurdling account of Catholic martyrdom after the Reformation in England.

title: Tony Kornheiser
description: Inside a storefront on Grand Avenue in Englewood, N.J., the two best decathlon athletes in the United States work. They write exercise prescriptions and supervise workouts at the Olympic Sports Medical Training Center, a health spa for people who are more serious about health than spa. If the 1980 Olympic Games were held tomorrow, Fred Dixon and Fred Samara would contend for medals; Dixon would even be a goldmedal candidate. But tomorrow is Monday, Moscow remains three years down the road and neither Dixon nor Samara thinks he can afford the gasoline. Only an amateur athlete is eligible to become The Next Bruce Jenner, but in this country it seems that only Jenner, with his milliondollar endorsements, can afford to become amateur athlete.

title: NEW YORK TAXES FOUND TO SUBSIDIZE SKI LIFTS
description: ALBANY, Aug. 6 (AP)  New York State taxpayers are subsidizing three stateowned ski areas in the amount of nearly $1 million a year, according to an audit from the State Comptroller's office.

title: New Help for the Innocent
description: The New York State Crime Victims Compensation Board has announced its first payments to victims and next of kin of the psychopathic killer who calls himself the Son of Sam. Total payments to the father of Christine Freund, killed Jan. 30, will reach the $20,000 maximum available for personal injury suffered by an innocent victim of violent crime. The board may disburse $6 million in the present fiscal year; since its inception in 1966. it has paid approximatelv $20 million.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Do you recall that silly party gameor more accurately magazine game, for it was the sort of game that only really appealed to journalistsof who's in and who's out? I suppose it satisfied some brute snob instinct most of us hide under the thin skin of our better natures, and also appealed to some concept, almost ethical concept, of change and movement. A change in status, however illusory, represented a world alive, and this at least could awaken our interest. In the same manner we study the fortune of ball clubs and their moves up and down the ranking tables of fortune, and watch out for champion riders or motorists, all in the sacred name of sport, but possibly more simply, and more honestly, in search of nothing but change.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IN the window of Equanimity, in Mount Kisco, the glamorous softsculptured figure of a woman redines languidly in a basket suspended from the ceiling. The rungs of a white pine ladder nearby hold a calico tea cozy shaped like a fat cat, an eggshellblue china teapot, madras napkins, a stuffed woolly lamb and other samples of the tempting things for sale in this brightly decorated shop.

title: Article 10  No Title
Radio to Plumb Cause Of British Backaches
description: LONDON, Aug. 6 (Reuters)TWO hundred volunteers from Britain's Post Office are being asked to swallow a tiny radio transmitter to help find out what causes backache.

title: Catherine Comerford Married to Peter Smyth
description: Catherine M. Comerford, who is in the book division of Time Inc., was married yesterday morning to Peter H. Smyth, a financial analyst with the Nestl Company in White Plains. The Rev. John Ryan performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Osterville, Mass.

title: The Region
description: Social dynamite is the term favored by sociologists to describe the high rate of unemployment among teenagers who are black or members of other minorities. Just how explosive the matter is became dearer last week with a new kind of Labor Department analysis showing that in 1976 out of 100 minority teenagers in New York City, 86 had no jobs. White teenagers were slightly better off. Out of 100 in that category, 74 had no jobs.

title: Dr. Howard I. Diamond, 50, Obstetrician and Gynecologist
description: Dr. Howard I. Diamond, an obstetrician and gynecologist from Great Neck, L.I., died yesterday morning of cancer. He was 50 years old.

title: Pending Sale of Notes Holds Potential of Gain for Beame
description: The offering of New York City bonds and notes used to be a prosaic enterprise whereby the City Comptroller pulled bids out of a green tin box in his office. The fiscal crisis, changed things in 1975 when fears of bankruptcy closed the city off from the regular borowing marketplace  the amorphous world where private investors make the not alwaysrational decisions about what is a safe security for their money.

title: CARTER IS CONFIDENT ON LANCE'S FINANCES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  President Carter told a news conference in Plains, Ga., today that he had full confidence that Bert Lance, his budget director, and John Heimann, the Comptroller of the Currency, would handle properly an inquiry into Mr. Lance's finances.

title: Highlights of the President's Plan
description: Following are the highlights of President Carter's plan to revise the nation's welfare system:

title: Article 6  No Title
More Tourists From Eastern European Nations Are Allowed to Leave Home for the West
description: INNSBRUCK, AustriaThe novelty on the highways of Western Europe this summer is the quantity of motorists from Hungary and Czechoslovakia. There are a few hitchhikers with Communist passports, too.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MOST home maintenance tasks that involve using a step ladder around the inside or outside of the house also frequently call for the use of various tools, painting equipment or other materials.

title: Yokum Hokum
description: ELMSFORD THE ASSUMPTION has always been that people do not want to think in the summer. They want their reading, their movies, and their theater on the light sidein other words, the arts are supposed to come fully airconditioned. And that may explain the revival of the 1956 musical Li'I Abner at An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford. Unfortunately, the lightness was not of the sort that made you forget the heat: it merely added boredom.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: Audit Finds New York City Got Only 22% of $502 Million Parking Fines
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt has estimated that New York City's Parking Violations Bureau has collected only about 22 percent of the $502 million in Outstanding fines and penalties for the six years ending July 1976.

title: Article 2  No Title
MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: As Wall Street peers ahead at what remains of a simmering summer, some stock market analysts pin their hopes on this rationale: What goes down must come up.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: When consideration is given to the recent array of unsettling economic statistics, it becomes quite difficult for even the most rabid optimists to remain highly confident about fairly strong growth in the months immediately ahead. There is, however, one major comforting factor, the belief that much of the current data, whether negative or positive, may be somewhat misleading because of faulty seasonal adjustments or other problems.

title: BOOKS
description: This is the story of an institution. It is, in fact, the second installment in the official life of the International Monetary Fund. The first, comprising three volumes published in 1969, took us through the first two decades of the Fund's career.

title: DINING OUT
description: THIS big, open, casual restaurant is an Atlantic City landmark. It is perched on a whitewashed pier that accommodates not only a restaurant, but also fishing and sightseeing boats, a separate clam and oyster bar and a retail seafood shop.

title: Parks Apply Woman Power
description: SOMEONE viewing at the scene might have been reminded of an old Katharine Hepburn film. The blueeyed, auburnhaired young woman in this case was wearing a pair of denim overalls and a shortsleeved Tshirt, but the vocal inflections, the fillylike toss of the head, the sense of assurance and independence were the same.

title: KORCHNOI DRAWS AND WINS CHESS WITH POLUGAYEVSKY
description: EVIAN, France, Aug. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)Viktor Korchnoi, a Soviet expatriate won his world chess challenger semifinal match against Lev Polugayevsky of the Soviet Union today by drawing the 13th of their 16game series. Korchnoi had 8 points to 4 for Polugavevsky.

title: Growing Controversy, Surrounds Who Gets $40 Billion and for What
description: WASHINGTONFounded in the closing days of World War II to accelerate the reconstruction of Europe, the World Bank has become the largest source of technological and financial assistance to the developing nations. Slowly, though perhaps with less lethargy than other bureaucracies, the bank has tried to adapt to the changing needs of these countries. Its lending plans, including one to establish a special fund to aid countries with balance of payments difficulties that was discussed at a meeting in Paris this weekend attended by Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal and other finance ministers, have brought it into conflict with Administrations in Washington in the past, and, most recently, with Congress.

title: Does America Measure Up?
description: WE who are English expatriates in the United States naturally and enevitably spend our time measuring Up the British world we've left against the American world we've come to. Even when we're not aware of it, this I suppose is what we are doing every hour and minute of our waking lives, and so to us this is a topic of absorbing interest. I see no reason why this collection of essays on the theme by Martin Green should be equally interesting to the American, or for that matter to the British, reader. It is all pretty much an expatriate ingroup game, and one that Green has played over the years with great power and verve if not always with finesse.

title: A Confusion of Banalities
description: PARIS  Most people know what human rights and racism mean but it is exceedingly difficult to apply the generality of such knowledge to the specific of its political application. This lacuna produces misinterpretations when statesmen seek to put their own philosophical credos into practice.

title: Text of White House Message to Congress on Proposal to Overhaul Welfare System
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  Following is the text of President Carter's welfare message to Congress:

title: Red Tape
description: VLADIMIR VOINOVICH is the most refreshing news from the Russian literary scene (official or dissident) in many years: the first genuine comic writer entirely produced by the Soviet system. And it is about time. For if, as Robert Tucker first remarked, Russia with Stalin's death moved from 1984 to 1884i.e., from a totalitarian nightmare to a more traditional authoritarian orderit was inevitable that, sooner or later, preoccupation with historic traumas would recede and some irreverent young person would address the question of the empire's new clothes.

title: At Home With The Coast Guard
description: EATONS NECK THE Coast Guard station here changed commanding officers late last month, butmany Long Islanders are treating the departure of the old commander more as the moving away of a good neighbor than as a typical bureaucratic shift.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Sweet dreams. What does a woman want? Sigmund Freud once demanded, with some exasperation. He might have found an answer on this week's paperback best seller list, where half the titles offer romance designed for the feminine trade. Oldtimers cannot remember a period to match this summer for the number of such novels, the most popular of which are set in the past, particularly the 18th and early 19th centuries.

title: Food
description: We think a lot about the changing eating and drinking habits of people, mostly Americans. In a way, it could be said that the public has moved into the ice age within the past quartercentury. Before the Second World War, cocktails on the rocks were all but unknown, if not unthinkable. Asa matter of fact, we doubt that the phrase on the rocks had even been coined. Of course, drinks were taken with ice Scotch and soda, Scotch and water and so on, but martinis, oldfashioneds, manhattans and other mixed drinks were almost never nursed over ice. The same is true of soups. Prior to that same war, soups were almost never chilled. Gazpacho probably existed in Spain, but was practically unknown on this continent. The first cold soup to become popular in this country, of course, was Louis Diat's creation, vichyssoise. Happily, the public now knows well the joy of these chilled first courses, a few of which are set forth here.

title: ART VIEW
description: The first thing to be said about Paris's new Centre National d'Art et de Culture Georges Pompidou (Beaubourg to most people) is that in terms of public response it could hardly be a greater success. During its first four months it drew over two million people. On Sundays up to 90,000 of, them came teeming in until the line stretched right across the shelving piazza which is one of the few new open spaces to have been programmed in central Paris during the 20th century. Not only that piazza but the whole neighborhooda square mile in allhas been reanimated by the Centre Pornpidou.

title: Tour Earnings
description: P.G.A. GOLF

title: The Standings
description: Sunday, August 7, 1977

title: Pepper Fete Hears 3 Bands
description: Friday evening's show at the Dr. Pepper Music Festival in Central Park was a full one, with two singersongwriters and their bands and a third band from .Austin, Tex. It was also one of the better shows of the season, and perhaps the best. The shorter set times goaded at least two of the three groups into giving tight, succinct performances, something the festival's other shows have been notably short on.

title: Base Stealer: What He Needs Is Arrogance
description: When Lou Brock, Ty Cobb or Maury Wills stole a base, it was like taking the clothes off the pitcher. The catcher got embarrassed, too, not to mention the fellow trying to make the tag.

title: Lefkowitz Goes to Court to Force Compliance With CarRepair Law
description: The first court action to force an automobile repair shop either to register with the state or to stop doing business has been started by New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Ozark Air Lines Strike Averted
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP)Mechanics and technicians at Ozark Air Lines have voted to accept a new 32month contract, averting a strike that could have begun as early as Monday. John Miller, spokesman for Airline Mechanics Fraternal Association Local 24 in St. Louis, said yesterday that the contract had been approved by a close vote despite recommendations by union leaders that it be rejected.

title: The World
description: Ethiopian rebels, who toppled Emperor Haile Selassie three years ago had their reasons, but at least the venerable Lion of Judah had managed to keep the country in one piece. Last week, it seemed to be coming apart, although the remoteness of the region made it difficult to determine exactly how quickly.

title: New Patterns, New Victims
description: It was small comfort, but because for a year the .44caliber shootings have followed a pattern, most New Yorkers assumed they were safe from attack. Last week, the pattern was disrupted, and throughout the city and its nearby suburbs, frightened young people, particularly women, changed their hairstyles, took new routes home, cancelled dates all to reduce the odds they might be the next target.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Farewell to the Amateur
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph appearing on page 3 of today's Arts and Leisure section announcing the reopening of Andrei Serban's Agamemnon on Wednesda at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park incorrectly shows Priscilla Smith as Clytemnestra. The part is being played by Gloria Foster.

title: Golf
description: AT WETHERSFIELD, CONN.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: Copyright 1977 by Dally Racing Form, Inc.

title: OFFICER SHOT BY OWN GUN IN TUSSLE AT BUS STATION
description: A police sergeant for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was shot with his own service revolver yesterday as he struggled with a robbery suspect on an almost deserted platform in the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 41st Steret and Eight Avenue

title: Zoning Wall Is Breachable
description: SOMETHING unexpected happened recently in Orange County that could eventually put the brakes on the mad dash to parochialism in suburbia. And the surprise development in zoning could have farreaching effects in a number of Westchester communities whose established provincialism has made them the target of opponents of the practice.

title: Wine
description: St. Emilion: Warm, Open and Easy to Like

title: Cocker Spaniel Stars in California
description: A black cocker spaniel from Georgia sparkled brightest in a field of 4,254 dogs at Santa Barbara, site of the nation's biggest show, and a miniature wire dachshund defeated more than 6,500 dogs in three shows on the Carolina circuit last Sunday. The sporting allbreed winner is Ch. LizBar Magic of Music and the hound is Ch. Spartan's Sloe Gin Fizz MW, the little guy that just keeps chalking up one victory after another.

title: Headliners
description: Governor Carey's chief aide, David W. Burke, has resigned to become a vice president with ABC television news.. Mr. Burke. was the Governor's chief of .staff and was considered the second most powerful man in the Carey administration. The resignation set off intermural feuding among Carey staff members and advisers over who would succeed Mr. Burke, with Robert Morgadothe state operations director, winning the post despite vehement objections. by Mr. Carey's chief counsel; Judah Gribetz.

title: Shaw Conducts Choral Music
description: Choral music was on the agenda for the Mostly Mozart concert Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall, and with Robert Shaw in charge of the vocal and instrumental forces, superior performances were virtually a foregone conclusion. Mr. Shaw has long been one of the country's leading choral maestros as well as an orchestral conductor of proven talents.

title: Dance: May O'Donnell Troupe at Clark Festival
Speaking for the Public
description: In 1976, the eleven major American airlines spent $2.8 million for outside counsel to represent airline interests in regulatory proceedings before the Civil Aeronautics Board. That same year, public, interest organizations spent the grand sum of $20,000 on representation at C.A.B. proceedings.

title: CRITICISM DEFLECTED BY WHITE HOUSE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6President Carter's astminute decision to add $6.2 billion to his plan to revise the welfare system appeared today to have deflected much of the anticipated criticism. Initial reaction was much more favorable than might have been expected on the basis of the original version of the plan.

title: Maryland's Buried Treasure
description: Each year about this time I take off for southern Maryland in search of burled treasure.

title: The Many Studies About the United States Intelligence Apparatus End the Same Way: Reform Is Needed
description: WASHINGTON When Senate and House Committees completed their investigations of the operations of the intelligence community last year, several conclusions stood out:

title: Another Small Step for Man:
description: They were two days out of cape Canaveral, out on another 3R patrol. That's what the astronauts called the kind of flights that were becoming an increasingly routine part of their trade. now that space was hardly the highwire act it used to be. Release a satellite here, retrieve an old one there, and maybe repair a wornout satellite somewhere else. These were the three R's, the basics, for a crew hauling the orbital freight.

title: STAMPS
description: Anew series of stamps, Black Heritage USA, which commemorates the contributions of American negroes to the growth and development of the nation, will be issued by the United States Postal Service, starting next year and continuing into subsequent years.

title: Orantes, Alexander Gain Final.
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 6 (AP) Harold Solomon, worn out by his victory yesterday over Jimmy Connors, was beaten, 64, 61, today by John Alexander of Australia in the semifinals of the $125,000 Volvo International tennis tournament.

title: 44 Boats Sail Out of the Past
description: MYSTIC THE language coming from the engine room of Old Timer II was briny. That's Mr. Reid, the owner, explained First Mate Sandra Shepard at last weekend'ss second annual antique and classic boat rendezvous at Mystic Seaport. Engine won't start. I don't think we'll be in the parade.

title: IRVING KREVITT
description: Irving Krevitt, the golf coach at Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn, died in Portland, Me., last Thursday after having been hit by an automobile while on vacation. He was 57 years old and lived in Brooklyn. His team won the public schools title, last spring. He taught industrial arts. He is survived by his wife, Joan; a son, John; a daughter, Beth Eres; three sisters; Essie Goldstein, Syde Liebling and Rose Minsky, and two grandchildren.

title: FOOD
description: OLD BROOKVILLE THERE is a big corn field in the midst of the immaculate lawns, manicured gardens, golf courses and horse pastures of Old Brookville. The corn and other crops grown on the 90 acres belong to Youngs Farm and are sold at the farm stand on Hegeman's Lane. Youngs Farm is one of the last surviving farms in Nassau County and the only one with a farm stand on the premises open most of the year.

title: Kratzert Takes 2Shot Lead Over Elder on 64 for 196
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 6For a man who had to try, try and try again before qualifying for the professional golf tourand quit the game Once because of his frustration in the processBill Kratzert found himself in a most. unaccustomed position today after the third round of the $210,000 Greater Hartford open.

title: Andrea Smith Wed on Coast
description: In All Saints Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills, Calif., yesterday afternoon Andrea Patricia Smith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. Russell Smith of Los Angeles, became the bride of Jonathan Knapp Sprole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Sprole of Darien, Conn.

title: Shaky Start
description: AMMAN, JordanBefore he left Washington on his Middle East mission, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was asked if he expected to know definitely at the end whether the Geneva peace conference could be convenedas he had hopedby the end of the year.

title: Bronx Man, 21, Shot Dead
description: A 21yearold man from the Bronx was shot to death yesterday at 4:45 P.M. in the hallway of an apartment building at 18 Morningside Avenue in Morningside Heights, the police said. The victim was, identified as Lincoln Burges of 1711 Davidson Avenue. A spokesman for the police said two suspects who were not identified, were seized Its an auto at 155th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue by officers who were supplied with a description of the killers.

title: Tennis
description: AT GLEN COVE, L.I.

title: Beame Says Plan Would Let City Hire More Policemen and Firemen
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that the $173 million additional a year that New York City was expected to receive in Federal revenues, under President Carter's proposed welfare program would enable it to hire more police officers and firemen, to provide more in other municipal services and, hopefully, to roll back taxes.

title: Young, in Jamaica, Says He Is Symbol of Racial Progress in U.S.
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 6Andrew Young, here on a mission for President Carter, told a group of American Peace Corps members that his own appointment as chief delegate to the United Nations attested to the genuine progress in race relations in the United States.

title: On Top of it All, More Bombings
description: It has been a trying summer for New York City, one of a long blackout and widespread looting, of uncontrolled arson and psychopathic shootings. The city's malaise deepened last week when bombs planted by a selfstyled Puerto Rican nationalist group, the F.A.L.N., exploded in two Manhattan office buildings, killing a man and injuring seven other persons. Puerto Rican nationalist group, the F.A.L.N., exploded in two Manhattan office buildings, killing a man and injuring seven other persons.

title: Editors' Choice
description: AMEN,by Yehuda Amichai $7.95. Translated 34.95) author by Israel's known living poet on war, death, sensuality, love; a harshly lovely, exhilarating, saddening book.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE OCEAN SEA GRILL offers a delicacy found too seldom in Connecticut restaurantsgood, fresh, crisp and, in this case, homemade bread. It is hard to understand why so many restaurants, including some that apply high standards to the food they serve, seem oblivious to the stale, soggy, tasteless or just plain undistinguished bread that introduces the meal. Surely first impressions do count: witness our delight at the Ocean Sea Grill when we tried their crisp, thincrusted Italiantype rolls. And, though we had to wait a while for seconds, it was worth it, for they came warm from the oven and still fresher.

title: C.I.A. Mind. Probes Now More Benign
description: WASHINGTON  There seemed to be nothing the Central Intelligence Agency had not considered: Lobotomies, powerful drugs, hypnosis, mental telepathy, deprivation of sleep and food, subliminal suggestion, isolation, ultrasonic sound, flashing stroboscopic lights. The agency even consulted magicians and Interviewed prostitutes.

title: Bergen to Widen Aid
description: ROCKLEIGH NEW JERSEY'S first countyrun residential treatment center for troubled children is preparing to admit its first group of girls. The Bergen County Residential Center, which is little more than six months old, now has a population of 23 boys, 13 to 17 years old; plans call for 24 girls in the full complement of 66 places by sometime next year.

title: 1,800 Peruvian Unionists Dismissed
description: LIMA, Aug 6 (Reuters)Some 1,800 union officials in Peru have been dismissed for their part in a general strike last month against the country's austerity program, Interior Minister Luis Cisneros said yesterday. Meanwhile a strike by 2,000 workers at the United Statesowned copper mine at Toquepala, southern Peru, went into its third day in protest against the dismissal of 31 other union officials who had taken part in the general strike. Strikes are banned under the state of emergency in force in Peru.

title: Decline New York State's Population Means Loss of $1.7 Million More From Federal Government
description: New York State is losing $1.7 million more in Federal grants for social services in the program year starting Oct. 1, based on its continued declining percentage of the nation's, population.

title: CONGRESS AGAIN ACTS TO BOLSTER FARMERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 6With huge grain surpluses accumulating and farm income declining, it was again time for the Government to come to the aid of the farmers, and Congress did so this week.

title: Sir Alexander Bustamante, Jamaican Leader, Is Dead
description: Sir Alexander Bustamante, hero of Jamaica's struggle for sovereignty and the Caribbean island's first prime minister when it became independent, died yesterday at the age of 93, after a long illness.

title: Article 14  No Title
A New Light for Big Ben
description: LONDON, Aug. 6 (Reuters)Big Ben, the London clock tower, is to be illuminated by a laser beam to add a bit of color to the London scene, the Department of the Environment says. The beam, provided free by a private company, will produce a green glow around the pinnacle of the tower.

title: BRIDGE
description: Suppose that an inexperienced player sat down to kibitz in a major tournament, knowing nobody. How could he tell whether the player he has chosen to watch is a great player or merely a good one? One clue could be found by studying the defense: The good player strives to keep his honors adequately guarded at all times, while the expert will occasionally see the need to bare a king or to reduce Q xx to a doubleton.

title: Turkey Bars Recognition of Greek As the President of All of Cyprus
description: ISTANBUL, Aug 6 (Reuters)Turke will not recognize Archbishop Makarios successor as president of the whole of Cyprus, according to Foreign Minister Ihsan Sabri Caglayangil.

title: U.S. WITHDRAWAL PLAN PUZZLES SOUTH KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 3A policeman flags down Americans' cars near Seoul now, scurries over and sternly lectures them on the perils of the scheduled American troop withdrawal. Writers and poets and dissidents tell Americans that President Carter's policy leaves them nervous and confused.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Robert J. Ringer
description: With titles like Winning Through Intimidation and Looking Out for #1 to his credit, Robert J. Ringer promises to be a real stinker. True, the book jacket photo shows a fairly likeablelooking sportive youngster, but then Nero was probably a lovely baby, too.

title: CARTER ASKS NEW WELFARE SYSTEM WITH EMPHASIS ON REQUIRED WORK; NEW YORK COULD SAVE $527 MILLION
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 6President Carter disclosed today a comprehensive blueprint for restructuring the nation's welfare system. Among other things, it could eventually save New York State and City $527 million a year in relief payments.

title: Balloons Protest Nuclear Plants
description: Antinuclear demonstrators set loose thousands of multicolored helium balloons across the nation today on the 32nd anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima.

title: EUROPE'S (ALMOST) UPBEAT VIEW OF AMERICA
description: PARIS. After the long, impatient wait of the campaign period, then the sudden and irritating discovery that the United States had imposed an unknown new leader on the unconsulted world, then the nervous examination of straws and other auguries to decipher the meaning of change, Europe is settling down now with some relief and satisfaction to a new and yet nostalgically familiar image of America.

title: Weddings
description: SokolAbramowitz

title: Gail Ellen Gimbel Is Married
description: Gail Ellen Gimbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hy Gimbel of Roslyn Heights, L. I., was married there last evening to Ronald David Steiger, grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Max Robins of Merrick, L. I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Roslyn Country Club.

title: Football Reaps $82.5 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)Radio and television stations and networks will pay $82.5 million for rights to collegiate and professional football games this year, about $1 million more than in 1976, Broadcasting Magazine has reported.

title: 12 Women Are Selected For Directing Workshop
description: Twelve women in television and films have been selected by the American Film Institute Center for Advanced Studies to take part in the institute's 197778 Directing Workshop for Women. Participating in the workshop, which will begin later this month in Beverly Hills, are the actresses Joanne Woodward, Cicely Tyson, Marsha Mason Simon and Nan Martin, as well as Caryl Ledner, writer; Eva Brandstein, casting head; Daisy Gerber, assistant director: Ann S. Hayward, assistant producer; Maysie Hoy, assistant editor; Brianne Murphy, cinematographer; Susan Racho, producer, and Sandra Weintraub, program executive.

title: Jury Duty: Is It a Privilege?
description: JOHN P. RICHERT's interesting article on jury duty (June 19) makes me wonder whether he has ever had the privilege of serving. As a threetime petit juror in Monmouth County, my own (purely, subjective) observations are at odds with Mr. Richert's studies.

title: Nan McRee Married To T.N. Williams Jr.
description: Annie Belle Sackett McRee, a research assistant at the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Nelson Williams Jr., a processdesign engineer with the Mobil Chemical Corporation. in Edison, N.J.

title: State Is Hopeful On Welfare Reform
description: TRENTON ABOUT 16,000 New Jersey families would lose Federal food stamps under a proposed revision of the program being debated in Congress. However, according to state welfare officials, the overall effect on New Jersey's one million poor residents should prove beneficial.

title: Red Smith
description: Because professional football has a college draft and had a regulation called the Rozelle rule, about 3,000 players who have been active since 1972 are cutting up $16 million in conscience payments from their employers. News that club owners have a conscience will come as a surprise to fans who buy tickets at today's prices and the truth is the sinners, though full of remorse, did of not lay out the reparations voluntarily. They were bailing out of damage suits.

title: Roosevelt
description: (OTB payoffs sublect to 5% Municipal surtax.)

title: Of Summers Too Hot, Too Cold, Too Wet
description: JUDGING by my years of studying Westchester's weather history, not all of our summers are sweetness and sunlightas the recent prolonged weat wave and consequent blackout demonstrate. If we de fine summer as the warmest 90 days of the year, then our summer begins in the second week of June and ends after the first week of September. These 90 days have provided some outright miserable weather.

title: Construction Jobs Increase by 6,200
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S lagging construction industry, which has been in a severe slump since 1973, is showing some signs of making a recovery, according to officials of the state's Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Home To Bridgeport
description: A DEATH in the family is a terrifying experience that time softens only when time is good and ready. And in looking for meaning in such a death, one can find oneself closer to the things one loves, and has tended to overlook.

title: The Decline and Rise of Wooster Square
description: NEW HAVEN TO THE CASUAL visitor, on the prowl for food after a night at Long Wharf or the Yale Art Museum, Wooster Square is a pleasant green one block from Wooster Street and the home of legendary postperformance pizzas made at Pepe's, the Spot and Sally's.

title: GARDENING
description: ALTHOUGH New Jersey gardeners may give over a small shady area to our many dainty springblooming wild flowers, the larger summerand fallblooming natives are seldom cultivated. This seems a pity, since gardens can be varied most attractively by the imaginative use of some of our commonest wayside flowers.

title: Sandra Kezer Wed To Joseph Dempsey In Jersey Ceremony
description: Sandra Adams Kezer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Kezer of Shrewsbury, N.J., was married there yesterday to Joseph Matthew Dempsey son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. J Dempsey of Malden, Mass.

title: Squalls Over Carter's Maritime Stand
description: Considering the $40 a year it would cost the average American family for higher gas and heatingoil bills to raise the percentage of oil imports carried in American tankers to 9.5 percent by 1982 from 3.5 percent at present, Republican leaders on Capitol Hill have found a juicy political issue in their charge that President Carter is backing the proposal to pay off a campaign debt.

title: How Benefit Programs Would Work
Europe's Trains, Inside and OutA Taster's Choice
description: In 1944 I was a second lieutenant in the Air Force, and our outfit had just disembarked in Naples. We were put on a decrepit Italian trainlong wooden benches, side doors and outside running boardsfor a 20mile journey to a staging area. By then the Luftwaffe had been chased from the southern Italian skies, but as the train crept along, stopping now and then just long enough for some of our young lions to get off and raid nearby fruit trees and vineyards, we were sure every overhead engine had to be Jerry.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IN winter we hunger for summer; in August many yearn for autumn. So it may now be a pleasant pastime to shop for suede and leather garments for the fall. And Patchwork by Miles, a custom shop in Manhasset's Miracle Mile, is an ideal place for browsing or buying.

title: Talks Resume Over Who Should Control the Vote in SouthWest Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG In John Vorster's rogues' gallery, there is no one so disdained as Sam Nujoma, leader of the SouthWest Africa People's Organization. I have nothing to say to Mr. Nujoma, the South African Prime Minister says, in the dulled tones he employs when speaking to those who challenge him. As for Mr. Nujoma's organization, Mr. Vorster contends that it was conceived In Communistic sin for the purpose of subordinating SouthWest Africa to the Soviet Union.

title: We Can All Learn From Our Mistakes
description: ALL photographers make mistakes, but the ones who improve their skills are those who have learned to profit by those mistakes. And the way to profit by them is not with sighs, lamentations and loud wailing but with an awareness of cause and effect, diagnosis and cure. Here are some of the most common errors and mistakes that affect us all at one time or another, and what we can do about them.

title: Powerboat Race to Satullo
description: CEDAR POINT, Ohio, Aug. 6 (UPI) Sandy Satullo of Fairview Park won the third running of the Stroh's Grand National offshore powerboat race today for the second straight year. Satullo averaged 79.8 miles an hour in Kopper Kettle over the 187mile course. and finished 45 seconds in front of Natural Light with Joey Ippolitto of Lakeland, Fla., at the wheel.

title: ART
description: HUNTINGTON ONE of the masterpieces of pictorial satire is George Grosz's The Eclipse of the Sun, and the painting, which belongs to the Heckscher Museum here, is the keystone of a magnificent retrospective at the Heckscher devoted to the artist. A very large canvas painted in 1926, the work is the summation of Grosz's primary creative spirit: his extraordinary ability to ridicule power, to flout ego, to devastate corruption, to use a palette in a composition to demonstrate his disgust for the bleaker, sadder aspects of the human condition.

title: Head of Painters Union Finds Local in New York Is Guilty of Financial Mismanagemegt
description: The head of the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades, following an extended investigation and 15 days of hearings, has found a painter's local of the union in New York guilty of financial mismanagement, failure to enforce trade agreements, and undemocratic procedures.

title: Fight Erupts As Diplomats Beat Cosmos
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Cosmos lost their last game of the regular season to the Washington Diplomats, 21 at R.F.K. Stadium tonight, but Pele's last appearance in the nation's capital will not be forgotten.

title: Inquiry Set on Roundabout Rail Service
description: WASHINGTON IF you live in Stamford or New Haven and you are driving to Florida or Texas for your vacation, it's not likely that you would go by way of Springfield, Mass. Yet Springfield is the gateway to and from the South and West for Connecticut's rail freight, which is vital to the state's economy.

title: ART
description: MORRISTOWN THE titles of Ray G. Ellis's watercolors at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences have something of the soft and seductive magic of his paintings. Simple and straightforward, North Point Light, Late Shadow, Rolling In, Cove Fire, Homeward Hunter, Caught Dozin'  and Polo at Honeyhorn are names that describe the artist's sense of place and his devotion to nature in all of its poetic manifestations.

title: Challis, Challis Everywhere!
description: Challis, that Old World country cloth once synonymous with grannies' shawls and peasants' dancing skirts, has suddenly become this season's candidate for fashion revival.

title: Immigration Service Is Reported Tardy In Checking Nazis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)The Immigration and Naturalization Service made mostly perfunctory checks of alleged Nazi war criminals living in the United States until Congress took an interest in the issue, a House Judiciary subcommittee has been told.

title: Secession Wars Push Ethiopia to the Brink
description: LONDONThe two most serious wars being fought in the world today are going on in Ethiopia. In the northern province of Eritrea, secessionist guerrillas are bringing a 15year conflict to a climax; while in the southeast guerrillas backed by Somalia (or, as Ethiopia insists regular Somali forces) are pressing at the fringe of the Ethiopian heartland.

title: The Arts on Main Street
description: RIVERHEAD THE first day the East End Arts Center opened its doors on Main Street here, a youngster in shorts, his bare feet displaying the remnants of a trip to the beach, wandered in to take a look at the paintings hanging in the parlor gallery.

title: Shovels Still Needed, But Computers Now Help Out
description: LOS ANGELESLast Monday, United States Forest Service technicians in Boise, Idaho, became concerned about a warning a computer had just issued: based on emerging weather patterns, the computer said, there was a high risk of serious lightningcaused fires within 24 hours in certain areas of dry northern California.

title: Yankees' Records
description: BATTING

title: Panel on Lilco APlant, and a Diffusion of Related Issues, Nears End
description: BABYLON, L.I.The hearings are nearly over, after almost three years, and by late next spring the Long Island Lighting Company will probably know whether it may begin building two 1,150,000kilowatt nuclear generators at Jamesport, at an estimated cost of $2.7 billion.

title: Man Once Marked for Murder Is Slain on a California Highway
description: CHUIA VISTA, Calif., Aug. 6 (UPI)A man whose wife had been imprisoned for trying to hire someone to kill him was shot to death yesterday as he rode his motorcycle on Interstate 5.

title: It's Ham, It's Salami, It's Pastrami, It's a Turkey
description: The invitation to lunch from the National Turkey Federation, an association of turkey growers, asked the question, Can the meat from the noble turkey justify the use of such terms as ham, pastrami, bologna and hot dog?

title: Courville, Ferrell in Met Final
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 6Every Jerry Courville enters a golf tournament these days, many persons expect him to fail short of victory when fatigue gets to him. He just is not expected to win the way he used to.

title: Jetliner Lands After Engine Blast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (AP)A 707 jetliner of American Airlines made it safely back to San Francisco International Airport yesterday after one of its four engines exploded in flight minutes after the plane took off, the airline reported. None of the 51 passengers aboard Flight 248. to Chicago were injured. There was no fire and three remaining engines had sufficient power to bring the plane back down, an airline spokesman said.

title: M.A.C. PLANS TO OFFER $100 BONDS FOR SALE
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation plans to offer $100 miniM.A.C. bonds to the public next month, one of the smallest denominations of taxfree municipals ever put on the market.

title: Yes, Rock Band, Affirms Fusion
description: Yes, the British rock quintet that gave the first of three soldout performances Friday night at Madison Square Garden, deals in a kind of rock toward which this listener is normally indifferent or even antipathetic. That is the fantasyladen, overbusy, semijazzish sort of artsy progressive rock that was especially popular in Britain in the early 1970's, when Yes first became massively successful.

title: Before and After Statehood
description: Surely there is a sense of omen in today's unending, indeed expanding fascination with the story of the Jews. In this world of unbelief and terror, under our increasing fear of manipulation by conspiracies, we perhaps hope for some hint to humankind through the heightened experience of that very people whose patriarchs and prophets offer us contact with the divine. Thus an enormous literature of the Jewish experience continues to grow.

title: Letters: On New York's Mayoral Primary
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Doing in BUDAPEST
description: QUEEN OF THE DANUBEIn recent years Budapest became popular with American travelers because it was inexpensive and because the visitor from the west could get a whiff of a Communist system without having to forgo completely the comforts of capitalism. During the last year or so, the cost of living has gone up for Hungarians and, so far as hotel rates and prices in better restaurants are concerned, even more for tourists. But the atmosphere of what Khrushchev called goulash communism lingers. Soviet officials rejoice when they get an assignment to Budapest. Polish and Czech travelers, mostly in big groups, irk their Hungarian hosts by buying as much salami as they can get to take home. Eastbloc cynics call Hungary the merriest barracks in the Soviet camp, an epithet particularly true of Budapest. United States visitorsincluding those of Hungarian descent who left in the tragic days of the 1956 uprisingand their dollars are made welcome. More than 20 years after the antiCommunist rebellion that Soviet tanks crushed, the inhabitants of Budapest appear to have adjusted, some sullenly, some pragmatically, to a situation they know they can't change. Although the secret police are still around, they seem to avoid bothering people unnecessarily. With a population exceeding two million and growing, the Queen of the Danube has a mottled face: crumbling 80yearold apartment houses with crumbling wooden corsets beside entrances to a gleaming new subway and lavish marble underpasses.

title: Article 16  No Title
Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: EAST BRUNSWICK MY affair with the Jersey Shorea lovehate relationship at bestis over. It's August and. for the first time in a decade, our children, who are 18 to 21 years old, have scoffed at an August vacation in Point Pleasant. As the saying goes, my husband and I have been sprung.

title: Asking the audience to play along tends to contradict the moral lesson.
description: moment, we are that society. And here we are, obediently joining the singalong.

title: Card of Thanks
description: FUTTERMANMoe. The Futterman famlly sincerely thank their friends and relatives for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: American League
description: Seattle 9, New York 2 (n.).

title: Nearly on Time Wins Whitney As Forego Trails 7Horse Field
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 Mighty Forego was buried in the mud of Saratoga today.

title: MEXICAN POLITICIANS FIGHTING FOR POWER
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5Behind the calm facade of Mexico's longlived political system, a bitter struggle for power and influence has erupted between the interest groups surrounding the country's new President, Jos Lpez Portillo, and his two immediate predecessors.

title: Modern Company Presents Works Old and New
description: One of the hottest new young moderndance companies is in fact an old and venerable one. But it has only been resuscitated for about a couple of years and it has the pristine look of a bornagain institution to it. There are trails of past glories that are admittedly lost in the clouds of future hope. It is, by the way, the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company, and on Friday it opened a threenight stint for the Clark Center Dance Festival at the Mall of the City University Graduate Center. The engagement ends tonight.

title: To Frisbee Fans, It's the Ultimate
description: WESTPORT IN THE beginning, of course, a Frisbee was a tin plate holding a pie that was produced by the thousands in a Bridgeport bakery. The Frisbie Pie Company was its name, and somewhere between 1871 (when William R. Frisbie started the business) and 1920 (when somebody saw the fun in tossing the empty tins), Frisbee started on its way to becoming one of America's rare native sports.

title: Article 4  No Title
Questions/Answers
description: Lack of hydrangea bloom is a frequently asked question. There are several kinds of hydrangea and each has its particular rule for pruning. We'll assume that the question refers to the most commonlygrown type, the summerflowering Hydrangea macrophylla with large blue, pink or white balls of petals during late July and August. One reason for lack of bloom, flowers are formed on the tips of last year's shoots. If the winter is severe, such as last year's, the flower buds can be killed.

title: Confessions of a News Addict
description: Let me begin with a confession. I am a news addict. Upon awakening I flip on the Today show to learn what events transpired during the night. On the commuter train which takes me to work, I scour The New York Times, and find, myself absorbed in tales of earthquakes, diplomacy and economics. I read the newspaper as religiously as my grandparents read their prayerbooks. The sacramental character of the extends into the evening. The length of my workday is determined precisely by my need to get home. in time for Walter Cronkite. My children understand that my communion with Cronkite is something serious and cannot be interrupted for light and transient causes.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (Reuters)The Soviet press agency Tass has attacked a United States Congressional report about human rights in the Soviet Union as a collection of lies and slander.

title: Iowa Bicycle Trek an Annual Summer Rite
description: LANSING, Iowa. Aug. 6More than 3,000 weary bicyclists rode into this tiny Mississippi River town today, ending a weeklong, 400mile bicycle trip across Iowa.

title: F.B.I.'s Files Also Revealing About Itself
description: WASHINGTONThe Federal Bureau of Investigation says that it has never conducted an investigation of the American Civil Liberties Union. Yet there are more than 10,000 pages of material on the organization in its files, ranging from a flimsy biography of former civil liberties union member Helen Keller (a writer on radical subjects is how the bureau, described the deaf, blind and mute author) to minutes of meetings of some of the organization's state affiliates.

title: When Youth Confronts the Law
description: PETER is a 14yearold Nassau County youth whose problems at schoolconstant truancy and tardiness, sleeping in class and consistently poor gradeswere compounded by his difficulties at home. His father is dead and he no longer got along with his mother.

title: Patronage? Turnure Wrote the Book
description: WHITE PLAINS POLITICIANS often complain that their heroic efforts to get out the vote is not rewarded by their party with adequate patronage. But few, if any, have ever posed their case as dramatically and as effectively as J. Harvey Turnure did 32 years ago. For 18 years until his death in July 1955, Mr. Turnure was the Republican leader of White Plains, a city that contributed mightily to the majorities Westchester rolled up regularly for Republican county, state and national candidates for public office.

title: Deborah L. Greene Wed to Alan Becker
description: Deborah Levering Greene and Alan Charles Becker, both summa cum laude graduates of Lehigh University, were married last evening in Pottstown, Pa. District Magistrate Richard Evans performed the ceremony at the Brookside Country Club.

title: Laboring in the Vineyards Near Cutchogue
description: Alex Hargrave, clad in the faded blue of weathered work clothes, strode with pride among his rows of towering green vines, pausing only to prop up an occasional fallen branch or to coddle the young buds in his great hands. Kneeling in the black earth, wet from the morning's rain, he plucked off a single cluster of new buds and brought it to his nose in clasped hands.

title: BUSINESS AND FINANCE
Affiliate, $8.80, Is First In Monmouth Invitational
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 6Strategy devised by Laz Barrera, the trainer, and studiously implemented by Miguel Rivera, the jockey, helped Harbor View's Affiliate race to his first stakes victory today in the $100,000 Monmouth Invitational.

title: Robert Brandt Weds Hilary Ann Kanter
description: Hilary Ann Kanter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Kanter of Miami Beach and Cincinnati, was married to Robert Brandt last evening in Miami Beach, where Rabbi Joseph Narot performed the ceremony aboard Southwin, the bride's parents' yacht.

title: Amin Said to Execute 4 Professors Who Fought Naming School for Him
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 6 (AP)  Four professors at Makerere University by who reportedly opposed naming the institution after President Idi Amin are believed to have been arrested and shot to death, a Nairobi newspaper reported today.

title: Bell System Accords Avert Strike Today
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Communications Workers of America announced tonight a tentative threeyear agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, averting a strike set for early tomorrow. The cost of The threeyear contract was put at $3.3 billion by Glenn E. Watts, president of the union.

title: In the Senate, Carter Won't Have a Commander Like Tip O'Neill
description: WASHINGTON Well, we're twofifth of the way along, said an exhausted White House side after the House of Representatives approved the President's energy package last week, but I have to say, the easy twofifths.

title: Bridge Could Shorten LongHaul Freight
description: WASHINGTON IF you live in Tarrytown or Yonkers and you are driving to Florida or Texas for your vacation, you're not likely to go by way of Albany. Yet Albany is the gateway to and from the South and West for Westchester's and Connecticut's rail freight, which is vital to the economies of the areas.

title: Liza Watters Bride Of Dr. David Hopper
description: Elizabeth Gilbert Watters, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John L. Watters of North Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. David Hershey Hopper, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Joe B. Hopper of Chunju, South Korea.

title: Letters: An Attack On Freeloading Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 18  No Title
Music in Found Objects
description: RIDGEFIELD I PLAY A HUBCAP, said Christian Becker, age 10. Strange as it may seem, one can play a hubcap. Of course, Christian had a choice. As a fifth grader at Veterans Park School here, he could just as easily have played a Whistle Tube, an Airtank, a String Box, a Thumb Piano, or even cans, jars and clay pots. Each can properly be called a musical instrument, if played with the right amount of enthusiasm and imagination.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: What may be New York's most important new building projectthe Museum of Modern Art plan for a luxury apartment tower and expanded museum space for its property on West 53d Streetis now bucking its way through the city's involved review processes. The hearings and approvals required for major new construction often include half a dozen city agencies and the community planning boards, which must now pass on all local landuse proposals under the new City Charter, with active participation by citizen groups, neighborhood associations and interested professionals. Any project as large and sensitive as the Museum of Modem Art proposal is in for scrutiny, trouble and delay.

title: French Rank Crime High on Their List Of Major Worries
description: PARIS, Aug. 6Most Frenchmen rank crime with unemployment and inflation as their chief preoccupations, according to a voluminous report on violence and crime handed over last week to President Valry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Laura Marie Culley Becomes the Bride Of John Alexander Meleney, a Lawyer
description: Laura Marie Culley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Culley of Cincinnati, was married yesterday afternoon to John Alexander Meleney, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Coit Meleney of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

title: DISOBEDIENCE MOVES SET IN ARUBAN FREEDOM DRIVE
description: ORANJESTAD, Aruba, Aug. 6 (Reuters) Political leaders on this Dutch island in the Caribbean island have started a campaign of civil disobedience as part of their fight for independence from the Netherlands Antilles.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: With this book the Sierra Club begins a series meant to teach respect for the environment to children. As a beginning it is disappointing. I doubt the pages of this gardening book will ever be soiled with dirt or riffled by the wind. While it talks all around the subject from anther to zinnia, explaining even such abstruse secrets as How to breed new plants, it never really tells you how to start a flat of lettuce on the windowsill. I can imagine children testing soil acidity in a classroom with litmus paper, but the directions for experiments leave one scratching one's heed. To crosspollinate a flower, for example, we are told to cut away the petals and anthem and leave the pistils. No definition of pistil and anther. No picture. I finally found definitions of pistil and anther in the back of the book. Pistil: Female parts of a flower. Produces seed after pollination. Pistil is made up of stigma, style, and ovary. No help. The lack of an index is a fatal flaw. I hope before the Sierra Club publishes its next effort it will first try it out on children. For spreading the word about conservation among the next generation, this kind of book is not

title: CIVIC EFFORTS GROW AFTER BUSHWICK FIRE
description: From the roof of the abandoned toy factory in Brooklyn's arsonplagued Bushwick section the heads of children in the schoolyard across the street make tempting targets for hoodlums. Three children have been taken to the hospital after having been hit with objects thrown from six stories up.

title: Job Agents Are Assailed on Basis of Survey of Ads
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 5Almost 80 percent of employment agency help wanted advertising was found by a survey conducted by 24 college students, to be either misleading. In some way or for jobs that did not exist.

title: Best Sellers
description: August 7, 1977/The New York Times Book Review

title: Alarm Sounds and CIA Wakes Up in Nightmare Alley
description: New revelations last week about the Central Intelligence Agency's past abuses can, in one sense, fall into the category of expensive and dubious activity of the sort that impelled President Carter to reorganize the country's intelligence apparatus. Theoretically, tighter control might prevent a repetition of such bizarre operations. (See stories Page 3.).

title: Islands Fulfill Dreams
description: NEW ROCHELLE AMONG Westchester County's natural endowments are 60 islands scattered off its shores. Government agencies and community groups have taken many for recreational and other purposes. Others are privately owned. And for sheer romance, there is the Island kingdom of a Manhattanbased architect who bought his gem at a public auction.

title: Yachting
description: AT NEWPORT, R.I.

title: World of Pocket Billiards Has a Tableful of Changes
description: It was only a year ago that the Professional Pool Players Association drove the first wedge into the tidy world of pocket billiards, but the intervening time has seen enough fresh developments to fill a decade.

title: The Elderly Come of Age
description: IF the adage that the future belongs to those who prepare for it is valid, and I believe it is, then today's senior citizens can justly pride themselves on blazing the trail for a vastly improved life style for the elders of tomorrow.

title: Enterprise, Tatoosh Win Cups in Newport Sailing
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 6Enterprise. the yacht many expect to be the fastest when the final trials to select the defender of the America's Cup are sailed later this month, beat her two competitors, Courageous and Independence, today and thereby won the Caritas Cup.

title: Monmouth Invitational
description: Copyright 1977 by Daily Racing Form, Inc.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: The article Mixed Grades For State's Colleges [July 10], was a welcome review of the appalling level of state support for Connecticut higher education, compared with that in other states in this nation. As a University of Connecticut alumnus, I was grateful for the focus on the university and its present struggle to stave off what seems like a steady trend to mediocrity because of niggardly financial support. I also get my information straight from professors who are purchasing supplies out of their own pockets. So, on the one hand, thanks.

title: PORT OF NEW YORK CALLED BIAS VICTIM
description: A Brooklyn Assemblyman has charged that the Port of New York is being victimized by discriminatory rate policies of Conrail and the Federal Maritime Commission.

title: Princeton Borough Backs Gene Studies
description: PRINCETON FOR members of the Princeton Borough Council, a long, spiraling molecule called deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA, has been the cause of many long nights.

title: CLOSER TIES WITH SYRIANS SEEN BY A TOP P.L.O. AIDE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6A new era of cooperation has begun between Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, according to Salah Khalaf, better known as Abu Iyad, who is the secondranking leader of the guerrilla novement.

title: FIVE BYST ANDERS SHOT, ONE OF THE FATALLY
description: Five bystanders, one of whom died, were shot in two separate incidents involving men being chased by gunmen ory Brooklyn streets yesterday, according to the police.

title: IRANIAN PRIME MINISTER ANNOUNCES RESIGNATION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 6 (AP)Amir Abbas Hoveida, the Prime Minister through most of Iran's recent economic and military buildup, resigned today after 12 and a half years in office, an apparent victim of public discontent with shortages and electricity blackouts.

title: FULL OF FRESH AIR, THEY RETURN HOME
description: Their small bodies were ladened with backpacks and suitcases as they filed one by one upstairs to the waiting area at the Port Authority Bus Terminal looking lost among the noonday shoppers and commuters.

title: 8 NATIONS' LEADERS DISCUSS TRADE TIES
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 6The prime ministers of three major economic powers in the AsianPacific region, Japan, Australia and New Zealand, met today for the first time with the leaders of the five nonCommunist countries of Southeast Asia, exchanging a series of pledges to remove the economic barriers that have traditionally divided them.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ROBERT E. CHASEN has spent the last few weeks making discoveries about the United States Customs Service. Among other things, the recently named Commissioner found that he is in charge of Customs offices at more than 300 ports of entry in the United States, that he presides over a network of 14,000 agents and employees and that he has the authority to sign tariff agreements with foreign countries.

title: Drama in the Age
description: Although mainstream American drama remains wedded to socialpsychological realism, the experimental theater is now pressing past the prosaic world of surface reality into a poetic realm of metaphor and myth.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Dogs don't hesitate: they fold up at their feet. And although they respond easily to the wonders of nature, they're apt to be caught in the rain: innocence is established by a drenched coat and a sopping hat. Quick grins or brief guffaws convey integrity. Colliding with furniture and lamps, thy fumble with their fedoras, and frequently get lost: there'S'a tendency to take the wrong bus, also to eat cookies out of a paper bag, or to order milk in a saloon. Brass bands that: blare in their honor make them flinch, and they recoil from admirers who rush to clasp their paws. Unhappy in tuxedos, enlivened by harmonicas, worshipful toward women one of them was once seen kissing a wilting corsage before pressed it between the pages of a bookprone to hurl sudden punches at impious persons, they rub their cheeks slowly when bewildered, and close their eyes before making a big decision. Quite after, reading seems difficult for them. But the backs of their necks tingle when they hear the national anthem, and their lips constantly part with aweor their jaws drap with pleasure or shock. They seem likely to pant when eager, and perhaps it's the perpetual dogginess of these men that captivates their canine counterparts.

title: David of Aztecs Is Hurt, Will Miss Goal on Goals
description: Today is the last day of the regular season in the North American Soccer League. On the first day, Steve David of Los Angeles predicted he would score 29 goals in the 26game season. In the 24th game David scored his 26th goal. It was to be his last of the season as the league's leading scorer collided with Mike Hewitt of the San Jose Earthquakes and suffered torn ligaments on the outside of his right knee.

title: The Wallenberg Dynasty's Struggle  for Succession
description: STOCKHOLMA Gothic tale is unfolding here among Sweden's tightly knit community of business leaders. It is the tale of an old and powerful man, touched by personal tragedy, who is now struggling against the pressure of time to complete a life's work and groom a fitting successor.

title: Inwood Old Dutch, New Latin
description: Inwood is that hilly little border country up at the end of the Independent Line where the storied A Train comes to rest. Apart from being Manhattan's most northerly neighborhood, it's more a principality than an arbitrary stretch of urban real estate. It has its own castle, medieval in mood; its own fortress site, Hessian in passing; and its own stately home, 18th century in fact.

title: INVESTING
description: The power blackout that beset New York City and Westchester County's 9 million residents on July 13 was an act of Cod, according to Charles F. Luce, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company. Mayor Beanie called it gross negligence. To Philip A. Canipne, utility stock analyst at Shearson Cayden Stone, it was a buying opportunity.

title: From Norwalk With Love
description: NORWALK IF Leib Khnokh, a Soviet Jew, is released from Vladimir Prison, where he has spent the last seven years, he may owe his freedom, in part, to the efforts of 12 couples in Norwalk he has never met.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ESSEX AT THE end of the narrow road that winds through a thick, dark forest, a rambling white house sits on a bluff overlooking Essex Harbor at the mouth of the Connecticut River. In the back of the 15room house, through a long living room where a dozing spaniel takes a momentarily interested peek at a visitor, there is a small study crammed with books on politics, history and economics.

title: Notes: A Calder Setting for Satie's Symphonic Drama
description: Joel Thome, conductor of the Philadelphia Composers Forum's Orchestra of Our Time, was having lunch with Virgil Thomson a couple of years ago. They were discussing. Four Saints in Three Acts, the opera Thomson wrote with Gertrude Stein. The conversation led to the organization that first gave the work, in 1934. It was called the Friends and Enemies of Modern Music and caused something of a commotion in music circles in its day.. Among other things it had done was Erik Satie's Socrate, a symphonic drama setting excerpts from Plato's Dialogues. Considered the composer's masterpiece, the austerity of this 109 work makes it seem avantgarde today.

title: Anne St. Goar, Bay State Bride
description: The marriage of Anne Franchot St. Goar to Shippen Lewis Page took place yesterday in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Walter T. St. Goar, in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Joseph A. Bassett, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Anderson Page of Exeter, Me., and the late Louise Page.

title: Shelving Violence
description: NEW HAVEN ABOYCOTT against record covers showing women as the sexual objects of sadomasochistic male behavior has been waged since December by a Los Angelesbased group called Women Against Violence Against Women, but the reactions of the record companies and the distributors has been one of business as usual, with most of them contending that the artists have the final say about what goes on the covers.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BROOKLYNSculpture by Richard D. Graham, now through Aug. 16. New England Center for Contemporary Art, Route 169. Daily, I to 5 P.M. For information, call 7744849.

title: A RealLife Music Man
description: HEARING a bunch of beginners struggle with fiddle and cello may not be everybody's idea of how to spend a Friday night, but the summer string concert, coming up in five days at the Roger Park Junior High School in Danbury is going to be music to John Burnett's ears.

title: 11 RHODESIANS KILLED IN A BOMB EXPLOSION
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 6A bomb exploded in a crowded variety store here just before closing time today, killing 11 persons and injuring 76 in what the police described as the worst act of urban terrorism in Rhodesia's fiveyear guerrilla war. There was no immediate word on who was responsible for the attack.

title: Pamela Dwyer, J. B. Stockton Are Married
description: The marriage of Pamela. S. Dwyer, a lawyer with the New York firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, to John Brent Stockton, a lawyer with the firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn in New York, took place in Princeton, N.J., yesterday. The ceremony in the Princeton the Chapel was performed by the Rev. James R. Davidson, uncle of the bridegroom and former archdeacon for the Episcopal diocese of South Carolina, and the Rev. John Campoli, Roman Catholic Priest.

title: In Memariam
description: BERGERCpl. Morris S. August 9, 1944. In loving memory of my devoted brother.

title: A Correction
description: Through a transmission error, the number of homes scheduled to be equipped with alarm buttons for the elderly under a Nassau County program was incorrectly given in last week's Long Island Weekly. The correct number is 150.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MOST home maintenance tasks that involve using a step ladder around the inside or outside of the house also frequently call for the use of various tools, painting equipment or other materials.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY AUGUST 7, 1977

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE Nobel Prize people, whose mills grind slow but sometimes coarse, have just let Nabokov get away unrewarded. They did manage to catch Neruda before he died; still, one wonders about the unwritten codicil in the charter that sets them up to honor writers. Merit is in it, of course; but longevity is in it as well. A man can hardly be considered a great writer, the committee members presumably tell each other, unless he knows how to take care of his health. The writing must stand the test of time, but so must the arteries.

title: THE MAKEBELIEVE WORLD OF TEENAGE MATERNITY
description: SAN FRANCISCO. One night my parents were talking about someone her dad works with my dad  and they were saying how dumb she was, ruining her life and all, and she was even older than me. She was 16 and I knew they were thinking. My daughter, she wouldn't ever do that. I thought they'd kick me out of the house when they found out. They didn't expect me to be that kind of person. They wouldn't think I was bad or anything, just stupid. But all along I knew I was going to keep the baby.

title: Realty News
description: France has taken India's seat in the great game of musical chairs on Fifth Avenue, and the Dutch have given theirs up.

title: Seaver Defeats Pirates As Morgan Bats In 4
description: The world champion Cincinnati Reds, though far behind the Los. Angeles. Dodgers in the National League West race, are not conceding yet.

title: The Sex PistolsA FiredUp Rock Band
description: KRISTINEHAMN, Sweden Even in America, where they haven't released any records, the Sex Pistols have achieved a kind of flamboyant notoriety. They are the leaders and most lurid of the British punk rockers, that bizarre cult of disaffected young people who dye their hair in tacky, multicolored array, wear calculatedly ragged clothes, drive safety pins through their ear lobes and noses and fight a lot.

title: A Genial Gadfly Vs. Lilco
description: BABYLON THE hearings are nearly over, after almost three years, and by late next spring the Long Island Lighting Company will probably know whether it may begin building two 1,150,000kilowatt nuclear generators at Jamesport at an estimated cost of $2.7 billion.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: IN what is becoming a familiar pattern, Stephen King, author of Carrie, Salem's Lot and The Shining, has left his hardcover publisher, Doubleday, to sign a lucrative threebook contract with New American Library, the paperback house. Mr. king's departure from the hardcover publishers, who encouraged him in his lean days, when he was unpublished and working in a laundromat to support himself, is a reflection both of the willingness of paperback houses to deal direct ly with authors of proved massmarket appeal, thus bypassing expensive auctions of paperback rights by the hardcover houses, and of restiveness among authors with negotiating muscle who want a larger share of subsidiaryrights income.

title: 600 in California March at Atomic Plant to Challenge Nuclear Power
description: GAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 6Marching with banners emblazoned No Nukes, End the Arms Race and Fund Human Needs, 600 opponents of atomic poker and weapons development staged an orderly twohour protest rally today outside the San Onofre nuclear generating facility near here.

title: FISHING
description: THE extensive concentrations of bluefish that have been hanging around the Klondike Banks for the last few weeks seem to have scattered a bit, with schools now, ranging from The Farms, off Asbury Pant, to a few miles off Seaside Park.

title: SELECTION
description: DEPARTURE

title: Barbara Freedman Is Married
description: Barbara Louise Freedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Freedman of Albany, was married there last night to Robert Steven Fischler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fischler, also of Albany. Rabbi Silverman performed the ceremony in Temple Beth Emeth.

title: It's Vintage North Fork
description: CUTCHOGUE ALEX HARGRAVE, clad in the faded blue of weathered workclothes, strode with pride among his rows of towering green vines, pausing only to prop up an occasional fallen branch or to coddle the young buds in his great hands. Kneeling in the black earth, wet from the morning's rain, he plucked off a single cluster of new buds and brought it to his nose in clasped hands.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: LOS ANGELES DEBATES 1984 OLYMPICS' COST
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6Los Angeles, the apparent frontrunner among American cities that hope to stage the 1984 Summer Olympic Games, is already debating how much the event will, or will not, cost taxpayers.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: DEPENDING on how you look at it, the Carmel Bicentennial Committee is either a year late or 99 years early. The ceremony, scheduled to take place today in front of Town Hall in Mahopac, is officially billed as a Bicentennial activity. But it is also the beginning of Carmel's celebration of the nation's Tricentennial.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONMr. Kittrell came to Washington this week, and during 48 hours in the nation's capital, he visited Congressmen, was interviewed by half a dozen journalists, attended the screening of a documentary by Eric Hoffer, the philosopher, and spent an evening carousing in Georgetown bars.

title: Bit of City Island Is on Every Sea
description: CAPT. FREDERICK L. LANE has sailed tankers in the Arctic and in the Gulf of Aqaba. He has shipped on 10,000tonners in wartime convoys; he has captained modem tankers of more than 700 feet and 40,000 tons. He has been to a score of ports in Europe, to as many in Asia, he has traveled to the Gulf of Mexico, to Ceylon and the Soviet Union.

title: Future Events
description: Go to a Cool Ball

title: SUNY Sings Praises Of Rare Pipe Organ
description: IT'S a magnificent organ which will be the centerpiece of a collection of instruments unmatched anywhere, said Michael Hammond, the newly appointed president of the State University College at Purchase, speaking about what arts department officials describe as this country's largest movable pipe organ. Assembly of the instrument will begin this week in the new performing arts complex.

title: Article 9  No Title

description: Last December, the Old Stonehouse of Gowanus, which stands in the center of Byrne Park in South Brooklyn and dates to 1699, was a building rich in past but apparently with no real future.

description: GENEVA, Aug. 6 (AP)The World Council of Churches today wound up a 10day meeting by approving new program to combat violations of human rights throughout the world.

Biggs performed the ceremony in the First United Methodist Church in Island Heights, N.J.

description: ELMONT, LI., Aug. 6The lines of a classic school desegregation battle of the 1970'swith white suburbs and black city areas facing courtordered pupil transfersare being drawn along the border between Nassau County and New York City, and emotions are running high.

title: Article 1  No Title

description: A PIONEER still photographer, a seminal cinematographer and a filmmaker, a museum director and a teacherWillard Van Dyke is a man of seemingly endless talents and inexhaustible energies.

description: Sometimes, Dick Neff philosophized the other day, mistakes can be turned to your advantage.

description: LONDON, Aug. 6A new ferment over issues involving sexual mores has emerged in Britain, with conflicts developing between those who take permissive attitudes toward laws regulating sexual behavior and those demanding a tougher line.

description: FRIDAY NIGHTS MATCHES Indiana 26, New York 21. Cleveland 24, SeaPort 21. Golden Gate 32, Phoenix 19. Los Angeles, 26, Boston 23.
