title: Controversial State Bill Mandates A Curb on Legalese in Contracts
description: Confronted with a lease or loan form and its tangle of herein's, parties of the first part, covenants and other legal jargon, most consumers usually surrender and sign after making, at best, a halfhearted attempt to read and understand the legal document.

title: Building Higher Expectations for the Mentally Retarded
description: As a preschooler, Frank Sullivan's I.Q. was under 70, and he was diagnosed as mentally retarded. His parents, Kathleen and Charles Sullivan of Philadelphia, sent him to special schools from the age of 6, and he ultimately completed a worktraining program run by the Philadelphia Association for Retarded Citizens. (Sullivan is not their name.)

title: State Is Now a Source of Soccer Talent
description: The game of professional soccer is dominated by players from countries like Brazil, West Germany and South Africa. There are few players from North America, even in something called the North American Soccer League, in which the New York Cosmos play.

title: Senate Ethics Panel May Appoint Counsel to Investigate Korea Gifts
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP)The Senate committee. investigating possible involvement by Senators in alleged Congressional influencebuying by the South Korean Government may name a special counsel in the next two weeks, its chairman said today.

title: NEW SKETCH OF .44 KILLER STILL NOT GIVEN TO PUBLIC
description: The police continued yesterday to show their newest composite sketch, of the .44 caliber killer to survivors and witnesses of the killer's eight attacks in which he killed six people and wounded seven others.

title: Angels 6, Royals 4
description: Angels 7, Royals 2

title: Sen. Church in Cuba To Talk to Castro On Improving Ties
description: HAVANA, Aug. 8  Senator Frank. Church arrived here tonight on a United States Air Force plane, the first to land in Cuba in 16 years.

title: Primary Roundup
description: In speaking out against capital punishment, Mario M. Cuomo was acting as a buffer for his boss, the Governor, Mayor Beame said yesterday.

title: CARTER SIGNS A BILL EASING FUME RULES
description: PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 8President Carter briefly interrupted his vacation here today to sign two bills into law, one allowing the manufacturing of cars under relaxed Federal emission standards, the other appropriating millions of dollars in Federal funds for several water development projects he had vigorously opposed.

title: India Demands KnowHow and 60% Share of CocaCola Operation
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 8The Indian Government has served notice on the CocaCola Company of the United States that it must transfer its knowhow and a majority share of its Indian company to Indian shareholders or discontinue operations in this country, it was disclosed today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Shipping Exchange Sets Sales in Secrecy
description: LONDON, Aug. 8The first hints of the huge purchases by the Russians in their 1972 grainbuying coup came not from the boisterous Chicago futures pits but from a relatively obscure exchange here that provides no public record of its transactions.

title: Miss Lawrence Stars In Women's Amateur
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 (AP)Mary Lawrence of Canton, N.Y., was the only player to break par in stormdelayed qualifying action today for the 77th annual United States women's amateur golf championship.

title: Prices of Soybean and Grain Futures Fall Sharply
description: A bearish crop survey issued over the weekend by Conrad Leslie, the leading private forecaster, sent soybean and grain futures prices tumbling in Chicago yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: U.S. Investigating Reports of Burns From Microwave Ovens
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8The United States Senate Commerce Committee and other agencies are investigating burns reportedly sustained by two Frankfort, Ky., women while heating food orders in a microwave oven.

title: U.S. AND CANADA SEEK AN EARLY GAS ACCORD ON ALASKA HIGHWAY
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 8  Canada and the United States will hold negotiations looking toward an early agreement on a pipeline to bring natural gas from northern Alaska, and eventually from the Canadian Arctic as well, to American and Canadian consumers by the Alaska Highway Route, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced today.

title: Missing Persons: Most Cases Solve Themselves
description: The girl in the white dress looked familiar. She vaguely resembled the photographs in newspapers and in flyers posted around town by a private detective retained by her family. As she left the unemployment office. and headed east on Barclay Street in Lower Manhattan, Police Det. Eugene A. Reavis of the Missing Persons Squad followed her. He watched her walk up the block and turn right onto Church Street. Then he watched her disappear behind a building.

title: Ramblin' Jack to the Rescue
description: Ramblin' Jack Elliott, who has Veen rambling longer than many of today's folk singers have been alive, rescued a sodden, lugubrious late show at the Bottom Line Sunday morning with a warm, funny absolutely captivating monologue. It began during the summer of 1953 with Mr. Elliott, Harry Smith, Guy Carawan, and some other budding folkies picking and singing in Washington Square Park, long before these activities reached epidemic proportions there. They were, Mr. Elliott recalled, the only folkies around, and they never dreamed of performing on stages for money.

title: 150 PRISONERS SEIZE 14 IN ULSTER COUNTY
description: NAPANOCH, N.Y., Aug. 8About 150 inmates armed with clubs and other makeshift weapons seized 14 hostages and a wing of the Eastern Correctional Facility here this morning, but the rebels released the last of their hostages and surrendered peacefully tonight after a 12hour siege.

title: The Law And the President.
description: CHICAGO,. Aug. 8The Carter Administration, Vice President blondele told the American Bar Association today, has rejected absolutely the doctrine that any government official, including the President, is above the law. President Carter has made it clear that he and everyone else who serves under him has a duty to obey the law just like everyone else In America.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Plan for Lincoln Towers Rent Rise Dropped as U.S. Reverses Stance
description: The Carter Administration, reversing its previous stand, has decided not to supersede local rent laws at the large Lincoln Towers apartment complex in Manhattan and not to authorize rent rises of up to 20 percent for a single year's renewal lease.

title: Beanie Drops Plan to Abolish the Board of Education
description: Mayor Beame, in a major shift from his proposal that the New York City Board of Education be abolished, recommended yesterday that it be retained, but with the Mayor appointing its members, and that its chairman serve as a salaried Schools Chancellor.

title: Altonell Hines Matthews, Sang in Porgy and Bess And Eva Jessye's Choir
description: Altonell Hines Matthews, a member of the original cast of Porgy and Bess and Four Saints in Three Acts, died Saturday at her home at 400 West 154th Street. She was 72 years old.

title: Deaths
description: ANDREWSDorothy H. Of Brooklyn and Higganum, Conn. Friday in Higganum. Sister of Marjorie Andrews of Brooklyn and Mrs. Phyllis Melnzer of Dayton, Ohio. Private funeral services al Doolittle Funeral Home, 14 Church St., Middletown, Conn., Wednesday, August 10.

title: Financing for B'nai Torah Institute Is Delayed, Pending U.S. Approval
description: The Beame administration, until yesterday a supporter of the problemplagued B'nai Torah Institute of Brooklyn, has decided to give no new funds to the institute until the city receives proper clearance from the United States Department of Labor

title: Consumer Borrowing Up in June But Repayments Set Record Pace
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)Consumers borrowed more money on the installment plan in June, but they paid off their past debts in record amounts, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: 2Hitter by John Gives Dodgers a Lead of 12
description: The Reds got Tom Seaver. The Dodgers are dead.

title: New Columbia College Dean
description: Like a freshman finding his way around a new campus, Arnold Collery is meeting new people, unpacking his books and discovering new places to eat. What distinguished himfrom just any new face on the Columbia University campus is that Dr. Collery is the new dean of Columbia College. His appointment was announced yesterday by William J. McGill, the president of Columbia. It is going to be very exciting to be here, the 50yearold Dr. Collery said in his new office, with, almost freshmanlike enthusiasm.

title: Article 2  No Title
S.E.C. Accuses Peska of Violating Fraud Laws in Inventors' Program
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a New Yorkbased concern that offers amateur inventors an inventiondevelopment program with violating registration and antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.

title: Remo Bolognini, Musician, 78; Served Under Toscanini in 1930's
description: Remo Bolognini, an assistant concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic in the 1930's under Toscanini, died Monday in Roosevelt Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 78 years old. He had been playing as a, substitute in the violin section of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra for the last five years.

title: 50% of 176 Cited In Looting Held FullTime Jobs
description: Of the 176 persons indicted on looting charges after last month's blackout, almost half had fulltime jobs and less than 10 percent were on welfare, District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Canal Negotiators Said to Seek Accord by Tomorrow
description: PANAMA, Aug. 8United States and Panamanian negotiators held long sessions today in an attempt to bridge the remaining gaps and conclude a treaty that would provide for transfer of the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone to Panamanian control by the year 2000.

title: JOHN HAAG ECKEL, AT 70, A SURGEON FOR 45 YEARS
description: Dr. John Haag Eckel, a surgeon associated with New York Hospital and North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., died Sunday in New York University Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Taif Is Saudis' Summer Capital
description: TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 8Taif is not exactly a household word around the world.

title: Revival of 1938 Angel Shows the Musical's Age
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.  Originally written as a movie musical, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart's I Married an Angel was rejected by Louis B. Mayer. In 1938, the team converted the script into a hit Broadway musical, and several years later it was filmed by MGM. The inevitable conclusion that one draws from seeing the show in its current revival at the Berkshire Theater Festival is that Mayer was right the first time. If this isn't the most foolish old musical comedy ever written, it certainly must be the most foolish old musical comedy ever written by Rodgers and Hart.

title: Study Backs GoldinNot Beameon Budget Issues
description: An accounting firm whose opinion had been sought on two controversial items in New York City's budget has concluded that Mayor Beame was wrong in balancing the budget with them and that Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin was right in opposing them.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: Pirates 7, Cubs 6

title: Competition Is Now Tight In Cup's Challenger Trials
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8A tonguelashing delivered by Alan Bond to the crew of his new yacht Australia reflected an encouraging development today on the America's Cup scene.

title: Durrett Named La Salle Aide
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP)Ken Durrett, who had been plagued with knee problems during a brief National Basketball Association :career with Cincinnati, Kansas CityOmaha and Philadelphia, was named assistant coach today at La Salle College Durrett, 28 years old, played basketball at La Salle from 1968 to 1971, during which the Explorers posted a 5720 record, including a 231 mark in 19681969.

title: Kaiser Industries Is Planning Second Liquidating Distribution
description: The Kaiser Industries Corporation said it would make its second liquidating distribution of corporate assets on Oct. 3 to shareholders of record Sept. 2. The distribution will be $1 per Kaiser Industries share.

title: Carey Supports Increase Of $300 for Each Student In Tuition Aid Program
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 8Governor Carey said today that he would support an increase of $300 a student in the maximum grant available under the state's Tuition Assistance Program next year. The increase is similar to a plan Mr. Carey declined to support when it was proposed by Republicans in the State Senate during the last legislative session.

title: House Aide Tells of Suspicion U.S. Uranium Was Stolen 10 Years Ago
description: WASHINTGON, Aug. 8A House investigator said today that United States intelligence officials had strong suspicions that highly enriched uranium, a type that could be used in bombs, was stolen from a Pennsylvania nuclear facility more than a decade ago.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: The language of accounting is frequently bewildering to outsiders. But business executives usually feel confident thatif they know anything at all about accountingthey can tell what constitutes an asset and what constitutes a liability.

title: Refugees Report Clashes on CambodiaVietnam Line
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Highly placed United States Government sources said today that Cambodian or Vietnamese rebels operating from bases in Cambodia had been harassing Vietnamese border areas with artillery, rocket and mortar fire, forcing the temporary evacuation of two towns.

title: Hydroplane Pilot Killed In Accident Is Eulogized
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (AP)A group of friends gathered today at Lake Washington's hydroplane pit area in a memorial to Jerry Bangs, 42 years old, who was killed yesterday when his thunderboat cartwheeled and threw him into the water.

title: SUMMATIONS TODAY IN TRIAL OF MANDEL
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 8The jury in the Federal conspiracy and corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland heard the final arguments of defense lawyers for his five codefendants today and prepared for the showdown in the nineweek case tomorrowthe summations of the chief prosecutor and the 57yearold Governor's defense counsel.

title: CASINOFEAR LIMITS RACE TRACK BUYERS
description: CHERRY HILL (UPI)Private investors are not eager to buy and rebuild Garden State Race Track because they want a harness permit and are worried that casino gambling may draw away potential bettors, according to Richard Weidner, head of the Garden State Racing Association.

title: Researchers Say That Students Were Among 200 Who Took LSD in Tests Financed by C.I.A. in Early '50's
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Students at Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Emerson College were among some ZOO persons who received LSD in experiments secretly financed by the Central Intelligence Agency at the Boston Psychopathic Hospital in the early 1950's, researchers who worked on the studies said today.

title: Apples Lose Despite Upset By Mrs. King
description: Despite a beautifully executed upset of Martina Navratilova by Billie Jean King, the New York Apples fell again to the Boston Lobsters in a World Team Tennis match last night before a crowd of 7,387 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Orioles 6, Indians 3
description: AT BALTIMOREThe Orioles snapped a threegame losing streak, getting a homer by Andres Mora and runscoring hits by Eddie Murray, Lee May and Mark Belanger. Dennis Martinez gained his 10th victory in relief.

title: Good Job Outlook Causes Jam in Accounting Classes And Colleges Strive to Cut Back on Their Enrollment
description: Because of good job prospects for graduates, accounting has become higher education's most popular subject.

title: A Broadway Opening for OTB
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation opened a plush new horse parlor yesterday in Times Square that could help bettors loseand who knows, even winin comfort.

title: New Crown Central Plan For Kewanee Is Set
description: The Crown Central Petroleum Corporation and the Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation, which have been seeking to acquire a controlling interest in Kewanee Industries Inc., have proposed a new plan to purchase under certain conditions all of Kewanee's outstanding shares at $46.50 each.

title: U.S. Court Voids F.C.C. EqualEmployment Rules
description: New rules by the Federal Communications Commission concerning equal employment opportunity procedures for local radio and television stations have been struck down by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York as arbitrary and capricious.

title: No Suspects Reported In Fatal IRT Stabbing
description: The police yesterday said they had no suspects in the slaying of 33yearold Claudia Castellana in the Lincoln Center subway station shortly after noon Sunday.

title: ETHIOPIA NOW TALKS OF 'FULLSCALE WAR
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 8 (UPI) The Ethiopian radio said today that fighting in the Ogaden desert between Government troops and Somali guerrillas had turned into fullscale war with Somalia.

title: Muriel S. Webb, 64, irector In Geneva of World Church Unit
description: Muriel S. Webb, director since 1974 of the Commission on Interchurch Aid, Refugees and World Service of the World Council of Churches in Geneva, died of cancer on Sunday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 5 Mill Pond, Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, August 9, 1977

title: EMI Sues Pfizer For Infringement
description: EMI Ltd., a British concern that was instrumental in the development of Xray scanners, said it had filed suit against Pfizer Inc. and its subsidiary, Pfizer Medical System Inc. in Federal court in Wilmington, Del.

title: New Museum Is Born in Paris For Modern Art of 1884 to 1904
description: PARISIn record time and with practically no publicity, a new museum has been born in Paris. Its bombastic, nouveau riche name, Palais de L'Alma, gives no indication of the nature and quality of its contents: the art of the period from 1884 to 1904.

title: DOLLAR IS UP BRISKLY IN EUROPEAN TRADING
description: The dollar made good gains against West European currencies in foreign exchange trading yesterday and a moderate gain against the Japanese yen, The Associated Press reported.

title: Dud Bomb Discovered in Midtown In Building Targeted by F.A.L.N.
description: An unexploded bomb was discovered yesterday in one of the buildings mentioned as a target last Wednesday by telephone callers who said they were speaking for the Puerto Rican terrorist group known as the F.A.L.N. Two bombs exploded that day, killing one man and injuring seven other persons, and dozens of bomb threats led to massive evacuations of office workers.

title: Auerbach and Loughery Are Rival Stokes Coaches
description: Arnold (Red) Auerbach, president and general manager of the Boston Celtics, will be coaching one of the teams for the 19th straight year tonight in the Maurice Stokes Memorial Game at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello. Auerbach, the most successful coach in the National Basketball Association when he led the Celtics on the court, will have with him several members of the current team, including Cedric (Cornbread) Maxwell, his No. 1 draft pick. The other Celtics are Jo Jo White and Charlie Scott. Others on Auerbach's squad include Henry Bibby, Steve Mix and Lloyd Free, of the Philadelphia 76ers and M. L. Carr, an outstanding rookie with the Detroit Pistons last season.

title: Sacco and Vanzetti Day Opposed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 8 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate voted, 21 to 14, today to condemn Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's proclamation declaring Aug. 23 Sacco and Vanzetti Day in Massachasetts, in memory of the anarchists executed 50 years ago. The Republ cansponsored resolution was backed by most Democratic leaders and opposed mainly by a bloc of liberal senators.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: When President Carter decided last month to cancel production of the B1 bomber, he said the United States would rely instead upon airlaunched cruise missiles to extend the life of the B52 bomber into the 1990's. Cruise (as distinguished from ballistic) missiles are, in effect, miniature unmanned aircraft, with wings and airbreathing jet engines; through sophisticated electronic guidance they canny at treetop heights to distant targets. Last week, Secretary of Defense Harold Brown explained the Administration's reasoning to the House Armed Services Committee in a statement notable both for what it said and for what it omitted.

title: White Sox 5, Mariners 4
description: AT CHICAGOLamar Johnson's second homer of the game, in the ninth, snapped a threegame losing streak for the White Sox and put them a game in front of Minnesota in the West. Randy Wiles, on his second day in the big leagues, pitched twothirds of an inning and won his first game. Johnson got his other homer in the first Inning and Oscar Gamble cracked homer No. 21 for Chicago.

title: S.E.C. Says Executive Diverted $4 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint today against a Bostonbased garbage removal company and alleged that nearly $4 million was diverted from the company by its former president.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Salmon Reappearing in New England Rivers
description: It seemed nearly impossible a decade ago that those of us over 40 had much chance, before we departed for that place from which no traveler returns, to fish successfully for Atlantic salmon in the rivers of New England.

title: Accident at Nuclear Power Plant Exposes Employees to Radiation
description: CLINTON, Ill., Aug. 8 (AP)An accident at a nuclear power plant being built outside Clinton exposed several workers to direct radiation, the Nuclear Regulatory Agency said today.

title: MOSCOW SAYS ABOMB NEAR IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP)The Soviet Union said today that South Africa was on the verge of creating a nuclear bomb and called for urgent international efforts to block such a development.

title: Fishing Trip Turns Into Uprising
description: The mutiny on the Island Queen, unlike the more celebrated insurrection on the Bounty, may not be the stuff of which bestselling books or movies are made, but it will probably be remembered for a long time by 23 city sanitationmen, a boat captain and his crew and law enforcement officers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Dismissal by N.S.A. Is Laid to Queries on Purchasing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8A former official in the National Security Agency has charged that he was dismissed from the highly secretive agency after raising questions about possible conflict of interest in its equipment purchases and not because there were valid objections to his work.

title: Young in Costa Rica; Rights Theme Focus In Warm Welcome
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug 8Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, was given a warm and friendly welcome here today and joined Costa Rican leaders in emphasizing that mutual concern for human rights would be the overriding theme of his visit.

title: Premier Declares Israel Will Exercise Veto
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 8Prime Minister Menahem Begin served notice today, on the eve of the arrival in Jerusalem of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, that it would be futile to prepare a role for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Middle East peace talks by trying to make the P.L.O. recognize Israel.

title: Navy Is Weighing Charges in Medical Center Deaths
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 8High officials of the Navy are investigating three deaths at the Navy Regional Medical Center here and charges by a resident anesthesiologist that the facility lacks adequate equipment and sufficient staffing.

title: Balasaraswati Dances Into Ecstasy
description: Her name is Balasaraswati and she is easily India's greatest classical dancer and one of the supreme performing artists of the world

title: Futurology's Pitfalls
description: OXFORD, EnglandThe summer of 1947 in London and Paris was uncomfortably hot. It followed the freezing winter of the fuel crisis in Britain when civil servants, like everyone else, worked by candlelight in Whitehall. We huddled in overcoats at the office and at home, with the electricity cut off from the center. France and West Germany had been shivering too, and in West Germany there was still a terrible shortage of food; in Britain, food was dreary and drab, but Just adequate.

title: Carter Aide Again in Argentina For Assessment of Human Rights
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8A highlevel representative of President Carter specializing in human rights is visiting Argentina this week for an assessment of continuing political violence, mysterious kidnappings and labor repression here.

title: World News Briefs
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 8 (Reuters)The police fired tear gas tonight to stop thousands of people trying to reach Lahore airport to greet former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: South African Tells of Finding Many Bodies in Mozambique Mine
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 (UPI)South African officials said today that a mine rescue team had found bodies but no survivors in a Mozambique coal mine where 70 black miners are believed to have died in an explosion last week.

title: Soweto, After 14 Violent Months, Seems Even Farther From Peace
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8Less than 45 miles separate the somber Cabinet room in Pretoria's Union Buildings and the smokeclogged streets of Soweto, but for all the communication between them South Africa's white rulers and the black leaders of Soweto might as well be at opposite ends of the globe.

title: Missing Persons: Most Cases Solve Themselves
description: The girl in the white dress looked familiar. She vaguely resembled the photographs in newspapers and in flyers posted around town by a private detective retained by her family. As she left the unemployment office and headed east on Barclay Street in Lower Manhattan, Police Det. Eugene A. Reavis of the Missing Persons Squad followed her. He watched her walk up the block and turn right onto Church Street. Then he watched her disappear behind a building.

title: Secretary Says Saudis Expect Change Soon
description: TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug, 8Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Saudi Arabian officials had advised him to expect an imminent change in the Palestine Liberation Organization's attitude toward a key United Nations resolution that recognizes Israel's right to exist and has been opposed by the P.L.O. for a decade.

title: New York Officials Now Question Saving Under Carter Welfare Plan
description: City officials who have been sifting since Saturday through President Carter's welfare proposals say they cannot be sure whether the revisions would actually save the city the $173 million that the White House said would be saved.

title: Article 1  No Title
Bell Asks Aid Abroad on Inquiries
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 8Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today urged foreign governments to cooperate with the antitrust investigations by the United States of the oil and uranium industries. Otherwise he suggested, the United States may be less willing to cooperate with investigations of these countries.

title: 11 Governors Assail Energy Plan
description: AFTON, Okla., Aug. 8Eleven Middle Western Governors, who have long favored deregulation of natural gas, today attacked President Carter's energy program and the recently passed House bill embodying it and began mapping strategy to fight in the Senate for increased production incentives.

title: Article 3  No Title
Gophers Won't Declare 3 Players Ineligible
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (UPI)C. Peter Magrath, president of the University of Minnesota, says the school will not declare three basketball players ineligible as a means of avoiding the probation placed on men's sports at the school by the Naitonal Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: 8,000 Seek Blackout Cleanup Jobs
description: A throng estimated at 8,000 to 10,000 people jammed New York City's regional manpower offices yesterday, seeking applications for 2,000 jobs to assist in the federally financed blackout cleanup project. The scene was one of confusion over who was to apply, when and where.

title: Homosexuality and Sin
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.Enter here the opinion that Christianity has nothing to do with denying homolexuals their civil rights.

title: CBS Gets Harpmaker
description: CBS Inc., the diversified communications company, said it had acquired Lyon & Healy Inc., the world's leading maker of harps, in a multimillion dollar transaction, the exact amount was not disclosed. Lyon & Healy will become a unit of the CBS Musical Instruments Division, which includes pianos, guitars, organs, electronic pianos, drums, flutes and piccolos.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: Rangers 5, A's 2

title: Soweto, After 14 Violent Months, Seems Even Farther From Peace
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8Less than 45 miles separate the somber Cabinet room in Pretoria's Union Buildings and the smokeclogged streets of Soweto, but for all the communication between them South Africa's white rulers and the black leaders of Soweto might as well be at opposite ends of the globe.

title: Vance Aide Regrets Identification Of Reporters on Tour as Christians
description: TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 8 (AP)A spokesman for Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance expressed regret today that all American reporters traveling with him were identified as Christians on, hotel registration forms.

title: Senate Subpoenas 4 for MindControl Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Four men who played significant roles in the Central Intelligence Agency's mindcontrol experiments have been subpoenaed to testify at a Senate hearing in September, aides to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, slid over the weekend. They are scheduled to appear before the Health and Science Subcommittee of the Human Resources Committee.

title: Munson's Shave in Time Saves the Yankee Nine
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 8All season long, the Yankees have averted some crises and eliminated others by clearing the air with meetings. Today Thurman Munson averted a crisis by clearing his face with a razor.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the word not was dropped from the final paragraph of a Middle East news analysis in some editions of Mondays paper. The sentence should have read: But unlike the situation in that period, a failure to bring about a Geneva conference now would not be likely to lead to War immediately, since the military balance in the region has shifted in Israel's favor.

title: American Hoechst Deal
description: The American Hoechst Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire EOCOM Corporation of Irvine, Calif. The amount of the cash transaction was not announced. American Hoechst, a subsidiary of Hoechst AG of West Germany, makes graphic arts, chemical, pharmaceutical and plastic products. EOCOM is a major producer of electrooptical systems.

title: Secretary Says Saudis Expect Change Soon
description: TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug, 8Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Saudi Arabian officials had advised him to expect an imminent change in the Palestine Liberation Organization's attitude toward a key United Nations resolution that recognizes Israel's right to exist and has been opposed by the P.L.O. for a decade.

title: A.T.&T.'s Jobs Going From East To the. Sunbelt
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7A substantial shift is under way at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in effect, moving thousands of jobs from the East to the Sunbelt states.

title: Bridge:
description: Two New York experts were among the winners in the first two days of play in one of the world's oldest bridge tournaments, which began Friday at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high. and dIndicates new low.

title: Television
description: 5:02(2) With Jeanne Parr (R)

title: ACCESS TO BROADCASTING FOR MINORITIES IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8The Congresshow very little black ownership of broadcasting outlets, has urged Congress to require greater minority access to them in the future.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the word not was dropped from the final paragraph of a Middle East news analysis. The sentence should have read: But unlike the situation in that period, a failure to bring about a Geneva conference now would not be likely to lead to war immediately, since the military balance in the region has shifted in Israel's favor.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: U.S. Export Drive Is Assailed in House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8The Federal Government's $50 millionayear exportpromotion program is wasteful and ineffective and needs to be drastically overhauled, according to a House subcommittee report scheduled for release tomorrow.

title: Nancy Lopez Is Fulfilling Her Promise as a Golfer
description: Nancy Lopez was an effervescent 18yearold amateur who had just finished high school when she shook up the experience women professional golfers in Atlantic City two years ago. She had been in position to pull off the biggest upset in women golf history when she had led the United States Wornen's Open championship after two rounds. She did not carry out the threat of victory, however, but she still finished impressively in a tie for second behind Sandra Palmer.

title: Philadelphia Bulletin Loses Plea To Bar Shift of a Comic Strip
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP)A Philaprevent a syndicate from shifting the Puprevent a syndicate fro mshifting the Pulitzer Prizewinning comic strip Doonesbury to a competing newspaper.

title: Planning Unit Approves Proposal to Build Market Under Queensboro Span
description: The New York City Planning Commission approved a plan yesterday for a $2 million market under the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge after receiving assurances from the city's Department of Highways that the bridge roadway above was structurally sound.

title: Loews' Net Triples to $70.7 Million in 2d Quarter
description: The Loews Corporation, engaged in tobacco, theater and hotels, insurance and investments, more than tripled its secondquarter net income, after including capital and investment gains, it was reported yesterday. Earnings from operations were up 42.6 percent for the quarter

title: A Bit of Rural Britain for New Yorkers
description: LONDON  Sixteenyearold Kim Ryan of Rye, N. Y., paused for a moment in the crowded shop and eyed a long, blue cotton dress, printed with small white flowers. She was running out of pounds but, Kim reasoned, her shopping companion could lend her a fewand besides, Where else could I get a dress like this for only $15?

title: RAY HILBERT
description: BARDSTOWN, Ky., Aug. 8 (AP)Ray Hilbert, a widely traveled Associated Press executive whose last assignment was as chief of communications in Milwaukee, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 38 years old.

title: Diplomacy With Diplomats Gets Some to Pay Unpaid Bills
description: New York City has managed to get foreign diplomats and governments to pay more than $750,000 in unpaid bills that New York businessmen had been dunning them for, a municipal official disclosed this week.

title: Giants Put Shaw on Waivers Sowells Is Among 10 Jets Cut
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 8Rich Sowells, a starting cornerback for three of his six seasons with the Jets, was one of 10 players cut today as the squad got down to tomorrow's 60player National Football League roster limit

title: LEROY F. PERCIVAL JR.
description: BRISTOL, Conn., Aug. 8 (AP)LeRoy F. Percival Jr., a career diplomat, died today of an apparent heart attack. He was 54.

title: Makarios Is Buried on a Mountaintop After Emotional Funeral Procession in Nicosia
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 8(AP)The body of Archbishop Makarios, the political and spiritual leader of the Greek Cypriots, was buried in a mountaintop tomb today after being borne through the streets of Nicosia in an emotional funeral procession.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended June 30 unless other wise Indicated. (N) indicates stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) everthecounter.

title: Polygraph Indicates Ray Lied
description: Polygraph tests arranged by Playboy magazine indicate that James Earl Ray Jr. acted alone in slaying the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Dawson Police Chief Testifies He's Seen No Racism in Georgia
description: DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 8 (AP)Police Chief Bill Law testified today that he knew of no racial discrimination in Georgia and that a former police officer who testified, as a defense witness about alleged police brutality against blacks here had been dismissed only because of misconduct.

title: Old Montreal Block ls Saved Amid Downtown Renovation
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 8In a city that has worked hard to be modern by transforming much of its center into characterless highrises, a blow for conservation is struck every once in a while. After another long hard fight, conservationists have just found something to cheer about.

title: Bruno Tells Investigation on Atlantic City He Wants to Stay Clear of Casino Operations
description: TRENTON, Aug. 8Angelo Bruno, regarded by lawenforcement officials as the head of organized crime in Philadelphia and South Jersey, insisted today that he wanted to stay away from Atlantic City with the approach of legalized gambling there.

title: Reichhold Split Backed
description: Shareholders of Reichhold Chemicals Ltd. in Toronto approved a 3for1 stock split and name change to Reichhold Ltd. Shareholders also approved creation of 3 million par $10 preferred shares. Reichhold Chemicals Ltd. is a unit of Reichhold Chemicals Inc.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GROWTH Much has happened since Roots attained one of the largest audiences in television history. New careers have opened up for some of the principal players. The basis for the episodic, homescreen drama, Alex Haley's bestselling book that traced his ancestry from Africa to the United States, received a special citation by the Pulitzer Prize committee. The television series itself is still being written about In terms of impact in sociology, the black heritaee and entertainment.

title: Nagataka Murayama Dies in Japan; Headed Country's Biggest Paper
description: TOKYO, Aug. 8Nagataka Murayama, an owner and former president of Asahi Shimbun, Japan's largest and most prestigious newspaper, died yesterday in a hospital in a suburb of Osaka. He was 83 years old.

title: Peckinpah Wrests Convoy From an 18Wheel Wild Bunch
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M.,Sam Peckinpah sits in a canvas chair in the middle of an empty highway licking the peanuts off a packaged ice cream cone. Except for a halfglass of beer with each meal, the 52yearold director of the Wild Bunch, The Getaway, and Straw Dogs has been a teetotaler for the last eight months.

title: People in Sports
description: O. J. Simpson got some reassuring news yesterday about his blurred vision from the Wilmer Eye Institute of Johns Hopkins University hospital in Baltimore. After being examined by two specialists, Dr. Walter Stark and the institute's director, Dr. A. Edward Muamenee, Simpson's vision was described as nearly perfect. The doctors also found no reason why Simpson could not continue to play football without restrictions. The Buffalo Bills said O. J. woud be back at practice in their Niagara University camp today.

title: Shearson Hayden Plans to Merge With Faulkner Dawkins Concern
description: Two more Wall Street firms, Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. and Faulkner Dawkins & Sullivan Inc., announced merger plans yesterdaycontinuing a securities industry trend that has become particularly pronounced this year.

title: Passer Too Rusty, Claims McVay
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 8Dennis Shaw, after having seemingly gone ahead four days in the Giants' quarterback battle, was placed on waivers today.

title: New Trip Is Planned For Orient Express
description: LONDON, Aug. 8A murderer will strike again on the Orient Express.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The water level in Lake Hopatcong will be kept the same until Nov. I this year to provide a longer recreational season for Morris County residents.

title: MRS. SHERMAN HAIGHT, BOOK COLLECTOR, 88
description: Mrs. Sherman Post Haight, author, rare book collector, aviation enthusiast and a student of Indian cultures, died yesterday in her home in Litchfield, Conn., after a short illness. She was 88 years old.

title: Apples Lose to Lobsters
description: The Apples got an upset victory by Billie Jean King over Martina Navratilova, but the Boston Lobsters got a, 2824 victory over the New York Apples for a commanding 2game lead in the Eastern Division of World Team Tennis. Page 40.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Syntex Settles Claim Of $986.000 With I.R.S.
description: The Syntex Corporation said that an Internal Revenue Service Claim for the company's fiscal years 1970 and 1971 had been settled for $986,000. Originally, the I.R.S. had proposed deficiencies in Syntex's United States's taxes of $8.5 million for the two years.

title: Market Place
description: The General Motors Corporation apparently disappointed shareholders late last Tuesday by declaring its usual 85cent dividend after reporting secondquarter profits of $1 billion, the largest quarterly result ever for an industrial manufacturing company.

title: Fluor Unit Contract
description: The Fluor Corporation said a subsidiary had been awarded contracts for about $42 million to design and construct a 45megawatt electric geothermal plant to be built at Heber, Calif. The facility is scheduled to begin operation in 1980 but is contingent on receipt of Federal and other funding.

title: Humor and Emotion Prevail As Cooperstown Inducts 6
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8A surprisingly youthful  looking Ernie Banks, who spent all his 19 major league seasons with the Chicago Cubs, was one of six players inducted this morning into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Belco Pollution Unit Gets Treatment Contract
description: The Belco Pollution Control Corporation said its water and waste division had been awarded a multiimillion contract for the design and assembly of a complete water treatment system for the Cajun Electric Power Cooperative Inc. in New Roads, La.

title: Advertising
description: National Airlines, whose former Fly Me advertising campaign won it enormous attention, as well as enormous animosity from many feminist organizations, will begin a new campaign next week that is strictly noncontroversial. In fact, it's downright homey.

title: Beame Drops Plan to Abolish the Board of Education
description: Mayor Beam, in a major shift from his proposal that the New York City Board of Education be abolished, recommended yesterday that it be retained, but with the Mayor appointing its members, and that its chairman serve as a salaried Schools Chancellor.

title: FIVE INDICTED IN SCHEME FOR CHEATING CITIBANK
description: Five businessmen were indicted in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on charges of defrauding Citibank of $1.6 million through the use of forged savings hank passbooks that were submitted as collateral to obtain corporate loans.

title: POLANSKI GUILTY PLEA ACCEPTED IN SEX CASE
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 8Roman Polanski, the film director, pleaded guilty today in Superior Court here to one felony count of unlawful sexual intercourse with a 13yearold girl.

title: Vilas Triumphs Over Tanner In Net Final
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug 8When he finally loses a tennis match and gets a chance to take a day off, Guillermo Vitas will work on his movie screenplay, edit a new poetry collection, mail monthold letters to friends and stock up on his stereo cassettes from a list already onemile lone in his diary.

title: Roosevelt
description: FIRST$7,500, pace, cl., mile.

title: 3 BLACKS IN SOWETO SHOT AS BOYCOTT IS ENFORCED
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 (UPI)Three blacks were wounded by police gunfire in Soweto today as youths tried to enforce a boycott of allblack schools. The police said 12 black youths were arrested.

title: Silk Receives Loeb Award
description: Leonard Silk, an economic columnist for The New York Times, has been named the 1977 recipient of the Gerald Loeb Memorial Award for distinguished business and financial journalism. The prize, $1,500, has been given since 1974 by the graduate school of management of the University of California at Los Angeles. The three previous recipients of the award were Joseph Livingston of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Vermont Royster of The Wall Street Journal and John McDonald of Fortune magazine.

title: Questions and Answers on Carter's Amnesty Plan for Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Should illegal aliens be granted amnesty by the United States?

title: Slow Progress in Fastnet Race
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 8 (AP)The Fastnet Race fleet, which left Cowes on Saturday in the final race for the Admiral's Cup, was still making very poor progress in lighttovariable winds tonight. In the early evening the leaders were reported to be still about 130 miles from the Fastnet Rock, off southern Ireland, where they will turn to race to the finish in Plymouth.

title: MONDALE DISCLOSES PROGRAM TO TIGHTEN F.B.I. AND C.I.A. CURBS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 8Vice President Mondale said today that a new set of regulations for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency being prepared by the Cater Administration would require warrants for all wiretaps, searches and mail opening.

title: Schlesinger Bids Senate Tighten Tax on Inefficient Cars and Industrial Use of Oil and Gas
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 8The Carter Administration called on the Senate today to strengthen its energy program by tightening the tax on automobiles that get poor gasoline mileage and the taxes on the use of oil and natural gas by industry.

title: RAILROAD LINE SABOTAGED ON BRIDGE NEAR SALISBURY
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 8 (AP)Saboteurs blew up a section of track on a railway bridge outside Salisbury today, halting trains to points north and west of the capital, the police said. No injuries were reported.

title: Pearl Harbor Visits Change
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 8 (AP)Navy boats carried a record monthly high of 71,025 visitors to the Pearl Harbor Arizona Memorial in July, the Navy said today. That was about 3,700 more than the previous high month set in July last year. Six commercial ships carried 53,469 additional visitors to Pearl Harbor last month, about 12,000 below the highest monthly total for commercial ships.

title: Notes on People
description: The Russian ballerina Natalya Makarova will be bowing out of ballet for a whileshe is expecting her first child in February of next year. The ballerina, who in private life is Mrs. Edward Karkar of San Francisco, is currently on tour in Europe and will make her final appearances before the child is due when she is guest star with the Scottish Ballet at the Edinburgh Festival this month. She expects to be able to resume her dancing career next spring.

title: C.B.O.E. Tests Wings For Further Growth
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange, founded onApril 26, 1973 and, despite its remarkable success, often considered only as an esoteric adjunct to the securities business is planning major moves to become a major factor in that business.

title: The Good, the Best and Welfare Reform
description: First, let us clear the record. In recent months we have sharply criticized President Carter for his pinched approach to welfare reform. When he said he was determined to achieve reform, but without any increase spending, we were left wondering about either his sincerity or his arithmetic. When he refuseddespite campaign pledgesFederal relief to burdened places like New York, the intimations seemed to us callous, even punitive. In his newly disclosed reform plan, Mr. Carter has altered course on both points. He deserves credit for doing so and greater credit for the way he has done so. His plan in theseand many other respects as wellturns out to be bold, intelligent and humane.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 9, 1977

title: Dud Bomb Discovered in Midtown In Building Targeted by F.A.L.N.
description: An unexploded bomb was discovered yesterday in one of the buildings mentioned as a target last Wednesday by telephone callers who said they were speaking for the Puerto Rican terrorist group known as the F.A.L.N. Two bombs exploded that day, killing one man and injuring seven other persons, and dozens of bomb threats led to massive evacuations of office workers.

title: Father Who Sued Over Respirator Sentenced in Beating Death of Gir
description: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 8 (AP)A man who filed suit earlier this year to prevent doctors from removing his stepdaughter from a respirator has been sentenced to five years to life for fatally beating the child.

title: The Lance Connection
description: The more we learn about the personal and business financial deals of Bert Lance, the nation's budget director, the greater the burden of proof upon him that these were well within the bounds of propriety as well law. The coincidence of a $3.4 million personal loan from a Chicago bank and the transfer to it of considerable business by Mr. Lance's former employer, the National Bank of Georgia, appears to have been a reenactment of a prior coincidence of a $2.6 million personal loan and a shift of business to the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York. The terms of the loans were prudent in Mr. Lance's view, generous the view of some experienced businessmen. from a Chicago bank and the transfer to it of considerable business by Mr. Lance's former employer, the National Bank of Georgia, appears to have been a reenactment of a prior coincidence of a $2.6 million personal loan and a shift of business to the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York. The terms of the loans were prudent in Mr. Lance's view, generous the view of some experienced businessmen.

title: North Carolina Town, Site of Labor Bill Hearing, Is Focus of Union Battle for Recognition at Stevens
description: ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C., Aug. 8.This quiet, green, Southern textile town of 14,000 people is the test locale for the value c f a labor law reform bill that organized labor regards as the key to sewing the union label on the booming and still largely nonunion South.

title: Article 5  No Title
Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 8Federal environmental officials said today that radioactivity concentrations in air, water and milk in the state had remained constant during the last two years or had decreased.

title: Diplomacy Gets Errant Diplomats to Pay Their Unpai Bills
description: New York, City has managed to get foreign diplomats and governments to pay more than $750,000 in unpaid bills that New York businessmen had been dunning them for, a municipal official disclosed this week.

title: Canadian Air Mail and Passengers Delayed in Controllers' Walkout
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 8Canadian airlines continued today to reroute thousands of passengers through United States airports in border cities, sometimes with long and arduous lelays in the second day of a strike by Canadian air controllers.

title: STEEL OUTPUT DECLINED LAST WEEK BY 0.4 OF 1%
description: Steel production fell to 2,294,000 net tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of fourtenths of 1 percent from the preceding week's 2,303,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

title: A Reuther Wedding, Krishna Style, in a Palace by Fisher
description: DETROIT  Like Kubla Khan in Xanadu, Lawrence P. Fisher had a pleasure palace built in 1929. However, the automobile magnate's place with its gardens and, fountains, its huge pseudoMoorish rooms with painted ceilings and pillars inlaid with gold (not to mention a swimming pool, bowling alley, miniature golf course and boat dock for his 100foot yacht) was setin East Detroit, an area that began to deteriorate after the Depression. His dream of an earthly paradise disappeared with the real estate slump.

title: ROSS LEWIS
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 8 (AP)  Ross Lewis, retired editorial cartoonist for The Milwaukee Journal who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1935, died Saturday in a hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Drought in Mexico Threatens to Bring Shortages of Food
description: CIUDAD OBREGON, Mexico, Aug. 8 (AP)The drought that is parching large areas of the United States has moved south into Mexico, sharply reducing water supplies in the northwest farmlands and threatening to bring nationwide food shortages.

title: Stocks Tumble Amid Fear Of Fed Tightening Credit
description: Fears of further credittightening moves by the Federal Reserve yesterday hammered the Dow Jones industrial average down to its lowest closing level since early January of 1976.

title: U.S. TREASURY ISSUES UP SLIGHTLY IN PRICE
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly yesterday despite the widespread belief that the Federal Reserve is likely to push interest rates higher in the near future.

title: Conviction of Rio Rancho Affirmed
description: Rio Rancho Estates lost another legal battle yesterday when a Federal appeals court affirmed the company's conviction in a major fraud case involving a scheme to sell $200 million of land in New Mexico.

title: Redskins Beat Browns On Moseley's Late Kick
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 (UPI)Mark Moseley, who missed an extra point try and field goal attempts of 38 and 42 yards earlier in the game, booted a 29yard field goal with 20 seconds left tonight that gave the Washington Redskins a 1614 victory over the Cleveland Browns in their first National Football League preseason game.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 9, 1977

title: Elli Marcus, Photographer Of Theatrical Subjects, 77
description: Elli Marcus, a theatrical photographer who began in her native Berlin with such subjects as Max Reinhardt, Bertolt Brecht and Marlene Dietrich, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived at 5 East 82d Street.

title: About New York
description: New York is a bookish city: three public library systems, a clutch of fine private ones, scores of publishers, armies of writers, unnumbered bookstores. If people do not come to New York to read, they often come here to write and to be read. It may not be by chance that handwriting on the wall is a New York specialty.

title: Doing Something About the Weather
description: The nation's weather has been extraordinary in most regions this year. Extreme cold imposed one pattern hardship. Now drought imposes another. It may seem hard to believe, but it has been worse in past years and it will be even worse in future years.

title: Major League Scores
description: DPDetroit 4. LOBMilwaukee 7, Detrait 10. 2BWockentuss, Thompson, Vcryzer, Moore. HRThompson (19). SBLeFlore.

title: Joseph Durso
description: Louis Clark Brock stole into town yesterday in pursuit of the sprinting ghost of Tyrus Raymond Cobb, and gaining fast. In his illustrious career, which began in 1905 and ended in 1928, Cobb stole a record total of 892 bases. his illustrious career, which began in 1961, Brock has stolen 886 basesjust six fewer.

title: JOHNSTOWN FAMILIES AWAIT A MOVE TO MOBILE HOMES
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 8 (AP)An estimated 2,000 families are still living with relatives and friends three weeks after they were forced to flee their homes in the area's third killer flood in a century.

title: Radio
description: 78 AM, WNCN. Nocturne in Ella, Chopin; Caprice Viennois, Kreisler: Symphony No. 12, Mozart; Prelude for Solo Violin, Enesco; Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring, Bach; Norwegian Dance No. 3, Grieg.

title: MONDALE DISCLOSES PROGRAM TO TIGHTEN F.B.I. AND C.I.A. CURBS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 8Vice President Mondale said today that a new set of regulations for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency being prepared by the Carter Administration would require warrants for all wiretaps, searches and mail opening.

title: Neither Mud nor Rain Stays Scout Mailman
description: MORAINE STATE PARK, Pa., Aug. 8 (AP)Neither mud nor rain nor makeshift addresses can stop the mail at the National Boy Scout Jamboree, which was hit by three inches of rain over the weekend. Some of the Scouts had to move to higher camping sites.

title: TAKEOVER REPRIEVE ENDED FOR BABCOCK
description: Babcock & Wilcox's temporary reprieve from the United Technologies Corporation takeover, granted last Friday by an Ohio court, has proved indeed to be temporary.

title: Suit of ICN Dismissed
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. said that a Federal Court in Brooklyn, N.Y. had dismissed a suit against it as being without merit.

title: Coyotes and Coast Suburbanites Wage ModernDay Range War
description: LA CANADA, Calif., Aug. 8Sin, a black cat owned by John Weyl, a La Canada lawyer, disappeared the other day. And Mr. Weyl is sure that Sin suffered the same fate as Erin, his 9yearold Shetland sheepdog.

title: C.I.A., in a Report to a Congressional Committee, Predicts an Economic Slowdown in Soviet Union
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)The Central Intelligence Agency is forecasting a slowdown in the Soviet Union's economic growth in the 1980's, partly because of a predicted oil shortage.

title: Around the Nation
description: RAINIER, Ore., Aug. 8 (UPI)Eightyone demonstrators who had vowed to camp on the Trojan Nuclear Plant grounds until the facility was shut down were arrested today when they refused an order to leave the Portland General Electric Company.

title: Begin Is Adamant on Palestinians As Vance Hints at a Shift by P.L.O.
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 8Prime Minister Menahem Begin served notice today, on the eve of the arrival in Jerusalem of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, that it would be futile to prepare a role for the Palestine Liberation Organization Middle East peace talks by trying to make the P.L.O. recognize Israel.

title: Cards Beat Mets, 42, on Reitz's Homer in Ninth
description: The Great Dane was rough enough on the Mets last night. And when the St. Louis Cardinals brought on the Mad Hungarian and the Zamboni Machine, they proved much too much, and the New Yorkers went to their third straight defeat. 42.

title: Article 4  No Title
BRUNO AVOIDS LINKS TO CASINOS, HE SAYS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 8Angelo Bruno, regarded by lawenforcement officials as the head of organized crime in Philadelphia and South Jersey, insisted today that he wanted to stay away from Atlantic City with the approach of legalized gambling there.

title: 150 PRISONERS SEIZE 14 IN ULSTER COUNTY
description: NAPANOCH, N.Y., Aug. 8About 150 inmates armed with clubs and other makeshift weapons seized 14 hostages and a wing of the Eastern Correctional Facility here this morning, but the rebels released the last of their hostages and surrendered peacefully tonight after a 12hour seige.

title: Books of The Times
description: This is what happens when a coal miner from West Virginia comes to Cambridge, Mass., to look for his runaway son in Harvard Square: Children passed him on all sides, shaking moisture from their hair. Children dressed in leather in silk and velour, in denim work clothes. Children with hiplength hair and beards, with designs painted on their faces, with beads and boots and feathers. Too many children. They were like a different people here, a different race. They had their own stores, their own newspapers, their own radio stations playing from the shop windows.... Hunter felt that there were too many, too many to ever pick one out as his own ... The children passed him, a cityful of them, and he had never felt so lost in his life.

title: ANDRUS CHANGES VIEWS ON ALASKA NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)Interior Secretary Cecil Andrus said ?? El Paso Alaska Company proposal, to transport North Slope natural gas through Alaska to the United States could cost $1 billion less than another plan that he had already supported.

title: Teachers Penalized for a Strike; Judge Terms Students Hostages
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 9 (AP)Students were hostages of a teachers' organization that staged a fourday strike in June, a judge said yesterday in fining the group $4,500 and ordering its leader jailed.

title: Condominium Campsites Offered As Vacation Home Alternatives
description: VERNON TOWNSHIP, Aug. 9Condominium camping, an alternative to owning a vacation home, is gaining popularity in New Jersey.

title: Inflation and TaxesWiden Appraisal of Art Objects
description: Apparently the itch is part of ownership. Whether it's a company with Norman Rockwell originals gracing its lobby or a brewery executive captivated by his private collection of 17thcentury beer steins, almost always there is curiosity to discover what the prized possessions would bring in cash.

title: U.S. Airports on Border Bustle to Provide a Substitute
description: ROMULUS, Mich., Aug. 9  United States airports along the Canadian border have emerged as key links in the airline industry's effort to continue offering travelers to and from Canada some sort of makeshift service during a strike by Canadian air traffic controllers.

title: Letters
description: New York City's second blackout in 11 years has antitechnology elements of our society calling for a change in our way of life. Our problem lies in our past, not in our technology.

title: Blumenthal Says Energy Incentives Are Adequate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Carter Administration, in a second day of chilly, even hostile questioning by the Senate Finance Committee, defended its energy Bill today against charges that it failed to provide adequate incentives for production and conservation.

title: A Glass Adds More Than Class
description: Imagine, if you can, the righteous indignation that would be registered by a wine connoisseur to whom a rare vintage burgundy or bordeaux was served in an oldfashioned glass or a highball tumbler. But let a whisky drinker name his poison in one of the city's tonier, Continental restaurants. and chances are it will be served in a wine glass, and generally in a wide, roundbowled one at that

title: Comptroller Is Said To Broaden Inquiry Into Lance Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Comptroller of the Currency has broadened his investigation of Budget Director Bert Lance's finances to include a wide range of activities by two banks that he headed in Georgia, as well as loans that he received from major banks, sources close to the investigation said here today.

title: C.I.A. Head Offers DrugTest Files If Justice Department Has Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Mm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that he would make all the records of. the Central Intelligence Agency's drugtesting activities available to the Department of Justice if it decided that an investigation into any aspect of the matter is warranted.

title: Canada's Lower House Orders Air Controllers to End Strike
description: OTTAWA, Wednesday Aug. 10 (Reuters) The Canadian House of Commons early this morning passed a bill ordering 2,200 airtraffic controllers to end a strike that has brought the country's air services to a virtual halt.

title: Anger Replaced By Resignation In Canal Zone
description: BALBOA, Canal Zone, Aug. 9Some of their grandfathers helped build the canal, many of them were born here themselves, most feel that the Canal Zone is more home to them than any part of the United States.

description: MONDAY'S GAMES

title: Police Begin Distributing New Drawing of .44 Killer
description: The New York City police yesterday began widespread distribution of a new drawing and a revised, moredetailed description of the elusive .44caliber killer who calls himself Son of Sam.

title: 4,000 Apply for 2,000 Cleanup Jobs Before the Cutoff
description: More than 4,000 applications were collected yesterday for the 2,000 jobs available in the federally financed blackout cleanup project before city officials halted registration late in the day.

title: STOCK MARKET ENDS INDECISIVE SESSION WITH SOME GAINS
description: Computer stocks and selected issues moved higher yesterday in an indecisive market. The Dow Jones industrial average, as if underscoring the market's uncertainty, finished without change at 879.42.

title: Article 2  No Title
Monmouth
description: RESULTS

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm plans to get married during the Thanksgiving holidays to Arthur Hardwick Jr. of Brooklyn, an architectural designer. The Brooklyn Democrat and Mr. Hardwick, who got engaged July 4, have known each other since the mid1960's, when both served in the New York State Assembly. Mrs. Chisholm. 52. years old, was divorced in February from Conrad Chisholm, her husband of 28 years. It was done rather discreetly, said Mrs. Chisholm. Irreconcilable differences: politics was just a small part of it Mrs. Chisholm, who is sporting a new engagement ring, was both surprised and sardonic about the interest in her personal life, but said she was happy.

title: G.S.A. Challenged for Removing Plaque Honoring 1874 Cannibal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture, demanded today to know what legal justification the General Services Administration had for removing the dedication plaque from the department's grill, newly named in honor of Alferd Packer, who was convicted of killing and eating five Colorado prospectors in 1874.

title: German Antinuclear Squatters Leave
description: BROKDORF, West Germany, Aug. 9 (Reuters)The police cleared about 50, protesting squatters from a nuclear power station site here today. The squat. ters, who had been living in tents, evacuated the camp within 45 minutes and marched to Brokdorf to hold a rally. Brokdorf was the scene of clashes between protesters and the police last May. A district court later ordered the project temporarily halted.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 9Dr. T. Edward Hollander, former deputy commissioner for higher and professional education in New York State, was sworn in today as Chancellor of Higher Education in New Jersey.

title: The $1.67 Deterrent
description: Is the prospect of paying $1.67 in civil damages sufficient to deter a President, Attorney General or F.B.I. agent from violating the privacy of American citizens? District Judge John Lewis Smith Jr. of Washington evidently thinks so. He has ordered Richard Nixon, H. Haldeman and John Mitchell to make a joint payment of $5 to the five members of the family of Morton Halperin, whose home telephones they had tapped for 21 months beginning in May 1969. Mr. Halperin was then a member of the staff of the National Security Council suspected of leaking secrets to the press.

title: Norton Simon Lifts Dividend 27% as Quarterly Earnings Climb 9.3%
description: Norton Simon Inc., a major international consumer marketing company, closed its fiscal year June 30 with earnings exceeding the $100 million mark for the first time, and directors yesterday increased the quarterly dividend by 27 percent to 19 cents a share from 15 cents.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Jazz: John Clark Horns In At Sweet Basil
description: THE FRENCH HORN, because of its nature and its history, has not yet found a notable place in jazz. Its distant, woodsy sound has limited it to little more than atmospheric coloration in jazz performances, while any innovativejazz uses of the horn have been conditioned by the fact that horn players are almost invariably classicly trained and oriented and, at best, play it peripherally in jazz situations.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE AND BREEZY One music critic has called the drumming of Chico Hamilton a contemporary groove that combines rock rhythms, blues, a little bit of Latin and some incredible musicianship. Mr. Hamilton's pulsating rhythms, backed by the, music of the group called the Players, may be heard, starting at 4:30 this afternoon, against the backdrop of Rockefeller Center's Exxon Park, between 49th and 50th Streets (west of Avenue of the Americu). The Jazz bour brings to a close this summer's Music for a City Evening series produced by Town Hall. Rain date: tomorrow.

description: Theater

title: Bar Group Urges Help for Grand Jury Witnesses
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9The American Bar Association urged Congress and the states today to adopt a broad program of grand jury changes aimed at curbing abuses by prosecutors and providing more protection for witnesses.

title: Young, in Costa Rica, Upholds Human Rights Drive
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 9Andrew Young upheld the Carter Administration's strong advocacy of human rights here today, insisting national boundaries and sovereignty become less important when human need cries out.

title: Government Says Laetrile Tests Found Drug Was Contaminated
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Federal Government stepped up its attack today on the use of the purported anticancer drug laetrile with the nation's chief medical officer warning that recent samples of the compound were contaminated.

title: SOUTHWEST AFRICAN JOINS TALKS HERE WITH THE WEST
description: The independence leader who once refused to attend meetings aimed at a peaceful settlement in SouthWest Africa, has changed his mind and is involved in such talks here.

title: Business Sees Lawyers as Necessary Evil
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9Invited by the bar to offer their views of lawyers, several prominent Chicago businessmen today acted as a blueribbon grand jury, handing up what amounted to an indictment of the profession. They found lawyers overpriced, pedantic, too talkative, too combative and not adequately concerned with the goals of their clients.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL UPHOLDS THE PORT AUTHORITY ON $1.50 BRIDGE TOLLS
description: The Federal Highway Administrator, William M. Cox, yesterday upheld the $1.50 toll imposed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey two years ago on all Port Authority bridges and tunnels linking New York and New Jersey. He also upheld the authority's practice of using the bridge tolls to support lessprofitable authority facilities.

title: Primary Roundup
description: More movies and television films should be made in New York City, Bella S. Abzug said yesterday.

title: $40,000 in Cellar Helps to Buy Bar in Atlantic City
description: TRENTON, Aug. 9A bag of $40,000 in currency hidden in a cellarpart of a friend to friend loan of $50,000 unsecured by any formally signed papersfigturd in tangled financial arrangements that led to the purchase early this year of a bar and discotheque in Atlantic City.

title: 3 Types of Trees Periled By Blights of Scale Insects
description: Three of North America's most important treesthe hemlock, red pine and beechare threatened by spreading blights of scale insects.

title: Uruguayan Military Pledges Return to Civilian Rule and a 1981 Election
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 9 (AP)The militarycontrolled Government of Uruguay announced tonight that it would return the nation to civilian rule through general elections in 1981 for a president and congress.

title: Golf
description: AT CINCINNATI

title: Letter: On Unemployment Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title: Costa Rica at a Glance
description: HISTORY  It was Columbus who in 1502 gave Costa Rica its name, which means rich coast. The name apparently same from the lush forests covering more than half the country, rather than from any great quantities of gold and silver, which attracted the Conquistadors to lier parts of Latin America. As a result, the country was virtually ignored by early Spanish empire builders. In 1821, Costa Rica declared its independence from Spain. After several years as part of the Confederation of Central America, the country became a separate republic in 1838. In 1889, Costa Rica had what has been called the first truly free election in Central America, establishing its strong democratic tradition. However, the country has experienced a number of shortlived dictatorships and some strife, including a brief civil war in 1948.

title: 18,000 in Nagasaki Note Anniversary of ABomb
description: NAGASAKI, Japan, Aug. 9 (AP)A crowd estimated st 18,000 atttended a solemn ceremony today in the Nagasaki Peace Park to mark the 32d anniversary of the United States' atomic bombing of this southern Japanese city.

title: Traveling With Children: How to Set the Pace
description: Our daughter, Rebecca, asked us recently, with considerable wonder in her 6yearold voice, why some people live in one place most of their lives. Then they never travel to new places and see new things, she said.

title: Israel Studies Military Changes
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 9 (Reuters)A special joint committee of army and Defense Ministry officials has been appointed to oversee a reorganization of the Israeli Army, Defense Minister Ezer Weizman announced.

title: F.B.I. Considers Disciplining Agents in Las Vegas Accused of Taking Favors From Casino Interests
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Clarence M. Kelley, is considering possible disciplinary action against a number of agents in the Las Vegas, Nev., field office, following allegations that they had accepted free meals and other gratuiities from owners and operators of gambling casinos there, a bureau spokesman said today.

title: Beame Cites Con Ed Omission in Blackout Report
description: Mayor Beame accused the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday of a glaring omission in the company's chronology of events before and after the blackout of July 1314, which was Issued on July 26.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHILE some American writers of fiction seem to hunger for an instantaneous professionalism with their first novel or story, there is a kind of English author who, even after publishing several wellreceived novels, appears to be trying to maintain the tone and manner of a gentleman amateur, the sort of person who regards writing fiction seriously almost as a rather sordid or vulgar act. I can think of good English novels so understated that one feels that the author wrote them apologetically, giving in to a slightly shamefaced eccentricity, a habit of going on about people to an unconscionable degree.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Ownership of the 754mile TransArabian Pipeline, called Tapline, will revert to four American oil companies when Saudi Arabia completes its takeover of the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco), the Middle East Economic Survey reported yesterday.

title: Only an Unintentional Irony Marks Anniversary of Nixon's Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9It was an anniversary marked only by an ironic ceremony that had not even been planned for the occasion.

title: Mets and Espinosa Stifle Cards, 41
description: It's been almost two months since Tom Seaver was traded by the New York Mets to the Cincinnati Reds. And last night Manager Joe Torre enjoyed a. fringe benefit of that deal, something other than the acquisition of Steve Henderson, the left fielder Mets' fans have been growing to love.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Aug. 9 (Reuters)People in a resort area southwest of here rushed for cover today to escape a hail of rocks and ash as fresh eruptions of a nearby volcano hurled flames thousands of feet into the air.

title: STOCK FRAUD IS LAID TO 2 L.I. BUSINESSMEN
description: Two businessmen from Long Island were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges that they had conspired to defraud the public in the 1972 sale of $1.9. million of stock in now defUnct Airways Enterprises Inc.
