description: AT INDIANAPOLIS

title: The Greatest Day Baseball Has
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 9All weekend, the Otesaga Hotel and the shaded streets had crawled with autograph buffs in assorted sizes. Monday morning was hot and sultry, but long before 10 o'clock every chair on the lawn of Cooper Park was occupied and so was every foot of standing room behind the Baseball Hall of Fame. The folding chairs and the crowds behind them faced a platform of new lumber with a corral behind, the stage where whippersin were herding demigods into two meandering queues. At a signal, the living legends filed up to take their seats on the platform. Cheering started with the first arrival. It went on and on, swelling in volume as the stage filled. Cheers used to be meat and drink to the men in the queues, but Burleigh Grimes doesn't hear much applause these days in Holcombe, Wis., nor Fred Lindstrom in New Port Richey, Fla.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, August 10, 1977

title: H.U.D. Withholding Aid for Areas On L.I. That Do Not House Poor
description: By withholding $8.2 million in community improvement funds for 25 Suffolk County towns and municipalities, the Carter Administration yesterday made good its threat to get tough with suburbs that refuse to build housing for poor people.

title: Bridge:
description: The duplicate game, in which small profits are often of great importance, offers the defenders some chances for deception that would avail them nothing in rubber bridge or team play. If a declarer can be led to think that an overtrick is available to him, he may be induced to jeopardize his contract with fatal results. This happened on the diagramed deal played in the last Blue Ribbon pair championshp during the Fall Nationals in Pittsburgh.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of the Franklin Life Insurance Company jumped from 24 last Thursday in overthecounter trading to yesterday's close of 27 bid, the gains in response to the purchase by American Brands of the Continental Insurance Company's 27 percent interest in the 10th largest stockholderowned life insurer at $30.50 a share.

title: WITNESSES DENOUNCE TACTICS OF STEVENS
description: ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C., Aug. 9A succession of more than 30 witnesses paraded before a Congressional panel in this Southern textile town today to tell Congressmen that without a tightening of the nation's labor laws, unions would remain unable to breach the wall of economic terrorism set up by what several witnesses referred to as the Southern antilabor conspiracy.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A lack of interest and poor written examination scores by minority group members have forced the New Jersey state police to reopen recruit testing to meet minority hiring goals.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: BERLINJoerg Eipel, West Germany, awarded European welterweight title when Joerg Hansen, Denmark, the champion, was disqualified for butting, 13 rounds.

title: JOHN HELLMER JENTZ
description: Dr. John Hellmer Jentz, chief attending physician in obstetrics and gynecology at Christ Hospital, Jersey City, until his retirement in 1962, died Aug. 1 in Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass., after a brief illness. He lived in South Wellfleet, Mass., and was 77 years old.

title: Technology
description: The success of a project being built in Astoria, Queens, could open the way to a new method of importing large amounts of energy into urban areas that can neither build many new power plants nor find new rights of way for overhead highvoltage lines. Page D8.

title: Northern Ireland, Awaiting Jubilee Visit by the Queen, Erupts in Violence Fatal to Two
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 9A 16yearold Roman Catholic boy and a British soldier were killed in sporadic violence today on the eve of the first visit to Northern Ireland by Queen Elizabeth II in more than a decade.

title: WEEDEN AND WAINWRIGHT SET ACQUISITION ACCORD
description: The Weeden Holding Corporation and shareholders and management of Wainwright Securities Inc., a small institutional researchoriented brokerage firm, jointly announced yesterday that they had agreed to terms for the proposed acquisition of Wainwright Securities by Weeden, a major third market brokerage firm.

title: E. E. Kleinschmidt, Teletype's Inventor, Dies in Connecticut
description: Edward E. Kleinsclunidt, creator of the highspeed Teletype machineconsidered a major breakthrough in communications when it was introduced in 1914died Tuesday at a nursing home in Canaan, Conn. He was 101 years old.

title: Sen. Church Meets With Castro In Visit Said to Be Ceremonial
description: HAVANA, Aug. 9 (Reuters)President Fidel Castro gave Senator Frank Church a particularly warm welcome to Cuba today, talking to him for several hours and driving him on a sightseeing tour of Havana in his jeep.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: The Sporting Life

title: Bennett College Shut As Result of Finances
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP)Bennett College, a former finishing school for girls in this Dutchess County community, closed today because of financial problems.

title: In Sporting Saratoga Springs, The Good Life Isn't Easy
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9It's true that some people think that living rich is living easy, but goodness only knows where they get that idea. Chauffeurs, butlers, bank accounts, horses, oil, real estate and other sundries can't buy stamina, and without it, one might just as well be poor. In fact, without it here, one could hardly survive the cheek kissing, let alone the season.

title: N.H.L. Governors Turn Down Merger With 6 W.H.A. Teams
description: After five years of being simultaneously wooed and wounded by the World Hockey Association, the National Hockey League's 18member board of governors yesterday rejected a merger with the rival W.H.A. The actual rejection came in the form of a vote against expansion.

title: Private Lives
description: DMITRI SITS on the sun deck of the mountain cabin, listening to his skin peel. He does not tan; he rots. The sundeck looks down on a creek. Bravely, the creek keeps on trickling, although it seems not to have rained in these mountains since Nixon went to China. They have tried to darn the creek. Why, Dmitri's son was asked, are you building a dam? Because it isn't there. Dmitri's son replied. Dmitri's son has hired some new writers for the summer.

title: Tire Blast Stirs Israeli Airport
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 9 (AP)A loud explosion on the tarmac minutes before Secretary of State Cyrus A. Vance's arrival today sent armed border police racing to the scene. The bang came from a tire on an aircraft stairway that exploded in the 86degree heat.

title: Panama Canal Negotiators Seeking Accord Today
description: PANAMA, ug. 9Negotiating teams for the United States and Panama continued marathon sessions today amid strict security in an effort to work out their differences over a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: The Which, Why and What of Whisky
description: Most of us drink blended whisky and would never admit that we do not know precisely what that means. We buy our Scotch and our Irish, our Canadian, and lately our American Light based on our individual tastes, our responses to advertising appeals, or in imitation of what wellregarded friends drink. Which is the why of the whisky business.

title: Maxwell Balfour, Pilot,82; Aviators' Friend, Official Of Spartan Aircraft Co.
description: Maxwell Balfour, who began his career as an airplane pilot in World War is and ended it with his retirement in 1961 as director of the aviation division of the Spartan Aircraft Company, died Monday in Tulsa, Okla. He was 82 years old.

title: Move to Bulldoze Cape Town Shanties Spurs Battle
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Aug. 9The South African Government's move to oust 26,000 black squatters near this coastal city provoked bitter clashes today when the police used dogs and tear gas to rout blacks trying to disrupt demolition of three shantytowns.

title: Red Wins, 114101, In Stokes Basketball
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 9  Red Auberbach, one of the top coaches in the history of the National Basketball Association, notched another victory last night when his Red squad defeated Kevin Loughery's Blue quintet, 114101, in the 19th annual Maurice Stokes benefit basketball game at. Kutsher's Country Club.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: PARIS FOR MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV, the odd thing about discovering himself to be a great American ballet star in Europe isn't the fact but the question.

title: TV: The Western Riding Into View
description: THE WESTERN is riding back into the gold country of primetime television, although at a slow gallop. In their search for new forms of actionadventure shows to take the place of the police and detective melodramas that have predominated in this decade, NBC, ABC and CBS all are tentatively reaching, back to a genre that has been a staple of the medium from its earliest days.

title: Illegal Immigration Called Threat To Hopes for Population Stability
description: The economic consequences of illegal immigration into the United States have attracted a great deal of attention, but the influx may also have important demographic implications. Some population organizations fear that a continued high revel of immigration will, as one publication put it recently, cancel the benefits of our declining fertility and difficult, if not impossible, for the country to achieve a stationary population.

title: Two Deaths on Long Island Rans: Was the Second a Lover's Suicide?
description: Late in the afternoon of Saturday, July, 30, Donald Byrne was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train. Eight days later the woman he loved, Lorraine Scheele, died. She was killed by a train driven by the same engineer, at the same time on a fading summer day and practically on the same spot at the Massapequa Park station.

title: About Education
description: The first major erosion has taken place in the conditions under which the City University of New York accepted the imposition of tuition.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS BILL ENDING FARMERS' TAX
description: SENECA CASTLE, N.Y., Aug. 9Governor Carey whirled through four upstate counties today, greeting people who toil in industry and folks who till the earth, and promising everyone a better economy in New York State.

title: HELEN RUSKELL
description: Helen Ruskell, assistant librarian at the New York Society Library, 53 East 79th Street, for 23 years, died Monday in University Hospital after a short illness. She lived at 49 East 73d Street, and was 74 years old.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHILE most restaurants are content to do very little about wineother than overcharge for ita small but growing number of alert restaurateurs are going out of their way to bring their customers and wine closer together.

title: About Real Estate
description: NEWARKThe first strip shopping center with onsite parking ever to be built in Newark has gone into construction, to the considerable pleasure of economic development officials.

title: F.C.C. Is Upheld on Telpak Rates
description: The Federal Appeals Court in Washington D.C. has affirmed a Federal Cornmunications Commission order holding that rates that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company charged for a portion of its Telpak services were discriminatory.

title: PANEL FEARS VOGUE FOR THE PARANORMAL
description: A group of scientists, philosophers and others, concerned about what they see as a rising tide of uncritical belief in astrology, parapsychology and other scientifically unfounded subjects, warned yesterday that this could lead a gullible populace to accept increasingly pernicious doctrines and virulent programs of dangerous sects.

title: The Dizzy Pace in the Middle East
description: It's been a madcap week for Middle East diplomacy. Secretary of State Vance has been dropping in on Arab capitals seeking recruits for a foreign ministers meeting in place of a Geneva conference made unlikely by Israel's unwillingness to deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization. President Sadat of Egypt favored such a meetingat least until President Assad of Syria rejected it. Meanwhile President Carter weighed in from across the seas with two statements suggesting that the United States would begin to deal with the P.L.O. if it would espouse Resolutions 242 and 338 of the United Nations Security Council and thusat least implicitlyacknowledge Israel's right to exist. Mr. Vance chimed in from Saudi Arabia with the news that his hosts there expected such a softening of the P.L.O's position, whereupon Prime Minister Begin of Israel replied that he would under no circumstances deal with an organization of genocidists... pirates and outlaws. Finally a P.L.O. spokesman in Lebanon contended that his organization had all along been willing to participate in Middle East negotiations on the basis of the United Nations resolutions provided they were revised to specify that the Palestinians are not simply refugees but a nation in their own right.

title: Land Developer Says He May Buy Lance's Stock in Atlanta Bank
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 9 (AP)A land developer with a building in almost every major Southern city said today that he had discussed buying Budget Director Bert Lance's stock in an Atlanta bank.

title: Fresh Frozen Yogurt:
description: For some, it's the guiltfree ice cream alternative. For others, it's frozen mush that tastes like mortar and only reminds them of the real ice cream they wish they were eating instead. It's frozen yogurt, and after nearly 10 years on the American scene, like it or not, it's not about to melt itself out of existence.

title: Saratoga Jockeys
HUGHES PROBATE JUDGE, A MORMON, DISQUALIFIED
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 9 (UPI)District Judge Keith Hayes, who has heard virtually every Howard Hughes probate proceeding in Nevada for the past 16 months, was disqualified today on the around of implied bias.

title: Jerseyan Dies After 23Year Coma
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Aug. 9 (UPI)Funeral services were held today for August Muscle, who died Sunday after 23 years in a coma, the result of a 1954 cartrain accident. Mr. Muscle, 57 years old, died in the King James Nursing Nome in Franklin Township. He had been in a coma since he was injured when his car collided with a Jersey Central Railroad train. Mr. Muscle was a welding equipment salesman at the time of the accident.

title: Copley Estate Put at $63 Million
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 9 (AP)The estate of James S. Copley, the late newspaper publisher, has been valued at $63 million. The figure was disclosed by trustees of the James S. Copley Revocable Trust, who said that the report was being filed in San Diego County Superior Court by the state inheritance tax referee. Mr. Copley, chairman of the corporation publishing the Copley newspapers, died Oct.6, 1973.

title: Best Buys
description: COFFEE DRINKERS got some grounds for elation yesterday. The City Department of Consumer Affairs reported that for the first time in nearly three months, the average price of a pound of coffee fell below $4. The average price, $3.96, was 7 cents less than during the preceding week, but still 84 percent above the $2.16 average price last August.

title: Pop: Seeger Sings of Fun and Politics
description: PETE SEEGER made his annual appearance in Central Park at Monday evening's Dr. Pepper Festival, and everything about it was reassuringly familiar. There were children's songs, songs from the labor and civilrights struggles, ballads from folk and popular sources, simple but effective accompaniments on banjo and guitar and a few recorder pieces. The audience, which was unusually heterogeneous in age, seemed to know the words to every song.

title: BEAME IS CRITICIZED ON MINORITY HIRING
description: A key official and other employees of the New York City agency responsible for insuring that businesses receiving contracts from the city have effective minorityhiring programs charged the Beame administration with rapidly backing off from any commitment to aid minorities and women in getting jobs.

title: Cabaret: Julie Budd Sings Easily
description: JULIE BUDD, who is singing at the Rainbow Grill this week, possesses a clear, expressive voice, excellent intonation, and an easy, relaxed way with a musical phrase. Although she is only in her early 20's, she has been performing professionally for 10 years, and the experience shows. The comparisons to Barbra Streisand that have plagued her careerand which, in the beginning at least, were amply justifiedhave begun to seem more and more inappropriate as Miss Budd finds her own style.

title: Blackout Feud Still Stirring
description: Nearly a month after a power failure plunged New York City into a 24hour siege of looting and vandalism, many city politicians are still smoldering over President Carter's failure to declare the city a disaster areaa designation that would presumably entile it to additional emergency assistance. Although the appeal for disaster designation has not formally been ruled upon, Governor Carey has been informed that President Carter was being urged to turn it down. With a formal rejection expected and even signaled by the President himself, however, the issue has become an unusual amalgam of contradictions and confusion, much of it with political overtonesa classic demonstration of coordination attempts by three levels of government that have gone awry, to the embarrassment of many of those involved.

title: Police Plagued by Bomb Threats As Park Ave. Building Is Vacated
description: The police and office workers in Manhattan were still coping with bomb threats yesterday, one of which forced the evacuation of the office building at 445 Park Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets.

title: ISRAELIS TELL VANCE THEY FIRMLY OPPOSE YIELDING TERRITORY
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9Israeli leaders told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Van.ce today that they remained strongly opposed to giving up any territory on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip, to the creation of any Palestinian homeland on Israel's borders and to any part for the Palestine Liberation Organization in an eventual negotiation at Geneva.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Jets Tab White Long Shot for Short Yardage
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug, 9Running six or seven feet in a football ganie isn't hardthe trick is doing it when everyone in the stadium knows that's what you're trying to do.

title: Soybean Futures Climb; Wheat About a Cent Lower While Corn Holds Steady
description: Rumors that Peking had bought soybean oil from European processors helped stabilize futures prices of the bean complex in Chicago yesterday.

title: Eluding the Last Ditch
description: PARISIt used to be said of Stanley Baldwin, the illfated British Tory leader, that his spiritual home was in the last ditch, a location John Vorster, the South African Prime Minister, is desperately trying to stay out of.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Aug, 9, 1977

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ONE SATURDAY EVENING, according Cell Waldrip, an attractive redhaired woman stood on the corner of Broadway and 90th Street, trying futilely to hail a cab.

title: DAYTON HOMES BURN IN STRIKE BY FIREMEN
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 9At least 11 families lost their homes today as three major fires spread uncontrolled while striking Dayton firefighters watched from their picket lines.

title: 50 Volunteers Man the Brooms And Clean Up a Midtown Street
description: A resounding cheer went up from 50 volunteer sanitation workers yesterday as Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarello pulled the cord on a mobile vacuum and it roared to life.

title: Dance: Bit Of Joy on The Streets
description: SREET THEATER now has the atmosphere of guerrilla activity, sniping at our sensibilities when we are otherwise engaged in the routine but essential business of crossing streets to get to the other side. It was not always so, for dancing was commonly found in the streets and in fact that phrase describes a particular type of joy. In the last several years startled New Yorkers have found various companies dancing at their elbows, and Monday afternoon they were introduced to a new one, Battery, directed by Jonathan Hollander, whose Streetmural proved a pleasant interlude in Jeanette Park at 55 Water Street.

title: G.M. Recalls 1,250 New Trucks
description: DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP)About 1,250 Chevrolet and G.M.C. 1977 model lightduty trucks with hydraulic brake boosters were called by the General Motors Corporation today to check for problems with their power brakes. General Motors said some of the nuts attaching the master cylinder to the hydraulic booster unit might have been put in too tightly, causing stripped threads or cracked hydraulic mounting flanges.

title: Two Deaths on Long Island Rails: Was the Second a Lover's Suicide?
description: Late in the afternoon of Saturday, July 30, Donald Byrne was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train. Eight days later the woman he loved, Lorraine Scheele, died. She was killed by a train driven by the same engineer, at the same time on a fading summer day and practically on the same spot at the Massapequa Park station.

title: NonJersey Resorts Seeking Casinos
description: STROUDSBERG, Pa., Aug. 9As the time approaches for the first spin of the roulette wheels in Atlantic City, competing resorts in New Jersey's neighboring states of Pennsylvania and New York are growing increasingly nervous.

title: ForeignControlled Coast Banks Are Charged With Discrimination
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9A coalition of 10 activist organizations today filed a class action antitrust complaint with state officials here against 39 foreigncontrolled banks, each with more than $100 million in assets in California.

title: Advertising
description: One of the fastestgrowing segments of the magazine business these days is the inflight magazine. It shouldn't be surprising therefore to find that a new marketing concept for some of these publications has been developed.

title: Cosmos Oppose Rowdies In Playoff Opener Tonight
description: The North American Soccer League playoffs get under way tonight, and when the first round is over at about midnight four teams will have only next season to look forward to.

title: Texts of Resolutions on Mideast
description: Following are the texts of two United Nations resolutions that are the focus of the talks in the Middle East. Resolution 242 was adopted on Nov. 22, 1967, after the 1967 war, and Resolution 338 was adopted Oct. 22, 1973, after the 1973 Middle East war:

title: From Bronx to Paris, Cameras Are Turning
description: China, the Bronx, Paris and Montana figure prominently in the movie news.

title: Chess:
description: A hot streak of aggressive play can easily go to a player's head, creating a euphoria destructive of objective judgment. He may then continue to charge in slugging even when the indications of a position are against such bold strategy, and thus get his fingers burned.

title: Seattle Slew, Forego to Compete
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP)Owners of Seattle Slew and The Minstrel, considered the world's top 3yearold thoroughbreds, and Forego, horseoftheyear the last three years, accepted invitations today to run their horses in the $200,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course on Nov. 5.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Hamlet Is Young, But Gertrude Is Younger
description: SAN DIEGO IT IS 8 P.M. IN SAN DIEGO. But the dying sunshine and the lute music blur the centuries. Beneath blueandgold banners, Queen Elizabeth I watches a group of peasants play leapfrog on a circle of grass. There are jugglers, acrobats and a maypole. It hardly matters that the tea comes in styrofoam cups and the Banbury tarts in cellophane, or that the occupants of the stone benches that ling the circle of grass will soon disappear into a plump round model of Shakespeare's Old Globe Theater.

title: Is Vance Advancing?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The big news here a couple of weeks ago was that President Carter and Prime Minister Begin of Israel had got along like old buddies. And now the latest news is that Secretary of State Vance and the same Mr. Begin are said to be facing some kind of crisis In United StatesIsraeli relations.

title: Truck Crash Burns 2 Buildings
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 9 (AP)A gasoline tank truck rolled over and exploded at the intersection of Interstates 40 and 24 today, and flames from the truck destroyed a nearby church and damaged a house. Fire Chief Charles Womack said eight firemen were treated at Nashville General Hospital, but none was seriously injured. A spokesman for Wooten Transfer of Nashville, which owned the truck, said the driver, George O'Fennel, and his assistant, Eddy Newson, both of Nashville, escaped unhurt.

title: Toronto Killing Spurs Drive Against Sex Shops
description: TORONTO, Aug. 5A thousand people last week went to the funeral of a 12yearold shoeshine boy, who, the police said, had been sexually abused before being killed and left on the roof of a building housing a massage parlor on Yonge Street in downtown Toronto.

title: U.S. Allies' Pressure Splits Carter's Advisers on I.L.O.
description: WASHINGTONThe United States is under strong diplomatic pressure from its allies among the rest of the World's industrialized democracies not to go through with its threatened pullout from the International Labor Organization. Britain, France, West Germany and other countries that have stood with the United States in its unsuccessful fight for rules changes aimed at depoliticizing the world labor body contend that withdrawal by this country world kill all hope of ending the domnation now exercised over the agency by the Arab states and the Soviet Union.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Moscow Assails Carter for Funding Neutron Bomb
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 9The Soviet press agency Tass today mounted a sharp personal attack on President Carter, accusing him of yielding to the Pentagon by approval to the neutron bomb. Tass apmanufacture a new neutron warhead.

title: Gerber Charged With Damaging Its Shareholders
description: Larry Berman, a stockholder in the Gerber Products Company, filed a class action suit against Gerber yesterday in the United States Federal District Court in Grand Rapids,. Mich., for damages resulting from the lowering of the Anderson, Clayton & Company bid for Gerber shares from $40 a share to $37.

title: ExPoliceman Repeats His Charge Murder Confession Was Forced
description: DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 9 (UPI)A former policeman repeated under crossexamination today his charges that officers used threats and coercion to obtain confessions from five black youths accused of murdering a white man.

title: PORT AGENCY UPHELD BY U.S. HIGHWAY CHIEF ON $1.50 BRIDGE TOLLS
description: The Federal Highway Administrator, William M. Cox, yesterday upheld the $1.50 toll imposed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey two years ago on all Port Authority bridges and tunnels linking New York and New Jersey. He also upheld the authority's use of the tolls to support lessprofitable authority facilities.

title: ETHIOPIAN DIPLOMAT SAYS SOMALIA GAINS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 9In the last two weeks Somali forces have moved swiftly and deeply to gain control over most of. Ethiopia's Ogaden Province, the Ethiopian ambassador to Kenya acknowledged today.

title: 3 Types of Trees Periled By Blights of Scale Insects
description: Three of North America's most important treesthe hemlock, red pine and beechare threatened by spreading blights of scale insects.

title: Queens Plant Seeking to Avert a Shutdown
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has been asked to settle a dispute involving a fatrendering plant in Queens, residents of Long Island City and eastern Manhattan, New York City's Environmental Control Board and a smell that the board believes is so foul that it is seeking to shut down the entire plant.

title: SKELETON FOUND IN WOODS MAY BE CLUE IN HUNT FOR 4
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 9 (UPI) The skeletal remains of a young man that were found in a wooded area may be connected with the disappearance of four people from the Lawrenceville, N.J., area, the Pennsylvania state notice said today.

title: RECIPIENTS CONFUSED BY RELIEF PROPOSALS
description: The immediate reaction in New York City to President Carter's welfare proposals among welfare recipients and advocates was predominantly one of mystification and uncertainty.

title: People in Sports
description: Noting that evening has come in the career of Muhammad Ali, Don King announced yesterday A Night of the Heavyweight boxing cardfive bouts involving top heavyweights to be held in Las Vegas and broadcast by NBCTV on Sept. 14.

title: Three Bodies Found in River
description: PERRY, Fla., Aug. 9 (AP)Three bodies weighted down with concrete blocks were found in a deep, deserted stretch of the Aucilla River by two youngsters who were skindiving, Sheriff Von Whidden of Taylor County said today. He would not speculate on a motive. The bodies have not yet been identified.

title: Memories of Rome
description: ROME AFTER SPENDING almost a week of dining in Rome, I am as full of mixed emotions as I am of mixed metaphorsat almost every meal 1) waiting for the next shoe to drop or 2) waiting for a cloud to pass. Believe me, there's an easy explanation for that.

title: Film: 'Satan's Brew' Is Cold and Bitter
description: IF YOU HAVE any doubt that there's such a thing as being too prolific, by all means go see Rainer Werner Fassbinder's "Satan's Brew." Mr. Fassbinder attempting physical, almost slapstick comedy, is Mr. Fassbinder at his least funny or enlightening; and the film, a kind of "Father Knows Best" on acid, showcases most of the director's worst qualities without leaving room for his best. Made in Germany early last year, this is an ice-cold work, and a stubborn and difficult one. The meager rewards it delivers are no match for the enormous energy it demands.Beginning and ending with a quotation from the French avant-gardist Antonin Artaud, to the effect that thinking from a non-human point of view is a way of maintaining contact with the gods, "Satan's Brew" operates as something of a sicko sit-com, with a set of domestic characters nonchalantly acting out their most bestial impulses.Walter Kranz (Kurt Raab) is a beleaguered poet with a hefty wife who complains loudly about their non-existent sex life and a brother whose hobbies are exposing himself and collecting dead flies.The menagerie also includes a duplicitous whore and a bug-eyed, warty mistress (played through heavy makeup by the usually stunning Margit Carstensen). Kranz himself is hard at work pretending he is Stefan George, a German poet favored by the Nazis, and writing a new opus, to be entitled "No Ceremony For The Fhrer's Dead Dog."Mr. Fassbinder can be both ironic and provocative when, as in "Mother Kusters Goes To Heaven," his only successful comedy, he gently contrasts people's manners with their desires. But in "Satan's Brew" his blunt directorial style merely exaggerates the coarseness of his characters, and his humor turns stolid and didactic. There are, for instance, a great many ponderous lessons here about the relationship between sex and money: a woman in kinky purple underwear goes into ecstasies while writing a check (at this point, her lover serenely shoots her), and the brother who collects flies tries to use them as both erotic offerings and as currency.Mr. Fassbinder also pokes fun at a wide range of perversions: one character, a masochist, has scrambled egg spat onto her face and happily lets it dry there. Also, there are repeated digs at the German national temperament, including several references to anti-Semitism and someone's scornful appraisal of death as "the fate of the weak." It's hard to be sure where Mr. Fassbinder stands on these or any other issues, because the film's plot is unintelligible and its directorial vantage point is somewhere off in the ozone. For all its brutishness, though, "Satan's Brew" is finally not vulgar enough. The film's premise calls for both precision and abandon and, while an exaggerated, reference-laden meticulousness is Mr. Fassbinder's specialty, he seems incapable of doing anything very freely. His characters follow their animal instincts, but they do so in such a careful way they might as well be trained seals. None of them flouts convention with the kind of spontaneity or enthusiasm that might have lent real wit to the film's bloodless, brittle scheme.

title: For Boy Scouts, Surprise Training in Mud
description: MORAINE STATE PARK, Pa., Aug. 9The Boy Scouts of America, troubled in recent years by declining membership and the need to urbanize their image, have plunged eagerly back into the woods and hills for a week of traditional camping at the organization's ninth quadrennial jamboree.

title: Recipes From Rome: A Taster's Choices
description: Zuppa di Vongole (Clam soup)

title: Bar Association President William Bowman Spann Jr.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9In the early 1960's, when William B. Spann Jr. began aiming for the presidency of the American Bar Association, the law was a quiet, dignified profession.

title: Q&A
description: Q I have a friend who repeatedly refers to her husband as a cordon bleu cook. I am under the distinct impression that a cordon bleu is properly applied to women only. Am I correct?

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Sharon Busch, Sundance Take Sussex Show Title
description: AUGUSTA, N.J., Aug.Sundance, owned and ridden by Sharon Busch of Holmdel, N.J., scored 16 points and won the largepony hunter championship today at the Sussex County horse show held at the Sussex County Fair and Horse Show Grounds.

title: EXCAVATION STUDIED IN BUILDING COLLAPSE
description: The threestory brick building that collapsed Sunday in Brooklyn's Red Hook section, killing an 8yearold girl and her father, had had a series of unsafewall violations dating from 1942 and the theory at the city's Department of Buildings is that the collapse stems from the drilling of the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel about that time.

title: NONJERSEY RESORTS PRESS FOR CASINOS
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., Aug. 9As the time approaches for the first spin of the roulette wheels in Atlantic City, competing resorts in New Jersey's neighboring states of Pennsylvania and New York are growing increasingly nervous.

title: Kapp's Appeal of N.F.L. Antitrust Suit Begins Today
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9  Joe Kapp's appeal of a jury verdict that found he was not entitled to any damages in his antitrust suit against the National Football League will be heard here by a threejudge Federal panel tomorrow, nearly 18 months after the trial ended.

title: Worldwide Glut of Fibers Blocking Textile Price Increases
description: A glut of textile fibers throughout the world, particularly of noncellulose types such as polyester and nylon, has weakened the textile market and made it impossible for textile prices to rise from their lows of the last two years.

title: Connors Tops Bunis on Clay In First Round
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 9 (AP)The topseeded men, including the defending champion, Jimmy Connors, won firstround matches today. But two seeded women were upset in the $160,000 United States claycourt tennis tournament.

title: Pointing Fingers
description: BERKELEY, Calif.President Carter has gone to great lengths to persuade us of his undeviating commitment to the advancement of human rights abroad. Clearly, there is much to applaud in his forthright stand, but there are also some significant inconsistencies in his approach to this critical issue.

title: GULF GAINS CONTROL. OF 68% OF KEWANEE FOR $47.50 A SHARE

description: Allport, Susannah

title: Marquette Hires Aide
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9 (UPI)Gerald Oliver, an assistant basketball coach last season at Jacksonville University, was named to the same post today at Marquette University.

title: MIDWEST GOVERNORS BACK GAS DECONTROL
description: AFTON, Okla., Aug. 9The Midwestern Governors' Conference voted today to fight for deregulation of newly drilled natural gas despite a warning from a high official of the Carter Administration that the proposal would be costly to consumers, inflationary and ineffective.

title: Article 3  No Title
Vermont Seeks Aid for Drought
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 9 (AP)Gov. Richard A. Snelling asked President Carter today to declare four western Vermont counties natural disaster areas because of a drought that has severly damaged crops. If approved, farmers in Addison, Franklin, Chittendon and. Rutland counties would be leigible for a Federal emergency livestock and feed program.

title: REM V. KHOKHLOV
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)The rector of the University of Moscow, Rem V. Khokhlov, died yesterday at the age of 51, the press agency Tass announced today.

title: Pro Pool Players Know No Mercy
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 9It was after two o'clock this morning, while a rainstorm soaked the deserted boardwalk here, that a little group of professional pool players in Convention Hall went on doing what tradition demands trying to beat one another out of their bankrolls.

title: Official Says Uprising at Upstate Prison Involved 2 Separate Incidents
description: NAPANOCH, N.Y., Aug. 9A prison official said today that two separate incidents, and not one, erupted between 8 and 9 A.M. yesterday at the Eastern New York Correctional Facility here, where a group of inmates seized 11 hostages and parts of the prison complex, holding some of the hostages for more than 11 hours.

title: Books: Selling Broadway Through 30 Years of Lean and Lush
description: THE THEATRICAL press agent is a resilient amalgam of glue and guile, chutzpah and heartburn, optimism and imagination. One ao the best and most successful of this special breed of salesman was Harvey Sabinson, who tilled the stubborn fields of Broadway for some 30 years, through seasons lean and lush, before coming to his senses a few years ago. Mr. Sabinson went into teaching for a while, but is now back on the showbusiness scene, though in a somewhat more donnish capacity, as a special consultant to the League of New York Theaters and Producers.

title: Bar Group Urges Help for Grand Jury Witnesses
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9The American Bar Association urged Congress and the states today to adopt a broad program of grand jury changes aimed at curbing abuses by prosecutors and providing more protection for witnesses.

title: In Memoriam
description: BIROOFFCharles. Dad, you are gone from my sight, but never from my heart. Love, SANDY.

title: Mozart Eve Entremont At His Best
description: PHILIPPE ENTREMONT, the gifted but erratic French pianist, enjoyed one of his better nights at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Monday evening. In works, constructed on a grand scale, his play ing sometimes sounds glib and offhand, and sloppiness occasionally obtrudes, despite his tremendous technical fluency. But on this occasion Mr. Entremont had no grand monuments to try to get his arms around, his program consisting of three Classical concertos that dealt, for the most part, in courtly graces, geniality and sparkling effects.

title: GILBERT M. STEINBERG
description: Gilbert M. Steinberg, founder and president of Pana Optical Distributors Inc., Great Neck, L.I. died last Friday at the age of 50 in Lawrence Memorial Hospital, New London, Conn., of injuries received in a road accident in Essex, Conn., the previous day.

title: ISRAELIS TELL VANCE THEY FIRMLY OPPOSE YIELDING TERRITORY
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9Israeli leaders told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today that they remained strongly opposed to giving up any territory on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan, and in the Gaza Strip, to the creation of any Palestinian homeland on Israel's borders and to any part for the Palestine Liberation Organization in an eventual negotiation at Geneva.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: Most home cooks tend to catalogue dishes in their mind in two categoriesthose for the everyday table and those for special occasions. In many casesdishes requiring elaborate and tediously prepared dough; dishes with costly ingredients such as truffles and foie grassuch divisions are justified. There are some dishes, however, so easily made and of such special character they can serve well as one or the other.

title: Cancer and the American Diet: New Habits for Better Health
description: THE PROPOSED BAN on saccharin, the earlier bans on cyclamates and Red Dye No. 2, the continuing debate over the safety of various food preservatives and the discoveries of pesticide residues in foods have prompted a growing concern about the cancercausing potential of the American diet.

title: Canadian Dollar Off to 7 Year Low

title: The Mixed Breed Of Dog Trainers
description: WHILE archeologists may quibble, it is generally believed that Homo sapiens first domesticated dogs about 7,000 years ago. In many ways, the task has yet to be perfected. The American Kennel Club in New York City (which estimates that more than 500,000 city residents own dogs) says it receives at least 300 calls a day from people interested in obedience training. Rather than buy training books, whose sales haVe significantly creased in the last two years, many urbanites take their dogs to a rather recently evolved breed, the professional dog trainer. There are 41 of these listed in the Manhattan telephone book alone, with rates ranging from $20 for a sixweek group class to nearly $300 for private, athome instruction boarding. The goals of most obedience courses are the same (Come, Heel. Sit, Sit Stay, no and O.K.), but training techniques differ. A random sampling of several schools disclosed the following philosophies.

description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 9There were more winners than losers today as the Giants got down to the National Football League's 60player roster limit.

description: A woman having lunch in a midtown coffee shop the other day put her shoulder bag over the back of the booth. Then, because she had heard about pocketbook thieves operating in restaurants, she carefully covered it with her trenchcoat, making sure the bag was out of sight.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)William C. Sibert seemed to have a lot more money than did other Government employees earning $10,000 a year.

Vance, the visiting Secretary of State, they remained strongly Opposed to yielding any territory on the Jordan's West Bank and in the Gaza Strip: They also took the expected hardline position against any Palestinian homeland on Israel's borders and to any part for the Palestine Liberation Organization in an eventual negotiation at Geneva. title: Awakened Cubs Startle Cynics, Beating Pirates, 41
description: Baseball embalmers probing the Chicago Cubs of late may have been startled when the potential corpse showed definite signs of life in a 41 victory over the Pirates in Pittsburgh last night.

title: Pardon Asked for Wilmington 10
description: LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP)Amnesty International appealed today to Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina to pardon the Wilmington 10, a group imprisoned in a 1971 racial disturbance. The human rights organization said that it believed the 10 had been jailed because of their race and political activities. Nine of the 10 are black and remain in jail. The 10th, who is white, has been paroled. They were sentenced to up to 34 year in prison for unlawful burning and conspiracy to assault emergency personnel.

title: Blue House Spying Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)Admiral Turner said today that American intelligence agents never bugged or taped conversations of top South Korean officials in the Blue House, the Presidential mansion in Seoul.

title: Daily Iranian Crude Production And Exports Fell From June to July
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 9 (AP)Iranian crude oil production declined an average of 390,833 barrels a day from June to July while its average daily exports dropped by 923,594 barrels, according to an official statement issued Tuesday.

title: Married Team Net Victor
description: LIBERTY, N.Y., Aug. 9A wife and husband team, Betty Anne and Ken Stuart of Long Beach, Calif., defeated Bill Lenoir and Clair Schmoyer of Phoenix, 64, 75, today to win the Kodel Cup national mixed doubles tennis championships.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Aug. 9The Massachusetts Secretary of State, Paul Guzzi, today ordered the state police to make public their records of the investigation of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the Italian immigrants convicted of murder and executed here in 1927.

title: Welcome to a Flawed Strip Mining Bill
description: When President Carter signed the bill to control strip mining last week he called it a disappointing and watered down measure. Nonetheless, the act is historic; its benefits far outweigh the drawbacks. He was right to sign it and can now fortify the law by choosing strong leadership for the new Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement and pledging it his support.

description: Two more former Government officials have taken management positions in private industry.

title: Canal, Though a Proud Engineering Achievement, Has Caused Serious Anguish for U.S. and Panama
description: It was early January, 13 years ago, on the Pacific Coast of Panama. Three times, American students had defied a United States general and run up the Stars and Stripes in front of their high school in the Canal Zone.

title: Harlem Opera: A1 Fresco, but Not in Italian
description: I've never liked opera, but this is all right, said Joanne Moore, a secretary who spent yesterday's lunch hour watching an outdoor performance by the Harlem Opera Society.

title: 'Kentucky Fried' A Yolky Film
description: ANYONE interested in the condition of humor and wit in the United States stands likely to come away depressed from "The Kentucky Fried Movie," which opened yesterday at the Eastside Cinema. The first film of the Kentucky Fried Theater, a comedy group that traces its origins to the University of Wisconsin six years ago, "The Kentucky Fried Movie" is in the tradition of "The Groove Tube" and "Tunnelvision." The range of its satire and comedy, as displayed in 22 segments running from a minute or two up to 30 minutes, is fairly narrow.Television is both an inspiration and a preoccupation, with commercials, news shows, early morning talk-news shows, talk shows and 50's-style courtroom dramas all serving as targets.Movies come next. "Cleopatra Schwartz," dealing with the love of a black superwoman and a Hasidic rabbi, is this movie's comment on black exploitation films.Disaster movies, soft-core pornographic movies and martial-arts films are also the focus of a mordancy that gives the impressionparticularly in the 30-minute martial-arts segmentof being undercut by the maker's affection for the original genre. Sex records and charity appeals are also inspirations for efforts at humor in this 86-minute film, which seems at least twice as long.Reportedly made on a budget of about $1 million, "The Kentucky Fried Movie" is a good-looking production well performed by a large cast that includes Donald Sutherland, Henry Gibson and George Lazenby in brief appearances.Television is at once this movie's nourishment and onus. The caliber of television wit and humor has never been uniformly high, and comedy derived from it is likely to have difficulty surmounting such humble origins. It is little wonder, then, that "The Kentucky Fried Movie," being freed from the restraints of television, though not from its inherent defects, occasionally descends into juvenile tastelessness (a dignified woman using four - letter words; a board game built around the assassination of President Kennedy; a charity appeal involving a child's corpse).Other episodes, such as the one involving a television newscaster Suddenly aware that he can see into the room of a lovemaking couple, last so long that the joke is dissipated by boredom; and in this case crosses the line from humor to an exercise in prurience.Lots of people will probably like "The Kentucky Fried Movie," just as they like Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonald's hamburgers. But popularity is still no reason for deifying mediocrity.

title: Pop: Lucy Lowe Roams Yesteryear in Song
description: THE RESUSCITATION and resesarch done by cabaret performers who in recent years have been digging up and re turning to currency songs of the 1920's and 30s has been a mere scratching of the surface when one considers the program that Lucy Lowe offered on Sunday and Monday at the Ballroom, starting a weekly series that will be presented every Sunday.

title: TV: British Are ComingAgain
description: BRITISH TELEVISION continues its invasion of air time on New York City stations. WNET/13 will have 10 days of special programs for its midsummer fundraising effort, to begin Aug. 20, and more than half the fare bears a madeinEngland label.

description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Aug.10 (AP)Striking coal miners in southern West Virginia refused to join a backtowork movement today, voting not to return to the mines.

Tipper Also survived by two grandchildren Mrs. Leland T. Bonnelll and Mrs. James H. Roach, Jr. One greatgrandson. Interment private. A merorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be sent to the First Baptist Church, Church St., Montclair or the Montclair Volunteer Ambulance Unit.

description: CHICAGO; Aug. 10 (AP)Asa precaution, all whipped butter manufactured at the Sugar Creek plant of the Beatrice Food Company in Louisville, Ky., has bee recalled, the company said yesterday.

title: Somalia Charges Ethiopia Imports Foreign Soldiers
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 10 (Renters)Somalia said today that between 5,000 and 9,000 foreign troops were on their way to Ethiopia, where. Somalisupported insurgents have seized control of the longdisputed Ogaden region.

title: Hawley Rides Favored Majestic Light to 3Length Triumph on Grass at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 Sandy Hawley, the fourtime national race winning champion, scored with Ogden Mills Phipps's favored Majestic Sight in the $38,625 Bernard Baruch Handicap today on the Saratoga turf course. After the race, the Canadian jockey said he enjoyed two rides during the day.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Aug 10 (Reuters)The 11th congress of the Chinese Communist Party is imminent or may already be under way, reliable sources said today. Chineseofficials declined to comment and have indicated that the congressthe first since Mao Tsetung's deathwill not be announced until it is over.

title: Connors, Orantes Triumph In ClayCourt Tournament
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP) Jimmy Connors, almost toying with an outclassed Matt Mitchell, scored repeatedly with his patented backtothenet overhead slam tonight and crushed the defending National Collegiate champion, 62, 60, in the second round of the $160,000 United States claycourt tennis tournament.

title: Atlantic City Hotel Buyer Used an Alias
description: TRENTON, Aug. 10A member of the farflung Gambino family used an assumed name in an effort with another man to buy the Shelburne Hotel in Atlantic City after casino gambling was legalized there, the State Commission of Investigation was told today.

description: In an apparent effort to compel Sunshine Mining Company to hasten a decision on its takeover offer, the Great Western United Corporation of Denver yesterday reduced its bid for 2 million shares of Sunshine to $14.75 a share from $15.75.

description: HAVANA, Aug. 10Fidel Castro, a relentless host who for two days led Senator Frank Church of Idaho on a nonstop convivial tour of Cuban social progress under his revolution, settled down this evening with the Idaho Democrat for a discussion of Cuba's economic problems.

title: Smithsonian Has 131st Birthday
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)The Smithsonian Institution marked its 131st birthday today. It was on this date in 1846 that President James K. Polk signed legislation establishing the Smithsonian, after eight years of debate in Congress.

description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 10 (AP)The Minnesota Department of Public Welfare said today that it would continue to reimburse welfare recipients for elective abortions.

title: ALCOA FILES A SUIT TO BAR PRIVATE DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10The Aluminum Company of America today filed in District Court here a suit against the Justice Department, which seeks to bar the agency from using in open court confidential data obtained from the company two years ago during an antitrust investigation.

title: Raging Fires, Striking Firemen
description: Uncontrolled fires burned out the homes of citizens in Dayton while striking firemen watched from a picket line. The horror of that image, with the firefighters holding back except where lives are directly threatened, is enough to turn the firmest friend of unionism into a raging foe. It also revives the hard question of which public employees, if any, should have the right to strike. The issue has been fitfully debated in New York's mayoral campaign since Bella Abzug confessed what she called a philosophical rather than practical view that every worker has a constitutional right to withhold his labor. We said then that the debate in those terms was not very useful, which is not the same as saying the matter is unimportant.

title: Notes on People
description: MIZ LILLIAN,78  year old mother of President Carter, will receive the Covenant of Peace Award from the Synagogue Council of America. Mrs. Carter will be the first woman to receive the award for Americans making outstanding contributions to the cause of peace She will be honored in New York Sept. 25. Previous recipients of the award were John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr. and Chief Justice Earl Warren.

title: A Guide for the Perplexed
description: HOUSTONGalen called it Head Melancholy. If afflicted, he said, there was too much black bile in your system. He recommended sunshine, fresh air, or a diversion like choler or lust. This is the very Galen who treated the Emperor Marcus Aurelius, the Galen whose medical theories were in vogue for close to 2,000 years.

Early that morning he shot and killed Donna Lauria, 18 years old, of 2860 Buhre Avenue in the Westchester Heights section of, the Bronx, who was sitting in a doubleparked car ouside her home with a friend, Jody Valenti, 19, of 1918 Hutchinson River Parkway. In Heu of flowers, donations may be made In her memory to the Pastors Discretionary Fund of the United Church of Dorset, Dorset, Vt.

title: With California Fires Nearly Contained, Effort Turns to Rehabilitation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10State and Federal firefighters expressed cautious optimism today about controlling the big fires plaguing California and began to turn their attention to the problems that follow such natural disasters.

title: Judge Orders Welfare Payments
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP)United States District Judge Barron McCune today ordered the State of Pennsylvania to resume welfare and medical benefits to at least some residents on public assistance whose checks had stopped because of the state budget crisis. The judge said that families with dependent children, and Medicaid and child support recipients should get their checks because Federal money was involved and the funds were already in the state treasury. However, general welfare recipients, whose checks are entirely state funded, will not be paid.

title: Los Angeles Gets a Law Designed To Stop Spread of Pornography
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (UPI)Mayor Tom Bradley signed today a temporary Zoning law designed to stop the spread of sexoriented businesses in the nation's thirdlargest city.

title: U.S. HAS EXCHANGED DATA ON POLITICAL DISSIDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)The United States has exchanged information about political dissidents with foreign governments and may do so in the future in an effort to check terrorism, the State Department reported today.

title: Salute to Margaret Mead Is Planned by Museum
description: The American Museum of Natural History will celebrate the 75th birthday of Dr. Margaret Mead with a fiveday festival of new and classical anthropological films. The festival, which begins Sept 14, will feature more than 80 hours of continuous weekend screenings in eight museum halls. Also included are a threeevening retrospective of the works of film ethnographer Jean Rouch, a familyfolklore workshop, informal talks by experts, displays and a special student screening area.

title: Reese, Crowder Given Jail Terms of One Year
description: MIAMI, Aug. 10 (AP)Two former Miami Dolphins players today were sentenced to a year in jail for selling cocaine, but were left some hope of returning to pro football once they were free.

title: 200 Years of Paint Imitating Life
description: Paint, over the centuries, has been the poor man's medium for fancy decoration, as well as the rich man's status symbol. The many approaches to paint as a decorative element on American furniture, from the end of the 17th century to the present, is the theme of a current show that ranges from small boxes to large cupboards.

title: Beame Policy Lets Employees Share Productivity Gains
description: Mayor Beame's office disclosed yesterday that Mr. Beame had agreed a week ago to a new policy enabling municipal employees to receive additional wage increases this year to be paid out of future productivity improvements in the work force.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: THEY LIVED in dirt for four months and endured having to go to neighbors for washing and cooking water, barbecuing dinners on the fire escape and aching from labors they were not trained to perform.

title: Screen: But When She Was Bad...
description: EVEN THOUGH she's cast as a murderess, Jodie Foster comes her closest yet to playing a normal kid in "The Little Girl Who Lives Down The Lane," a mild-mannered horror movie for people who don't much enjoy being scared. Miss Foster's foul deeds, which prove to be not so foul after all, are committed either accidentally or off-camera. The rest of the time, Miss Foster loafs around in blue jeans, plays with her hamster, and falls so desperately in love that, when things go wrong, she can barely touch her dinner, which consists of a burger and a shake.The story, set in the obligatory New England hamlet, involves Martin Sheen as a vicious child-molester who sees in Miss Foster the things that movie audiences have been seeing in her for the last few years, and Alexis Smith, as Mr. Sheen's wicked mother. Miss Smith plays the town real estate agent and, because she wears a Valentino wardrobe and drives a Bentley, it must be quite a town.In any case, Miss Smith has rented a house to Miss Foster and her father, a Very Famous Poet who hasn't been heard from since. Every time Miss Smith drops by to make trouble, Miss Foster announces that her father is out of town or says he is working in his study and can't be disturbed. Hah!Though Mr. Sheen does a chillingly effective turn as the psycho, and Miss Smith an unduly nasty one as his mother, the film's real source of energy is Miss Foster's bout of puppy love with Scott Jacoby, who brings freshness and ingenuity to a humdrum role. The affair blossoms, and then some: the pair begins sleeping together, and Miss Foster is called to murmur sweet nothings like "I never knew how much I needed you."Fortunately, there's more to it than that: they also share an easy camaraderie and a number of genial, even heart-warming moments. Nicolas Gessner's direction has a correspondingly comfortable feel, but this type of story is as old as the hillsno, olderand Mr. Gessner doesn't do much to make it plausible.Filmgoers with short attention spans may find themselves wondering not where Miss Foster has been stashing all the adults in her life but, rather, why she is wearing a stiff and obvious-looking wig."The Little Girl Who Lives Down The Lane" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), because of a few bloody closeups of a corpse and because of the terrible things Mr. Sheen does to a stuffed facsimile of Miss Foster's hamster.

title: Yanks Rout Blue, Beat A's by 63
description: The Yankees, who have endured enough of their own problems this seasort, returned to the friendly surroundings of Yankee Stadium last night and immediately dropped some additional problems on the heads of the Oakland A's, especially Vida Blue.

title: Lance's Former Bank Is Reported Under S.E.C. Inquiry on Securities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10The Securities and Exchange Commission is pursuing an inquiry into the securities activities of a bank that Bert Lance headed in Georgia, sources close to the commis. sion inquiry said today.

title: French Woman Who Died in City Left New York $300 as Thanks
description: A French woman who died in New York recently has left $300 to the City as a way of saying thanks for her treatment in the United States, Finance Commissioner Harry Tishelman said yesterday.

title: Queen Opens Her Jubilee Tour of Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 10Queen Elizabeth II began her Silver Jubilee visit to Northern Ireland today in a setting of bucolic beauty that contrasted sharply with the battlescarred, heavily guarded streets of Belfast.

title: Jobs Plan for Vietnam Veterans Is Off to a Slow Start
description: ATLANTAPresident Carter's program to provide jobs for 200,000 unemployed Vietnam veterans, announced last January, has been very slow getting off the ground and appears to have had little effect on the high rate of joblessness among veterans.

title: Lancegate
description: WASHINGTONWhen the White House press corps finally lobbed a softball about the Bert Lance scandal to the President, Mr. Carter curtly replied that he knew little about the details of the loan and directed the reporters to ask questions about welfare reform. Meekly, the corps complied. (Let us not languish in Lancegate.)

title: U.S. Energy Aide Favors Pipeline To Carry Alaskan Oil Eastward
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)The Federal Energy Administrator, John F. O'Leary, said today that a proposed pipeline from California to Texas could transport Alaskan oil cheaply and efficiently to Eastern and Midwestern states. However, he stopped short of telling a House energy subcommittee that he endorsed the terminal planned for the Port of Long Beach in California.

title: Economic Colonialism In the Soviet
description: , LONDONThe Kremlin apparently believes that detente and the stream of technology flowing from it will solve the Soviet Union's economic difficulties. Some of President Carter'sadvisers seem to accept the same proposition. The proposition, however, is faulty.

title: Hers

But one day I drove by a neighbor's house and spied a rather nicelooking dressing table set out for pickup. It turned out to he more than a dressing table.

title: Dollar Up Against Most Currencies
description: The United States dollar gained against most foreign currencies at home and abroad in foreign exchange trading yesterday, losing ground only to the British pound, while the Canadian dollar held steady after slipping to an eightyear low on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Strike by Steelworkers
description: The whole thing is madness, a nowin deal for both sides. There is no harm the steel companies can do to us that doesn't also kill them, and the same is true for anything we in the union can do to them. That gloomy assessment of the 10dayold strike by 16,000 iron ore miners and processing workers in Minnesota and northern Michigan came from a key strategist for the United Steel workers of America. Under a pledge of anonymity, he expressed fear that the walkout and the industry's announced intention to press for heavy monetary damages in the Federal courts might shatter the still shaky structure of cooperation pieced together by the basic steel producers and the union since their last industrywide strike, an economyshaking war of attrition that dragged on for 116 days in 1959.

title: Topics
description: MORAL DUTY  The Administration's plan to admit 15,000 more refugees fleeing the Communist regimes of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia is going into effect. Some 7,000 are expected to be boat people'still living aboard the small vessels on which they fledwho were denied even temporary haven in Southeast Asian countries. Another 8,000 will come from camps in Thailand over the next 16 months. America's moral duty was so clear that the predicted Congressional opposition failed to materialize. But Representative Eilberg of Pennsylvania is still pressing restrictive legislation, which we hope the Administration will resist. The new program will hardly begin to solve the problem. About 1,500 Indochinese refugees are still fleeing their countries each month. There already are more than 80,000 in camps in Thailand and thousands of others have been given temporary asylum in Asian countries, Canada; Australia and Europe. But when the United States virtually closed its doors in January, after admitting about 150,000 in 1975 and 1976, other nations began to deny even temporary haven and only France continued to take substantial numbers. President Carter has asked an interagency task force to develop an international program of permanent resettlement. Legislation that would hamper further substantial American admissions would undermine the effort to gain the cooperation of other countries.

title: U.S. Aide Tells Governors Group Farm Income Will Drop in 1977
description: AFTON, Okla., Aug. 10A high official of the Agriculture Department told Middle Western governors today that the income of farmers would continue to decline this year, taking them in real terms back where we were in 1971.

title: People in Sports

The Pittsburgh Pirate shortstop and basesteal ing artist began serving the suspension with last night's game against Chicago at Three Rivers Stadium. He will be eligible to rejoin the team Sunday while the Mets are visiting Pittsburgh.

title: Backup Centers Are Traded
description: PORTLAND, Ore, Aug. 10 (UPI)The Portland Trail Blazers today traded Robin Jones, a backup center, plus cash, to the Houston Rockets for another backup center, Torn Owens. Jones averaged 5.5 points and 4.7 rebounds a game as a backup to Bill Walton last year. The 6foot10inch Owens averaged 4.1 points and 3.1 rebounds game in 46 games for Houston last year.

title: ExAlaska Musk Oxen Calve in Soviet North
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (AP)Two calves have been born to a herd of musk oxen brought to the Soviet Union from Alaska in 1975 under an animal exchange program, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Truck Plunges Off Expressway
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug 10 (UPI)A flatbed truck skidded on wet pavement today, smashed through an overpass guardrail and plunged from the Cross Westchester Expressway onto the Bronx River Parkway, the state police reported. The driver was pulled from the wreckage and taken to White Plains Hospital. Ambulance attendants said that he had fractured both legs, injured his neck and possibly suffered fractures of his hip and right arm. He was not immediately identified.

title: Lisa Hammel
description: If you're still on the lookout for summery fabrics, Fabrications is a good place to start. There are dozens of shelves filled with ginghams and calicos starting $2 a yard, batiks and ikats, Haitian and Indian cottons, all well priced. The prints from Intair, a German company, would be charming in a summer houseor dramatic in any modern setting. You can get repeats, or one big splash, of poplars, butterflies, fish, gulls and the newest pattern, a pleated fan. The silkscreened prints come in a variety of colors, as well as negative and positive color patterns, or you can get white on a sheer white fabricespecially lovely for the gulls. The fabrics are $20 a yard in 65inch width. Fabric panels, 9 feet by 5 1/2 feet, are $95. The shop will also mount and frame the fabrics for you (the labor charge is $5 to $15); it's an inexpensive way to get a striking pattern on the wall. Or you can do it yourselfframes range from $2 to $6, up to five feet, larger if you wish. Another great doityourself idea for a summer housea fabriccovered lampshade. The wire frame is $6 to $10; a popopen frame, already wired, is $25. Wherever possible, the shop encourages customers to do it themselves, and is generous with printed instructions. But it also offers lots of services, including quilting by the yard, custom upholstering paper backing or vinyl coating of fabrics and custom made pillows. Fabrications is at 146 East 56th Street.

title: Legalese Isn't Legal Under New Law
description: ALBANY, Aug. 10Loan agreements, apartment leases and other consumer contracts will have to be written in clear, understandable language beginning next June under the provisions of a bill signed today by Governor Carey.

(nee Gibbons) native of County Mayo, Ireland, on Aug. 9, 1977, beloved wife of the late Patrick, devoted mother of Thomas, Joseph Patrick, Beatrice, John, Peggy Slegrist, Sr. Marita Rose S.C., Rev. Edward M., and the late Francis and Gerald, also survived by 13 grandchildren and 12 greatgrandcalidren. Reposing at her residence 260 W. 12th St., N. Y. C., on Thurs. day, 25 and 79 P.M., and on Friday, at St. Bernard's Church, 328 W. 14th St., from 25 and 79 P.M. Concelebrated Mass of Christian Burial at St. Bernard's Church, Saturday, at 10 A.M. Interment Holy Cross cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Vincents Hospital, N.Y.C. will be appreciated.

title: A Little Help From Our Friends
description: It was only briefly startling, the day after the blackout, to read the Wall Street Journal's opinion that The time does come when you have to pull the plug on New York. That view applied to much more than electrical connections and it seemed callous. But it was at least consistent, the Journal having favored, among other things, that the city go bankrupt. Nor was it greatly surprising that people elsewhere in the country were quick to give the city a kick when it was down. Heaven knows, New Yorkers have long been quick enough to belittle anyone who stands in, rather than on, line or to consider the rest of the country, patronizingly, a large, undifferentiated Walla Walla.

title: Georgia Authorities Deny Using Threats On 5 Held in Slaying

title: Cypriot Given Life Sentence
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 10 (AP)Lefteris Papadopoulos, 35, a leader of the extreme rightwing Greek Cypriot underground, was sentenced to life imprisonment today for participating in the coup that briefly toppled President Makarios in July 1974. Mr. Papadopoulos was arrested and tried after violating the terms of an amnesty proclaimed by President Makarios after the Turkish invasion of the island that followed the coup. President Makarios died last week.

But as of today, that's no longer true. The Yankees are mired in mudslinging, and Forego is mired under the staggering weights that people put on his back.

At the end of a tedious and forbidding meal my grandmother would say cheerily, We'll call the automobile and motor up to see Grant's Tomb. On other occasions it would be, We'll motor up to see the Soldiers' and Sailors Monument.

title: Squatters Ejected From Settlement Near Cape Town

title: Truck Driver Hurt in Crash
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10 (UPI)The driver of a flatbed truck was seriously injured today when the, truck skidded on wet pavement, smashed through. an overpass guardrail and plunged from the Cross Westchester Expressway onto the Bronx River Parkway, state police reported. The driver, James Reams, 45 years old, of Haverstraw, was taken to White Plains Hospital.

title: Sound
description: ONE TREND in current audio design is the extension of the frequency range covered by loudspeakers into realms formerly regarded as the exclusive domain of the dog whistle. Time was not so long ago, when a loudspeaker was regarded as having sufficient range on top if the treble reached the general vicinity of 16,000 Hz. Today, many of the better speakers scale to 20,000 Hz and beyond, employing new and ingenious tweeters to reach those highs.

title: Ohio Ballet Pleases
description: LEE. MASS.

title: Disks: Kalish Expresses Ives Gusto
description: Gilbert Kalish is no newcomer to Ives. Back in the prestereo era, he and Paul Zukofsky took one of the significant steps in the Ives revival by making an earopening recording of the four sonatas for piano and violin on the Folkways label. Mr. Kalish's performance of the Concord Sonata, while not a pathbreaking effort by any means, shows that his Ivesian sympathies have not diminished over the years. It takes a pianist for whom technical problems hardly exist to play the Concord persuasively, and Mr. Kalish is such a one.

title: A Warm Spell in the Antarctic
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 10 (Reuters)The midwinter temperature at Australia's Mawson Base in the Antarctic has risen above freezing in August for the first time in 24 years, science Minister James Webster said today. He said a change in the upper atmosphere air flow had caused the mercury to climb to 34.5 degrees on Aug. 1.

title: At the Movies
description: SHE'S POISED, pretty and universally praised. Yet she is an emotional mess a woman the grip of a poisonous obsession. At least, that's what Isabelle Adjani was in The Story of Adele H., Francois Truffaut's film in which she excelled as an unwavering romantic in feverish pursuit of the lover who has jilted her. And that's what she'll be in The Driver, a toughfibered thriller in which the writerdirector Walter Hill has transformed the 22yearold Frenchwoman into a fanatical Californian, a hardened drifter whose Insatiable vice is gambling. The film, now shooting in the sleaziest twilight zones of Los Angeles, also stars Ryan O'Neal as an engagingly brazen getaway driver, Bruce Dern as a relentless detective and Ronee Blakley as shady lady.

title: BIG BOARD EASES CRITERIA FOR SPECIALIST TRADERS

description: The marriage of Judith Kay Eckman of New York to Julian Allan Jadow of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Jadow, brother and sisterinlaw of the bridegroom. Rabbi Alan W. Miller performed the ceremony.

title: Night in August
description: The heat persists, but it is tempting to sense, at least far a moment a fresh climate. Lightning, looting and lunatics have so far given New York a heavy, angry summer. (The issue out on the streets, one campaigner observes, is no longer capital punishment, but capital punishment withor withouta trial.) Now, with an accused murderer in custody after nine months of grinding police work, it is possible to perceive the relief of young couples and even 9yearolds, possible to think of the evening news in New York that ought to be thought about in summer: the news that Reggie Jackson is hitting cleanup again for the Yankees; the news that the city's policemen, have accepted a twoyear contract; the news of Haydn and Mozart communicated at Mostly Mozart last night; the news brought by the Perseid meteor shower to the skies of a calm August night.

title: Maravich Signs: 5 Years, $3 Million
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 (AP)Pete Maravich signed a fiveyear contract for about $3 million with the New Orleans Jazz today, reportedly becoming the secondhighest paid player in the National Basketball Association.

description: Hans J. Hoffman, a retired shore manufacturer, died suddenly Tuesday in Bellevue Hospital at the age of 67. He had homes at 520 Park Avenue, and in Littleton, N.H., where he was the cofounder of Connors & Hoffmann Inc., shoe manufacturers.
