title: Carter's Family Linked to Royalty By British Publication on Peerage
description: LONDON, Aug. 11Jimmy Carter's carefully cultivated identification with the common man suffered a blueblooded 'setback today as a leading directody of British nobility said that the president not only was a descendant of the family that produced the first American millkinaire but was also related to both George Washington and the Queen of England.

title: Victims Show Relief and Bitterness
description: For Joanne Lomino and Robert Violante, the arrest late Wednesday night of the man called Son of Sam brought back bitter and painful memories of those terrible moments when gunshots crackled and changed their lives forever.

title: Restaurants
description: A VIEW OF NEW YORK from atop one of its taller buildings is an experience, as breathtaking as it is famous. What is perhaps less widely appreciated, but no less captivating, is a view of the city at water level. Anyone who doubts that should take an evening off and spend it at the new River Cafe, firmly planted on a solidly based barge on the Brooklyn side of the East River and nestled in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge. The caferestaurant, opened two months ago, offers an incomparable view of Lower Manhattan and the river, with Coast Guard cutters, Circle Line excursion boats, sailboats, tugs and tankers passing by almost close enough to be touched.

title: BURNS PATIENTS GIVEN LIFEORDEATH CHOICE
description: BOSTON. Aug. 11 (AP)Hopelessly burned patients at a Los Angeles hospital overwhelmingly ask to die when given a choice between quiet death and drawnout treatment.

title: DAYAN IS OPTIMISTIC ON PEACE TREATIES
description: JERUSALEM, Aug 11Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel today expressed optimism about the prospects for negotiating peace treaties at least with Egypt, Jordan and Lebanon, although he said a pact with Syria would be more difficult to achieve.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE IS SET FOR SOLO TEST TODAY
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 11The nation's space shuttle is scheduled to make its first solo flight here tomorrow when two astronauts take the controls and test the spaceplane's ability to glide without power back to earth after a future journey into space.

title: England's Geoff Boycott Gains Cricket Milestone
description: LEEDS, England, Aug. 11 (Reuters)  Geoff Boycott wrote his controversial name into cricket history here today when he scored his 100th firstclass century to help England reach a useful 252 for four wickets on the opening day of the fourth cricket test against Australia.

title: Space Shuttle Flight On Television Today
description: The three television networks and their local stations, Channels 2, 4 and 7, have scheduled live coverage of this morning's first manned free flight of the space shuttle, the Enterprise, from Edwards Air Force Base in California.

title: Connecticut Bank Chief Named
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 11David H. Neiditz, a former Connecticut State Legislator, was named by Gov. Ella Grasso today to be the state's banking commissioner. His appointment must still be confirmed by the General Assembly when it convenes again next February.

title: The Suspect Is Quoted on Killings: It Was a Command ... I Had a Sigh
description: For more than a year I had been hoping for just one thinga chance to talk to the Son of Sam, a chance to ask him why, said Detective Gerald Shevlin. He was part of the special homicide task force that had conducted the search for the .44caliber killer, the largest manhunt in New York's history.

title: Art People John Russell
description: IT'S POSTCARD time. That whispering flipflop that can be heard all over the city is the sound of postcards being delivered to house after halfempty house. They come from all overCopenhagen, Patmos, Edinburgh, Kyoto, Cadiz, Vermont and the Vineyardand they offer a double enjoyment. There is the image (compounded in many cases by a neverbeforeseen stamp). There is also the fact that someone has thought it worth while to make a signal. Those two enjoyments add up to an agreeable moment in the day.

title: Raiders Trade Hubbard To Lions in Cash Deal
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP)Two Oakland veterans, Mary Hubbard and Horace Jones, were traded in cash deals to the Detroit Lions and Seattle Seahawks, respectively, the National Football League Raiders announced today.

title: NEW JERSEY PAGES
description: NEW JERSEY PAGES

title: 12 Supporters of Gang of Four Reported Executed in Honan City
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 11 (AP)Twelve supporters of China's Gang of Four were executed last week in Honan Province for counterrevolutionary activities, the Far Eastern Economic Review says.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 12%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The Department of Commerce reported today that retail store sales in the latest week were an estimated $14.09 billion, up 12 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.61 billion. Department store sales in the same week were about $1.36 billion, also up 12 percent from last year's $1.21 billion.

title: DAYAN IS OPTIMISTIC ON PEACE TREATIES
description: JERUSALEM, Aug 11Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel today expressed optimism about the prospects for negotiating peace treaties at least with Egypt, Jordan and Lebanon, although he said a pact with Syria would be more difficult to achieve.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times Aug. 1 about divorced fathers, the name of a book to be published on the subject was incorrectly given. The title is Fathers and Custody, by Ira Victor and Win Ann Winkler.

title: Bluegrass Derby Off & Fiddling
description: THE SOUNDS of fiddles scraping, mandolins strumming and high lonesome tenors sailing through the night seemed an unlikely magnet for New York audiences when the first New York City Bluegrass and Old Time Country Music Contest and Crafts Fair was held at the South Street Seaport in 1973. But those same sounds will lead the annual festivities to new heights this weekend. And it's the largest scheduled event at the seaport this year.

title: Robin Kantor, Stanley Levin Are Married in L.I. Ceremony
description: Robin Karen Kantor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Kantor of Woodsburgh, L.I., and Miami, was married yesterday evening to Stanley L. Levin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Levin of Atlantic Beach. L.I.

title: California Legislature Overides Veto of Death Penalty
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11The California Assembly this afternoon voted, 54 to 26, the required margin, to reinstate the death penalty.

title: Love and Treachery
description: DAUGHTER OF DECEIT (LA HIJA DEL ENGANO), directed by Luis Bunuel; screenplay (Spanish with English subtitles) by Raquel Roies and Luis Alcoriza; photography, Jose Ortiz Ramos; music, Manuel EsPereon; produced by Oscar Dancig's, Ultramar Films S.A. Running time: 80 minutes. This film has not been rated. At the Jean Renoir Cinema, 100 Seventh Avenue South, near Sheridan Square.

title: Adcock Leads Dutch Open
description: ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Aug. 11 (UPI)Mitch Adcock of the United States took a onestroke lead over another American, Bob Risch, with a sixunderpar 66 today in the first round of the Dutch open golf championship. Carl Mason of Britain and John Bland of South Africa were tied for third with 68's and Bob Byman, of the United States was in a fourway tie for fifth place at 69.

title: News Summary
Refugee From Haiti Cannot Bank On Carter Plan for Illegal Aliens
description: Frank Joseph. fled his native Haiti in a small boat two years. ago for fear, he says, of being killed by the secret police. After months of jail in Miami and Texas, he is awaiting a deportation hearing while staying with some Haitian priests in Brooklyn.

title: Entreaty for a Treaty
description: The first Panama Canal negotiation is now over. The second will soon begin. The first was with the Panamanians. The second will be with a minority of United States Senators. President Carter will need to pay as much heed to the second as to the first. Otherwise our relations with Latin America will be poisoned and our assurance of longterm access to the Canal, far from safeguarded, will be put into jeopardy.

title: Neighbor Who Got Threat Letters Was at Arrest Site
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11Craig Glassman was still reeling at the irony of it all, and a little stunned at how he, the Westchester County Sheriff's office and the Yonkers Police Department had apparently stumbled into the yearlong search for the .44caliber killer.

title: Misses Simmons, Gingold In Westbury Night Music
description: Jean Simmons and Hennione Gingold will star in A Little Night Music at the,Westbury Music Fair on Long Island this weekend. The show is a musical version of Smiles of a Summer Night, the Ingmar Bergman film about the flirtations of elegant city couples in an elysian setting. Stephen Sondheim wrote the music and lyrics.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The wage talks between striking grave diggers and the association that manages the 28 cemeteries in the Ronan Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford remained deadlocked, as the strike continued in its 24th day and l80 unburied bodies had accumulated in funeral homes in 10 towns within he archdiocese.

title: Amram at the Museum
description: Rodin's majestic Balzac will be there. So will Joan Miro's earthbound Moonbird and Picasso's She Goat. Visitors can sit back to back with Matisse's The Backs in four basrelief nude variations beside the lush summer green ivy, weeping beeches and poplars and soothing fountains while listening to free performances of innovative music.

title: Market Place
description: An investing approach that has proved rewarding for some astute investors is to buy shares in companies whose prospects, however limited in the immediate future, seem extraordinary for the long term.

title: Ali Tickets on Sale Monday
description: Tickets for the heavyweight championship fight between Muhammad Ali and Earnie Shavers at Madison Square Garden Sept. 29 will go on sale at the Garden at 10 A.M. Monday. They are priced at $100, $75, $50, $40, $30 and $20.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended June 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: High Tides Around New York
You Finally Got Me, Suspect Told Police
description: Inspector, you finally got me. I guess this is the end of the trail.

title: A CENSUS REHEARSAL SET FOR MANHATTAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11All of Manhattan below Houston Street will serve as the stage next year for a major dress rehearsal of the 1980 Census, the Census Bureau announced today.

title: Out of Doors
description: WHEN I MET Al Foldes of Ossining, N.Y.', in a windchurned cove off Route 118 near the Pines Bridge across the Croton Reservoir, three largemouth bass festooned with acquatic weed were swimming in the water from his stringer.

title: Carey Signs Bill Aimed at Curbing Building Owners Arson for Profit
description: ALBANY, Aug. 11Governor Carey has signed a measure intended to curb arson for profit by landlords who have their buildings burned down to collect fire insurance, his office announced today.

title: Diary of a Day With Peripatetic Mr. Vance
description: LONDON, Aug. 11this was Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's longest dayfive countries in one sweepas he completed his Middle East mission. Starting in Israel this morning, it included stops in Jordan,Syria and Egypt to brief their leaders and concluded tonight in Britain.

title: Bird Halts 747 Flight
description: BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP)The pilot of a Trans World Airlines Boeing 747 was forced to return to Logan International Airport 20 minutes after takeoff when a bird was sucked into an engine, a T.W.A. spokesman said. The airline said later that the jumbojet was repaired last night and took of for Londonagainshortlyaftermidnight.

title: Berkowitz Is Described as Quiet and as a Loner
description: To his coworkers and most of neighbors, David R. Berkowitz was a quiet, almost cherubiclooking individual who kept pretty much to himself, never went out with women and was hardly the type to attract attention, much less inspire fear or terror.

title: Art: Graphics Revolution
description: NEVER THROW anything away! should be one of the laws of life for clever young people. It doesn't make for good housekeeping, but it means that in 20 or 30 years time the people in question will be curators of a cultural archive that will help others to understand the period through which they have lived. (It may also be worth a lot of money.)

title: CUBA AGREES TO LET 84 AMERICANS LEAVE WITH THEIR FAMILIES
description: HAVANA, Aug. 11Fidel Castro signaled another step toward the improvement of relations with the United States today by agreeing to allow 84 American citizens and their families to leave Cuba.

title: Philadelphia Mall Opens on the Upbeat
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11Mummer musicians played patriotic songs, hopeful politicians and merchant chiefs were stricken with Infectious hyperbole and thousands of eager Philadelphians rushed into the huge, new suburbanstyle shopping mall that opened here today in the oncedecaying heart of the city.

title: Miss DuPont Sets Back Maria Bueno, 57, 64, 62
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (AP)Thirdseeded Laura DuPont advanced to the semifinals in the United States claycourt tennis tournament today before a series of downpours delayed competition by more than three hours.

title: Wife Slain, Grocer Will Reopen Store Despite His Fears
description: Although they are frightened to death, Hector Sepulveda and his 18yearold son, Hector Jr., intend to reopen their grocery in Brooklyn next weekthe store in which Hector Sr.'s wife was murdered on July 25.

title: Advertising
description: The training of economically disadvantaged men and women for advertising jobs has not generally been a primary focus of the agency business. When such action is taken, therefore, attention often focuses on that particular agency for its efforts.

title: Former Aide Says Hoover Order to Find Radicals By Any Means Was Relayed to Indicted Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11A former top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William C. Sullivan, said today that in 1970 he relayed an order from the director of the bureau, the late J. Edgar Hoover, that agents should use any means necessary in their search for Weather Underground fugitives.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 12, 1977

title: Notes on People
description: It was the opening concert at Saratoga Springs for the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, Eugene Ormany conducting. Those in the audience, who had braved a summer storm Tuesday night to hear the pianist Andre Watts, waited through a rather elaborate dedication ceremony. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney had donated an $18,000 pianofrom funds raised by an exhibition of her grandmother's dollhouseand many and long were the appreciations. At last, Mr. Watts began to play a Liszt concerto but soon stopped. He then went offstage to fetch Richard Varley, a piano tuner. Mr. Varley in his gray suit and Mr. Watts in his tuxedo commenced to crawl around on the floor under the piano. Someone had neglected to put in a 25cent wedge to prevent the pedal assembly from corning off; the new piano had thus been rendered impotent. Eventually. another piano was brought in and Mr. Watts finished the concerto.

title: Broadway
description: WHEN Ellis Rabb was four years old Memphis, he fell into a marionette stage. Immersed, literally, in the world of theater, he thought for a moment that he was a marionette. Then came the realization: he was an actor! In his career, much of it in tandem with Rosemary Harris (his former wife) in the A.P.A. company, he has acted in and directed plays by everyone from George S. Kaufman to William Shakespeare. But one thing has largely eluded him. Rarely has he been in a new play. This season he will rectify that oversight by starring in David Mamet's A Life in the Theater. Directed by Gerald Gutierrez, the twocharacter play opens Oct. 20 at the Theater De Lys.

title: How to Get There
description: How to Get There

title: SUCCESS ON GRANTS CITED BY REP. HUGHES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11William J. Hughes, the United States Representative, said today that he had succeeded in getting the Federal Economic Development Administration to restore $2 million in publicworks grants to 24 communities in his district.

title: Carey Signs Bills on Mental Hygiene and Home Care
description: Governor Carey yesterday approved a series of bills that will drastically reorganize the state's mammoth Department of Mental Hygiene, expand health care at home for the elderly, encourage the prescribing of lesscostly genericname drugs and restructure ratesetting for nursing homes.

title: Saratoga Jockeys
Festival of Soap Stars in Bryant Park
description: New York may not be America's cleanest city, but it's the soap capital of the nation; 10 out of television's 13 daytime dramatic serialssoap operas are produced here.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Thursday, August 11, 1977

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Discharged Penney Employee Is Convicted on Tax Charges
description: W. Stuart Lyon, a discharged employee of the J. C. Penney Company, was convicted yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on charges of filing false returns that failed to report as income about $40,000 of home improvements.

title: Museum of Modern Art Tower Endorsed by Community Board 5
Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Obsolete Warning Signal Blamed In TrainBus Crash Fatal to Nine
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)An obsolete warning signal was a contributing cause to a trainbus collision that killed a minister, his wife and seven Sunday school children in Stratton, Neb., last year, the National Transportation Safety Board reported today.

title: Sanitation Union Members Ratify Contract Including A Productivity Provision
description: Members of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association have approved a new twoyear contract that provides for a costofliving payment of $304.50 next month and a gainsharing productivity provision.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The parents of twins laugh a lot. They have all these stories to tell. Like the one about the mother who learned that she'd just bathed the same 5yearold girl twice. She became aware of that as soon as she noticed one stilldirty 5yearold giggling in a corner.

title: CAREY CITED ON VOTE FOR DEATH PENALTY
description: Governor Carey, who last month vetoed a deathpenalty bill passed by the Legislature on the ground that he was morally opposed to the taking of another person's life, voted in 1972 while a member of Congress in favor of the death penalty for those who hijack airplanes.

title: Tanglewood Turns Playful With Tootling Toy Symphony Played by Celebrity Soloists
description: Tanglewood, that summertime bastion of serious music in the Berkshires, slips into a playful mood tonight. The tootling and tinkling of Leopold Mozart's Toy Symphony will be heard at 8 P.M. in the Music Shed as a feature of the annual daylong event known as TanglewoodonParade. Scheduled to appear as soloistson such instruments as cuckoo whistle, quail whistle, toy trumpet, toy drum and triangleare Alice Brock, owner of Alice's Restaurant; Thomas D. Perry Jr., executive director of the Boston Symphony; Seiji Ozawa, music director of the orchestra, and other local celebrities.

title: $9.8 MILLION GOES TO LOOTING VICTIMS
description: The New York district office of the United States Small Business Administration has so far approved 265 loans, totaling $9.8 million, to the victims, mostly small retailers, of looting that took place during the July 13 and 14 power blackout here.

title: Watson, Hayes and McGee NextNicklaus Among Trio at 69
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 11Gene Littler, who at age 47 is chugging along as smoothly as the ancient RollsRoyces he buys and restores as a hobby, toured his favorite golf course in 67 today and led the first round of the 59th Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: St. Louis Business to Carter: Show Me!
description: ST. LOUISIn this gateway city to the West, the jury is still out on the new Washington of Jimmy Carter.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Radio
description: 78 AM, WNCN. Mother Goose Suite, Ravel; Scherzo for Orchestra; Lelo; ValseCaprice, Beach; A Rumor, Creston; Concerto a Quattro in B minor, Albicastro.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns a Ruling On Goldman, Sachs
description: ST LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP)Goldman, Sachs and Company has been ordered by a Federal appellate court to pay $599,186 plus 6 percent interest to the Alton Box Board Company of Alton. Ill.

title: White House Opens Drive to Win Senate Approval of Canal Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The Carter Administration, which sees the fate of the new Panama Canal treaty as a major test of its ability to deal with Congress on major foreign policy issues, has plunged immediately into what the White House expects to be a tough uphill fight for Senate approval.

title: The Suspect Is Quoted on Killings: `It Was a Command ...I Had a Sign
description: For more than a year I had been hoping for just one thinga chance to talk to the Son of Sam, a chance to ask him why, said Detective Gerald Shevlin. He was part of the special homicide task force that had conducted the search for the 44caliber killer, the largest manhunt in New York's history.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Driving from upper Manhattan or Yonkers to the Croton Reservoir, take Interstate 87 to a point just east of the Tappan Zee Bridge, getting off on the Saw Mill River Parkway, taking it to its juncture with 9A near Hawthorne Circle then 9A to CrotononHudson and from there east on Route 129 along the north side of the reservoir. Route 129 eventually runs into Route 118 and then Route 100.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, August 12, 1977

title: Silly Season Samples
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11I venture to propose for the reader's favorable consideration, Bertrand Russell once wrote, a doctrine which may, I fear, appear wildly paradoxical and subversive. The doctrine in question is this: That it is undesirable to believe a proposition when there is no ground whatsoever for supposing it true.

title: July Wholesale Prices Fell With Farm and Food Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Wholesale prices, usually the harbinger of what the consumer pays later, fell in July for the second consecutive month, thanks to lower farm and processed food prices, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Cosmos, Gaining in Playoffs, Must Avoid Pitfall
description: Having eliminated the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 30, on two goals by Pele and one by Giorgio Chinaglia on Wednesday night, the Cosmos now must avoid a trap Tampa Bay fell into last year when it beat the Cosmos in the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: Making Sense of Intelligence
description: The multiple investigations of the nation's intelligence agencies have raised three disturbing questions: How can abuses, such as illegal wiretapping at home and assassination plots abroad, be prevented? How can the quality of intelligence and analysis be improved? How can management of this $5billionayear industry be made more efficient, economical and responsive to elected leaders?

title: Emminger Named I.M.F. Aide
description: Otmar Emminger, president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, has been named as the new German governor of the International Monetary Fund. He succeeds at the fund, Karl Klasen, whom Mr. Emminger had succeeded earlier this year as president of the Bundesbank.

title: Harsh Realities Killing Off Fan Magazines
description: Dick and Liz, Farrah and Lee, Jackie O, Paul Michael Glaser, Streisand and Redford, Sonny and Cher. Some are out, the others are in, and which is which and who is who is the ephemeral business of movie magazines, where current cover subjects fade away like Cheshire cats, leaving behind only the memory of a toothy grin.

title: Some Jobless? Less Pay for All!
description: ST. LOUISWhen paid jobs become scarce in the United States, a small minorityabout 6.9 percent of the current work forcebears the resulting burden of income loss. The 93.1 percent who continue at work need not pay attention to the concentrated suffering of that minority until there is an explosion such as New York City's blackout looting, which, in any event, affected only relatively small groups: the ghetto residents and ravaged merchants.

title: How to Get There
description: To get to the American Shakespear Theater, from New York, take the Connecticut Turnpike (Interstate 95) to Exit 32 and follow the signs. The drive takes about 90 minutes, and the grounds are open for picnics before the performance.

title: Reserve Report
description: *Seasonally Adjustad

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB payoffs Subject to 5% Municipal surtax.)

title: Leonard Clocks 9.98 At 100 Meters in Mexico
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Aug. 11 (UPI)Silvio Leonard of Cuba was within eighthundredths of a second of tying the world record for the 100meter dash today when he won in 9.98 seconds on the second day of the American Elimination Tournament for the World Track and Field Cup.

title: Pirates Get 15 Hits, Rout Mets, 9 to 1
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11The Mets wandered onto the wrong field tonight. Instead of playing a local tavern team in a game of slowpitch or perhaps, an allstar Little League team, they ended up against a real, honesttogoodness majorleague outfit  the Pittsburgh Piratesand were promptly steamrollered by a score of 91.

title: BatteredWife Campaign Focusing On Woman Charged With Murder
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 11A Clementon N.J., resident charged with the murder of her husband, following a night when she was reportedly brutally beaten by him, pleaded not guilty today in a case that might serve to dramatize the plight of battered women throughout the country.

title: Some Questions and Answers Linked to Lance Loan Case
description: The Comptroller of the Currency and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating the financial affairs of Bert Lance to determine whether any of his dealings with banks before he became budget director were improper or possibly illegal.

title: SAM SUSPECT, HEAVILY GUARDED, ARRAIGNED AND HELD FOR TESTING
description: A reclusive, 24yearold postal worker alleged to be the night stalker known as Son of Sam was arraigned on murder and other charges and held for psychiatric tests yesterday as the police wound down a yearlong investigation of a shooting spree that left six young people dead.

title: Mary Mills Leads by Stroke on 68 but Suspects Clubs Are Illegal
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 11Some of the women on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour suspect that they are playing with illegal clubs, the same type of improperly grooved clubs that have caused problems for Tom Watson, Ray Floyd, Gary Player and George Burns on the men's tour.

title: Fed's Move to Raise Interest Rates Depresses Dow by 9.61 to 877 .43
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 10 points yesterday to reach its lowest level since early January 1976 in response to moves by the Federal Reserve to push shortterm interest rates higher in the money markets.

title: The U.N. Today
Higher Revenue From Canal Tolls Expected to Aid Panama Economy
description: PANAMA CITY, Aug. 11The new Panama Canal treaty may result in higher ship tolls, but it should also help Panama's economy, American officials said today. Under the treaty, Panama will get $60 million to $70 million a year from tolls and other revenues. The present annuity is $2.3 million.

title: Turcotte Leaves Hospital
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP).Ron Turcotte, the jockey who suffered a mild concussion, whiplash and face bruises in a spill Tuesday, was discharged today from Saratoga Hospital. He plans to resume racing Saturday in Chicago.

title: Pop: Dave Mason And Sideman
description: DAVE MASON'S career has been a long time developing. In the last half of the 1960's Mr. Mason was an offandan member of Traffic, a widely admired English progressiverock group. His contributions to the group's repertory tended to be cheerful and catchy; they lacked the intensity of the tunes written by the group's leader, Stevie Winwood. After Traffic, Mr. Mason displayed a widening range of styles on series of solo albums. Although he was originally something of a cult figure, he has grown slowly but surely into an artist with a large popular following.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY. AUGUST 11, 1977

title: Big Days In Jersey
description: IT'S FESTIVAL TIME in the Village this weekendthe Village across the Hudson River, that is. For in the heart of Jersey City lies Italian Village, that city's oldest and largest ethnic neighborhood, established early this century when Italians came to work on the PATH subway line and other construction projects and stayed to live in Jersey City. Italian Village began to suffer a decline in the 1950's, but in the last three years it has come to life again in what villagers call their risorgimento, or resurgence.

title: Photography Show Celebrates the Hamptons
description: A collection of 300 photographs portraying 140 years of the Hamptons will go on view tomorrow at the Guild Hall, 158 Main Street in East Hampton, L.I. Photography in the Hamptons: A Survey of Historical and Contemporary Camera Work contains prints by 66 photographers, including Alfred Eisenstaedt and Henri CartierBresson.

title: For Panama, It's a National Holiday
description: PANAMA, Aug. 11Panama celebrated a national holiday today to mark the agreement with the United States on treaty that, by the year 2000, would give this Central American republic full control over the Panama Canal and all its national territory for the first time.

title: Soybeans Lead Decline in Prices For All Farm Futures Contracts
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)Prices for all farm futures on the Chicago Board of Trade fell today in light trading.

title: JUDGE WILLIAM THETFORD; BUS BOYCOTT PROSECUTOR
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 11 (AP)Judge William F. Thetford of Circuit Court, who prosecuted the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his followers in connection with the 1955 Montgomery bus boycott, died at a local hospital today. He was 64 years old.

title: Music: Memphis Slim
description: THE RETURN of Memphis Slim from his home in Paris for appearances at the Village Gate and elsewhere in the United States has been one of the more important jazz and blues events of the last year. Much has been written concerning the return of jazz expatriates, but of all the American musicians who have made their home in Europe in the last two decades, Memphis Slim seems to have achieved the most lastine popularity there.

title: The Police Sketch vs. the Suspect
description: As New Yorkers scoured the news photographs, searching for the kind of evil in the face of David Berkowitz that they have long expected to find in that of Son of Sam, the 44caliber killer, many found their thoughts returning to the four sketches of the killer that have been released in the last year by the police.

title: Major League Scores
description: ERMetzger, Cabell, Alexander, Ha licki. DPHouston 1. LOBHouston 9, San Francisco 8. 2BMadlock, McCovey, Whitfield, Cedeno 3. HRAlexander (3). SBPuhl, Cabell 2, Ferguson. Clark. SSadek. SFAlexander.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERJoseph E. Beloved husband of Hanna, devoted father of Gem Bonner and Shirley Steinberg, dear brother of Ylsroel, ovine grandfather of Rena, Mimi, Naomi, Jeremy and Judy. Services today, 10 A.M. at Congregation Kohllath Jeshurun, 125 E. 15th St., New York City.

title: Carter Is Briefed on Lance Inquiry; Aides Take WaitandSee Position
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  President Carter today heard a report on the progress of an investigation into the banking andloan activities of Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, but a spokesman for the President carefully avoided defending Mr. Lance or expressing confidence in him.

title: Morgan Attacks Study of Stocks. In Bank Trust
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has attacked a study by a Georgetown University law professor that concludes that normal trading activities of bank trust departments can unduly affect the price of stocks in which they have a high concentration.

title: Californian's Silence Frustrates Investigation of Mass Murders
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Aug. 7He lives alone in a twoman cell, segregated from other prisoners, silent with law enforcement officers, still a mystery to them.

title: About Real Estate
description: IRVINE, Calif.Kenneth Agid, a marketing executive for the Irvine Company, the California land develop er, saw some statistics recently indicating that Americans who had been resisting small autos in favor of big ones in spite of the energy crisis were now finally beginning to take small cars seriously.

title: New Face: Robert Picardo
description: In his first professional acting job, a few seasons back, Robert Picardo couldn't be seen at all. On that occasion, he was simply a disembodied voice translating the foreign words and phrases spoken by other, luckier actors out there on stage in Israel Horovitz's comedy The Primary English Class.

title: Heavy Casualties Are Reported in Month of EthiopiaSomali Combat
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 11The fighting between Somali and Ethiopian forces in the eastern reaches of this country has been ferocious and intense, with thousands of casualties suffered by both sides in the last month, according to diplomatic sources here.

title: Carmines Follows Calling From Camp Meeting to Cabaret
description: By his own count, Al Carmine. has composed the music or written the words or done both for more than 40 musical shows, but until Camp Meeting, playing at the Greenwich Mews Theater, he had never begun and ended one with hymns. Camp Meeting opens with the Doxology (Praise God From Whom All Blessings Flow) and closes with God Be With You Til We Meet Again.

title: Books of The Times
description: EVERY WEEK, another book comes out exhorting us to do something about ourselves. In Freedom in Meditation, ,Patricia Carrington suggests instead that we give ourselves permission to be, that we make an appointment, an assignation, with that part of ourselves that cannot be commanded or controlled. Because many of us know ourselves only through our desires or our anxiety, she proposes that we stop trying for a while and simply let ourselves occur.

title: Bonds and Angels Cool Off Red Sox, 73
description: Boston's 11game winning streak came to an end in Fenway Park last night as the California Angels upended the Red Sox, 73, behind the heavy hitting of Bobby Bonds and the pitching of Paul Hartzell.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Around the Nation
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 11 (UPI)The city's 370 firefighters resumed normal operations today, and its 221.000 residents had full fire protection for the first time since the firemen walked off the job Monday.

title: SAM SUSPECT ARRAIGNED, HELD FOR MENTAL TESTS
description: A reclusive, 24yearold postal worker alleged to be the night stalker known as Son of Sam was arraigned on murder and other charges and held for psychiatric tests yesterday as the police wound down a yearlong investigation of a shooting spree that left six young people dead.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
Food Stamps Sought By Deputy Sheriffs
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (AP)Nine of the 11 deputy sheriffs in Forsyth County, a resort area 30 miles northeast of here, applied for food stamps today, the day after the county commission refused them a raise.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph Kallinger of Philadelphia, already serving a life sentence for the murder of a Leonia nurse, was sentenced to 42 to 51 years in prison yesterday after his conviction of breaking and entering and attempted rape in 1974.

title: TV: Sugar Time!
description: IT SHOULD NOT SOUND grudging to say that Sugar Time! a new situation comedy that starts tomorrow night at 8:30 on ARCTV, is a mildly refreshing summer cooler, a formula affair in which the ingredients are somehow blended to offer an entertaining 30 minutes. For such things, one should be thankful.

title: What to Do About Laetrile
description: Laetrile, the compound made largely from apricot pits. that is being touted as a cancer cure, has now been called hazardous by the Surgeon General. Responsible medical opinion regards laetrile as worthless and the Food and Drug Administration prohibits its shipment in Interstate commerce. Yet its use has been legalized in a dozen states and many people elsewhere are obtaining it illegally.

title: P.L.O. Watching U.S. on Resolution 242
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 11 Bemused by a sudden flurry of interest in a fairly wellestablished position on Security Council Resolution 242, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization are watching with keen interest to see What shifts might take place in the American stand on the decadeold United Nations document.

title: TOUCHE, ROSS WEIGHING MERGER WITH J. K. LASSER
description: Touche, Ross & Company, one of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms, and the smaller J. K. Lasser & Company are discussing a possible merger, it was announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times Aug. 1 about divorced fathers, the name of a book to be published on the subject was incorrectly given. The title is Fathers and Custody, by Ira Victor and Win Ann Winkler.

title: Razing of South Africa Shanty Site Nearly Finished Despite Protests
description: CAPE TOWN. Aug. 11Despite the efforts of three white protesters who prostrated themselves in front of a bulldozer, the demolition of the first of three black squatter camps in this area was virtually completed today, with only 10 of the 1,200 shanties still standing.

title: Uganda Policeman, Aide to Amin, Is Reported Strangled in Kampala
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 11 (AP)The body of a ranking Uganda secret police officer who was described as an adviser to President Idi Amin has reportedly been found in Kampala, travelers arriving here from the Uganda capital said today.

title: France I Gets the Edge But Australia Is Victor
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11For 10 exhilarating minutes today. America's Cup watchers with even an ounce of compassion in their veins found themselves humming La Marseillaise.

title: Miss Krupsak Tours Bronx Ruins
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak toured the southern and western parts of the Bronx yesterday looking for hope amid the ruins.

title: Mets Box Score
description: DPMets 1, Pittsburgh 1. LOBMets 5, Pittsburgh 10. 2BRandle, Garner 3, Stennett, Robinson, HRHodges (1), Robinson (18). SBParker.

title: Carter Is Briefed on Lance Inquiry; Aides TakeWaitandSee Position
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  President Carter today heard a report on the progress of an investigation into the banking and loan activities of Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, but a spokesman for the President carefully avoided defending Mr. Lance or expressing confidence in him.

title: County Fair Season Blooms in the Garden State
description: County fairs, those annual celebrations of rural life, are once again adding their special touches of color and energy to the New Jerky summer season.

title: Issue and Debate: Should the Media Accept Contraceptive Ads?
description: The television commercial in slow motion, shows a young married couple on a beach and embracing tenderly. But it takes the copy to explain that what is being sold is a contraceptive device and not a shampoo or an automobile.

title: Mexican Police Clash With Reds
description: HERMOSILLO, Mexico, Aug. 11(AP)A gunfight in a park between policemen and members of an outlawed Communist group resulted in the deaths of two officers and a Communist, the police said today. They said two suspected Communists were wounded in the battle, which took place yesterday in this northern city.

title: BloodDoping Controversy Thickens
description: It was a topic of conversation at the 1976 Olympics. It has been a source of curiosity to medical researchers, athletes and officials. And now, as results appear in scientific experiments, blood doping has become a source of major controversy in sports.

title: Carrier Submits Successful Bid Of. $244 Million to Acquire Inmont
description: The Carrier Corporation, the nation's largest producer of airconditioning equipment, has become the successful bidder for the Inmont Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of printing ink and an important producer of chemical components for paint.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Aug. 11, 1977

title: Phase Two to Begin On Robert Hall Ads
description: Phase Two of the great Robert Hall auction will begin on Aug. 23, so Phase Two of the advertising for this big liquidation will get underway even sooner.

title: THOMAS F. POLICASTRO, 57; NEW ENGLAND LABOR CHIEF
description: Thomas Francis Policastro, president of the Rhode Island A.F.L.C.I.O. and the organization's New England Council, died yesterday at the Summit Medical Center in Providence. R.I. He was 57 years old.

title: Film. Mayan Tribe In Slick Focus
description: Chac, is officially identified as Panamanian film though it was made in Mexico by a young Chileanborn film director, Rolando Klein, who studied cinema at the University of California at Los Angeles. The film itself is equally eclectic, a sort of Museum of Natural History movie about Mayan culture, put together with all sorts of slick, elaborate, sophisticated film techniques.

title: SISTERS BRING A LAWSUIT AGAINST 2 U.N. OFFICIALS
description: The AntiSlavery Society has appealed to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations to intervene on behalf of two Asian sisters who have brought a $6 million lawsuit against two United Nations officials for whom, they charge, they worked here under conditions constituting involuntary servitude.

title: Saratoga Racing
New Face: Hollis McLaren
description: One critic speculated that she must be an authentic nervous wreck. Given the choice, Hollis McLaren would rather play Lady Macbeth than Ophelia. But she's pretty convincingly mad in the new Canadian film at Cinema II, Outrageous! In it, Miss McLaren scampers across Toronto cityscapes in the role of a hyperactive young schizophrenic who finds acceptance with a homosexual male hairdresser.

title: The Pop Life
description: John Rockwell

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11Bobby Dotter, the former jockey who trains a public stable, rode his Apaloosa pony, Geronimo, through the barn area toward the backstretch of the main track. It was the sort of morning that is taken for granted by the dowager queen of American race tracks, fresh as a wedge of Hand melon, sweet as four inches of nose on the finish pole. Dotter had his left foot in the stirrup but his right leg stuck out at an angle of 45 degrees. When he was riding races Bobby never had an injury more serious than cracked ribs but two weeks ago another pony fell and rolled on him, breaking the leg in two places. Now hotwalkers and grooms laughed aloud as he rode by, not because of the cast on his leg but because of the crow on his head. The crow's name is Pedro and he perched upright on the crown of Dotter's cowboy hat surveying the premises with a black, imperious eye.

title: Basic Terms of Canal Agreement
description: PANAMA, Aug. 10 (AP)  United States and Panamanian officials close to the negotiations say that the basic terms of agreement to be incorporated into a new treaty on the Panama Canal are as follows:

title: Monmouth
Ballet: Jazz Echo In Latin Cadence
description: URBAN BLUES and Old World castinets are the unlikely musical companions that suggest the range of Ballet Hispanico. The company's jazztrained feet are firmly placed in New York, but its heart still echoes with the rhythmic cadences of Spanish dancing. The first of its programs Wednesday evening was a mixture of the two and will be seen again tonight and Sunday at the City University Graduate Center Mall as part of Clark Center's dance festival.

title: American Auto Plants Expected To Lag by 8% in Week's Output
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11American auto plants are scheduled to build 98,484 cars this week, off 8 percent from 107,058 last week and 3 percent below the 101,496 cars produced in the corresponding week a year ago, according to Ward's automotive reports.

title: Catholic Conference Assails Soap
description: IN THE MOST significant denunciation to date of Soap, the sexabsorbed series scheduled to begin on ABC next month, the United States Catholic Conference has in a formal statement assailed the program as a debasement of a family medium.

title: S.E.C. to Review Accounting Rule Governing Replacement of Assets
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would undertake a major review of its controversial replacementcost accounting rule early next year but indicated that the rule would remain in effect, at least until the end of this fiscal year.

title: Southern Stonewall
description: ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C.Not far down the road from this city near the North CarolinaVirginia border, in the small town of Whittakers, N.C., workers voted in 1975 by a majority of over 200 out of a thousand votes to form a union at the American Enka Company.

title: Yonkers Neighbors Saw Arrest Unfolding
description: YONKERS, Aug. 11Some of the residents along Pine Street saw it all from the beginningthe waiting, the stalking from rooftops by armed detectives and finally the quick arrest of David Berkowitz when he got into his car.

title: For Children
description: Plays

title: Bridge:
description: Tournament officials and players are constantly involved in arguments about the alert procedure, which requires a player to alert the opponents when his partner has made a conventional bid. The opponents are thereby put on notice that some special understanding is involved, and can ask the alerter a question if they so choose.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.5 billion tonmiles up 7 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 447,768 cars, a rise of 4.6 percent from last year. Labor problems in some eastern coal mines affected loadings in both years and a strike by iron ore mines affected traffic this year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 7.6 percent from a year ago.

title: Hussein, After Vance Visit, Urges Arabs to Unify in Face of Danger
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 11King Hussein of Jordan called on the Arabs today to unify ranks and bypass their differences in the face of the aggressive, racist attack.

title: Sadat Pointedly Speaks of Date Sinai Pact With Israel Runs Out
description: LONDON, Aug. 11President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that he was disappointed with the very hard Israeli line and noted that the current EgyptianIsraeli ceasefire agreement expired in 14 months.

title: FED ACTIONS SIGNAL A RISE IN FUNDS RATE
description: By its actions in the money market yesterday, the Federal Reserve Board gave its strongest signal so far that it wants to push shortterm interest rates still higher to slow the recently rapid growth of the nation's money supply. Consequently, it was widely predicted that the central bank soonperhaps today  would increase its discount rate from 5 percent, its level since last November.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses liste? In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Bushwick Block Seeking Light After Enduring Blackout
description: It is a rainy day and the debrisstrewn pavement on Gates Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn is slippery. Lucille Moore steps out of her apartment at No. 1089 and walks toward a drugstore on the block to buy some aspirin. She finds the store shuttered, and suddenly Mrs. Moore remembers that it had been looted and that it has closed down, probably for good.

title: 4 Newsmen Arrested In Suspect's Apartment
description: Yonkers, Aug. 11Four newsmen were arrested today after they allegedly were found, inside the Son of Sam suspect's apartment after it was officially sealed by the police.

title: Dollar Mixed in Europe; But Climbs in New York; Prices of Gold Decline
description: The dollar closed mixed against west European currencies in Europe yesterday, but gained later in New York after the, Federal Reserve confirmed that it had tightened credit policies. The Associated Press reported.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: THERE aren't many surprises in the scenario for Daughter of Deceit, a melodrama Luis Bunuel directed in Mexico in 1951. A happygolucky man discovers that his wife is unfaithful and, when the wife spitefully announces that the couple's daughter isn't really his, he throws his wife out and then abandons the baby. Years later, when the wife makes a deathbed confession that the girl was legitimate after all, the father sets out to find her.

title: CUBA AGREES TO LET 84 AMERICANS LEAVE WITH THEIR FAMILIES
description: HAVANA, Aug. 11Fidel Castro signaled another step toward the improvement of relations with the United States today by agreeing to allow 84 American citizens and their families to leave Cuba.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP)The third night of the annual FasigTipton Yearling Sales got off to a sensational start tonight with a $210,000 price for a filly, but a colt by Secretariat proved a disappointment.

description: Long before New York was a summer festival, before there was a film festival at Lincoin. Center or .even a Lincoln Center,. before the Carnegie Hall Cinema, the Elgin, the New Yorker and the St. Mark's Playhouse began showing classic film revivals, there was the Thalia on 95th Street west of Broadway.

description: YONKERS, Aug. 11Sam Carr, a 64yearold answering service owner who lived around the corner from David Berkowitz, learned today that his brooding neighbor had been identified by the police as the Son of Sam and he, himself as the Sam of the suspect's obsession.

title: McGovern Visits Dalmatian Isle
description: SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 (ReutersSenator George McGovern today visited the Dalmatian Island of Vis where he once made an emergency landing as a bomber pilot in World War II He was piloting his bomber over Czechoslovakia in 1944 when it was hit and he landed at Vis. Marshal Tito's Partisan headquarers were there for some time during the war.

description: A surge in domestic crude oil production, reflecting 600,000 barrels a day from Alaska's North Slope, is anticipated during the month of August, according to the latest weekly petroleum supply statistics released by the American Petroleum Institute.

description: TRENTON, Aug. 11 (AP)State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, a Republican, off to an early lead against Governor Byrne, a Democrat, a public opinion poll on the New Jersey gubernatorial election disclosed today.

title: Antiques
description: THE CENTENNIAL celebration of Thomas A. Edison's phonograph Moves into high gear today with a twopart ceremony at the New Jersey sites the inventor made famousMenlo Park and Glenmount in West Orange.

title: LEGAL STEPS IN CASE FACING COMPLEXITY
description: The arraignment yesterday of David Richard Berkowitz, the Son of Sam murder suspect, was pro forma, andexcept for the security and standingroom only courtroom audienceas cutanddried as such prodedures ordinarily are. But the legal steps that will follow are likely to become extraordinarily complex.

title: Economics In Disarray
description: CAMBRIDGE, EnglandProfessional economics grew and flourished on an unprecedented scale, especially in North America, after the end of World War IL At the same time, the Western industrial nations were enjoying a period of continuous growth and high employment, interrupted only by brief and shallow recessions and accompanied by only a mild rate of inflation in the price level. The central teaching of orthodox economic theory was the natural tendency to equilibrium in the freemarket system, and this did not appear to be in obvious contradiction to the facts of experience.

title: U. S. AIDES IN CHILE FIND SHIFT ON RIGHTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11Terence A. Todman, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, arrived here today on the heels of Allard K. Lowen stein, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations who specializes in human rights.

title: Young Cites Restraint By Cubans on Canal
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinichd, Aug. 11 (UPI)  Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, today praised what he termed Cuban restraint on the Panama Canal issue and said President Fidel Castro had urged the Panamanians to reach an early settlement.

title: BatteredWife Campaign Focusing On Woman Charged With Murder
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 11A Clementon resident charged with the murder of her husband, following a night when she was reportedly brutally beaten by him, pleaded not guilty today in a case that might serve to dramatize the plight of battered women throughout the country.

description: HIRSCHHORNBernard. In memory of my father and my friend, whose purpose guided me lo his very end.

title: Neutrality Act Cited by Defense at Haitian Exile Trial
description: TRENTON, Aug. 11Attorneys for five Haitian exiles accused of plotting to buy weapons for an invasion of their homeland, charged today that covert activities of the Central Intelligence Agency had rendered unconstitutionally vague the Federal Neutrality Act, which the men are accused of violating.

description: Dr. H. M. Marvin, a physician and former president of the American Heart Association, died Saturday at the PutnamWeaver Nursing Home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Seven Ready for Sapling
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 12Three of the top 2yearold colts In training head a field of seven juveniles for tomorrow's $111,215 Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park. The winner of the sixfurlong dash will earn $66,729 if all seven go to the post.

description: Fire Islanders are funny about their wagons.

description: FREEDOM FEST New Yorkers are invited tomorrow to attent a celebration at Columbia University hailing the 30th anniversary of India's independence. The free event has been organized by the Joint Committee of Indian Organizations, representing 50,000 residents of Indian origin in the metropolitan area.

title: Imp Wins Fastnet Race, But British Retain Cup
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 12 (UPI) Britain retained the Admiral's Cup today with fine performances by its threeboat team in the 605mile Fastnet Race, the last contest in the fiverace cup series.

title: McClellan Leaves Hospital
description: LITTLE ROCK Ark., Aug. 12 (AP)Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, was released from the Arkansas Baptist Medical Center here today, but doctors told him to continue to rest fo a while. The Senator, 80 years old, entered the hospital July 22 because he was suffering from chest discomfort and overexertion, his office said.

title: About New york
description: Three weeks to go until Labor Day, when what in some dim, forgotten past used to be called the summer doldrums traditionally ends. Summer, and especially this summer, has become a twofaced season. It is slack and playful and makes one want to stretch out toward nothingness. Yet it is often stealthy and sleek, a New York street kid full of eerie noises, and mysterious footfalls and turbulent tensions.

title: New Oil Strike Made in Vietnam
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 12 (Reuters)Vietnam has made a new oil strike with the assistance of the Soviet Union in Thai Bihn province, south of Hanoi, a Vietnamese official said here today. Le Van Hau, head of the Hanoi Trading Mission in Singapore, did not disclose the size of the new field, but said it was regarded by Hanoi as d good commercial prospect.

description: Article 2  No Title

title: HOWARD I. DOHRMAN
description: Howard I. Dohrman, a retired assistant vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday at his Miami home. He was 100 years old.

title: In Brazil, August Is a Month for the Unexpected in Politics
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12The crisis in Brazil had been building for weeks. Then, suddenly, with the threat of ouster from office hanging over his head for the second time, President Gehllio Vargas decided to commit suicide: He shot himself through the heart.

title: 2,000 Evacuated for Fumes
description: NOVI, Mich., Aug, 12 (AP)The police led 2,000 residents from their homes in this Detroit suburb today after 22 freight cars derailed and toxic fumes began escaping from an overturned tank car that carried paradichlorobenzene. Novi officials opened two schools to shelter the evacuees.

title: EDGAR H. LAWRENCE
description: Edgar Harcourt St. Leger Lawrence, former New York City newspaperman and a hospital administrator, died Thursday in his home at 102 East 31st Street. He was 73 years old.

title: McDermott, in a Surprise, Seeks More Babcock Stock
description: J. Ray McDermott & Company, a dark horse in the race to acquire control of the Babcock & Wilcox Company, has suddenly come to life with a tentative bid of $55 a share for an additional 35 percent of Babcock & Wilcox stock. McDermott already owns 9.9 percent of Babcock's shares.

title: U.S., Britain and South Africa Discuss Rhodesia Plan
description: LONDON, Aug. 12The United States, British and South African foreign ministers conferred for more than six hours today on the details of a joint AngloAmerican proposal on transferring power in Rhodesia from the white minority to the black majority.

title: Met Will Sell Fashions With a Russian Theme
description: The Metropolitan Museum has been in the selling business for years with copies of glassware, silver, jewelry and porcelain, and now it's going into readytowear. By the middle of September the museum will be offering clothes for men, women and children. Eleven pieces, along with a halfdozen accessories such as hoods and belts, are to be sold in a new little shop at the Met.

title: RESULTS; (OTB payoffs sublect to 5% Municipal surtax.)
Carnation's SecondQuarter Net Increased by 4% to $25.9 Million
description: The Carnation Company, one of the nation's major food processors, yesterday reported profit increases of 4 percent for the second quarter and 7.9 percent for the half year, the company's smallest gains in recent years.

title: An Offer to Sell 6 Hours of Berkowitz Tapes to The News Reported
description: A representative of Phillip Peltz, one of the lawyers for David R. Berkowitz, the socalled Son of Sam, called The Daily News yesterday morning and offered to sell more than six hours of taped conversations with the suspected .44caliber killer for $50,000.

title: Fine Folk Duos at Bottom Line
description: The Bottom Line has a bill through tonight that should please any lover of folk music. The headliners are Doc and Merle Watson, and they have their charms. But the opening performers, Mary McCaslin and Jim Ringer, are equally appealing, and more noteworthy simply because they are less well known.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 12, 1977

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARKS, Crocheron Park, Queens, 8:30.

title: First Aid for Foreign Aid
description: A new look at the country's foreign aid program needed if Americans are to be persuaded to increase the amounts they contribute to the impoverished peoples the world. This country now spends on foreign aid only half the proportion of its wealth that it did 15 years agoand only oneeighth the proportion spent during the Marshall Plan years. Jimmy Carter caught the weary mood of the nation in his campaign last year when he spoke against taxing the poor in the rich countries to help the rich in the poor countriesbut how do we help the poor in poor countries?

title: Kids Will Like Third 'Sinbad'
description: Question: What has the foot of a seagull, the power of an evil sorcerer and the accent of a Gabor sister?Answer: Zenobia, the sinister and ambitious royal stepmother in "Sinbad and the Eye of the Tiger," No. 3 in the latest generation of Sinbad movies, which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.Determined to look upon the throne of ancient Charok and be able to point out her son, the Caliph, Zenobia reduces Prince Kassim, the rightful heir, to the status of baboon, albeit one who retainsat least for a timethe ability to play chess.Things look bad in Charok until Sinbad (Patrick Wayne), seeking the hand of Kassim's sister, Farrah (Jane Seymour), returns from a voyage and determines to set things right.Along the way, he and his allies cross paths with some of the creations of animation expert Ray Harryhausen that have given this series something of a cult followingfleshless assassins with the heads and eyes of insects; a metal bullheaded giant called Minaton; one bee that acts like a B-1; an enormous troglodyte and, in the climactic battle, a saber-toothed tiger inhabited by the spirit of the villainous Zenobia, played by Margaret Whiting.Well, at least by becoming a tiger she has managed to rid herself of the fowl foot acquired during a potion shortage incurred while doing a turn as a tern to spy on Sinbad and his companions aboard their ship.Under the direction of Sam Wanamaker, this latest Sinbad adventure maintains the innocent and atavistic juvenile charm of the others in the series.In the midst of rather rudimentary acting by some of the humans, there are the admirable Harryhausen monsters; a reasonable amount of action; exotic locales, Spain, Jordan and Malta among them; Jane Seymour and Taryn Power (daughter of Tyrone Power and Linda Christian) to look good while looking frightened; and a happy ending (at least for the survivors).No child could ask for much more.

title: Congress Facing Proposals to Improve Its Standards as an Employer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12In 1964, Congress passed the Civil rights Act aimed at eliminating racial discrimination. At that time, the roster of Congressional employees was overwhelmingly white.

title: LANCE SAID TO FACE WIDER LOAN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 12The Comptroller of the Currency has widened his investigation of Bert Lance's financial dealings to include loans that may have indirectly benefited him and is searching bank records for about 20 loans that may have been extended to his wife, other members of the family and business entities, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: THOMAS L. HARRIGAN
description: Thomas L. Harrigan, who retired in 1961 as general sales manager of the Sinclair Refining Company, died Thursday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. Mr. Harrigan, who lived in Long Branch, was 81 years old. He is survived by his wife, Joan, and a brother, Raymond.

title: Pirates Sweep Mets Milian Injured
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12Add the Pittsburgh Pirates to the list of people not to fool with in a pennant race. Like Mother Nature, the Pirates are playing for keeps, something the Mets found out the hard way tonight when they lost a doubleheader as well as Felix Milian. The second baseman's collarbone was broken in a fight with Ed Ott, a Pirate catcher.

title: Billy Graham Presents Defense Of Unpublicized $23 Million Fund
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, attempting to quell any doubt about the fiscal integrity of his evangelistic organization, has issued a sixpage statement defending controversial $23 million fund that the vast majority of his supporters knew nothing about until recently.

title: Jailed Filipino Still Political Force
description: MANILA, Aug. 8On a recent morning Lupita AquinoConcio, a film director, stood before a group of businessmen as a breakfast speaker and startled the audience.

title: Researcher Says Motion Sickness May Be Defense Against Poisons
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)  A British researcher suggests that motion sickness is an unfortunate byproduct of a natural protective process developed in many animals to guard against ingestion of certain kinds of poisons.

title: CARTER ASSERTS U.S. CAN STILL INTERVENE IN DEFENSE OF CANAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12President Carter and his chief treaty negotiators stressed today that there would be no restrictions on United States rights to intervene in defense of the Panama Canal in the agreement relinquishing eventual control of the waterway to Panama.

title: EMILY DE FOREST WHITE
description: Emily DeForets White, active in civic and educational affairs, died Tuesday at I her home in St. Huberts, N.Y. She was 74 years old.

title: News Summary

title: Prostitutes Losing Berkelei, Fight As Residents Patrol in War Zone
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug, 11About mile from the University of California campus in Berkeley, where free speech and free love become touchstones of the last decade, a civic battle is being waged over sex for sale.

title: World Team Tennis
OFFICER WHO FIRED PISTOL IN PARKING LOT REASSIGNED
description: A policeman who allegedly fired his revolver during a dispute with a parkinglot attendant early yesterday has been placed on modified assignment pending an investigation, according to the Police Department.

title: An IrishAmerican Political Shibboleth Is Laid to Rest
description: WASHINGTONBehind the disclosures that the United States plans to offer economic aid to Northern Ireland to help heal its political wounds is an even more monumental development: a major shift in political philosophy by the leaders of a substantial segment of the United States electorate.

title: Paying CivilRights Legal Fees
description: Lawsuits have been a potent weapon in the struggle for civil rights, from opening the voting booth for all to insuring fair hiring practices and equal educational opportunity. Shepherding most of the cases through the courts have been a handful of civilrights litigating organizations. They represent the victims of systematic discrimination who are too poor to afford adequate counsel and have long been denied access to justice.

description: Incoming

title: 2 Shot to Death in Car on L.I.
description: A man and a woman were found shot to death in a car in Wyandanch, L. I. The police discounted comparisons with the Son of Sam slayings. Page 23.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA doctor of physical chemistry at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia has devised a reversible, nonsurgical method of birth control. The technique has been used successfully with rabbits on a laboratory scale, and preparations are being made for testing on women within the next three months.

title: Dual Purpose Funds

title: Four Newsmen Freed Without Bail On Yonkers Trespassing Charges
description: YONKERS, Aug. 12 (UPI)Four newsI men were arraigned here today on charges of criminal trespass for allegedly breaking into the apartment of David Ber1 kowitz, who the police say is the .44caliber killer.

title: Abie Nathan Mounts Protest for Peace
description: TEL AVIV, Aug 12In the latest of his selfprofessed demonstrations for peace, Abie Nathan presided over the burial of smashed military toys in a seafront park here today.

title: New Firemen Are Sworn In
description: Mayor Beame swore in 150 new firefighters yesterday, the first to be appointed to the Fire Department since the city imposed a hiring freeze three years ago.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The current twoyear session of the Legislature is drawing to a close with relatively little accomplished in the way of consumeroriented legislation.

title: LANCE SAID TO FACE WIDER LOAN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 12The Comptroller of the Currency has widened his investigation of Bert Lance's financial dealings to include loans that may have indirectly benefited him and is searching bank records for about 20 loans that may have been extended to his wife, other members of the family and business entities, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Helicopter Makes Daring Rescue High on Tallest Mountain. in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12A spectacular helicopter rescue was accomplished earlier this month high on the frozen slopes of the Soviet Union's highest mountain, the 24,590foot Communism Peak, in an effort to save the life of one of the country's most prominent scientists and educators.

title: Ewbank Needs Surgery For Hip Injured in 68
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 12Weeb Ewbank, the former New York Jets coach, will undergo surgery in November for a hip injury he suffered after the Jets 1968 American Football League championship victory over the Oakland Raiders.

title: CRIMINALS REVENUES FROM STORIES CURBED
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12A bill to prevent criminals from profiting on the tales of their crimes before compensating their victims has been signed by Governor Carey. his office announced today.

title: Rate of Inflation Off in Britain; Trade Gap Cut
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP)The British, long accustomed to bad economic news, learned today that their inflation rate was falling, their trade gap narrowing and interest rates dropping.

title: Theft by Executives Closes Swiss Firm
description: GENEVA, Aug. 12 (AP)Swiss authorities closed a private Geneva investment house today and issued warrants for the arrest of its president and vice president, alleging that they had fled the country with millions of dollars in customers funds.

title: Canadian Air Slowdown Continues
description: TORONTO, Aug. 12 (AP)Air traffic controllers at Toronto and Montreal airports continued a slowdown for the second day today, forcing some cancellations and delays of flights, Air Canada officials said. A spokesman said Air Canada flights were being delayed by 30 to 90 minutes. The controllers at the two airports have been operating a slowdown since a threeday strilir by the 2,200member Canadian Air Traffic Control Association was ended by federal legislation early Wednesday. The controllers had demanded more pay.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OT8 listing.

title: Quake Jolts Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (AP)Windows broke, dishes rattled and buildings shivered last night when a moderate earthquake rumbled through southern California from Santa Monica to Santa Barbara. James Whitcomb, a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, said the tremor's epicenter was outside of Sylmar, 25 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles in the San Fernando Valley.

title: In Memorian
description: GRAYLIlla. August 13, 1972. Sadly, missed, lovingly remembered.

title: Four Plead on Snake Imports
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP)Four herpetologists pleaded not guilty today to charges of illegally importing snakes, endangered reptiles and other exotic specimens. Entering pleas on arraignment before United States Magistrate Edwin Naythons were Henry A. Molt Jr., 37 years old, of Berwyn; Edwin A. Allen Jr., 50, of Newtown Square; Robert A. Udell, 33, of Cheltenham, and David Christensen, 24, of Princeton, N.J.

title: Hijacker Bumped Off Jet in Italy
description: BRINDISI, Italy, Saturday, Aug. 13 (AP) A 19yearold Egyptian student hijacked a Cairobound French jet and forced it to land here, but the pilot pushed him out of the cabin into the arms of the police as the aircraft was being refueled early today.

title: Carey, Citing Court Action, Vetoes Bills to Restore Some Blue Laws
description: ALBANY,Aug. 12Governor Carey, citing constitutional questions and a possibly adverse effect on the state's economy, announced today his veto of the legislature's efforts to restore a partial ban on Sunday sales in New York State.

title: More Refugees From Indochina May Be Allowed to Come to U.S.
description: Representatives of a number of Government agencies are preparing recommendations for approval by President Carter for the admission of Indochinese refugees beyond the 15,000 the Administration authorized last month.

title: Israel Is Moving To Make Pound Convert Freely
description: JERU$ALEM, Aug. 12  Menahem Begin's sevenweekold Likud Government has begun to relax the foreigncurrency controls that helped lead to the downfall of the previous Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin of the Labor Party.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Shareholders of the financially ailing Commonwealth Oil Refining Company approved at the annual meeting in San Juan, P.R., yesterday a proposal to grant Ashland Oil Inca an option to buy a $50 million issue of new Commonwealth convertible preferred stock.

description: Inmates at the maximumsecurity prison in Auburn, N.Y., have carried their peaceful strike into its fifth day, but the prison superintendent has called for an end to it by Monday.
