title: Jane Barus, Jersey Civic Leader And Women Voters Official, Dies
description: Jane Barus, a prominent leader in New Jersey civic affairs, a former suffragette and a national officer in the League of Women Voters, died Tuesday at the age of 84 at her summer home in Cape Cod, Mass. She also lived in Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: Texts of Carter's Statement and Summary of Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Following are the texts of President Carter's statement on the agreement on a new Panama Canal treaty and the Administration's summary of the hey elements in the accord, as made public today by the White House:

title: Gunman Slays a Man and a Woman in a Car on L.I.
description: WYANDANCH L.I., Saturday, Aug. 13A man and a woman were found shot to death in a 1976 red Mercedes Benz in an industrial section of this Suffolk County community last night.

title: McGee Is SecondNicklaus at 140
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 12It was late afternoon as Jack Nicklaus was assessing the leader board after the second round of the 59th Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: Alfred Brittain, Veteran Banker In Chicago and New York, Was 81
description: Alfred Brittain, a veteran banker in New York and Chicago for more than three decades and the father of Alfred Brittain 3d, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, died Thursday in the Greenwich Hospital. He was 81 years old, and lived on Cedar. Cliff Road, Riverside, Conn.

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesterday's editions of The Times, Charles T. Duncan was incorrectly identified as dean of the Harvard University Law School. Mr. Duncan is dean of the Howard University Law School. He is a graduate of Harvard Law School.

title: EEL PERMITS RISE IN ALASKA OIL PRICE
description: The Federal Energy Administration said yesterday it had adopted regulations that would permit Alaskan North Slope oil to be priced at the levels of imported crude and proposed to once again adjust oil prices for inflation, effective Sept. 1.

title: A Scenario for Writing Success
description: LOS ANGELESIn April 1978, 36yearold Spencer Eastman sat down to write the first page ce his first screen play. Sixteen months later, Eastman has sold two original screenplays. In addition, he has done an adaptation of Leslie Waller's nonfiction horror story, Hide in Plain Sight, about a man who loses his children when his former wife marries a Mafia stool pigeon and takes them into hiding with her. It will go into production at MGM late this fall.

title: World News Briefs
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Aug. 12 (AP) The police reportedly fired on protesters who showered them with rocks and bottles during a general strike on the island of Aruba called to protest: the exclusion of the island's proindependence majority party from the governing coalition of the Netherlands Antilles. Three persons were reported iniured.

title: Nkomo Insists Smith Must Resign
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 12Joshua Nkomo, the black nationalist leader of guerrilla forces in Rhodesia, said here today that, despite discussion of a number of plans aimed at ending guerrilla warfare and peacefully transferring rule to the black majority, his group would not accept anything less than the removal from office of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

title: Computer to Keep Track of Criminal Cases Is Tested
description: Robert M. Morgenthau remembers with displeasure the time a rape victim complained to him that she had been called before two grand juries to tell the story of the same attack. The result, the Manhattan District Attorney learned, was that the suspected rapist was indicted twice, because the case had inadvertently been given to two different assistants to prosecute.

title: 21,000 Jehovah's Witnesses Watch 262 Baptized
description: Elizabeth Citavacis, who is 82 years old, needed some assistance as she climbed down into the waistdeep portable pool in a swimsuit and orange bathing cap.

title: Jaki Byard at Village Corner
description: No one draws on the entire panorama of Jazz piano styles in quite as catholic a fashion or with as much Joyful relish at Jaki Byard, who is playing, alone and unaccompanied, at the Village Corner, Bleecker Street at La Guardia Place, through next Wednesday.

title: LessDeveloped Nations to Benefit From Auctions of Gold Into 1978
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Monthly gold auctions to raise money for lessdeveloped countries will continue at least through the spring of 1978, the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: Notes on People
description: An angry constituent of Edward M. Kennedy was so bent on berating the Senator that he broke up a volleyball game and forced the Massachusetts Democrat to pack up his family and leave Cuttyhunk Island last weekend. Senator Kennedy and some of his clan sailed to Cuttyhunk, about 15 miles southeast of New Bedford, Mass., and started a volleyball game on the public court. The island has only 90 yearround residents, but one of them is Asa Pain Cobb Lombard, 63 years old, who is angry about Senator Kennedy's Island Trust Bill. Asa's a bitter man, said Alpheus P. Tilton, an island selectHe feels he wasn't raid enough for some of his land that was turned into the Cape Cod National Seashore. Mr. Lombard was so vituperative that the Kennedys departed. The island selectmen are sending an apology to the Senator.

title: JUROR HOSPITALIZED IN TRIAL OF MANDEL
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 12One of the 12 jurors deliberating a verdict in the Federal corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five business friends was hospitalized tonight, raising the possibility of a second mistrial in the prolonged prosecution of the twoterm Democratic Governor.

title: 8 Charged With Stealing Checks For Welfare and Social Security
description: A former bank manager and a suspended post office clerk were among eight persons indicted on charges of conspiracy to steal and cash more than $200,000 in welfare and Social Security checks, Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta announced yesterday.

title: Todd May Open Up
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12Very early tomorrow night, maybe on the New York Jets first play from scrimmage, the quarterback is going to do something flashyperhaps a keeper, perhaps a long pass, perhaps a rollout.

title: Proposal to Cut F.B.I. Budget Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12A plan for heavy cuts in the budget of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for the fiscal year 1979 has been proposed by topranking Justice Department officials, Administration sources reported today.

title: PANAMA NEGOTIATOR DEFENDS CANAL PACT
description: PANAMA, Aug. 12The Panamanian Government today mounted a strong defense of the new Panama Canal treaty, arguing that the negotiated deal with the United States was the only way of averting the massacre of the best of our youth.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing. FIRST59,000, cl., f., 3Y0, 6f.

title: Around the Nation
description: Twentymileanhour winds blew the Marble Cone fire in the California's Big Sur country northward yesterday, jumping creeks and fire lines and covering 100,000 acres.

title: Pennsy Offers Complex Plan for Back Taxes
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company, languishing in bankruptcy since June 1970 and unable to pay its debts, now wants to pay its back taxes. But it's not easy, the company is discovering.

title: James Earl Jones Is in Rehearsal ForOneCharacterTaulRobeson
description: James Earl Jones. last seen on Broadway as Lennie in Of Mice and Men in 1974, will return next February in Paul Robeson, a onecharacter play by Phillip Hayes Dean. based on the life of the renowned actor and singer. Mr. Jones began rehearsals last Monday in Los Angeles, under the direction of Charles Nelson Reilly, who also staged The Belle of Amherst, the onecharacter play in which Julie Harris portrayed Emily Dickinson.

title: WINFIELD PARKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)Winfield Parks, a prizewinning photographer for the National Geographic magazine, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 45 years old.

title: Assad Rejects Idea of Talks at U.N.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Aug. 12President Hafez alAssad of Syria dismissed today the idea of Americansponsored proximity talks at the United Nations next month between Arab and Israeli foreign ministers.

title: League Leaders
description: BY The Associated Press

title: Carter Signs Appropriations Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)President Carter signed legislation today appropriating $12.7 billion to the Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration for fiscal 1978, which begins Oct. 1.

title: ENTRIES
Connors Gains Clay Semifinal In 3Set Test
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (AP)Stung by a firstset loss, the topseeded Jimmy Connors withstood a strong challenge by Dick Stockton tonight and won a threehour quarterfinal match, 26, 64, 108, in the 67th United States clay court tennis championships.

title: Iran Says Factories Hurt Caviar Industry
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 12 (UPI)Having first blamed the Soviets, the Iranians now concede that wastes from their new industries dumped into the Caspian Sea are hurting Iran's caviar industry.

title: A Heatwave in Antarctica
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 12 (AP)Temperatures at an Australian scientific station in Antarctica went above the freezing point early this month for the first time since records were started, scientists reported today. T. J. Petry, the engineer with the Bureau of Meteorology'. Antarctic division, said a temperature of 42 degrees Fahrenheit was recorded on Aug. 2, compared to a normal temperature at the base at this time of the year of between 13 and 22 below zero.

title: Australia, Gretel Win Narrowly
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12Playing a catchup game on the America's Cup course is almost impossible if your boat falls as far astern as Gretel II and France I fell today. But there are several variables that can turn things around in a hurry, and two are a fickle breeze and a sudden fog.

title: EXLANDLADY ASSERTS SHE KNEW IT WAS HE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 12 A woman who rented a room in her home to David R. Berkowitz, more than a year ago said today that she was certain as early as June 10 that her former tenant was the .44caliber killer.

title: Army Bars Widow's Plea to Void Conviction of G.I. Executed in 45
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Army offered sympathy today to the crippled, destitute widow of Pvt. Eddie Slovik, the only American soldier executed for desertion in World War II, but rejected her request to reverse his conviction so that she could collect $68,000 in Government life insurance benefits.

title: Israel's Alliance With Christians In Lebanon May Strain U .S . Ties
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 12Prime Minister Mcnahem Begin's administration has made a basic, if informal, alliance with the Lebanese Christians that may lead to an important policy divergence with the United States, according to an authoritative Israeli source.

title: Centenary of Edison's First Phonograph Is Marked
description: MENLO PARK, N.J.. Aug. 12Conrad Beneshan shouted the nursery rhyme into the m:gaphone attached to the tinfoilencased cylinder, probably as loudly as Thomas A. Edison did when he invented the phonograph in 1877.

title: Young Criticizes Cuba On Human Rights
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago, Aug. 12  Andrew Young criticize' Cuba's human rights record here today, saying it would have to be taken into account if and when the United States moved toward normalizing relations with Cuba.

title: Personal Investing
description: Municipal bond mutual funds and unit trusts are pitted against each other in a vigorous marketing battle for investor dollars, The relatively new mutual funds differ in structure and objective from the unit trusts, faptors the individual must consider in choosing between the taxfree investment vehicles. Page 27.

title: Dow Index Falls 6.33 to 871.10; LowestSince'76
description: The reality of rising shortterm rates and the threat of a slowing economy plunged the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday to its lowest level since the first trading day of 1976.

title: Public TV Finds Popularity Rising
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)The Corporation for Public Broadcasting said that surveys had shown an increase in viewing of public television in the last year.

description: Kids Decathlon, Laced With Mud

title: Arabs View Vance Trip as Aid in Clarifying Positions
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 12It was clear today that while there were few tangible results to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's 11day mission to Israel and five Arab countries, it did much to clarify positions.

title: Carson Disoriented
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12In the Giants confusion over the searches for a quarterback, an offensive line, wide receivers and, in fact, an entire offense, let it not be overlooked that Harry Carson is confused, too.

title: Cleveland Trust Prime to 6%
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP)The Cleveland Trust Company, the last major bank to maintain a 6 percent prime lending rate, today raised its rate to the 6 percent charged by other major banking institutions. Last week,. the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifthlargest commercial bank, raised its prime rate by  percent to 6 percent. The prime rate is a bank's charge for loans to its most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: SATELLITE LAUNCHED TO WATCH RADIATION
description: Instruments Will Record the Signs of Violent Activity in the Universe Major Discoveries Expected

title: INDICTMENT OF STEINGUT IS DISMISSED BY COURT
description: An indictment against City Councilman Robert Steingut, charging him with failing to list a 1973 campaign contribution, has been dismissed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Security Debate Growing in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 12A controversy over the activities of Government intelligence agencies was intensified today by a report that a Government security agency had collected personal information on prominent member of Parliament who later became the head of his party in the House of Commons.

title: Henry A. Laughlin Is Dead at 85
description: Henry Alexander Laughlin, president of Houghton Mifflin Company, the Boston publishers, from 1939 until his retirement in 1963, died Wednesday in his summer residence in Fermoy, County Cork, Ireland. His home was in Concord, Mass., and his age was 85.

title: SETSUTARO KOBAYASH
description: Setsutaro Kobayashi, chairman of the board of the Fuji Photo Film Company, died yesterday in .Tokyo, a company spokesman in New York reported. Mr. Kobayashi, who was 77 years old, joined Fuji in 1934. He was named a director of the company in 1937, became executive managing director, in 1943, and was appointed chairman of the board in 1971.

title: Due Process for Candidate Nadjari
description: Many New Yorkers doubt Maurice Nadjari's fairmindedness. As special prosecutor he left a record of convictions and indictments overturned, and of damage inflicted on the reputations of defendants later exonerated. But no one doubts his qualification as a member of the Republican Party. It is therefore odd that his candidacy for Queens District Attorney should be terminatedat least for the momentnot by public rejection of his courtroom record, but because a Supreme Court judge found him technically not enrolled as a party member on the day of his nomination.

title: Phils Rout Cubs on 6 Homers, 103
description: When the game was critical, the Chicago Cubs had pitched Rick Reuschel. Along with Bruce Sutter, the Cubs relief star, Reuschel had kept the oncelowly Cubs at the top of the standing in the National League East for almost three months.

title: ExtraSensible Perception
description: In the cyclical way of the world, we have been passing through a period of resurgent mysticism. Educated people ask each other what signs they were born under; witchcraft is discussed seriously on college campuses; occult bookshops flourish, and cults of all kinds contend with pornography for the sidewalks of our cities.

title: Books of The Times
description: The life of Montgomery Clift, as documented in Robert LaGuardia's graphic, harrowing, yet admiring bibgraphy, is an American nightmare, with tragic dimensions. A pampered, handsome child, Montgomery Clift made his Broadway debut when he was 14 years old, and by 20 he was sharing a stage with Alfred Lunt, and learning from him as pupil to master.

title: Immunizing of 90% of Schoolchildren, Especially for Measles, Planned in Fall
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (AP)A program to immunize at least 90 percent of'the nation's schoolchildren this fall for measles and other childhood diseases was announced today by the National Center for Disease Control. The program will/Include k special effort to stein outbreaks of measles, which have increased markedly in some states this year.

title: Plan to Reunite Adoptive Children And Natural Parents Is Announced
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)The Division of Youth and Family Services, New Jersey's largest adoption agency, announced today that it would establish a voluntary program to help reunite adoptive children and their natural Parents.

title: New York City Has a Plan to Resolve Budget Problem
description: New York City officials said yesterday that they had come up with a plan to reduce the impact on the city's budget of an adverse accounting ruling to a manageable S23 million.

title: Crop Estimates Depress Soybean Future Prices; Wheat and Oats Weaken
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)Prices for soybean futures, depressed by official estimates of a record harvest, fell 25 cents a bushel to new lows today and kept the lid on farm futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: MARK W. LAIBE
description: Mark W. Laibe, who retired in 1966 as vice president in charge of purchasing for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio, died Wednesday in Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital. He lived in Naples and was 76 years old.

title: Terrors and Delights of the Traveler Abroad
description: PRINCETON, N.J.

title: Deaths
description: ALOENDr. Ruel Lawrence, 78, of Setauket, N. Y.. died Aug. 9. at the home of his son, Dr. Peter D. Alden in Burlington, Vt. Burial will be at New Rochelle, N.Y., in September. Born al Concord, N. II., he was a son of Ruei Seabury Alden and Oretta Watson Alden, educated at scnoots at Proctor, Vt., he graduated from the University of Vt., College of Medicine, and interned at Postgraduate Hospital Columbia University, N. Y. C., prior to his retirement he practiced medicine at Hempstead, N. where he was on the staff at Nassau, Mercy and Meadowbrook Hospitals, survivors include his widow, Harriet Edwards Dunham Alden of 45 Bilodeau Pkwy., Burlington, Vt., a sister, Isabel A. Wansker of Sarasota, Fla., a son, Dr. Peter D. Alden, Burlington, Vt., 2 daughters, Elizabeth A. Little, ,Lincoln, Mass. and Priscilla A. Button, Summerville, S. C., and 10 grandchildren.

description: BASEBALL

title: VLADIMIR KARPOV
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (UPI)A provincial daily this week reported the death of Vladimir Karpov, a Byelorussian author. Sovietskaya Byelorussia said Mr. Karpov died recently at the age of 65 of a grave disease. Mr. Karpov, a schoolteacher before World War II, published his novels Year After Year, Autumn Rains, The Bloody Banks of the Nemila, and Byelorussia, during the 1950's and 1960's.

title: Cuomo Proposes Setting Up Unit To Coordinate Help for Families
description: Mario M. Cuomo, expounding what has become the major theme of his campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination, yesterday proposed a Family Protection Agency to coordinate municipal services to a growing number of troubled households in New York City.

title: Republican Calls for Lance's Resignation
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 12Representative John B. Anderson, the thirdranking Republican in the House, called tonight for the resignation of Bert Lance, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Cash Prices
description: Friday, Aug. 12, 1977

title: Ban on Home Sale SignsNear DetroitDefied
description: OAK PARK, Mich., Aug. 11Shirley Cash, a real estate agent, reposted sale sign in front of a house this morning in defiance of a new ordinance designed to minimize socalled white flight. She said it would remain there until she was prosecuted.

title: CANADA'S LIVING COST UP BY 0.9% IN JULY
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 12The announcement by the Government today of another jump in the cost of living has added to the adverse influences, symptomatic of the sagging economy here, that have depressed the Canadian dollar to its lowest point in . eight years on international money markets.

title: Anibal Escalante Is Dead at 67; Communist Leader Jailed by Cuba
description: HAVANA, Aug. 12 (Reuters)Anibal Escalante, a proMoscow leader of the Cuban Communist Party who was jailed in 1968 after being accused of trying to split the party, has died here, the Government announced today. He was 67 years old.

title: Plaque to Cannibal Won't Return
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)A plaque honoring Alferd Packer, the Colorado mountain man convicted of eating five prospectors in 1874, will not be restored to the wall of the Agriculture Department cafeteria, Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today.

title: Enterprise Survives in Soviet Asian Bazaar

title: LOSER IN MINE UNION RACE BIDS U.S. CANCEL ELECTION

description: The American Bridge Association, which has a primarily black membership, regularly welcomes nonmembers at its tournaments. A result of this hospitable policy was that a major title at the association's 44th Summer Nationals in Los Angeles this week was won by a visiting sextet.

description: SALAMANCA, N.Y.The Seneca Nation of Indians is putting the finishing touches on its new $265,000 museum here In preparation for its public opening sometime in September.

title: 'Suspiria,' a Specialty Movie, Drips With Gore
description: Right from the start, it's clear that the Italian-made, English-language "Suspiria" is a specialty item: The opening credits show the title of the movie carved out of pulsating glands. Writer-director Dario Argento has an unusually horrific slant on life, to say the very least, and his film's most powerful moments have a way of making one think about open-heart surgery. But "Suspiria," which opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater, does have its slender charms, though they will most assuredly be lost on viewers who are squeamish.The plot, as transparent as the pane of glass that slices up the movie's first victim, is intentionally ridiculous, and Mr. Argento's direction has the mocking, stylized simplicity of a comic strip. A strange, pouty girl named Susy Banyon (Jessica Harper) arrives at a German ballet academy, and within minutes a monster is whittling away at her classmates. Nobody will level with Susy about what's going on and, in general, the students' compassion for one another leaves a lot to be desired. "Poor David," remarks one, "torn to pieces. Incredible!"The headmistress, played primly by Joan Bennett, is no help either. Though she puts up a great show of gentility in public, she secretly shrieks things like "She must die, die, die!"The film's ostensible highlights include a bat on the rampage, a plague of white worms, "Tubular Bells"-type music by a group called The Goblins, and a great many graphic tips on how to carve one's fellows into rib roast.However, Mr. Argento's methods make potentially stomach-turning material more interesting than it ought to be. Shooting on bold, very fake-looking sets, he uses bright primary colors and stark lines to create a campy, surreal atmosphere, and his distorted camera angles and crazy lighting turn out to be much more memorable than the carnage."Suspiria" is really quite funny, during those isolated interludes when nobody is bleeding.

title: SelfPark Garages Sound Death Knell of Car Jockey
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12Through trial and little error, 52yearold Rheuben Blackmon has mastered the art over the last 37 years of being a car parking jockey. But just as cars have changed, so has the parking garage business.

title: Space Shuttle Glides to a Landing, Passing Its First Solo Flight Test
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 12The space shuttle Enterprise, the first of a fleet of reusable vehicles for making space travel a more workaday experience, passed its first flight test today by making a smooth glide landing on a dry lake bed in the Mojave Desert.

title: Centenary of Edison Phonograph Marked
description: MENLO PARK, Aug. 12Conrad Beneshan shouted the nursery rhyme into the megaphone attached to the tin feilencased cylinder, probably as loudly as Thomas A. Edison did when he invented the phonograph in 1877.

J. His age was 89. He is survived by his wife, Ruth: two daughters, Nancy L. Coati and Carol L. Baldwin, and six grandchildren.

Schwartz, long a wellknown friend of Greenwich Village literary figures, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness, He lived at 30 Greenwich Avenue, and was 78 years old. Mr. Schwartz started a newspaperdistribution business and stationery store in 1929 in the Village that became popular gathering spot for writers and others, He is survived by his wife, Syd; a son, Norman; two daughters, Leda FremontSmith and Marcia Schapiro; four grandchildren, and a brother, Louis.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER

But for six days, beginning Tuesday, they will descend on the Westchester Country Club in Harrison where, along with thousands of spectators, they will watch little white balls careen over manicured greens.

title: Here Come the Firemen
description: Here are the New York City firemen: at ease and on the job, drinking coffee in the firehouse, crawling on their bellies into black smokefilled rooms, horseplaying, laughing, fighting fires, fighting for breath on a stretcher. The text of Firehouse (Doubleday, $14.95) is by Dennis Smith, firemanauthor (Report From Engine Company 82). It describes the fireman's daily tasks, highs and hangups, what keeps him at this dangerous dirty job. Jill Freedman's stark, brilliant photographs record indelibly the exhaustion on men's faces, the lost terror in a small boy's eyes, camaraderie of two firemen embracing, the tears of a new widow.

title: More of the Campaign Than the Country
description: JULES WITCOVER, for many years a reporter on The Washington Post, now a columnist for The Washington Star, is one of the ablest and most expert political reporters in Washington. It is probably true that if he had worked for another newspaper, where he would not have had to share prominence with so many other wellknown writers, his reputation outside the. Washington political community would stand even higher than it does: Inside that community he stands in the first tank.

title: Notes: 3 Ships= 5,000 Lire
description: Travelers in Italy (and people in this country who have Italian money stashed away in a drawer) should examine their 5,000lira (about $6) bills very carefully. There are two kinds of 5,000lira notes, both the same size, both light green on one side, blue on the other, but one of the two has ceased to be legal tender. And Italian officials say that there's still an enormous number of this version in circulation. The bill that has been scrapped shows only one of the three small ships with which Christopher Columbus made his celebrated first voyage to the New World in 1492. The bill that remains current displays all three vessels. Both notes carry a portrait of Columbus on their other side.

title: The Magnetism of Eilshemius
description: LOUIS EILSHEMIUS was a true eccentric, and his bizarre behavior so influenced his reputation as an artist that even today he is seen in many quarters as more an eccentric than an artist. He wrote letters to editors, dealers and critics castigating them for lack of vision in understanding his work. He had a highly exalted view of himself and handed out pamphlets in which he described himself as a supreme genius, the world's mightiest mind, an exdoctor, exathlete, exmimic, scientist supreme.

The men, who stopped frequently to remove boulders from their path, wore heavy, frayed clothes almost matching the color of the deep brown soil they worked.

title: An American Accord
description: After 13 years of negotiations, the United States and Panama have finally reached agreement on the draft of a treaty to transfer control of the Panama Canal and the adjacent Canal Zone to Panamaand then only by the year 2000. The proposal must still be confirmed by the United States Senate, and that is hardly a certainty. Substantial bipartisan opposition remains to surrendering, even 23 years from now, control over a waterway that Washington has operated for most of this century.

The proposed rules came under intense attack from institutional investors, including insurance companies, banks, pension funds and investment houses. All of them complained that the reporting requirements would be too burdensome.

On Friday night at 8 the Mets are back at Shea Stadium against Cincinnati, in a series that marks the first New York appearance of Torn Seaver in a Reds uniform. Burke chronicled the adventures of a house dick/private eye named Samuel Moses Kelly, a black who works in New York around Broadway and 72d Street. Both were fine books. very New Yorkish, and both were well received. But for some reason Burke has dropped temporarily, one hopesSam Kelly. In his new book, THE HAMA SUTRA TANGO (Harper & Row, $7.95), he introduces Joseph Streeter, a jazz pianist and part owner of a restaurantclub (illegal gambling upstairs) on West 50th Street.

You look like the wicked witch. Somewhere else on the dial he is a sick man in pajamas, sweating out a fever that eventually will be cured by Bufferin.

Yanatelli performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of the Sacred Heart Church.

title: A Religious TugofWar
description: A RELIGIOUS tugofwar for Jewish souls is going on throughout the United States. On the Island, B'nai Yeshua, a Jews for Jesus group, has settled on a milliondollar estate at Stony Brook and has announced plans to witness to (attempt to convert) the two million Jews of the Greater New York area.

title: Wh't's Doing in LOS ANGELES
description: TRUE AND FALSEFor many people who haven't been here, Los Angeles has an image concocted of unequal parts of freeways, sun, smog, blondes, Hollywood glamour and Hollywood debauchery, Beverly Hills wealth and Watts poverty, drivein churches and sleepin encounter groups, cultural unsophistication and relentless urban sprawl50 suburbs in search of a city. To a degree, all these clichs are trueand false. As in any large city, you can find just about any kind of life style. It is a complex city, where almost any generalization is inadequate, where new arrivals have a tendency to keep searching for the heart of things and never finding it. The easiest way to come to grips with the 460 square miles of Los Angeles is to think not of one city but a collection of many communities knitted together by a network of freeways. Its reputation notwithstanding, that network provides a highly efficient way of getting around.

title: Yankees Records

Its neighborhood is gray with warehouses and clouded with the exhaust of trucks that steadily rumble along beneath the West Side Highway.

title: Mandel Trial Is Delayed by Hospitalization of Juror
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 13The prolonged trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five of his business friends was delayed again today by the hospitalization of a juror just as the 12member jury jury seemed to be near a verdict in the twoyearold case.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Lake Kezar, the quickest route from the tristate area is Interstate 95 to New Haven, I91 to Hartford, I84 and I86 to 190 (Massachusetts Turnpike) at Sturbridge. Take the Worcester exit onto I290 to I495 to Lowell. Take U.S. 3 to New Hampshire's Everett Turnpike to I93 to the Meredith exit onto New Hampshire State Routes 104, 25, 113 and 16 to Conway, then State Route 113 to U.S. 302 to Fryeburg, then Maine State Route 5 to Center Lovell. The trip takes about seven hours from New York City.

title: COLUMBIA IS MEETING SNAG ON KOREAN GIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  Columbia University has been seeking a $1.5 million gift from South Korea, but the grant has evidently been delayed because of adverse publicity that followed an earlier Korean donation to Harvard.

title: Correction
description: In The Review of July 31, it was incorrectly stated that the Gospel of Matthew and the Epistle to the Thessalonians were in the Old Testament. Both are, of course, in the New Testament.

title: Reform Needed in Federal Aid
description: WEST HAVEN

title: Poll Finds Most jerseyans Don't Use Seat Belts
description: ALTHOUGH 75 percent of New Jersey motorists responding to a Gallup Poll said that the use of seat belts was important in reducing deaths and serious injuries in automobile accidents, 60 percent said that they never, or hardly ever, used the safety devices.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WHAT F.A.O. Schwarz is to a rich city kid, the local hardware store is to your middleclass suburban male. Not all males, mind you: the older ones seem to have sacrificed enoughegos, cocktail hours at the clubwhile the younger ones are too busy losing themselves and finding girls. Or are they finding themselves and losing girls, these days?

title: INTERVIEW
description: MICHAEL DiPERSIO of Bradley Beach is a builder who has compressed to only eight hours the time from groundbreaking to ribboncutting. He works fast, for his bulldozer is the sea, with waves more powerful and regular than manmade metal laws.

title: Delivering The Bomb
description: ENOLA GAY is a fascinating, uneven, detailed but, in parts, shamelessly padded account of the seminal military operation of this strident century: the dropping of the first atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945.

title: The Great Idea Man
description: YOU already know one Mortimer Adlerthe public Adler of nationwide and formidable reputation: the polymathic promoter of the great books movement, the circuitriding evangelist of liberal education based on these books (the gospel according to St. John's College), the brains behind the new 15th edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, the cataloguer who recruited a staff (including a young novelist named Saul Bellow) to index the great ideas of Western civilization (all 102 of them) in a giant Syntopicon, the author of the bestselling How to Read a Book, close friend and colleague of the University of Chicago's late Robert Hutchins, guiding spirit of the annual Executive Seminars in Aspen, Colo., scourge of John Dewey and progressive education, founder of the Institute for Philosophical Research (with its grandiose dream of a modern Summa Dialectica).

title: Laura Baugh Attracts Attention, Not Victory
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.The man said he was looking for Laura Baugh, and the woman behind the players registration desk gave him one of those Aren'tTheyAll looks.

title: Adm. Edward Dannreuther of Britain; Survivor of 1916 Battle of Jutland
description: HASTINGS, England, Aug. 13 (AP)Rear Adm. Hubert Edward Dannreuther, who saw 1,025 fellow British seamen killed when his ship was blown up in the World War I battle of Jutland, died at his home here yesterday, relatives reported, He was 96 years old.

title: GARDENING
description: MOST of the insect pests that plague gardeners are sneaky. The creepy crawlers usually work at night. Voracious feeders, they dine underneath leaves or inside them and crawl inside stems. There they quietly do their damage undetectedat least for a while.

title: Many Homeless in Mindanao Flood
description: MANILA, Aug. 13 (Reuters)More than 1,500 people have been made homeless by floods and a fire in Mindanao in the last few days, the Philippines Red Cross reported today. It said 226 families had to move to higher ground in Maguindanao when the Rio Grande overflowed following heavy rain. In Parang, the Red Cross is caring for 670 persons made homeless by a fire.

title: HENRY WILLIAMSON
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Henry Williamson, the author of Tarka the Otter and Saler the Salmon died today at a Berkshire nursing home. He was 81 years old. An introspective author, he wrote prolifically about his World War I experiences and rural life in Norfolk and Devon. He wrote two semiautobiographical works, The Flax of Dream and A Chronicle of Ancient Sunlight, but he was best known for his books on nature.

title: IN AMERICA
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio. Normally we've time only for the now people who always seem to be finding themselves in a new marriage, career or therapy after having discovered they were lost when they last thought themselves found. Hut occasionally we can spare an instant for the then people. Those from that political and stylistic farrago we used to know as the Movement are of special interest because we can view their present through the prism of their past and in that pure light, see compromise spelled out in living color. The satisfaction isn't easy to define but it's a pleasure to react that Rennie Davis, still devoted to the oleaginous Guru Ma raj Ji, is now selling insurance in Denver; or that Eldridge Cleaver is evangelizing with Chuck Colson; or that Tom Hayden, last year's media candidate, has some new schemes to spend Jane Fonda's money.

title: Chimp in Driver's Seat Is Among Surprises for Zoomobile Visitors
description: WANTAGH, L.I.Charlie, Oscar, Eric and Nanny are neither sports enthusiasts nor average swimmers or boaters. Not one of the four is interested in obtaining an enviable tan or finding a summer romance, yet for several weeks they have been regularly frequenting parks and beaches throughout Long Island.

title: Corporate Moves: New York Region Holds Its Own
description: WHEN Maurice Chevalier was asked, as he frequently was in his last years, how felt about life as an octogenarian, his stock reply was, Well, when I think of alternative . . . . The same kind of reply is heard these days when business and political leaders are asked how they feel about the continuing movement of New York City companies to New Jersey, Westchester County, Long Island and Connecticut. both suburban and city leaders, the alternative to be avoided is the relocation of companies to distant sunbelt states. Their concern is real, because some New York concerns are moving to Georgia. Florida. Texas and California.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThey came from Wall Street and Chicago, from prestigious universities and from the Pacific Coast. Day after day, a veritable caravan of men in conservative blue suits filed into a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing room to protest or support the proposed elimination of an apparently simple regulation.

title: West Virginia Air Crash Kills 4
description: PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Aug. 13 (AP) A twinengine airplane returning from a flight to Buffalo crashed near the Wood County Airport late last night, killing all four persons aboard. The victims were identified by officials as Blane Gable, 21 years old, the pilot; Woulter DeVries, 22,, the copilot, a native of Holland, and two passengers, Wanda Barker, 39, of Smithvine, W.Va., and Arthur Cunningham, 56, of Harrisville, W.Va.

title: Planning Pinelawn's Successor
description: PINELAWN

title: Design
description: In a pastoral setting just outside Brussels, Belgian artist Pierre Culot plies his art  sculpting robust ceramics in an 18thcentury farmhouse surrounded by gardens. His sculptures pervade the house, turning every room into a series of still lifes. The rooms derive their color and mood from his sculpture. For instance, the walls echo the buff tones of potter's clay and the paved floors reinforce the coolness of stoneware. Culot chose the furniture, such as the modern seating in the living room and the provincial Empire furniture in the dining room, to allow his art to predominate. In this spare but elegant setting he has realized his intent  to live in a private museum where his art can be savored and enjoyed.

title: A Storm Over Nassau Housing
description: MINEOLA

title: Headliners
description: Alterd Packer, a frontiersman, won a dubious place in history in 1874, when, driven by dwindling provisions, he killed five prospectors he was guiding through the Colorado wilderness, and ate them. He later became a folkfigure to the people of Colorado, and the University of Colorado named its cafeteria grill after him. So, following the Western example officials of the Federal Department of Agriculture decided to name their new cafeteria after Mr. Packer. Last week, however, a General Service Administration official ordered the dedication plaque removed, saying it was in bad taste. Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture, who has complained about the quality of the cafeteria's food, reluctantly agreed, saying the plaque was an inside joke. Mr. Bergland, a Democrat, had defended the choice by pointing out its bipartisan nature. In sentencing Mr. Packer, the Secretary said, the judge 103 years ago declared, There was only six Democrats in all of Hinsdale County, and you ate five of them.

title: Soviet Says West Germans Would Violate Berlin Pact By Holding a Trial in City
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 13 (Reuters)The Soviet Union has warned that a trial in West Berlin of six alleged urban guerrillas on murder and kidnapping charges would violate the fourpower pact, covering the city defense lawyers said today.

title: Dolphins 27, Redskins 15
description: MIAMI, Aug. 13 (AP)Don Strock, a reserve quarterback, converted an interception and a fumble recovery into two touchdowns on passes in the second half tonight and led the Miami Dolphins to a 2715 victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: Florida Banks Out of the Swamps
description: In the wake of the nation's most severe economic recession in four decades, the banking industry was hard hit by loan losses, resulting in sharp declines in earnings and stock values. Florida's banking industry, In particular, was affected by loan losses and nonperforming loans because of Its concentration of credits in real estate and constructionthe hardest hit segment of the economy.

title: U.S.BRITISH PROPOSAL ON RHODESIA'S FUTURE COMPLETED IN LONDON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The United States and Britain agreed today on the final details of a plan for transferring power in Rhodesia from the white minority to the black majority some time next year.

title: Suspected .44 Killer's Father Terms Himself a Victim, Too
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 13The 68yearold father of David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the .44caliber killer, tearfully expressed his grief today for the families of the victims and said, I will live with this heartache for the rest of my life.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Aug. 20MG Car Club Long Island Center 60mile noviceoriented rally; start at Howard Johnson's, Exit 64 of Long Island Expressway, Medford, L.I. Registration: 7 P.M.; first car off 8:01. Information: Roger or Edith Forsyth, phone (516)4733679.

title: Nabokov In Berkeley
description: WE came down from the beatitude of the mountains, where there hadn't been a television set, to the fleshpots of Berkeley, California, where (1) nobody wanted to talk about Vladimir Nabokov and (2) everybody wanted to talk about water and cigarettes. Not only that, but the onedishanight French restaurant run by 1960's radicals was closed on Monday.

title: Rebuffed W.H.A. Teams Prepare Again to Battle the N.H.L
description: The day after the National Hockey League rejected a merger with the 5yearold World Hockey Association, phones at the New England Whalers. office began to ring.

title: Black Kids, White Homes
description: FOR a few innocent years back in the 1960's, social forces converged to produce an odd spectacle: Thousands of young white married couples descended upon the nation's childwelfare agencies asking to expand their families by adopting babies who were black or racially mixed.

title: Offense Again Sputters in 237 Setback
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 13Either (a) the New Orleans Saints, who have never won more, than five games in any of their 10 National Football League seasons, are a powerhouse this year; (b) exhibition games mean nothing, or (c) the Giants are in deep trouble.

title: Miss Lillian's Reincarnation
description: JOHN BERRYMAN used to say that a man could live his whole life now in America and never find out if he was a coward; never need to ao anything that scared him. Contemporaneous with the Vietnam War was the Peace Corps, howeverthat invention of the Kennedyswhich, though you don't hear much about it any more, was an equivalent adventure for many people, without the same regret in retrospect. This little book is a collection of letters from President Carter's mother when she was in her late 60's, a dutiful but restless Georgia gentlewoman gone to India to work as a nurse in a clinic. A decade would pass before her son won the Presidency; at the time he was trying unsuccessfully for his state's governorship.

title: Pelham Manor Figures Seen as a Paradox
description: PELHAM MANOR, the Westchester community with the highest number of percapita crimes, reflects the county as a whole in terms of the kinds of crime that predominate and points up the need to go beyond the raw crime statistics.

title: Pick One: The Panama Canal Is, Is Not, as Valuable as in the Past
description: PANAMAWhen Teddy Roosevelt decided to take Panama, sponsoring its breakaway from Colombia in 1903 exchange for the right to build and control an interoceanic waterway, he was convinced that a canal was vital to both the economy and security of the United States. Now, following last week's agreement on a new Panama Canal Treaty transferring control of the canal to Panama by the year 2000, President Carter has the unenviable task of trying to convince the twothirds of the United States Senate needed for ratification of the agreement that the canal is no longer that important.

title: Crash on Takeoff Kills Floridian
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 13 (AP) The pilot of a singleengine plane was killed today when his aircraft spun out of control and crashed as he tried to take off from a small airport, the authorities said. The plane nosed in at about a 45degree angle and it looked totally demolished, said Bill Ruthvan, a firefighter at the Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport. The victim was identified as Michael R. Huckor, 27 years old, of Coral Springs.

Dorothy Kripke said yes, whereupon the child asked if this meant he had squeezed part of God out of the kitchen by corning in and taking up some of His space. I Was startled that Saul already seemed to have an intuitive grasp of the notion that two objects cannot occupy the same space at the same time, recalls Mrs. Kripke. I found that a sharp question for a 3yearold

title: Tamerlane and Grandson Are Honored by Uzbeks
description: SAMARKAND, U.S.S.R.Six centuries ago the name Tamerlane evoked terror from the Volga to the Ganges, but now four small children swung impudently on a mulberry tree outside his tomb while an older boy in a dirty undershirt took potshots at the fluted turquoise dome with a slingshot.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: These summer days, theater takes to the streetsor any cranny of the city which supports a mobile unit, such as a park, plaza or pierwith productions free to the general public. Theater for the New City, naturally unaware that we would experience the recent blackout and that their zany musical The Time They Turned the Water Off would have reverberations, has been cavorting about town with its entourage of actors, clowns, jugglers and tumblers. This afternoon, the troupe will appear in St. Mary's Park and next Saturday in Fort Green Park.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE way Representative Andrew Maguire, Democrat of Ridgewood, looks at it, New Jersey won a doubleheader victory over two of the nation's toughest special interest groups in the hectic days prior to the current Congressional recess.

title: Alfred Lunt, 18931977 Joy Was His Gift to the Stage
description: Although the Lunts (Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt) retired from the stage in 1958, their continuous presence on their farm in Genesee Depot, Wis., was comforting. I had an irrational feeling that in case of need they could return at any time to restore fervor to the theater. But now Alfred Lunt has gone. He died at the age of 84 on Aug. 3, in a Chicago hospital. The immortal partnership is finished. The two dedicated actors can never appear together again. They were individual performers who often appeared in separate plays, especially during the Theater Guild's valiant attempt to organize a repertory company. Among other separate assignments, he appeared in O'Neill's Marco Millions; she, in his Strange Interlude. But after several triumphant performances together in the early 1940's, they decided never to appear separately again, and their technical perfection and their personal gusto made the theater a stimulating institution for the rest of their career.

title: Newfoundlands Get a Chance to Show Rescue Ability
description: A demonstration by fourfooted lifesavers will take place Saturday at Lake Harmony at the Great Boulder ski area in Pennsylvania's Poconos, These lifesavers with a difference are Newfoundland dogs, whose legendary feats include the reputed rescuing of Napolean from a stormy sea. The French government, recently has backed up lifeguards on beaches with Newfoundlands for rescue work.

title: Four Newsmen Freed Without Bail On Yonkers Trespassing Charges
description: YONKERS, Aug. 13 (UPI)Four newsmen were arraigned here yesterday on charges of criminal trespass for allegedly breaking into the apartment of David Berkowitz, who the police say is the .44caliber killer.

title: IN BRIEF
description: WHOLESALE PRICES fell for the second month in a row in July because of lower farm and processedfood prices, the Labor Department reported. The July decline, 0.1 percent, followed a larger June drop of 0.7 percent. . . Consumer installment credit increased by $2.28 billion in June, the Federal Reserve Board said. This was less than the $2.52 billion increase in May and the record $2.85 billion increase in March.

title: Victorian Shadows Linger Along Cape May's Beaches
description: On a treelined pedestrian mall in a small country town by the sea, a man in a multicolored patchwork suit climbs onto a low platform. His face is made up like a clownlarge white eyes and mouth, bulbous red nose. He is a mountebank, really, a throwback to another era. He is on that platform to put on a show to celebrate the anniversary of the mall. Dozens of youngsters gathers around him in a semicircle, kittens to a bowl of sweet cream.

We beat them twice, it's true, but were lucky not to lose one of the games. You remember how many times they hit the post. They are not an easy team, I tell you.

title: Maryland Is Putting Girls On School Football Line
description: When Maryland high schools open early next month, coaches of formerly allmale teams, such as football and wrestling, may find girls trying out. As a result of efforts to comply with the state Equal Rights Amendment and Federal Title IX, the Maryland State Superintendent of Schools, David W. Hornbeck, announced revisions last week of the rules governing interscholastic athletics in the state. The thrust of the new regulation is that a secondary school will be required to allow girls to go out for any sport in which it does not offer a girls team. The rule is similar to one in New Jersey.

title: Martha Pruden Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter DeWitt Pruden Jr. of Suffolk, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Martha Brothers Pruden of New York, to William Coulson McMahon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McMahon of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Food
description: One of the characteristics of lu nouvelle cuisine, the cooking as practiced by the younger generation of cooks who now rule the great kitchens of France, is an absence of the superfluous garnishes that an older generation of chefs felt essential to their art. Gone are the excesses of Duchess potatoes used to border the silver serving dishes, the dazzling floral displays in wax and the nonsensical puffpastry crescents. Some garnishes can he elegant and practical as well as delicious; the presentation of food remains an important element in good gastronomy. Molded vegetables are an example of garnishes in good taste,which please the eye as well as the palate.

title: Reserve Mining Asks Court to Ease Air Pollution Rules at Dump Site
description: TWO HARBORS, Minn., Aug. 13 (AP) The Reserve Mining Company has petitioned for less stringent air pollution rules for its Milepost 7 disposal site for taconite ore than those laid down by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis.

title: Air Force Says Clark Base Would Be Vital in Case of a Mideast War
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Aug. 8The United States Air Force, worried about the future of this mammoth base, is strenuously arguing that it would be crucial in the event of a Middle East war.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Arms and the Boxing: Man
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GARDENING
description: THERE is a host of hostas so handsome that one would be willing to work hard to keep them growing well. However, with one exception, they need no pampering; they are as tough and troublefree as they are beautiful.

title: For Birds of Passage, a Vacation Can Be the Moment of Truth
description: My husband and I have never taken vacations seriously, but for a long time the children didn't notice. They were too little, and besides, we were living in Hong Kong, where they were more or less on permanent vacation. Whenever we came back to the States on leavefrom my husband's assignment as a television news correspondentwe were once again vacationers. Relatives gathered up the children, friends invited us to parties and weekends in the country. We were birds of passage, lighting for a month or so with gifts of exotic funny stories and handplaited baskets, then flying off again, back to our foreign place.

title: Laura DuPont Captures U.S. Clay Crown
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13 (AP)Thirdseeded Laura DuPont defeated sixtime winner, Nancy Richey, in straight sets tonight and won the women's singles final in the United States claycourt tennis tournament. The scores were 64, 63.

description: The first gold and silver coinage of the KeelingCocos Islandsa tiny atoll in the Indian Oceanhas been released by that government to mark the 150th year of their settlement. The coins were struck by the Valcambi Mint of Switzerland and are being marketed by the Eastern Gold & Numismatic Society of Hong Kong.

title: BRIDGE
description: ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: 2 Senators Urge Liberalizing Investment Tax Credit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Less than a month before President Carter is to unveil his tax reform plan, two influential Senators, one the head of the taxwriting Finance Committee, have called on the President to liberalize the investment tax credit to spur corporate expansion and improvement.

title: A Revived Debbie Austin Leading Charity Classic
description: HAUPPAUGE, Li., Aug. 13This might have been the last year on ,the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour for Debbie Austin. Nine years without a victory had taken its toll on the upstate New York native, who had said she was tired of hearing, You'll win some time.

title: If You Go .. .
description: . . . to Cape May City from New York, take the Garden State Parkway 160 miles south to the end, or the New Jersey Turnpike to tho parkway connection in Woodbridge. From Philadelphia, take the Atlantic City Expressway to the Parkway, then south to Cape May.

title: Mr. Carter's Many Choices Will Involve Both, Although During His Campaign He Talked About Merit Only
description: WASHINGTONIt is probable that before his first year in office is ended, President Carter will have appointed more than 150 new Federal judges, putting his stamp on the Federal judiciary for years to come.

title: New Electric Fence Wards Off Coyotes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AMAgriculture Department scientists say they have refined an Australian's idea and come up with an electric fence that has proven 100 percent effective in Protecting sheep from coyotes.

title: Compost: Solution to Sludge?
description: AN experiment in composting sewage sluge into fertilizer, approved in Columbia County recently, may eventually help Westchester solve a big environmental problemgetting rid of sewage sludge.

title: 104 Hurt in London As Leftists Battle Rightist Marchers
description: LONDON, Aug. 13  A march by rightists through a multiracial South London, neighborhood today erupted in bloody battle with leftwing counterdemonstrators. As thousands of demonstators fought each other and the police, scores were arrested and at least 104 persons were injured, including 46 policemen.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: ANNA KISSELGOFF

title: Pirates Beat Matlack and Mets by 20
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug 13Jon Matlack is back. The good news for the Mets tonight was the return of their lefthander after nearly three weeks of false starts and misstarts because of a sore muscle in his pitching arm.

description: WEST CORNWALL

description: Saturday, August 13, 12th day.

title: Jill Goldman, Denis Tanney Plan to Be Wed in November
description: Jill Andrea Goldman and Denis Loeb Tanney plan to be married in November.

title: Bomb Breaks Windows In Rhodesian Capital
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 13 (AP) A 15pound bomb exploded today in central Salisbury, shattering windows in a 13story office building and damaging cars parked nearby. No one was injured.

description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCH
