description: AT AUGUSTA, N.J.

title: Convicts in Canada Demonstrate For Better Conditions in Prisons
description: OTTAWA, Aug, 13Convicts protesting prison conditions, abetted by humanrights organizations outside, have focused national attention on their grievances in a 24hour demonstration that included hunger strikes, refusals to work and, in one instance, a group escape.

title: Pop Rivets Can Solve Many Home Repair Problems
description: Blind rivets, more commonly known as pop rivets (POP rivets are actually the brand name of the USM Corporation, one of the largest manufacturers, but most dealers now call all brands pop rivets) can be used for many different repair and assembly jobs around the house, as well as on automobiles, boats, lawn and yard equipment, toys, luggage and furniture

title: Laughter and Tears From A Hungarian Molire
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: The Minstrel Is Sold for $9 Million
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 A record price of $9 million for the syndication of a thoroughbred racer was reported today when it was made known that E. P. Taylor, owner of the Windfields Farm, had purchased The Minstrel, Europe's champion campaigner

title: 3 Deaths Laid to Toxic Herb Teas
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 13 (AP)Four cases of poisoning, three of them fatal, that have been associated with drinking teas made from noxious plants have been reported to the national Center for Disease Control. Two of the incidents involved infants in Arizona who were given large quantities of a tea prepared from a locally marketed product called gordolobo yerba. The center said that an analysis of the tea had shown it had been made from a toxic herb by mistake. In the state of Washington an elderly woman and her husband died, the center said, after drinking tea that was apparently mistakenly made from foxglove plants.

title: 7 Killed in Thailand Explosion
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 13 (Reuters) Seven persons were killed and about 50 injured when two rocketpropelled grenades exploded accidentally during a display of weapons captured from Communist guerrillas, the police said today. They said the accident occurred yesterday in a school in northern Petchabun Province.

title: Some Hints of Calm
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Although the new coalition Government of Suleyman Demirel is not quite two weeks old and although the burly Prime Minister has as his partners two highly nationalistic and rightwing miniparties, he is uttering some helpful noises aimed at neighboring Greece, with which Turkey has been engaged in a bitter quarrel.

title: Marriage Gave Rider Star in Shows
description: James F. O'Rourke Jr. admitted the other day that before he was married 22 years ago, his interest in horses was negligible. In fact, the 54yearold O'Rourke said, I really was more interested in racing outboards. But when you marry into a horse family, you become a horseman. On that day 22 years ago O'Rourke married Mary Rice, whose father James, had owned Rice Farms, a Long Island landmark. James Rice died three years ago, but Rice Farms remains in the family.

title: Idi Amin's Achilles Heel
description: When the Anglican Archbishop Janani Luwum and two Ugandan officials were murdered last February, joining in death an estimated 50,000 to 300,000 victims of President Idi Amin's sixyear reign of terror, President Carter said that the wholesale violence in that tortured country had disgusted the entire civilized world.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: RICHARD KLUGER is not a particularly religious man. In fact, his visits to the synagogue might be said to fall into the tourist category. So it's appropriate that tourism was the occasion for his presence at Temple Mikve Israel in Savannah, Ga., in August 1975, when he received a kind of writer's revelationone that set him to writing his new novel, Members of the Tribe. Mr. Kluger, his wife and two boys were doing some sightseeing in Savannah after vacationing at Hilton Head. Pe rusing a guidebook of the historical old city, Mr. Kluger saw a mention of Temple Mikve Israel, which was founded in 1733 and is the oldest in the South. And so, the Kluger family paid a visit. As they were walking down the aisle, Mr. Kluger's eye fell on a piece of paper lying there. Out of some obscure antilittering instinct, he picked it up and noticed there was writing on it. The words, in a jagged script, read, Get history of the Congregation.

title: MajorLeague Scores
World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: POLITICS
description: THE task of mending fences after a tough party primary is a difficult but necessary political exercise. In the weeks since the June 7 primary, Governor Byrne has made some tentative steps to close ranks with his former political foes, but because he had nine opponentsfour of them considered major candidateshis fencemending task resembles repairing cracks in the Great Wall of China.

title: HEAD OF KENT STATE ACTS IN GYM DISPUTE
description: KENT, Ohio, Aug. 13A Federal judge in Cleveland is expected to rule next week on whether Kent State University officials may proceed with construction of a gymnasium annex near the site where students were killed and wounded in a 1970 antiwar protest. But university officials under the guiding hand of the school's new president, Dr. Brage Golding, may now be working toward moving the gym site on their own.

title: SHOP TALK
description: APPROXIMATELY a dozen old houses up Mount Kisco's Lexington Avenue from the commodiously quartered Calico Corners sets a white bungalow recently renovated, by four unemployableintheirfields college graduates, into a fish store called Mount Kisco Seafood.

title: 10th Rifle Title to Wigger
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 13 (AP)Lones Wigger of Columbus, Ga., an Army major, won the 1977 national smallbore rifle position championship today for the 10th time. A twotime Olympic gold medalist, Wigger set a record by posting an aggregate score of 3,181221x. He set the previous mark of 3,179201x last year. The xring is the smaller circle within the bullseye, used to break ties.

title: The Foreign Delegations, in Fact, Cost the City a Lot of Money
description: When the Australianborn writer Shirley Hazzard served on the staff of the United Nations Secretariat in the 1950's, she soon learned that many New Yorkers looked down on the organization's thousands of foreign employees.

title: Walter Pidgeon Is Hospitalized
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 13 (UPI) Walter Pidgeon, the 78yearold actor, has been hospitalized for more than a week with an ailment that his doctors and family will not disclose. A spokesman for St. John's Hospital said yesterday that Mr. Pidgeon admitted himself to the hospital Aug. 4. Hospital officials refused to say why he was hospitalized or what his condition was.

title: Stockholder Suits Stepping Up Merger Pressure
description: As Wall Street had predicted, angry shareholders of the Gerber Products Company have filed suit against the corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of baby foods, for damages resulting from the company's resistance to a profitable takeover bid.

title: True Colors Triumphs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP)True Colors, owned by Robert Billips of Lexington, Ky., closed strongly under Eddie Delahoussaye and scored a 3length victory today in the $96,300 Roundtable Handicap at Arlington Park.

title: CURB ON BANK VOIDED JUST BEFORE LANCE WAS NAMED TO POST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13One day before it was publicly disclosed that Bert Lance was to be nominated to head the Office of Management and Budget, the Atlanta regional director for the Comptroller of the Currency rescinded a potentially embarrassing agreement between the Comptroller and a bank Mr. Lance then headed.

title: YOUNG SAYS POLICY CHANGE SHOULD PRECEDE CUBA TIES
description: MAIQUETIA, Venezuela, Aug. 13Andrew Young said today that before diplomatic relations between Washington and Cuba are reestablished, the United States should devise an approach to economic development for the entire Caribbean basin.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
Oasis of the Arts in Clinton
description: WHERE do novelists, magazine columnists, composers, musicians, businessmen and educators with an interest in the arts go to let down their hair?

title: Chiefs 23, Steelers 21
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 13 (UPI)Jan Stenerud's third field goal of the game; a 29yarder with 15 seconds to play lifted the Kansas City Chiefs to a 2321 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers tonight. The field goal capped a 65yard drive in the final 4 minutes.

title: Bohemian GroveWhere Big Shots Go to Camp
description: MONTE RIO, Calif.When Gerald R. Ford, Henry A. Kissinger and A. W. Clausen joined 2,000 of the richest and most powerful men in the country at the annual ritual known as the Summer Encampment at Bohemian Grove near this sleepy hamlet of 997 last month, did they make decisions that will shape America's destiny, or was It merely the greatest men's party on earth?

title: Viktor Belenko
description: One of the Soviet Union's most advanced jet fighters, the MIG25, fell into Japanese hands on Sept. 6, 1976, when its pilot, Viktor I. Belenko, a Soviet Air Force lieutenant, fled to the island, of Hokkaido. On landing, the lieutenant requested refuge in the United States. It was granted within a day by President Gerald R. Ford.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The right to the presence of counsel during legal proceedings is widely viewed as basic to the American criminal justice system, yet at one stage in the criminal process, before a grand jury, that right and others equally basic are generally denied. For that reason, many thoughtful persons have long been considering ways to remedy the situation.

title: Michael R. Donovan Marries Ellen Lay
description: Ellen Louise Lay, assistant to the international marketing manager of Germaine Monteil in New York, was married yesterday in Sandusky, Ohio, to Michael Raymond Donovan, a senior accountant at Price Waterhouse & Company in New York. The Rev. Robert A George performed the ceremoney in Grace Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. James Patton, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Economic Post Filled
description: ALBANY, Aug. 13 (UPI)William A. Lyons of Binghamton, former chairman of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation,will become chairman of the Economic Development Board on Tuesday, Governor Carey announced yesterday. Mr. Lyons, 69 years old, has been a member of the board since it was formed in 1975 to advise the Governor on economic development policy. He will succeed Donald Gaudion, who will continue as a board member.

title: Bluegrass: Festival At Waterloo
description: STANHOPE

title: Diane E. Scott Becomes Bride
description: Diane Elizabeth Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leslie Scott of Lloyd Harbor, L I., was married at noon yesterday to Robert Murray Finlayson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finlayson of New York and Ponta Vedra, Fla.

title: A Festival of Local Talent
description: ONE OF the most ambitious summer festivals in Connecticut has been bringing an astonishing variety of musical forms and styles to the Levitt Pavilion for the Performing Arts, in Westport. The programs, most of them featuring Connecticut artists, operate on an eve rydaybutMonday basis, and whether your tastes run to jazz, rock, folk or the classics, you are sure to find what you like someplace along the line.

title: There Are Many Motives, but Chief Among Them Is Profit
description: Several factors have combined in recent weeks to heighten public consciousness of arson: the fires that accompanied the July blackout and Mayor Beame's decision, apparently under pressure of his reelection campaign, to emphasize New York City's efforts to combat incendiarism. But as exhausted firemen, frightened residents and dismayed community leaders can testify, in the city and elsewhere in the region from Rochester, N.Y. to Elizabeth, N.J., arson u a phenomenon that has been aroundand growingfor more than the last few weeks

title: Hindemith on DisksNew Light On a Prolific Composer
description: Paul Hindemith, we are forever being told, is the classic case of the influential, respected and frequently performed composer who suffers an eclipse after his death, and now patiently awaits another generation to right the perspective and assign him his true position in the compositional hierarchy.

title: Real People, Mythic History
description: WHEN handling explosive objects, it is well to begin slowly and simply. So I'll first say that Robert Coover's The Public Burning is a long and fantastic fictional account of the events surrounding the executions for espionage of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in 1952, that virtually all the characters bear the names of historical personages, and that the principal narrator identifies himself as the thenVice President of the United States, Richard Milhous Nixon. Already, no doubt, you hear an ominous ticking sound.

title: A Weak Currency
description: The international value of the Canadian dollar dropped last week, to its lowest point in more than seven years, following a series of pessimistic reports on the Canadian economy. For the first time since the currency had been unhitched from the American dollar in May 1970 to float in the exchange markets, the Canadian dollar has traded in recent days at less than 93 United States cents. Its value stood at 92.74 cents in foreignexchange trading in Toronto Friday.

title: Randi Jeanne Bader Is Fiancee of J. A. Wise
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bader of New Hyde Park, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Randi Jeanne Bader, to Jeremy Alan Wise, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Wise of New Rochelle, N. Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Royalties for Artists: California Becomes The Testing Ground
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Carrying On the Tiffany Style
description: DEER PARK

title: Vance Discovers How Hard It Is to Stay at Home
description: LONDON, Aug. 13When Cyrus R. Vance became Secretary of State he told reporters that he would definitely travel less than his predecessor, Henry A. Kissinger. In fact, when Mr. Vance interviewed applicants for the job of press spokesman, he reportedly told at least one of them not to take the job if he thought he would get to see much of the world.

title: Chart of the Alabama
description: Copyright 1977 by Dally Racing Form. Inc.

title: Hijacker Says His Aim On CairoBound Plane Was Peace With Libya
description: BRINDISI Italy, Aug. 13 (AP)The 49year old Egyptian student charged In the hijacking of a Cairobound Air France jet told an investigator today that his father had been killed in the recent fighting between Egypt and Libya and that his action was aimed at reconciling the Arab neighbors.

title: ENDANGERED PLANT LISTING ANGERS CONSERVATIONISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPD)Conservationists are unhappy over the Government's decision to place only four plants on the endangered species list in its first listing of such plants. They think 40 to 70 plants should have been listed.

title: A Pioneer Public Defender
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Commuters Lament Progress
description: TO MICHAEL DENGENIS, the acting director of rail operations for the Connecticut Department of Transportation, they are the finest commuter train coaches in the worldcars that assure a far more comfortable ride than the bumpitybump rattlers that preceded them and scalded the lips of thousands of morning rushhour coffee drinkers.

title: JAMES HENRY JONES
description: MACON, Ga., Aug. 13(UP1).lames Henry Jones, an author and former sportswrittr, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 70 years old.

title: THE REGGAE WAY TO SALVATION
description: So he comes jiggling out onto the stage, this wiry, spindleshanked singer, this selfstyled black prince of reggae, his clenched fist high above his head, his dreadlocks flopping round his ears. The crowd rises to its feet and begins to scream and the singer shouts, Yes! and the crowd shouts, Yes! Yes! Yes! And then, with slight menace in his voice, the singer says, Jesu, light the fire to my salvation. Whom shall I fear? Jah. Ras Tafari. And the crowd screams, Jah, Jah, Ras Tafari! and begins to whistle and clap and the band begins to play and the singer slides into one of his early songs called Lively Up Yourself.

title: Retired Colonel Has U.S. Olympic Plans on March
description: One year after America's amateur athletes struggled for survival on the paying fields at Montreal, significant strides to upgrade the system have been made by the United States Olympic Committee on the road to Lake ??????? and Moscow in 1980.

title: Silver Jubilee Girl Scouts of '37 Plan Reunion
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR

title: The EverChanging Formula for School Financing
description: HARTFORD

title: FundRaiser Plays a Round of Memories
description: WILLIAM M. JENNINGS traces the origins of the Westchester Golf Classic, one of the richest events on the circuit, to a modest exhibition he organized in 1948 at the Apawamis Club in Rye to help raise money for United Hospital. He remembers it well, except for who won.

title: MARKETS
description: With gloom hovering over Wall Street and thoughts of a summer rally all but gone, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled at the end of last week to its lowest level since the first trading session of 1976.

title: Lake Kezar: Camps in the Woods
description: In the summer of 1962, when pianist Vladimir Horowitz was preparing to return to the concert stage after several years of retirement, he booked a cottage at a camp called Quisisana on Lake Kezar, Me. He had a Steinway shipped from Boston and put in his long daily hours of practice in the cottage, while Quisisana's dazzled guests lurked among the pines to enjoy the unexpected bonus.

title: The Poetry of Autobiography
description: Day by Day is Robert Lowell's first book since the appearance of his two Selected Poems (England 1974, United States 1976). It continues his verse autobiography [which] sometimes fictionalizes plot and particular: it continues as well his struggle to break the icon  to dismember and reconstitute the English lyric. As selfportrait, it is linked backward to the guilty joy of Lowell's marriage to Caroline Blackwood, the birth of his son Sheridan and his removal to England, all celebrated in The Dolphin (1973); this new collection recounts the attrition of that marriage and looks ahead with foreboding. The domestic plot, centered in the exceptionally beautiful titlesequence, escapes the confines of that sequence and tinges the rest of the poems.

title: The Magnetism of Eilshemius
description: LOUIS EILSHEMIUS was a true eccentric, and his bizarre behavior so influenced his reputation as an artist that even today he is seen in many quarters as more an eccentric than an artist. He wrote letters to editors, dealers and critics castigating them for lack of vision in understanding his work. He had a highly exalted view of himself and handed out pamphlets in which he described himself as a supreme genius, the world's mightiest mind, an exdoctor, exathlete, exmimic, scientist supreme.

title: A Congressional Wife's Down Home Letter From Washington
description: WASHINGTONIt was 32yearold, redheaded John J. Cavanaugh who was elected to Congress last year from the Second District of Nebraska, which encompasses Omaha and five counties along the Missouri River, but it is 29yearold, auburnhaired Kate, his wife, who has turned into a celebrity back home.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:00 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: New York State Assembly Majority Leader Stanley Steingut.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: WALTER KERR

title: Speculation Over Attempt on Chinatown Leader's Life Stirs Controversy
description: While the police investigation of the July 11 stabbing of Man Bun Lee, the former Mayor of Chinatown, continues, published speculations on motives for the attack are stirring a controversy in the Chinese community.

title: Simpson Scores: 2 Touchdowns As Bills Win
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Aug. 13 (UPI)O. J. Simpson ran for touchdowns of 1 and 15 yards tonight and led the Buffalo Bills to a 1710 victory over the Detroit Lions in a National Football League preseason game at Rich Stadium.

title: Nancy Kilbridge Married To Paul Pontier in Jersey
description: Nancy Ethel Kilbridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Xavier Kilbridge of Franklin Lakes, N. J., was married yesterday to Paul Jeffrey Pontier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Pontier of Clifton, N. J. The Rev. Joseph Doyle performed the ceremony in St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Wyckoff, N. J.

title: Summer of 37: Girl Scouts Reunion
description: FORTY years ago, at a woodsy encampment in Briarcliff Manor, north of New York City, several dozen Girl Scouts from 27 countries gathered to celebrate the silver jubilee of girl scouting in this country.

title: STAMPS
description: The founding in 1777 of El Pueblo de San Jose de Guadalupe in Alta (Northern) California, at what is now the city of San Jose, had a profound influence on the development of the West Coast and the United States as a whole, and the event is being commemorated with a new 13cent stamp being issued on Sept. 9 in the modern San Jose.

title: Calumet Scores a Double At Monmouth, Saratoga
description: OCEANPORT, NJ., Aug. 13Getting out of the starting gate poorly and running last in the early stages, Calumet Farm's Alydar recovered nicely to take the lead at the eighth pole and scored a 2 12length triumph today in the 43d running of the Sapling Stakes before a dampened crowd of 21,183 at Monmouth Park.

title: U.S. AGENCY TO MONITOR NEXT PIPELINE PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, August 13 (UPI)A Transportation Department official said today that the agency had learned a lesson from the Aleyska oil pipeline and would send its own people to monitor construction of the next major Alaskan project, a pipeline to carry natural gas from the North Slope.

title: Roosevelt
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% Municipal surtax.)

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Monmouth
Sandra Ann Titus, Colorado Teacher, Married to Michael McKinstry, Lawyer
description: Sandra Ann Titus, a teacher in the Boulder, Colo., school system, and Michael McCoy McKinstry, a lawyer with Fairfield & Woods, Denver law firm, were married yesterday morning in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Bay Shore, L. L, by the rector, the Rev. Donald McPhail. A reception was held at the Southward Ho Country Club in Bay Shore.

title: Braves Disqualify Pitcher
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 13 (AP)Max Leon, an Atlanta Braves righthanded pitcher, who was arrested last Saturday on several charges, including driving under the influence of intoxicants, has been placed on the disqualified list, Bill. Lucas, general manager of. the National League club, said today. The Braves recalled a lefthander, Mike Davey, from Richmond of the International League to replace Leon on the roster.

title: Littler Goes 4 Strokes Up In P.G.A.
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 13The 59th championship of the Professional Golfers Association has divided itself into two fieldsGene Littler and 70 other players.

title: POLICE HIRING QUOTA ON TRIAL IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13The Detroit Police Department's threeyearold affirmative action program went on trial in Federal District Court this week, charged with illegally discriminating against white officers.

title: Paperbacks:
description: TRINITY, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $2.75.) The fortunes of three representative families of northern Ireland from 1840 to 1916: a sprawling, meandering, almost constantly engaging historical novel that helps illuminate today's headlines. A best seller in hardcover.

title: Yanks Waste Chances, Fall, 65, To Angels in 12
description: The Yankees wasted enough opportunities to win three ordinary games yesterday afternoon at the Stadium as they were defeated by Nolan Ryan and the California Angels, 65, in 12 innings.

title: A FESTIVAL OF FSTOPS IN FRANCE
description: Arles is used to artists. The old town has seen them come and go  and linger, as van Gogh did, warming himself under the golden lights of an outdoor cafe, watching the stars spin in the midnight sky. But lately Arles has had to adjust to a different kind of artistone with a cyclopean eye  and a different kind of light  sudden bursts from flash guns, pulsing glows from strobes. Ever since the summer of 1970, when photographer Lucien Clergue, who lives in Arles, installed an impressive exhibition of photographs in a local gallery and launched a photography workshop, the historic town in the south of France has lured throngs of photographers, dealers, collectors, art directors, exhibition goers and sightseers to its July photo fling.

title: DINING OUT
description: IN Chinese restaurants, the menus go on for pages. At Dynasty in Roslyn, the menu goes on for menus. Upon being seated, you are handed small black folder containing eight attractive minimenus: cocktails and wines, appetizers and soups, seafood, poultry, beef and pork, chop suey and chow mein, lowcalorie and vegetarian, desserts. Each is a different color, decorated with an example of Chinese inkbrush drawing. It's an interesting and pleasant presentation.

title: Still Terrible Terrell
description: DAWSON, Ga.  Cattycornered, as Southerners say, across the intersection ,from the redbrick Terrell County Court House here is the TeenClub swimming pool operated by the county youth foundation. This week, with the south Georgia sun blazing down and the thermometer hovering around 90, the pool was closed and silent, its water drained, its usual hordes of young white swimmers nowhere in sight.

title: Love Styles In Mime Fun And Serious
description: Programming is an art that's quite independent in and of itself and frequently eludes even the most accomplished performers. The evening of mime with Bob Welter and Lavinia Plonka at American Theater Laboratory on Friday was full of excellent sections but drummed away a little too heavily on one emotional theme. The subject was Love Styles, but the mood of pathos was sounded too often at the expense of variety.

title: Shoemaker Is Banned
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 13 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker was given a sixday suspension today by Del Mar's stewards.

title: Hymn to The Republic
description: THIS is an extremely bold book. The theme is as simple as the theme of Diabelli; its working out in the book as complex and rich as Beethoven's variations; but sometimes the thunder of the left hand, or the brilliant, sparkling flights of the right, obliterate moments of doubt. As questions begin to form, they are quickly forgotten as Henry Commager's rhetoric seizes the imagination and holds it.

title: Repaired Course Is Site Of Rich Westchester Golf
description: The west course of the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y., which was severely damaged by vandals 10 days ago, has been almost completely repaired and should be in good shape for the $300,000 Westchester Classic, which will begin Thursday.

title: DINING OUT
description: NEW PRESTON

title: Laetrile Backers Ponder Referendum in California After Legislative Reverse
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13Proponents of the legalization of laetrile in California said that they were considering a move to put the issue on the ballot next year after a bill that would have legalized the drug was killed in the state Legislature earlier this week.

title: Saratoga Jockeys
Patricia A. Murray Becomes the Bride Of Frank Sparrer

Murray of Bronxville and Sarasota, Fla., to Frank Walter Sparrer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Sparrer of Bronxville and Barryville, N.Y. The Rev. Lawrence M. Orson performed the ceremony. title: Corporate Moves: New York Region Holds Its Own
description: WHEN Maurice Chevalier was asked, as he frequently was in his last years, how he felt about life as an octogenarian, his stock reply was, Well, when I think of the alternative . . . . The same kind of reply is being given these days when business and political leaders are asked how they feel about the continuing movement of New York City companies to Westchester County, Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WHEN it comes to healthcare costswhich Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, warns may reach $230 billion by 1980top Government and Private policymakers seem to show signs of schizophrenia.

title: Fashion
description: They're sexy, they're fun, they're even comfortable  they're what fashionable feet will wear this fall. Highheeled sandals for evening; lowheeled for day. Boots have a little of the Old West about them, whether they're in satin and gold or fringed suede. And legs are in sharp focus, wearing patterned stockings by day, the sheerest of pantyhose by evening.

title: The Shinnecock, Their Neighbors, And the Land: A Quiet Complex Of Ambiguities
description: In 1640, when the first English settlers in New York State disembarked on a rock in the Great Peconic Bay, they were greeted by a band of Shinnecock Indians who were living by hunting and fishing in the woods and waters of Long Island's East End.

title: Bob Marley, Injured, Delays Reggae Tour
description: Bob Marley's tour of the United States has been indefinitely postponed, because of the reggae singer's injured right foot, which was operated on in London last Sunday.

description: CASEMENT windows differ from doublehung or sliding windows in that they are hinged at one side to open and close much like a hinged door. title: GARDENING
description: A BEAUTY contest for flowers and vegetables? Well, pert Parks isn't there singing Here She Comes, Miss America, but the AllAmerica Selections trials are held throughout the United States and Canada each year to select the best new flowers and vegetables. Seed companies submit their most likely candidates to be judged by experts, with the hope that they will win an award.

title: Golf

title: Korean Factions Clash in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 13 (AP)Korean supporters and opponents of President Park Chung Hee clashed today in Tokyo in a brawl that left 19 persons injured, eight of them seriously, the police said. Authorities said about 300 Korean supporters of the Park Government had disrupted an antiGovernment conference, hurling bottles at the dissidents and overwhelming guards and the police.

title: DINING OUT

title: A U.S. OFFICIAL PRAISES CHILE'S ACTION ON POLICE
description: SANTIAGO. Chile. Aug. 13Chile's decision to disband its secret police agency is a very positive move toward reducing tensions, according to Terence A. Todman, the Assistant Secretary of State for Interamerican Affairs.

title: Nassau Officials Oppose Tristate Body's Plan to Add 93,500 Dwellings to the County Within 20 Years
description: MINEOLAA plan to require Nassau County to provide more lowincome housing and to increase total housing units by 25 percent over 20 years has provoked criticism at all levels of local government.

title: AMTRAK REDUCING SERVICE ON FOUR ROUTES SEPT. 8
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP)Because the Administration and Congress cut its Federal subsidy, Amtrak has announced that it is reducing service on four railroad passenger routes, effective Sept. 8.

title: Talk With Eleanor Hibbert and Helpers
description: SHE calls them my ladies. One is Philippa Carr, another Jean Plaidy, and the most famous is Victoria Holt, and they all live together in a large, twostory penthouse in London. They are writers.

title: Appeals Court Orders Wife to Pay Child Support
description: NEW CITY, N.Y.One of the land mines laid down by the feminist movement has exploded for a former resident of Rockland County, Carolyn R. Carter. The of justices of the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, have ruled unanimously that she must pay child support to her former husband, who retained custody of their child when they were divorced in 1973.

title: Consumer Sales Continue to Limp Along
description: Retail sales in July continued to limp along at the lackadaisical pace of recent months, disappointing Government economists who were counting on heavier consumer buying to sustain the momentum of the recovery.

description: In the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue last night Sharon M. Spellman. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Spellman of Randallstown, Md., became the bride of David M. Olasov. sop of Bernard .J. Olasov of Charleston, S. C., and the late Harriet T. Olasov.

title: COURT INQUIRY IS SET ON BID TO SELL TAPES
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn plans to investigate the conduct of two lawyers who offered to sell taped memoirs they had obtained from David R. Berkowitz to at least two newspapers.

title: A CookieMuncher Winds Up in Court
description: OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, Aug. 13 Lawrence E. Wallick appeared in court today on charges of eating a chocolatechip cookie in public. Ruth Bushnell was up on charges of eating crumb cake, and Michael Mastandrea was before the judge because he had been caught holding a glass of water.

title: A Predicament for Civil Libertarians
description: The revelation that a few officials of the American Civil Liberties Union passed along information about its activities and members to the Federal Bureau of Investigation during the 1950's is disheartening. By its nature, the A.C.L.U. is an adversary of police agencies and a champion of privacy. Any such confidential dealings must threaten its integrity as America's preeminent civil liberties organization.

title: The Montauk That Might Have Been
description: ON Sept. 21, 1925, at the height of the Island's realestate boom, Carl Graham Fisher, the developer of Miami Beach, bought nearly 10,000 acres that make up just about all of Montauk Peninsula with nine miles of waterfront. It was another of Fisher's big dreams to build an extravagant resort and to create what he called the Miami Beach of the North.

title: Our Mims Scores by Neck at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 The sudden resurgence of the Calumet Farm as a producer of stakes winners continued at this upstate resort's thoroughbred track this afternoon.

Smith, the Atlanta entrepreneur who offered to buy Budget Director Bert Lance's shares in the bank, have come to a standstill and are likely to collapse. sources familiar with the nr000sed transaction said today.

title: Cadet Sailing Title to Briton
description: MONNICKENDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 13 (UPI)  Simon Gervin, of Britain, won the ninth and last race of the Cadet class world sailing championships and won the title today. Martin Bolloch of Argentina was second.

description: SPOKANE, Wash, Aug. 13(AP)1f the Postal Service is to cope with inflation, it must eliminate Saturday mail delivery, according to Postmaster General Benjamin Bailar.

description: MOST of the insect pests that plague gardeners are sneaky. The creepy crawlers usually work at night. Voracious feeders, they dine underneath leaves or inside them and crawl inside stems. There they quietly do their damage undetectedat least for a while.

title: Music Hath Bookspans
description: THERE was an audience of two watching a rehearsal at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. The performers on stage were singing a series of operatic arias as spotlights were being adjusted. Seated together in the auditorium were Janet and Martin Bookspan.

title: Efforts Are Being Made in Nassau County Police Department to Comply With AffirmativeAction Program
description: MINEOLAAn effort to comply with the Federal Government's affirmativeaction program, a desire for improved community relationships and a strong personal conviction that a police force should be truly representative of the people it serves are behind an intensive campaign by Police Commissioner Daniel Guido to recruit blacks, Jews, Hispanic persons and women into the Nassau County police force.

title: Viktor Belenko
description: One of the Soviet Union's most advanced jet fighters, the MIG25, fell into Japanese hands on Sept. 6, 1976, when its pilot, Viktor I. Belenko, a Soviet Air Force lieutenant, fled to the island of Hokkaido. On landing, the lieutenant requested refuge in theUnited States. It was granted within a day by President Gerald R. Ford.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia Charles Namby Wynn Woodward likes to breed champion quarter horses and to ride the range of his halfmillionacre Douglas Lake Ranch, one of Canada's largest spreads devoted to cattle raising. Being chairman and chief executive of Woodward Stores Ltd., western Canada's top retailing company, used to take less than half his time, and that's the way he wanted it.

title: Party Workers Don't Live on Pay
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: CHILDREN"s BOOKS
description: I don't mind books whose text has obviously been concocted to accompany a visual joke when the pictures are as inventive as these by Helen Oxenbury. Young Simon Diamond's house blows away one night, leaving only the electric wiring, a few bricks and the milk and morning paper on the front steps. Diamond pere takes his problem to work (he happens to be a zookeeper), and soon has the situation in hand. If you took en elephant, a camel, a rhinoceros, and a yak, you'd have your walls, muses his boss. Then a few long snakes for perches, and some mixed birds with large wings to perch on them. And, let's see, a pelican's beak to wash your hands and face in.

title: Texas Picks Women's Coach
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 13 (AP)Margie Shuer has been named the first fulltime women's swimming coach at the University of Texas, officials said today. She comes to the Austin school from the United States Modern Pentathlon Training Center, where she was on the coaching staff of the summer Olympic development clinic. Miss Shuer is a graduate of Stanford and Michigan. The former women's varsity swimming coach at the New Hampshire has also coached at Gavilan Community College in Gilroy, Calif.

title: City Constructs Statistical Profile In Looting Cases
description: The first comprehensive survey of suspects seized citywide in the looting that accompanied the blackout last month shows that 45 percent of the adults arrested had jobsan employment rate half again as high as the rate among those normally arrested for crimes in New York City.

title: If You Go .. .
description: . . . in search of scuba diving instruction, it is a good idea to shop around. Diving schools are listed in the Yellow Pages; in addition, Skin Diver magazine, available on newsstands, contains classified listings. Schools should be willing to supply a printed curriculum that spells out fees, duration of courses and required equipment. Diving clubs are a good source of information about schools in your vicinity. Most clubs are not well publicized, although dive shops often distribute individual clubs literature. The ,quarterly Sportdiver magazine may also be consulted for information on schools and clubs. Skin Diver, Sport Diver and Undercurrent magazines all carry reports on diving resorts all over the world; Skin Diver is the best publication to consult for listings of travel agents that handle packages tailored to divers.

title: Emanuel Ax Prefers Concerts to Contests
description: It was a dream, of course. The young pianist, whose idol was Arthur Rubinstein, seemed to be in contest sponsored by that ageless artist, and seemed to be winning. No, he had in fact won, and Rubinstein, who was one of the judges, was on the stage giving the young pianist a bear hug. And, no, it was not a dream after all: Emanuel Ax, at 25, had gained the first prize of $5,000 in the Arthur Rubinstein International Piano Competition in Israel and enough prestige to last many a pianist a lifetime.

title: Why Stay in the I.L.0.?
description: A Cabinet committee meets this week to decide whether the United States will leave the International Labor Organization. In late 1975, Henry Kissinger officially informed the organization that unless it took steps to get politics out of its proceedings, the United States would withdraw after a mandatory twoyear waiting period. Departure would give some moral satisfaction to some Americans. But it would be a mistake.

Within a few months he had pulled the country back from the edge of war, held elections, drafted a new constitution and conducted a referendum that ended a disabling dispute over the monarchy.

title: Out of This World: One Man's Odyssey
description: On the surface, it might seem difficult to understand why roughly 4,000 Americans a week are signing up for scuba diving instruction. At 50 or 100 feet below the surface, however, it's easy. Diving Is escape, an easy adventure of discovery into another world, and though not without its dangers, a lot safer than taking LSD or going to the moon.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The Japanese beetle population is on the rise in many sections. The chief reasontwo of the old reliable pesticides that kept the insect under control are no longer doing the job. The one, chlordane, is now a restricteduse pesticide. One application gave three to five years of beetlefree gardening. The othermilky spore diseasea biological control which infected and killed the grub stage of the beetle, is weakening in its effectiveness.

title: Tito Still Speaks for The World's Nonaligned
description: BELGRADEPresident Tito, that most durable of national leaders, will set forth on the diplomatic trail again this week, striving, as ever, to bring the world closer to his ideal of things before he leaves it. The Yugoslav leader is stopping in Moscow for talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, then taking a brief holiday on the shores of Lake Baikal in Siberia before proceeding to China and North Korea.

The Rev. Kermit Castellanos performed the ceremony in the Reformed Church in Bronxville. N. Y.

title: John Howard Lawson, 82, Writer Blacklisted by Hollywood in 47
description: John Howard Lawson, the screen writer and one of the Hollywood Ten who was blacklisted by the motionpicture industry and jailed for refusing in 1947 to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist, died Thursday in San Francisco at Mount Zion Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Needed: Some Real Horse Sense
description: DEAR, Amy wants a horse for her. birthday. It's that easy for a wife to transfer onerous responsibility to her spouse with his breakfast coffee.

title: Horses for Courses
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13The man was saying that he had run the last several Saratoga race meetings through a computer. and the Brain had told him that horses that had done well here in the past Could be expected to do well here again. Thus. through the miracle of electronic science the man had discovered what Charles II knewthat certain horses had a distinct preference for certain courses. By a happy coincidence, Phil Bieber had just wrftten a monograph on the subject of horses for courses.

description: ROME, Aug. 13The Italian Communist Party's youth organization has acknowledged that it is having difficulty reaching last year's recruitment level.

title: Miss Hay, S. B. Haas 2d, Law Students, Wed

title: HISTORY & BIOGRAPHY
description: The extraordinary Mrs. Max Mallowan was 80 when she died. Under the name from her first marriage, Agatha Christie, and the pseudonym she used for her romantic fiction, Mary Westmacott, she had written 80 books, was among the world's best sellers, a writer of recordbreaking, longrunning mystery plays and the source of a number of highly successful motion pictures.

title: The World
description: Her timing is usually flawless, as befits a Queen, but the British monarch went to Northern Ireland last week, and the timing was dismaying. Queen Elizabeth II arrived during a week of grim anniversaries: Six years ago last Tuesday hundreds of Roman Catholics were interned without trial, eight years ago Friday British troops were dispatched to Ulster after the Derry Apprentice Boys march.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times/Louis Manna

title: OUR NEXT MOVE ON CHINA
description: After focusing on the Soviet  Union, the Middle East, Europe, Africa and other foreignpolicy issues, President Carter is finally  perhaps belatedly  beginning a serious approach to China. Secretary of State Cyrus Vance arrives in Peking next week, the first senior member of the Carter Administration to visit the People's Republic. The big question is whether his trip will advance SinoAmerican relations, which have largely languished in the diplomatic doldrums since Richard Nixon's delirious journey across the Pacific more than five years ago. Another question, currently being debated among diplomatic specialists, is whether failure to make progress at this juncture would dislocate the tenuous link with China and, as a consequence, unhinge the power equilibrium in Asia.

title: Jets Beat Falcons, 172; Saints Overpower Giants
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 13Finally making their own luck, the New York Jets won their first exhibition game for Coach Walt Michaels tonight with a 172 decision over the notveryterrifying Falcons.

title: Fortune's 500 and Connecticut
description: OVER THE last 10 years more than 100 corporate executive offices have relocated in Connecticut, virtually all from New York City, and concentrated for the most part in lower Fairfield County. According to David Driver, executive assistant to the State Commissioner of Commerce, 104 such companies were listed as of February 1976, and at least a dozen more have come in since.

title: FISHING
description: FOR New Jersey fishermen, it has feast or famine these days. The abundance of bluefish has been offset by the scarcity of fluke and sea bass throughout much of the New York Bight. Most of the party boats that have been fishing the bottom have switched to bluefishing, and one captain in Atlantic City reported that bottom fishine was off by 80 percent.

title: ALIEN RULING SNARLS MIGRANT JOB INQUIRY
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13Federal immigration agents, in what they say is a preview of what will happen if President Carter's amnesty proposal for illegal aliens becomes law, are drowning in paperwork generated by a court ruling six months ago. As a result, they have virtually abandoned their investigations of alien job holders.

title: Patriots 38, Packers 3
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 13 (AP)Raymond Clayborn and Stanley Morgan, New England's two first round draft picks, scored on punt returns of 88 and 62 yards, leading the Patriots to a 383 victory over the Green Bay Packers to night. The Patriots never were headed; taking the lead on John Smith's 25yard firstquarter field goal.

title: An Old Fashioned Bargain
description: THE highways and shopping centers advanced to the very edge of Chatham, in Morris County, and then stopped. Someday, certainly, they will lumber westward once again, and when they do The William Pittnot to mention many other landmarks in this attractive suburban townmay disappear.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: CASEMENT windows differ from doublehung or sliding windows in that they are hinged at one side to open and close much like a hinged door. Although this type of window seldom breaks down, it does need periodic maintenance to keep it in good operating condition, and to make certain it will continue to form a reasonably airtight seal when shut.

title: From Henry To Jimmy
description: WASHINGTON  Henry Kissinger has abandoned, temporarily, the conduct of American foreign policy for the much more difficult And challenging tasks of writing a book and dieting, and though he has lost 25 pounds he hasn't lost his sense of humor.,He says, with mock solemnity, that he has already reviewed the first two years and two chapters of his stewardship in Washington without finding a single error of personal style or judgment, and is thinking of calling his book: KissingerA Study in Infallibility.

title: Cost of Nassau Services Termed Relatively High In Report by State Unit
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 13Nassau County spends more money and uses more administrative personnel in providing various public services than do either Suffolk or Westchester Counties, a state Commission has reported.

title: Elizabeth Hamilton Is Wed
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Reed Hamilton of Greenwich, Conn., widow of William H. Hamilton, to Waldo Wilshire Pennels, a widower, also of Greenwich, took place in Cos Cob, Conn., yesterday. The Rev. Samuel Walker of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Dunlaevy. Mr. Pennels, who is retired, was formerly executive vice president of the Royal Typewriter Company.

title: Getting Fired With Style
description: Few executives are ever fired, Yet, each year, thousands are displaced, 'surplused or squeezed. No matter what euphemism is used, two urgent problems face the executive who is forced out of his job: overcoming any termination trauma and finding a new job.

title: MiamiGateway to the Latin Dollar
description: MIAMIFor 25 years the heart of South Florida's power structure was the exclusive Miami Club, where small group of rich and conservative men, members of the old local families with ties all over the South, meeting informally over drinks and lunches, made decisions that later became policy for the area's utilities, railways, Insurance and real estate brokerages and handful of establishment law firms.

title: POLICE SEEK CLUES IN SLAYING OF 2 ON L.I.
description: WYANDANCH, L.I., Aug. 13The Suffolk County police today sought clues and a killer in the shotgun slaying of a 57yearold Hempstead man and his 24yearold daughter in a luxury car parked in a deserted industrial district here last night.

title: Vikings 34, Browns 33
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 13 (AP)Ri'k Danmeier's 30yard field goal as time ran out lifeted the Minnesota Vikings to a 3433 exhibition victory over the Cleveland Browns tonight.

title: Rock: Fresh Steve Miller Band
description: Steve Miller, who led a bluesoriented rock band in San Francisco during the 1960's, retired for two years during the early 1970's, and then returned with two poprock albums that quickly rose into the Top 10, brought his band into Nassau Coliseum Friday night. He had said that he was testing the water, so to speak, before committing himself to a major concert in Madison Square Garden; the thunderous reaction of the audience at Nassau must have been encouraging.

title: FEDERAL SURPLUS GOODS IN SOUTH CALLED UNEQUAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP)The South's heavy concentration of military installations helped that region get a disproportionate share of Federal surplus property at the expense of the Northeast sand Middle West, a Congressional report said today.

title: Is the Legislature A Joke on the Voters?
description: WHILE serving an eightweek internship in the office of Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak, I managed to take in the final weeks of an Albany comedythe bicentennial session of the New York State Legislature.

title: Dried Blossoms Will Last Forever
description: Dried flowers and plants are those whose moisture has been removed in order to make them last indefinitely. There are four basic techniques for removing this moisture: hanging the plants for airdrying, using a dehydrating agent, processing with glycerine and pressing.

title: Attempts at Control Have Been Erratic, Confused and Frequently Mysterious
description: WASHINGTONFormer President Nixon, his aide, H.R. Haldeman, and former Attorney General John N. Mitchell were recently ordered by a Federal court to pay $5 in damages to a former National Security Council staff member and his family for placing an illegal wiretap on their home. Although the court had ruled that the tap violated the constitutional rights of the staff member, Morton Halperin, awarded only a nominal sum because the tap had not cost him income.

title: Miss Hayford Bride Of Joseph H.Philipp
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Elizabeth Hayford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Joseph Hayford, of Greenwich, to Joseph Harding Philipp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Philipp of Bristol, Conn. The Rev. John Gilmartin performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: I HAVE high standards of ethics and morality. I am honest and lawabiding. I don't cheat or steal. But now and again, some dark secret corner of my being becomes restless and yearns to live dangerously, to be daringto be Robin Hood.

description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: Listing to the Right
description: THERE is a touch of wit on the cover of Allen Drury's new novel. The book is called Anna Hastings: The Story of a Washington Newspaperwoman, but Ms. Hastings has crossed out woman and written person. She has Just published her own memoirs, and the novel opens with severer of the reviews. To Washington Anna Hastings came, saw; conquered, writes Time. The story of how she planned it that way and made it all come true is one of the most intriguing inside accounts of Washington ever written. The little Polish girl from Punxsutawney, P.A. [sic] who rose to become one of the capital's two major publishers has a tale to tell. . . . Each chapter begins with a snippet of the memoirs. Then Ed Macomb, Anna's former managing editor, tells his story of the same events.

title: INVESTING
description: From World War II until recently investors paid little attention to the bond market, and with reasonyields were low and fell almost without letup for nearly 30 years. In 1974 times changed.

title: Crime in County Swings Northward
description: CRIME increased in Westchester County last year, but moderately, and at a rate roughly equivalent to that on Long Is land. The trend in this county was northward, following the population, with juveniles more involved than ever before.

title: Bombs Explode in Corsica
description: AJACCIO, Corsica, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Six bomb blasts early today damaged buildings here and a television relay station in the north of this French Mediterranean island, the police said. No one was injured. The attacks occurred on the eve of a meeting of one of the island's two separatist movementsthe Union of the Corsican People. The rival, more militant Corsican Liberation Front has decided not to attend the meeting.

title: No Society to Write About
description: THE DARK LADY is perhaps Louis Auchincloss's 20th work of fiction. Since he has also devoted volumes to Henry James and Edith Wharton, it would be pleasant to regard him as a Nr,w York novelist of society carrying on their valuable tradition more than threequarters of a century after the publication of such masterpieces as Washington Square and The House of Mirth. Unfortunately, Mr. Auchincloss isn't good enough to be placed in a line with James and Wharton. The Dark Lady is a trivial book about trivial people with clockwork insides or no insides at all. And there is another reason why calling him a novelist of society won't do. There just isn't any society, in the James or Wharton sense, anywhere in the AngloAmerican world to be the novelist of, nor has there been any for a long time.

title: Julie E. Brief Is Fiancee Of Saul Samuel Schwarz
description: Dr. and Mrs. Donald Kent Brief of South Orange, N. J, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Elizabeth Brief, to Saul Samuel Schwarz, whose greatgreatgrandfather, Rabbi Isaac Schwarz founded in 1860 and was the first rabbi of Congregation Oheb Shalom in South Orange.

title: Homer's Interest Odyssey
description: The news about interest rates is that they have made very little news of late. Even now, in the third year of recovery and economic expansion, shortterm rates are only beginning to be nudged upward, while longterm rates remain lodged pretty firmly where they have been for some time.

title: 22.522 at Roosevelt Finale
description: WESTBURY, LI.,Aug. 13Roosevelt Raceway closed its most successful. meeting tonight since the Meadowlands in New Jersey opened nearly a year ago.

title: Driving Is Safer On the State's Roads
description: DURING the 12 months between April 1, 1975, and March 1, 1976, the police in New Jersey arrested 489,342 speeding motorists. That was almost twice as many as the 280,000 arrested in the preceeding 12 months. Therein lies the reason why for 1976, New Jersey had the safest highways in the nation.

title: Suzanne Middleton Wed to M. B. Jeffers

The Rev. Joseph Farley performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Books of The Times
description: Robert J. Seidman, who is 36 years old and who seems to have spent much of his life in one college town or an-.other, here and abroad, has written a 19thcentury novel. He has even set it in the middle of the 19th century. It is part historical romancewe are intro-duced to Horace Greeley and Stephen Douglasand part Bildungsroman, as if Goethe had composed one of his edu-cational novels about an American Indian. It teems with characters, none of them safe from Mr. Seidman, who, in the grand manner, intervenes when-ever he chooses to set things straight or to supply some inside information. And for most of the way, it is very good indeed.

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE SCORED ON SHOOTING
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14The shooting of an unarmed man by a police sergeant 10 days ago has prompted new allega-tions that some members of the Los An-geles Police Department are trigger happy, at a time when the department's controversial chief, Edward M. Davis, is preparing to run for Governor.

description: Horses listed In order of Post positions

title: Bernardi Arriving To Rehearse New Role
description: Herschel Bernardi will arrive in New York Wednesday to prepare for his.new play, The. Confirmation, by Howard Ashman. It begins rehearsals early in September under the direction of Ken-neth Frankel and opens on Broadway on Oct. 18. The play, set in suburban Baltimore in 1962, will depict two days in the life of Arnold Polenplayed by Mr. Bernardihis wife , and their 15-yearold daughter.

title: AUG. 29 MEETING SET ON HEAD OF COLLEGE
description: The Board of Higher Education has called a special meeting for Aug. 29 to decide whether Dr. Edgar D. Draper will be retained as president of the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Ethiopia Shows ShotDown Somali Jet, Cache of Arms

title: Federal Laws Said to Favor Illegal Betting
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 Maintaining that present Federal gambling laws discriminate against legal enterprise and benefit illegal operators, James E. Ritchie,,a Washing-ton attorney, advised Jockey Club members today to become involved in changing the tax policies.

description: PARAMUS, Aug. 14More than 350 hardcore fans screamed and squealed with delight at a Soap Opera Festival here today as some of the actors told what it was like to serve up the steady diet of daytime drama that the fans crave.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug.l4The Carter Administration is opposing new restric-tions on the use of an electronic surveil-lance method that has long been favored by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other law enforcement agencies.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The Soviet Union, urging that Ethiopia and Somalia stop their fighting and start ne-gotiating, indicated today that its sympa-thies were leanine toward Ethiopia.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14After voyaging smoothly over most of the charted waters of the ancient world, conferees who had come from 11 countries to talk about maps struck a reef called Vinland.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14With more pride than urgency, Randy Dean has thrown his helmet into the ring as quarterback candidate for the Giants.

title: CANAL NEGOTIATORS APPEAL FOR SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The Ameri-can negotiators for a new Panama Canal treaty, appealed for bipartisan support today and warned of possible violence in Panama and bitterness against the United States in other countries if the pact was rejected by the Senate.

title: America's Cup Ball Is a Party Fit for Gatsby
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14Pamela Gray was having a fantastic, fabulous time, although every time she swung around on the dance floor, the flowers pinned to her shoulder bag would whirl and hit someone, usually in some strategic spot. But a swat with a hand-bag is minor league, when one consid-ers that some of the colony's best and near best were being stepped on, kicked in the shins, and cracked in the elbows.

title: Former Drug Addicts Find Personal Growth in Gardens
description: There was a time when W. Sherman Drew would not touch his mother's house plants because he said he was afraid he would destroy them. Then, when he was fighting drug addiction and looking for a hobby, he tried growing one spider-plant cutting.

title: Mayor in Ohio at 18, U.S. Airman at 20

title: Art of Weaving Is Dying in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyFor countless centuries the nomads add villagers of rural Anatolia have woven rugs to cover their floors, flaps to close their tents: sacks to carry their grain and saddlebags to sling over their donkeys and camels. Like many crafts and tradi-tions in this ancient land, the art of weaving is rapidly disappearing under the uressures of modernization.

title: High Tides Arotind New York
The Editorial Notebook
description: Reports from Paris describe the emergence of a group of young in-tellectuals, some of them former Communists, who have concluded that Marxism is monstrous. These new philosophers have upset the leftist world of French intellectualdom by arguing that Marxist theory cannot be divorced from the abominable reality of Solzhenitsvn's Gulag.

Mackie Wunderle of Huntingdon Valley, P. The Rev. Dr. Charles Agin performed the nondenominational ceremony at the North Hills Country Club.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)Chip and Caron Carter, whispering, smiling and holding hands, attended church today with President and Mrs. Carter amid re-ports that the young couple were separat-ing.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14Legislation to reduce Government regulation of airlines has been caught in a crossfire of lobby-ing, and Congressional action appears un-likely before spring, its supporters say.

description: The Yankees packed up all their missing runs in one bundle yesterday and unloaded them on the California Angels at Yankee Stadium for a 153 romp.

title: 415 American Tourists Leave Shannon After Being Stranded
description: SHANNON, Ireland, Aug. 14 (AP)A total of 415 Americans tourists left for their destinations today after having been stranded here for several hours because of mechanical problems on their charter nlanes.

title: Former Las Vegas Operator Expects  Atlantic City to Retain Family Trade
description: .ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 14William S. WOMberger, who quit as president of Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., last month tooperate a proposed new casino hotel complex for the Bally Manufacturing Corporation here, says he will run the new place on the Boardwalk about the way he did the one on the Nevada desert strip.

Anna Moffo, the opera star, sings at noon. A revue group featuring Claudia Villa will also perform daily from 11:30 A.M. to P.M.

title: Union to Consider Merger

The guild represents 35,000 newspaper employees.

title: Buoyant London Stock Market Is M ost Upbeat of Foreign Exchanges
description: With the exception of a buoyant turnaround on the London Stock Exchange, major foreign stock markets have been generally sluggish through the first part of the year.

title: Robinson, Clarinet, Becomes Group Leader
description: Perry Robinson has been win-ning jazz polls as a clarinetist for well over a decade now, yet he has rarely sought the spotlight as group leader. Instead he has been heard, buried in enseMblelor play-ing intriguing but brief solos, with the Jazz Composer's Orchestra, Archie Shepp, Three Generations of Brubeck, Interface and other groups. His poll winning has been largely on the basis of reputation; there have been few modern clari-netists around to challenge his position.

title: Consumer Agency Helps Draw Up Safety Standards for Skateboards
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)The Consumer Product Safety Commission and skateboard manufacturers are jointly developing safety standards for skate-boards, which have been associated with 13 reported deaths from 1973 to April 7977

title: Conference to Be Broadcast
description: The Public Broadcasting Serv-ice and National Public Radio have announced plans to cover the National Women's Con-ference in Houston in mid-November, with funding from the Corporation for Public Broadcast-ing.

title: Nuclear Plants Protested in Spain
description: MADRID, Aug. 14 (AP)Thousands of Spaniards staged peaceful demonstrations in Valencia and Badajoz today to protest the construction of ,a nuclear power plant and plans to build another. About 5,000 persons marched through the main streets of Badajoz, and several thousand rallied at Valencia.

title: Tunisia: A Test For Carter

title: 114 Years Later, Minor Skirmishing Flares at Gettysburg
description: GETITSBURG, Pa., Aug. 9It is 114 years since the Union and Confederate armies and Abraham Lin-coln gave this town a place in history, but subsequent battles of Gettysburg, most of them nonviolent, contin-ue. The battles include one that has been going on sporadically for years between Gettysburg and the Library of Congress over a handwritten copy of the speech Lincoln made here dedicating the national cemetery on Nov. 19. 1863.

title: Judith Mary Markewich Is Wed to Steven Fisher

title: A Soothing Sessions Leads Off Contemporaries at Tanglewood
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14Of the two great, overriding human con-cernslove and deathit is the gloomy inevitability of the latter rather than the precarious possibil-ity of the former that seems more consistently to excite the imagina-tions of latterday composers. This is not strange: death lends itself to contemplation, while love is much too volatile a phenomenon to be pinned down long enough to be thought upon heavily. Perhaps for some such reason and afew others including expressive limitations inherent in some 20thcentury com-posing techniquesthe opening pair of programs of this year's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood turned out to be sober affairs.

title: Plane Crash Kills Pennsylvanian

title: Italian Film About Sex Isn't Much
description: The hero of "The Sensual Man" is crazy about women, and women are crazy about him, too. Right from the moment when Paolo (Giancarlo Giannini), then the barely adolescent scion of a Sicilian noble family, begins fooling around with the maid, his life becomes a hectic one. There are a tempestuous blonde, a rich Roman brunette with a lot of modern furniture, and a stern lady Communust who, rather inexplicably, wears black lace garters.There are the fresh-faced girl at the chemist's and the countess with the yelowish teeth. There is the pretty nurse at whom Paolo, always at the ready, makes a pass, even though the nurse is busy ministering to his dying father. There is even, very nearly, Paolo's unusually nubile Mama.The only problem is that "The Sensual Man" isn't a comedy, at least not intentionally. Instead, this is meant to be the long, sad story of Paolo's congenital inability to control his carnal passions (by way of an explanation, it seems it'sh ereditary; his uncle and grandfather were ladykillers, too). The tale culminates in Paolo's failure to stay married to the only woman he truly loves, a sweet young thing 20 years his junior, a creature so untainted that the very notion of sex makes her burst out crying.There isn't much of a lesson to be learned from "The Sensual Man," and there isn't much to watch here, either. Marco Vicario's direction is stultifyingly banal; he favors dark rooms overdecorated with antique furniture, romantic strolls through the autumn leaves and swelling strings each time the billing and cooing begin.Giancarlo Giannini has played characters like Paolo too often to attack the role with much energy, even though he is this time confronted with an unusual difficulty. Even in 1974, when "The Sensual Man" was made in Italy, Mr. Giannini looked substantially older than the rapscalllion of 25 he is supposed, at least during the middle of the film, to be. As if that weren't bad enough, he also looks older than the actress who plays his mother.

title: Electricity Fails in Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar, Aug. 14 (AP)A power failure cut the electricity supply through-out this Persian Gulf sheikdom today, blacking out homes and halting air condi-tioners in sweltering weather. Electric company officials said the blackout had affected power grids throughout the na-tion but did not elaborate. It said power would be restored within two hours.

description: Seattle had its World's Fair in 1962, Gut the artifacts remain. The revolving restaurant atop the Space Needle does big:business. Diners sip peculiar North-viest drinks, watch Lake Union come iiito view, admire the sun bouncing off the Homeric blue of Puget Sound. On cfear day, you can almost see Tokyo. The monorail still runs from Seattle Center to downtown Pine Street: non-stalk 15 Cents.

title: Begin's New Strength Rests On Shifts in Israeli Society
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 14Prime Minister Menahem Begin's emergence as a leader of unquestioned domestic strength re-flects not only a remarkably rapid growth of authority in his less than three months in power but important underlying changes in Israeli society.

title: Carter's Nuclear Test in Japan
description: President Carter must soon make a decision that will reveal whether there is substance or only bluster in his efforts to restrict the spread of dangerous nuclear tech-nologies. Japan seeks permission to reprocess nuclear fuel supplied by the United States in a pilot plant at Tokai Mura, northeast of Tokyo. Mr. Carter has rightly tried to minimize such reprocessing because it typically produces plutonium, which can be used as fuel in nuclear reactorsor as the explosive force in nuclear bombs. No responsible American official believes the Japanese intend to make bombs; they could have done so long ago had they desired. But the Administration's response to the Japanese request could determine whether Mr. Carter's general campaign against proliferation will suc-ceed or fail.

title: Fire Threatens California Homes; Residents Alerted for Evacuation
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP)Flames from the blaze known as Marble Cone jumped a fire line the width of six bull-dozer tracks today and seared across some 4,000 acres, threatening some sum-mer homes in the Carmel Valley on the scenic central California coast. The blaze has burned more than 122,000 acres.

title: Jury in Mandel Trial Reconvene
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 14The jury in the Federal corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and his five code-fendants resumed deliberations today after the recovery of one member whose illness forced a oneday recess yesterday. For the fourth day the panel failed to reach verdicts, and it will convene again tomorrow.

title: Wadkins Takes P.G.A. Title; 77,691 See Cosmos Win
description: Lanny Wadkins defeated Gene Littler on the third hole of their playoff yester-day and won the Professional Golfers Association championship. Wadkins and Littler had tied at 282, six under par for the regulation 72 holes, at the Pebble Beach Golf Links in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Rosemarie Ackermann Sets HizhItimp Mark
description: HELSINKI,Finland, Aug. 14 (AP)-Roseinarie Ackermann broke the'20;women's world highjump record by clearing 6 feet 534 inches In the last event of the European track and field final at the Olympic Stadium today.

title: Wind and Rough Seas Dismast Sverige
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14Sweden's promising America's Cup venture hit another snag today when Sverige was dismasted in high winds and rough seas about halfway through her 24.3mile race with Gretel II

title: Despite Forecast, Brightest Cosmos Day
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 14From the time he woke up this morn-ing, which was about 9 o'clock, until the time he left his Manhattan apart-ment for Giants Stadium, which was about 3 o'clock, the general manager of the Cosmos telephoned the National Weather Service every hour to get an update on the forecast. Mike Martin only wanted to hear the word, clear-ing. If the rain would go away, he thought, the Cosmos could sell the house out. But each forecast was dis-couraging. Every time Martin called, all he heard was showers and thunder-showers.

title: Ted Daniel and Energy Band
description: Ted Daniel has been leading Energy, a 14piece band, at the Studio We community music cen-ter on Saturday nights. The Studio, at 193 Eldridge Street, is an oasis of sorts in one of the Lower East Side's more forbiddinglooking neighborhoods, and Energy is po-tentially an important addition to Manhattan's relatively small corps of workine bie bands.

description: About the only thing encouraging brokers to go to work this morning after the dismal stock market performance last week is the timetested adage that it may be darkest before the dawn.

title: 48 Johnson Victory Debated Anew In Texas as Fraud Issue Is Revived
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 14Although 29 years have passed since Lyndon B. Johnson won the runoff in the Democratic primary for the Senate, Texans are discussing charges of vote fraud as though the elec-tion were a current event

title: Church Group Is the Only Opposition in Philippines
description: MANILA, Aug. 9Nearly five years after imposing martial law, President Fer-dinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, have cemented their control in a nation where virtually all political opposition has been silenced except for an emerging nd vocal movement within the Catholic hierarchy.

title: Croangle s Control of Erie County. Democrats at Stake in Buffalo Primary
description: BUFFALOIn 1961, the late Frank Sedita lost the Democratic mayoral pri-mary here to Victor E. Manz, a City Coun-cilman. Mr. Sedita, the incumbent and the organization candidate, then ran in the general election as an independent. He and Mr. Manz split the Democratic vote and gave the city one of its few Republican mayors in modern times, Chester Kowal.

title: Sadat Stopping Exports Of Cotton to the Soviet; Cites ProblemWithTanks
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 14 (Reu-ters)Egypt has decided to suspend cot-ton shipments to the Soviet Union and an Eastern European country because the Sovietbloc nation had halted delivery tanks purchased by the Egyptians, Presi-dent Anwar elSadat said today.

title: Plane Crash Investigated
description: VANCLEAVE, Miss., Aug. 14 (AP)Federal Aviation Administration officials examined the, wreckage of a Beechcraft TwinAir today, looking for the cause of the crash that killed three persons. The small twinengine plane went down short-ly before 11 A.M. yesterday in wooded country about eight miles north of Van-cleave. The authorities identified the vic-tims as Cy Emery, 65 years old, of Laurel, Miss., the pilot, a retired manager of Lau-rel Municipal Airport; Richard G. Lucas, 18, of Chatham, Ala., a, student and. Charles Crawford, 50, of Milky, Ala.

title: Fukuda Begins Visit to Thailand; Pledges Peaceful Role for Japan
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 15 (UPI)Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan, pledging that his country will never become a military power again, arrived in Thailand today for a twoday visit.

title: Doctor Pleads Guilty in Death
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (AP)A 31year old doctor pleaded guilty today to voluntary manslaughter in the beating death of his former lover's 8yearold son, whose body has never been found. Dr. Stuart Kutler, a Brecksville, Ohio, emergency room physician, faces a possible sentence of four to 25 years in prison and a possible fine of $10,000.

title: GROUP ASKS U.S. COURT TO VOID NIXON PARDON
description: A National Committee for Impeachment emerged again yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan with a law suit against former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Richard M. Nixon and Attorney General Griffin B. Beli, asking that the pardon granted to Mr. Nixon in September 1974 be declared null and void.

title: Dewey Redman's Quartet Shows An Impressive Mastery of Jazz
description: Dewey Redman is neither as flamboyant nor as charismatic a personality as Sam Rivers, but Mr. Rivers is surely his only peer among contemporary, postColtrane tenor saxophonists. Yet Mr. Redman is sometimes overlooked when lists of top saxophonists are made, and ironically enough, the consistency of his playing is at least partly at fault. Whether playing Ornette Coleman's music, Keith Jarrett's or his own, he has always played superbly, and such dependable excellence tends to get taken for granted.

title: BIRMINGHAIYI BLASTS OF 60'S RESTUDIED
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 14Birmingham relived part of its past last week when a state grand jury began taking testimony on a series of racially motivated bombings of the 1960's, including the 1963 dynamiting of a church that killed four young girls attending Sunday School.

title: Ancient China Tomb Yields 1,000 Artifacts
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 15 (UPI)A 2,100yearold tomb containing more than 1,000 burial objects was unearthed recently in China's Kwangsi Chuang Autonomous Region, the Hsinhua press agency said today.

title: Vilas Captures Fifth Straight Tennis Tourney
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina won his fifth consecutive tournament tonight, defeating Brian Gottfried, 62, 61, in the finals of the $125,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament at Muirfield Village.

title: Putting More Women in Uniform
description: The Pentagon's restrictions on women in the military services appear to be weakening. The Navy has asked for modification of a law that prevents women from serving at sea, and the Senate has asked the Secretary of Defense to study a change that would make it easier for women to serve on Air Force planes.

title: FERNANDO R. AYUSO
description: Fernando Rodriguez Ayuso, who was the director of the Spanish Tourist Office at 665 Fifth Avenue for the last two years, died Saturday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He was 47 years old. He is survived by his wife, Victoria; his mother; two brothers, and two sisters.

title: Visit to WarTorn South Lebanon: Ghost Town and Roving Guerrillas
description: NABATIYE, Lebanon, Aug. 15By coincidence of the lunar calendar, today was both the beginning of the Moslem fast of Ramadan and the celebration of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary. But, here in southern Lebanon, this fragile symbol of Islamic and Christian sanctity did not silence the guns.

title: QUALIFIED SUPPORT OF PANAMA TREATIES GIVEN BY KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  President Carter stepped up his drive to muster bipartisan support for two new Panama Canal treaties today by obtaining a qualified endorsement of the pacts from former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and by making an appeal by telephone to former President Gerald R. Ford.
