title: Stewardesses Organize To Defend Against Rape
description: LOS ANGELESA group of Los Angeles airline stewardnesses, alarmed by a rising number of assaults on flight attendants, have formed a selfdefense organization whose members hope eventually to alert most of the nation's 38,000 stewardesses about wouldbe rapists.

title: Tanglewood Fete Stumbles Over Xenakis 'Persephassa
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15One of the more pernicious notions entertained by composers in the last decade or two may be called the X delusion. That is, take one or two commonplace ideas, inflate them by any convenient number. and the result will be not only something more than commonplace but even, perhaps, musical art. Such a delusion seemed to be all that could explain Persephassa, a piece for six percussionists by Yannis Xenakis that closed last night's program at Tanglewood, where the annual Festival of Contemporary Music is in session this week.

title: Mets Snap Streak
description: The Mets ended a sixgame losing streak as Craig Swan and Bob Apodaca pitched them to a 74 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in St. Louis. Page 47.

title: Premiere of Agnes Varda Film Opens Festival at Lincoln Center Sept. 23
description: New works by film makers from France, Italy, West Germany, Algeria and the United States, as well as an animation festival and a retrospective of 10 important American films will be seen at the 15th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, from Sept. 23 to Oct. 9, it was announced yesterday by Martin E. Segal, president of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Newspapers Backed by N.L.R.B. On Formulating Code of Ethics
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa. Aug. 15 (UPI)A three  man National Labor Relations Board panel has upheld the right of newspapers to formulate codes of ethics unilaterally without reference to unions, as long as the newspaper does not impose penalties or refuse to bargain over changes of working conditions that may ensue. The ruling came on an appeal by The Pottstown Mercury against an early decision by Samuel Singer, an administrative law judge, that the paper would have to rescind its code of ethics issued April 15, 1974.

title: Mother Not Angry At Baby Sitter, 12, In Kidnapping Case
description: To me, she always seemed like a very nice little girl, said Loretta Brown, of the 12yearold baby sitter who the police say kidnapped Mrs. Brown's 5yearold son, Hasan, and demanded $17 and a new dress for his return.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Thursday on auto production in the Andean Common Market was illustrated by an archive ohotograph of a General Motors plant in Lima, Peru. G.M. discontinued assembly activities there on Dec. 31, 1970.

title: 3 NEW U.S. AMBASSADORS ARE NOMINATED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)President Carter today nominated ambassadors to Honduras. Burma and the Bahamas. Also announced were selections of the second ranking officials at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the National Science Foundation and the new head of the Agriculture Department's Agricultural Marketing Service.

title: Gimbel Discloses A $2.2 Million Loss For Fiscal Quarter
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc., which is continuing its program of phasing out lowmargin, hard goods lines in its department stores, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $2.2 million in the third fiscal quarter ended July 2. In the corresponding period last year the loss was $718,000.

title: PRICE WAR RECORD STORES FILE BANKRUPTCY PETITION
description: Jimmy's Music World, a chain of discount record stores that touched off a price war when it opened in New York City in 1974, has filed bankruptcy proceedings in Federal Court along with its parent company, Sutton Distributors of Rahway, N. J.

title: The New South And the Old
description: DAWSON, Ga.The Rev. M. W. Merritt, pastor of the Sardis Baptist Church here, took the witness stand the other day during pretrial hearings in the case of the Dawson Five. He told how a local pharmacist had recently refused to allow the Reverend Mr.Merritt's 5yearold daughter to use the toilet in a downtown drug store.

title: Bridge:
description: The nature of duplicate is such that hairtrigger doublers often reap a substantial reward. But a high degree of judgment is called for. At a low level, it is hardly ever right to double the opponents unless the doubling side has most of the highcard strength and the hand appears to be a misfit.

title: BAN LIFTED ON U. S. AID TO HARTFORD SUBURBS
description: A court order that barred Federal communitydevelopment funds last year for several relatively affluent suburbs of Hartford was overturned yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: S.E.C.Charges Winters Firm With Fraudulent Ginnie Mae Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (LTDThe Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Winters Government Securities Corporation used fraudulent methods in the sale of $400 million of Governmentbacked mortgage securities in a sixmonth period.

title: ExportImport Bank May Lend Mexico $400 Million for Pipeline
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 15 (AP)The United States ExportImport Bank may lend Mexico up to $400 million of the $1.2 billion it needs to build a pipeline to carry natural gas from Mexico to the United States, according to the United States Ambassador to Mexico.

title: Twins Take Over First in A.L. West
description: How close is the race in the American League's Western Division? Itisthisclose.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP AT SLOWER RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15A further slackening in the rate of economic growth was signaled today with a report that industrial production in July rose by 0.5 percent compared with jumps of 0.7 percent in June and of 0.9 percent in May.

title: George Oppenheimer, Drama Critic And Writer for Stage and Screen
description: George Oppenheimer, who wrote for the Broadway stage, movies and television, and was drama critic for Newsday, died Sunday. He was 77 years old and lived at 15 East 64th Street.

title: ARCHBISHOP ANTONI BARANIAK
description: WARSAW, Aug. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)The Archbishop of Poznan, Antoni Baraniak, died in his diocese Saturday after a long illness, he was 73. Archbishop of Poznan since 1957, he was director of the secretariat of Stefan Cardinal Wysynski, the Polish primate.

title: Torrez's 5th in Row Tops White Sox, 62
description: The New York Yankees treated 33,902 of their customers to some more revival baseball last night in Yankee Stadium when Mike Torrez pitched them to a 62 victory over the slipping Chicago White Sox.

title: Lance Inquiry: A Carter Test
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The persistent investigation of the personal financial problems of Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the nagging publicity that has accompanied it pose a severe test and an acute political dilemma for President Carter.

title: I Roving Pickets From West Virginia Enter Other States to Shut Mines
description: Militant roving pickets spread out from the West Virginia coal fields into neighboring states yesterday to shut down several mines in a wildcat strike over cutbacks in miners health care benefits.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 16, 1977

title: EXILES REPORTED FOILED IN PLAN FOR RAID ON CUBA
description: MLAMI, Aug. 15 (AP)Federal and state agents frustrated the plans of Cuban exiles to raid their former homeland today, seizing three boats, an antitank cannon and other weapons, a federal spokesman said.

title: Expos Garrett Disabled
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 15 (UPI)  The Montreal Expos announced today they have placed Wayne Garrett, an infielder, on the 21day disabled list, effective last Saturday. Garrett, a former New York Met, suffered an ankle injury in a game against Philadelphia last week. The Expos said they did not plan to call up a replacement.

title: 2 Women Tie for Medal In North Carolina Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 15 (AP)Cathy Reynolds of Springfield, Mo., and Noreen Uihlein of Hershey, Pa., tied for medalist honors today, the opening day of the Women's Trans National golf championship. Each shot a 73 at the Mid Pines Country Club.

title: F.C.C. Accused of Laxity in Efforts to End Biased Portrayals on TV
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The United States Civil Rights Commission said today that television was marked by racial and sexual stereotyping and that the Federal Communications Commission appeared unwilling to push hard to end such discrimination.

title: PRICE OF F16 MAY EXCEED LIMIT, ACCORDING TO G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)Joint United States and European production of the F16 lightweight fighter may drive the price above the agreed ceiling of $6.09 million a plane and this could have a grave political impact, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: JURORS IN MANDEL TRIAL DELIBERATE FOR 5TH DAY
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 15The jury in the Federal corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland went through its fifth day of deliberation today, still without reaching verdicts on the conspiracy and bribery charges against the twoterm Democratic Governor and his five codefendants. Today's session ended at 6 P.M.

title: Prices Decline to Contract Lows In Many Key Commodity Futures
description: Many key commodity futures fell to contract lows yesterday as prices retreated on a broad front, much to the gain of holders of short positions in the market.

title: Leftists Clash With Police in Britain
description: LONDON, Aug. 15Members of the Socialist Workers Party clashed with the police in Birmingham tonight as they tried to break up a meeting of the rightwing National Front.

title: Users of Food Stamps Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)The number of families using food stamps declined 2.5 percent from May to June to a total of about 5.09 million households, the Agriculture Department said today. Benefits totaled $398.8 million for June, a drop from May of $4.3 million. About 5.22 million families received the coupons in May, and about 5.63 million participated in June 1976.

title: CHARLES JOHN KAHWATY
description: Charles John Kahwaty, a former president of the Passaic County Bar Association, died Sunday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. Mr. Kahwaty, who lived in Franklin Lakes, N.J., was 59 years old.

title: Convicts Want $11,000 For Youth Program
description: WOODBRIDGE, Aug. 15 (AP)A group of convicted murderers and armed robbers want $11,000in bills of any denomination they can getto keep a nationally acclaimed juvenilecrimeprevention program alive.

title: Into the Wild Blue Yonder
description: RALEIGH, N. C.Once I was born again. It was at a revival at the First Baptist Church in my hometown in North Carolina, and I was 13. I have my friend, Pammy Lou Hinson, not God, to thank for it. The church had gone all out for the saving of souls that week. It hired a Baptist lay preacher from Texas, an artist who drew pictures in iridescent chalk to illustrate the sermons, and a soloist whose bass voice reverberating through the church could have brought Bertrand Russell to his knees. Actually, they were all from Texas, an irresistible and flashy evangelical team. We did things in a big way.

title: No article
description: Mexico,Aug. 15 (UPI)A er truck apparently swerved

title: Lou Walters, Nightclub Impresario And Founder of Latin Quarter, Dies
description: Lou Walters, one of the nation's leading: supperclub entrepreneurs in the 1940's and 50's, owner and operator of the famed Latin Quarter in midtown Manhattan, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Miami. He was 81 years old.

title: Default Rate Is High In Student Loan Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)Students are defaulting on federally guaranteed loans at a continuing high rate and more vigorous collection attempts are needed, the General Accounti?g Office said in a report today.

title: Ray Files a Libel Suit Against Playboy But Is Told to Withdraw It
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 15 (AP)James Earl Ray, convicted killer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has filed a $1 million libel suit against Playboy magazine, according to his attorney, who said he had advised Mr Ray to withdraw the suit.

title: Carter's Appointees Who Opposed Him On Abortion Hailed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)The women in the Carter Administration who spoke out against the President's opposition to using Federal funding for abortions were praised today, by 27 women's and public interest groups.

title: Notes on People
description: Pope Paul VI was in an exceptionally morose mood yesterday when he spoke to a crowd on the banks of Lake Albano, near his summer palace of Castel Gandolfo in the hills south of Rome. Speaking sadly, on the Feast of the Assumption, of his own death, the Pontiff said that he could see the threshold of the beyond. He said that he would like to make an appointment with those present to celebrate the Assumption mass together again next year. But who knows if I, old as I am, can hope to make this feast day with you again, the Pope said. The 79  year  old Pontiff normally speaks of himself with the papal we, but before 2,000 persons yesterday he used the first person singular.

title: Television
Phone Call Gave Police Key Clue To Berkowitz
description: YONKERS, Aug. 15A chance telephone encounter last Tuesday between a New York City detective and a police ??atcher here who is the daughter of Sam Carrbelieved to be the Sam in Son of Samappears to have played the pivotal role in the search that led to the arrest the following day of David R. Berkowitz as the socalled .44caliber killer.

title: Saxbes Got $5,000 From Household Sale
description: MECHANICSBURG, Ohio. Aug. 15 (AP)The William B. Saxbes sold pretty much everything we wanted to at their twoday weekend sale, and now are about $5,000 ahead. They said the main reason they held the sale was that their house was too crowded with objects they had acquired over the years

title: Marius Casadesus Suing Over Concerto by Mozart
description: PARISAlmost every morning, lovers of classical music here have switched on their radios to hear Yehudi Menuhin's violin strings soar through the Adelaide Concerto.

title: New Bond Issues
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARKS, Sheep Meadow, Central Park, 8:30.

title: Flood Kills 35 in India
description: MADURAI, India, Aug. 15 (AP)A rain swollen river flooded an encampment of Hindu pilgrims near this city in southern India, killing at least 35, the national news agency reported today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: One Crow Ties Up Conrail Line
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 15Tell a commuter that his train has been delayed by a fire on the tracks, a derailment ahead or a switch problem, and he'll know what you're talking about. But tell him that the fate of a crow is the reason his train is sitting idly in the Westchester country side, and you may have a communications problem.

title: Berlin Pays Tribute to 20's Art Scene
description: WEST BERLINFifty years ago Berlin was one of the centers of an explosive art scene in which painters, playwrights, musicians, sculptors and architects sought new and complex answers to mankind's changing sensibilities and to political and social upheaval. In Trends of the Twenties, a mammoth art exhibition staged under the auspices of the Strasbourg Council of Europe, West Berlin is presenting a dazzling display of works and documents showing what happened in that golden age of innovation and controversy.

title: U.S. Sues to Revoke the Citizenship Of Man Accused of Executing Jews
description: MIAMI, Aug. 15 (UPI)  The Justice Department filed a civil suit today to revoke the American citizenship of a former Russian soldier accused of helping the Nazis execute thousands of Jews in a World War II death camp.

title: Honorary Degree for Gen. Haig
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 15 (AP)Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree from the University of Utah at the Septa 10 commencement for the university's graduate students in Europe. General Haig, a former aide to the President and Henry A. Kissinger in the Nixon Administration, is now Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

title: 6 Cup Contenders Will Sail Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 15Ted Turner, Alan Bond, Baron Marcel Bich and a slew of lesscontroversial contestants will be sharing the same ocean tomorrow when double  barreled action begins on the America's Cup yachting scene.

title: Saudi Oil Cut in Test Of Wells Is Reported
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 15 (AP)Saudi Arabia has informed its four major United States customersExxon, Texaco, Socal and Mobilthat they will be cut back by 700,000 barrels of crude oil a day for three months, starting Sept. 1, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: World News Briefs
description: BONN, Aug. 15 (UPI)Herbert Kappler, a Nazi war crimminal serving a life sentence for the massacre of 335 Italians, vanished from a Rome military hospital early today and was reported brought back to West Germany.

title: SIX AIRLINES AGREE TO ROUNDTRIP FARE OF $256 FOR LONDON
description: The six scheduled airlines flying between New York and London agreed yesterday to reduce the price of the lowest available offseason roundtrip fare to $256, or $94 less than the lowest at present. The new restricted rate would take effect Sept. 15.

title: Horsemen Appeal to Byrne
description: TRENTON, Aug. 15The New Jersey Division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association petitioned Governor Byrne today to have him extend the Meadowlands thoroughbred meeting, opening Tuesday night, Sept. 6, through next March. It is scheduled to close at the end of the year.

title: Bomb Explodes Outside the Office Of Radical West German Lawyer
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug. 15 (AP)A bomb exploded before dawn today at the office of the radical lawyer Klaus Croissant, who fled to France last month and is wanted in West Germany for questioning on his contacts with urban terrorists.

title: CLIFFORD WELLS
description: GARLAND, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP)Clifford Wells, the former Tulane basketball coach, died at his home early today of an apparent heart attack. He was 81 years old.

title: Con Ed Preparing FuelCell Test Plant
description: The Consolidated Edison Company is preparing to carry out in Manhattan the nation's first test on a practical scale of an advanced, nonpolluting fuel cell for generating electricity in urban neighborhoods.

title: Blast Levels a House in Hackensack
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 15An explosion of undetermined origin destroyed a twostory house here early this morning and heavily damaged two adjacent homes on a quiet residential street. No injuries were reported.

title: Uranium PriceFixing Impact
description: A Congressional subcommittee has been unable to determine what impact an international uranium pricefixing cartel has had on domestic electricity prices. Page 51.

title: Admiral, ExPrisoner, Is Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)President Carter has approved the promotion of Rear Adm. James B. Stockdale, senior United States Navy prisoner held by the North Vietnamese during the Southeast Asia war, to vice admiral, the Pentagon announced today. Admiral Stockdale, 53 years old, will become president of the Naval War College at Newport, R.I. He spent seven and a half years as a prisoner in Hanoi before being released in February 1973.

title: People in Sports
description: I'm starting to move, I'm dancing! an exuberant Billie Jean King said yesterday after working out with the New York Apples in preparation for tonight's openinground World Team Tennis playoff match against the Indiana Loves in Felt Forum.

title: 13,000 Walk Out at G.M. Plant
description: ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 15 (AP)More than 13,000 members of the United Auto Workers walked off the job today at General Motors DelcoRemy plant here in a dispute over local working conditions.

title: Young Urges Haitian Leader to Move on Rights
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 15Andrew Young, pursuing the Carter Administration's campaign for human rights, urged President JeanClaude Duvalier of Haiti today to move his country in the same direction on human rights as other countries in the hemisphere.

title: Con Ed Preparing FuelCell Test Plant
description: The Consolidated Edison Company is preparing to carry out in Manhattan the nation's first test on a practical scale of an advanced, nonpolluting fuel cell for generating electricity in urban neighborhoods.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Overture to Susanna, Handel; Variations on a Theme of Paganini, Lutoslawski; Motet: Flos Florum, Dufay; Classical Symphony, Prokofiev; Hungarian Dances, Brahms.

title: Japan Mourns War Dead and Fetes Spirits of Ancestors
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15These are the days for the dead in Japan.

title: FIREMEN SLOW BLAZE ON CALIFORNIA COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (AP)A 105mile fire line began containing a huge forest fire about eight miles from the Carmel Valley on the central California coast today, but a new chain of smaller blazes flared out of control in the northwestern part of the state.

title: Two Soldiers Killed in Canal Zone
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)Two United States soldiers died as a result of an accident during a mortar firing exercise in the Panama Canal Zone last week, the Army said today. Sgt. 1st Class Charles H. Cole, 40 years old, of Little Rock, Ark., was killed instantly on Aug. 8. Pfc. Charles E. Hampton, 21, of Columbus, Ga., died of his injuries Saturday, the Army said.

title: Ethiopians Accused By Somali President Of Planning Invasion
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 15 (Reuters)Somalia said today that the threeweekold war on its borders had spilled into Somali territory, and President Mohamed Siad Barre warned his people to prepare for an invasion by Ethiopia.

title: Black Elks Honor Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)President Carter was presented the Elijah Lovejoy Award today by a black Elks organization that saluted him as fairminded. We feel you're talking right, said Hobson R. Reynolds, president of the Improved Benevolent Protective Order of Elks of the World, in making the presentation in the Oval Office.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: People and Business
description: Joseph J. Pinola, 52 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Western Bancorporation, Los Angeles, the nation's 10thlargest bank holding company, effective Jan. I. He is now president and chief operating officer of the United California Bank, Western's largest affiliate.

title: KATHERINE MATHER M'LEAN
description: Katherine Mather McLean, a former president of the Women's Board of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, died yesterday of cancer in Coatesville Hospital, Coatesville, Pa. She was 64 years old.

title: Snorkler's Artificial Leg Stolen
description: NEW BRAUNFELS, Tex., Aug. 15 (UPI) An artificial leg belonging to a Houston man was stolen yesterday while the man went snorkling, the police said. Greg Greenway told officers that he had hidden the leg and the rest of his gear in tall grass when he entered the Guadalupe River. When he returned, the leg was gone.

title: Sins of Mankind Kill Christ In New Oberammergau Play
description: OBERAMMERGAU, West Germany, Aug. 15 (UPI)It is mankind's sinsand not the Jewsthat kill Christ in a new Version of the centuriesold Oberammergau passion play that opened Saturday night.

title: Spirited Rally by Glamour Issues Raises Dow 3.03 After Early Drop
description: A spirited rally in glamour issues brought some sunshine into the stock market yesterday and even helped to raise the Dow Jones industrials to higher ground after earlymorning weakness.

title: USE OF BELL EMPLOYEES AS PIMPS IS ALLEGED
description: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 15 (AP)A Dallas lawyer testified today that T. 0. Gravitt, a former executive of Southwestern Bell, told him a few days before he committed suicide that company employees had been used as pimps to secure women for high officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Monmouth
description: By The Associated Press

title: Heinz in Trouble With Britain For Wage Rises Over Guidelines
description: LONDON, Aug. 15The H. J. Heinz Company has come under 57 varieties of pressure to cancel a wage increase granted workers far in excess of the Government's target for avoiding a new wage explosion.

title: Spassky in Lead Over Portisch After Candidate Match's 13th Game
description: GENEVA, Aug. 15 (Reuters)Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union took the lead today in his World Championship Candidate's Match with Lajos Portisch of Hungary with a 40move victory in the 13th game.

title: ENVIRONMENTALIST HAILS DROP IN PORPOISE KILLING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)Environmental groups applaud the United States tuna fleet, which this season reduced accidental killing of porpoises by almost 500 per cent. But the industry is not exactly taking a bow, according to an Environmental Defense Fund lawyer, William Butler.

title: Yonkers Attendance Short of Rooney's Expectations
description: YONKERS, Aug. 15By the end of the third race at Yonkers Raceway tonight, Tim Rooney, the track president, knew that the $100,000 facelift at the track, the darkness at the New Jersey Meadowlands or his old rule of thumb was working.

title: In Memoriam
description: FENSTERSTOCKHorbert. Life Is ?? the same without you. Your Family.

title: CONGRESSIONAL UNIT TAKES BLEAK VIEW OF ECONOMIC GOALS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The Congressional Joint Economic Committee published a rather bleak assessment of the nation's economic prospects today, asserting that President Carter's longer range goals probably cannot be met.

title: WASHINGTON MANUSCRIPTS IN NEWBURGH ARE STOLEN
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP)A cache of irreplaceable historical documents, including some bearing George Washington's signature, is missing and presumed stolen from his Revolutionary War headquarters here, the site curator says.

title: Haiti at a Glance
description: HISTORYThe aboriginal Arawak Indians were annihilated under Spanish rule and the French, who gained possession in 1697, used African slaves to grow sugar and coffee, and make St. Domingue, as Haiti was then called, one of the most prosperous colonies in the New World. A slave rebellion that began in 1791 ultimately led to independence and the country's aborignal name Haiti was restored. Following a period of prolonged civil strife and political violence from 1910 to 1915, the country was occupied by United States forces. The occupation ended in 1934, although United States fiscal control was maintained until 1947, Francois Duvalier, who was elected President in 1957, used voodoo as an instrument of control over the masses and ruled with the aid of a secret police known as the tonton macoutes. On his death in 1971, he was succeeded by his son JeanClaude.

title: Nation's Output of Steel Rose 1.5% in Week Ended Aug. 13
description: Steel production rose 1.5 percent to 2.33 million tons in the week ended Aug. 13, compared with the preceding week's 2.3 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Scientology Church Asks $1 Million In Second Suit Against the F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Church of Scientology filed today a $1 million damage suit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation and asked that it be protected against any more search and seizures by the agency.

title: Courts Harsher on Looting Suspects, Survey Finds
description: The newest statistics on those arrested during the blackout last month show that judges and prosecutorswho were under pressure to handle their cases strictlydid, in fact, treat suspects more severely than they treat those seized normally for similar crimes.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Telephone installations are exempt from the state's 5 percent sales tax, a state appeals court ruled.

title: N.B.A. Voids Robinson's Jazz Pact
description: Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association disapproved yesterday the contract signed earlier this month by Len Robinson with the New Orleans Jazz.

title: Another Shooting Laid to Suspect In the Sam Case
description: David R. Berkowitz, the man the police have identified as the 44caliber killer, said after his arrest that he was also responsible for the wounding of an elderly Yonkers woman with a 45caliber rifle found in his apartment, according to court documents presented to the Brooklyn grand jury.

title: Jersey Man Killed in Crash
description: CHESTERFIELD TOWNSHIP, N. J., Aug. 15 (AP)  A Burlington County motorist was killed yesterday when his car crashed broadside into another automobile on Sykesville Road here, the police said. The dead man was Stanley Dobrowolsky Jr., 41 years old, of Mount Laurel. The driver of the other car, John Mazzeo, 22, of Hamilton Township in Mercer County, and his two passengers were treated for minor injuries, according to the police.

title: TWO ARRESTED IN SLAYING OF MANHATTAN SHOPKEEPER
description: A 32yearold shopkeeper was shot to death during an attempted holdup of his Lower East Side clothing store last night, according to the police, who said that a good description provided by a witness led to the arrest of two suspects within minutes of the 7:30 P.M. shooting.

title: Visit to WarTorn South Lebanon: Ghost Town and Roving Guerrillas
description: NABATIYE, Lebanon, Aug. 15By coincidence of the lunar calendar, today was both the beginning of the Moslem fast of Ramadan and the celebration of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary. But, here in southern Lebanon, this fragile symbol of Islamic and Christian sanctity did not silence the guns.

title: Convention Center an Issue in Campaign for Mayor, With 2 Democrats Opposed to It and 5 Supporting It
description: The proposed New York City convention center would probably run in the red, Herman Badillo said yesterday. He opposed any big commitment of municipal money to build it.

title: Dominican Boxer Killed
description: SANTODOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 15 (Reuters)The Dominican Republic's national welterweight boxing champion, Fausto Rodrigucz, was killed here with his wife and 4yearold son when his car collided with a bus last night, the police said today.

title: ArmoredCar Companies Sued
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)An antitrust suit charging two armored car companies with price rigging was filed today.by the State Attorney General, Francis X. Bellotti. The suit, against Brinks Inc., and the Wells Fargo Armored Car Service Corporation, was filed in United States District Court in New York where the companies have headquarters.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A,M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 1691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Busy Candidates for Mayor Map Their Battle Strategy in Off Hours
description: After a hard day at the office and an evening making campaign speeches, Mayor Beame often comes home to Gracie Mansion to find a living room full of visitors munching his potato chips, sipping diet sodaand chewing over politics.

title: Misses Austin, Jordan in Net Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15  ThirdSeeded Tracy Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif., and Kathy Jordan, seeded 14th, from King of Prussia, Pa., each showed adept volley work in gaining the final of the United States girls 18andunder tennis championship today. The tourney is being played on the grass courts of the Philadelohia Cricket Club.

title: At the Cosmos Game, 77,691 Stars
description: The loudest cheer was not for Franz Beckenbauer, Pele or Giorgio Chinaglia in the Cosmos 83 playoff triumph at Giants Stadium on Sunday night. It was not for former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, one of those present. The loudest noise was for all the noisemakers.

title: Aruba Said to Be Without Tourists As Strike on Island Continues
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Caribbean island of Aruba was reported today to be without one of the main staples of its economytouristsbecause of a general strike by workers favoring independence from the Netherlands Antilles.

title: C.I.A.   DATA DESCRIBE SIXYEAR DRUG TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The Central Intelligence Agency sponsored a sixyear search for a knockout drug during which scientists were supposed to analyze spinal and other vital fluids from comatose and delirious patients hospitalized with terminal cancer, liver failure, uremia and severe infections, newly declassified records show.

title: Kennedy Calls for Diplomatic Split With Taiwan and Ties With China
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for the ending of diplomatic relations with Taiwan to pave the way for fullscale ties with China.

title: TESTS ON PESTICIDES CHALLENGED BY EPA.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Environmental Protection Agency reported today that it had found significant deficiencies in tests by a major laboratory that raised questions whether supposedly safe pesticides might cause cancer, birth defects, nerve damage or other problems.

title: 2,000 HIRED BY NEW YORK FOR BLACKOUT CLEANUP
description: New York City said yesterday that it had hired 2,000 workers to clean up debris from looting during last month's blackout

title: Working for Welfare
description: That people should have to work to receive welfare is hardly a new idea. It arose early in the Kennedy years. The city manager Of Newburgh, N. Y. called for all ablebodied welfare recipients to work 40 hours a week, even if it meant raking leaves, and all welfare would be cut off after three months. The Administration in Washington, among others, denounced the proposal as heartless, and it was struck down by the courts.

title: Netherlands Concern Said to Bid $160 Million for MillerWohl Chain
description: C. & A. Brenninckmeyer, the large Netherlandsbased holding company, which in 1962 bought the Ohrbach's stores, has reportedly made a bid of $160 million to purchase the MillerWohl Company, a chain of 142 women's apparel shops, mainly in the Middle West and South..

title: Another Shooting Laid to Suspect In the  Sam Case
description: David R. Berkowitz, the man the police have identified as the .44caliber i killer, said after his arrest that he was also responsible for the wounding of an elderly Yonkers woman with a .45caliber rifle found in his apartment, according to court documents presented to the Brooklyn grand jury.

title: Advertising
description: When an adman talks to other admen, the presentation usually has to e informative or provocative to attract attention. O. Milton Gossett, president of Compton Advertising Inc., achieved both qualities in a speech last night.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: EVeryzer, Oglivie, Milbourn?, Thompson. DPSeattle 3, Detroit 1. LOBSeattle II, Detroit 5. 2BMMay, B?ez. HRMMay (10), Oglivie (15), Le???e (Q????( . SBCo???ns, Baez S? Thempson, MMay, Staub

title: Warranty Expanded By General Motors And Also Simplified
description: DETROIT, Aug. 15  The General Motors Corporation, in an effort to reduce the number of unhappy car buyers, said today its 1978 model cars and light trucks would be covered by a new, expanded and simplified warranty.

title: Rights Organization Accuses Nicaragua Regime of Widespread Abuses
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15Amnesty International said today that there had been widespread abduction, torture and killing or peasants by the National Guard in Nicaragua last year, although church and diplomatic sources there said the human rights situation had improved in recent months.

title: $5,000 BIG BOARD FINE LEVIED ON HORNBLOWER
description: The New York Stock Exchange fined Hornblower Weeks Noyes & Trask Inc. $5,000 yesterday for alleged shorttendering violations during the tender offer for Marcor Inc. by the Mobil Oil Corporation in August 1974.

title: Reporter Freed by African Empire
description: LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP)An Associated Press correspondent who was held in prison for a month in the Central African Empire arrived here late today after his release.

title: Awards Dinners to Honor A Myriad of Golf Standouts
description: It is time for a pause at the 19th hole.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES HIGHEST SINCE 1975
description: The Federal Reserve continued yesterday to encourage shortterm interest rates to rise, and the Treasury incurred the highest rates since late 1975 as it sold $5.7 billion of bills at its weekly auction.

title: Electrical Storm Kills Motorist, Blacks Out Jersey Shore Area
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 15 (UPI) An electrical storm yesterday, killed a motorist and knocked out power In several shore communities.

title: BOND ACCUSES CARTER OF IGNORING BLACKS
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 15State Senator Julian Bond of Georgia, one of the nation's leading black spokesmen, assailed President Carter today, saying that he had reneged on campaign promises and ignored the powerless and the poor, particularly blacks, whose votes were crucial to his election.

title: SIX AIRLINES AGREE TO ROUNDTRIP FARE OF $256 FOR LONDON
description: The six scheduled airlines flying between New York and London agreed yesterday to reduce the price of the lowest available offseason roundtrip fare to $256, or $94 less than the lowest at present. The new restricted rate would take effect Sept. 15.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 16, 1977

title: SaccoVanzetti Vote Reversed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate reversed itself today on a resolution to condemn the Governor for his proclamation setting a SaccoVanzetti memorial day. The resolution was tabled, 23 to 12, putting it in a legislative limbo where it is likely to remain. The resolution would have censured Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for declaring Aug. 23 a day of memorial for Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, whose execution in 1927 on charges of murdering two men in 1920 remains a controversial issue.

title: William R. Hull Jr. of Missouri; Democrat Served 7 Terms in House
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 (UPI)William R. Hull Jr., who represnted Missouri's Sixth Congressional District for 18 years, died today. He was 71 years old.

title: Wood, Field &Stream: City Aid for Catskill Trout
description: Blazing heat and sparse rainfall have reduced some Catskill Mountain trout streams to little more than warm trickles, but all is not gloom among those who care for these waters.

title: Proxmire Seeks Carter Approval Of Oil Pipeline Through Canada
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, calling the transAlaska oil pipeline a pipeline to nowhere, today urged President Carter to approve an overland route through Canada to bring Alaskan natural gas to the Middle West.

title: PORT UNIT OFFICER IS SHOT BY AN OFFDUTY POLICEMAN
description: An offduty policeman from the Englewood, N.J., force shot and slightly wounded a Port of Authority of New York and New Jersey police officer outside St. Clare's Hospital in midtown Manhattan Sunday night, the police said.

title: Jaworski Promises Thoroughness As He Takes Over Inquiry on Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)Leon Jaworski, warning against jumping to conclusions, took charge today of the House investigation into alleged South Korean influencebuying in Congress.

title: The U.N. Today
Mets Snap 6Game Streak; Swan, Apodaca Halt Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15As any gambler can tell you, when it comes to losing streaks, you either go broke or finally win one. Against the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, the Mets, losers of six games in a row, went for broke by using a pitcher who had also lost six games in a row to the Cards.

title: 75% of Businesses Damaged During Blackout Are Reopening as New Yorkers Provide Aid
description: First there was the blackout looting that completely wiped out the store for a loss estimated at $75,000. Then there was restocking and a new start two weeks ago, only to have a flood from vandalized water pipes above the store last Wednesday cause an additional loss of $35,000.

title: About New york
description: Although we prostrate ourselves before it and pray that it bathes us in its benevolence, we more often than not fail to recognize that New York weather is an absolute despot. The New Yorker. who would rather cover his head with a newspaper than with raingear, would rather leap across a puddle than wear rubbers, regards weather as a fringe benefit or nuisance, but not as a lease on life, as farmers and people of the land do.

title: Beef Producers Sue Stores
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Aug. 15 (UPI)More than 150 beef producers filed suit today against the nation's largest supermarket chains, alleging conspiracy to set the price of beef at artificial levels. The suit, filed in United States District Court, listed more than 150 Texas and New Mexico beef producers. It accuses the major food chains of manipulating prices and seeks a jury trial. Damages, if any, will be determined by the court.

title: 19 Persons and $300,000 Seized In Narcotics Raids in Rhode Island
description: NORTH KINGSTOWN, R. I., Aug. 15 (UPI)State and local policemen today were counting cash and bales of marijuana seized in drug raids believed linked to last week's mysterious appearance of a Colombian fishing boat in Narragansett Bay.

title: DR. TALMAN W. VAN ARSDALE JR.
description: Dr. Talman W. Van Arsdale Jr., the former president and chancellor of Bradley University in Peoria, Ill., died Sunday night of a heart attack in Peoria. He was61 years old.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 15The president of Lawn King Inc., Joseph Sandler, was sentenced today to six months in jail and fined $43,120, the equivalent of his annual salary, for criminal violation of New Jersey's antitrust laws. It was the first conviction of its kind in the state.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Florida Paper Shifting Schedule
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 15 (UPI)The Gainesville Sun, an afternoon newspaper since 1935, announced today that it would convert to morning publication on Labor Day. W. G. Ebersole, publisher of the newspaper owned by The New York Times Company, said that the decision to switch to the morning field followed extensive research of production and delivery methods and a readership survey.

title: Listing of New Books
description: Americans Remember: The Homefront, by Roy Hoppes (Hawthorn, $12.95). Americans reflect on life during World War II.

title: Msgr. Healy to Head State Mediation  Panel
description: ALBANY, Aug. 15 (UPI)Governor Carey has designated Msgr. James Healy of Buffalo as chairman of the State Mediation Board, it was announced today.

title: Csonka Ready; Giants Sign J. J. Jennings
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 15The Giants, who had been down to zero fullbacks, as Coach John McVay said yesterday, added two todayJ. J. Jennings and Larry Csonka.

title: 4 GANDHI AIDES HELD ON CHARGES OF GRAFT
description: NEW DELHI,Aug. 13The Government, in its most decisive move so far against former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, today arrested on corruption charges four men who had been key figures in her administration.

title: Tony Kornheiser
description: Four coffees to go was the order.

title: Car Sales at Record Pace; A.M.C.'s Decline to a Low
description: DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP)The pace of domestic newcar sales in early August matched the industry's record of 1976, although the American Motors Corporation today reported its lowest sales for a 10day period in at least a decade.

title: Hugo Perls, Art Dealer; Founded Gallery in Berlin And Wrote Books on Plato
description: Hugo Perls, an art dealer who was well known in New York and abroad, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He lived at 128 Central Park South. He was 91 years old. He retired several years ago.

title: Closeness in the First Minutes of Life May Have a Lasting Effect
description: CLEVELANDMost of the time at the Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital here, the doctors talk about children and their mothers. Sometimes, they talk about goats.

title: Employers Gone, Workers Get Antique Cars
description: MULHOUSE, France, Aug. 10Fritz and Hans Schlumpf arrived in this Alsatian town on the eve of World War II, built a textile factory that prospered under the German Occupation and emerged in the postwar era as the largest woolen textile producers in Alsace.

title: Pennsylvania House Weighing Passage of Budget To End 7Week Crisis Halting Welfare Payments
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 15The House of Representatives worked late today as it edged toward reluctant passage of state budget that would end Pennyslvania's funding crisis.

title: WELDER WHO WAS GIVEN HEART IN TRANSPLANT DIES
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 15 (AP)Donald Pello, a 51yearold retired welder from Philadelphia who received a new heart in transplant surgery here July 24, died today at the Medical College of Virginia Hospital.

title: 2 LOBBYISTS TERMED MENTORS OF KOREAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Park Tong Sun, who was allegedly the South Korean Government's principal agent in its covert lobby here had as his mentors two of the ablest lobbyists in Washington, Anna C. Chennault and Thomas G. Corcoran, according to associates of Mr. Park.

title: BILLY GRAHAM VISIT TO HUNGARY IS SET
description: Billy Graham, the evangelist, has accepted an invitation to visit Hungary from Sept. 3 to 10 for religious meetings. He is the first Western religious leader invited by Hungary since World War II.

title: Commander Cody Flies Again, With New Band at Bottom Line
description: Commander Cody and the Lost Planet Airmen formed one of the great bar bands and cult bands of recent years. They had a passel of colorful, vibrant personalities, and they could knock out a set of boogiewoogie, rhythmandblues, rockabilly and novelty numbers that would have a crowd cheering deliriously. But the same hippie fervor that informed their performances undermined their discipline, and they were never able to make successful records

title: 4 GANDHI AIDES HELD ON CHARGES OF GRAFT
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15The Government, in its most decisive move so far against former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, today arrested on corruption charges four men who had been key figures in her administration.

title: Pizzeria Owner Slain in Shop As His Wife and Son, 13, Look On
description: As his wife and 13yearold son looked on in horror, Frank Scotti, the 38yearold operator of a pizzeria in the South Bronx, was shot to death with his own gun by one of two men who attempted to rob his store shortly after midnight, the police reported.

title: Books of The Times
description: Perhaps the greatest compliment we can pay a writer is to say that no one before him ever thought of looking at the world in precisely the way he does. The world and ways of looking at it have been pretty well picked over by now, yet I feel that, in Eccentric Spaces, Robert Harbison has opened my eyes and mind to more original speculation than I would have thought possible.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENJane Hotiheimer, beloved wife or the late Richard James Allen. Devoted mother of Susan Stern and Nancy Allen. Dear grandmother of Arthur IV and Jeffrey Allen Stern., Cherished daughter of Marie S. Hoffhelmer. Loving sister of Arthur Hoffhelmer Jr. Friends may call at Frank E. Lampbell, Madlson Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday from 79. interment private. Please omit flowers.

title: Methane Seepage on L.I. and Elsewhere Forces Out Some Families
description: HOLTSVILLE, L.I.Cruz Albert and Esperanza Negron lived for many years in a Brooklyn apartment, working hard and saving their money. On June 4, 1976, they moved into their first house, a fourbedroom, cedarshingled structure large enough for them, their daughter and soninlaw and their two grandchildren.

title: Arabs on West Bank Fear Services Are Step Toward Israeli Annexation
description: JERUSALEM. Aug. 15Leading Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank of the Jordan expressed fears today that Israel was moving to annex the area and wipe out any chance that the drive for ArabIsraeli negotiations could lead to peace.

title: Effect of Uranium Cartel on Electricity Eludes Inquiry
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 15A Congressional subcommittee investigating an international uranium cartel, which says it has disbanded, failed today in its efforts to determine what impact the pricefixing plan has had upon domestic electricity prices.

title: QUALIFIED SUPPORT OF PANAMA TREATIES GIVEN BY KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  President Carter stepped up his drive to muster bipartisan support for two new Panama Canal treaties today by obtaining a qualified endorsement of the pacts from former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and by making an appeal by telephone to former President Gerald R. Ford.

title: Severe Storms Flood Deserts in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (AP)Vestiges of Hurricane Doreen lashed the southern California deserts with rain and 60mileanhour winds today, flooding four highways and washing away a large section of Interstate 15, the major artery linking Los Angeles and Las Vegas.

title: Market Place
description: Some investors who purchased highyielding electric utility bonds and preferred shares over the last eight years will soon lose their high returns as utilities redeem the issues to cut interest and dividend costs.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Chemetron Corporation amended its complaint against the Crane Company in Federal Court in Chicago charging Crane with Federal securities laws violations in addition to the antitrust violations alleged earlier this month after Crane announced a proposed tender offer of $40 a share for Chemetron common shares.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listings. FIRST$8,000, cl., 2YD, 6f.

title: Even Swap: Nuns Get a 77 Car for a 29
description: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP, Aug. 15After nearly 50 years of service to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, Brigid has retired to a museum in Michigan.

title: Welcome Demise in Chile
description: President Carter's human rights campaign and the hints of American economic pressure to back it up appear to be getting some results in Chile, one of the most repressive countries in Latin America. Last month, the head of Chile's ruling junta, President Augusto Pinochet, outlined a program for a slow, not to say glacial, end to the present system of military rule. Last weekend, while Assistant Secretary of State Todman was in Santiago, the Chilean Government announced the dissolution of the National Intelligence Directorate (DINA), the powerful secret police agency, responsible for killing and torturing political opponents of the Pinochet regime. It is to be replaced by an agency which will apparently have no powers of arrest.

title: Sniper, 15, Wounds Boy and Man After an Argument With a Girl
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 15 (UN)A teenage newspaper boy was critically wounded today by a young sniper who stationed himself on the roof of an abandoned building. The sniper then shot a man who tried to aid the boy, the police said.

title: Commuter Van Starts With City in Pursuit
description: Six passengers, who said they were happy to avoid hot subways and high taxi fares, rode in an airconditioned 14passenger van from their Upper East Side homes to midtown Manhattan in a newly inaugurated $1.50aride commuter service. But the New York City Bureau of Franchises said it had not authorized the service and would try to stop it today.

title: HomeGrown Sportswear
description: American fashion designers have had a reason to feel slighted. For a decade or so, since the mercurial rise of French readytowear, stores through out this country have fought for the privilege of being the first to present European clothes. They have given their Frenchand more recently, Italianimports key positions in their stores. They have feted the designers and given elaborate shows to present their wares.

title: Doctor's Taped Voice Found to Aid Patient
description: WALNUT CREEK Calif., Aug. 15 (AP)Patients at a hospital here who listen to the taped voice of a comforting doctor the night before an operation require less medication and recover more quickly, officials report.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UPI)A 27yearold Chicago man, convicted Saturday of killing two pharmacists, tonight became the first person sentenced to die in the electric chair under a new capital punishment law in Illinois.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Babcock & Wilcox Board Endorses McDermott Bid
description: Yielding to a bid of $55 a share, the directors of Babcock & Wilcox have recommended to its shareholders that they accept the offer of J. Ray McDermott & Company of New Orleans to buy virtual control of B. & W.

title: Judge Rules Youth Must Be Tried As Adult in Setting of Jail Fire
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., Aug. 15 (UPI)Andrew Zinmer, 16 years old, an emotionally disturbed Wisconsin runaway accused of setting a jail fire that killed 42 persons, must be tried as an adult on two counts of arson, a judge ruled today.

title: U.S. Official Has Talks in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15Terence A. Todman, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, said today that everyone he talked with during a twoday official visit to Argentina said violations of human rights have decreased.

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS CHARGES AGAINST ALABAMA SHERIFF
description: MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 15 (AP)A Federal judge said today that he had serious questions about Federal conspiracy charges against Sheriff Tom Purvis and eight of his officers in the alleged ambush slaying of an inmate escaping from the Mobile County Jail.

description: Tuesday, August 16, 1977

title: Conservatives Map Drive Against the Canal Treaty
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15Conservatives will open a campaign against approval of the new Panama Canal Treaty next Sunday with newspaper advertisements aimed at Southern Democratic Senators and a television appearance by the current leader of their fight, Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 15, 1977

title: A Coalition For the City
description: In 1977, New York is a city predominantly made up of young blacks, young Hispanics and elderly whitesand most of them are poor, although the Federal census does not reflect it. Twentyfive percent of the city's population is black (including illegal aliens from Haiti), with a median age of 22

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE FOR ALL A family evening of oldfashioned, oompah hand musiccircus tunes, marches and the works of Rossini, Sousa and otherswraps up the Washington Square Music Festival tonight at 8, with Henry Schuman conducting. In case of rain, the concert shifts to the Washington Square Methodist Church 133 West Fourth Street.

title: C.I.A. Chief Puts U.S. Well Ahead Of Soviet in Military Technology
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15] (UPI)Adm. Stansfield Turner, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has told Congress that the United States is well ahead of the Soviet Union in military technology while China is 15 to 20 years behind the Russians.

title: Phone Call Gave Police Key Clue To Berkowitz
description: YONKERS, Aug. 15A chance telephone encounter last Tuesday between a New York City detective and a police dispatcher here who is the daughter of Sam Carrbelieved to be the Sam in Son of Samappears to have played the pivotal role in the search that led to the arrest the following day of David R. Berkowitz as the socalled 44caliber killer.

title: Players in Philadelphia Compete With Amateurs Antics
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15  As the Philadelphia Company performs classical theater in the southeast corner of the City Hall courtyard these steamy summer nights, the play's the thing, but not the whole thing.

title: Berkowitz Lawyer Seeking to Pull Out of the Case After Reported Attempt to Sell Tapes of His Client
description: A Brooklyn lawyer who is said to have tried to sell the taped memoirs of David R. Berkowitz, the accused .44caliber killer, to two newspapers asked a Criminal Court judge yesterday to relieve him as Mr. Berkowitz's attorney. But the judge told him to take his request to State Supreme Court, where the murder case is now being heard.

title: N.L.R.B. Revises Its Procedures To Speed Up Bargaining Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)A new step designed to speed procedures in collective bargaining elections was announced today by the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Oppenheimer, Apartheid Foe, Faces Snag
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 15Relations between the South African Government and the country's largest business enterprise, Harry F. Oppenheimer's Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, often uneasy in recent years, have been strained anew by the Government's controversial decision to block a $345 million deal under which Anglo American would have taken control of the state  owned manganese producer, South African Manganese Amcor Ltd.

title: Castro Plays Charming Host on Guided Tour for Yankees
description: HAVANAIt looked like a scene from Jaws. Hundreds of bathers, mostly skinny young kids, broke from the surf at Santa Maria Beach in a frenzy of churning legs and shrieks, clawing their way out of the water to reach the hot sand and the tall bearded figure in military fatigues and cap standing there with another man.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A man and a woman pleaded not guity to seconddegree murder charges in the shooting deaths of a faith healer and his daughter as they sat in a parked car in Wyandanch, L.I., last Friday night.

title: TOWN IS TAKING LAND BUT NOT ITS GREENERY
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, Aug. 15For five years, Don Roehrs, a prizewinning landscape architect, has been fighting the Bergen County government and the Town Council over the fate of greenery in his front yard, a hedgerow, laurel, rhododendron bushes and three pines that date to near the turn of the century.

description: By The Associated Press

title: ELVIS PRESLEY DIES; ROCK SINGER WAS 42; Heart Failure Is Cited by CoronerAcclaim Followed Early Scorn
description: Elvis Presley, the first and greatest American rockandroll star, died yesterday at the age of 42. Mr. Presley, whose throaty baritone and blatant sexuality redefined popular music, was found unconscious in the bedroom of his home, called Graceland, in Memphis yesterday at 2:30 P.M.

title: Carey Kills Bill On Assailants Of the Elderly
description: ALBANY, Aug. 16Governor Carey today announced his veto of a bill that would have increased penalties for crimes against the elderly or disabled. He asserted that its provisions were inconsistent with the state's criminal laws and that it would not be effective in achieving its stated goals.

description: What will United Technologies do now that J. Ray McDermott's plan to offer $55 a share for an additional 35 percent of the shares of the Babock & Wilcox Company has Babcock's approval?.

title: Lawsuit Against California Doctor Charges Fraud in Use of Laetrile
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16A woman whose husband died of lung cancer after 18 months of treatment with laetrile has filed a $2.5 million suit against the doctor who administered the drug.

title: Finding Roots Through Reunion
description: BRUNSWICK, GA.

title: BREZHNEV DEPICTS CARTER'S OVERTURE AS A POSITIVE MOVE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16Leonid I. Brezhnev indicated today that he welcomed Presi'ent Carter's latest efforts to mend SovietAmerican relations and pledged that the Soviet Union would respond to any practical measures to resolve the current differences.

title: Ronan Defends T rips at Assembly Committee Hearing
description: Dr. William J. Rohan defended yesterday the expensepaid overseas trips he took with his wife when he was chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and he told a legislative inquiry that such business travel by commissioners and their spouses should be enconraged.

description: CUMBERLAND, Me., Aug. 16Dr. Herman C. Petterson of Chebeague Island, a specialist in pediatric medicine, died in his home yesterday. He was 85 years rdri

title: Personal Health
description: AT A TIME when better birth control, legal abortion, rising costs and population consciousness have prompted and enabled millions of American couples to precisely control their family size, a growing proportion of couples are finding themselves faced with the opposite problemhow to have the children they want.

description: On the ground that if Mario M. Cuomo was elected Mayor he would have no obligations to the old political structure, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, who is virtually a oneman political establishment, endorsed Mr. Cuomo yesterday

title: Books of TheTimes
description: DO WE REALLY need another treatise on all the dreadful probleths of India, asks the weary student of that vast and troubled land; must we be subjected to yet another round of the familiarly hopeless sighs? The surprising answer, in the case of V. S. Naipaul's latest tour de force, is yes, indeed we do, for this is a brilliant book.

title: $3 Johnny D. Rallies for Turf Score
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 16 (AP) Dana '. Bray Jr.s Johnny D., ridden by Angel Cordero, rallied in the final yards to take the $25,000 Great Saratoga Chamber of Commerce Handicap today at Saratoga.

title: A Good Way to Build a Pipeline
description: When negotiators from Canada and the United States meet shortly to seek agreement on a natural gas pipeline, they will be spared the slipshod planning that preceded construction of the pipeline for Alaskan oil. The reason, surprisingly, is the National Environmental Policy Act, a law often portrayed as the natural enemy of vast engineering projects.

title: 2 Cosmos in the Doghouse; Others in Florida Tonight
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 16Coach Eddie Firmani of the Cosmos was seething at New York's La Guardia Airport shortly before 9 this morning, and his anger was directed at the two Yugoslav players the Cosmos purchased earlier in the year for close to $250,000.

title: Maine Wins Its Court Challenge; U.S. Must Review Fishing Quotas
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 16 (UFI)Maine has won the first challenge to the Federal Government's fisheries management policy under the new 200mile limit, forcing the Secretary of Commerce to review fishing quotas for foreign fleets.

title: METAL USED IN DEODORANT BANNED BY DRUG AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UFI)Warning that millions of consumers could be exposed to an unnecessary risk, the Food and Drug Administration issued a final order today banning the use of zirconium in aerosol deodorant sprays.

description: With Sandy Mayer holding off the flamboyant Vitas Gerulaitis in a set decided by tiebreaker and Virginia Wade trouncing Sue Barker, the New Yojk Apples defeated the Indiana Loves last night in Felt Forum, 3321.The contest opened a twoofthree match series as the Apples begin their drive toward a second consecutive World Team Tennis chamnionship.

title: Shapp and Protesters Agree: The Budget Is Needed
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.,Aug. 16Under the dollargreen dome of the State Capitol here today virtually everyone, including Milton J. Shapp, the Democratic Governor, and Clara Harris, a grandmother and welfare recipient from Philadelphia, was talking about money.

Martinez, a 30yearold lawyer with the office of the State Attorney General, was sworn in today as director of the Division of Gaming Enforcement, major post in New Jersey's program to keep organized crime out of Atlantic City's newly legalized casino gambling industry.

description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 16It is five days and counting here in Baltimore's new Federal Courthouse, a structure of vaguely menacing poured concrete that since last Wednesday has housed this city's newest industrythe Mandel jury vigil.

Carter to Prime Minister Menahem Begin in Jerusalem that was believed to be devoted to Israeli actions in the occupied. areas. title: Sitting During Flag Pledge Upheld
description: NEWARK, Aug. 16A state law requiring all public school students in New Jersey to at least stand at attention during the pledge of allegiance to the American flag was overturned as unconstitutional today in Federal District. Court.

title: Yugoslav Jeans With U.S. Flags Come In for Ideological Cuffing
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 16Komunist, the official organ of the Yugoslav Communist Party, has denounced state enterprises in this country for following the fashion of putting likenesses of the American flag on locally made blue jeans.

title: Cathleen Nesbitt: God Be Praised,
description: BOOKJACKET COPY so often sounds as if it had been written by the author's mother. A remarkable, sensitive, enduring woman, the blurb reports on the cover of Cathleen Nesbitt's new autobiography, A Little Love & Good Company. It is not rote hyperbole.

title: Blast in Hackensack Is Laid to Arsonists
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 16The police said today they believed that arsonists yesterday touched off an explosion and fire that demolished a twostory home at 29 Poplar Avenue, tore away half a threestory home net door and heavily damaged a third house.

title: Best Buys
description: ALTHOUGH THE COST of feeding n. family of four in New York City declined last week by only one tenth of one percent, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday that food prices have been declining since the second week in July.

title: Panama: What's The Rush?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The Administration is anxious for early ratification of the Panama treaty, but Democratic leaders in the Senate are recommending that the formal debate be postponed until next January or February.

title: Israeli Pound Devalued
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  The Israeli pound has devalued tonight by nearly 2 percent against the United States dollar. It was the second devaluation this month. The Finance Ministry said the Israeli currency would be devalued from 1.17 pounds to the dollar to 10.37, a devaluation of 1.8 percent.

description: If you believe what happened in Yankee Stadium last night, you would believe almost anything, but here goes: The Yankees scored tour in the eighth inning to grab a 94 lead, blew it in the top of the ninth when the Chicago White Sox scored six times, then won it by 1110 in the bottom of the ninth on a home run by Chris Chambliss.

title: ELVIS PRESLEY DIES; ROCK SINGER MS 42
description: Elvis Presley, the first and greatest American rockandroll star, has died at the age of 42. Mr. Presley,, whose,throaty baritone and blatant sexuality redefined popular music, was found unconscious in the bedroom of his home, called Graceland, in Memphis yesterday at 2:30 P.M.

title: Japanese Official and Publisher Arrested in Resins Secrets Case
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16 (UPI)An official of Japan's Fair Trade Commission and publisher were arrested today on charges of disclosing corporate secrets on epoxy resins.

title: The Past And Future
description: Over the past several years New York City has passed through a difficult era of retrenchment and economic crisis to a new period of physical redevelopment and municipal reform.

title: Changes That Are Spurring Labor Union Merger Talks
description: When the old American Federation of Labor and Congress of I::dustrial Organizations merged in 1955, expectations were strong that their example would swiftly be followed by dozens of overlapping international unions that

title: Vance to Seek Formula for Peking Ties and Safeguards for Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance during his trip to China next week would explore with Peking's leaders the possibility of finding a formula that would allow the United States to establish formal relations with China while being assured that Taiwan would not have to fear an armed attack from the mainland.

title: BERKOWITZ'S LAWYERS GET NOTICE ON MONEY EARNED
description: New York State's Crime Victims Compensation Board yesterday notified lawyers for David R. Berkowitz that any moneys owing him or his representatives as a result of crimes he is accused of committing must go to his victims he is convicted in the socalled 44caliber shootinogs.

title: 20 DelcoRemy Plants in Indiana Shut by Strike of Auto Workers
description: ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 16 (UPI)Twenty factories ceased production yesterday and remained closed today in strike by United Auto Workers Local 662 acainst DelcoRemy.

title: Gold Delivery Set for New York
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (Reuters}The International Monetary Fund said today that gold to be sold at its Sept. auction would be delivered in New York. This is a return to its usual procedure after delivering gold sold at the last aucton in London.

title: 11YearOld Charged With Murder
description: PAYETTE, Idaho, Aug. 16 (AP)An 11yearold boy has been charged with one count each of firstdegree murder, firstdegree arson and seconddegree arson in connection with two recent major fires in Payette, the authorities say. The boy, whose name was not released because of his age, was arraigned yesterday before lay Magistrate Wiliam Jordan. The boy will be tried as a juvenile, the authorities said.

title: F.T.C. CRACKDOWN IS URGED ON THE FUNERAL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)  A Federal Trade Commission hearing officer recommended today that the agency go ahead with a crackdown on the $2 billion funeral industry to protect bereaved consumers from a variety of abuses.

title: People in Sports
description: The Milwaukee Bucks yesterday sold their negotiating rights to Bob Dandridge, their threetime National Basketball Association allstar, to the Washington Bullets for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Open Interest
description: Tues., Aug. 16, 1977

title: Letters
description: Schizophrerfia and the Family

title: Deaths
description: ALLENJane Hoffheimer, beloved wife of the late Richard James Allen. Devoted mother of Susan Stern and Nancy Allen. Dear grandmother of Arthur IV and Jeffrey Allen Stern. Cherished daughter of Marie S. Hoffheimer. Loving sister of Arthur Hoffhelmer Jr. Friends may call at Frank, E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday from 79. Interment private. Please omit flowers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BLEECKER BONUS Remember that lovely Indianmade moviesby Satyajit Ray titled The Music Room. There's now a real one, called the EastWest Music Room, for extended entertainment at the restaurant A Taste of India down in Greenwich Village.

description: Culling The Chicago Cuisine

title: Greek Bank Robbery Foiled by Civic Spirit
description: THEBES, Greece (AP)A bank robbery in this central Greek town ended for a pair of holdup men when one accidentally shot his partner to death and was himself captured by an angry crowd.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Monday incorrectly reported the number of deaths in Los Angeles this year resulting from policeinvolved shootings. The police department said the correct number was 26.

title: You May Beg, Borrow or Rent: It's Dacha Time Again in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16  The official press may be busy orchestrating a public debate over the new constitution, but in these sultry August days many Russians seem far more preoccupied with their summer dachas.

title: Citibank Trying to Acquire Idaho Visa Card Business
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 16Recent attempts by Citibank of New York to acquire new Visa chargecard customers in this Rocky Mountain state have raised eyebrows of local bankers and sent attorneys scurrying for the law books.

title: Courageous Beats Enterprise Twice in Final Trials
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16The America's Cup yachting competition today presented a tripleheader, three contests, from which Ted Turner emerged as one hero and Pelle Petterson and his gallant Swedes as 11 more. Also there was one large argument.

title: RAINS FALL ON COAST BUT NOT IN FIRE AREA
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (AP)Rains from a waning Mexican hurricanedrenched portions of California's southern half today, submerging crop lands. stranding thousands of motorists and endangering _ Santa Barbara's ,firescorched canyons with mud slides.

title: Reed's Coaching Debut For Knicks Set Oct. 18
description: Willis Reed, a former AllStar center, will make his National Basketball Association coaching debut with the New York Knicks on the first night of the 197778 campaign, according to the N.B.A. schedule released yesterday.

title: Victim's Parents Tell Yonkers They Will Sue
description: The parents of Stacy Moskowitz, the last victim of the Son of Sam killer, plans to sue the city of Yonkers for $10 million, charging that its Police Department failed to follow up complaints against David R. Berkowitz, accused of being the killer.

title: Mercantile Exchange Plans Oil Contracts
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange, which provides markets for potato and platinum futures among other commodities, announced yesterday that it planned to trade petroleum products contracts.

title: JUDGE ORDERS TRIALS FOR FIVE IN GEORGIA
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 16Judge Walter Geer of Terrell County Superior Court ruled today that there was no evidence sufficient to prove police misconduct in the case of the socalled Dawson Five and ordered the five defendants to stand trial consecutively for firstdegree murder beginning Aug. 29.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 16 (UPI)With the next flu season a big question mark in the minds of many medical experts, the national Center for Disease Control made plans today to store 75 million doses of unused swine influenza vaccine in an Atlanta refrigeration facility.

title: FED CLUES AWAITED BY CREDIT MARKETS
description: Shortterm interest rates continued to rise and bond yields were stable as the credit markets awaited some signalexpected today or tomorrowof the Federal Reserve's decisions at its policysetting Open Market Committee meeting yesterday.
