description: uCoupled: Touch 01 Purple; Flip's Folly and No Talkie.

title: Management
description: Supervisors may think that technical expertise is the name of the game these days, but they are wrong, according to Thomas DeLong. so wrong, he believes, that they may find themselves out of a job as a result of their ability or unwillingness to stress the human element.

title: Civil Libertarian and Gandhi Foe To Be Indian Ambassador to U. S.
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 18  Nani A. Pallchivala, a prominent civil libertarian and staunch opponent of Indira Gandhi's government, has been chosen as India's new Ambassador to the United States.

title: Events and Openings
description: THE BAD NEWS BEARS IN BREAKING TRAINING, cIrected by Michael Pressman, at nelortborhoco theaters,

title: F. D. I. C. Files a Suit Against 21 Directors Of Bank That Failed
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 1STwentyone prominent businessmen and professional men have been sued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in Federal District Court here to recover as much as $13. 7 million in the aftermath of the failure of the International City Bank and Trust Company of New Orleans.

title: Publishing: Merlyn Conjured Up Again
description: TH. WHITE'S The Once and Future King'the epic novel that inspired Camelot'is not yet over. King Arthur lives. Thereby hangs a tale.

title: Books: Wit and Whimsies
description: LITERATE AMERICAN humor is alive and well but harder to find, Burton Bernstein writes in his introduction to this collection of casuals by younger writers, Mr. Bernstein's point being that there are fewer magazines around that publish humorous pieces so the young writers who want to write it are harder nut to find an outlet.

title: Island of Aruba Endures A 2Day Power Blackout In Midst of Labor Strike
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Aug. 18 (AP)  Electric power was restored today on the Dutch Antilles island of Aruba and shops reopened after a twoday blackout. Government employees and oil workers have been on strike for a week.

title: Korean Lobbyist Sought In U. S. Inquiry Reported Visiting Mother in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 18 (UPI) Park Tong Sun, the South Korean businessman sought by the United States authorities for alleged influence peddling in Washington, arrived in Seoul today to see his ailing mother, informed sources said.

title: Cabaret: In Russia. We Have Microphone
description: MORRIS MOSCOV1TCH, Soviet dissident, arrived in America less than a year ago with two ambitions: to become an architect or a con= orwho knows in Americamaybe both.

title: Beame Submits Package Of Tax Incentives to Spur Business Growth in City
description: A package of taxincentive bills to spur business expansion in New York City was submitted yesterday by Mayor Beame to the City Council for enabling legislation.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE 1960's continue to exert their spell in mysterious ways. The 1970's aren't so much contradiction of the previous free swinging decade as they are a subtler, more pervasive extension of it. The music and the life style may have lost some of their radical intensity, but they have permeated ever more broadly through the population at large.

title: Soviet Everest Expedition
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (Reuters)The Soviet Union will launch its first expedition to climb Mcunt Everest, the world's highest mountain, in 1980, it was reported today.

title: Jill Sheaber Becomes Bride Of Frank Tulin. a Student
description: Jill Sheaber, daughter of Myron P. Sheaber of Scardale, N. Y. . and the Iato Ann Sheaber, was married yesterday to Frank Tulin, son of Dr. and Mrs. . Bernard Tulin of West Hartford, Cor

title: 8 Flee Boat Sinking in Hudson
description: SCHUYLERVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 18 (AP) A 32foot cabin cruiser with eight persons abroad, including two 11old babies and a 11old girl, sank in the Hudson River near here last night, the state police said. All those abroad managed to get to shore safely after the craft struck a submerged log. It sank very quickly. They just had time to grab their life jackets, a state police spokesman said. It must have been quite a swim with the babies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, announced yesterday that the Warner Lambert Company and four of its executives had been indicted on charges of reckless manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide in connection with the explosion and fire in its Queens chewinggum factory last Nov. 21. Six employees were killed and dozens burned.

title: Opera: Santa Fe Tries On Straw Hat
description: SANTA FEE, N. M. PEOPLE who complain that contemporary opera has no tunes will no doubt be delighted with Nino Rota's The Italian Straw Hat, which is receiving its American premiereperformances at the Santa Fe Opera. From the opening C major scale of the overture to the sensuous nocturne that concludes the work, there is scarcely a note that would be out of place in a Rossini or Donizetti onera.

title: Dow Continues to Set New Lows For 1977 as Midday Rally Falters
description: A brisk midday rally in the stock market ran out of steam yesterday, leaving both the Dow Jones industrial and transportation averages at new yearly lows for the third session straight.

title: From Lounging to Loungewear
description: What do you do when you're bored with what you're doing! You become a designer. This week, the industry welcomed to its ranks Maria Jose Pagliai, who looks just like her former stepmother, Merle Oberon. Talking to her, one gets an uncanny feeling of being taken back to the time when Miss Oberon's dark eyes and cheekbones made her an overnight star after she played Anne Boleyn The Private Life of Henry VIII.

title: Backgammon Fund Is Focus of Dispute
description: The promoter of a milliondollar Las Vegas backgammon tournament scheduled. or December has solicited and collected what his associates say could be as much as $400,000 in entry fees that he had promised to keep in an escrow account, but bank officials said yesterday that the account never existed.

title: The Cuban Beginning
description: Fidel Castro's promise to Senator Frank Church that he will permit the departure of some 80 Americans with their Cuban families, which long had been denied exit permits, is his first significant concession responding to a series of American moves since January to improve United StatesCuban relations. These include cessation of American surveillance flights, a fishing agreement favorable to Cuba and lifting of the ban on travel by American citizens. Next month lowlevel diplomats will be exchanged to handle consular matters and to facilitate the developing CubanAmerican dialogue. Mr. Castro also indicated to Senator Church that he might release the seven political prisoners among 19 Americans still in Cuban jails.

title: Sri Lanka Calls Out Army to Quell Violence That Killed 14 in 3 Days
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 18 (AP) The Government announced today that the army had been called out to help curb a threeday. wave of intercommunal violence, arson and looting that has left 14 persons dead and many injured.

title: Capital's New Man in the Middle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Although Bert. Lance has been getting the headlines, John Gaines  Heimann, who moved into town as Comptroller of the Currency four weeks ago, seems likely to emerge from the Lance affair as one of the bright new faces in Washington. Mr. Heimann, a 11old New York Democrat and early supNews porter of President Carter, spent 20 years on Wall Street before jumping full time into the appointive poitical arena at the state level two years ago.

title: PENNSYLVANIA HOUSE REJECTSBUDGET AGAIN
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 18 (UPI) Despite the efforts of a Philadelphia lawmaker who voted from his hospital bed 100 miles away, the Pennsylvania House today rejected for the sixth time the 197778 proposed budget of $5. 1 billion.

title: Slight Rebound in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 18 (AP)The dollar rebounded slightly against the Japanese yen in fairly active trading on the foreign exchange market here today, closing at 266. 875 yen.

title: BALLY CO. CONFIDENT ABOUT CASINO LICENSE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18William T. O'Donnell, president of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, said today that even though certain officers of the company had been forced to resign by Nevada's casino regulatory agency because of questionable associations, he was confident that New Jersey would grant Bally a license to operate a casino here.

title: Don Murdoch
description: BRAMPTON, Ontario, Aug. 18 (AP)Don Murdoch, a 1scoring rookie with the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League last year, has been charged with possession of cocaine.

title: Sampling the Arts at Rockland Festival
description: A ballerina pirouetted, a guitarist strummed, quartets sang in harmony, poets read, drums rolled, bands played, troupers recited their linesand not far away hammers fell on wood and plaster as booths of craftsmen and workshops, art exhibitions and displays were rushed to completion.

title: The Standings
description: Los Angeles 7, San Francisco 0.

title: Tequillo Boogie, 40 to 1, Captures Empire Stakes
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 18. (AP) Milfer Farm's Tequillo Boogie, a 401 shot blew past Dame Keys, the pacesetter and won the $37,525 Empire Stakes at Saratoga today by threequarters of a length over Long Wait, another long shot.

title: New Face: Perils of Jessica Harper
description: Something's not quite right in the vast Art Deco hallways of Joan Bennett's Freiburg Dance Academy. There's a blind pianist and a misshapen butler, a plague of maggots and a runaway bat, a wild dog that chews its victim to death, and several murders by stabbing. It all seems like a plot to scare Jessica to death but Jessica Harper, who plays a much putupon young American ballet student, looks a lot less scared than do the audiences watching her run screaming through Suspiria, a new Italianmade horror film. In fact, not much seems to unsettle the vulnerablelooking young actress in real life, either.

title: U. S: Canadian Proposal
description: ST. ANDREWS, New Brunswick, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The Alberta provincial government today called for greater provincial participation in the settlement of disputes between Canada and the United States. In a position paper given at the opening session of the Premiers Conference here, the government of Premier Peter Lougheed suggested that protaces can contribute to the enrichment. of CanadianUnited States relations thrpogh regional conferences and visits between elected representatives.

title: Art People
description: FROM FRANCIS PICABIA before 1914 to Richard Hamilton and others at the present time, there have been artists who thought of their automobiles as an extension of their own personalities. Love my car, love me, was Picabia's message to the world as he burned up the long straight roads of France. Picabia drove to impress, and he liked his cars to be fast, open and spectacular.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars) Daily Averages tor tne weeks ended:

title: Glossary of Terms in the Report
description: The Comptroller's report on Bert Lance's dealings with various banks contains many technical financial terms. Below is a glossary of the most important terms.

title: ZAIRE CONDEMNS TWO MEN IT LINKS TO SHABA INVASION
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Aug. 18 (AP)A former Zaire army commander and a for. mer governor of Shaba Province were sentenced to death today after being convicted of collaborating with invaders who attacked the region in March, an official announcement said.

title: New York Wins CleanAir Accord, Easing Limit on Midtown Parking
description: If the new plan is approved by a Federal judge, as expected, most of the parking ban that the city began implementing under duress last June will be scrapped. The hoods will be removed from 206 parking meters in midtown, and parking will be permitted there after 6 P. M. Parking at 871 downtown meters will be banned only between 8 and 9 A. M., and no regulations will affect Chinatown or the Lower East Side.

title: Soviet's Men Gymnasts Win at University Games
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 18 (UPI)Russian gymnasts won the first gold medal of the World University Games today when they retained the men's team title. The Soviet Union scored 171. 60 points, leaving Japan to collect the silver for the second time in succession with 170. 15. China finished third with 169. 20. Bulgaria, the United States and Rumania filled the next three places.

title: Cabaret: Weill Reprise
description: THE THREEWAY partnership between Martha Schlamme, Alvin Epstein and Kurt Weill is still growing and developing after a decade together. Because their professional careers have taken separate paths, Miss Schlamme and Mr. Epstein have been able to come together in their programs of Weill songs for only brief periods in those 10 years, but the very infrequency of their gettogethers seems to add a freshness and a constantly probing quality to their performances.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's largest steel maker, announced in Tokyo yesterday that three of its steel trading affiliates had signed a contract to merge in November.

title: PERILOUS POLLUTANT SOUGHT IN BAYONNE
description: BAYONNE, Aug. 18Federal scientists, today finished gathering water samples, at a chemical company here in one aspect. of a nationwide investigation to learn how pervasive a suspected cancercausing chemical has become in the environment.

title: MRS. ROBERT SHRIVER, 95; SARGENT SHRIVER'S MOTHER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Mrs. Robert S. Shriver, the mother of Sargent Shriver, the 1972 Democratic VicePresidential nominee and former director of the Peace Corps, died in her sleep today at the home of her eldest son, Thomas Herbert Shriver, in Baltimore. She was 95 years old.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: PITTSBURGH (N. ) CHICAGO (N. )

title: Barber, North Lead By Stroke With 66's
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 18It happens. After a major golf championship, there is usually a letdown, physical and emotional, and the current example is the effect of last week's Professional Golfers Association championship on this week's $300,000 Westchester Classic.

title: Downtown Dig Sifts New York's Past
description: Archeologists are producing something new from a very old piece of Manhattanits auto. biography.

title: Dorsett Charges Dropped
description: DALLAS, Aug. 18 (UPI)A bartender who said Tony Dorsett, Dallas Cowboys running back, slugged him in an eye during a discobar altercation has decided to drop charges against the 1976 Heisman Trophy winner. A barmaid who complained that Dorsett struck her with a whisky glass during the June 30 incident had already said she would not file charges. Dorsett had been scheduled to stand trial in Municipal Court today.

title: A Park Fit for a Rajah
description: You don't really have to outfit yourself at Abercrombie & Fitch before setting out for the Bronx, but if you're headed for the Bronx Zoo's new Wild Asia preserve, an explorer's wardrobe could fit in with the magnificent outdoor decor.

title: Fuel Line Blaze in Los Angeles Injures Two and Threatens Homes
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP)Flames from a ruptured underground fuel line blanketed a city block today, injuring two passersby and threatening homes and businesses before it was extinguished, firemen said.

title: REPORT ON LANCE FINDS NO GROUND FOR PROSECUTION, BUT IS CRITICAL; PRESIDENT BACKS HIS BUDGET CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  The Comptroller of the Currency reported today that he had found no information to warrant the criminal prosecution of Budget Director Bert Lance, but he criticized Mr. Lance's practices while an executive of a Georgia bank.

title: Redskins Down Chiefs On 2dHalf Kicks, 137
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. IS (UPI)Mark Moseley, troubled by tendonitis in his kicking leg, recovered well enough tonight to bdot two secondhalf field goals and give the Washington Redskins a 137 preseason victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, twilightnight doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 5:30 P. M. (Television Channel 9, 8 P. M. ) (RadioWNEW 8 P. M. )

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The Red BlueGrass Western Flyer Show, which is scheduled to run through Oct. 16, has evening performances Tuesday through Sunday. matinees on Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday. Tickets range from $6. 50 to $9. 75, and reservations are must; call (203) 8738668.

title: Red Smith
description: Yesterday was Earnie Shavers Day in both Calcutta, Ohio, and East Liverpool, the pottery capital down the road a piece. Shavers, who fights out of Warren up in Trumbull County, plans to drop Muhammad All on his comely head in Madison Square Garden Sept. 29 and he is preparing for that rite in a barn on Turkana Farm, a 208acre spread at Calcutta. He interrttpted, training long enough to accept the key to East Liverpool from Mayor E. L. Tulis and a piece of pottery from Miss Pottery Queen. .

title: Trial in I. B. M. Case
description: Charges that the International Business Machines Corporation engaged in monopolistic practices should go to trial, a San Francisco court has ruled. The allegations were made by the Greyhound Computer Corporation. Meanwhile, a Canadian court has ordered, I. B. M. 's Canadian subsidiary to stop using all copying machines that infringe on Xerox Corporation patents. See Paee D2.

title: Willis A. Boughton, Chemist, 92, Author of More. Than 40 Books
description: Willis A. Boughton, who was a chemist before he retired, because of his health, to Florida in 1940, and then wrote more than 40 books on various subjects, died Aug. 7 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: QUEENS PLANT SEALED UNDER POLLUTION LAW
description: When commissioners and inspectors arrived at the Van lderstine Company's fatrendering plant in Queens yesterday to shut it don for filling the air with foul odors, it appeared the company had beaten them to the punch. And it was an important punch to be beaten to, since the closing was to have been the first ever carried out by the city.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Says Role In Its Loan to Lance Is Vindicated
description: In a lowkey statement, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday said it had been vindicated in the heated controversy that erupted over the big New York bank's $2. 6 million loan to Bert Lance, President Carter's budget director.

title: Teachers Union Refuses to Support Hiring and Admissions Quotas
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 Delegates to the American Federation of Teachers convention here today turned back a move by black members to support a system of quotas for minority hiring and admissions.

title: Issue of Lance's Fitness Remains in the Political Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Rather than disposing of the vexing dispute over Budget Director Bert Lance, as the White House once hoped, the report by the Comptroller of the Currency, John G. Heimann, has virtually insured that the Lance controversy will spurter on into the fall. By neither providing an unmistakable indictment of Mr. Lance nor clearing him un.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Aug. 18, 1977

title: Advertising
description: McNeil. Laboratories Inc. won a round yesterday in its fight to stop Whitehall Laboratories from claiming in advertisements that Anacin is superior to Tylenol.

title: It's Hard to Predict Political Consequences Of Disclosure of Testimony on City Finances
description: Like a roll of the dice. Mayor Beame's surprise disclosure this week of his testimony before the Securities and Exchange Commission was a gamble with political consequences that are difficult to pre. dict. Mr. Beame's move could, on the Newz Analysis one hand, defuse a potentially explosive problem if he succeees in preempting any criticism by the S. E. C. of his handling of city finances in 1974 and 1975. But it could also make the damage worse by giving such criticism added publicity. The stakes are obviously high, since many politicians say Mr. Beame's already precarious chances for reelection are on the line.

title: Dollar Ends Mixed In Europe, Gold Is Higher in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP)The United Stetes dollar had a mixed day against Europe's major currencies today. The price of gold rose in London but stayed the same in Zurich.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SURRENDERS AFTER RELEASING HOSTAGES: Thomas B. Wilson in custody Wednesday after he was persuaded by the Santa Cruz. Calif., police to release the 70 hostages hijacked aboard city bus and held for nearly six hours at a religious mountain retreat north of the city. No injuries were reported by the police.

title: U. S. Sues Over Oil Spill
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Federal Government sued two companies today for the $392,878 that it cost to clean up an oil spill in Bayport Channel three years ago. Assistant United States Attorney Robert Darden said that owners of a vessel that had run aground and leaked 600,000 gallons of oil into Galveston Bay failed to clean the mess properly. The Government hired a contractor to do the job. The suit also seeks a $5,000 penalty against Thomas Marine Company and C. F. Bean Corporation.

title: Backgammon Fund Is Focus of Dispute
description: The promoter of a milliondollar Las Vegas backgammon tournament scheduled for December has solicited and collected what his associates say could be as much as $400,000 in entry fees that he had promised to keep in an escrow account that bank officials said yesterday had never existed.

title: Spreading Peter Pan $12 Million Thick
description: Swift & Company, the maker of Peter Pan Peanut Butter, is about to undertake its largest ad campaign for a peanut product. This big news from peanutland was announced yesterday, along with the news that the company would spend 312 million in television to promote its newly reformulated peanut butter, beginning Monday.

title: Egypt Weighs FoodAid Cuts Again
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18 The Egyptian Government cautiously disclosed a proposal today to cut foodprice subsidies but stressed that such cuts would be compensated by a substantial rise in lowincome wages.

title: Canadian Court Order to Xerox
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 18A Canadian court has ordered I. B. M. Canada Ltd., a subsidiary of the American company, to remove from use in this country all its copying machines that infringe on patents held by the Xerox Corporation, the Xerox affiliate in Canada announced today.

title: Monica L. Sergott, at 71, Served Long as a Clinical Psychologist
description: Dr. Monica L. Sergott, for more than 40 years a clinical psychologist and social worker, died Wednesday in her home at 10923 71st Road, Forest Hills, Queens, where she had an office. Her age was 71.

title: Mosley, Top Draft Choice, Signs Contract With 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Philadelphia 76ers today signed Glenn Mosley, their top draft choice from Sewn Hel, to a multiyear contract.

title: FIVE FIELD IN CONSPIRACY TO PASS BOGUS $50 NOTES
description: Five men were arraigned in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having conspired to pass $50,000 worth of counterfeit $50 Federal Reserve notes.

title: R. L. Riker, 62, Retired Head Of Combustion Engineering Unit
description: Robert L. Riker, who retired in 1975 as president of Combustion Engineering Inc. 's CE Canada Division in Montreal, Quebec, died Monday in Myrtle Beach, S. C. He lived in Myrtle Beach and was 62 years old.

title: A Crime by Any Other Name
description: Governor Carey has measured up to the responsibilty of his office by vetoing a measure that responded to public passion about a real problembut would have done more harm than good. We speak of the New York Legislature's bill to create three new crimes, consisting of violent felonies against victims over 62. The feloniesburglary, robbery and serious assaultare, of course, already crimes; but the bill would have mandated stiffer penalties for firsttime offenders against the elderly.

title: Albert P. Rose, 68, Band Leader And Then AirTraffic Controller
description: Albert P. Rose, a danceband leader in New York in the 1930's and later chief airtraffic controller at Mercer County Airport, Trenton, until his retirement in 1971, died, yesterday in Point Pleasant (N. J. ) Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 26 South Farragut Avenue, Manasquan, N. J.

title: Carter Used Plane Lance Bank Owned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18A White House spokesman said today that President Carter made five trips in 1975 and 1976 in an airplane owned by the National Bank of Georgia, of which Budget Director Bert Lance was then president, but that it was not clear whether the trips were a part of his campaign activities and if so whether the bank had been reimbursed for the use of the plane.

title: Purse Snatcher Meets Match in a Tourist, 60
description: A 11old Australian woman seeking directions to a friend's house was taken for a long subway ride today to a remote area of the Bronx and robbed of $500, the police said.

title: Finn Shatters Walk Record
description: TURKU, Finland, Aug. 18 (UPI)Reima Salonen of Finland set a world record in the men's 10kilometer walk today, clocking 40 minutes 42. 6 seconds to lower by nine seconds the record established last year by Daniel Bautista of Mexico.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended June 30 unless otherwise Indicated.

title: Bocce Tournament Rolls Into Cunningham Park
description: Aficionados of boccea form of. lawn bowling for the steely nervedfrom all over the metropolitan area wilL compete for cash prizes and medallions: this weekend in the fourth annual Sambuca Romana bocce tournament. It will be in Cunningham Park. Union Turnpike and 196th Street in Queens. tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A. M. to dusk. The final matches are scheduled for 1 P. M. on Sunday. Admission is free.

title: Notes on People
description: The new acting president of Cyprus, Spyros Kyprianou, yesterday announced a onesixth reduction of all prison sentences as a prerogative for mercy on the occasion of the death of President Makarios and his own assumption of office.  By terms of the reduction one of 125 prisoners to have sentences cut is Nicos Sampson, the former guerilla who served briefly as president in the unsuccessful coup of 1974. Mr. Sampson, given 20 years in prison, is now expected to serve little more than half that time.

title: Alleged Hijacker of Bus and Killer Of 2 Pleads Insanity at a Hearing
description: Luis Robinson, a 11old Navy enlisted man, pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to 33 charges, ranging from murder and kidnapping to assault, in the July 4 hijacking of a Vermontbound bus to Kennedy International Airport in which two persons were shot and killed and three others were iniured.

title: TitoBrezhnev Talks End With No Gains Reported On Settling Differences
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (Reuters) President Tito of Yugoslavia and Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, ended two days of talks today on longstanding problems that have divided their two nations, Yugoslav sources said.

title: Angling for Blues Picks Up As August's Days Dwindle
description: With September close at hand, one can logically expect the mid and late summer scarcity of striped bass landings to end, and there are indications that angling for bluefish in the western end of Long Island Sound will soon greatly improve.

title: AIR TRAFFIC DISPUTE IN CANADA CONTINUES
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 18 Travelers in Canada appeared today to be facing the prospect of delayed and canceled flights for some time to come as a result of worktorule tactics adopted by disgruntled airtraffic controllers, who are demanding that the federal Government reconsider a wage settlement imposed on the controllers by special legislation.

title: Goodell Takes StarLaden 400 rn A. A. U. Swim
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif. . Aug. I8Brian Goodell, the hometown hero, won the big race tonight as the Amateur Athletic Union's national longcourse swimming championships began.

title: Rockland's New Window on History
description: It was Sept. 22, 1780 and Maj. John Andre was negotiating with Gen. Benedict Arnold for the betrayal of West Point, N. Y. They sat before a large window in Joshua Hett Smith's house in West Haverstraw, glancing occasionally at the British sloop of war Vulture sitting at anchor in the Hudson River.

title: 2 Men Held in the Stabbing Death Of ExYankee Owner's Son in Miami
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18 (AP)Two men were held today in connection with the stab bing death earlier this week of Robert Reed Topping, 20, son of the former New York Yankees owner, Dan Topping Sr., the police said.

title: Why They're Hurrying to Goodspeed
description: David Keith, Robert Donley and Candy Darling in The Red 1Grass Western Flyer Show, a new musical directed by John Cullum at the Goodspeed Opera House In East Haddam, Conn. The current Broadway hit Annie is among the shows that had their beginnings at Goodspeed. See Page C3.

title: Bookkeeping
description: One out of six borrowers of federally guaranteed college tuition loans don't repay them. Their delinquencies, according to the General Accounting Office, cost the Government almost $300 million from the beginning of the program nine years ago through 1976. No Federal program is free of parasites and hustlers, but the image of students accepting a loan to improve their financial prospects with a college degree and then defaulting seems particularly dingy. One defaulter is $31,000 a year psychiatrist, another.

title: FRANCE ERRS AGEE AS AN UNDESIRABLE
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) France today expelled Philip Agee. the former C. LA. agent, and said the American's presence could have harmed relations with friendly countries.

title: Girl With Dog on Leash Is Injured In an Electrical Accident on L. I.
description: HOLBROOK, LI, Aug. 18 (AP)  A 11old girl was critically shocked, and burned, and her dog was killed when the dog urinated on the wiring of an electrified sign here, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: MRS. CARTER CELEBRATES BIRTHDAY AT CAMP DAVID
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 18 (AP)The Carters celebrated a double birthday here today with a Chinese dinner and tennis lessons for Rosalynn Carter, who turned 50, and a telephone call to their son, Jeff, who became 25.

title: How to Get There
description: To get to the Nanuet Star Theater, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway north to Exit 8W and then Route 59 direct to the theater. From New Jersey, follow the Garden State Parkway to the Goy. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, Exist 14, turn left on 59 to the theater. Other routes include the Tappan Zee Bridge to the Thruway and Route 59, and north from the city on the Thruway to Exit.

title: Flushing Airport Is Called Safe in F. A. A. Report
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said last night that it had studied the operations of Flushing Airport in Queens and had determined that it was still a safe airport.

title: Monmouth
description: ENTRIES

title: Canada Won't Cancel PayPrice Curb Soon
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said in a radio interview here the decision of the Canadian Labor Congress yesterday not to participate in a voluntary program of wage restraint meant that there would be no early end to national wage and price controls.

title: Carter Used Plane Lance Bank Owned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  A White House spokesman said today that President Carter made five trips in 1975. and 1976 in an airplane owned by the Nation. al Bank of Georgia, of which Btdget Director Bert Lance was then president* but that it was not clear whether the trips were a part of his campaign adtivities and if, so whether the bank had been reimbursed for the use of the plane.

title: New Passion Play Draws Protest
description: OBERAMMERGAU, West Germany, Aug. 18 (AP) Angry townspeople sought today to block a new version of the town's worldfamous Passion Play, a daylong dramatization of the Crucifixion of Jesus. The play was changed to eliminate antiJewish material.

title: Yes, Yes.  But.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Legislative and judicial processes inevitably conflict. Legislators make the laws and judges interpret and occasionally overturn them. What the legislators hail as in the public interest, courts sometimes reject as violating individual rights. The majority inevitably seeks its vindication in Congress, the minorities in court.

title: Mozart Is His Metier
description: can safely say that my favorite composer is Mozart, Lawrence Foster announced Tuesday shortly after he had arrived in New York to go into rehearsal for the Mostly Mozart concerts he's conducting at Avery Fisher Hall tonight and tomorrow night.

title: Plea for Dr. Mudd, Who Aided Lincoln's Killer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) President Carter was asked today to reverse the military conviction of a southern. Maryland physician who set the broken leg of John Wilkes Booth, Abraham Lincoln's assassin.

title: Regional Stores Outperforming Bigger Chains
description: Regional retailers, although their total profit dollars are fewer and their names lack the glamour of a Federated or Gimbel Brothers, appear to be weathering an uncertain economy and erratic consumer buying trend better than their larger cousins.

title: Sunken Ship Becomes Trove for Japanese City It Attacked
description: ESASHI, Japan  One day more than a century ago, the Kaiyo Meru. the threemasted flagship frigate of the Japanese Navy, appeared offshore here with cannons blazing to attack this prosperous northern city as feudal lords fought against their Overthrow and the modernization of Japan.

title: Elvis Presley Entombed
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 18  Elvis Presley, the king of 11roll, was laid to rest today amid scenes that ranged from the serenity of a green Southern cemetery to hysteria by fans who tried to charge the gates of his home and the cemetery. Two women were killed and one was critically injured after car plowed into the crowd of mourners outside Mr. Presley's home at 4 A. M. today. The driver was charged with two counts of seconddegree murder.

title: Analyzing Vast Quantities of Business Data
description: Falling apples and falling profits may have something in common. When one studies hundreds of companies, their business results display a certain stability, a predictability loosely akin to the Newtonian laws of nature in the physical sciences.

title: Deborah Appel Wed To Thomas Moses 3d
description: The marriage of Deborah Appel, editor of Die Audubon Leader, the national newsletter of the National Audubon Society, to Thomas Lanier Moses 3d, editor and publisher of The Times, a weekly newspaper in Hillside. N. J., took place at noon yesterday in Dublin, N. H. The Rev. Herman Lingerman performed the ceremony in the Dublin Community Church.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: SUPPORT FROM OPPOSITION: Raymond H. Bateman, right, Republican gubernatorial candidate, with Mayor Richard J. Mulligan in New Brunswick yesterday. The mayor, a Democrat, read statement endorsing Mr. Bateman.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18An important defection in Governor Byrne's traditional tradeunion support appeared today with the disclosure that the New Jersey State A. F. L. C. I. O. had issued harsh 10point criticism of the Governor's record to its 200member local unions.

title: REAL INVESTMENT ABROAD BY U. S. DOWN THIS YEAR
description: United States industry will spend $22. 4 billion on overseas capital investment this year, the economics department of the McGrawHill Publications Company reported yesterday.

title: The Diaphragm Is Regaining Acceptance Among Some Women
description: The oldfashioned diaphragm, which was relegated to thousands of handKerchief drawers with the advent of the birthcontrol pill in the 1960's, is staging a modest renaissance these days.

title: HUMPHREY'S CANCER IS CALLED TERMINAL
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 18 (AP) Hubert H. Humphrey has cancer of the pelvis that is beyond surgical help, his physician saidtoday. But the 11old Senator can probably continue his usual activities while undergoing chemical treatment, doctors said.

title: Of Blame And Needs
description: When I filed suit in Federal court to force the Securities and Exchange Commission to release its longoverdue report on New York City's fiscal scandal. the news media said the report could embarrass Mayor Beanie. The Mayor had been directly involved in the municipalbond sales that were at the heart of the S. E. C. investigation.

title: New Y orkWins CleanAir Accord, Easing Limit on Midtown Parking
description: New York City and the Federal Government announced yesterday that they had agreed on a new cleanair plan for Manhattan that would rely less on banning parking and more on bolstering mass transit and enforcing traffic laws.

title: WarmboldTodt Leads Rally
description: ATHENS (UPI)Achim Warmbold of West Germany and Jean Todt of France held the lead today as cars arrived here on the second European stage of the 18,000mile 1toSydney Auto Rally. Warmbold and Todt, driving a Mercedes 280, headed the 26car field at the end of the first European stage yesterday in Turin, Italy, and will lead off the next stage tomorrow to Istanbul.

title: Hardy Space Robots Still on the Job
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 18When the two Voyager spacecraft set out on their journey to Jupiter and Saturn, they will be joining a hardy breed of robot explorers still active out in the solar system.

title: JURY PANEL COMPLETED IN BOLLES MURDER. CASE
description: PHOENIX, Aug. 18 (AP)  After six weeks of selection, a panel of potential jurors for the Don Bolles murder trial was completed today.

title: What's On Outside
description: Tuesday: Steel Band, Future Shock (Fountain Plaza, 1 P. M. ); Manna House Inner Space Ensemble, Gimme 5 Lord (Fauntarn Plaza, 2:30); Walter Nicks Dance Theater (Fountain Plaza, 5).

title: HERBERT ROBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)Herbert Roback, an official with the Federal Paperwork Commission and former staff director of the House Government Operations Committee, has died of cancer. He was 62 years old.

title: Kenya Bars Uganda Coffee
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 18 (Reuters)No more Uganda coffee will be transported to the Kenyan port of Mombasa until the Kenyan railroad system devises new security measures to cope with a wave of coffee thefts, a railroad official said today.

title: President of Bally Company Says He Expects It to Get Casino License
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18William T. O'Donnell, president of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, said today that even though certain officers of the company had been forced to resign by Nevada's casino regulatory agency because of questionable associations, he was confident that New Jersey would grant Bally a license to operate a casino here.

title: WEST COAST FOREST FIRE CONTAINED AFTER 18 DAYS
description: A mighty force of men and machines conquered the Big Sur last night after it rampaged for 18 days through 175,000 acres of striking but rugged wilderness and valuable watershed near the central California coast, United Press International reported.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: While President Carter's program for better jobs and income is a laudable attempt to improve the welfare system and relieve localities of their fiscal burdens, I am deeply disturbed by its neglect of Medicaid. The failure to extend reform to health care ultimately may defeat the overall goals of the program, especially with regard to preserving families and insuring that work is always more profitable than public assistance.

title: News Summary
description: Israel's decision to establish three new Jewish settlements on the West Bank were denounced by the Carter Administration as illegal, and it said that there would be new obstacles to constructive negctiations.  The Administration, in a statement issued by the State Department, also criticized Prime Minister Menahem Begin's decision to extend Israeli Government services to Arabs living on the West Bank as unhelpful.  [Page 1, Column 3. ]

title: Judge Johnson Meets SOG
description: Frank Johnson is such an outstanding choice to be the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that there is a danger of letting hopes rise too high. He is a man of unusual character and courage and, as two decades on the Federal bench in Alabama demonstrate, a judge of intense devotion to the supremacy of law. These have been sometime qualities at the F. B. I; they are essential if that onceproud agency is to reclaim the public's trust. The President and the Attorney General bring honor to the Administrationand to the F. B. I. by persuading Judge Johnson to accept the chair so long filled by J. Edgar Hoover.

title: SERVICES TOMORROW FOR DELMER L DAVES
description: Memorial services will be held tomorrow and Monday in southern California for Delmer Lawrence Daves, a retired writer, director and producer who contributed his talents to about 80 movies in a 40year career.

title: At the Movies
description: "IBET YOU want to know where I've been, said the 1blonde in a vibrant, husky voice that has not been heard in too long a timenot since Carrie Snodgress, a nobody from Park Ridge, Ill., captivated the critics with her sly humor, unspoiled charm and luminous looks in Frank and Eleanor Perry's Diary of a Mad Housewife.  That was seven years ago, and where she's been since has been on the road with the rock star Neil Young and on a remote ranch the couple shared with their son Zeke and random herds of horses and buffaloes. But now she's back, toiling for the producer Frank Yablans in The Fury, the latest blast of funfilled fright from Brian De Palma, the director of Carrie.

title: In Memoriam
description: DENTONAnna Miriam, died August 19, 1965. You are still missed by your friends and myself. JACK.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: SEVENTH511,000, Class B1, ril'1e.

title: Firefighters in a Tentative Accord On the Economic Side of New Pact
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association and New York City have reached a preliminary agreement on the economic term of a new cotract and they submitted it yesterday to the Emergency Financial Control Board for approval.

title: Longshoremen Talks Adjourned
description: Bargaining talks between the International Longshoremen's Association and the North Atlantic shipping companies adjourned yesterday without an agreement, a spokesman said. Negotiators for both sides will review the situation and decide later when to resume discussions. The current agreement, covering 35,000 longshoremen in ports between Boston and Hampton Roads, Va., expires Sept. 30.

title: 6th Test of Trident Successful
description: CAPE CANAEVRAL, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) bcape canaveral, fla., Aug. 18 (AP) The United States Navy said that it successfuly test fired a Trident missile from a land pad today. It was the sixth successful flight test of the missile. The firing had been delayed five times this week because of weather and technical problems. A Navy spokesman said that there would be 15 to 20 land pad launches and 10 to 15 firings from submerged submarines before the missile was declared operational, possibly in 1979.

title: Carey Finishes the Signing of Bills; Freedom of Information Expanded
description: ALBANY, Aug. 18Governor, Carey announced today that he had signed the last of 982 new laws for 1977, including bills to broaden the state's Freedom of Information Act and to revise the 71Yearold law regulating political lobbying.

title: Emily Wilson Becomes Bride
description: Emily Walker Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Philip Walker of Southport, Me., and Hartford, was married in Duxbury, Mass., yesterday morning to Samuel Dacre Bush 3d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bush 2d of Boston. The Rev. Lewis Hartman Mills performed the ceremony in St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church. Previous marriages for both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: The New York Tfmes/Fred R. Conrad FOLLOW THE LEADER: On Roosevelt Island, children enjoy a sunny day 14 playing under an Iron sculpture of a pyramid inside a pyramid.
Restaurants
description: RAO'S, a tiny, unprepossessing but excellent Italian restaurant improbably situated at the corner of Pleasant Avenue and East 114th Street, just behind Benjamin Franklin High School in one of the city's most brokendown and devastated neighborhoods, is the sort of place every rev!ewer longs to come upon. It is, in every sense, a find. Set a few steps down in an otherwise ramshackle building, Rao's looks, at first glance, like little more than a prosperous neighborhood bar, which it is in part, servicing the few Italian families still living along the more sprucedup streets this area.

title: Apples Sweep Loves AndInto Eastern Final
description: Billie Jean King and Virginia Wade were convulsed with laughter last night as they sat on the bench watching two of their teammates, Sandy Mayer and Ray Ruffels, complete a 3115 laugher against the Indiana Loves at Felt Forum. The victory advanced the New York Apples to the second round of the World Team Tennis playoffs.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A group representing 400 clubs of the elderly called upon the State Insurance Department yesterday to prohibit insurers from charging New Jersey's 673,000 elderly drivers higher auto insurance rates.

title: Control Board Defers Meeting; Waits State. Action on Appointees
description: To pressure the recessed New York State Senate to reconvene and act on three appointments to the Emergency Financial Control Board, a regular meeting of the board was postponed yesterday. However, there was nothing pressing on the agenda, it was reported.

title: Blanket Hill Again
description: On May 4, 1970, during a protest against the American invasionof Cambodia, four students were killed by National Guard gunfire at Blanket Hill on the campus of Kent State University in Ohio.

title: Concert: A Contemporary Armory of Sounds
description: LENOX, MASS. WHY IS IT, do you suppose, that in a century that has made intolerable noise condition of daily life many composers want to write music of such loudness and piercing nastiness that it makes the teeth hurt? Just to get their messages heard over the din? Possibly. But in such a work as Yoshihisa Taira's Hierophonie V (1974), which had its first American performance Wednesday night at Tanglewood's Festival of Contemporary Music, one could also hear what seemed like angry hostility and frustration. For audiences, exposure to noise that reaches or crosses the pain threshold also has a narcotic effect, which is as observable at intellectual gatherings such as this as at heavily amplified rock concerts.

title: About Real Estate
description: In theory the city's rent regulations establish a fairly straightforward way for the owner of a brownstone or other small building to free an apartment for occupancy by his immediate family. Rent control regulations say that if the owner has a 20 percent equity interest in the property and can establish that the application is in good faith.  he is entitled to a certificate of eviction to oust the tenant.

title: Seaver Back at Shea
description: Seaver is scheduled to pitch the final game on Sunday. His opponent will be Jerry Koosman, who asked Manager Joe Torre more than a month ago if he could oppose Seaver in this series.

title: Touring Pros Wives Rate Golf Courses for Nurseries
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 18The men on the pro golf tour have their favorite courses. Jack Nicklaus always speaks highly of Pebble Beach where the Professional Golfers Association championship was held last week. Most of the pros rate the Augusta National Golf Club (the Masters course) highly along with such courses as Harbour Town Golf Links at Hilton Head, S. C.

title: Craft to Fly to Saturn and Jupiter Ready for Launching Tomorrow
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 18  The most farranging reconnaissance of the outer solar system thus far is set to begin with the planned launching Saturday of the first of two Voyager spacecraft,. unmanned vehicles outfitted with camera and scientific sensors to examine the planets Jupiter, Saturn and possibly Uranus.

title: Escaping From the Prison of Shyness: A Little Love May Make the Difference
description: The uncontrollable child has always been viewed as a big problem. That's especially true today. One hears that Americans have a tendency to overpraise their children and allow them to run wild. Discipline, it's said, is what the children need.

title: Harlem, Redlich Troupes to Dance at Newport
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will perform tonight and tomorrow at 8 P. M., and the Don Redlich Dance Company will perform Sunday, also at 8, in Newport, R. I. . as part of the American Dance Festival.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 7:30 P. M.  (5) Return of Tom Terrific.  The former Mets pitching star Toni Seaver talks about his return to Shea Stadium in the uniform of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Sales of Singer's Disks Soaring
description: Records stores throughout the country reported a surge of interest in the late Elvis Presley's recordings yesterday. RCA Records, the sole provider of Presley disks, found its inventories quickly exhausted.

title: Jordan Praises F. B. I. Choice
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, has praised President Carter's nomination of Federal District Judg efrank M. Johnson Jr. as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He called the judge a devoted civil libertarian and courageous man of principle, United Press International reported.

title: Moscow Quandary: Ethiopian Combat Finds Soviet on Both Sides
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. I8  The fragile props of African unity  the principles of national integrity and inviolate borders  are crumbling in the undeclared war between Somali forces and Ethiopian armies. The longexpected crisis in the Horn of Africa has apparently arrived, with strange alliances forming behind both countries and the Soviet Union facing its most serious foreign policy debacle since the eviction of Soviet technicians from Egypt in 1972.

title: Bethlehem Sets Cutbacks, Expects Loss
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 18  The troubled Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steelmaker, today said it would cut steel production 10 percent and lay off 7,300 workers in New York and Pennsylvania.

Dear brother of Miss Rose Bomar and the late Francis Kramer. Relatives and friends and the Reverend deli are invited to attend the fuaaral at tne Burke Funeral Horne. 3279 Kennedy Blvd. Jersey City on Monday at 9 A. M. description: Now that United Technologies has equaled the bid of J. Ray McDermott at $55 a share for Babcock & Wilcox the emphasis shifts from price to tax considerations.

title: War Hero's Statue Bombed in France
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) An explosion today felled the statue here of a French war hero, Marshal Philippe Leclerc, the liberator of Paris, just week before celebrations to mark the 33d anniversary of the end of the Nazi occupation.

title: Rights Group Acts to Heal ModerateMilitant Rift
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 18 (UPI)Faced with a struggle between moderates and militants, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference compromised here today by electing a member of each faction to its top leadership posts.

title: Polygraph Tests for Jobs: Truth and Consequences
description: Fill in name, address, Social Security number. List past employers and dates of employment. Give three references. Indicate salary expected, hours available. Note all health problems. Sigr here if all information given in this application is true to the best of applicant's knowledge. Finally, take lie detector test.

description: Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest securities concern, said it planned to issue American Depositary Receipts, equivalent to from 20 million to 25 million shares of the company's common stock, in New York later this year. The company said it hoped to increase its underwriting services in the United States.

title: SAFETY GROUPS DISCUSS NEW RULES ON AIR BRAKES
description: Two truck and bussafety groups, which represent manufacturers and operators, completed a threeday technical meeting in Washington yesterday on implementing airbrake safety standards of the Department of Transportation.

description: Terming the arts New York City's neglected big business, Representative Edward I. Koch set forth yesterday 17point program aimed at helping artists, performers and cultural institutionsand promised that if elected the next Mayor, he would carry it out at no cost to the taxpayers.

title: White Sox Acquire Renko
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Chicago White Sox went across town today for the pitching help and came. hack with Steve Renko, acquiring the righthander from the Chicago Cubs for a minor league pitcher, Larry Anderson. Renko had a 22 wonlost record with the Cubs.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Do you have a painting or a necklace that you thinkor hopehas great value? You can find out its worth at the Guild Hall in East Hampton, LI., where today is Appraisal Day. You can bring up to two items, which must conform to some simple rules: nothing larger than you can carry, no furniture and no diamonds. Before the appraisals get under way, Robert Myron, a Hofstra University professor, will give a talk on the subject at 10 A. M. Then he and three colleagues will get down to business. Admission is $10, for the benefit of Guild Hall. From New York, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 70 and follow Route 27 to East Hampton. Information: (516) 3242155.

title: COURT ORDERS TRIAL ON I. B. M. PRACTICES
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Aug. 18 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today that there should be a trial on allegations that the International Business Machines Corporation monopolized various markets in the electronic data processing industry.

title: PAT BRADLEY
description: LIMA, Pa., Aug. 18 (AP)  Funeral services will be held Saturday in Philadelphia for Pat Bradley, a professional boxer between 1912 and 1922. Mr. Bradley died Tuesday at a home for the aged here. He was 83 years old.

title: Mandel Jury, Pressed for Verdicts, Asks for Note Pads and Blackboard
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 After seven days and more than 70 hours of deliberations, the jury in the Federal corruption case against Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland recessed at 7:15 P. M. tonight without yielding verdicts in the trial of Governor Mandel and his five wealthy codefendants.

title: Sutton's 5th OneHitter Deals Giants a 70 Loss
description: In the long history of the Dodgers there have been many outstanding pitchers: Dazzy Vance, Hugh Casey, Don Newcombe, Joe Black, Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale. to name few. Many wrote history in Brooklyn, a couple in Los Angeles.

description: Belew 42d Street V

title: Art: Philadelphia, More Than a Story
description: PROPERTY and propriety are the twin blasons of the thoroughbred Philadelphian. He looks well, he behaves well, he never needs to raise his voice and in a Solid and inconspicuous way he lives very well indeed. He takes a proper pride in the Pennsylvania Academy of Art, and he knows that it is not only one of the oldest but also one of the very best things of its kind. But the archetypal Philadelphian is more interested in keeping a good house and not letting the wrong kind of person know about it than he is in esthetic adventure:

title: Wealthy Candidates Spend Heavily In Bids to Win New York Primary
description: City Councilman Carter Burden has already spent $336,615 of his own money and an additional $60,000 of family money in his quest for the Democratic nomination for City Council President, post that pays $50,000 a year.

title: YanksTopTigers,54, With Hunter and Lyle
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18The Yankees spent another nervous evening dissipating a lead tonight before they prevailed over Detroit at Tiger Stadium, 54.

title: Lackawanna Recoils From the Loss of 3,500 Steel Jobs
description: LACKA\VANNA, N. Y., Aug. 18The men who work at Bethlehem Steel's sprawling plant here, on the 1. ake Erie shore, were angry and shocked at the news that 3,500 of the plant's 11,000 employees would he laid off. Officials of this city, which has prided itself on the name, The Steel City, are worried that their biggest local industry is preparing to end its operations.

title: Fraud by Computer Is Charged to Fisco
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a Philadelphiabased auto insurance company with using a computer program to understate losses and inflate profits to raise the value of stock that is now practically worthless.

title: How to Get There
description: Take Palisades Interstate Parkway (from George Washington Bridge or Thomas E. Dewey Thruway) to exit 10A, turning right on New Hempstead Road for two miles to downtown New City. Turn right on North Main Street for one mile to stop sign, where North Main becomes Zukor Road, Museum is first driveway on right, at 20 Zukor Road.

title: Palmer in Pinehurst Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 18 (AP)Arnold Palmer will enter next week's first ColgateHall of Fame Golf Classic. The $250,000 tournament, which starts Thursday at the Pinehurst Country Club, will be Palmer's first appearance here since the 1975 World open, when he missed the 36hole cut by one stroke. Palmer was one of the original 13 members selected in 1974 to the World Golf Hall of Fame, which is located at the Pinehurst course.

description: KENNEBUNK BEACH, Maine Aug. 18 (AP)Bishop Thomas J. Riley, auxiliary Roman Catholic Bishop of Boston, who wrote a syndicated newspaper column, Theology for Everyman, that ran weekly in the archdiocese newspaper, the Pilot, died yesterday. He was 76 years old.

title: WIFE OF DOUBLE AGENT DISPUTES SOVIET ACCOUNT
description: Blanka Shadrin, who is married to Russianborn double agent, Nicholas Shadrin, said yesterday that she did not believe the explanation given earlier this week by the K. G. B., the Soviet intelligence organization, for the disappearance of her husband in Vienna two years ago.

description: The following metropolitanarea television stations have scheduled special programs as a tribute to Elvis Presley:

title: Japan Asks Mutual Trust in Asia
description: MANILA, Aug. 18, 1977  Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan ended his 10day tour of Southeast Asia here today with a speech outlining Japan's new doctrine of peaceful cooperation with its neighbors based on mutual trust.

title: WNBC Radio Shifts Cast and Policy
description: Don Imus, whose stock in trade in morning radio has been the offcolor remark that his devoted listeners regard as outrageous, has lost his berth on WNBC radio after six years. Leaving with him, in a clean sweep of the station's disk jockeys, will be Joe McCoy, Walt Baby Love, Cousin Brucie Morrow, Dick Summer, Bill Rock and Steve Warren.

The Administration, in a statement issued by the State Department, also criticized Prime Minister Menahem Begin's decision to extend Israeli Government services to Arabs living on the West Bank as unhelpful. description: PUSHKINO, U. S. S. R., Aug. 18 (Reuters) At least 10 people were killed and dozens injured when a crowded footbridge over a main rail line collapsed yesterday at this town near Moscow, Soviet sources said today.

title: Royal Dutch/ ShellGroup Net Up 7. 3% in Quarter and 30. 2% in Half
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group. of companies, the largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation, yesterday reported a profit increase of 7. 3 percent for the second quarter on a 21. 2 percent climb in revenue.

title: Court Group Asked That Berkowitz, Having Job, Be Let Go Without Bail
description: The day after David R. Berkowitz was arrested and accused of being the. 44caliber killer, a pretrial agency recommended that the 11old postal worker be released without bail on his own recognizance because he had a permanent residence and a steady job.,

description: CUNARD PRINCESS (Cunard), Lott Bermuda Aug. 13; due 8 A. M. at W. 55th Street.

title: U. S. Banks Placed Large Sums Of Money Abroad in 2d Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)United States banks, reversing the firstquarter trend, placed large sums of money abroad in the second quarter, new Commerce Department statistics show.

title: U. S. Policy, And Israel's
description: BEIRUTWhat will President Carter have to say to the Arab foreign ministers in September that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance cannot say in New York or has not already said in his recent tour of Arab capitals?

title: Arts and Outdoors Meet At Lincoln Center
description: LINCOLN CENTER PLAZA tends to have an informal festival atmosphere all year round, but this weekend the strolling crowds will cluster around jazz musicians and dancing robots. All but one the center's theaters will be dark. It is once again time for Lincoln 111Doors.

title: Broadway
description: IN A CAREER that has included plays by every one from Tom Stoppard to William Shakespeare, somehow John Wood has neglected Moliere. Until Tartuffe (which begins public performance Sent. 2 and opens Sept. 25 at Circle in the &mare). he had never played Moliere professionally, although years ago at Oxford University, he once, daringly, did Monere in French. That was when I was thinking of becoming a French actor, he said during a recent break in rehearsal. Now he is thinking of becoming an American actor. He is happy about performing with an American companvas Tartuffe, he costars with Tammy Grimes, Mildred Dunnock and Patricia Elliottand readily offered a passing crit'cism of his native theater: Something corrodes Moliere in England. It must be the air.

title: UNITED RAISES ITS BID FOR BABCOCK TO $55, MATCHES M'DERMOTT
description: Determined to stay in the running in the battle for the Babcock & Wilcox Company, the United Technologies Corporation yesterday raised its bid for all shares of Babcock to $55 a share.

title: Miss Whiting Happens to Like New York
description: The panoramic view through the windows of the Rainbow Grill on the 65th floor of the RCA Building, revealing Manhattan from the George Washington Bridge to the Statue of Liberty, is an ideal setting for songs about New York. Margaret Whiting, during her engagement this week at the Grill, is taking advantage of this awesome backdrop to sing a medley of songs that have been inspired by the city, including Rodgers and Hart's Manhattan, Cole Porter's I Happen to Dice New York, Vernon Duke's Autumn in New York and the two songs called New York, New York, one by Leonard Bernstein, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, the other by John Kander and Fred Ebb.

title: Film: Bunuel's Line
description: "THE ILLUSION Travels by Streetcar," the third Mexican Luis Buuel film of the early 50's to have its American premiere at the Jean Renoir Cinema, is simultaneously the most characteristic and the most uneven of the lot. Satirical, at times almost allegorical, and full of surreal touches, it is also at times ponderous and rambling. It begins, for instance, with a somber and preachy voice-over, to the effect that life is full of small but meaningful stories and that what follows will be one of them.From there, it details the adventures of a pair of transit workers who have lovingly repaired a ramshackle old trolley, only to learn that the streetcar company has decided the car is obsolete. The two get drunk that night and steal the trolley, piloting it around Mexico City until they can safely return it the following evening.They have no set course in mind, but the car is commandeered over and over again by peculiar bands of people. An impatient schoolteacher loads her children onto the car, and soon anarchy reigns; a group of wealthy businessmen climb on board and are shocked and irritated by the crew's refusal to collect fares. In another, shabbier part of town, peasant women decide that anyone who won't take money is probably a thief.On board the trolley, the mood is deadpan and decidedly strange. A butcher climbs on and calmly sets up shop, carving meat and hanging up carcasses. Two women carrying a plaster saint wander along in the middle of the night, on their way to church to have the saint blessed??? it seems this noctu???nal urge strikes them regularly, the way the craving for chip dip affects others.This behavior is never made to seem grotesque; in fact, it hardly seems out of the ordinary. At its best, the film inhabits a cool, only slightly distorted fantasy world that has its own eccentric rules of decorum.The film ach???eves this tone effortlessly much of the time, but occasionally it strains, as when a neighborhood party includes a little morality play that casts the trainmen as God and the Devil. Occasionally it meanders??? too, and the trolley conceit begins to wear thin.But its best moments combine inspired whimsy with tight control, and make it eminently recommendable to anyone even remotely interested in Buuel's oeuvre and its evolution.

title: PAVEL SEREBRYAKOV, 68, NOTED LENINGRAD PIANIST
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (AP)The pianist Pavel Serebryakov, rector of the Leningrad Conservatory, has died in Leningrad at the age of 68. Tass reported today. The Soviet press agency gave no details.

title: John S. Gillen, Retired Editor At The Philadelphia Inquirer
description: John S. Gillen, retired managing editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, died Wednesday at Bryn Mawr, Pa., Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Laborites Win ByElection in Birmingham by 2 to 1
description: LONDON, Friday, Aug. 19 The Labor Party won a solid victory in a byelection to fill a vacant seat in Parliament yesterday at Birmingham.

title: Publisher Will Take Legal Action On New Child Pornography Law
description: The president of St. Martin's Press, publisher of the sexeducation book Show Me, said yesterday that his company would take legal action on constitutional grounds to prevent the enforcement of part of a new law intended to stop the exploitation of children in pornography.

title: Prison Inmates in Food Boycott
description: ALLENWOOD, Pa., Aug. 18 (AP)A majority of the 514 inmates at the Alenwood Federal Prison Camp are participating in a food boycott for undisclosed reasons, a prison spokesman said today. The food boycott began Tuesday evening, the spokesman said, adding that no grievances had been presented and all activi4 ties were peaceful.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of CarterLance Session
description: I have reviewed the report of the Comptroller of the United States both personally and also with the White House legal counsel, Bob Lipschutz and my faith in the character and competence of Bert Lance has been reconfirmed. I see no other conclusion that can be drawn from any objective analysis of these findings.

title: Folk Art Museum Director Puts Spotlight on Changes
description: The town house setting for what promises to become one of the liveliest stages in town is two blocks east and light years away from Broadway where Robert Bishop was once a hoofer.

title: Miniature Holy Land Undergoes Ordea
description: WATERBURY, Conn. Things just haven't been going right for Holy Land since the Catacombs were torn down and the Garden of Eden burned.

title: Carter to Meet Press Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)President Carter will hold a news conference Tuesday afternoon, his press secretary said today. It will be his first general news conference since July 28. Jody PowII, White House press secretary, said that the Tuesday meeting would be the President's regular news conference.  It will be available for broadcast. Mr. Carter has said that he would hold news conferences twice a month.

title: G. N. P. Growth Slows
description: The gross national product rose 6. 1 percent and inflation increased 7. 1 percent in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported. Both measures were higher than had been forecast by the agency. Page 31.

title: BEAME ORDERS A REVIEW OF USE OF OFFICIAL CARS
description: Mayor Beame has ordered a review of the use of official city cars following reports that many city officials had been using them for unofficial business, in violation of the Mayor's directives.

title: Weiskopf Among Seven Tied At 135 for Westchester Lead
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 19  Tom Weiskopf, who walked out of the 10th Westchester Classic a year ago, saved the 11th Westchester from suffocation today by shooting 64 to tie six others for the lead in the second round.

title: U. S. Drops a Sugar Subsidy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The Justice Department said today that a proposed Agriculture Department subsidy for sugar producers would be illegal.

title: Pirates, Mighty at Home, Defeat Giants
description: If the National League's Eastern D1vision race were decided by home games only, the Pittsburgh Pirates would be a shooin.

title: Brezhnev and Tito Join in Endorsing Independent Roles
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 19The Soviet Union. joined Yugoslavia today in a new pledge of noninterference that tacitly endorsed the independent course that Belgrade has long charted in the Communist move ment.

title: G. N. P. GROWTH SLOWS AND INFLATION RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)The gross national product grew at a slower rate and inflation was worse in the second quarter than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.

title: DR. DONALD COOKSEY, 85, RADIATION LAB PHYSICIST
description: Dr. Donald Cooksey, a physicist who helped organize and direct the Radiation Laboratory of the University of California at Berkeley, died yesterday in Berkeley. He was 33 years old.

title: Csonka, Mullen to Test Knees Versus Chargers
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 19Now is the time for Larry Csonka to come to the aid of his team.

title: Bonn Disputes Brandt on Revival of NeoNazism
description: BONN, Aug. 19The West German Government, in open disagreement with former Chancellor Willy Brandt, said today that neoNazi activities were not a cause for concern and were well under control.

title: Australian Parliament Bans Government Strikes
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 19 (AP) The Australian Parliament outlawed strikes by Government employees today, setting the stage for a showdown between the conservative Government and the trade unions.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Using himself as bait, Dr. Wayne J. Crans captured mosquitoes with a suction tube and canister in a field near salt marshes in Barnegat Bay. At

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: F. B. I. TOLD TO YIELD FILES ON INFORMERS
description: A judge has ruled in unusual secrecy that; the Federal Bureau of Investigation must give its files on 18 informers to lawyers for the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Insuring Health
description: WASHINGTON  A national health insurance system provides government an opportunity to play a major, novel and economically sound role in health maintenance by using financial incentives for patients who complete tests for early *detection of treatable disease. Incentives should include payment for the test to the provider and monetary bonuses to the patients themselves.

title: CryerFord Team Sings At Cookery
description: Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford, who first came to attention as composers of scores for onandoffBroadway musicals, have more recently been concentrating on songs about women, which they have been singing and recording with great success. But now their attention has turned back to the theater and, while they are at the Cookery this week and next, they are singing songs they have written for a new show, along with some of their older pieces.

title: 1,000 to Start Competition In World Rowing Today
description: AMSTERDAM, Aug. 19More than 1,000 participants from 33 countries are entered in the 1977 world rowing championships, which start tomorrow on the Sosbaan course, making this year's event the largest in the history of the sport. The Dutch, sponsors of the regatta, have scheduled the women's events, the lightweight men's rowing, and the men's elite, or heavyweight, racing over eight days, instead of two weeks, as in the past.

title: ASIAN BANKER AGREES TO BUY LANCE'S STOCK
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 19An Indonesian banker and financier, Mochtar Riyady, agreed today to purchase Budget Director Bert Lance's 200,767 shares of stock in the National Bank of Georgia, which Mr. Lance headed before joining the Carter administration.

title: Most Grains Down In Futures Buying; Old Soybeans Up
description: CHICAGO, AUG. 19(AP)  Oldcrop soybeans advanced the limit on the Chicago Board of Trade today but newcrop futures declined 10 cents a bushel and grains closed mostly lower.

title: U. S. Drops Wiretap Case Against F. B. I. Supervisor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Justice Department has dropped the case it was preparing against the onetime superior of a Federal Bureau of Investigation official who is under indictment for wiretapping and mail opening, an. Administration official said today.

title: Train Hits Bus, 6 Argentines Die
description: ROSARIO, Argentina, Aug. 19 (Reuter) Six people were killed today and at least 12 injured when a train crashed into a bus in this city 190 miles north of Buenos Aires, the police said.

title: Pregnant Lobsters Safe in Sound
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Aug. 19Two hundred and eightysix pregnant Maine lobsters were flown to Long Island from Syracuse in an emergency airlift today and were dropped with little ceremony into maternity wards in the Long Island Sound. How many of their eggs will hatch into lobsters, however, is something that may never be known.

title: IDEOLOGICAL SHIFT CONSIDERED LIKELY AT PEKING MEETING
description: PEKING, Aug. 19A mass meeting, apparently the 11th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, was under way in the Great Hall of the People late tonight amid reports that a major shift in the official ideology from revolutionary radicalism to more downtoearth policies would be announced within 24 hours.

title: Monticello Driver's Ban Overturned by U. S. Panel
description: A Federal appeals panel yesterday threw out a Jaw that had enabled New York State to continue the suspension of a harness racing trainer for more than a month without making a final ruling on the trainer's alleged violation.

title: Mrs. Chapot Rides Good News to Title
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 19Mary Chapot rode Good News to the preliminary jumper championship and Sharrar to a tie for the open jumper title today at the Monmouth County Horse Show.

title: ExU. S. Prisoner in Vietnam Says His Torturer Was Cuban Officer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Two former United States prisoners of war in Vietnam believe the man who tortured one of them and 11 of their celimates a decade ago in a small camp outside Hanoi was Cuban military officer.

title: City Bans Flushing Landings, but Airport Stays Open
description: The Beame administration yesterday banned all landings at Flushing Airport in Queens, effective immediately, but the airport continued to operate and its management said it would go to court Monday.

title: nooks of The Times
description: I'm Eve is the story of bizarre neurosis, but it also emerges as a case history of the negotiability and exploitability of celebrity in this country. Christine Costner Sizemore reveals herself, as her litle suggests, as the reallife person upon whom the book and movie The Three Faces of Eve were based. (Another book, The Final Face of Eve, was also written about her, plus several magazine articles over the years, making hers one of the longestrunning public neuroses of our time. )

title: Foster Hits Two, Reds Sweep Mets
description: Tom Seaver was the man everyone was talking about before the New York Mets twilightnight doubleheader against Cincinnati at Shea Stadium last night. After the Reds had swept the Mets, 41 and 43, the man everyone was talking about was George Foster.

title: Fed Decides on 6% Funds Rate to Ease Money Rise
description: The Federal Reserve decided on Aug. 5 to permit the Federal funds rate, the key shortterm interest rate of the money market, to trade as high as 6 percent in an effort to slow down the extremely rapid arowth of the money supply that occurred in July.

title: South Africa Is Planning a Wider Role for Minorities
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 19The South African Government, under growing pressure to abandon exclusively white rule, reported to have completed a constitutional review and to have settled on system that would allow Asians and those of mixed race, but not blacks, to share political power.

title: SPASSKY TOPS PORTISCH, SET TO PLAY KORCHNOI
description: GENEVA, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Grandmaster Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union today defeated Lajos Portisch, a Hungarian, in a world chess championship Candidate's Match and qualified to play Viktor Korchnoi in the final of the qualifying tournament.

title: Accord Lacking on Wheat Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)Representatives of four major wheatexporting countries reached no specific agreements on the form of a new international wheat trading pact during a twoday closed meeting here, a joint statement said today. Officials of the United States, Argentina, Australia and Canada did. identify areas for further examination by the respective govenrnents, a spokesman said.

title: Lefkowitz Begins an Investigation Of Backgammon Tourney Venture
description: The New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, yesterday ordered an immediate investigation into a milliondollar Las Vegas backgammon tournament whose promoter had reportedly attracted as much as $400,000 in entry fees by promising to keep the money in an escrow account that turned out. not to exist.

title: An Emotional Reunion Of Girl Scouts of 37
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 19  Did you see the tears? asked Mrs. Olwyn Nugent of Gisborne, N. Y., as she tromped around Camp Andree Clark with 55 other women from all over the United States and 15 other countries in a reunion of participants in an international gathering of Girl Scouts and Girl Guides held here in 1937.

title: DiseaseCarrying Mosquitoes Are Hunted
description: PORT NORRIS, N. J., Aug. 19No cases of eastern equine encephalitis have been reported among humans in New Jersey for more than four years, and publid health officials believe that there is little likelihood of an outbreak of the mosquitoborne disease this summer.

title: Cape Codder System Inc. Files Chapter XI Bankruptcy Petition
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 19 (AP)Cape Codder System Inc., franchiser of Cape Codder Seafood Restaurants, has filed for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: WILLIAM J. ERWIN, AT 76; RETIRED DAN RIVER HEAD
