description: William J. Erwin, former chairman and chief executive officer of Dan River Inc., a textile concern, died yesterday at Duke University Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Danville, Va.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: REWARD FOR DILIGENCE: Five of 25 policemen who were promoted yesterday for their work in. 44caliberkiller case saluting during national anthem at Police Headquarters. From left: Timothy Dowd, Joseph Sorrell, George C. Hambrecht, James Chillis and Michael Cataneo Jr. Page

title: Two Dow Averages at 1977 Lows For 4th Session as Volume Sags
description: The stock market weighed conflicting developments yesterday and finally resolved its dilemma by moving downward once again. The worry over rising interest rates, along with signs of a slowing economy, tipped the scales in a dull session.

title: East Germans Dominate Swim Meet in Sweden
description: JONKOPING, Sweden, Aug. 19 (AP)Eastern bloc nations swept all five titles today in the final session of the 14th European swimming championAlps, with East Germany winning three gold medals for a total of 11 in five days.

title: Ted Cowell
description: DEMONSTRATORS ARRESTED: Police attempt to move members of Youth in Action group away from New York Stock Exchange yesterday. About 200 members of group marched on Wall Street Thursday, camped overnight at Battery Park, and attempted to close down the exchange yesterday. About 15 of the protestors were arrested in the incident, which was intended to focus attention on the need for jobs for youth in the nation's inner cities.

title: VICE PRESIDENT HEARS TEACHER GRIEVANCES
description: BOSTON, Aug. 19 Vice President Mondale told a convention of 2,500 teachers here today that the Carter Administration was committed as giving classroom teachers a greater role in education policy. He then demonstrated that cornmitment by sitting down with 20 veterans of the classroom to hear what was on their mind.

title: Somalis Said to Resume Offensive
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug, 19 (UPI) Somalis today renewed their attacks near a major Ethiopian stronghold, pressing their offensive to capture all of the Ogaden region of southeastern Ethiopia, diplomatic sources in the Kenyan capital here said today.

title: Black Labor Union Recognized by Ford
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 19 (AP) The Ford Motor Company and SKF Industries have recognized South Africa's predominantly black United Automobile Workers union, The Johannesburg Star reperted today.

title: Arson Task Force Is Credited With Reducing Fires
description: In its first 10 days of operations, New York City's arson task force, which was set up to combat the recent rash of suspicious fires in Brooklyn and the Bronx, made 14 arrests, the Beame administration said yesterday, and had reduced suspicious fires in Bushwick, Brownsville and East New York sections of the borough by 60 percent.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended June 30 unless otherwise indicated.

title: Plans Set to Convert Trenton Prison Into a Model Correctional Facility
description: TRENTON, Aug. 19  Plans for converting Trenton State Prison, one of the oldest active penal institutions in the country. into a model correctional facility, were announced today by Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, State Commissioner of Corrections.

title: Talks on Copper Pact Snagged
description: A fourth round of consumerproducer talks on a proposed international marketstabilization agreement for copper failed to make any headway yesterday in Geneva. As a result, the United Nations Commission on Trade and Development was urged to draft further market and feasibility studies to serve as the basis for fifth round of talks in November.

title: CHASE REALTY TRUST CUTS OPERATING LOSS
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust. a real estate investment Trust trying to work its way out of its financial troubles, yesterday reported sharply lower operating loss for its latest fiscal year and its first net profit since fiscal 1974.

title: 2dQuarter Profits Of Business Surge, To Top $ 100 Billion
description: Rebounding from the deep freeze of the first quarter, corporate profits after taxes in the second quarter reached $104. 1 billion, exceeding the $100 billion mark for the first time, according to preliminary figures reported yesterday by the Commerce Department in Washington.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENMrs. Gertrude Katherine, 72 of 168 Orleans Circle, Norfolk, Va., died In her residence Friday. She was a native of New York and former school secretary of St. Peter's and Paul's School, Bronx, survived by 2 daughters, Mrs. Roberta Grosso, Norfolk, Mrs. Sandi Doman, Jacksonville, N. C., and 2 sons, Donald J. Allen, West Orange, N. J., and William A.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Ideal Basic Industries, producer of cement and potash, said that seven defendant companies, including itself, had agreed to pay in varying amounts a total of $3. 2 million to settle the potash antitrust trebledamage action now pending in Federal Court in Chicago.

title: REP. NIX SCORES BID TO END SATURDAY MAIL DELIVERIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)Congress should be given the authority to block any attempt to eliminate Saturday mail delivery, Representative Robert N C. Nix, chairman of the House Post Office Committee, said today.

title: Israel Refuses to Accept Protest By Common Market on Settlements
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Israel has refused to accept a protest by the European Common Market on the establishment of Israeli settlements in occupied Arab territory, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.

title: 80 Injured in Plane Evacuation After Engine Stalls in Honolulu
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 19 (AP)Eighty persons were injured, none seriously, when a Philippine Airlines jetliner was evacuated today after an engine stalled at the, Honolulu International Airport.

title: ELIZABETH NESBITT
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19Elizabeth Nesbitt, a library science educator and specialist in library work with children, died of cancer Wednesday in Atlantic City, N. J. She was 80 years old.

title: OFFICIALS EMPHASIZE U. S LINKS TO TAIWAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19On the eve of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's trip to China, Carter Administration officials have gone out of their way to stress that the United States will refuse to normalize ties if it means giving even the appearance of abandoning Taiwan.

title: JUDGE WON'T REINSTRUCT JURORS IN MANDEL'S TRIAL
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 19Federal District Judge Walter L. Taylor today rejected for the weekend at least a proposal, made yesterday by the Federal prosecutors in the trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, that the judge summon the jury for reinstruction. The jury ended its ninth day of deliberations tonight without ireturning verdicts.

title: Lance Issue Prompts Wide Inquiry Into Comptroller Office Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The inquiry into the financial activities of Budget Director Bert Lance has touched off fullscale examination of the standards and methods used by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency in regulating the nation's banks, wellplaced officials said today.

title: Women Deacons Urged By Baltimore Archbishop
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 (AP)Archbishop William D. Borders of Baltimore has called for an increasing role for women in the Roman Catholic Church, but he stopped short of urging their ordination.

title: Irwin Smith, 85, Wrote 2 Books On Shakespeare's Playhouses
description: Irwin Smith, author of Shakespeare's Globe Playhouse and Shakespeare's Blackfriars Playhouse, died Wednesday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I., after a long illness. He lived at 67 Hilton Avenue, Garden City, L. I., and was 85 years old.

title: East Ramapo Teachers Ask State To Intervene in District's Pay Cuts
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Aug. 19The East Ramapo Teachers Association has filed improperpractice charges against the largest school district in Rockland, County under new provisions of the State Taylor Law. The provisions give the Public Employment Relations Board the power to seek a court injunction against either side in a publicemployment dispute if there has been a failure to negotiate fairly.

title: Yanks Name a Vice President
description: The New York Yankees appointed Marsh Samuel yesterday to the post of a vice president in charge of marketing and public relations. Samuel, a veteran public relations counsel, previously worked with the Chicago White Sox, Cleveland Indians and Cleveland Browns. He also has worked outside sports. The Yankees owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, is among his business clients.

title: Many British Flights Disrupted By Slowdown of Controller Aides
description: LONDON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Many flights to and from Britain were delayed or canceled today when a goslow job action by air traffic control assistants severely disrupted London's two main airports.

title: Great Western United Discloses Loss of $2. 8Million in 3d Quarter
description: The Great Western United Corporation, which is largest domestic beet sugar processor, and a leading cane sugar refiner, yesterday reported a net loss of $2. 8 million in the third fiscal quarter ended June 30, in contrast to a net income of $9. 7 million, or $4. 17 a share, for the corresponding quarter last year.

title: Debbie Austin Is Ahead By 3 Strokes With 67
description: WHEELING, V. Va., Aug. 19 (AP)Debbie Austin, The 1977 success story in the tour of the Ladies Professional Gall Association, conquered the diffilull course at Speidel Golf Club with a fiyeunderpar 67 today and took a threeshot lead in the first round of the $50,000 Wheeling Classic. She is trying to gain her fifth victory of the year.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: UNUSUAL TOURIST ATTRACTION: The bow of the Greek tanker Apollonian Wave, which ran aground last December, is now an attraction at the beach near Mimizan, on France's southwest Atlantic coast. The tanker, about 350 feet long, had its oil pumped out after ran aground, preventing any pollution of the beach.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state granted New Jersey Blue Shield an average rate increase of 9. 9 percent for almost 1. 6 million subscribers of the medical Insurance plan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: R. Bruce Brougham was inadvertently identified in yesterday's Times as the author of a Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company memo describing Bert. Lance's request for, a personal loan:

title: Personal Investing
description: The investment managers at the Marine Midland Bank, whose pension and trust funds are performing better than most, have become progressively bearish on both stocks and bonds.

title: Figures on Short Interest Listed
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 2,221. 309 shares to 30. 068,903 shares in he month ended Aug. 15. The short interest a year earlier totaled 22,809,707 shares.

title: 2 Held in Robert Topping Staying
description: MIAMI, Aug. 19 (UPI) Two teenagers have been charged in the cocainerelated stabbing death of Robert Reed Topping, son of the late owner of the New York Yankees, Dan Topping Sr. The younger Mr. Topping, a 20yearold student at Emory University, was stabbed 33 times before his body was pushed from a moving car in Miami's Little River area Tuesday night. Yesterday, the police charged Barry Adler, 18, of Miami, with first degree murder in the slaying. Andrew Schel, 18, was charged as an accessors.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA solar energy converter invented at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is expected to provide supplemental electricity and hot water for homes at a competitive cost.

title: Bergen Republicans, After ToDo, Admit Women to Stag Golf Outing
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 19 The Bergen County Republican Party, never known for its tranquillity, has been flustered all week by the latest flap, this one about a stag golf outing.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARKS, Cunningham Park, Queens, 8. 30.

title: H. WERNER BUCK
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP)H. Wermen's shows the past three dcades, died ner Buck, a producer of major sportsof heart failure this morning while attending a fishing tackle show in Kansas City, o., a family spokesman here said. He was 59 years old, a resident of the Los Angeles suburb of Tarzana and a native of Kalispell, Mont.

title: Madison Square Garden Corp.  Taken Over by Gulf P Western
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 19Gulf and Western Industries completed its eightyear campaign to absorb the Madison Square Garden Corporation and its sports holdings this morning after hectic final stockholders meeting at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Serious Business at Summer Camps
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Aug. 19Frank Burns pounds spoon on the table for attention. He has something very important to. say, and there is this look of nononsense in his deep, darkbrown eyes. Frank Burns would have made great Kamikaze pilot.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 20, 1977
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 20, 1977

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A PunkRock Group Returns
description: Not to be confused with Torn Petty and the Heartbreakers, the Heartbreakers are a punkrock quartet that grew out of the original New York Dolls. Johnny Thunders, guitarist, and Jerry Nolan, drummer, come from the Dolls; the others are Walter Lure, guitarist, and also, along with Mr. Thunders, singer and front man, and Billy Rath, bassist.

title: M'DERMOTT RAISES ITS BID FOR BABCOCK
description: The fight to gain control of Babcock & Wilcox brought another increased bid yesterday from J. Ray McDermott & Cornpany$60 a share for 4. 3 million shares of Babcock.

title: S. E. C. HIRES TRIAL LAWYERS IN A SHIFT TO LITIGATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission has hired several experienced trial lawyers and promoted others in a unique reversal for a Federal agency, its enforcement director, Stanley Sporkin, said today.

title: Three Children Die in Fire
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP)Three children were killed and five persons were injured yesterday when fire engulfed a small apartment here. The fire apparently started when the childrens father brought a gasoline container too close to a flame on the kitchen stove, firemen said.

title: The Law Went Dark, Too
description: In the 24 hours following the blackout last month, nearly 3,800 people were arrested. Confined under wretched conditions, their whereabouts unknown to friends and relatives, most were held for days, many up to a week before being brought to court.

title: Primary Roundup
description: The Citizens Union endorsed Representative Edward 1. Koch yesterday as its preferred candidate in the sevenway Democratic primary for Mayor and State Senator Roy M. Goodman as its choice in the Republican mayoral primary, which may or may not be held.

title: Torrez Cools Off Rangers For 6th Victory in Row, 81
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 19Mike Torrez, pitching his sixth straight completegame victory for the New York Yankees, tightened up both American League pennant races tonight by heating the Texas Rangers, 31, with the aid of five unearned runs and basesempty home runs by Reggie Jackson and Roy White.

title: Paying Fairer Dues in the South
description: In recent years the Snowbelt has developed an inferiority complex. The Sunbelt states have appeared to be the promised land for business, a land with buoyant local markets and relatively cheap labor, energy and real estate. The North, with its aging industrial plant, vigorous labor unions, and costly imported oil, found itself at a serious disadvantage.

title: Flushing Landings Banned by City, But the Airport Contiues to Operate
description: The Beame administration yesterday banned all landings at Flushing Airport in Queens, effective immediately, but the airport continued to operate, and its management said it would ask a court Monday to determine whether the city's order was legal.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: BEAUVAIS DUFFY
description: Beauvais Duffy, an engineering executitre with Bethelem Steel and American Chain & Cable, died Aug. 10 in Philadelphia. Mr. Duffy, who was 63 years old, had lived for more than 50 years in Point Pleasant Beach, N. J.

title: Vesco Family Suit Is Filed
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19 (AP))A suit that would retain some family interest in the company headed by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, was filed today in Federal court in behalf of Mr. Vesco's infant daughter, Dawn. It seeks to block a courtordered transfer of stock to the International Controls Corporation in Florida. The suit seeks to have any certificates transferred returned, said Joseph Foglia of New York, the infant's lawyer.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES SCHOOL WHERE BOY, 13, WAS SLAIN
description: ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP)A team of investigators reported today that David Smith, a 13yearold who was stabbed and beaten to death by other youths at a state institution for juvenile delinquents, had complained before the incident about being hassled by others, but that nothing was done.

title: Montgomery Takes 200
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 19Jim Montgomery won the men's 200meter freestyle tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national longcourse swimming championships. He almost broke the world record held by Bruce Furniss.

title: The New York Times
description: CARRYING A MESSAGE: The Voyager spacecraft being lifted onto the TitanCentaur booster rocket in preparation for today's launching to outer planets of solar system. Craft will carry recorded message from earth. Page

title: Church Group Urges Court to Free Minister Who kefused to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The National Council of Churches of Christ urged a Federal appellate court today to release a Scientology minister who was jailed for contempt after refusing to testify before a grand jury about documents allegedly stolen from the Government by a Scientology agent.

title: Commodity Price Index Declined 1. 2 From Level of a Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 200. 2 from 201. 4 last week.

title: U. S. Accuses Miami's Republic Bank Of Discriminatory Hiring Practices
description: MIAMI, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Treasury Department says the Republic National Bank's hiring practices are discriminatory only five of its 173 employees are white Americans. The Latinowned bank, the nation's largest minorityowned lending institution, has 168 Latin employees, both white and black.

title: Delay on Commonwealth Oil Investment Tie Is Asked
description: The beleaguered Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said yesterday that the antitrust division of the Justice Department had asked it to delay for 30 days the effective date of an investment agreement with the Ashland Oil Company.

title: MARK KAPLAN RESIGNS AS PRESIDENT OF DREXEL
description: Mark N. Kaplan, president of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, a Wall Streetbased brokerage house is resigning to join a leading industrial company.

title: Earthquake Strikes Indian Ocean; It May Be the Strongest on Record
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 19  A powerful earthquake, possibly the strongest ever recorded, struck the eastern Indian Ocean between Australia and Indonesia today, rattling tall buildings as far away as Perth, Australia, 1.000 miles to the south.

title: Search Warrant in Berkowitz Case Was Sought 4 Days Before Arrest
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 19An investigator from the Westchester County sheriff's office tried in vain to get a search warrant to enter the apartment of David R. Berkowitz on Saturday, Aug. 6, four days before the 24yearold postal worker v as arrested as the suspected. 44caliber killer, the office said today.

title: Tennessee Nuclear Plant To Cost $1 Billion Extra
description: KNOXVILLE, Aug. 19 (AP)The Ten nessee Valley Authority's proposed Hartsville Nuclear Plant in central Tennessee will cost $1 billion more than anticipated, officials of the Government utility said today.

title: Alabama Miners Join In Spreading Walkouts
description: Alabama miners have joined the wildcat; strikes in the Appalachian coal fields, apparently dashing hopes for a quick ends to the walkout that began in West Virginia eight weeks ago and spread to involve, some 80,000 miners in five states.

title: A Sampler of Groucho Marx Wit
description: Groucho: Oscar [Levant], you look tired. Why don't you come to my house for dinner? I've got the most wonderful cook in town, I've saved a steak four inches thick and we'll have a dessert that's nut of this world.

title: Codd Thanks a Diligent Officer
description: On Aug. 9, the day before the alleged Son of Sam killer was arrested, a 30yearold Bronx police officer, Dennis Roberts, captured a man long sought in a murder case and in the subsequent attempted murder of a witness.

title: Letter & Reply
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 12 editorial support for the incredible Panama Canal treaty is grossly misinformed, the apparent victim of an intensive and equally misinformed propaganda campaign from the Administration.

title: The New York Times
description: CARRYING A MESSAGE: The Voyager spacecraft being lifted onto the TitanCentaur booster rocket in preparation for today's launching to outer planets of solar system. Craft will carry recorded message from earth. Page

title: William P. Allen, Retired Judge Who Set Up Florida Appeals Court
description: BARTOW, Fla., Aug. 19 William P. Allen, a retired judge who was instrumental in setting'up Florida's Second District Court of Appeal in Lakeland, died Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: Wholesale Gasoline Cut 0.7c By Texaco in Face of Brief Glut
description: The reduction is effective on all grades of gasoline in all parts of the country, except certain parts of the Great Plains and North Central regions, company spokesmen said. Facing a shortterm glut of crude oil and large inventories of gasoline and other refined products, other major oil concerns have reduced their wholesale prices.

title: Durables Report Rescheduled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters )The Commerce Department said that the July report on durable goods orders, originally scheduled for today, had been tentatively rescheduled for Monday.

title: Give Con Ed's Experiment a Chance
description: Poor Con Edison can't do anything to please. When it sought to build large generating plants in the city, it was accused of threatening the environment. When it imported electricity from distant plants, it was berated for despoiling the countryside with its transmission wires not to mention the nowobvious fact that it left its system vulnerable to acts of God.  So what happens when Con Edison proposes to build a small power unit in Manhattan, one that is unusually clean and close to the customers? More complaints. But this time they are illfounded.

title: Teacher Loses Fight Over Dress Regulation
description: A teacher in East Hartford, Conn., lost a court battle yesterday against a school regulation requiring him to wear a jacket and tie in class.

title: G. A. O. Charges Poor Management Killed U. S. Bid to Turn Coal to Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)Inadequate planning, incredibly poor management and a 211 percent cost overrun killed the Government's first effort to turn coal into cleanburning synthetic oil, Congressional investigators reported today.

title: GROUCHO MARX DIES; COMEDIAN WAS 86
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19Groucho Marx died today at the age of 86.

title: Miniature Holy Land Undergoes Ordeal
description: WATERBURY, Conn. Things just haven't been going right for Holy Land since the Catacombs were torn down and the Garden of Eden burned.

title: Rowland Cox, 49, Head of Groton; Helped Make School Coeducational
description: Rowland Cox, the head of Groton School who helped bring about the change of the allboys preparatory school into a coeducational institution two years ago, died yesterday of cancer in Naushoba Hospital in Groton. He was 49 years old.

title: REDWOOD PARK COSTS RAN $100 MILLION OVER BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Four major timber companies have been paid nearly $100 million more than Congress authorized when the Government bought land for the Redwood National Park, Congressional auditors said today.

title: ZALE CHARGED BY S. E. C.  WITH STOCK VIOLATIONS
description: DALLAS, Aug. 19 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit against the Zale Corporation today, charging the company with securities fraud violations, including incometax evasion and operation of an illegal slush fund.

title: Senate Decision on Canal Pact Unlikely Till January
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Officials said today that although the Carter Administration still hoped for Senate approval of the new Panama Canal treaties by the end of the year, it recognized that the decision would probably be put off until January.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE GOOD EARTH Weekend museum browsers can take in a new show titled The Grand Landscape: Paintings of the American Romantic Period at the NewYork Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street. These are largescale pictures from the museum's collection of 19thcentury art.

title: About New York
description: The breathtaking breadth of New York harbor Is beneath their eyes, a blue sculptured gameboard on which they are moving pieces. From the 53d floor of 1 World Trade Center, the two men listen to staccato radio, pick up telephones and, in quiet voices, spin out their big game.

title: A Cast of Young Actors Turns the Spotlight on the Problems Teens Face
description: It looks, at first, like a TV soap. Jasmine becomes pregnant antlpust break the news to a furious mother. Johnny is an abused and battered runaway. Tina's wealthy father gives her little love or discipline. Lorna is a shy, overweight girl who feigns a familiarity with men that is obviously and pathetically contrived. Karen is a heavy drinker. Kandy is sensual and sexually aggressive.

title: Oil Bought for U. S. Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The Federal Energy Administration announced today the purchase of some 16 million barrels of crude oil for the nation's new strategic petroleum reserve, the planned insurance policy against any future cutoff of foreign oil. The oil was bought for $212. 17 million, an average of $13. 26 a barrel.

title: Music: Witty, Winning Arlo Guthrie Rambles Round
description: The nice thing about playing a little club like this, y'know, is that you don't have to know what you're doing, Arlo Guthrie said during Thursday's early show at the Other End, where he concludes a threenight engagement this evening. That may betrue of some performers, but Mr. Guthrie is very definitely not one of them.

title: A Strange Link Continues In the Fortunes of 2 Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 19That strange bond that somehow ties Tommy Marvaso to the fortunes of Shafer Suggs continues.

title: Dollar Shows a Decline in Europe
description: The dollar was generally lower in foreign exchange trading yesterday, and posted a shrarp drop against the Swiss franc, the Associated Press reported.

title: Bridge:
description: Players who open the bidding with rather less than the usual quota of highcard points regularly find themselves at higher levels than others would reach with the same cards.

title: Republic National Bank Sets Up Midtown Factoring Subsidiary
description: Expanding to meet what it believes is a fastgrowing source of income, the Republic. National Bank of New York has established Republic Factors, a new factoring operation at 1114 Avenue of the Americas, and has named David Rubin as president.

title: Huge Illegal Drug Lab Is Seized in Dallas
description: DALLAS, Aug. 19The largest illegal drug laboratory ever found in the United States was seized here yesterday by agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: Jim Sheppard, Stunt Man, Killed While Doubling in Robards Western
description: WESTCLIFFE, Colo., Aug. 19 (AP)Jim Sheppard, a movie stuntman, who was doubling for the actor Jason Robards. was killed here yesterday while being dragged by a horse during filming of Comes a Horseman, Wild and Free, the Custer, County Sheriff's Department said.

title: DR. ASHLEY WEECH, 82, A PEDIATRICS EXPERT
description: Dr. A, Ashley Weech, president of the American Pediatric Society in 1957 and 1958, a widely known educator, died Wednesday in his home in Gainesville, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: DiseaseBearing Mosquitoes Are Hunted in Salt Marshes
description: PORT NORRIS, Aug. 19 No cases of eastern equine encephalitis have been reported among humans in New Jersey for more than four years, and public health officials believe that there is little likeliifood of an outbreak of the mosquitoborne disease this summer.

title: Pennsylvania House Votes Budget, Ending Impasse
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Saturday, Aug. 20 (AP)The Pennsylvania House of Representatives passed a new state budget early today after more than 8,000 state workers called in sick yesterday to pro1 est a sevenweek deadlock that left them without paychecks.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PLANS WIDER MINORITY ROLE
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 19The South African Government, under growing pressure to abandon exclusively white rule, is reported to have completed a constitutional review and to have settled on a system that would allow Asians and those of mixed race, but not blacks, to share political power.

title: Radio
description: 6 A. M., WNYCAM. Ich Freu Mich, Heinrich Schutz; Ricercar; Gabtleli; L'Olica, Canzon Per Sonar, Correggio; Non Rumor di. Ramburi, Bell'Haver.

title: Lobsters Oust Nets, Meet Apples in Next Round
description: BOSTON, Aug. 19The New York Apples will open the Eastern Division finals of World Team Tennis here tomorrow night against the Boston Lobsters in a twoofthree match series.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CUNARD PRINCESS (Cunard). Left Bermuda Aug. 18; due 8 A. M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Israelis on Lebanon Line Ignore War, Not Good Fence
description: METULLA, Israel  In the evening people who have come to this little town in the foothills of Mount Hermon for a rest and the clear, fresh air play cards or watch TV dramas on the terraces of the modest hotels along the sinele street. At the foot of the street is the elaborately Hired fence dividing Israel rom Lebanon, and just across the border shells burst. flares drift down and machine guns jabber all night long.

title: Backing of Parking Plan Explained
description: Environmental groups that had been pressing New York City to implement strict trafficcontrol program to help reduce auto fumes in the air said yesterday that they had agreed to a looser compromise plan because it finally got the city moving.

title: The Magical Beaux Arts Trio Totally Fine at Mostly Mozart
description: Ordinarily, chamber musicespecially the kind playable by a trio consisting of piano, violin and cellois not thought of as best seller in the concert business world, but patrons of Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival seem not to have gotten the word.

title: SRILANKA WIDENS CURFEW IN MOVE TO QUELL RIOTING
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 19 (AP) The Government imposed a curfew on the city of Kandy in central Sri Lanka today amid continued efforts to quell communal violence in which 14 persons have been killed.

title: Courageous Wins Again At Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 19Ted Turner and his crew aboard Courageous trounced Enterprise by 8 minutes 21 seconds here today at the America's Cup trials, and afterward Turner was anything but humble.

title: BARUCH SHEFNER
description: Baruch Shefner, a member of the news staff of The Jewish Daily Forward since arriving in this country from Poland in 1941, died Thursday in New York University Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 575 Grand Street and was 81 years. old.

title: Groucho Marx, Comedian, Dead; Movie Star and TV Host Was 86
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19Groucho Marx, the comedian, died tonight at the Cedar Sinai Medical Center here after failing to recover from a respiratory ailment that hospitalized him June 22. He was 86 years old.

title: Miss Daniel Gains Final, 1 Up
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Aug. 19 (AP)Cathy Reynolds, a comedalist, and the United States Amateur champion, Beth Daniel, meet tomorrow in the final of the women's transnational golf championship, Miss Reynolds, of Springfield, Mo., eliminated Julie Stanger of Phoeenix, Ariz, 3 and 2, to gain the final. Miss Daniel, of Charleston, S. C., ousted Jerry Keil of Toledo, Ohio, I up.

title: Tomato Patch Kid is Primed for a Travers Harvest
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 His mother couldn't win for a $2,000 claiming price, and his father lost 43 of 45 races.

title: Colombia Cuts Coffee Tax
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Colombian Government has cut the tax on coffee exports, hoping to stimulate sales of Colombian coffee. An official communiqu announced that the tax was lowered by $47. 25 per 154 pound sack. It was the third reduction in the tax in six weeks. It was reduced by $38. 50 July 11, and by another $15. 50 on July 15.

title: 26 Fire Bombs Explode In Center of Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 19 (AP) Twentysix small fire bombs exploded during a 90minute period last night in bars and stores in the center of Belfast, the fire department reported.

title: Steel Pier in Atlantic City May Become CasinoHotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 19  The Steel Pier, a landmark here since before 1900, was earmarked today for conversion to a $75 million, fourblocklong Casino at Sea that would be housed in a siloshaped hotel where all guests would have oceanfront rooms.

title: News Summary
description: An earthquake, possibly the strongest ever recorded, struck the eastern Indian Ocean between Australia and Indonesia, shaking tall buildings in Perth, Australia, 1,000 miles to the south. There were no immediate reports of injuries. The Indonesian islands closest to the quake's epicenter are relatively isolated, and reports from the area were delayed. Earthquake monitoring stations around the world indicated that the strength of the tremor was between 7. 7 and 8. 9 on the Richter scale. [Page 1, Columns 45. ]

title: Inquiry Asked on Election Aide Charged With Business Activities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)Senator Dick Clark, Democrat of Iowa, called today for a Congressional investigation of reports of outside business activities by Robert O. Tiernan, a member of the Federal Election Commission.

title: Moiseyev of U. S. S. R. Wins 10,000 at University Games
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 19 (AP)Leonid Moisyev, of the Soviet Union, pulled away from Franco Fava of Italy in a furious sprint down the stretch to win the 10,000 meters at the World University Games tonight.

title: Colts Defense Excels in 297 Rout of Vikings
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 (AP)The Baltimore Colts converted two firsthalf fumble recoveries into touchdowns, one on a Bert Jones pass, and frustrated four Minnesota scoring chances to beat the Vikings, 297, in a National Football League exhibition game tonight.

title: Police Kill Soweto Black In Raid on High School
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 19 (AP) The police shot dead one black youth and seriously wounded another in Soweto today after raiding a high school where, they said, some students were holding lessons on how to make fire bombs and booby traps.

title: Clean (Cough) Air
description: NEW HAVENCongress has reluctantly permitted the public to buy new cars this fall. Until its lastminute revision, the Clean Air Act would have outlawed all further production.

title: Song Styles Happily Mix
description: Jimmy Miller, who's at Imus's Musicroom, 50 East 54th Street, through next Saturday, has begun to make a name for himself on the local cabaret circuit. A tall, lean black man originally from North Carolina, Mr. Miller sings in throaty baritone in a style that blvds several idioms that do not always complement one another cotfortably. Backed by a threepiece jazzish trio, he ranges from gospel exhortations to 1960's solo shouting to Broadway emoting to cabaret intimacies to jazz.

title: Forest Service Restricts Logging In Alaska During Record Dry Spell
description: JUNEAU. Alaska. Aug. 19 (AP)The Forest Service imposed extraordinary restrictions on commercial logging in the Tongass National Forest today because a record dry spell is causing a fire hazard in the 10millionacre rain forest.

title: Farm Agency Aide Appointed
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 19 (AP)Former Lieut. Gov. Brian D. Burns of Vermont was appointed today as regional director of the Farmers Home Administration, in charge of the agency in five New England states, Senator Patrick J.

title: SovietFinanced Company Made Arms for NATO
description: LONDON, Aug. 19 A Ministry of Defense spokesman acknowledged today that a small number of unclassified items for British defense contracts had been made by a company financed by the Moscow Narodny Bank, a Soviet institution.

title: Taxpayer Revolt Gains in Chicago Suburbs,
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19Taxes are immoral, intoned the speaker, and 350 normally sedate, mostly elderly homeowners shouted their approval.

title: Kennecott, 2 Others Join 7. 7% Cut in Copper Price
description: Three more companies, including the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the industry's giant, joined yesterday in a 7. 7 percent cut in copper prices.

title: Consumer Agency Issues New Warning on Tris
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission,: has issued a new warning to retailers: who are still selling children's sleepwear; treated with the banned flame retardant Tris.

title: Greek Fire Or NBomb?
description: ANKARAEvery time a major new weapons system is developed by ingenious technicians, humanity itself is appalled. During the Middle Ages the Byzantine Empire's secret weapon, Greek fire, was outlawed by the papacy as too horrible. Yet it continued to be used effectively for some decadesan inflammatory mixture of pitch, oil and sulphur that devastated warships and their crews.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: R. Bruce Brougham was inadvertently identified in yesterday's Times as the author of a Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company memo describing Bert Lance's request for a personal loan.

title: Dutch Christian Democrats Reject Compromise Plan on Abortion Issue
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 19 (Reuters) The Christian Democratic Party tonight rejected Prime Minister Joop M. den Uyl's proposals on changes in the abortion law, bringing talks on the formation of a new centerleft cabinet in the Netherlands to the verge of collapse.

title: U. S. Gains Semifinals
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Aug. 19 (AP)Lee Trevino birdied the 18th hole to seize a half with Scotland's Brian Barnes and insure the United States a semifinal berth in the Double Diamond World Golf Classic today.

title: MARITIME UNIT FINE AGAINST SONY PAID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The Federal Maritime Commission announced today that it had accepted a $340,000 fine from Japan's Sony Corporation and its United States subsidiary to settle a case in which the company had been accused of accepting illegal rebates.

title: Dividends
description: xrecord Zs payable dates being corrected, due to error by Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: REWARD FOR DILIGENCE: Five of 25 police officers who were promoted yesterday for their work in. 44caliberkiller case saluting during national anthem at Police Headquarters. From left: Timothy Dowd, Joseph Borrell, George C. Hambrecht, James Chillis and Michael Cataneo Jr. Page

title: South African Gang Seizes Uncut Gems Worth $3. 5 Million
description: CAPE TOWN. Aug. 19 (UPI) Robbers forced diamond dealer to go to his factory by threatening to kill his family, then blinded him with acid and escaped with more than $3. 5 million in diamonds, the police said today.

title: Dayan Says Plan Gains Support
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19 Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan said today that his plat for Israel and Jordan to divided adminis trative functions instead of territory the disputed West Bank was gaining ad. herents on the other side.  He said the United States was also showing interest.

title: 9 Canadian Premiers Reject Deal For Easing Quebec Language Bill
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 19 The premiers of the nine predominantly Englishspeaking provinces of Canada have turned down an offer by Premier Rent Levesque of Frenchspeaking Quebec to soften the planned restraints on Englishlanguage education in his province if the others would guarantee more schooling in French in theirs:

title: CARTER USED A PLANE OF BANK AS CANDIDATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19  President Carter made two political campaign trips in 1975 aboard a corporate aircraft belonging to Budget Director Bert Lance's former Georgia bank, the White House said today.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT FRIDAY, Aug. 19, 1977. Petition Filed Br:

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who on Wednesday underwent surgery that revealed he has %operable cancer, got up yesterday apparently ft eling good and walked in his room at the University of Minnesota Hospital in Minneapolis. The 66yearold Senator was said to have slept well after the surgery, which found an inoperable tumor in the pelvis. He is on his way to a superb recovery, said a hospital statement. The Senator will undergo chemotherapy, a continuation of treatments begun last October after Senator Humphrey had a cancerous bladder removed. Aides said yesterday he hoped to be back at his desk in midSeptember.

title: Dr. King's Old Organization Joins Chorus of Black Critics of Carter
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 19The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 's organizational legacy, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, concluded its 20th anniversary meeting in Atlanta today, and its major message was clear: The nation's black leaders are sorely disappointed in the Presidency of Jimmy Carter.

title: CONSUMER PRICE RISE OA% FOR LAST MONTH, SMALLEST THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Consumer prices rose fourtenths of 1 percent in July, the smallest monthly increase of the year, thanks in large measure to a decline in grocery food prices, the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index showed today.

title: Donor of Police Horses Unveiled
description: Back in June, a wealthy Texan gave the New York City police 20 purebred Tennessee walking horses, the fanciest mounts they ever had, on the condition that his identity be kept secret.

title: U. S. BANKERS CONFERRING WITH PERUVIANS ON DEBT
description: Representatives of 20 major United States banks met yesterday with tap Peruvian officials to work out arrangements for the repayment of $1 billion in loans this year against a backdrop of possible default, according to United Press International.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 20, 1977

title: Thai Official Says Rising Was Averted in Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 19 (AP) A senior Thai military commander said today that neighboring Cambodia crushed a projected uprising in February and that the Cambodian President had been stripped of power in a shakeup.

title: Top Rank Gains in Suit Over AliShavers Bout
description: A Federal appeals court put Top Rank Inc., a boxing promoter back in its court battle with Madison Square Garden over next month's Muhammad AliEarnie Shavers heavyweight title bout.

title: Brazilthn Out of MillionDollarJob
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 19The salary that Walter Clark, a 42yearold Brazilian television executive, took in last year put him ahead of Ford Motor Company's Henry Ford 2d, International Telephone and Telegraph's Harold S. Geneen and CBS's William S. Paley.

title: COAST COMPANY BUYS CONNECTICUT PAPERS
description: STANFORD, Conn., Aug. 19The publisher of The Stamford Advocate and Greenwich Time announced today that agreement had been reached to sell the two daily papers to the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles for an undisclosed amount of Times Mirror stock.

title: Madison Square Garden Corp: Taken Over by GulfWestern
description: WESTBURY, Aug. 19Gulf and Western Industries completed its eightyear campaign to absorb the Madison Square Garden Corporation and its sports holdings this morning after hectic final stockholders meeting at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: RUSS TAYLOR
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 19 (AP)Russ Taylor a longtime sports broadcaster, died at his home today, his 51st birthday, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Taylor, of Montreal. was director of broadcasting for the Montreal Expos baseball team. He began his career in broadcasting at radio station CECF here in 1948 as controlroom operator.

title: Egypt Says Israelis Purposely Prevent Peace Negotiations
description: CAIRO, Aug. 19 Egypt accused Israel today of deliberately raising obstacles to undermine efforts to reach a solution in the Middle East.

title: Dodgers Add Davalillo To Get Hitting Help
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Vic Davalillo, out of major league baseball since 1973, joined his sixth major league team, the Los Angeles Dodgers, today and sat on the bench while the Chicago Cubs won a 62 decision.

title: CITIBANK LIFTS PRIME TO 7% AMID EVIDENCE OF STRONG RECOVERY
description: Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, yesterday raised its basic, or prime, commercial lending rate to 7 percent from 6% percent, the first such increase since May 31.

title: Statue of War Hero Is Bombed in Paris
description: An explosion toppled the statue of Gen. JacquesPhillipe Leclerc from its pedestal at Porte d'Orleans Square in Paris early Thursday. A proNazi group left handbills at the scene, taking responsibility for the bombing. Gen. Leclerc led French forces that freed Paris in 1944.

title: TheElegant Skipper, Tough as Old Boots
description: LONDONAs sailors go, Clare Francis looks as if she should be in the Sunfish class. The blond, 31yearold Englishwoman measures only 5feet2 and 105 pounds. Lounging alongside St. Katherine's Dock near the Tower of London recently, she shuddered delicately at the revolting color of the polluted River Thames.

title: Veteran Diplomat Is Selected by U. S.  For Cuban Mission
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 A veteran Foreign Service officer with tours in four Latin American countries will head the first United States diplomatic mission to function in Cuba since 1961, the State Department announced today.

title: CONSUMER PRICE RISE OA% FOR LAST MONTH, SMALLEST THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19consumer prices rose fourtenths of 1 percent in July, the smallest monthly increase of the year, thanks in large measure to a decline in grocery food prices, the Labor Department's Consumer Price index showed today.

title: PreElection Release
description: The Criminal Justice Agency showed extraordinary bureaucratic mindlessness in preparing a report that seemed to recommend release without bail for David R. Berkowitz, the accused. 44caliber killer. But Mayor Beame's infuriated attack on the agency at a press conference compounds the silliness. The agency did not in fact really make such a sweeping recommendation; it had no authority to do so; and there was never any likelihood that the accused killer would be released.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State will soon begin selling more special license plates, allowing motorists who are willing to pay an extra $15 a year to get up to eight tharacters of their own choosing on their license plates.

title: Three Summer Interns Find Themselves Working HardAnd in Love With the City
description: I find myself walking down the street talking to people, telling them to smile, Austin Fitts said. I tell them, You know, you really could smile; it's not that tough.  Hardly anybody smiles back. In New York, it's just not kosher. I'm always doing something to make somebody laugh. One morning going to work on the subway I sang Yes, We Have No Bananas.  The faces were deadpan.

title: BAIL AGENCY DECIDES TO CHANGE ITS ROLE
description: The New York City Criminal Justice Agency, which had recommended that David R. Berkowitz, the alleged 44caliber killer, be released without bail because he had ties to the community, decided yesterday to stop making bail recomittendations in homicide cases.

title: CASINOINN PLANNED AT ATLANTIC CITY PIER
description: ATLANTIC CITY Aug. 19The Steel Pier, a landmark here since before 1900, was earmarked today for conversion to a $75 million, fourblocklong Casino at Sea that would be housed in a siloshaped hotel where all guests would have oceanfront rooms.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sauro
description: Using himself as bait, Dr. Wayne J. Crans captured mosquitoes with a suction tube and cannister in a field near salt marshes in Barnegat Bay, N. J.

title: Father Watches as 2 Sons Die In a Plane Crash in Michigan
description: CEDAR. Mich., Aug. 19 (AP)As the father watched, a seaplane carrying his two sons on a pleasure excursion plunged into a resort lake near here, killing all four persons aboard.

title: $1 Million Spent to Try ExFollower of Manson
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP)The two murderconspiracy trials of Leslie Van Houten, a former follower of Charles Manson, have cost the taxpayers of Los Angeles County more than $1 million.

title: The Mills, And Unions
description: Spokesmen for the textile industry cry out that the industry, already facing increased competition from foreign imports, is confronted by other problems.  The first is that workers are seeking to organize so they can bargain collectively; the second efforts by the Federal Government to promulgate a new occupationalhealth standard to protect workers from excessive and harmful exposure to cotton dust.

title: 4 Russians Coming to Study U. S.  End Up Explaining Soviet Life
description: They came to the City University's Graduate Center on West 42d Street to compare educational systems, these four Russians on an exchange program, but by the time the morning was out, they had been questioned about the dissident writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the opportunity structure of the Soviet Union and the Russian attitudes on marriage, sex and abortion.

title: Spanish Police Recover Stolen Church Jewels
description: OVIEDO, Spain, Aug. 19 (AP)The police said today they recovered part of a priceless jewel collection stolen from crosses in historic Oviedo Cathedral 10 days ago.

title: 'Bad News Bears' Make Comeback In an Effort to Go On to Japan
description: Even without Walter Matthau and Tatum O'Neal, who were the stars of "The Bad News Bears," there is apparently no stopping, or even slowing down, that team of pint-sized California baseball players in their spin-off movie, titled, for no particular reason except that it has a nice ring to it, "The Bad News Bears in Breaking Training."The film, which opened at the Forum and other theaters yesterday, is as American as Budweiser beer, Coca-Cola, Hilton Hotels and the Houston Astrodome, all of which receive such prominent plugs it seems as if the film's subsidiary purpose is to keep capitalism afloat. In this respect the film may simply be pursuing accuracy. We live in a time when it's impossible to carry on a lengthy conversation without mentioning a noun that isn't also a trademarked name."The Bad News Bears in Breaking Training" is manufactured comedy of a slick order, depending Almost entirely for its effects on the sight and sound of a bunch of kids behaving as if they were small adults. It's a formula that worked for Our Gang Comedy for many years, and works again here with a bright screenplay by Paul Brickman, based on Bill Lancaster's original characters, and direction of intelligent lightness by Michael Presman. He's the young man (now 26) who made a funny movie, "The Great Texas Dynamite Chase," out of a standard road picture earlier this year.What plot there is concerns the efforts of the Bears, whose ages run from 9 to 13 (though one or two look older), to get from California to Houston to play in the Astrodome, the winning team then to go on to play the Japanese champions. A critic is not allowed to tell you who wins the Houston game, but it's general knowledge that the next Bears film will be called something on the order of "The Bad News Bears in Tokyo." The story of a film such as this isn't anywhere near as important as the number of variations that the moviemakers can successfully work on a severely limited number of jokes. Mr. Pressman and Mr. Brickman do well, considering that there are only so many ways that a baseball team can be made to look like losers in order to make a succesful comeback in the final sequence.They are helped by some excellent actors, including Jackie Earle Haley who, just a couple of years ago, was the brat Donald Sutherland stomped to death in "The Day of the Locust" and who now looks almost 18, but is an actor of real potential. William Devane is absolutely straight as young Haley's long-lost father, the man who coaches the young pirates to victory.Some of the other Bears who are very funny are Chris Barnes, who appears to be smaller than Tom Thumb and who, like so many kids who are disadvantaged in height, is ready to fight at the merest slight; Erin Blunt, as the teams' black kid, and Jaime O. Escobedo and George Gonzales as the team's two Mexican-Americans."The Bad News Bears in Breaking Training," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), seeks (and finds) a number of laughs by having its young actors use vulgar four-letter words with the pounding enthusiasm of children who've just learned to speak pig-Latin.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Power Authority may have wasted as much at 321 million by buying up some of its own financial paper too quickly, state Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday.

title: Around The Garden
description: It's not too early to start thinking about fall planting: plan hardy bulb borders, replacement of winterravaged evergreens that did not revive this summer and check out any shade trees that may need pruning and/or feeding&. Keep up with vegetable harvests; can and freeze the surplus when it is at its peak of quality&. Dry flowers and grasses for winter bouquets.

title: Miss Boone Has Nuptials
description: In Grace Episcopal Church in Salem, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Catherine Elizabeth Boone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Brownie Boone of St. James, L. I., became the bride of Arnold Lawson 3d, son of Mr, and Mrs. Lawson Jr. of Topsfield, Mass.

title: On Knowing When to Talk And When to Listen
description: I was minding my own business one daywhich is not what journalists are paid to dowhen the telephone rang and I found myself being interviewed. The interview was about interviewing. How, as an interviewer. did I try to come across?

title: Gretel Wins and Staves Off Elimination in Trials
description: NEWPORT, R. 1., Aug. 20Gretel II of Australia, the old boat with the old crew, was programmed for elimination at the America's Cup competition today, but she balked. Given a great opportunity for survival at the start by her rival, the Swedish yacht Sverige, Gretel managed to stay ahead all around the 24. 3mile course and defeat the Swede by 45 seconds.

title: The Arts Go To Day Camp
description: HER young, supple dancer's body arched gracefully, Caren Binder toiled at the, barre. Keep the hip close, boomed her instructor, Valentine Froman, who was Anna Pavlova's last partner. Close, he ordered, tapping the 14yearold on the backside to emphasize his direction before moving on to his next student.

title: Realty News
description: The Citicorp Center project on Lexington Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets has rented 96 percent of its office and retail space. It will not open officially until the fall.

title: Why Graduate Education Stays Popular
description: THERE is a surplus of teachers.  Schools of education are suffering serious declines in enrollment.  Teachers and administrators do npt care about their students anymore.  Educators are not interested in learning new skills and techniques.

title: New Boating Safeguards Sought
description: WHITE PLAINS THE nine harrowing hours that Rye man and two teenage boys spent atop an overturned sailboat while it drifted in darkness across Long Island Sound may result in some marked improvement in marinesafety precautions for pleasure boaters who use the waters off Westchester.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HE best way to perform a smooth job of handsanding on such flat surfaces as paneling, furniture, doors and wood trim is to use a wooden block as a backing pad and holder for the sandpaper. While trtire are commerciallymade sanding becks or pads available, these are not part of everyone's tool kit, and all too often they are not quite the size desired.

title: In Summary
description: A Federal judge has greatly increased the chances of the supersonic Concorde airliner landing regularly at Kennedy International Airport. But the legal journey of the plane has been tortuous throughout and probably will remain so. Appeals will be filed, and since courts usually prefer to keep the status quo while they consider controversial issues, the Concorde might be kept out of New York City for months.

title: U. N. Delay Asked on Hostage Pact'
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 (AP) A United Nations committee set up to draft an international treaty outlawing the taking of hostages has failed to meet its first deadline and is asking the General Assembly for an extension into 1978.

title: RichardM. Hamilton Weds Dola S. Davis
description: Dola Shepard Davis and Richard Mansfield Hamilton were married yesterday afternoon in St. JosephontheBrandywine Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del., by Msgr. Henri I. Foltz, secretary, finance and planning devartment of the Diocese of Wilmington.

title: Pesky Cubs Beat Dodgers On Mitterwald's Hit, 5 to 4
description: The Chicago Cubs, who made such a tremendous run at the National League East flag over the first three months of the season, have fallen from grace. But they are going to have a say in the pennant races, nevertheless.

title: Wildlings Make Themselves At Home When Encouraged
description: What better way to simplify life than to grow wild flowers in the ga den. They are right in keeping with the current trend toward naturalism in landscaping and design. Fortunately. nature hates a vacuum.

title: Aides Blocked Hughes Plan to Reorganize Empire
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20The continuing legal battle over the control and taxation of the vast estate of Howard R. Hughes has uncovered details of a palace revolt by his inner circle of employees that frustrated his efforts to reorganize the management of his affairs.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek
description: BROOKLYNPainters, sculptors, graphic and mixedmedia artists from Brooklyn, N. Y., exhibiting at New England Center for Contemporary Art, Route 169. Reception today 2 to 5 P. M. Free. Thereafter Wednesdays through Sundays 1 to 5 P. M., until Sept. 6. 7744849.

title: Headliners
description: The escape of Herbert Kappler, a convicted Nazi war criminal, from a military hospital in Rome, has strained relations between West Germany and Italy. Mr. Kappler was serving a life sentence for personally ordering and participating in the killing of 335 Italian hostages in 1944. His wife apparently smuggled Mr. Kappler, who is suffering from cancer and whose weight was down to 105 pounds, out Italy and into West Germany in a large suitcase. Italian officials have asked for extradition, but German law prohibits the forcible transfer of a German citizen to another country. Some Italians have angrily accused the Italian Government of complicity in the escape, and, fearful of public reaction, officials postponed a scheduled meeting between Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of Germany and Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy. You can imagine my reaction, said an Italian demonstrator at the cemetery dedicated victims of the massacre, I have seven in there.

title: MACY TOLD TO STOP SELLING CLOTHES TREATED WITH TRIS
description: Macy's has been ordered by a Federal district judge to stop selling children's clothing treated with Tris, a suspected cancercausing chemical, The Associated Press reported. The order was issued Friday by Judge Richard Owen in response to a complaint filed by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Letters
description: As a psychologist, I am very familiar with the nature of neurosis, and as citizen of our beleagured economy, am exposed every day to the analogy between personal neurosis and the national dilemma. The inflation which besets us in the free world has the character of a social neurosis which guarantees its own continuance by dividing the self against itself.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Article Called Setback To Pelham's Progress

title: The Conflicts That Led to Civil War Are Unresolved
description: BEIRUT, LebanonAn appearance of law and order has begun to settle over most of Lebanon nine months after the Syrian Army entered Beirut and put an end to the murderous, mindless shelling duels that had terrorized the capital and destroyed much of the nation. A lively subsistence economy has revived and cafes and movie houses stay open in the evening. Traffic moves with deceptive smoothness between Christian East Beirut and Moslem West Beirut, stopping routinely at the checkpoints of the Syriandominated Arab peacekeeping force. But the intrepid who cross the invisible green line between the two Beirutsand the two Lebanonstend scurry home at nightfall.

title: H. W. CARHART, HEAD OF HOSPITAL BOARD, 63
description: H. Whitfield C2. rhart, chairman of the board of directors of Roosevelt Hospital in New York and a partner in Brosirn Brothers Harriman & Company, a Nvall Street ??? died Friday night aboard his yacht. the Manu lwa, in Northeast Harbor, Me. He was 63 years old.

title: GARDENING
description: AFEW perennials are more nearly dormant in August than at any other time, and thus can be transplanted with the least injury now. At the top of this small group are varieties of the flamboyant Oriental poppy (Papaver orientate), which blooms in late May and June. wait until a clump is really overgrown to lift and divide it. The foliage begins to die down in midsummer.

title: How to Get There
description: If you don't know the territory, the best way to get to the Puskas Wildflower Nursery is to take route 7 to Kent, go east for five miles on Route 391, then turn right onto the Kent Hollow Road. Go down the hill, bear left at the triangle, and around the next curve you will see the sign at the driveway to your right.

title: The Carter Circle
description: The Comptroller of the Currency has issued his report on the former businese practices of Bert Lance, President Carter's budget director, and while the report doesn't indict Mr. Lance, doesn't unequivocally absolve him, either. What it does do is state that none of the evidence it has considered provides the bas's for cr::niral proseuticn under Federal banlrng law, ani then questions the adequacy of that law to regulate sound banking practices.

title: Major League Averages
description: National League

title: 59 SCIENTISTS SELECTED FOR 21 SPACELAB FLIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has selected 59 scientists from the United States and the United Kingdom to carry out research in the second flight of the Europeanbuilt Spacelab aboard the space shuttle rocket plane in 1981.

title: Connoisseurs of Ice Cream Cones Get Their Licks In at Swensen's
description: MANHASSET, L. I. They say that everyone on Long Island is on a diet. One look at Swensen's in Manhasset on a warm summer evening flatly disputes that theory.

title: Leslie A. Ayvazian Planning Marriage
description: Dr. and Mrs. L. Fred Ayvazian of South Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Ayvazian, to Samuel Mather Anderson, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. David L. Anderson of Oberlin, Ohio.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It was in 1964 that Ferruccio Busoni's Doktor Faust was introduced to America. Dietrich FischerDieskau was the protagonist in a concert version of the opera. Several years later the opera department of the Indiana University school of music presented the first American stage production, and a brilliant one it was. There matters rested until last Aug. 5, when Dr. Faust was staged Wolf Trap in a multimedia extravaganza under the auspices of Frank Corsaro and Ronald Chase. I will be discussing ater on in this article. Grimly.

title: Mr. Lance Is Not A Crook
description: Three times during his jubilant news conference last week, Budget Director Bert Lance declared that a report by the Comptroller of the Currency had found that he had violated no laws while he was the hardcharging president of two Georgia banks.

title: Flying Beach Ball Tested in Lakehurst
description: IT DIDN'T create much excitement. There were no crowds cheering, flashbulbs popping or reporters scribbling. But for half a dozen huddled in a at Lakehurst, recent flight tests of a device resembling an oversized whirling beach ball were as electrifying as the Wright Brothers first flight or Lindbergh's landing in Paris. canny machine was conceived by Don Doolittle, an engineer who now lives in Brielle, did aerospace experts give serious thought to combining a helicopter's precision with a balloon's buoyant, but rambling, lift capability.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Catching Blues on Fly Rod
description: NOMANS LAND ISLAND, Mass. A whisper of a southwest breeze and gentle swells greeted us shortly after dawn when we arrived off the eastern end of Nomans Land Island where we will try for the bluefish that have been there most of the summer.

title: The PlainLanguage Movement Is Gaining
description: Attempts to simplify legal language in the United States reach back at least as far as Thomas Jefferson, but in the last several years an accelerated movement for plain language has paralleled the growth of consumerism, resulting, for example, in New York's new law requiring clear and understandable language in such contracts as apartment leases and loan agreements. Even lawyers tend to agree that people ougnt to be able to unaerstand what they are obliged to sign, but many also fear that the cures adopted may themselves lead to more litigation as the movement to banish legalese gains momentum.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE'Jesus Christ Superstar.  Today and Wednesday through next Sunday at 8:30 P. M. (through Sept. 4). 55. 50 to $6. 50, students, children and the elderly 54. 50, except Friday and Saturday. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6. 6281169.

title: BEAM EDICT OBEYED AT FLUSHING AIRPORT
description: The management of Flushing Airport in Queens yesterday reluctantly obeyed Mayor Beame's order to close down the cityowned facility, but its lawyer went to court to request an injunction that would stay the mayoral directive.

title: Tax Loophole for Multinationals
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Navios Shipping Company of Liberia brought iron ore from the Orinoco Mining Company in Venezuela to the United States from 1957 to 1960, it overcharged for its services by 10 to 30 percent, a United States Tax Court ruled recently.

title: Westbury Polo Victor
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 20Jack Whittemore scored five goals and led the Westbury polo team to a 97 victory over Jericho today at Hickox Field. Paul Rizzo was the high scorer For Jericho, also with five goals.

title: Miner Allen Crary Marries Helen Veeder Hinshaw
description: In the Reformed Church, of Bronxvine, N. Y., yesterday afternoon Helen Veeder Hinshaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Veeder Hinshaw of Bronxyille, was married to Miner Allen Crary, son or Mr. and Mrs. Miner Dunham Crary Jr., of Northport, L. I. The Rev.
