title: Rhodesia's Capital Guarding Against New Bombings
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug, 20 (Reuters)Salisbury, the capital of embattled Rhodesia, today had the look of a city at :war as it tensely awaited any repetition. of the bomb attacks of the last two weekends.

title: James S. Davidson Weds Lyn McHugh
description: Lyn Michelle McHugh, a law student, was married yesterday morning to James Stuart Davidson, an architect in the Chicago office of Skidmore, Owings &

title: DINING OUT
description: A BIBLIOTHEQUE is not a bad restaurant, but it could be much better. It's expensive, attractive and apparently popular, centrally located on a quiet, winding street in Westport, a town that would happily support a firstrate, sophisticated Alining place. Although much of the food on the Continental menu is reasonably good, the chef appears to be following the pattern set by other, similar restaurants anther than his own convictions about how good food should taste.

title: A Short Long Jump Costs Miss Frederick a Victory
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 20 (UPI) Jane Frederick, the American champion in the women's pentathlon, was beaten by Valentina Dimitrova of Bulgaria today at the World University Games. She was beaten by 5 points after having been overtaken in the final event, the 800 meters.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: show. Great Barrington (Mass. ) Fairgrounds, 1. 283 dogs; 8 A. M. to 7 P. M.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: William Safire
description: Sometimes fiction is better for getting at the truth, William Safire says. And the truth of Full Disclosure, a first novel about the constitutional problems raised when a President becomes disabled in office, is that politics is where it's all at: treachery, steamy sex, casual conversation governed by fear of leaks and inclusion in future memoirs. Just the sort of thing to disillusion those optimists among us who still believe there's a smidgeon of honor among politicians.

title: Nieporte 48, Is Selected As Winged Foot's Pro
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 20 Tom Nieporte, a 48yearold teaching pro who won three tournaments when he was on the tour of the Professional Golfers Association, has been appointed to one of the most prestigious positions in American golfhead professional at the Winged Foot Golf Club here.

title: ON RECOGNIZING A YOUNG EINSTEIN
description: Even the young Albert Einstein was not immediately recognized as intellectually gifted. All too often, a child's extraordinary intelligence is overlooked as the signs go undetected or are misinterpreted. A gifted youngster who is shy may not allow his talents to flourish and one who is bored may be falsely labeled as lazy. Parents who train themselves to be aware of the traits and behavior of the gifted will be better able to insure that their own gifted children do not get shortchanged in a system that is not geared to the needs of the exceptional.

title: From Little Nutmegs
description: NUTMEG does not grout in Connecticut, but in the warm, humid ambiance of the East and West Indies. How, then, did Connecticut come to be called the Nutmeg State? Well [although the Nutmeg State now calls itself the Constitution State], the story still goes that shrewd old Yankee peddlers, traveling up and down the Atlantic Seaboard in their heavily laden wagons, sometimes passed off a few wooden nutmegs to unsuspecting housewives and thus gave the state a name for sharp business practices.

title: DINING OUT
description: ABER ER's may well be the master of the dinner package, and what the restaurant does, does rather well, despite an ambience that ranges from eyecatching to garish. Even the DayGlo signs that spring up periodically on the roads leading to the vast restaurant do not prepare one for seeing it, a sprawling brown building bedecked with plastic animals, artificial flowers and bronze plaques commemorating the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

title: World News Briefs
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 20 (Reuters)Seventy human rights campaigners have appealed on the eve of the ninth anniversary of the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia for the release of political prisoners.

title: Michelangeli Will Play Here Again Next Year Maybe
description: Among the handful of the world's legendary pianists, Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli is perhaps the most reclusive, enigmatic and obsessive. Living in voluntary exile and isolation in Lugano, Switzerland (for reasons he chooses not to divulge, he has refused to reside or perform in his native Italy for the past 10 years), Michelangeli makes infrequent appearances on the European concert stage. When he does perform, he avidly shuns all publicity and avoids any contact with either his fellow artists or an adoring public. Often given to cancelling concerts, Michelangeli seems law unto himself, following in the dictates of his feelings and moods.

title: Need for Fresh Air Fund Increases With Inflation
description: As money gets tighter, a child's world gets narrower.

title: Israel, Apartheid and Hypocrisy
description: Israel's withdrawal from a United Nations conference on apartheid beginning tomorrow in Lagos, Nigeria, should be a source of concern to the governments the black African states at whose urging the meeting being held. It demonstrates that the Palestine Liberation Organization and its Arab and Soviet bloc supporteis are more interested in using the conference to express hostility to Israel than to address seriously the racial policies of South Africa.

title: New ShotPut Mark
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 20 (AP)  Helena Fibingerova of Czechoslovakia established a women's shotput world record of 73 feet 2 inches in an international meet at Nitra, the Czechoslovak press agency, C. T. K., reported today. She surpassed her own previous record of 721 Terry Albrighton won the men's shotput with 653 beating his American compatriot, Al Feuerbach, who had 631. The women's put is lighter than the men's.

title: PLANTS EMPLOYEES HELP IN REMODELING
description: Ground was broken for a $5. 1 million expansion and remodeling of a Carborundum Company foundry near Jamestown, N. Y., kit week, and when the work is completed it may become a monument to a new kind of labormanagement cooperation.

Peter Kaczmarek, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

description: The recent spate of discussion among various knowledgeable theater personalities as to the most desirable future course for the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center seems to me to lack a fundamental ingredient.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: Iam writing in response to the article by Hilton Kramer, Support for the Arts Has Never Been Greater [July 31]. I was wondering how much of his research included artists, institutions, and 1thescene studiesor was it primarily based on his own ingenuity and intuitive wisdom?

title: Eating in Public Case Dropped on Fire Island
description: OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, Aug. 20Charges against a man accused of violating this village's ordinance against eating in public were dismissed today when the complaining officer failed to appear im court for the second time.

title: Forest Hills and Wimbledon: Memories of the 1931 Champion
description: The surrender and 1978 transplant of our nation's only tennis monument, the still splendid, 11old horseshoe stadium at Forest Hills, to a 11bebuilt complex in Flushing Meadows is all the more incomprehensible after returning from Wimbledon's memorable, 100year celebration.

title: The Trauma of the African Athlete
description: Politics and sport are inseparable, and they are an intrinsic part of modern life all over the world. African politicians, usually unsophisticated, have exploited their athletes to the point that the views of the African athlete and the African politician are now diametrically opposed.

title: Women's Relay Mark Set
description: LONDON, Aug. 20 (UPI)A world track record in the women's 800meter relay was set today. Verona Elder, Donna Hartley, Sharon Colyear and Xonia Lannaman clocked 1:31. 57 to erase the previous mark of 1:32. 4 set one year ago by an East German team. The feat came at the British women's track championships at Crystal Palace.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: In recent reading undertaken more in pleasure than duty, this professional dancewatcher has come across spme memorable quotations. A sampling follows.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: IT is not easy to live a writing career through, and Howard Fast has had more ups and downs than most over the 45 years he's been at it, since he published his first novel at 18. Once a member of the Communist Party, Mr. Fast served a prison sentence in 1950 for refusing to supply names of contributors to an orr'anization on the Attorney General's list to the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities; he had another runin with the Committee in 1953a year in which he also received the Stalin Peace Prize. In 1957, however, he left the party, an apostasy he wrote about in The Naked God.  For a time, beginning with Spartacus in 1952, he published his books himself, being unable to find a commercial publisher for them. Spartacus sold 50,000 copies, but Mr. Fast said recently from his home in Los. Angeles that he would not recommend selfpublishing to anyone, and it had been something of a disaster for him, all told.

title: Alexander Szabo jr. Weds Madeleine Bamman Slack
description: The marriage of Madeleine Bamman Slack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Eugene Slack of Greenwich, Conn., to Alexander Szabo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Szabo of Westwood, N. J., took place yesterday in the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich. The Rev. David Hanna performed the ceremony.

title: Hazards Resulting From Second Avenue Subway Construction Persist
description: Ask residents of East Harlem and the East Side if things got better after the city's Metropolitan Transportation Authority promised in June to improve hazardous street conditions resulting from construction of the Second Avenue subway and they answer: Just look at the streets.

description: IT is 5:20 P. M. Traffic is backed up for miles on the Hutchinson River Parkway, and homebound commuters are fuming. But there is satisfied smile on Donna Caruso's face. She is above all that.

title: Fort Worth Millionaire Freed on Bond as His Murder Trial Starts
description: AMARILLO, Tex., Aug. 20 (UPI) After exactly one year in jail, T. Cullen Davis, the millionaire on trial for murder, posted $1 million bond today and drove off in a blue and white Cadillac, planning to eat a fourpound steak.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug 20 (AP)Happy clams lie snug in the mud In Gulf Coast bays, living out their 17year span undisturbed by man, except for offshore oil drillers or pipeline dredges. But those good times may be ending.

title: Seaver at 60 Feet
description: And now for the main event: Tom Seaver, having pitched 367 games for the New York Mets, now pitching one against them, returning to Shea Stadium in the uniform of the Cincinnati Reds and firing baseballs across 60 feet of ground toward his old roommate, his old catcher, his old gang. We're probably going. to have dinner afterwards, Seaver said, referring to Bud Harrelson, his longtime roommate and closest friend, and to Jerry Koosman, who volunteered to pitch for the Mets this afternoon. But whenit comes time to work, it's time to work. I'm not going to go out there and root for the Mets to win.

title: Wellwood Hanover Scores
description: YONKERS, Aug. 20Capping one of the most successful days in his career, Billy Haughton drove Wellwood Hanover to an easy victory tonight in the $52,638 Lawrence N. Sheppard Pace for 2yearold pacers at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Pilot Killed in Florida Crash
description: OCHOPEE, Fla., Aug. 20 (AP)A twinengine plane with 11 persons aboard crashed today into a swampy area in the Florida Everglades and burst into flames soon after takeoff from a small airport, the authorities said. The pilot was killed, the copilot was seriously injured and six members of a skydiving club were slightly injured. Three other skydivers escaped without injury, the authorities said.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: PROTEST NAZI OFFICIAL'S FREEDOM: AntiNazi demonstrators in Soltau, West Germany, picketing in front of family home of Herbert Kappler, former SS officerwho escaped last week from an Italian prison hospital. Former Chancellor Willy Brandt charged the government with failing to combat neoN'azi activities.

title: Mr. Vance Will Find the Main Topic in China Is Still Taiwan
description: HONG KONG  Five years ago, when President Nixon set his hand to the Shanghai communique, ending decades hostility between China and the United States, the Chinese insisted on including an important reminder in their section of the document. The Taiwan question, they said, is the crucial question obstructing the normalization of relations between China and the United States.  Since then, fcr better or worse, nothing has really changed to alter that situation, and ChineseAmerican relations have lost the momentum Mr. Nixon once imnarted to them.

title: Baseball
description: Tomorrow night at 8 and Tuesday afternoon at 2, the Mets are hosts to the Houston Astros in Shea Stadium. Rod Carew and the Minnesota Twins have 8 P. M. games against the Yankees in Yankee Stadium on Wednesday and Thursday. The Texas Rangers come in for a weekend series against the Yanks Friday night at 8 and at 2 o'clock on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Center for Creative and Performing Arts on Long Island Furthers the Goals of Talented Youngster
description: WYANDANCH, L. I.  Her young, supple dancer's body arched gracefully. Caren Binder toiled at the barre. Keep the hip close, boomed her instructor, Valentine Froman, who was Anna Pavlova's last partner. Close, he ordered, tapping the 14yearold on the backside to emphasize his direction before moving on to his next student.

title: The Best Summer Job?
description: PORTLAND ON A GRASSY plateau atop steep and leafy hillside with a panoramic view of some of the state's loveliest countryside sits Camp Meshomasic. Once its remote and secluded location made it ideal as Nike site, and after that it was a rehabilitation center for drug addicts. Now, sporting fresh paint in a multitude of colors and with a spiffy white Y emblem on the side of each building, the camp plays host every July and August to teenage members of the state's Youth Conservation Corps.

title: Woman Gets Life in Slaying
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 20. (AP)Elizabeth Duncan, 58 years old, was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for the courtroom murder of a man moments after a jury declared him rightful owner of a house they both said they owned. Judge Robert W. Tyson Jr. of Circuit Court accepted a jury's recommendation on the sentence after jurors found her guilty in the shooting death last February of George Kissak, 62.

title: 76 VEHICLES ARE TICKETED AT DAILY NEWS PLANT
description: Police ticketed scores of cars and trucks parked near the Brooklyn printing plant of The Daily News last night, reportedly prompting threats of a job action by newspaper employees.

title: Mindy Percival Is Married
description: Mindy Percival. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Percival of New Hyde Park, LI, was married last night to Mark Goldfarb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Goldfarb of Albany. Rabbi David Moseson performed the ceremony in Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Beame Grants Agency Chiefs Wider Power
description: A milestone in municipal government passed quietly the other day, but no one at City Hall sent up any flares to mazk the occasion. Perhaps that was because the event was couched in techlanguage disguising the fact that it constituted a significant change in the way the city's sluggish bureaucracy breathes and functions. The event was Mayor Beame's Executive Order No. 90, which invested all agency heads wan new powersgranted by the new City Charterto award salary increases, hire personnel, authorize trips or purchase equipment without getting permission first from either the Mayor's office or the Budget Bureau.

description: Elizabeth MacDonald Lamont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald lain Lamont of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married there yesterday in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less to Michael Elwin Smith of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dudley J. Stroup performed the ceremony. His father is president of the Amex Iron Ore Corporation in Greenwich.

title: Around the Nation
description: DENVER, Aug. 20 (AP)The American Legion has been asked to support change in Federal Civil Service practices that would give veterans less preferential treatment in hiring.

title: The News Wasn't Happy
description: Win or lose, Hubert H. Humphrey always has been The Happy Warrior, down to refusing to brood over the bladder cancer that required radical surgery last October. Oh, my friend, it isn't what they take away from you that counts, Senator Humphrey told a magazine interviewer recently, it's what you do with what you have left.  Last week, doctors discovered that he might have little time left. The cancer had spread throughout the pelvic area, beyond surgical help. Mr. Humphrey's physician called the condition terminal but refused to speculate on his patient's life expectancy. The chemotherapy begun last year will continue and the Senator, characteristically, was enthusiastic about the treatment.

title: Icelandic Horses in Glen Cove Are Right Medicine for Disabled
description: GLEN COVE, L. I. When 30 Icelandic horses arrived at the sevenacre estate of Geni and Josephine Laemmlin on Duck Pond Road here recently, the neighbors immediately began wondering what was going on. Was a circus moving in or were the Laemmlins building a race track?

title: Lucy Dyer Stover Wed To Charles H. Ashton
description: Lucy Dyer Stover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Spoor Stover of Princeton. N. J., was married there yesterday to Charles Hopkins Ashton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ashton, also of Princeton. The Rev. Ronald Parks Conner performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Why the F. C. C. Can't Help State's TV
description: 'CAN'T the F. C. C. do something?'a question frequently asked by publicinterest groups when the subject of poor news coverage of the Garden State by New York television stations comes up. No, the Federal Communications Commission cannot.

title: Talk With Paul Scott
description: Here and there in the hills of India, in towns like Ootacamund and Simla, where the air Is nicely cool and the gentle rains persuade roses to flourish, there are cottages set in careful English gardens. Through the long winters of the British reign, India was ruled from cities on the plains. But in summer, the English left the cities to the overwhelming heat, to dust and fat black flies and Indians, and moved to the temperate hills. Today, though there is no longer a season at Simla, no longer a summer whirl of ball gowns and fluttering fans and white jacketed Indians serving midnight suppers, the hill station cottages are not empty. They are home to the English who, in the phrase that was current as the reign was ending, stayed on. Independence, in 1947, caught them at the wrong moment, as it caught Tusker Smalley, the retired colonel who blusters his sad, funny way through Paul Scott's most recent novel. Like Tusker, they were too young to retire, too old and perhaps too frightened to piece together a new career at Home in England. Besides, many of them had been home on leave, and though they would never admit it aloud, those visits proved only that Home was neither as they remembered it nor as they had recreated it in the cantonments and civil lines of India. So, they have stayed on, going to the Club, discussing the servant problem, growing old. Each in his own small way helped to manage an empire. Now, there is nothing to do but the roses, and even those will be seen to by the gardener, provided there's enough slack in the pension to keep the garPaul Scott shares with Tusker Smalley a look of wearied but unmistakable Englishness. His suit, even his nose, is too large for him, as if there was a time when more of him was needed. At 57, he is not retired, and there can have been no time in his life that demanded more of him than have the last 10 years, during which he has produced five novels that encompass the decline and fall of the Jean G. Zorn practices law in New York and occasionally reviews books on Asia.

title: Primary Election Expected to Mean More Women and Hispanic Members in City Council
description: The shape of New York's City Councilwhose membership profile changes at a rate that can best be described as glacialwill be altered in one important respect next month, when voters go to the polls in the primary election for party nominations.

description: WHEELING, W. Va., Aug. 20 (AP) Debbie Austin scrambled to an evenpar 72 by overcoming some admittedly poor putting and held a twostroke lead over Laura Baugh after two rounds of the $50,000 Wheeling Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: THE best way to perform a smooth job of handsanding on such flat surfaces as paneling, furniture, doors and wood trim is to use a wooden block as a backing pad and holder for the sandpaper. While there are commerciallymade sanding blocks or pads available, these are not part of everyone's tool kit, and all too often they are not quite the size desired. That is why it is often advisable to make your own. Simply cut scrap pieces of 2 by 4, 2 by 3 or similar lumber to the length needed, then fasten pieces of sandpaper to it by wrapping around the sides and securing with a staple gun as shown here. Driving the staples into the sides will keep them away from the sanding surface so there is no danger of scratching and a new piece can simply be stapled over the old one when it is needed. If a flexible backing is desired, staple a scrap piece of carpet to the block first, then wrap the sandpaper around the outside with the carpet on the underside.

title: Eastern Settings, Western Writers
description: TO Somerset Maugbam it was the F. M. S., to Henri Fauconnier Malaisie, to myself Malaya; to the American writer Paul Theroux (best known for his travel book, The Great Railway Bazaar and such novels as The Family Arsenal and Saint Jack) it is Malaysia. It is recognizably the same place in all its nominations, and there is nowhere in the world quite like it. I wrote about it from the viewpoint of a Colonial Education Officer, Fauconnier from that of a French rubberplanter who loved the Malays and was learned in their language. Willie Maugham, who knew the country least, has unfairly effected a literary nearmonopoly of it. In Theroux's new volume of stories, narrated by a young American consul who appears in each of them, the Ayer Hitam Dramatic Society puts on an adaptation of The Lotter, and old British expatriates try to behave like Maugham eccentrics. Maugham is always around somewhere, even in the postVietnam age, sardonically sipping gin pahits on the club veranda, observing exilic adulteries, defiled by mold on the termiteeaten shelves of the Carnegie Library.

title: CORNELIS VLASBLOM
description: Cornelic Via Sblorn. formerly general vassenger agent for the HollandAmerica Line. a shipping concern died yesterday at the Cabrini Health Care Center in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived at 647 East 14th Street in Manhattan.

title: After 55 Years, Berlin, a Cradle of Psychoanalysts, Is Their Host Agai4
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 20After an interval of almost 55 years, a congress of international psychoanalysts was held this week in Berlin, the city that was once considered a cradle of psychoanalysis and later became a synonym for Nazi persecution of Sigmund Freud, his teachings and those associated with him.

description: To the Editor: Our own recent encounter could be the French sequel to Jonathan Evan Maslow's I Was the Only Guest (Travel Section, Aug. 7).

description: Despite attention to the women's issue, change has been slow to nonexistent. The occupational distributions of men and women shifted remarkably little over the decades since the situation has been made clear to policymakers and the general public.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI)The Postal Service said today that it would issue two Christmas stamps this year, one showing George Washington kneeling in prayer at Valley Forge, the other a snowcrusted rural mailbox jammed with gifts.

title: Nyerere Says French Owe Apology To Tanzanians, Not the Opposite
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 20 (UPI) President Julius K. Nyerere said today that France should apologize for selling arms to South Africa and not expect a Tanzanian apology for a protest that abruptly ended a visit by the French Foreign Minister, Louis de Guiringaud.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: ON June 4, three women set out by automobile on their fourth annual weekend trip together. This year's itinerary: from New York City to the upstate town of Cazenovia. Miriam Eisler (also called Babe'), who will be 89 years old next week, plays the piano and makes her own clothes. Babe's daughter, Nanette Scofield, is a writer on jobs and employment in her early 50's who returned to work after her children were grown. Nanette's daughter, Elizabeth Scofield, is a 28yearold advertising account executive who has retained her maiden name through seven years of marriage. An innovation on this year's trip was that at its beginning Nanette issued each participant a notebook in which, by preagreement, each kept a candid record of her impressions. Their accounts constitute a kind of a triptych, parallel panels in which three generations confrontand mirror  each other.

title: Mr. Duffey Goes to the Humanities Endowment
description: WASHINGTON president Carter's recent nomination of Joseph D. Duffey as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities concluded a selection process marked by confusion, delay and intense lobbying over the goals of the agency. A White House staff member compared the search to a Marx Brothers movie, but it was more like a Roman circus.

title: Commuting a LongTerm Sentence
description: THINK of it as a giant Pachinko game board, with mercury silver pellets darting and switching, dropping and dipping into Grand Central Station. During the high tides of the rush hours, about 50 of these silvery balls, each bearing approximately 800 souls, fall into the city's maw.

description: MORRISVILLE, Pa., Aug. 20 (UPI)A Pennsylvania man was killed yesterday in the crash of a light plane, which hit Amtrak overhead wires and went down near here, the police said. The victim was identified as James Curtis McKinney, 53 years old, of Titusville.

title: PROGRAM IS SET UP ON INFANT MORTALITY
description: Cumberland Hospital in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn has started an instructional program for residents aimed at lowering a high rate of infant mortality. A New York City Bureau of Statistics report for 1976 shaves that for every 1,000 live births in Fort Greene, 30. 4 infants under one year of age died.

description: LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters)Britain's Education Department has confirmed that it wants to see a reduction in the number of overseas students studying here during the next academic year.

title: John L. Speller Weds Lydia Margaret Agnew

Harry Langley, assisted by the Rev. Herbert Stevens, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. A reception followed at the home of Mrs. Seth Marshall Agnew, stepmother of the bride, in Siasconset, Mass.

title: Miss Wetherill Becomes Bride Of P. G. Gerry
description: Alexandra Wetherill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs: Elkins Wetherill of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., and Waldoboro, Me., was married on Jones Neck in Waldoboro yesterday to Peter Goelet Gerry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge Thorias Gerry of Old Westbury, L. I., and Delhi, N. Y. The Rev. Raymond Donahue, an Episcopal priest and chaplain of the Lake Delaware Boys Camp of Delhi, performed the ceremony.

title: Ireland's Governing Party Wins Control of Senate by Slim Margin
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 20 (UPI)Prime ister John Lynch's Fianna Fail party won control of the Irish Senate by a narrow margin today.

title: Bert Lance Writes Newspaper Article On Fiscal Inquiry
description: Budget director Bert Lance wrote a thousandword copyrighted article, describing his reaction to the Federal investigation of his financial dealings, for the Sunday editions of The Miami Herald.

title: Somalia Rebukes Soviet Union,
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 20 (Reuters)Soenelia has accused its ally the Soviet Union, of taking a provoqutive attitude over the fighting between Somalis and Ethiopians in the disputed Ogadan region.

title: Charts of Saratoga Racing
description: Attendance, 35,530. Track parl'mutuel handle, 53,143,442. OTB handle, $3,260,181.

title: Post Mortem
description: AS this is being written, the Governor of Massachusetts has issued a proclamation calling for a memorial day on Aug. 23, the anniversary of the electrocution of Sacco and Vanzetti the Charlestown Prison for a holdup and murder, and his legal counsel has cited the very real possibility that a grievous miscarriage of justice occurred with their deaths.  It has taken the law exactly 50 years to acknowledge publicly that it might have made a mistake. But after that same 50 years, the renowned shortstory writer and novelist Katherine Anne Porter has written a book, The NeverEnding Wrc:. g, also to be published on Aug. 23; and seems to her that she still believes and feels today the same as she believed and felt at that time, on that.

title: CHESS
description: MALAGA. Spain Wbile the candidates are vying for the opportunity to meet Anatoly Karpov, the champion himself is making very clear what his challenger will be un against.

title: Whites Finding Jobs at Black Newspapers
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 20When 24yearold Ellen S. Freilich was hired recently as a reporter for The Cleveland Call and Post, a weekly newspaper that is basically for and about blacks, her arrival caused little stir, although she is white.

title: ToughTimesReported For Spiritual Values
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) Teaching spiritual values in a practical society gives religious educators in the United States a tough assignment, the Rev. Stephen Doyle told New England Roman Catholics yesterday.

title: Fish Farm Opposed In Amagansett
description: AMAGANSETT PLANS to establish the first saltwater fin fish farm in New York State are foundering in a sea of opposition from baymen who fear the operation could damage natural fish nurseries in the area and from residents who object to having the aquaculture project in their neighborhoods.

title: Hopeful on Relations, Vance Flies to China
description: ELMENDORF AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska. Aug. 20 (UPI)  Convinced that full diplomatic relations between Peking and Washington are both possible and desirable, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance flew to China today for the Carter Administration's first highlevel official meeting with Mao Tsetung's successors.

title: The 1MuseNew Life For Some French Landmarks
description: PARIS In Paris right now, a rococo wedding cake of a train station is being considered for a museum of the late 19th century. In the industrial area of Le Creusot, a coal mine where men once toiled miserably has become the setting of a permanent exhibition on man and the mine.  And a steel baron's chateau redolent of privilege will soon house a show on the representation of labor.

title: Takeover Threat At the Eiffel Tower?
description: PARISAfter gracing the Paris skyline fat 48 years, Alexandre Gustave Eiffel's Z2. eation is under attack again. No one is proposing to tear down this city's bestknown landmark, as Guy de Maupassant and other aesthetes of the 1890's urged. But the business life of the Eiffel Tower has been thrown into question: Should Mr. Eiffel's corporate successor be allowed to continue operating the tower concession?

title: Behind The Irish Cause
description: IN the late 1870's a disastrous combination of bad harvests, falling agricultural prices and bankrupt or relentless landlords brought the small farmers of Ireland, particularly In the west, to the verge of famine and despair and often beyond it. In order to protect these unfortunates from eviction and rackrenting and (in due time) to win the land of Ireland for the people of Ireland a young man named Michael Davitt, fresh from the hell of Dartmoor Prison, organized his famous Irish National Land League.

title: Focus Needed on Child Safety
description: MORE THAN 250,000 children under 5 years of age in Connecticut, plus more than 50,000 infants to be born by year's end, are at greater risk than their parents (with the exception of those with heart and lung conditions) to a wide range of organic and inorganic compounds in the air they breathe both indoors and out, the milk and water they drink and the food they eat. They are also at greater risk to a host of physical hazards that threaten life and limb.

title: Fugitives From Bench Warrants Linked to Thousands of Crimes
description: Nearly one in five persons arrested for felonies in New York City last year was a fugitive from earlier charges, according to statistics compiled, by a legislative

title: Joseph Rooney, Accountant, Marries Kathleen R. Blissert
description: Kathleen Rita Blissert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Blissert of Manhasset, L. I., was married yesterd. v afternoon to Joseph Gerard Rooney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Rooney, also of Manhasset. The Rev. Richatd C. Blissert, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Mulepowered Barge Makes a Comeback on the C & O Canal
description: Mules are back at work on the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal, but the barge they're hauling along the 19thcentury waterway these days is full of tourists, not coal.

title: A Change in the Capitol
description: NANCY Lewinsohn sees the business of government as Degas saw the ballet, as a subject with romance and excite ment and an infinite variety of light and movement. She knows it and indulged herself with it. In managing the complicated business of the Governor, Miss Lewinsohn captured the essence of it. But she never allowed the thrill or turmoil of government to swallow her soul or her considerable intellect. And when the time came, she left it.

title: Ocean Tests Predict More Fish Kills
description: FEDERAL and state environmental officials are keeping an eye on the waters off the Jersey coast to determine if there will be a recurrence of ocean conditions that led to massive fish kill last summer. They do not expect a kill as severe as the one last year, but they do expect smaller ones.

title: The Long Weekend
description: What I really wanted to do that weekend was to spend it in New York with my husband. I'd just been with my tamily over the Memorial Day weekend, and had been away on business during the week. I just wanted weekend alone.

title: Indeed, the Moral Equivalent of War
description: Two crises of significant dimensions are currently facing this country.

title: Tunisian National in Catskills Held for Rape on Fire Island
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Aug. 20 (AP)A Tunisian national employed at a summer camp in the Catskills was ordered held in lieu of $19,000 bail today when he was arraigned in the rape of a woman on Fire Farhat Bessrour, 24 years old was arrested yesterday in the attack on the woman in Fire Island Pines. The police said he was also charged with attacks on three women Thursday night.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market's relentless slide continued last week, while bond prices moved higher and posted their best gains for a single week since late June.

title: The Odd Shape:
description: What this city needs is elliptical foyers, angled closets, open kitchens, sleeping balconiesin a word, diversity in apartment design.

title: Focusing on Bateman's Image
description: THE most recent look at the New Jersey race for Governor by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University points up an unusual problem for State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican contender from Somerville.

title: The Ice Cream They Line Up For
description: MANHASSET THEY say that everyone on the Island is on a diet. One look at Swensen's in Manhasset on warm summer evening flatly disputes that theory.

title: The Whopperizing (etc. ) of the Area
description: First there was McDonald's. Then, just when people around Bedford and. Mount Kisco were getting tired of Big Macs, along came Burger King with its giant Whoppers.

title: $47,000 Linked to the Slaying Of Robert Topping Is Recovered
description: MIAMI, Aug. 20 (AP)A brown paper bag containing $47,000 has been recovered by detectives investigating the slaying of Robert Reid Topping as a result of what the authorities say was a cocaine deal.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: New York 6, Texas 2 (n. ). Baltimore 6, Minnesota 2. Kansas City 5, Boston 2 (n. ). Milwaukee 4, Chicago 2. Cleveland 5, Oakland 4 (12 inn. ). Detroit 7, Seattle 3 (n. ). Toronto 5, California 4 (n. ).

title: Jatski Wins Travers on Foul Claim
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 Jatski took the 108th Travers Stakes on a disqualification today, but the biggest winner of the afternoon was horse racing itself.

title: SPOT LIGHT
description: TOKYOFive decades ago when Yoshihiro Inayama consulted a nalmreader for good luck, as many aspiring young Japanese businessmen still do, he was told that he was a man of ironwilled resolve who would overcome all obstacles to accomplish what he set out to do.

title: Dr. Michael Miller, 67, Psychiatrist Who Specialized in Using Hypnosis
description: Dr. Michael M. Miller, a Washington psychiatrist who specialized in therapeudic hypnosis to treat obesity, alchoholism and cigarette smoking, died in Pittman, N. J. on Aug. 11. He was 67, years old.

title: City Ballet's Maestro Reminisces About Life on the Podium
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS. N. Y. Robert Irving, born, reared and educated in Winchester, England, is now in his 20th year as musical director of New York City Ballet, the longest period anyone has ever occupied the post. And, if anything, he seems to be increasing the scope and pace of his musical activities rather than coasting on his considerable reputation.

title: Starring Mothers
description: On any given night of the week, sometime before curtain time, in the pompously pretend French provincial lounge of the Alvin Theater, anyone who cares to can get a pretty fair idea of what Danielle Brisebois, or Shelley Bruce, or Diana Barrows will look like when they grow up.

title: Houstom Hooked on PCB
description: FOR bur decades a highly toxic chemical was discharged innocently into the Housatonic River, some of it settling to the bottom, some being absorbed by tiny aquatic creatures, and some eventually ingested by trout and perch and other fish in quantities that health and environmentalquality officials fear increasingly may be a peril to the humans who eat them.

title: Eileen Cooke Becomes Bride: Of Jean Brown.
description: Eileen Marita Cooke and Jean Mc:: Cauley Brown were married yesterday, in St. Patrick's Cathedral by Ms. George Murphy of Holy Trinity Church: Monsignor Murphy had also officiated at the marriage of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Cooke of _ Allenhurst, N.. 1., 27 years ago.

title: Primary Roundup
description: Representative Herman Radiilo ofthe Bronx, Whose latestarting and badly finzincicl campaign for the liemocratic mayoral nomination has only recently begun to show signs of life, callid yesterday Tor ??? limits on individual andsorpoeate. contributions to political contestants.

title: DiMauro Is Not Giving Up Easily In Quest for Little America's Cup
description: Tony DiMauro is stubborn. For 14 years he has clung to a dream of capturing the Little America's Cup. And now, after a seemingly endless series of frustrations, Tony DiMauro is headed down the homestretch. His boat, PaNews of Boating tient Lady III, trounced Coyote last week and became the United States defender for the International C Class Catamaran Challenge Trophy, commonly known as the Little America's Cup. The matchrace series for the cup started yesterday with Patient Lady winning the first race from the challenging Australian boat. Nicholas II, in the Pacific Ocean off Cabrillo Beach, Calif.

title: Cheri E. Bogert Becomes a Bride In Pennsylvania
description: Cerisa Eugenie Bogert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Calvin Bogert of Newton Square. Pa., was married yesterday to William Macintosh Throop 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Throop Jr. of New Canaan. Corm. The Rev. David Morrill Reed, a Presbyterian minister, performed the cereSwiss mony in the Japanese garden Pines, a park in Charlestown, Pa.

title: GARDENING
description: AGREEN convertible is a familiar sight on North Shore estates. Many wealthy and famous owners of estates have sat alongside the convertible driver to survey the condition of trees on their property.

title: Bruner Captures A. A. U. 200Meter Butterfly Title
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 20 Mike Bruner of Los Altos, Calif., an Olympic champion, swam to an impressive victory tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national longcourse championships. Then he told how he could have gone faster.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A. M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Mayor Beame,

title: Apples Conquer Lobsters, 2921, in W. T. T. Semifinal
description: BOSTON, Aug. 20 The icy confines of Boston University's hockey arena warmed quickly tonight as the New York Apples beat the Boston Lobsters, 2921, to open the twoofthreematch series for the Eastern Division title of World Team Tennis. The series moves to New York Monday for the second match. The winner of this series probably will be favored against the representative from the West Coast Division, either SeattlePortland or Phoenix, in the W. T. T. finals.

title: 2 Police Officers Hurt in Fire
description: Two police officers were injured slightly last night while evacuating residents of a Queens building during a twoalarm fire, according to the police. The officers, treated at St. John's Hospital for smoke inhalation and released, were Joseph Greco and Ronald Muscarella of the Catalpa Avenue station house in Ridgewood. The fire broke out in a threestory building at 663339 Fresh Pond Road near Woodbine Street, Ridgewood, Fire officials said they suspected arson.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: LARRY S. SNOWHITE, 30yearold deputy chief of New Jersey's office in Washington, quietly picked up his seven dwarfs a few and moved to a Federal job.

title: Holly M. Patterson Is Bride Of Kirk Schuessler on L. I.
description: Holly Moore Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Patterson, was married yesterday morning to Kirk John Schuessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Schuessler. The Rev. Thaddeus Semila performed the ceremony in St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church in Sea Cliff, L. I., where both families live.

title: How Business Grappled With The Arab Boycott
description: With the scratching of President Carter's pen on June 22, compliance with the Arab boycott of Israel became illegal. The intention of the new lawto limit the involvement of United States companies in the boycottis clear. The details of how the law will work are not clear. The legislation the President signed left many aspects of a touchy national issue to be resolved later.

title: Wine
description: Someday. someone is going to Write a novel about the wine count ry  the American wine country.

title: Notes: Tours Slated For Historic Homes
description: Once a year, in communities all over the nation, privacy goes by the board as the owners of historic homes open their doors to visitors as part of fundraising programs for local institutions. Two such events are upcoming in Litchfield, Conn., and Alexandria, Va.

title: Inside The British Government
description: IFIRST met Richard Crossman at a crowded London party, the sort where the host stands talking to you looking over your shoulder for a more important guest. It was 1965, and Crossman was Minister of Housing in the stillnew Labor Government. I said something about a muchcriticized housing plan in our neighborhood, Islington: the destruction of a beautiful square to build an ugly development. He defended the decision, giving the official logic; I backed off, saying he doubtless knew more about it. Then Crossman gripped my elbow and said Oh no, don't stop arguing!

title: Mary Hubbard, Traded, Remains Eager to Perform
description: They come and go in agate, small print that reports their movements as if they were soybeans or other commodities:

title: Now Britain Has Complex Racial Difficulties That Last Week Provoked Violence
description: LONDON  Mohammed Shafi was convicted of bigamy in Glasgow last week. The court was told that he had a wife and five children back home in Pakistan and had married a Scottish woman when his visa expired so he wouldn't have to leave Britain. The authorities did not call out the riot squad to deal with him, as they did this month when left and rightwing extremists got out of. hand in London and in Birmingham. But the bigamy of Mr. Shafi is one more paragraph in the same frustrating story. The race issue has turned out be as complex, painful, embarrassing and apparently insoluble in Britain as in the United States. The trouble is much newer for the British, but what lacks in age it makes up for in intricacy and passion.

title: The Patient, Tenacious Cleveland Indians Fan
description: My friend John is a Yankee fan. We are the same age, but of different loyalties. John learned about baseball in Ridgefield Park, N. J., within hailing digtance from Yankee Stadium. He has developed an affection for the Yankees that approaches religion.

title: Montclair Athletes Try Basic Ballet
description: MONTCLAIR AHUNDRED Montclair High School athletes are developing their coordination this summer by learning fundamental techniques at the New Jersey School of Ballet in West Orange.

title: TIIIOPIA'S LEADER ASKS FOR SUPPORT
description: ADDIS ABABA. Ethiopia, Aug. 20Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Miriam, the chairman of the military Government. here, tonight appealed to his Ethiopian countrymen to rally to defeat what he termed Somali invaders.

title: Japanese Beachhead in California
description: GARDENA, Calif. A motorist could get lost in this southern California city of 4,500 and think he had wandered into Japan. The tallest building in town is the Mitsubishi Bank. At the Pacific Square shopping center there are 40 shops, and it is unusual in any of them to see a face that is not Japanese.

title: PRENCE DENNIS, 83; ADVOCATED FASCISM
description: Lawrence Dennis. a diplomat, economist, writer and a staunch advocate of rascism for the United States, and who was one of 29 persons tried by the Federal Government in 1944 on charges bf sedition, died yesterday in the Community Hospital of Rockland County, in. Spring Valley, N. Y. He was 53 years old. His death was attributed to heart failure.

title: Margaret A. Felmly Bride of a Doctor
description: Margaret A. Felmly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lldyd M. Felmly of Salem, N. Y., tiers married there yesterday to Dr Hugh Ci:lbert Maddox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hueh G. Maddox of Carrollton,. Ga. The Rev. Edward Durkin performed tha ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Jane Fromstein Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Jane Fromstein to Kenneth Henley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Henley of Forest Hills, Queens, took place in Fox Point, Wis., last evening. Rabbi Jay Brickman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell S. Fromstein. The couple are thirdyear students at the Villanova University School of Law. Mrs. Henley graduated magna cum laude from Washington University. Her husband is an alumnus of Hamilton College.

title: STARRING CHILDREN
description: This season's newest, brightest fashions are modeled by this year's Wunderkinder of the theater who take center stage in Broadway's biggest hits  the girls from Annie and the boys from The King and I and Shenandoah. They, like children anywhere, look terrific in the fall clothes that are softer than ever with the loose lines and classic good looks that mirror adult fashion trends. For girls, silhouettes are loose, flowing and touched by the peasant influence. Many end with a bouncy hem flounce.

title: Lebanon, 19 Months After Civil War, Remains Divided by Religion and Foreign Troops
description: BEIRUT, Aug. 20Nineteen months after Syrian troops ended its savage civil war, Lebanon remains divided by sectarian passions, occupied by a foreign army, weakly governed and deeply embroiled in the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Christine Kolody Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Kolody of Garrison, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Christine Anne Kolody, to Mark Allen Wells, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Wells of Orchard Park, N. Y. Miss Kolody and her fianc attend Ashland (Ohio) College. Mr. Kolody is senior vice president of Barickman Advertising Inc.

title: Work Style
description: Do employees in suburban industrial parks spend their lunchtime dawdling over a sandwich, making an airplane out of the paper it was wrapped in, then twirling it around for a while?

title: Two Games Set in China By Cosmos
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 20The Cosmos have accepted an invitation to play two games in China, it was announced today by Warner Communications, the company that owns the North American Soccer League team. The two games will be played between Sept. 15 and 21 during the Cosmos'tour of Asia.

title: Paiunanian Leader Praises Treaty
description: PANAMA, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Panama's head of government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, described the new Panama Canal treaty as the triumph of this generation.

title: The Man With the Perfect Ear
description: WHEN in the 1920's Virginia Woolf drew the attention of thousands of English readers to Ring Lardner as a writer about games, she offered the theory that games gave American writers an indispensable meeting place for the divers activities of people whom a vast continent i'olates, in whom no traditions control.  I don't know if there is anything in this, but there is a vast amount of play, from poker upwards, in American writing; there is a close link with popular journalism, which has often been the starting point of writers as original and deft as Lardner was.

title: All That Attention Spurs Hoboken Rents and Prices
description: The media blitz in the last few years about that onceslumping city on the Hudson River has, predictably, resulted in escalating housing prices and apartment rents and speculative buying by both professionals and zealous newcomers.

title: STAMPS
description: To the customary high artistic quality of Swiss stamps, add the enhancing costumes and pageantry that accompany folk rites and festivals rich in tradition. The result is new issue of definitives that portrays the customs and observances that are part of the cultural heritage of the Swiss people.

title: James Boyd Jr. Weds Georgiana B. Smith
description: The marriage of Georgiana Birchard Smith to James Erwin Boyd Jr. took place yesterday at the home of Edythe Pulley Smith, mother of the bride, in Stamford, Corm. The bridegroom is the son of the Rev, and Mrs. James E. Boyd of Uniontown, Ohio. His father, a retired United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Births
description: Stephen and Jane (net Landau) joyfully announce the birth of Monica Jill, sister of Matthew Seth, born August 4, 1977.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: BELMAR AN Open Letter to a Former Pupil from a Retired Teacher. Dear George: Ive come to the beach at Belmar today because of you. I wonder if you remember the day you entered my fourthgrade class in 1967. You were shy and strangely quiet. In some way you were a transient, having attended the school before and and then returning after a stay with your grandfather in Florida.

title: The Strike Is Not the Problem
description: THE Taylor Law, which governs labormanagement relations for teachers and other public employees in New York State, will be 10 years old this September, but don't expect to see much celebrating by teachers or school boards. In fact, for several years now, both groups have been lobbying to change the law.

title: Liz Ducas Married ToSimonP. Bonham
description: Elizabeth Ann Ducas, a remedial teacher for the Inner London Education Authority, was married yesterday in Pawling, N. Y., to Simon Philip Bonham. a chartered surveyor with Bernard Thorpe & Partners, London chartered surveyors. The Rev. Leonard Niels per. formed the ceremony in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: My Trip Upstate
description: Well, we're off, three generations of charmers.

title: When Companies Move From City,
description: WHEN Maurice Chevalier was asked, as he frequently was in his last years, how felt about life as an octogenarian, his stock reply was, Well, when I think of alternative .  The same kind of reply is heard these days when business political leaders are asked how they feel about the continuing movement of New York City companies to the Island, New Jersey, Westchester County and Connecticut. both suburban and city leaders, the alternative to be avoided is the relocation of companies distant sunbelt states. Their concern is real, because some New York concerns are moving Georgia, Florida, Texas and California. Corporate Moves: New York Region Holds Its Own

title: An Emotional Success Story
description: Outside Of the mass pop market, most popular music in this country is still geared toward 45rpm singles. Acts that appeal primarily to lowerincome groups of the population, like country artists, black artists and Latin artists, can hope for a hit single more readily than a hit album. Their albums reflect that bias and generally consist of two or three potential hits and a residue of indifferent filler. Even if one of their singles crosses over into the mass market, the albums aren't consistent enough to enjoy a similar success. But the Emotions, a generally unknown black female trio, have managed to achieve a top10 single inBest of My Love, and a top10 album as well, in Rejoice.

title: The World
description: The fight was political but the underlying issue was race. Last week, Members of Britain's leftist Socialist Workers Party tried to break up march in London and a rally in Birmingham of the ultrarightist National Front. More than 100 police officers were injured and dozens of persons were arrested.

title: Ineligibles on Welfare Decline in New York State
description: New estimates indicate that the per centage of welfare families believed to be ineligible for aid throughout New York State has been reduced to its lowest proportion since state sampling surveys began in 1972. The reduction has been achieved by tighter controls, closing out old cases and blocking some newcomers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article Bohemian GroveWhere Big Shots Go to Camp (Aug. 14) implied that Andy Devine, the actor, is still living. Actually Mr. Devine died last Feb. 18 at the age of 71.

title: Bar Groups Urge Grand Jury Changes
description: TRENTON THE New Jersey Bar Association and the American Bar Association are pushing for changes in the way people are charged with crimes by reorganizing the grand jury system, the method now used in the state to bring criminal charges.

title: Yugoslavia's Roads, Even at Best, Test the Nerves
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 20Shrouding the narrow, snaking road with opaque exhaust smoke, four tractortrailer trucks, bumper to bumper, fix the 20mileanhour pace for the dozens of vehicles behind them.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Aug. 27Fairfield County Sports Car Club 350mile tulip rally; start at PitneyBowes parking lot, Route 7, Norwalk. Conn. Registration: 4 P. M. ; first car off 6:30. Information: E. Briner, phone t 203)9297783.

title: The Death of Groucho
description: Groucho Marx, perhaps the most gifted of America's funny men, died last week at the age of 86. A vaudeville performer from the age of 10, he and his four brothers brought insult, effrontery and brashness to previously unrealized artistic heights in a series of Broadway and movie hits in the 1920's and 1930's. Lately in failing health, Mr. Marx died unaware of a bitter legal battle over the management of his estate.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Since 1941 the United States Navy had used the Hawaiian island of Kahoolave as a bombing range, and for two Years. starting in 1975, a group of Hawaiians called Project Kahoolawe Mane had protested vigorously. The 45squaremile island, they said, was the home of their ancestors and contained their heiauf, rocked enclosures of religious significance.

title: New Mayor of West Berlin Flies To U. S. for Meeting With Carter
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 20  Dietrich Stobbe, West Berlin's new mayor, flies to Washington today for hi first visit since he took office in May. He will meet withs resident Carter at the White House.

title: Cynthia Merz Is Married To Carter Combe, Lawyer
description: Cynthia Merz and Carter K. Combe, graduates of the Boston University School of Law, were married yesterday in the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Richard Chrisman, a chaplain at Princeton, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: United States Asks The South Africans About ABomb Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI)The United States has formally asked the South African Governement whether reports that it plans to test a nuclear bomb are accurate, the State Department said today.

title: Bronx Tenants, Now Landlords, Toast a Victory
description: They opened champagne inside a fivestory walkup in the Bronx yesterday in a rare celebration by tenants of a once dilapidated building that had been abandoned by its landlord and then taken over by the, city.

title: Frost and Fungus Mar Season For Upstate YuleTree Growers
description: ALBANY, Aug 20It looks like a bad year for growers and users of Christmas trees. An early spring frost and virulent fungus have damaged Christmas tree plantations in upstate New York, indicating a short supply of trees and a possible nrice increase.

title: Klamath Forest Fire, Still Uncontained, Has Burned 43,000 Acres
description: The fire in the Klamath National Forest in California had scarred nearly 43,000 acres by today, and firefighters were still unable to estimate when the 10dayold blaze could be contained.

title: 5,000Meter Park Run Slated for Wednesday
description: The last of three runs in Central Park this summer for employees of New York City businesses will be held at 7 P. M. on Wednesday. The runners will gatherat the Tavern on the Green, Central Park West and 67th Street, and ran two laps around the southern end of the park, from 59th Street to 72d Street.

title: The Rush to Judgment on Lance
description: With a crack of his Presidential gavel, Chief Magistrate Carter has declared Bert Lance to be innocent. The hearty Mr. Lance, the Presidents budget director and adviser, may be just thatinnocent of illegal conduct or asserted improprieties, none of which, in any event, relates to his government service. But in reaching that conclusion on the basis of a partial report of the investigation by the Comptroller of the Currency, the President has rushed to judgment. To expect the public to accept that judgment is like expecting a jury to vote even though the trials only half over.

title: Sunday, August 21, 1977
description: Sunday, August 21, 1977

title: Education
description: Several weeks ago two dozen students at Parsippany Hills High School in New Jersey divided themselves into groups representing the world's population. The class was then given styrofoam blocks representing food, weapons and technology, and a process of bargaining began. By the end of the session emotions were high.

title: Alex Haley's Son Helps G. I.  s to Understand Each Other's Roots
description: FORT DIX, NJ. Bill Haley is the son of Roots.

title: Lissim: Artist Of Many Hues
description: WHEN Simon Lissim was aboard ship on a recent cruise to the South Pacific, he painted a monastery in Kiev, where he was born. Once home again in his Dobbs Ferry studio, he painted a bright canvas entitled South Pacific'sea serpents with scales of shimmering gold and a pearly octopus in the translucent emerald deep.

title: IN SEARCH OF BELLA
description: What I was doing on a weathered Greenwich Village stoop at the ungodly hour of 7:30 A. M. was keeping an appointment with Bella Abzug.

title: Tenants Turning to Rent Boards
description: FAIR RENT Commissions in the state are experiencing an increase in the complaints about high rent and poor services that they receive each year. As more tenants become aware of them, the commissions get more calls, said Diana M. Crouse, director of the Fair Rent Commission in Stamford and chairman of the State Federation of Fair Rent Commissions.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. & Mrs. Arthur Bennett, Baldwin Harbour, NY announce the engagtment Aug. 10, 1977 cf their daughter Eileen to Eugene Shailk. son of Mr. E. Mrs. Alvin Shalik, Oceanside, N. Y.

title: George's Girl
description: IT is Paris, in the autumn of 1836, and Chopin has met George Sand, the cigarsmoking, pantswearing woman novelist. How unpleasant this Sand is, he remarks to a friend as they leave the Hotel de France. Lc she really a woman? I almost doubt it.  And Sand, at about the same moment.

title: Dog Fanciers to Receive PostLabor Day Rewards
description: The nation's fanciers have any number of postLabor Day delights in store. The prestigious Westchester and Tuxedo Park allbreed dog shows on Sept. 11 and 9, respectively, again will be held amid the spacious, treeshaded.

title: Margaret Gilliland Married
description: Margaret Seeley Gilliland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Alexander Gilliland of Fairfield, Coust. was married there yesterday afternoon to Andrew Dimitri Soussloff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dimitri Gregory Soussloff of Wyomissing, Pa. The Rev. Stanley Houston performed the ceremony in the Greenfield Hill Congregational. Church.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE community is beginning to look like any other suburban development with allyear homes. There is a macadam road, an official traffic sign, a mailbox for every house. But it wasn't always like that. It seems it was just a few years ago, in the time of my youth, that it was a summer bungalow colony in Putnam Valley to which owners and renters from the Bronx and Brooklyn escaped every July 1 and remained until after the big Labor Day weekend party.

title: P. G. A. Launches Drivel To Erase Chalk Lines
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 20 Play it where it liesa basic tenet of the grand old game of golfhas not been a basic tenet of the Professional Golfers Association in recent years. But it soon will be again.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: There's no end to it, no end to it, a friend observed the other day, referring to the interminable round of meals she had to prepare for her 6yearold son. I'll send you a book I just read, I answered, It'll put things in a different light.

title: MANY INDONESIANS KILLED IN LANDSLIDE
description: JAWARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 20 (AP)At least: 98 persons are feared dead on the Indotiesian island of Sumbawa as a result of a landslide caused by an earthquake in the Indian Ocean, officials said here today.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: ATENTATIVE study reportedly places some of the blame for the state's high cancer rate on the chemical industry. A state official who has seen the preliminary version of the report called it a blockbuster that could set off considerable public debate.

title: John Desmond, 68, ExTimes Editor
description: John Desmond, a former assistant Suneditor of The New York Times, died yresterday at Central Siiffolk Hospital in liverhead. L. I. He was 68 years old and Ived in Quogue, LI.

title: Columbia Student Is Killed by a Car While Helping Friend Load Truck
description: A graduate student at Columbia University died early Friday morning after a freak traffic accident on West 90th Street, in which a taxi allegedly ran a red light and struck a bus, which then struck a passenger car that went out of control. The passenger car pinned the student, David Sheehy, against a truck.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: ADOLF HITLER, by John Toland. (Ballantine, $2. 95. ) A long, full biography of a strange, transfixing, repellent man, from his obscure childhood Austria to his Gdtterdamerung death in a bunker in Berlin. From many interviews with survivors and a close study of published sources, John Toland offers some new clues to a great enigma. A best seller in hardcover.

title: Actors Find Theater
description: MONTCLAIR HERE is a touch of Don Quixote about the Whole Theater Company. Four years ago they moved into the basement of the First Baptist Church with the impossible dream of being New Jersey's first resident professional theater company.

title: Russia Breaks the Ice
description: The eternal dream of generations of sailors and polar explorers has been realized, Soviet television announced last week after the Soviet Union's nuclear powered icebreaker Arktika became the first surface ship to reach the North Pole.

title: Today's Sections
description: Today's Sections

title: ARAB RADIO A GAUGE OF POLITICAL FEELING
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 21 (AP) Radios are the thermometer of Arab political emotion, an Arab columnist wrote recently. But this emotion is 501 volatile that the thermometer keeps going up and down like a crazy acrobat.

title: Amy Natkins Bride Of Richard Lipton, A Medical Student
description: Amy Natkins, who starts her second year at the Boston University School of Law this fall, was married yesterday to Richard Lipton, a student at the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine. Rabbi Stephen Pinsky performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents in Putnam Valley. N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Natkins of Great Neck, L.I. Her father is a lawyer and a deputy mayor of the Village of Thomaston, which is part of Great Neck. Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Lipton of Wilmette, Ill., are the parents of the bridegroom, whose father is a chemist.

title: Putting the Festive Into Opera Festival
description: What makes a summer opera festival festive? The Santa Fe Opera's !answer to this question has remained pretty much the same since the company's first season 21 years ago, and on the whole it has worked well: Revive at least one interesting opera from the past, balance that with a contemporary novelty and fill out the bill of fare with important repertory staples, all restudied and rehearsed under optimum performing conditions.

title: Vicki Rachel Grossman Bride of Arnold Phillips
description: Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown, N.Y., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Vicki Rachel Grossman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Grossman of Irvington, N.Y., to Arnold M. Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Phillips of New York. Rabbi Paul Siegel performed the ceremony and Cantor Albert Ruttner, cousin of the bride, assisted.

title: Mine Union Chiefs to Meet on Ways to Halt Strike
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Aug. 21The top leadership of the United Mine Workers Union is to convene here tomorrow in an effort to end a wildcat strike that began two months ago in reaction to cutbacks in miners medical benefits by the U.M.W. Health and Retirement Funds.

title: Cavett's Interview Show on WNET To Go On Despite a Fund Shortage
description: Dick Cavett's new nightly interview program for the Public Broadcasting Service will have its premiere Oct. 10, as scheduled, an official of WNET said yesterday, despite a shortage of more than $1 million in production funds for the series.

title: Unable to Bury Jets, Steelers Praise Them
description: Because he has a long memory, Dan Rooney, the president of the Steelers, permitted himself his little laugh on Saturday night after Pittsburgh completed a thirdand21 pass against the Jets.

title: Senate Banking Unit to Investigate Practices Noted in Lance Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Senator William Proxmire, citing some of the activities of Budget Director Bert Lance before he joined the Government, announced today that the Senate Banking Committee would conduct a broad investigation of the ethics and soundness of American banking.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Saratoga Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUNSET SAFARI Roosevelt Island, an easily accessible area that nevertheless remains unfamiliar at close range to many New Yorkers, will be the scene of the latest guided tour by the enterprising group Adventure on a Shoestring. Recent itineraries have included visits to a portrait painter, an interior designer and tours of a Manhattan winery and a Fifth Avenue mansion. The membership unit is also open for single events to nonmembers.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 22, 1977

title: A. T. &
description: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 21A former employee who has led a threeyear attack against the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company has admitted that he filed false expense statements in his 23 years with the company.

title: Rotary Leader Gives Awards To 11 Jerseyans
description: NEWARK, Aug. 21Rotary International's president, who supervises the service activities of more than 800,000 Rotarians in 152 countries, came to New Jersey yesterday to praise the service and the support of 11 persons.

title: Linda R. Sinsheimer Wed to Robert B. Moser
description: Linda Ruth Sinsheimer and Robert B. Moser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Moser of Maplewood, NJ., were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Sinsheimer of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: New Investments In Manufacturing Soar Worldwide
description: Despite pessimism and caution about business in this country and in Europe, a surge of manufacturing investment activity around the world augurs well for improved economic prospects, according to a report by the Conference Board.

title: ESCAPED NAZI'S HEALTH IS SAID TO DETERIORATE
description: BONN, Aug. 21Unconfirmed reports said today that the health of Herbert Kappier, the Nazi war criminal who fled from Italy to West Germany last Monday, was deteriorating.

title: MAN HIJACKS A JETLINER, YIELDS IN SALT LAKE CITY
description: DENVER, Aug. 21 (AP)A man pretending to carry a bomb took over a HonolulutoDenver jetliner carrying 31 persons and ordered the pilot to land at Salt Lake City and to have the flight met by the police. Once on the ground, the man surrendered and the plane cornTileted its trip.

title: Preseason Football
Rift Emerges in CasinoGambling Law Enforcement
description: MAYS LANDING, Aug. 21The first rift in lawenforcement circles in the new casinogambling era emerged over the weekend when the Atlantic County sheriff, Mario Floriani, charged Richard J. Williams, the County Prosecutor, with blocking him from appointment to Governor Byrne's Atlantic City Area Law Enforcement Council.

title: THOMAS M. WOLSIN
description: TAORMINA, Sicily, Aug. 21 (AP)Thomas M. Wolsin, an American businessman and an owner of the Baldwin Piano Company, was found dead in the swimming pool of his hotel here, authorities said today. The 53yearold Mr. Wolsin was believed to have died yesterday of a heart attack while vacationing here, officials said. A native of Ohio, he had been living in Geneva for some time.

title: Yacht Items Returned, White House Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)Missing furnishings from the Presidential yacht Sequoia, which was sold this spring as part of President Carter's nofrills campaign, have all been returned to proper Government hands, according to a White House official.

title: Princeton Radio Interviewers Put Powerful on the Spot
description: PRINCETON, N.J.The country's secondmost popular publicaffairs radio program is prepared and produced here each week by a bunch of college kids who think nothing of putting famous people on the spot.

title: North Gains His First Victory By Taking Westchester Classic
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 21The man was wrong, Andy North did not choke. In fact, he was so sure of himself that on the first tee of today's final round, when a tournament official asked him if he wanted to fill out a selfaddressed envelope so that his winnings could be mailed to his home, North answered, No, thanks; I'll collect on the 18th green.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 21 (Reuters)Ethiopia's military rulers told their people today about major battlefield casualties in their eastern border war.

title: Creamer/FSR Lands Three New Accounts
description: Three pieces of new business have been acquired recently by Creamei/FSR Inc. that add up to $2.5 million in billings. The accounts are the Gruvann Aerospace Corporation, StudebakerWorthington Inc. and New York and New West magazines, for a special advertising program.

title: 16 Rhodesian Blacks Reported Killed by Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY. Rhodesia, Aug. 21 (Reuters)Sixteen African men women and children were killed by black nationalist guerrillas who attacked and burned their homes on a whiteowned farm in eastern Rhodesia, military headquarters said today.

title: Csonka's Knee Holds Up in Giants
description: The Giants look like they have finally found the entrance to the tunnel with all the light at the end.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/William E. Sauro

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 21 (AP)The first outbreaks of influenza have been reported in the Southern Hemisphere this summer, but the national Center for Disease Control says that it is too early to tell which variety might prevail in any outbreaks this winter in the United States.

title: De Gustibus: Of Body English and Italian Muscle
description: In a recent article from Pontedassio, Italy, it was noted that Gioacchino Rossini had an almost passionate craving for pasta in any and all of its forms. This prompted a letter from a friend, Edward Schneider, of Woodhaven, N.Y.

title: Michele Mandelbaum Wed to William Bursten
description: Michele Mandelbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mandelbaum of Woodmere, L. I., was married last evening to William C. Bursten, an assistant attorney general in New York. Rabbi Morris S. Friedman performed the ceremony in Temple Hillel in North Woodmere.

title: League Leaders
Toronto Holds Fugitive for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)Larry Smith, listed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as one of the nation's 10 most wanted fugitives, was arrested yesterday by the Toronto metropolitan police, the bureau announced today. Mr. Smith, charged in Toronto with carrying a concealed weapon and marijuana law violations, escaped from custody in Detroit before he was to be tried for murder and conspiracy to attempt murder.

title: Chess:
description: In the third game of his semifinal Candidate's Match with the Hungarian grandmaster Lajos Portisch in Evian, France, Boris Spassky, a former world champion, suffered the first defeat because he failed to produce any initiative against the Breyer defense and later fell into errors.

title: Son of Sam
description: Like an ultimate law school or journalism school hypotheticala scenario built of conflicting principlesthe press's coverage of the Son of Sam case has raised some of the thorniest questions in American journalism. As the case itself began to recede from the public consciousness in recent days, the coverage grew as a subject of debate among journalists and the public at large.

title: Wizardry Brims Land of Oz Alive
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK. Calif.One hundred Winkles from the West of Oz met recently in the sun room of a Yosemite National Park Hotelabout as far west as they could comfortably get in the continental United Statesto bid at an auction of Oz books, Tshirts, pillowcases, homemade dolls and coloring books.

title: Swimming
Bogus Documents Hamper Drive on Illegal Aliens
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 21An enormous black market in fraudulent documents is thwarting efforts to stem the flow of illegal aliens into the United States.

title: KAUNDA SAYS KISSINGER FAILED IN RHODESIA TALKS
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 21 (UPI)President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia said today that the effort by fornier Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to solve the Rhodesia crisis was finished once Mr. Kissinger let Britain talk him into dealing with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith..

title: U.S. RABBIS FIGHT BEGIN IN ISRAEL ON CONVERTS
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 21Two American rabbis lobbied in the Israeli Parliament and said today that they were assured of sufficient votes to block a move by Prime Minister Menahem Begin that would deny the privileges normally accorded Jews to converts to Conservative or Reform Judaism who immigrate to Israel.

title: Bogus Documents Hamper Drive on Illegal Aliens
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 21An enormous black market in fraudulent documents thwarting efforts to stem the flow of illegal aliens into the United States.

title: Indiana Police Station Burns After Burglary
description: FRANKTON, Ind., Aug. 21 (AP)Someone broke into the local police station yesterday, then set a fire that destroyed it, the police said.

title: CHINESE LEADERSHIP APPEARS CONFIDENT UPON VANCE ARRIVAL
description: PEKING, Monday; Aug. 22The Chinese with whom Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will talk on a visit that began today appear to be in a far more confident and stable position than the Peking leadership has been since at least the visit of former President Nixon in early 1972.

title: Riders Compete for Top Honors In the 5th Horse Show in Leonia
description: LEONIA, Aug. 21If one had suggested staging a horse show in Bergen County two or three years ago, the idea would probably have been dismissed as impractical. The idea might even have gotten some laughsthe horse variety. There were laughs when the bigleague football, basketball, soccer and thoroughbred and harness racing were first proposed for the ???.

title: Hopes of 78 Solar Energy Boom Buoy Manufacturers at Coast Show
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21Manufacturers of solar energy systems gatherN here over the weekend with optimistic projections of a doubling or tripling of industry activity in the coming year.

title: Topics
description: TESTING A PLANE  The Concorde may finally get its chance for a fair test at Kennedy airport if the latest court decision holds up. A Federal District Court judge only stated the obvious when he criticized the Port Authority for its arbitrary refusal to permit tests to determine whether the supersonic plane can meet existing noise standards. The Port Authority has, of course, announced its intention to appeal the decision, and local resident groups have announced that they may shut down the airport if the tests should actually been.
