Both threats seem to us misguided. The only way to determine whether the Concorde will make life more uncomfortable for the people who live near the airport is to test it. If it proves too noisy, it can be barred. We hope the appeals will move fast; the continuing delays are inexcusable.

title: 4 Gunmen Flee Museum With $50,000 to $100,000 in Rare Coins
description: Four armed men overpowered two guards at the American Numismatic Society's museum at Broadway and 156th Street yesterday afternoon, and then, after smashing four display cases and scooping up as many as 300 rare coins, strolled out the front door, telling waiting visitors that the museum was closed.

title: A New Globe
description: Actor Converts Church to Elizabethan Stage

title: Advertising
description: Sales Maids of America, which provides instore merchandising services to supermarkets, drugstores and discount houses, is going national next month after four years of operation. So William P. Cleussen, its president, made the trip last week from his Westport, Conn., offices to New York to talk about the growth of this type of organization.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/William E. Sauro

title: World University Games
description: AT SOFIA, BULGARIA

title: Royals Turn Back Red Sox, 64, in Battle of Threatened Division Leaders
description: The upperechelon density of the American Laegue's two divisional races continued apace yesterday. The Kansas City Royals and the Boston Red Sox remained atop their respective divisions, but five other valid contenders, all within 1 games of the top, were nionina at the leaders heels.

title: The Party Gives French Reds a Taste of La Bonne Vie
description: MONTGENEVRE, France, Aug. 17Tucked in a valley at the foot of the Alps only a few miles from the Italian border, the St.Ouen Mountain Center resembles any of the other nearby lodges and small hotels that are packed with French tourists during the summer vacation.

title: Parley Is to Discuss Health Care
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (UPI)National health care policies are to be discussed at the annual convention of the National Association of Community Health Centers Inc. to begin tomorrow in Cincinnati. More than 1,000 community health administrators, physicians nurses and educators are expected attend the convention, which is to end Thursday.

title: U.S. Considering., a Takeover of Chicago's Public Jobs Program
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Carter Administration, reacting to charges of irregularities in the assignment of public service jobs under a federally funded program in Chicago, is considering whether the Labor Department should take control of the program from local politicians, according to White House sources.

title: Border Dispute Doubly Taxing for Villagers
description: ANDES, N.Y.Dismayed farmers and villagers who own land along the border between Andes and neighboring Bovine, upstate in Delaware County, are suddenly faced with tax bills from both towns.

title: Soviet Apparently Trying to Prove Dissident Is a Hardened Criminal
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21Soviet authorities preparing a case against Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, an imprisoned dissident have reportedly been interrogating former prison acquaintances in what appears to be an effort to portray him as a hardened criminal who deserves a stiff sentence.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee

title: Gwen Solan, Cornell Student, Is Bride of James S. Teicher
description: Gwen Emily Solan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Solan of Great Neck, L. I., was married yesterday evening to James Steven Teicher, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Teicher of Kings Point, L. I. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at the Inwood (L. I.) Country Club.

title: In the Name of Reason
description: Several thousand psychiatrists will meet in Honolulu next week at the sixth congress of the World Psychiatric Association. The event sounds like one of professional interest only. In fact, it will be a testing ground on an issue of profound public importance, involving human rights and international politics as well as medical ethics.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because a typographical error, the number of crime complaints to New York City's Police Department was incorrectly stated in yesterday's Times. There were 1,183,000 complaints in the year ended June 30, down from 1,260, 000 in 1975.76.

title: 2 Sons of Political Figures Press Primary Campaigns
description: The sons of two politically influential figuresyoung men hoping to scale the political heights themselves somedayare squaring off against each other and two other opponents in the personalitydominated Democratic primary for Manhattan borough president.

title: Dividend Meeting
description: Pertial list scheduled for week follows:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: McIntire's Parade for Tax Exemption Runs Into a Traffic Charge
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 21 (UPI)The Rev. Carl McIntire, a fundamentalist preacher, faces charges of obstruction of traffic for leading supporters of his tax dispute with the city in a rally down Beach Street here yesterday.

title: Beame Links Lawyer Who Wrote S.E.C. Report to Cuomo Campaign
description: Pressing his preemptive campaign against the forthcoming Securities and Exchange Commission report on New York City's fiscal, troubles, Mayor Beame linked its main author yesterday with a law firm involved in the campaign of one of his opponents.

title: Liddy Prison Strike to Be Reviewed
description: ALLENWOOD, Pa., Aug. 21 (UPI)A prison board will determine whether any action will be taken against G. Gordon Liddy, the convicted Watergate burglar, and 57 other inmates at the Federal penal facility here who are accused of intimidating prisoners to take part in a hunger strike, an official said today. The official said he did not know whether the incident would affect Mr. Liddy's scheduled release on parole next month. The fiveday strike ended yesterday. Mr. Liddy and the others were transferred to the maximum security penitentiary in nearby Lewisburg.

title: Shah Is Due in Warsaw Today
description: WARSAW, Aug. 21 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran arrives here tomorrow on a fiveday official visit for talks with the Polish Communist Party leader, Edward Gierek, centering on economic cooperation. Trade between the two countries has risen sharply in recent years, and a Foreign Trade Ministry spokesman said today that Poland was proposing regular imports of Iranian crude oil at fixed annual quotas.

title: BELL PLANS TO FORM CRIME DATA BUREAU
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has taken steps to create a new bureau of criminal justice statistics to replace a fragmented and muchcriticized system of measuring crime in the nation.

title: Risking Popularity
description: History has been unkind to Mayors of New York City, and the world of politics has been unreceptive even to those who have survived the job.

title: Ceausescu, Ignoring Communist Rift, Cables Fraternal Salute
description: VIENNA, Aug. 21 (Reuters)President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, ignoring Moscow's ideological rift with Peking, today cabled a cordial fraternal salute to Chairman Hua Kuofeng at the end of China's 11th Communist Party Congress.

title: Climb to HalfGame of Top After Beating Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 21It was Graig Nettles's turn to take the spotlight tonight as the New York Yankees continued their winning streak and moved to within half a game of first place in the American League East. He knocked in both runs and contributed some fine defensive play to a 21 victory over the Texas Rangers, pitched by Ron Guidry and Sparky Lyle.

title: Women Work Harder Michigan Study Show
description: WASHINGTON (Agence FrancePresse)Men waste more time at work than women, get better paid despite this and do not pull their weight in chores at home, a University of Michigan study shows.

title: Foes at an Energy Parley Agree To Seek Alternative to Courtroom
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Aug. 20A new apDroach to resolving environmental conRiots, through mediation instead of litigation, won significant endorsement from ongtime adversaries at a national confermce here this weekend.

title: Fuel Tanks Empty in Coast Crash, Federal Air Investigator Reports
description: MODESTO, Calif., Aug. 21 (AP)All six fuel tanks were empty when a private twinengine plane crashlanded an a busy freeway where it killed three persons, a Federal investigator said yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: ARAB SIGNAL TO U.S. BELITTLED BY ISRAELI
description: Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations, Chaim Herzog, suggested yesterday that it was merely for Western consumption if Egypt, Syria and Jordan signaled to Washington a willingness to sign peace treaties with Israel as part of an overall Middle East settlement

title: Competing With Freddy Laker
description: It took Laker Airways six years to win approval for cheap, noreservations, nofrills Skytrain flights between New York and London. Now the established international airlinesPan Am, British Airways, TWA, Air India, Iran Air, El Alpropose to meet Freddy Laker's challenge. They plan service at competitive prices that would permit reservations and a few frills as well. Best of all, they would fly into London's convenient airports, rather than being exiled to Stansted field, some 35 miles from downtown.

title: Westchester Classic Golf Scores
South Africa Says It Is Not Planning Atomic Bomb Tests
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, Aug. 21 (Reuters)South Africa has told the United States and other countries that reports that it is about to test a nuclear weapon are wholly and totally unfounded, Foreign Minister Roetof F. Botha said today.

title: Official Hails Cattlemen's Merger
description: DENVER, Aug.,21 (UPI)An official of the American National. Cattlemen's Association today said that the organization's merger with the National Livestock Feeders Association next month would give cattlemen more power in state legislatures and Congress. George S. Spencer, executive vice president of the cattlemen's association, said that the merger was effective Sept. 1 and the new group to be based in Denver, would be called the National Cattlemen's Association, repreenting 275,000 cattlemen and cattle feeders across the nation. The feeders association has 12,000 members concentrated in the Corn Belt.

title: 11 Lebanese Killed On Leaving.Church. In Christian Village
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 21Eleven people were killed and 26 wounded today in clashes in a Christian village In the Chuf district 18 miles south of here, the Lebanese police reportde.

title: Bridge:
description: Like most other activities, bridge. playing virtually ceased when the lights went out in New York City last month. But at one location, the duplicate game went right on to the finish. The All Souls Club, which has a weekly game Wednesday nights at 1157 Lexington Avenue, was able to continue its game because Ted Kovaleff, the director of the tournament, was able to borrow some church candles, which is what he did during the last blackout 12 years ago. And three of the players, Lauck and Jeanne Walton and Ruth Leigh, write having this unusual experience for the second time. In 1965 the blackout was on a Tuesday, but since then the All Souls Club, like the Consolidated Edison Company, has changed its day.

title: Singing of Irene Kral a Revelation
description: For New Yorkers, Irene Kral has been more a rumor than a reality for many years. She was singing with Maynard Ferguson's band 20 years ago but, shortly after that, she settled in Los Angeles and, aside from an occasional record, was rarely heard in New York.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rutherford Wins in 200
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 (AP)Johnny Rutherford, taking the lead when Al Unser dropped out 27 laps from the finish, scored an easy victory today in the Tony Bettenhausen 200mile race for Indianapolis cars. The winning average speed was 103 miles an hour.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Wildwood Police Replace Dismissed Lifeguards

title: FEW REGARD RALLY IN CREDIT MARKETS AS OF LONG DURATION
description: The credit markets advanced last week in their most solid gain since late June, but few people in Wall Street seemed convinced that it would last very long. The primary determinant of the market rally, explained William E. Gibson of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, appears to have been the realization that shortterm rates, as measured by Federal funds, have already made their most dramatic moves.

title: Dance: Mitchell
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21The dance viewer who had a nickel for every ballet he saw called Untitled would be indecently rich. Untitled is far and away the most handy and intriguing catch word to describe a work that a choreographer Is struggling with. It may mean either that he simply can't think of a name that is entirely suitable or that the piece has yet to find its final form snd will require extensive resetting.

title: Begin's Unswerving Policy
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 20Despite numerous predictions that he is on a collision course with the United States, Prime Minister Menahem Begin does not think so. On the contrary, he gives every sign of being so deeply convinced of the righteousness of his view that he cannot imagine how rightthinking people, including an American President, could possibly insist on the opposite.

title: Tornado Kills Two in Italy
description: ROME, Aug. 21 (AP)A tornado cut through three coastal towns in Italy early today, killing at least two young persons and causing widespread damage and flooding. The police said the body of a yearold baby had been pulled from the wreckage of a mobile home after the tornado struck a campground in Santa Marinella, about 30 miles northwest of Rome. An 18yearold Roman youth was killed when the twister knocked a small cabin onto his tent, authorities reported.

title: Science Satellite to Land Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)Seven American biological experiments launched. in a Soviet satellite Aug. 3 are to parachute Thursday to a soft landingin. Siberia. The mission is the second in. which American lifescience experiments have been carried out in a Soviet satellite. Among the items placed on board were containers of fruit flies and 30 rats.. The satellite also carried experiments. ifrom the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia I and France.

title: In Memoriam
description: MURPHYWilliam J. In memory, William (Bill) J. Murphy, August 22, 1976. Always remembered. Our dear friend. The Fishman Family

title: Deaths
description: ACHILLESHelen Newell. Wife of H. Laurance Achilles, peacefully at home in Manchester Lanier, Vermont, on August 2U, atter a long Illness.

title: P.T.A. to Fight Television Violence
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)Grace Baisinger, the president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, said today that her organization would begin a nationwide effort to reduce television violence and might boycott violent programs and their sponsors. Mrs. Baisinger, interviewed on CBSTV's Face the Nation program, said that her group was I trying to educate parents to be more discriminating in the programs they allow their children to watch. She said that local P.T.A. groups would report their findings on television violence to the national organization and that either group may decide to boycott objectionable programs or the products of their sponsors.

title: Pierre Cot, Minister of Aviation In France Before World War II
description: CHANBERRY, France, Aug. 21 (Reuters)Pierre Cot, a former French cabinet minister and leftwing politician died here today, his family said. He was 82 years old.

title: Sverige Reaches Finals for America's Cup Challenger
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 21Sverige, the Swedish entry whose name the domestic yachting crowd now bothers to pronounce correctly (phonetically it's Svereeah), got into the finals of the America's Cup Challenger Series today by defeating Gretel II, the sevenyearold Australian yacht from Sidney. The margin at the end of an unexceptional race was decisive1 minute 58 seconds.

title: Reds
description: Tom Seaver, who pitched 367 games for the New York Mets in 10 years, finally pitched one against them yesterday. And in a dramatic homecoming before 46,265 persons in Shea Stadium, he not only outpointed his longtime friend, Jerry Koosman, but also fired a classic sixhitter with 11 strikeouts that gave the Cincinnati Reds a 51 victory and a fourgame sweep of the weekend series.

title: BELL PLANS TO FORM CRIME DATA BUREAU
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has taken steps to create a new bureau of criminal justice statistics to replace a fragmented and muchcriticized system of measuring crime in the nation.

title: Again, BackAlley and SelfInduced Abortions
description: WASHINGTONIn 1973, the United States Supreme Court ruled that an abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy is a matter to be decided on by a woman and her physician. It is, therefore, particularly disappointing that recent Congressional action would deny the realization of that decision for poor women by prohibiting Medicaid funding for elective abortions.

title: Amy Ellen Jaroslow Is Bride of Richard Gallagher
description: Amy Ellen Jaroslow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Jaroslow of Manhasset, L. L, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Gallagher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Gallagher of Clarks Summit, Pa. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony in the Rainow Room in Rockefeller Center. Cantor Richard Berman assisted.

title: Marcos Tells Law Parley He'll Ease Martial Law
description: MANILA, Monday, Aug. 22President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that he would ease his fiveyear martial law restrictions by calling for National AssembItt electionq nest ??? the 1 A.M.to4 A.M. curfew and the ban on foreign travel by ???.

title: Ethiopia, if History's a Guide, May Face Cataclysm
description: Ethiopia is disintegrating. The Dergue, Ethiopia's ruling military council, in Addis Ababa, is now confronting escalating hostilities by secessionist forces in Eritrea to the north, by Somali secessionist forces in the Ogaden region to the southeast, and by antiDergue forces in the western provinces. In the process, Ethiopia is gradually becoming a landlocked state, with limited or no access to Red Sea ports, which are essential to the country's economic development. If history is any guide, the consequences for Ethiopia be cataclysmic.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: California Report Shows Lobbyists Spent $40 Million in 197576 to Influence State
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21The staff of the California Fair Political Practices Commission spread before the voters last week the financial nuts and bolts of the state's lobbying industry.

title: Yale Faculty Members Charged With Sexual Harassment in Suit
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18A court battle over whether Yale University faculty members have sexually harassed their students is scheduled to commence soon as thousands return here for a new academic year and for soul searching about the issues in the controversy.

title: TAIWAN CALM AS VANCE HEADS FOR PEKING TALKS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 21The mood in Taiwan remains calm and even relaxed as Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance travels to Peking to discuss ways of normalizing United States relations with China.

title: Ingrates Unite,
description: Tom Seaver, a pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds who owns a house in Greenwich, Conn., rode to Shea Stadium yesterday with Skip Lockwood, a neighbor who pitches for the New York Mets. They arrived about 10:45 A.M., ahead of the other Cincinnati players and well before writers, photographers and radiotelevision types descended on the visitors clubhouse. Seaver had changed clothes in this room on Friday when the Reds won the first two games of the series and again on Saturday when Cincinnati made it three straight, but then he was only spectator. This was the real thing. This time he would pitch for the first time against the team whose star and leader he was until June 15, the date he was traded in M. Donald Grant's Wednesday Night Massacre.Seaver fished a yellow Tshirt from his locker.

title: Begin's Unswerving Policy
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 20Despite numerous predictions that he is on a collision course with the United States, Prime Minister Menahem Begin does not think so. On the contrary, he gives every sign of being so deeply convinced of the righteousness of his view that he cannot imagine how rightthinking people, including an American President, could possibly insist on the opposite.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee

title: Leg Ailment Turned North To Golf and Good Fortune
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 21Andy North cried on the way home that day in 1963 after his doctor informed him: You have to quit everythingfootball, baseball and basketball. You have two choices. You can either stay in bed for a year or wear a leg brace and use crutches for 18 months.

title: Haunted by a Death, Man Saves 3 in River
description: MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Aug. 21 (UPI)Recalling his inability to save a young boy's life six years ago, Don Schmidt frantically hacked through the hull of an overturned cabin cruiser Friday to save the lives of three boaters.

title: Commodities
description: Starting this morning, institutional and ordinary investors in longterm fixedincome securities will have a way to hedge their investments against the ravages of inflation and adverse interest rate movements.

title: The Standings
description: Monday, August 22, 1977

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: SeventhDay Adventists Oppose Church Approval of Homosexuals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)ResistIng a trend in some more liberal Protestant denominations, leaders of the Seventhday Adventist Church today strongly condemned homosexual behavior.

title: Major Reductions in Death Rates Reported by Newark Health Aides
description: NEWARK, Aug. 21City health officials reported here today that, after more than a decade of receiving Federal healthcare funds and after intensive local efforts, death rates for several major illnesses had been dramatically reduced.

title: Carter Back in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)President Carter returned to the White House tonight, ending a week's vacation at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. Earlier the President and his family attended a private church service at the retreat in the Catoctin mountains.

title: The MosCow Circus
description: MOSCOW, July 19 (UPI)Ah, circus, the Moscow Circus with the tigers, the elephants, the bears, the dancing cows.

title: Major League Scores
Son of Sam
description: Like an ultimate law school or journalism school hypotheticala scenario built of conflicting principlesthe press's coverage of the Son of Sam case has raised some of the thorniest questions in American journalism. As the case itself began to recede from the public consciousness in recent days, the coverage grew as a subject of debate among journalists and the public at large.

title: Cosmos Overcome Lancers, 21, in Series Opener
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 21After the Cosmos rallied and defeated the Lancers, 21, today, Coach Eddie Firmani of the Cosmos wanted to let the world know that his team could play defense and win away from home.

title: OWNERS TO BE BILLED IN MEADOWLAND FIRES
description: LYNDHURST, Aug. 21Municipal lead. ers here are pianning to bill the owners of property in the Hackensack Meadowlands for firefighting protection in the last two months.

title: U.S. Fails in World Rowing
description: AMSTERDAM, Aug. 21The United States made a poor showing in the opening heats of the men's heavyweight category in the 1977 world rowing championships. Boasting the largest squad of any nation represented here, the United States advanced its entries in only two of the eight events that comprise the elite level of competition. The six boats which failed to qualify today will participate in a secondchance, or repechage, heat on Tuesday. The United States eight and pair without coxswain finished second and third in their respective heats, and qualified for Friday's semifinals.

title: Deborah Prinz Wed To Lawrence Neher
description: Deborah M. Prinz, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Joachim Prinz of Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to awrence T. Neher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Neher of Franklin Sauare L I.

title: Miss Goolagong to Skip U.S. Open in Comeback
description: TORONTO, Aug. 21 (UPI)Evonne Goolagong has decided to skip the United States Open at Forest Hills, her husband, Roger Cawley, said today.

title: The Jewelry Is Disparate, But the Artists Share a Bond
description: Torn and Angela Ambrosina are known for romantic jewelry based on floral designs and organic shapes. Karen ScottTopol indulges in ornate fantasy pieces. Robin Garin ghost designs fine jewelry to be sold under such names as Anne Klein and Pierre Belmain. Claudia Kuehnl's work is influenced by architectural forms. Drewery Hanes makes gold and enamel beads to be strung into elegant necklaces.

title: Mexican Judge Rules 2 Officers Are Guilty in American's Death
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP)A Mexican judge has returned preliminary findings of guilt against two policemen in the killing of a St. Louis travel agent, according to a United States Embassy document.

title: 2 Cubans Set Records
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 21 (AP)Alejandro Casanas and Alberto Juantorena set world records in track and field tonight, a wild night of glory for Cuba at the World University Games.

title: Races With Few Rooters
description: A clear signal of the decline of the Democratic organization in New York City is that district leaders will be elected in next month's primary in Manhattan but that very few voters and even politicians say they care. The collective yawn over the district leaderships markedly contrasts with the politics of 10 and 20 years ago, when the unpaid district leaderships were fought for as if they were major public offices. Then, reformers squared off against regulars and doves against hawks in emotional and hardfought contests up and down the West Side, in Greenwich Village and in the middle and Upper East Sidewherever the middle class concentrated in Manhattan. Almost every district had contests then. This year there are about half a dozen contests for district leadershipsabout a fifth of the leaderships in Manhattanand it is difficult to find any great ideological or political stakes in any of them,, other than outs wanting to become ins.

title: Wilderness Plan Disputed in Alaska City
description: SITKA, Alaska, Aug. 21Few people in this former capital of Russian Alaska would want to join the Soviet Union, but there are many here who want the 49th state to secede from the United States. They think the Federal

title: Market Place
description: There is more than one way of looking at it. Either stocks are the only bargain left at current pricesthat's bow Salomon Brothers sees itor stocks have offered the poorest results relative to alternative investments over the last 10 years.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Jail for Mentally Ill

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the number of crime complaints to New York City's Police Department was incorrectly stated in yesterday's Times. Thue were 1,183,000 complaints in the year ended June 30, down from 1,260,000 in 197576.

title: Miss Austin Wins Wheeling Golf Event
description: WHEELING, W. Va.. Aug. 21 (AP)Debbie Austin sank a threefoot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to turn back a challenge by Hollis Stacy and win the $50,000 Wheeling Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: New Lineup Is a Shift From Mao
description: PEKING. Aug. 21The new Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party, dominated by senior military officers rehabilitated party veterans and technocrats, marks a clear shift from the era of the late Mao Tsetuns.

title: Printers
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (AP)The president of the International Typographical Union called yesterday for the creation of a single union to cover all employees in the news industry.

title: Major Reductions in Death Rates Reported by Newark Health Aides
description: NEWARK, Aug. 21City health officials reported here today that, after more than a decade of receiving Federal healthcare funds and after intensive local efforts, death rates for several major illnesses had been dramatically reduced.

title: Apples Seeking to Clinch Playoff Series Tonight
description: The New York Apples, defending World Team Tennis champions, could clinch the Eastern Division title tonight with a victory over the Boston Lobsters at the Felt Forum. The Apples lead the twoofthreematch series. 10. after defeating their opponents, 2921. Saturday night in Boston. Tonight's match begins at 7:30 o'clock.

title: Senate Banking Unit to Investigate Practices Noted in Lance Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Senator William Proxmire, citing some of the activities of Budget Director Bert Lance before he joined the Government, announced today that the Senate Banking Committee would conduct a broad investigation of the ethics and soundness of American banking.

title: Israel Defends Policy Over New Settlements
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 21The Government tonight defended Israel's right to establish Jewish settlements anywhere in the ancestral homeland while at the same time pursuing peace talks with the Arabs.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: URBAN LEAGUE CHIEF HAILS TWO SIGNALS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)Vernon Jordan Jr., director of the National Urban League, said today that there had been two encouraging signals from the Administration since he asserted last month that President Carter was not keeping his promises to blacks.

title: Yonkers
description: ENTRIES

title: Catherine M. Mitiguy Bride of John Solow
description: Catherine M. Mitiguy, a graduate of Albertus Magnus College in New Haven, was married yesterday to John L. Solow, a Yale graduate and a doctoral candidate in economics at Stanford University. The Rev. Frank Flaherty performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Burlington, Vt.

title: Top Retail Executives Playing Musical Stores
description: Ten, fifteen years ago, things were so good, you could open a new store, put a gorilla in charge and be successful. Nowadays, the gorilla wouldn't have a chance.

title: Saudis Join Connally to Buy Bank
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 21Two Saudi Arabian businessmen have joined with John B. Connally, former Texas Governor, to purchase the controlling interest in the Main Bank of Houston, reportedly the first such investment by Arabs in Texas, according to a Texas banker involved in the deal.

title: WILTWYCK CLOSING CAUSES UNCERTAINTY
description: YORKTOWN, N.Y.They are sometimes called the kids nobody else wants and now that a decision has been made to close a place that took them in and tried to help them repair their lives, there is a deep uneasiness among their mentors as to where they will be sent next and how they will fare.

title: Edward A. Hill, Former Macy's Aide And Skating Champion of 20's, at 78
description: Edward Armitage Hill, a former assistant to the president of R. H. Macy & Company, died Friday at the Geer Memorial Nursing Home in Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in New York City and in Norfolk. Conn.

title: Doubt Cast on 2 Republicans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21One of the most active Senate opponents of two new Panama Canal treaties expressed doubt today that Senators Barry Goldwater of Arizona and S. I. Hayakawa of California, both Republicans, would support the pacts, as Carter Administration officials have assumed they would do.

title: Beame Links Lawyer Who Wrote S.E.C. Report to Cuomo Campaign
description: Pressing his preemptive campaign against the forthcoming Securities and Exchange Commission report on New York City's fiscal troubles, Mayor Beame linked its main author yesterday with a law firm involved in the campaign of one of his opponents.

title: Princeton Radio Interviewers Put Powerful on the Spot
description: PRINCETON, N.J.The country's secondmost popular publicaffairs radio program is prepared and produced here each week by a bunch of college kids who think nothing of putting famous people on the spot.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 22, 1977

title: The Soviet Bear
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is bearish on the Soviet economy. Moscow, says the C.I.A., will feel increasing strain in the years ahead; sharply reduced rates of economic growth will pose excruciating choices for the Kremlin leaders. Gone are the C.I.A.'s cries of alarm of twenty years ago that the Soviet Union might soon surpass the United States economically.

title: Books of The Times
description: Shortly after midnight tonightat 12:19:02 and at 12:26:55, respectivelyNicola Sacco, shoemaker, and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, fishmonger, will have been dead exactly 50 years because they were anarchists at the wrong time an the wrong place. That grim anniversary inspires these two peculiar books. Although both books agree that Sacco and Vanzetti should not have been electrocuted, the two authors would be uncomfortable in the same room together, because Katherine Anne Porter is precisely the sort of person Roberta Strauss Feuerlicht seems to hate: the quintessential WASP.

title: Mona J. Deutsch Married To Steven Jeffrey Miller
description: Mona Joy Deutsch and Steven Jeffrey Miller, graduates of the Stanford University Law School, were married yesterday at Temple Rodeph Sholom. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg, assisted by Cantor Ephraim Biran, performed the ceremony.

title: Deputy Attorney General Bids U.S. Look to Rights in Its Own Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)The Carter Administration must protect the basic human rights of inmates in American prisons and jails, Deputy Attorney General Peter F. Flaherty said today.

title: Prestige Space For Corporations Is Expanding Past Park Avenue
description: Park Avenue is brimming with status, but running out of space, and New York City's corporate residents are moving into new fashionable addresses.

title: Jailed Puerto Rican Nationalist Flown Home for Father's Funeral
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 21One of the four Puerto Rican nationalists who shot up Congress in 1954 was whisked here from prison for seven hours yesterday to attend the funeral of his father.

title: Prestige Space For Corporations Is Expanding Past Park Avenue
description: Park Avenue is brimming with status, but running out of space, and New York City's corporate residents are moving into new fashionable addresses.

title: Princeton Hires Samara As Assistant in Track
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug_ 21 (AP)Fred Samara, an Olympian in the decathlon, was named assistant track and field coach at Princeton, the university announced today.

title: German Anarchists
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug. 21A hunger strike by anarchists iri a maximumsecurity prison here and in other penitentiaries is focusing attention on the imprisoned members of West Germany's radical movement and causing disputes over the conditions in which they are being held.

title: CHINESE LEADERSHIP APPEARS CONFIDENT ON EVE OF U.S TALKS
description: PEKING, Monday, Aug. 22The Chinese leaders that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will talk with when he arrives in Peking today appear to be in a far more confident and stable position than at any time since at least former President Nixon's visit here over five years ago.

title: Monmouth
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Synagogue Desecrated in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Aug. 21 (AP)Nazi slogans were found painted on the entrance gate, the ceremonial hall and about 40 gravestones of a synagogue in downtown Vienna, the police reported today. Some of the slogans said, Out with the Jews.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Brooks Robinson Retires As Oriole Player at 40
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 21 (AP)Brooks Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles, regarded as one of the best third basemen in baseball history, retired as an active player before his team's game here today.

title: Events/Sports
description: 7:30 P.M., WVNJ: Tennis. Playoffs. (If necessary).

title: S.E.C. SURVEY SHOWS INVESTOR RELIANCE ON ANNUAL REPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, August 21Results of a recent Securities and Exchange Commission survey of small investors appear to lend support to the agency's campaign to require companies to make simpler, more extensive disclosures about their business activities in company annual reports according to a spokesman for the commission.

title: Center Settles Disputes Amicably
description: CORAM, L.I.He was already fed up with the noise from a neighboring youngster's minibike as be drove home from work that day not long ago.

title: Making a Good Energy Bill Better
description: The House has approved a comprehensive energy plan that gives President Carter most of what he wanted. To encourage conservation, the bill provides powerful incentives for industrial conversion to coal and raises oil prices to consumers through a wellhead tax on domestic crude oil. Gasguzzling autos would be taxed and homeowners who buy insulation or energysaving devices would get a 20 percent credit against their income taxes.

title: Family Honors Groucho Marx at Private Gathering
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21Relatives of Groucho Marx avoided the the pomp of a Hollywood funeral and instead held small family gathering today in memory of the 86yearold comedian, who died Friday night.

title: Overtounter Supplementary Listings
description: Week ended Aug. 19, 1977

title: CALIFORNIANS BRACE FOR NEW DISASTERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21Drought, fires, floods and infestations are only some of the natural afflictions in California this summer.

title: British Steens Struggling to Compete
description: LLANWERN, Wales, Aug. 18An enterprising automobile dealer has set up shop here just outside the main gate of the British Steel Corporation's complex where 9,000 workers help produce steel fnr cars.

title: FELIX T. HUGHES
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21  Felix T. Hughes, a retired vice president of P.P.G. Industries and a second cousin of the late Howard R. Hughes, died today in Presbyterian  University Hospital. Mr. Hughes, who had been ill for five months, was 65 years old.

title: Voyager Steadies on Its Course; Launch of Twin Craft Is Delayed
description: CAPE CANAVERAL. Fla., Aug. 21After a fitful start on an interplanetary journey, the Voyager 2 spacecraft sped quietly and steadily on its course for Jupiter today as flight controllers grew more confident that they had a healthy vehicle of exploration.

title: Miss Browne, 15, Shatters Mark In 1,500 Swim
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 21Alice Browne turned 15 years old a week ago.

title: Student Sets Record In RollerCoaster Rides
description: A 19yearold student shattered the world record for consecutive roller coaster rides yesterday on the cyclone roller coaster at Astroland Park in Coney Island.

title: Mrs. Heiskell and Samuel Lefrak Appointed to Park Commissions
description: Marian Sulzberger Heiskell and Samuel J. Lefrak, both of New York City, were among four members of regional state park and recreation commissions named yesterday by Governor Carey. The nomiL nations are subject to confirmation by the State Senate.

title: LEON SAKS
description: EPIDAURUS, Greece, Aug. 22 (AP)Leon Saks, 56 years old, the leading violinist of the Soviet Bolshoi Ballet Orchestra, died yesterday of injuries suffered when he fell from a cliff while sightseeing with the orchestra near here.

title: Breaking the Ice
description: The Soviet announcement the other day that its nuclear icebreaker Arktika had become the first surface ship to reach the North Pole, confirms, yet again, how rapidly man is conquering the inaccessible places on the planet. The question, yet again, is whether man's capacities in the political, legal and economic arenas can keep race.

title: OneV an Commuter Line Ends Run After 2 Weeks
description: A private van that began regular commuter runs along the East Side was abruptly taken out of service by its owners yesterday after New York City threatened to serve them with a summons for operating without a license.

title: U.S. and Chicago Officials Near Accord in Jobs Program Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The Labor Department and Chicago officials reached a tentative agreement here today that could head off a Federal takeover of the citt's public service jobs program, Labor Department sources said.

title: 40 Routed by FoulSmelling Gas Near Cuomo Brooklyn Headquarters
description: Campaign workers for Mario M. Cuomo were routed from a Brooklyn office yesterday by a foulsmelling gas that someone sprayed in an adjacent hallway, the police reported.

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, August 23, 1977

title: Bomb Blast at West German Plant
description: NUREMBERG, West Germany, Aug. 22 (AP)A bomb exploded at an industrial complex here early today, ripping doors and windows from walls and causing heavy damage to the administration building. No injuries were reported. The M.A.N. complexthe initials stand for Maschinenfabriken Augsburg Nuremberg makes trucks, buses, tanks, lokomotives and steel.

title: Space Agency to End Its Moon Monitoring
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 22 (AP)Scientific instruments left on the moon by astro nauts of the Apollo mission are stir sending information to earth, but the data will not be monitored after thi: month because the national space agem cy cannot afford it, the Johnson Space Center announced today.

title: The Case of the German Colonel
description: After all the complex circumstances are sifted surrounding the bizzare escape from a Rome prison hospital of a convicted Nazi war criminal, the fact remains that Col. Herbert Kapplersentenced to life imprisonment for the 1944 murder of 335 Italian civiliansis now free, and the West German Government has taken a handsoff attitude that cannot but dismay its friends abroad.

title: Advertising
description: Promoting Sales of Quebec's Products

title: Business Records
AMERICAN FREEDOM TRAIN TO START LAST JOURNEY
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 22 (AP)After traveling 25,833 miles throughout the continental United States, the American Freedom Train is to begin its last journey tomorrow under that name. The 15 red, white and blue cars are to be hauled northward from here to Buffalo, and then to Canada. The train is to become Discovery Train, part of the National Museums of Canada.

title: BOND CREDIT RATING FOR ISSUE BY MAC. RAISED BY AGENCIES
description: INVESTMENT GRADE IS AWARDED

title: Somalia Calls for Revolution
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 22 (AP)Somalia urged workers in neighboring Ethiopia today to overthrow their country's 11arxist regime. It vowed to take steps to counter a general mobilization ordered by Ethiopian leaders to press their war against two secessionist armies.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY. AUGUST 23, 1977

title: Us. Officials Express Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Officials of the Carter Administration privately expressed concern today at French charges that South Africa was preparing to exDiode a nuclear device.

title: Apples Defeat Lobsters, Reach Final in W.T.T.
description: A pair of dramatic tiebreaker victories both involving Sandy Mayer, the consummate World Team Tennis player, pushed the New York Apples into the finals of the league championship last night as they beat the Boston Lobsters, 2926. With his Apples teammates screaming on the sidelines Mayer defeated Tony Roche, 76, and then teamed with Ray Ruffels to defeat Roche and Mike Estep by the same score.

title: Encyclopedia, After 10 Years, Is Due Sept. 30
description: The publication of the Random House Encyclopedia on Sept. 30 is the culmination of a major international publishing venture that began almost 10 years ago. For the first time, 14 publishing houses in Europe, Africa, Asia and the Middle East will be using the basic information to produce their own editions between now and 1980.

title: 11% RISE IN AUTO OUTPUT PLANNED IN LAST QUARTER
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22 (UPI)United States auto makers are planning an 11 percent increase in auto production. in the final three months of the year that could put 1977 on record as the second best ever, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: Events Today
South Africa Parley On Apartheid Issue Urged by Waldheim
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 22 (Reuters)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that the best way to solve South Africa's apartheid problem would be to hold a national convention composed of genuine representatives of all the people of the country.

title: G.M. Starts Output Of Its 1978 Models
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP)The sprawling General Motors Corporation passenger car assembly line moved sluggishly into life today as the retooled operation began production of 1978 models based on the Vega style.

title: Employee PensionFund Interest Is Ruled a Security by U.S. Court
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22A Federal Appellate Court has ruled that an employee's interest in a pension fund is a security, subject to the antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: Yanks Lose, 53, but Stay HalfGame Back
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22On the verge of taking over first place in the American League East, the New York Yankees lost a 30 lead in the seventh inning and then experienced a defensive collapse in the eighth, which let the Chicago White Sox win tonight's game, 53.

title: 2 LAW GROUPS SCORE BEAME ON JUDGESHIPS
description: Bar Association and Legal Aid Unit Cite Quality of Appointments by Mayor and Vacancies

title: Belgium's Premier to Meet Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (Reuters)The White House announced today that President Carter had invited Prime Minister Leo Tindemans of Belgium to meet him in Washington Sept. 8. The Prime Minister will be accompanied by Belgium's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Henri Simonet.

title: LauraDean's Spiral
description: Laura Dean, a dancer and choreographer who also composes her own music and directs an ensemble of musicians, gave a strictly musical performance at the old United States Customs House near Battery Park on Sunday. The Custorn and Culture series being held there is turning out to be one of the best showcases for new music this summer; the events are free, and the crowds are large, even when the performer is hot as well known as Philip Glass or Steve Reich, who are also in the series.

title: Taxes &
description: If you buy a $200 lawnmower in order to get your teenager to mow the lawn, does that outlay qualify as a support payment for tax purposes?

title: U.S. Acts to Protect Captive Sea Mammals
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 22 (AP)The Agriculture Department is proposing new standards for the care and feeding of sea mammals in captivity. The category includes polar bears, sea otters. whales, porpoises, dolphins, seals, sea lions and walruses.

title: SOCIAL GROUP UPHELD ON CONFIDENTIALITY
description: New York State Supreme Court Says Community Service Society Need Not Comment on Client

title: Shop Offers Bargains to Migrant Workers
description: CRANBURY, Aug. 22Years ago, Mall. bubeh Stave recalls driving past farm( on the outskirts of this picturesque vii lage of tall arching trees and pristin( white houses and seeing black migrant workers in the fields.

title: ParkerHannifin Net Up 25% in Quarter, 42% for Year
description: The ParkerHannifin Corporation, a supplier of fluid power components and automotive parts, had a 25 percent earnings jump in the quarter ended June 30 and a 42.3 percent increase for the full fiscal year, the company reported yesterday.

title: U.S.Asia Fares Would Be Pared By Airline
description: Trans International Airlines, the nation's largest charter carrier, escalated the war over intercontinental air fares yesterday, this time making incursions into Asia.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Javamine, $7.60, Wins With Ease at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP)Cragwood Stables Javamine won the $54,400 Diana Handicap for fillies and mares today at the Saratoga track, covering the mileandaneighth grass course in 1:48 2/5.

title: CHESTER J. LA ROCHE, ADVERTISING LEADER
description: Chester J. LaRoche, a leader in adverlising who for 20 years headed the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame, died Sunday night, three days before his 85th birthday, at the Meadow Club in Southampton, L.I. He had been living in Palm Beach since 1972.

title: Army Chief Urges Preparedness, With Vow to Use Force if Needed
description: MINNEAPOLIS. Aug.22 (UPI)  The United States Army Chief of Staff told the Veteran:. of Foreign Wars conventio today that the overriding goal of the armed services was. to avoid war because no one. would win a nuclear exchange.

title: Records of Missouri County Jail Saved From Fire by 12 Inmates
description: NEW MADRID, Mo.. Aug. 22 (AP)Inmates of the New Madrid county jail pitched in to help save case records and evidence today as the jail burned, the authorities said.

title: Crimes by Government, Continued
description: Last spring, Attorney General Griffin Bell made painful, historic and correct decision: to authorize the first Federal indictment ever of an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The defendant was John Kearney, a squad supervisor, and the charges involved illegal wiretapping and mailopening by the F.B.I. connection with the Weather Underground. We welcorned the indictment, not out of any special feeling against Mr. Kearney or .a belief that he was singularly responsible. On the contrary, it is hard to believe that he acted without clear authority from his superiors. The indictment seemed important to us as a demonstration that the United States Government was willing, at last, to proclaim that the law applies to all, evenindeed especiallyto its own employees. Now, however, that commitment is again in question.

title: New Yonkers Store Added by Alexander's
description: YONKERS, Aug. 22Alexander's, which already has department stores in White Plains and central Westchester County and in Cortlandt in the northern part of the county, broadened its efforts today by opening another store in this city on the county's southern border.

title: SaccoVanzetti Case Is Evoking Passions 50 Years After Deaths
description: Today is the 50th anniversary of the execution in Boston of Sacco and Vanzetti, but passions endure and doubts persist. Was their murder conviction, which stirred demonstrations, strikes, riots and even bombings in many countries, justice or injustice? Were they criminals or martyrs?

title: West Said to Err on Soviet Navy
description: LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP)United States Naval Intelligence says that for 10 years Western assessments of the armament and purpose of the latest Soviet missile cruisers and destroyers have been totally wrong, according to a report by Britain's Foreign Affairs Research Institute.

title: Edwards Defeats Leonard In Dash
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 22 (AP) Clancy Edwards ofthe United States edged Silvio Leonard of Cuba by 1Shundredths of a second tonight and won the 200meter dash at the World University Games.

Cup Course Will Remind British Golfers of Home
description: George H. Walker, who served as president of the United States Golf Association in 1920, had an idea for an annual series of matches between the best United States amateur golfers and the best amateurs from Britain and Ireland. His idea became a reality in 1922 when the United States wcn the first such meeting for the U.S.G.A. International Challenge Trophy.

title: Bus Crash in Mexico Kills 20
description: HERMOSILLO, Mexico, Aug. 22 (UPI) Twenty persons died and 27 were injured when a bus toppled into a waterfilled ditch last night after rain had washed out the highway. The accident occurred on the HermosilloNogales Highway.

title: More Banks Lift Prime Rates to 7%; 71/2% Level Foreseen by YearEnd
description: Major banks across the nation raised their basic, or prime, lending rates yesterday to 7 percent from 6% percent following the increase set in motion Friday by New York's Citibank.

title: Notes on People
description: Msgr. Thomas Fee, a Gaelic scholar and authority on early Irish Christianity, was named yesterday by Pope Paul VI to be Roman Catholic Primate of all of Ireland. Monsignor Fee, who was born in Northern Ireland, is 53 years old and since 1974 has been president of St. Patrick's College, an major center for training priests in the Irish Republic. title: FRANCE SAYS DATA SHOW SOUTH AFRICA PLANS ATOMIC TEST
description: PARIS, Aug. 22The French Government said today it had received new information that South Africa was getting ready to set off an atomic test explosion.

title: DesignerWho LeftHis Mark On Millions of Cars Leaves
description: DETROITAs auto dealers clear their showrooms for this year's offering of smaller, more efficient models, William L. Mitchell has reason to reflect with pride. The majority are his designs.

title: Magazine Labels Must Give Date Subscription Expires, New Law Says
description: Magazine mailing labels will have to bear subscription expiration dates starting next year, under a New York State law enacted on the recommendation of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: West's Leaders Sweep East's in American League
description: For a change, their were no adjustments in the sfandings in the American League's two torrid divisional races last night The three top teams in each division stayed in exactly the same relationship to each other. The reason? Because the three Western Division leaders beat the three top teams in the East.

title: The City Hall Race
U.S. Narrows Inquiry on Imports Of Stainless Pipe From Japan
description: The United States International Trade Commission has narrowed its inquiry into stainless steel pipe and tube imports from Japan. Last October, a group of United States specialty steel producers accused a number of Japanese companies of engaging in predatory export pricing practices.

description: Libby Howard was a construction worker, one of thousands who worked on the new Labor Department headquarters in Washington. Now she was back in that building, attesting to the ordeals of women hard hats.

Egypt Is Uneasy as Sadat juggles Promises of Peace and Prosperity
description: CAIRO, Aug. 22On these warm nights of Ramadan, the month of daytime fasting, Egyptians crowd the cafes and complain bitterly over rising prices and the failure of peace.

title: Aide Cites an Oversight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The White House said today that the Georgia bank formerly headed by Budget Director Bert Lance had not been paid for five flignts that President Carter took on an airplane owned by the bank in 1975 and 1976, even though some of the flights were political campaign trips. The White House press secretary, Jody Powell, said that arrangements were being made to pay now.

title: Musicians and Met to Resume LaborPact Talks Tomorrow
description: Negotiators for the Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra musicians scheduled a meeting for tomorrow in hopes of breaking a deadlock in their attempt to reach a labor agreement before Sept. 9. If there is no agreement by that date, the Metropolitan has warned, the opera season will be canceled.

title: Syrian Troops Sent to Scene of Lebanese Clashes As Christian Leaders W arn of Renewed Civil War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 22  Syrian troops of the Arab League's peacekeeping force moved today into the mountain area near here where ChristianMoslem fighting yesterday left 17 persons dead, and Christian leaders warned that a new civil war could erupt if such clashes could not be prevented.

title: World News Briefs
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 22 (UPI)More than 150 person were reported dead or missing today because of a powerful earthquake and waves that struck Indonesia's eastern islands Friday. A Government official said more people might have died than in the 1976 tremor that left 500 dead on the island of Bali.

title: Second Tropical Wave Forming
description: MIAMI, Aug. 22 (UPI)A tropical wave in the central Caribbean that had threatened to become the first tropical storm of the season weakened today. But another wave formed in the central Atlantic Ocean, the National Hurricane Center said.

title: Charge Is Called Incomprehensible
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 22 (AP) Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha refused today to comment on the French charge that South Africa was preparing for a nuclear explosion, but Brand Fourie, the Foreign Under Secretary, called it incomprehensible.

title: Study Urges Onshore Oil Bases Be Limited to Atlantic City Area
description: PRINCETON, Aug. 22Princeton University's Center for Environmental Studies recommended today that New Jersey minimize the adverse effects of offshore drilling by limiting to the Atlantic City area any onshore bases built to support and supply oil rigs in the ocean.

title: Council to Ponder 2 Bills on Elderly
description: Two bills that would guarantee rentincrease exemptions for qualified elderly people who move and that would prevent discrifnination in housing and mortgages because of age were voted out yesterday by the New York City Councils General Welfare Committee.. Previously, the City Council had passed a bill to allow qualified elderly people to maintain exemptions from rent increases when they moved between regulated units.

title: Sri Lanka Lifts Weekend Curfew But Then Reimposes It at Night
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 22 (AP)A nighttime curfew was imposed on this island nation today in an attempt to quell a wave of violence between rival ethnic groups that has taken 25 lives, driven plantation workers from their jobs and produced hundreds of refugees.

title: Ailing Mathematician Said to Get Permission to Leave Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW, Aug..22 (AP)An ill Jewish mathematician, his parents and his brother received permission today to leave the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and prominent dissident, said. Moscow dissidents had carried on a publicity campaign in their behalf.

title: Dayan Denies He Will Meet Hussein
description: LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters)The sudden visit to Britain today of the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, brought denials that he would meet King Hussein of Jordan, who is also on a visit here.

description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 22Princeton Univeisity's Center for Environmental Studies recommended today that New Jersey minimize adverse impacts of offshore drilling by limiting to the Atlantic City area any onshore bases built to support and supply oil rigs in the ocean.

title: Shipment of Crude From North Slope Resumes at Valdez
description: VALDEZ. Alaska .Aug. 22 (AP)A tanker of the British Petroleum Company departed from the transAlaska pipeline terminal here today with the first load of North Slope crude to go south since a pump station oil leak forced the line , to close down a week ago.

title: Presley Will Names rather as Executor; Assets Go to Family
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 22  Elvis Presley named his father, Vernon, executor of his fortune in a will probated this afternoon in Memphis. But the singer did not include his fiance, Ginger Alben, one of three witnesses who signed the will March 3, or his wife, Priscilla, in the dbcument.

title: REGINALD F. X. CONNOR
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 22 (AP)Reginald F. X. Connor, who was a Labor Party Member of Parliament for 14 years and the Minister for Minerals and Energy from 1973 to 1975, died today in a Canberra hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: School Integration In Rockville Centre Is Put Off for Year
description: MINEOLA, LI., Aug. 22The state's new Commissioner of Education today extended by one year the time that the Rockville Centre school district has to begin integrating its six elementary schools. The order, which affects 4,000 students, overruled one issued by former Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist as he left office last June.

title: Malaria Spreading in Central America as Resistance to Sprays Grows]
description: GUATEMALA  Two decades after campaigns were launched to eradicate malaria from Central America, the disease is once again spreading through the region because of the resistance of mosquitoes to traditional insecticides.

title: LOUIS ZAHN OF CHICAGO, STARTED DRUG COMPANY
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP)Louis Zahn, who built a multimilliondollar pharmaceutical business out of a $225 investment, died of cancer yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: 3 Brothers Jailed for Contempt In Inquiry Into Terrorist Bombings

title: Ethiopia Said to Have Repelled Fierce Somali Attack
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 22Ethiopian forces relying heavily on air power repelled a fullscale Somali attack last week on the important Ethiopian city of Diredawa, according to official and diplomatic sources here.

title: Books of The Times
description: I find it reassuring to see a good writer occasionally at a loss for something to say. Literature should be difficult, like loving. All unbroken round of successes might take some of the romance, the mystery, out of writing. Good art tends to conceal or sublimate the author's personality: when he is at his weakest we see him more clearly. As a reader, I identify not only with the authors characters, but with him. And so it is comforting now and again to see him human and imperfect. No man, someone said, is a hero to his valetand what is the critic but a writer's valet?

title: Gilbert C. Tompkins, a Historian Of Golf and Art Representative, 94
description: Gilbert C. Tompkins, an artists representative and a golf historian, died Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 94 years old and lived in Matamoras. Pa.

title: Alice Crimmins Wed To Man Who Gave Testimony at Trial
description: Alice Crimmins, the onetime Queens cocktail waitress who was convicted of manslaughter in the 1965 strangulation of her 4yearold daughter, was married July 15 to Anthony Grace, the contractor who had testified that he had been having an affair with her at the time her two young children were kidnapped and murdered.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON. Aug. 22  The State Assembly majority leader, Christopher J. Jacman, Democrat of West New York, pledged an allout fight today against establishment of any kind of theme park or commercial amusement center on the site of Liberty State Park in Jersey City.

description: The last Of the oldcrop soybean futures contracts, the spot August, expired at noon yesteday, but not before traders witnessed a nervefraying display of roller coaster price moves.

title: People in Sports
description: Howard Baldwin, who spearheaded the unsuccessful drive for a merger of the World Hockey Association and the National Hockey League, was named president of the W.H.A. yesterday. The 35 yearold Baldwin succeeded Bill McFarland, who resigned for personal reasons. Baldwin will remain as managing partner of the New England Whalers, the franchise he has been affiliated with since the inception of the W.H.A. in 1972. Before that he was business manager of the N.H.L. Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Town in Oklahoma Still Tense and Angry 2 Months After Slaying of 3 Girl Scouts
description: LOCUST GROVE, Okla., Aug. 22People in this small northeastern Oklahoma town normally spend free August afternoons taking a dip in Spring Creek or fishing for bass with crawdads, but for the last two months the swimming holes have been deserted and the fishing poles have been tucked into closets.

title: Judge May Investigate Alleged Berkowitz Tapes Reported by Agent
description: The administrative judge of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday directed his legal staff to determine wheth er he had the power to conduct a hearing on the reported attempt to sell 10 hones of conversations with David R. Berkowitz. the man accused of being the .44caliber killer. to a literary agent.

title: Bateman Joined By Kean in Try To Oust Byrne
description: NEWARK. Aug. 22State Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville and the man he beat by more than 64,000 votes in tr,e Republican gubernatorial primary, Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston, joined forces today in an atttmpt to unseat Governor Bryne in the November elections.

title: F.D.I.C. HAS 368 BANKS ON ITS PROBLEM LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22(AP)  The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today there were 368 banks on its problem list as of June 30, one more than a year earlier, but 18 less than they oeak reached in November 1976.

description: SOUTHAMPTON, LI., Aug. 22  The Southampton cat burglar struck again last weekend, making off with at least $1,500 in jewels and cash, and a prescription for sleeping pills from two lavish summer homes here.

title: Formula One Car Unveiled
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 22 (UPI)A new Formula One racing car, the MartiniBrabhamAlfa Romeo BT46, including spacecraft and Concorde supersonic airliner features, was presnted today. The racer, weighing only 1,265 pounds, was designed by tv 33yearold South African, Gordon Murray. The 12cylinder Alfa Romeo engine is cooled by a system, used in space capsules, that passes through two oil and water heat exchangers in aluminum bonded to the car's sides. The brakes have many features in common with the Concorde system.

title: 3 Cabinet Meetings Canceled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)President Carter canceled three of his weekly meetings with his Cabinet this month to give its executives time to be with your families and do some reflection, Jack Watson, the Cabinet Secretary, said today. The Cabinet meetings will resume next Monday, Mr. Watson said. He said that Mr. Carter said at the last meeting, on Aug. 1, that with Congress in recess, it's a good chance to take some time off, to be with your families and do some reflection.

title: Nurses in Brooklyn Vote to Strike
description: Nurses at Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn rejected a proposed contract settlement yesterday and voted for strike of begin today at S A.M. The 635 registered nurses, members of District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employeer, turned down a hosiptal proposal that was offered after talks that lastes from Sunday morning to yesterday morning. A strike deadline that had been set for Monday morning was postponed to today. Both sides continued negotiations, however, with the assistance of a Federal mediator.

description: MONTAUK, L. 1., Aug. 22 (AP)The heaviest tuna caught in United states waters, 1,017 pounds,  was reeled in 15 miles off Block Island yesterday.

description: PUERTO LA CRUZ, Venezuela, Aug. 22 (UPI)  Luis Estaba of Venezuela scored an 11thround technical knockout over Juan Alvarez yesterday and retained his World Boxing Council junior flyweight title. Estaba dropped Alvarez for an 8count in the seventh round. The referee stopped the fight in the 11th because of a deep cut over Alvarez's left eyebrow. Estaba weighed 1071% pounds and Alvarez, 1071/2.

description: Steel production remained steady during the week ended Aug. 20, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesetrday. Production totaled 2,331,000 tons, up onetenth of 1 percent from the 2,329,000 tons produced during the previous week.

description: Heir apparent to John Ferguson since being named assistant coach a year ago, JeanGuy Talbot became head coach yesterday of the New York Rangers. The fiery Ferguson will devote full time to his work as general manager.

title: Bomb Scare Halts Paris Trading
description: PARIS, Aug. 22 (AP)All trading at the Paris stock exchange was halted today by a bomb scare, police said. The building was evacuated and a thorough search was made, but no explosives were found. The stock market had about 45 minutes remaining in the scheduled session when trading was stopped. Officials decided not to resume quotations and the foreignexchange market was closed. The threat was made in an anonymous letter.

title: Death
3 SouthWest African Guerrillas Reported Killed by South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 22 (AP)Sout:i African security forces have killed three black nationalist guerrillas near the Angolan border in SouthWest Africa, the South African radio reported today.

title: There Will Re an Equality Day After All, Says a Carter Aide
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 22 (AP)President Carter will designate Friday Women's Equality D4y, the White House said today. Earlier a Carter aide had mistakenly announced that the President had decided against such a move.

title: Where to Learn a Trade
description: Do women really want to break into the skilled construction trades? The Labor Department contends that they do and cites as proof the growing numbers of grassroots organizations set up to recruit and place women in these goodpaying jobs.
