description: Tale of Two Silvers

title: Anker Meets School Group's Head In a Dispute Over Opening Date
description: With the official opening of the city's public schools only weeks away, Chancellor Irving Anker met yesterday with the president of the Community School Board Association to try to resolve a dispute over the date of the first day of classes.

title: SENATE PANEL STUDYING ACTIVITIES OF U.S. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)The staff of the Senate Rules Committee has been ordered to gather information about the outside business activities of Robert O. Tiernan, a member of the Federal Elections Commission.

title: An Italian Court Releases. Woman Terrorist Suspect Long Held Without Trial
description: ROME, Aug. 24Twentynine months of imprisonment without trial in Switzerland and Italy ended today for a woman terrorist suspect who was ordered released by a court in Naples after campaign on her behalf in which the Italian Government nlaved a Dart.

title: Behind the Aluminum Curtain: A Kitchen
description: While most people these days are looking for ways to enlarge their kitchen, Michael Christiano, an interior designer, shrank his walkin kitchen to a pullman kitchenette.

title: InnerCity Equestrians Show Their Skills
description: Looking a bit starryeyed, 13yearold Francina Wallace of East Harlem smiled as she recalled her recent introduction to horseback riding through 4H program on Staten Island.

title: INDIA CHOOSES 77
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 (AP)The Government, in the process of running CocaCola out of India, said it had chosen the name 77 for its stateproduced substitute cola drink.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Bridge:
description: Many experts are convinced that the ideal system of bidding is one based on the relay principle: One player takes charge and makes a series of minimum bids, or relays, requiring partner to describe his hand. At the end of the proceedings, which are usually lengthy, one player knows virtually everything, and makes the final decision, while his partner knows virtually nothing.

title: Williams, Griffith Help U.S. Quintet Crush Brazil
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 24 (AP)The United States men's basketball team defeated Brazil, 10381, today and scored its sixth straight victory in the World University Games.

title: Panamanians Say Carter's Idea for SeaLevel Canal Imperiled Talks
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 24Panamanian officials say that an 11thhour espousal by President Carter of a sealevel AtlantictoPacific canal project severely jeopardized the negotiations over two Panama Canal treaties as they were about to be concluded earlier this month.

title: Organizing Agreement Could Bring First Union of Religious Employees
description: Officials of the National Council of Churches yesterday reached an agreement with representatives of the council's clerical staff that could result in the first successful unionizing effort within a national church body.

title: Personal Beauty
description: IF BY FALL you're still looking natural in light lipstick and a discreet touch of rouge you may be dating yourself. Although fashions in facet painting are slower to change than those in clothes, change they dc: Cupid!c ?? mouths and hairline eyebrrws ?? the 20 and 40's. Pale lipstick and false lashes were the rage with miniskirts in the 60's. Streaks of brcwn blLsher pla..e you in the early 70's.

title: Last Holdout on the Mandel Jury Tells of Feeling
description: BALTIMORE. Aug. 24The jury that deliberated for 12 days in the Federal corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five codefendants reached its guilty verdicts after a holdout juror decided to go along with the others despite his feeling that all the parties were innocent

title: Joyce Cuoco, Fabulous Dancer, at Jacob's Pillow
description: LEE, MASS.

title: 90% POLICE RESPONSE ON BLACKOUT IS CITED
description: Ninety percent of the New York City Police Department's available personnel reported for duty during last month's blackout emergency, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

title: Hers
description: OUR HOUSE, the first house I knew, was in the middle of a block that my mother once ingenuously described as being across the street from the residential district. That phrase more or less sums up the way the rest of my life has gone, but in real terms she was absolutely correct. From the front steps you saw lawns. From the back porch you saw laundry lines. When I had a birthday, children from both sides of the neighborhood were invited.

title: Ham Auction Sets Record
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., Aug. 24 (UPI)The prizewinning country ham at the 1977 Kentucky State Fair brought $35,150 at an auction at the fair today, or $1,850 a pounda new world record. The previous. high price was $1,100 a pound paid for the 1976 ham by the CocaCola Bottling Company. The prizewinning ham, produced by Broadbent B&B Foods Producti. of Cadiz, Ky., was bought by Harold B. Morgeson.

title: Family Money: New Savings Through Mortgage Refinancing
description: HOUSES MEAN different things to different peoplea showcase or a sanctuary; a place to hang one's hat; and sometimes, when the boiler goes or the roof needs to be fixed, a real nuisance.

title: Solar Power Design Set
description: A design has been decided on for a $100 million solar power tower and mirror system to be, built near Barstow, Calif. Page D9.

title: People and Business
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today announced the appointment of Terry L. Claassen as head of the agency's division of trading and markets.

title: VanceTens Meeting Seems to Bring Ties No Closer
description: PEKING, Thursday, Aug. 25Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance discussed normalization of relations between China and the United States with Teng Hsiaoping, China's thirdranking leader, for two and a half hours yesterday but apparently made no progress on the critical issue of Taiwan.

title: Badillo and Hirschfeld Join Forces to Bolster Faltering Candidacies
description: Putting together a rare combination of political views, Representative Herman Badillo and Abraham Hirschfeld will link their respective campaigns for the Democratic mayoral and City Council President nominations in an effort to stimulate their faltering candidacies.

title: Order to Clear Lance's Bank In 76 Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Internal Revenue Service is investigating an allegation that an official of the Atlanta office of the Comptroller of the Currency ordered a bank examiner to give Bert Lance's bank in Calhoun, Ga., a clean bill of health in a 1976 review, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Notes on People
description: THERE will be a royal wedding in Monaco soon. How soon isn't known, but Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace, announced yesterday that their daughter, Princess Caroline, will marry a 37yearold French insurance broker.

title: Soviet Hints Space Cooperation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)The Soviet Union will send a delegation to meet with officials of the expanding European Space Agency this fall, possibly signaling a move toward a cooperative effort. In disclosing to a luncheon of the National Space Club that the Russians have asked for another meeting, Col. Wilford Mellors, the British head of E.S.A.'s Washington office, cautioned that it may carry no special significance.

title: MILTON DUKE GRAHAM
description: Milton Duke Graham, former director of research for the American Foundation of the Blind, died yesterday in his Greenwich Village apartment. He was 61 years old.

title: ExAvis Aide Enters Plea of Guilty
description: Val Marino, a former director of construction and engineering at Avis Inc., yesterday pleaded guilty to charges that he failed to report in his 1972 Federal income tax return a $40,000 kickback received from H. L. Lazar Inc., a New York construction company, according to the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn.

title: Advertising
description: lei the new frontier in licensing.

title: Health Agency Cites Wild Mushroom Peril
description: The city's Health Department has issued a warning against picking mushrooms from the ground. Eating mushrooms, which grow wild in the city in the late summer and early fall, can be fatal.

title: Market Place
description: Can the misfortunes of leftfooted dancers, monotone vocalists and butterfingered magicians provide the basis for a sound investment?

title: Ted Knight's Debut Scheduled for Oct. 25
description: Ted Knightuntil recently a star with TV's Mary Tyler Moore Showwill make his Broadway debut in Some of My Best Friends, at the Longacre Theatre Oct. 25. Stanley Hart's new comedy was announced by the producers, Arthur Whitelaw, Jack Schlissel and Leonard Soloway.

title: Opera Talks Broken Off
description: Negotiations on a new contract between the Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra musicians broke off again yesterday after a meeting at the opera house. Edward Silver, labor counsel for the company, said no movement toward a settlement had been made. He said the Metropolitan had advised the musicians, represented by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, that the Sept. 9 deadline for cancelling the season was real.

title: WASHINGTON WEIGHS LIMITED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24A White House spokesman said today that there had been discussions within the Government about limited American efforts to help settle the sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland.

title: Carter Not Invited
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP)Jimmy Carter was the first President not invited to a national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in 27 years, and he will probably not be invited next year either, according to a top official of the organization.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: East Berlin Arrests Dissident in Party As Fame Spreads
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 24East Germany disclosed today that it had arrested dissident East Berlin party official who won sudden fame in both parts of Germany through his criticism of Communist bureaucracy.

title: CANAL PACT SIGNING SET FOR NEXT MONTH
description: WASHDIGTON, Aug. 24  President Carter intends to sign two Panama Canal treaties here on Sept. 7 in the presence of a large number of Latin American heads of state and government, Administration officials said today.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY. AUGUST 24. 1977

title: SOVIET CALLS CHINA TALKS A THREAT TO WORLD PEACE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP)As Chinese and American officials met in Peking, the Soviet Union declared today that new Chinese attempts to Improve relations with the West were a threat to world peace.

title: Tropical Wave Peril Declines
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (UPI)Showers from a tropical wave that threatened to become the season's first tropical depression decreased today and the Nation& Hurricane Center said that the system was showing no signs of gaining strength.

title: Mafia Figure Held on Stolen Bond Charge
description: John A. Masleno Sr., reportedly a major Mafia figure in Westchester County, was charged yesterday with conspiracy to sell $750,000 in stolen securities.

title: Tito Said to Get a Warm Welcome On His Arrival in North Korea
description: TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP)President Tito of Yugoslavia was greeted with firm handshakes and warm hugs by President Kim II Sung of North Korea today as he arrived in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, for an official visit, the Nnrth Knrean nress aeencv reported.

title: Tribeca Follows SoHo Footsteps, Gingerly
description: Tribeca isn't SoHo, but you'll notice there are fixture fees for even those loftments, said the apartmenthunting young artist, who was really not speaking in tongues. From what I've seen, though, a lot of places down here will never get a C. of 0. to qualify for a J51 from the city.

title: Not Entirely Pure
description: BOSTON, Aug. 24In the spring of 1976 The Tennessean of Nashville discovered that one of its copy editors, Mrs. Jacque Srouji, had been playing an undercover role for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The publisher of the paper, John Seigenthaler, decided after much discussion that her activities had been inappropriate for a journalist. On May 5 he dismissed her.

title: Reporter's Notebook: War Grips New and Old Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 23A chill rain is falling on this city. It is morning and from the clutter of tinroofed houses spreading around and over the hills of Addis Ababa rise thousands of spumes of fragrant eucalyptus smoke.

title: NEW ASSET OF REAGAN: CONTROL OF $4 MILLION
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24Ronald Reagan has a campaign asset today that he missed sorely in his drive for the Republican Presidential nomination last yeara million dollars.

title: AMEX QUARTER NET OFF BY 5.9% FROM YEAR AGO
description: The American Stock Exchange fared better in the second quarter than in the opening quarter this year, but earnings continued their decline with the net of $238,000 off 5.9 percent from the $253,000 a year ago, according to the Exchange's report issued yesterday.

title: Airlines Plan to Cut Britain Runs to Meet A Threatened Strike
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP)Some international airlines drew up plans today to cut flight schedules sharply to meet threatened fourday strike of assistant air traffic controllers that could shut down all British airports.

title: Mine and Refinery Copper Output Off Sharply in July Due to Strike
description: Mine and refinery production of copper fell sharply in the United States during July following the start of a nationwide strike on July 1, the American Bureau of Metal Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Conran Can't Use Habitat Name
description: I've always wante& my flaw! over the door, Terence Conran said yesterday after learning that he can't legally use the name Habitat for his new shop, which will open soon in Citicorp Center at 575 Lexington Avenue near 50th Street. Mr. Conran is the founder and head of Habitat International, a chain of home furnishings emporiums in Europe.

title: Suspect in Carter Threat Held
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 24 (AP)A man who gave his name and address when he telephoned the White House and threatened to shoot President Carter was being held here on $10,000 bond for a hearing Friday, the authorities said today. Charles Cleveland, 50 years old, was still talking to a White House Secret Service agent Saturday night when an Atlanta policeman arrived at his apartment and took the telephone out of his hand, a Secret Service spokesman said.

title: British Pornographer Freed
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters)James Humphreys, the former owner of a chain of pornographic bookstores and brothels, was freed from prison today for his help in convicting several top members of Scotland Yard's Porn Squad on corruption charges. Mr. Humphreys was jailed in 1974 for eight years for wounding his wife's lover.

title: 3 AT NORTHSOUTH TALKS TELL OF WALKOUT THREAT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (Reuters)The 27nation economic conference in Paris this June nearly broke up in disarray because of a threatened walkout by some of the industrialized countries, three United States delegates to the meeting renorted today.

title: Democrats Lack Harmony
description: NEWARK, AUG. 24With the New Jersey gubernatorial election less than 11 weeks away, the five Democrats who garnered more than 67 percent of the vote in the June primary sit at dockside like members of a bewildered varsity rowing

title: Business Records
Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)The Marriott Corporation said today it had reached agreement in principle to sell six or seven of its hotels to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: CLARENCE JONNARD, 79, A MAJOR LEAGUE SCOUT
description: Clarence (Bubber) Jonnard, a major league baseball scout for 40 years and the metropolitan area scout for the New York Mets for the last 15 years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: New Edition of Jane's Says AllVolunteer Navy Gives U.S. an Edge',
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP)The new edition of Jane's Fighting Ships says the allvolunteer United States Navy has the edge over conscript rivals. The book also has high praise for what it calls the Soviet Union's very powerful and wellknit fleet and for France's achievement of global sea Dower.

title: Bergland Advises Carter to Reduce Planting of Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has advised President Carter to counter a growing national wheat surplus by approving a 25 percent acreagereduction program for 1978.

title: JGE Jerry in Job Search
description: The latest story in the saga of Jerry (What's the story?) Rosenberg was told on Tuesday in the form of a position wanted ad in the Wall Street Journal. Mr. Rosenberg, who stated that he was ready for challenge, sought an executive position in sales promotion, merchandising, advertising or public relations.

title: Berglund Seeks Cut In Wheat Planting
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has advised President Carter to counter a growing national wheat surplus by approving a 25 percent acreagereduction program for 1978.

title: SOLAR POWER DESIGN IS CHOSEN FOR TEST
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI)A design has been chosen for a 5100 million solar power tower and mirror system to be constructed near Barstow, Calif., the Energy Research and Development Administration announced today. The design was developed by the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company, of Huntington Beach, Calif., Honeywell Inc. and the Martin Marietta Corporation had also submitted proposals.

title: Quebec Acts on Independence Vote
description: QUEBEC, Aug. 24The Quebec government today moved a step closer to a vote on independence by issuing an outline of rules by which a referendum campaign would be held.

title: A.P. OFFICIALS WILL BEGIN 2WEEK CHINA TOUR AUG. 30
description: A delegation or Associated Press executives and directors will make a twoweek visit to China beginning Aug. 30.

title: CREDIT MARKET RISE RESUMES AFTER SLIP
description: After a minor retreat early yesterday. the credit market resumed the moderately strongand to some dealers, mystifying advance that began a little more than a week ago. dealer remarked after the close of trading. Still, he added, it's perplexing.

title: INDIA DROPS SOVIET FOR U.S. AID ON STEEL
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 24India has quietly terminated an agreement with the Soviet Union and turned instead to the United States for technical help in the expansion of the Bokaro steel plant in the eastern state of Bihar.

title: Monmouth
Lobster Company Is Identified
description: The company whose berried. or eggbearing, lobsters were seized last week in Syracuse and then dropped into Long Island Sound was the NAL Company of Syracuse, not the North American Lobster Company, as it had been identified by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. NAL previously had been known as the North American Lobster Company, but it recently agreed to change its name to NAL after a Calstadt, N. J., concern complained that it had been granted thou trademark for the North American name: The North American Lobster Company in Carlstadt was not involved in last week's seizure.

title: DORSIE W. WILLIS, 91, VICTIM OF ARMY BIAS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP)Dorsie W. Willis, the last survivor of a company of black soldiers that the Army discharged without honor in the Brownsville Incident of 1906, died today. He was 91 years old.

title: Dancers Turn From Pirouettes to Plastering
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

title: Traurig Sweeps Jumper Honors
description: WESTBURY. L.I.. Aug. 24Bernie Traurig, a 32yearold professional, has ridden the winners of hundreds of jumper classes in horse shows, and he even has handled the first and second finishers on rare occasions.

title: Lawn Mower Tied Up the
description: It was a lawn mower that delayed 30 Long Island Rail Road trains with perhaps 3,000 passengers up to three hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, according to the railroad.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor.

title: Sinking Bureaucratic Hooks Into the Public
description: WASHINGTONWater, a commodity typically in great abundance, is suddenly scarce in the Western United States. Public officials have used the drought to impose more regulations and controls on the lives of many Americans. Indeed, what is taking place in the San Francisco area may foreshadow a future of growing bureaucratic control over all Americans, especially those who live in the West.

title: Stanley Noble, 72, a Retired Book Publisher
description: Stanley Rodman, Noble, retired president of Noble & Noble Publishers, died yesterday at his Point O'Woods summer home on Fire Island. He was 72 years old and lived at North Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday attributed more of the blame for the blackout of July 13 and 14 to human and mechanical failures within its own system, and less to the lightning strikes that started the emergency.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Six years ago, Treasury Secretary John Connally stopped the world and got off. The Nixon Administration unilaterally withdrew from the international monetary system that had been constructed, to United States specifications, in 1944. Henceforth, Secretary Connally declared, the United States would not defend the value of the dollar in exchange with other currencies.

title: Opening the Cage for Foreign Circus Workers in U.S.

title: Film: 'One on One' Scores for Fair Play
description: HENRY STEELE (Robby Benson) is a high school basketball star who seems no more or less bright than his contemporaries but he is extremely ambitious. When, in the middle of his senior year, he is approached by university basketball scouts, Henry holds out for the best deal, which includes not only a four-year scholarship, private tutoring and various jobs to put money in his pocket, but also an automobile of his choice.That autumn, en route to the big West Coast university that has won Henry, the car of his choice starts to steam ominously. The car looks great but it's a lemon.This is pretty much the opinion that "One on One," directed by Lamont Johnson ("The Last American Hero") and written by Mr. Benson and his father, Jerry Segal, has of the high-pressure, big-business world of supposedly amateur university athletics.This is not the reason that "One on One" seems so decent and entertaining. The most money-grubbing movies often are insufferably high-minded about other people's ambition and money-grubbing. "One on One" "never makes any of its points lightly but never is it smug, as if it had a franchise on truth, nor is it condescending to its characters.The Benson-Segal screenplay has an appreciation both for the formula of films of action (in this case, on the basketball court) and for characters of unexpected backbone. In Mr. Johnson, "One on One" also has a director whose best films have been concerned with competition as a dangerously important expression of American life.According to "One on One," which opened at Loews State 2 and other theaters yesterday, a certain amount of competition is a healthy thingin politics as well as the fast-food businessbut the need to win at all costs is a perversion of a system that otherwise is never seriously questioned."One on One" is mostly about the modified awakening of Henry Steele. At first, Henry is nonplussed by the professional thoroughness of the university's athletic program but later he becomes its victim when he doesn't measure up. After he refuses to renounce voluntarily his scholarship, he elects to fight the system to become the basketball star they said he never would.In movies of mystery and suspense, predictability is fatal. In something like "One on One," predictability has the effect of enriching our interest as we wait to see not what will happen but how it's brought about. A lot of the success of the "how" in "One on One" has to do with the performance by writer-actor Benson, whose clean-cut navet masks a surprising moral strength, which, even if it's not very common, is something we'd all like to believe in.Until her role becomes squeaky clean, Annette O'Toole is most winning as the beautiful, sharp-tongued young woman who is assigned to tutor the basketball star and stays on to fall in love with him. Gail Strickland is very funny as a coach's secretary, who likes to ravish her boss's players, and G.D. Spradlin is fine as her boss, a tough man who stands by the system, right or wrong."One on One" is the sort of pop movie that has too much music on the soundtrack and too much bright color in the photography, which, I suppose, is part of its style. Yet it also has some very good sequences that are not at all expected, including the smashing basketball game that concludes the film."One on One," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language that you are as likely to hear outside a locker room as in one.

title: Visible Campaign, Invisible Issues

They are the realities of life, the concerns New Yorkers will have to contend with in the next four years. Yet, as the New York Times/C.B.S. surveys attest, to most voters the issues remain a blur. And that creates special responsibilities both for the candidates and for the voters.

title: infants Making Splash in Class
description: In class designed to teach the skills of swimming to infants, Mrs. Thomas Feury puts her 4monthold daughter, Danielle  Nicole Feury, through her paces. The class for infants up to 1 year in age is directed by Leslie Eyster, a physical education teacher at Kittatinny Regional High School in Hampton Township, N.J. Program is set up to teach breathing skills so babies won't develop a fear of water as they older.

title: Major League Box Scores
Typhoon Hits Southern Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 24 (UPI)A typhoon smashed into Japan today, deluging southern parts of the nation with nearly a foot of rain in 10 hours. The storm struck the coast between Nagasaki and Kumamoto on the southern island of Kyushu, after advance rains had sent hundreds of people fleeing homes threatened with flooding from rising creeks and rivers. The typhoon killed two persons in Taiwan before reaching Japan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ON THE TOWN at today's 10th annual Lower East Side Festival from noon to midnight, the public is invited to sample drama, dance and music events, along with displays of crafts and food prepared by the multiethnic community. The place is Henry Street between Jackson and Montgomery Streets.

title: About New York
description: As a pushcart peddler, John Zervas tells you, he did what he had to do and then some: wearing four pairs of socks on a winter day, upgrading his cart with wheels costing $30 each, conquering evolutionary stages beyond the pretzel and Cracker Jack beginnings with the addition of stove and dryice units that opened up new profit vistas in hot dogs sodas and flavored ices.

title: TinyTot Classes Wash Out Fear of Water
description: HAMPTON TOWNSHIP, Aug. 24Leslie Eyster's task of teaching schoolchildren to swim was complicated by their acquired fear of water by the time they reached school age, so she decided to get them in the pool before they could walk.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, August 26, 1977

title: Frederick Tompkins, Former Head Of Newark Plaster Company, at 82
description: Frederick Tompkins, a retired manufacturer of building materials, died Wednesday at Orange Memorial Hospital in Orange, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in East Orange.

title: Bluegrass In Jersey, on Real Grass.
description: Bluegrass has made such admirable progress in the metropolitan area in the last 10 years that there is hardly any new ground to conquer. After all, bluegrass is now heard in Fifth Avenue cafes, student auditoriums, the South Street Seaport and indoor music halls in New Jersey, even airconditioned shopping centers in the suburbs. What else is left?

title: Bomb Hurts 3 in Israeli Resort; Another Is Found Aboard a Bus
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 (AP)A terrorist bomb exploded in a sidewalk trash can today, injuring a woman and two children in the resort town of Netanya, 15 miles north of Tel Aviv, the police reported.

title: The Regency Extends MGM Film Festival
description: The Regency Theater at Broadway and 67th Street will extend its MGM Festival one week, until Sept. 17. Two musical films starring Gene Kelly, Singin in the Rain and An American in Paris, and two dramas, Mrs. Miniver and Goodbye, Mr. Chips, will be repeated during the week beginning Sept. 11.

title: World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The Pakistan National Alliance will take Pakistan out of the Central Treaty Organization and pursue a nonaligned foreign policy if it wins the election in October, its secretary general said today.

title: Notes on People
description: There was joy in the tiny realm of Monaco yesterday following the announcement of Princess Caroline's engagement to Philippe Junot, a Paris businessman whose father is a Deputy Mayor there. Sources at the palace of Prince Rainer and Princess Grace, the former movie star Giace Kelly, said that although no date had been announced, the wedding would actually take place next June in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Mary, where Caroline's parents were married. The family celebrated the engagement yesterday with a luncheon attended by the parents of Mr. Junot whose courtship of Caroline was at first frowned upon by her parents because at 37, he is 17 years her senior. Caroline was wearing her engagement ring, a sapphire encircled by diamonds.

title: New Face: Mummenschanz
description: At center stage is a simple platform flanked by ramps. At the foot of one ramp sits a huge brown blob resembling nothing so much as an overgrown Idaho potato. Silence. Then the blob twitches, contracts, expands. It inches toward the ramp and, in a series of slowmotion convulsions, makes a desperate effort to reach the platform. The silence of the Bijou Theater has given way to cheers and laughter as the surprised audience begins to root for the plucky potato. Another performance of Mummenschanz has begun.

title: Most Soweto High Schools to Close
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The South African Government announced today plans to close all but two secondary schools in the black township of Soweto after a classroom boycott by students there.

title: In Memoriam
description: BERINSTEINWilliam. August 26, 1957. In loving memory always. BOB

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT IS FOURTH HIGHEST WITH $2.33 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The United States imported less oil and coffee last month to reduce its trade deficit from the record set in June, but the excess of imports over exports was still the fourth highest in history.

title: Leo H. Strauss, at 79, Chairman Of Travel Agency, Dies in Italy
description: Leo H. Strauss, chairman of the travel Agency of StraussSimmonsSullivan, died Tuesday in Montecatini, Italy, while on a business trip. He was 79 years old and lived at 215 East 79th Street.

title: Chile Allows Some Dissenting Voices to Be Heard
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, Aug. 25Things seem to be relaxing here, said Joaquin Valdez a businessmanfarmer, while looking over the headlines in Chile's afternoon newspapers.

title: Carey and Beame Rated Adversely In a Poll of Party Members in City
description: A year before he is expected to seek reelection, Governor Carey was rated unfavorably in a survey of New York City registered Democratsa complete reversal from the favorable rating he received in a poll last October.

title: CARTER PLANS A REVIEW OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters)President Carter today announced the initiation of a review of the Federal Government's economci analysis and policymaking machinery to try to improve ways in which economic decisions are made and carried out.

title: Ford Engine Factory Is Planned for Europe
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP)Ford of Europe Inc. will build an engine plant in Western Europe, it was announced today, The plant is needed to meet the market's needs In the 1980s, according to a statement released by Ford of Europe, which is based in Warley, England.

title: Radio
Carey Asserts Beame Bypassed Control Board on Police Raises
description: Governor Carey charged yesterday that Mayor Beame had tried to circumvent the procedures of the New York State Emergency Financial Control Board by moving in court to confirm a 6 percent wage increase for New York City's police force without first consulting the board.

title: Around the Nation
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP)Policemen of the Bay Area Rapid Transit system defied a court order and declared a strike today, disrupting service for 70,000 commuters.

title: Esmark Profit Up 14.3% in Quarter
description: Esmark Inc., comprising Swift & Company, the world's leading meat packer and three other major operations, reported an increase of 14.3 percent in earnings for the third fiscal quarter and a 16.7 percent drop for the nine months ended July 30. However, directors yesterday declared an increased quarterly dividend of 46 cents a share, payable Oct. 1 to holders of record Sept. 9. Shareholders had received 44 cents a share in former quarters.

title: CHARLES M. ODORIZZI, 68, LONG A RCA EXECUTIVE
description: Charles M. Odorizzi, a retired executive vice president of the RCA Corporation, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Labrador. He was 68 years old and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: VANCE FINISHES VISIT WITH PEKING LEADERS
description: PEKING, Friday, Aug: 26Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has concluded four days of talks on normalizing ChineseAmerican relations including a onehour meeting yesterday with Hua Kuofeng. Chairman of the Communist Party. Mr. Vance said the discussions had been candid and serious: and had enhanced our mutual understanding.

title: Article 2No Title
description: The New York Times/Robert Walker SITTING ON TOP OF THE WORLD: Figuratively speaking, of course. Louis Nasti spent a pleasant afternoon yesterday at Flushing Meadow Park, playing in the shadow of the Unisphere. More pleasant weather is forecast for today and tomorrow, with temperature in the mid70's.

title: CHAIN STORE SALES SURGED 16% IN JULY
description: The nation's chain stores moved massive quantities of merchandise in July and finished the month with a gain of 16.4 percent from July of 1976. For the JanuarythroughJuly period the chains reported a gain of 11.9 percent over the comparable 1976 period.

title: Reserve Report
Unsoaking the Rich in the West
description: A populist chorus now hails the decision by Interior Secretary Cecil Andrus to enforce a 1902 law limiting the size of individual farms and banning absentee ownership of land irrigated by Federal water projects. His decision is seen as a victory for the family farmer, chance for rugged individualists to buy lands now in the clutches of speculators, railroads and ketchup manufacturers. Indeed, the ruling should force the very largest owners to divest their holdings. But, as in other instances of Federal intervention in agriculture, the beneficiaries will not be hundreds of thousands of small farmers who barely scratch a living from the soil. They will be farmers who are already in middle and upperincome brackets.

title: Georgia Pattern
description: Not surprisingly, President Carter and his lieutenants have failed to put an end to the Bert Lance controversy by their contention that a recent report of the Comptroller of the Currency, proved Mr. Lance's good character and competence.

title: State Says Goodman Must Pay for His Times
description: ALBANY, Aug. 25The State Audit and Control Department, which reviews expense accounts of legislators, rejected a $91.25 tab of State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, for copies of The New York Times airmailed to him during a 1976 vacation, it was disclosed today.

title: New Bond Issues
description: THURSDAY, AUG. 25, 1977

title: Assembly Unit Bars Letting S. E. C. Speak for State,
description: ALBANY, Aug. 25The Assembly Banking Committee will hold public hearings on the role of major New York City banks in the city's 1975 fiscal crisis, the committee's chairman said here today.

title: Savings Unit to Buy A Commercial Bank In New Jersey Deal
description: In an unusual banking transaction, a New Jersey savings bank announced yesterday it planned to take over a commercial bank.

title: Plane Crash at Golf Club Hurts Six
description: POCONO MANOR, Pa., Aug. 25 (UPI) A light plane crashed today on the west course of the Pocono Manor Golf Club, injuring six persons. The police said that a singleengine Piper aircraft crashed in a wooded area just off the crowded second fairway of the golf course while on a sightseeing tour that originated at Mount Pocono Airport.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
Inquiry Into Carter Flights Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)The United States Attorney who investigated Bert Lance's bank dealings said today that the National Bank of Georgia, of which Mr. Lance was president, should be investigated for possible illegal campagn contributions because it gave President Carter free plane trips.

title: ARRAIGNMENTS PLAN PROTESTED BY POLICE
description: The first step in an effort in Manhattan to reduce delays in bringing prisoners to arraignment drew a protest yesterday from police officers, who found themselves waiting in a former prison to process their arrests instead of in the Criminal Court building.

title: 140 Prisoners Are Removed From Work Program As Controls Are Tightened Under New State Law
description: Because of tightened controls under new state law. 140 prisoners in New York State were removedf ro m work programs and other temporaryrelease projectsyesterday and were returned to regular prisons.

title: About Real Estate
description: Is success spoiling the preservation movement?

title: Rock: The Punk Circuit
description: THE WEDNESDAY night rock triple bill at the Palladium might have seemed a deliberate attempt to bring punk rock to major concert hall. All seats were democratically priced at $3.50, and at least two of the bands, AC/DC and the Dictators, have been associated with the CBGB's circuit.

title: Mysterious Soviet Vehicle, in Orbit A Month, Puzzles Space Observers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25A Soviet space vehicle that has been in orbit for a month and is large enough to be manned but appeals not to be is puzzling observers in the United States and abroad.

title: HOTDOG KING
description: The Central Park hotdog war got hotter on the legal front yesterday, but peace reigned in the Dark.

title: Begin Holding Talks in Rumania, Israel's Only Link to Communists
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 25In an atmosphere of secrecy and stringent security, Israel's Prime Minister, Menahem Begin, arrived here today and opened four days of talks with leaders of Rumania, the only Communist country that recognizes Israel.

title: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett ASSEMBLY LINE OBSERVERS: Youngsters from the Bronx, members of Police Athletic League, at Ford Motor Company's Mahwah plant watching cars being assembled as part of the company's community relations program.
Philadelphia Folk Fest Back to Basics
description: The Philadelphia Folk Festival will move back to basics during its 16th annual session this weekend on the: rolling fields of the Old Pool Farm near Schwenksville, a small community in the Pennsylvania Dutch country northwest of Philadelphia.

title: Letter to Berkowitz Searched for Bomb
description: David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the 44caliber killer, yesterday received a letter that correction officers at first thought contained a bomb, the city's Correction Department reported.

title: Art People
description: IT'S NOT EVERY DAY that you can see a genuine authenticated fake in a reputable Manhattan gallery. But as of now and through Sept. 10 at the A.A.A. Gallery, 663 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street, you can see a whole wall of them as part of an exhibition called The Discerning Eye.

title: Dr. Janet Anderson Caldwell, 82, Pathologist and Nutrition Expert
description: Dr. Janet Anderson Caldwell a pathologist and an expert in nutrition died Monday at her Manhattan home. She was 82 years old.

title: CARTER URGES CYPRIOTS TO RESUME PEACE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters)President Carter today urged the Greek and Turkish communities of Cyprus to resume negotiations and to overcome lack of progress in settling theCyprus dispute.

title: More Funds Sought for E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)President Carter asked Congress today for a supplemental appropriation of $35 million for the Environmental Protection Agency. The funds for the 1978 fiscal year would he earmarked for research to find ways to reduce pollution from coalusing energy sources.

title: Film: 'Garden' Offers Glimpses of Genius
description: TO CONCLUDE its minifestival of heretofore unreleased films by the great Luis Buuel, the Renoir Cinema yesterday opened "Death in the Garden" ("La Mort en Ce Jardin"), a comparatively big-budget, color, Mexican-French co-production made in 1956.Like "Fever Mounts at El Pao," a 1959 Mexican-French co-production that Buuel himself would like to forget. "Death in the Garden" is full of marvelous, uniquely Buuelian moments set in a melodramatic custard. It's not a film by which to be introduced to Buuel, but if you know and appreciate his work as I do, it's one of the few movies around that should not be missed."Death in the Garden," set in the backwaters and the jungles of an unidentified South American dictatorship, is a large-scale narrative that takes on state, church, the military, society and the individual in such a way that you feel the director must have intended this primeval locale to be a kind of psychological mirror-image of the Franco Spain from which he exiled himself.Though the film's intellectual substructure is fascinating, the screenplay (by Buuel, Luis Alcoriza and Raymond Queneau) is so packed with incident that it's all that one can do to keep up with the plot, which is at war with reflection.Its principal characters are a beautiful hard-hearted whore (played by a very young Simone Signoret), a handsome, amoral young drifter (Georges Marchal), a well-meaning but ineffectual priest (Michel Piccoli, with all of his hair), an aging diamond miner (Charles Vanel) who dreams of opening a restaurant in Marseilles, and his pretty, mute daughter (Michele Girardon).Through one ruse and another, including a bloody but ineffectual rebellion, Buuel and his collaborators put the characters into the position of having to flee for their lives upstream and into the jungles. Nobody in the small party of fugitives either lives or dies by accident. Their fates are decided by a scheme that invites interpretation more than surprise.It's not the story, the performances or even the ideas (much more wittily and succinctly put in both earlier and later Buuel films), but the sudden moments in which a Buuel image or gesture comes shining through a haze of melodramatic conventions.There's an extraordinary moment when the body of a headless python, killed by the fugitives for their supper, suddenly seems to come alive again as it is attacked by an army of ants. That one image could be one entire movie. In another scene, Mr. Piccoli, the priest, recalls for no easily apparent reason a story about a fellow seminarian who once had a compulsion to eat poached eggs. In moments like this, one glimpses Buuel's appreciation for the act of disorder.At the time Buuel made "Death in the Garden" he had already produced such masterpieces as "Los Olvidados," "El" and "The Criminal Life of Archibaldo de La Cruz," and he was within four years of beginning his golden age that includes "Viridiana," "Simon of the Desert," "Belle de Jour," "Tristana" and "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie.""Death in the Garden" is a kind of halfway house for the film genius, made when he had yet to receive the acclaim that would give him full control of his movies, but after he had been taken seriously enough by the money men to be entrusted with an expensive movie with big stars."Death in the Garden" is a perfectly honorable compromise, but you won't see in it the simplicity and the clarity of technique and spirit that are so breathtaking in his best movies.A word about the film as it's being shown at the Renoir: It's a 16-mm print in which the color is not first-rate and many of the white subtitles, especially at the beginning, are virtually invisible.

title: CARTER'S F.B.I.CHOICE TO UNDERGO SURGERY
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Friday, Aug. 26 (AP)Federal Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. selected last week by President Carter to become director of the Federal Bureau Investigation is scheduled to under to surgery today at Methodist Hospital in Hnuctnn fora suspected blocked blood vessel in the stomach.

title: Market Place
description: The most spectacular takeover battle since Northwest Industries abortive attempt to seize B. F. Goodrich ended yesterday with J. Ray McDermott's capture of enough of the shares of Babcock & Wilcox to cause United Technologies to retire from the lists.

title: A Reputed Mafia Figure Accused With 7 of a Plot at To Seize Bronx Concern
description: John A. Masiello Sr., reputedly a major Mafia figure, and seven other persons were indicted yesterday on charges of coercion, grand larceny and assault in an alleged conspiracy to take over a Bronx poultry business.

title: AMEX TO VOTE SEPT. 28 ON 150 NEW OPTIONS SEATS
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday its members would vote Sept. 28 on proposals to create 150 new options memberships and to allow the renting of Amex seats.

title: Management
description: While many would agree that the job of running a large city is enough to drive one crazy, the notion that the pressures could make the nation's mayors and city managers seek professional help might be going too far.

title: U.S.P.L.O. Dialogue: Chances Seem to Ebb
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 25  The chances for a dialogue between the Carter Administration and the Palestine Liberation Organization appear to be ebbing, hampered by a gap of misunderstanding and suspicion, division among the Pal estinians and growing doubts in the Arab camp that the News United States is capable of Analysis delivering a peace settlement in the near future.

title: Antiques
description: ANTIQUES COLLECTORS usually seek expert help when table needs refinishing, the veneers of a commode blister, chairs wobble or a lacquered screen has lost its sheen. But frequently they do not know to whom to turn for assistance, nor do they know what to expect in services or the cost of repairs.

title: JAPAN WEIGHS EASING CURBS ON REFUGEES
description: TOKYO. Aug. 25Prodded by the United States and the office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Japan is considering liberalizing its restrictive polices toward accepting refugees from Vietnam who arrive in Japanese ports after having been rescued at sea by ships heading for Japan.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Declines 6.7%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15 billion tonmiles. down 6.7 percent from the yearearlier level. Strikes in the coal and ironore industries were considered the main causes for the decline. Carloadings in the same period totaled 434,928 cars, a decline of 8.6 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity, truck tonnage rose 5.7 percent from year ago.

title: A Museumgoers
description: Claude Monet would have understood

title: DOLLAR SHOWS RISE IN FOREIGN MARKETS
description: The United States dollar weathered an announcement of depressing July trade figures and moved upwards on foreign currency exchange markets yesterday, the Associated Press reported.

title: United Bows Out Of Babcock Fray; McDermott Wins
description: The United Technologies Corporation withdrew yesterday from the battle to acquire control of the Babcock & Wilcox Company, one of the nation's leading manufacturers of steam generating equipment and other industrial products. The apparent winner of the fight is J. Ray McDermott & Company of New Orleans, a major producer of offshore oil rigs.

title: LIMITED RIGHTS ADVANCES ARE REPORTED BY TODMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)The Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, Terence A. Todman, reported progress toward enhanced human rights in four South American countries under military control today but said each nation still hs a long way to go.

title: VANCE FINISHES VISIT WITH PEKING LEADERS
description: PEKING, Friday, Aug. 26Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has concluded four days of talks on normalizing ChineseAmericari relations including a onehour meeting yesterday with Hua Kuofeng. Chairman of the Communist Party. Mr. Vance said the discussions had been candid and serious and had enhanced our mutual understanding.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. letter designates OM listing.

title: Philippine Police Break Up Protest M arch by 2,000
description: MANILA, Aug. 25 (AP)Policemen used water cannon to break up a march today by 2,000 people protesting alleged humanrights abuses in the Philippines. Four American delegates to an international law conference were among hundreds of demonstrators doused.

title: Device Found Near Plains Church May Be Remote Control Bomb
description: PLAINS. Ga., Aug. 25 (UPI)A makeshift device that Federal explosive experts belive is a remote control bomb was found 125 feet from the Plains Baptist Church in President Carter's hometown, the authorities said today.

title: House Panel Studying Korean InfluenceBuying Questions ExAide to Albert 5 Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Suzy Park Thomson, who was threatened yesterday with a contempt of Congress citation for refusing to testify in the investigation of Korean influence buying, was questioned at a fivehour closed session today by members of the House ethics committee.

title: Monmouth
Three Meetings in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Meetings in three African capitals over the next week will probably decide the political and racial future of Rhodesia, topranking Ad ministration officials specializing in African affairs said today.

title: Francis Wallace, Sportswriter And Author of Kid Galahad
description: BELLAIRE, Ohio, Aug. 24 (UPI)Francis Wallace, a sportswriter for nearly 20 years and author of the book, Kid Galahad, was buried today. He died Friday at a hospital in Cape Canaveral, Fla., at the age of 83.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: ROBERT ERSKINE CAMPBELL, EPISCOPAL BISHOP WAS 93
description: The Right Rev. Robert Erskine Campbell, senior member of the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church, died Tuesday at a hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 93 years old and lived at the Mount Calvary Retreat House in Santa Barbara.

title: Judge Who Suggested Boy in Rape Reacted Normally
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 25A judge who caused a furor recently by suggesting that a teenage boy was reacting normally to sexual permissiveness when he participated in a rape received more criticism today with the release of a court transcript detailing his remarks.

title: VIEW ON BLACKOUT BY CON ED DISPUTED
description: The general counsel of New York City's Special Commission of Inquiry into Energy Failures predicted yesterday that the panel's investigation into the blackout of July 1314 would show that the management of the Consolidated Edison Company, and not just one single solitary employee was at fault.

title: Police Step In as Lifeguards
description: WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 25Most lack the deep and even tan that marks the true summerlong professional, and few seem adept at preening. But that's only because many of the men on duty atop the lifeguard stands here are not lifeguards at all.

title: Parents/Children
description: Autism is one of those disorders about there is so much uncertainty and disagreement that one wonders why any single label is used at all. But regardless of the confusion that surrounds the term, it is clear that children who are called autistic are in trouble.

title: Utility's Holders Bar Sale of Stock; Nuclear Power Foes See Victory
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Aug. 25 (AP)Minority shareholders opposed to the sale of more than $20 million in Public Service Company of New Hampshire stock are claiming a moral victory in their fight against nuclear power.

title: Deaths
Owner Banned; Seattle Slew Is Out 30 Days
description: Dr. James Hill, a veterinarian who emerged publicly as one of the owners of Seattle Slew a few days after the colt won the Kentucky Derby, was suspended yesterday for 30 days, by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: For Children
description: Boscobel

title: Alden Bunn, Singer of Blues, 52; Used Stage Name Tarheel Slim
description: Funeral services for Alden Bunn, who was better known to blues fans as Tarheel Slim, were held yesterday in the Bronx. Mr. Bunn died Sunday of pneumonia. He had achieved his widest renown in recent years through a record album, No Time at All, and concert appearances in the New York area. Several of his performances at downtown lofts and art galleries sold out. For one, given last year at Environ, on West Broadway, a second show had to be scheduled to accommodate a line of blues fans that stretched down the block.

title: Weston and Miss Glasgow Swim To Gold Medals in World Games
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 25 (AP)American swimmers won three gold medals and Canadian swimmers two as they overcame a severe turnaround in weather conditions at the World University Gaines tonight.

title: The Pop Life
description: LINDA RONSTADT'S new album, Simple Dreams, should be in the record stores sometime next week. It's a beautiful disk, arguably her best. It will probably climb rapidly to one of the top positions on the sales charts, as her three previous albums have done (and as her Asylum Greatest Hits package did, too). But it will be interesting to follow the album's commercial progress. because one of the key cogs in the Ronstadt hitmaking machine has drooped out.

title: Policeman Accuses 2 Of Credit Union Bribe
description: Two New York City municipal credit union employees were arrested yesterday on charges of extorting money from a police officer to expedite his $2,800 loan.

title: Public Services to Golan and Sinai Proposed
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The Minister for Religious Affairs, Aharon AbuHatzeira, today proposed public services for inhabitants of the occupied Golan Heights and Sinai equal to those provided to Israelis.

title: Reagan Declares Canal Treaties Should Be Rejected by the Senate
description: After being briefed on the new Panama Canal treaties here yesterday by the chief American negotiators, Ronald Reagan declared that the Senate should refuse to approve them.

title: Bills
description: PLEASANTVILLE. N.Y., Aug. 25There's a hole in his left eye, and he can't see how his team possibly can get to the Super Bowl while he's still around, but O.J. Simpson finally has it made.

title: TaxIncentive Bills To Spur Business In New York Voted
description: Mayor Beanie's package of taxincentive bills to spur business expansion the city was passed by the City Council yesterday by a vote or 37 to 0.

title: RULING SAYS MANDEL COULD REGAIN OFFICE
description: ANNAPOLIS. Md., Aug. 25The Attorney General of Maryland ruled today that Lieut. Gov. Blair Lee 3d could not assume the title of Governor when Marvin Mandel, who was convicted Tuesday on Federal corruption charges, is sentenced and removed from office on Oct. 7, because Mr. Mandel could reclaim the office if he is vindicated on appeal.

title: India Names New Envoy to U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 (AP)India today officially announced appointment of a noted tax, constitutional and industrial lawyer, Nani A Palkhvala, as Ambassador to the United States. The 57yearold Mr. Palkhivaia will succeed Kewal Singh. Mr. Palkhivala, who has written extensively on taxation and constitutional rights, criticized the curtailment of those rights when Indira Gandhi was Prime Minister.

title: Myrna Gail Sameth Is Married to Kenneth W. Juster
description: Myrna Gail Sameth, daughter of Mrs. Herman Sameth of New York and the late Mr. Sameth, was married last evening to Kenneth William Juster, a widower and son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Juster of New York. Rabbis Edward E. Klein and Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue.

title: The U.N. Today
Cosmos Happy for Title Game
description: The harder the rain fell, the better the Cosmos played in their 41 semifinal playoff victory over the Rochester Lancers.

title: Broadway
description: YOU ALN'T HEARD NOTHING until you hear Stranger in Paradise with eight drums and bell sounds. The speaker was Luther Davis, and the show is Timbuktu, a black, African Kismetdirected, choreographed and costumed by Geoffrey Holder and starring William Marshall (in the role created by Alfred Drake), Eartha Kitt and Gilbert Price.

title: G.A.O. Says ShipPreference Bill Would Add 240 Million to Oil Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The General Accounting Office has estimated that cargopreference legislation supported by the Carter Administration would raise the nation's fuel bill by at least $240 million a year, more than double an estimate made by the Commerce Department in testimony last month.

title: Kennedy Tournament at Forest Hills Tomorrow
description: Arthur Ashe, Stan Smith and John Newcombe are among the professional tennis players who will compete at the sixth annual Robert F. Kennedy ProCelebrity Tennis Tournament tomorrow at the Forest Hills Stadium in Queens.

title: Advertising
description: When a company the size of the Ford Motor Company prepares to celebrate its 75th anniversary, the public might expect it to be a big deal. That's just about what we're getting from the giant automaker.

title: COMPROMISE REACHED ON SCHOOL'S OPENING
description: The possibility that there will be two opening dates for schoolone set by the Central Board of Education and the other set by community boards  diminished last night when 19 community boards agreed to compromise on the issue, if scheduled winter vacation is canceled.

title: Companies List Earnings Figures
TV Ads Canceled on ABC's Soap
description: SEVERAL companies have can celed their advertising spots in ABC's controversial new situation comedy Soap. which has been under fire from religious organizations for its preoccupation with adultery, homosexuality, impotency and related subjects.

title: jazz: Mingus at the Gate
description: THE SLOW, steady revitalization of Charles Mingus, from his virtual retirement in the late 1960's to his somewhat tentative return to music in the early 70's, has now reached a point at which he is once again approaching the creative, generating role he played 20 years ago. His latest record, Three or Four Shades of Blue, is the most distinctively Mingusian work he has put out since this period of reemergence began. And the quintet that he is leading at the Village Gate through tomorrow night has the personal hallmarks of his earlier Jazz Workshop groups that were not present in the recent, more loosely organized ensembles he has tars

title: Cooling Area Waters Lure Bounty of Bigger Bluefish
description: AREA ARalph Stork of Captain Andy's Marina in Margate, N.J., says fishing is 'at the peak for the year. He says the water temperature has dropped from 70 to 57 in a week, bringing out large schools of blues, fluke and weakfish. The blues and weakfish have been abundant in front of Ocean City and down to the Sea Isle Lump. The blues have been averaging about 10 pounds and the weaks about 7 or 8 pounds. Fluke have been swarming around Sandy Hook and south on beach fronts and in inlets. Bluefishing has also been good off Barnegat Ridge where 10pounders are average for fishermen using bananas during the day and bunkerbacks at night. Fluke fishing is also good in Barnegat Inlet. Offshore, fishermen are trolling for tuna and bonito.

title: Westerners Meet Chairman Hua
description: PEKING, Aug. 25When Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance shook hands with Hua Kuofeng, Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, in the Great Hall of the People today, he became the first active American official to meet China's highest ranking leader.

title: TV: Life Of Dickens Is Deftly Portrayed
description: THE NEWEST ARRIVAL to Masterpiece Theater, where the sun never sets on the British Empire, is Dickens of London, a 10part series dealing with the life of Charles Dickens that starts at 9 P.M. Sunday on public television over WNET 13.

title: ATLANTIC CITY WAITS FOR STORES TO COME
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Aug. 25 (UPI)In city that will soon be filled with gambling casinos ano new hotels, it's hard to believe that a shopper cannot find single department store.

title: Bomb in Beirut Market Kills 3
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25A bomb explosion in the center of town here today killed three people and wounded 12. The police department said the condition of some of the wounded was critical.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN MUCH of the poetry of the last two decades, there has been a struggle between what Freudians would call the oral and the anal, between a hoarding of references and a spewing of confidences. The hoarding arose partly out of a conviction that poetry implied compression, that a poem should be dense with significance. Also, it was a matter of dignity: One does not expose one's secret parts without some preliminary ceremony. There was reticence to overcome, evident not only in the convo. luted imagery, but in the clotted rhythms as well.

title: New Face: Jackie Earle Haley
description: I just act. Long pause. You have to kind of prepare yourself  mentally  A kind of breathy groan issues from the telephone. It turns out to be a yawn. No one can put into words how they think. Another pause. You do the person.

title: U.S. Pays Tax to New York
description: Mayor Beame accepted a $2 million check from the Federal Government yesterday as prepayment of real estate taxes on the addition to the Federal Building at Broadway, between Duane and Worth Streets. The prepayment for taxes due Oct. 1 and April 1978, is the fourth in series that will continue for another years.

title: Primary Roundup
description: Taking aim at a favorite target of mayoral candidates, Bella S. Abzug called yesterday for abolition or reduction of three New York City nuisance taxes and a test plan to reduce parking fines to a maximum of $15 a ticket.

title: Major League Box Scores
BAN ON OIL LEASE SALE OFF EAST COAST ENDED; 77 DRILLING IS POSSIBLE
description: The Government won approval yesterday for the first sale of oil leases in the Atlantic Ocean when a Federal appeals court lifted a ban imposed by a Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Restricts Hearing Aid Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration put into effect today new restrictions on hearingaid sales that will make buying the devices somewhat like buying drugs with a doctor's prescription.

title: People and Business
description: J. Donald Rauth, 59 years old, president and chief executive officer of the Martin Marietta Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chairman of the board. He succeeds George M. Bunker, who has resigned for personal convenience a few months short of the company's mandatory retirement age of 70 for directors. Mr. Rauth also will become chairman of Martin Marietta Aluminum Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabela TISCTIFIES IN KOREANINFLUENCE CASE: Suzi Park Thomson, accompanied by her niece, Carol Huh, arriving for five hours of questioning behind closed doors before House ethics committee in Washington. Page A9.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Suzy Park Thomson, who was threatened yesterday with a contempt of Congress citation for refusing to testify in the investigation of Korean influence buying, was questioned at a fivehour closed session today by members of the House ethics committee.

title: Columbia Sets Up Special Patrols After Four Suspicious Dorm Fires
description: Special security patrols were set up at Columbia University yesterday following four dormitory fires that firemen called suspicious.

title: Variety Tops Field At Dutchess Fair
description: All that you would expectand a lot that you might notis happening in Rhinebeck, N.Y., this weekend, as Dutchess County kicks up its heels with its 132d annual fair.

title: INQUIRY ON BRITISH STRIKE LARGELY FAVORS WORKERS
description: LONDON, Aug. 25A Governmentappointed inquiry into a strike at a London filmprocessing plant that was the scene of extreme picketline violence in June recommended today that the strikers get their fobs back or be compensated.

title: Dow Chemical Is Trying to Recall Supplies of a Suspected Pesticide.
description: MIDLAND. Mich., Aug. 25 (AP)The Dow Chemical Company announced today that it was trying to recall all stocks of a potent pesticide suspected of causing sterility in the company's employees and cancer in animals.

title: United Press International UNDER ARREST: Bansi Lal, Defense Minister of India in the Government Indica Gandhi, being led away by soldiers in Bhiwani on Tuesday. He was charged with misappropriating $60,000 in Congress Party funds.
Open Interest
description: Thursday, Aug. 25,1977

title: DR. CHARLES M. GRATZ, A RETIRED ORTHOPEDIST
description: Dr. Charles Murray Gratz, a retired orthopedic surgeon and a member of the staff of one of the earliest flying clinics, died Wednesday at the Northport (L.I.) Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Port Washington. L.I.

title: Not Just for Sleeping
description: No one ever said that fashion was, or should be, logical. So it's not at all surprising that the newest dance dresses are neither new nor dresses.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: G. M. Chairman Sees Vehicle Sales Record
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that combined car and truck sales in the United States would reach a record of 15.5 million units during the 1978 model year, which will begin at the end of next month.

title: Apples Beat Racquets in Series Start
description: Chris Evert's efforts notwithstanding, the New York Apples defeated the Phoenix Racquets last night, 2722, in the opener of the World Team Tennis championship series.

title: Federal Agents Are Sent to West Virginia Coalfields After Shooting, Governor Says
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 25Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th said tonight that the Justice Department had sent agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to the West Virginia coalfields to help prevent further outbreaks of violence between miners who want to end their nineweek wildcat strike and those who do not.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: DEAR DIARIES

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 9 P.M. (13) Shades of Greene. Denholm Elliott portrays a man who returns to England after years of traveling overseas, only to discover that he has terminal cancer, in a onehour adaptation of Graham Greene's Under the Garden.

title: Briton: Jolly Good
description: It was almost to good to be true. A match made in heavenDr. Renee Richards versus Virginia Wade in the first round of the United States Open tennis championships.

title: United Press International ON TO THE WORLD SERIES: Members of the El Cajon, Calif., Little League team cheering their 63 victory over Rotterdam, N.Y., in semifinal game Williamsport, Pa., yesterday. The Californians will face the team from Taiwanwhich defeated Venezuela, 92, yesterdayon Saturday in the 31st Little League World Series finals.
U,S. Alleges Discrimination by Masonry Contractor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25(AP)A major Philadelphia construction company with a branch in Marshfield, Mass., has been barred from doing business with the Federal Government because of alleged employment discrimination against minorities, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Australia Lifts Ban on Uranium Mining and Exports
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug 25 (Reuters)Australia today lifted a fouryearold ban on the mining and export of its vast reserves of uranium, the first step toward eventually becoming a leading world supplier of nuclear fuel.

title: British AirControl Aides Strike; International Travel Is Snagged
description: LONDON, Friday, Aug. 26Airtraffic control assistants struck British airports just before midnight last night, making nearchaos a certainty for at least four days in the peak summer tourist season.

title: Saratoga Racing
description: RESULTS

title: FRANCE SEEMS TO SOFTEN POSITION ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: PARIS. Aug. 25 (AP)Apparently seeking to mend fences with South Africa, France took note today of Prime Minister John Vorster's assurance that his Government had no intention of building an atomic bomb.

title: Yankees Subdue Twins, 6 to 4, As Rivers Again Leads Attack
description: With their hottest hitters providing the heat once more, the Yankees won another game last night. Ho hum. Just as intrasquad squabbles had been routine for the first four months of the season, winning games has become routine this month.

title: 46% in Survey Rank Beame Above Lindsay
description: Fortysix percent of those interviewed in The New York Times/Channel 2 poll said they thought Mayor Beanie was a better Mayor than John V. Lindsay.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor.

title: Con Ed's PreBlackout Calls Punctuated by Worries
description: You've got to shed load immediately or you're going to go right down the pipe with everything, the dispatcher in the New York Power Fool control center shouted to the man running the Consolidated Edison Company's power control center, as systems strained shortly before the city was plunged into blackness on July 13.

title: Brock Steals Two Bases
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP)  The Cardinals Lou Brock stole two bases tonight, drawing within one steal of Ty Cobb's major league career record of 892, as St. Louis bowed to the San Francisco Giants at Busch Memorial Stadium, 42.

title: Reds
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 25  Sparky Anderson inspected the gnawing topic in baseball tonightthat his Cincinnati Reds might not take their third straight world title after alland said:

title: Rosalynn Carter Says Mentally III Must Be Given Priority Treatment
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 25 (AP)Rosalynn Carter told an international meeting of mental health experts today that their first priority should be teaching society not to fear the mentally ill.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 26, 1977

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Tenneco Inc. announced that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Philadelphia Life Insurance Company for the equivalent of about $170.6 million. Tenneco, based in Houston, now holds about 24 percent of Philadelphia Life. which has about 10 million shares of capital stock outstanding.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Dividends
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 25. 1977

title: Sverige Overtaken
description: NEWPORT, R. L, Aug. 25For more than an hour and a half today, yellowdecked Sverige looked like solid gold in the opening race of the America's Cup challenger final.

title: San Francisco Police Will Hire Homosexuals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Police Commission approved last night a new equal opportunity hiring plan that includes recruitment of homosexuals.

title: Paradox Found In Mine Dispute
description: In President Carter's early weeks in the White House, his Administration's greatest labormanagement concern was that internal chaos in the miners union would upset plans for a massive expansion in the use of coal to meet national energy needs.

title: 13 Imprisoned At Rest Home; Owner Sought
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 23Federal and state authorities in Texas and California pressed their search today for a woman who operated a rest home near Houston in which more than a dozen former mental patients and disabled war veterans were found to be living as virtual prisoners in squalid conditions.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry Is Said to Criticize Beame and Others
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Securities and Exchange Commission will assail Mayor Hearne and other New York City officials tomorrow on the ground that they knowingly failed to inform investors of the city's perilous financial condition when the city sold a record amount of shortterm securities in 197475, administration officials predicted tonight.

title: CARTER ORDERS STEPS TO INCREASE ABILITY TO MEET WAR THREATS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25After months of preparation and study, President Carter has issued a secret directive on national strategy that commits the United States to modest increases in defense spending, seeks to improve the combat ability of American forces in Europe to absorb an initial shock and calls for light, mobile and flexible forces to meet threats in such areas as the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and East Asia.

title: Dayton, Fearing Chilly Replay, Is Preparing Early for Winter
description: DAYTON. Ohio, Aug. 25Swimming suits may still he in season, but many people here are already preparing for the winter.

title: Bohen Wins Met Open For 2d Year
description: JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 25  Marty Bohen a 6foot4inch assistant pro at the Leewood Golf Club in Eastchester. N.Y., joined some famous company today when he became the first man in 39 years to win the Metropolitan Golf Association open championship two years in a row.

title: U.S. Women Gain World Rowing Final
description: AMSTERDAM, Aug, 25The United States had mixed results today in the semifinals of the women's and lightweight men's races at the world rowing championships.

title: Carrell vs. Waganheirn
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25Wanted Punter. Must be able to do light office work.

title: At the Movies
description: I AM an Innocent victim of circumstance and someone is trying to kill me. But don't know who. Is it the albino? Or the dwarf? Or the scarfaced man? Or the sex pervert? Goldie Hawn, the LaughIn cutup who blossomed into a movie queen, giggled with delight at the dilemma she'll face in Foul Play, a flaky thriller set for filming in October under the direction of Colin Higgins, who also wrote the screenplay. It is Miss Hawn's first production since the birth of Oliver a wonder boy if ever there was one.

title: INCREASED FED RATE ON LOANS EXPECTED
description: Commercial banks substantially increased their borrowing from the Federal Reserve during the week ended Wednesday, heightening speculation that the central bank would raise the discount rate this afternoon.

title: Computer Show's Message: Be the First on Your Block
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25The computer revolution seems endless. Every six months, a new product comes along that outdates everything before it. The latest is the microcomputer, based on the same technology as the pocket calculator but capable of putting a powerful computer into homes and small businesses.

title: Restaurants
description: IF ONE WERE MAKING A LIST of New York's formal, plush haute cuisine restaurants, Le Cirque, in the Mayfair Hotel on 65th Street near the corner of Park Avenue, would certainly be cmong them, even though a few North Italian pasta and veal dishes are offered, in deference to Sirio Maccioni, one of the partners, who is Italian. The other partner and chef, Jean Vergnes, is French, and it is his influence that is most conspicuous on the menu.

title: Books: Birdwatchers
description: IT IS PROBABLY an indication of the popularity of birdwatching that yet another field guide has been added to the several already commonly in use for the Eastern region of the United States. But a new guide presumably must have something to offer that the others don't, and in the case of The Audubon Society Field Guide to North American Birds the big new element is color photographs of every bird cited in the text, rather than the diagrammatic paintings and drawings in the other guides.

title: WheatCutback Decision Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25, (Reuters)President Carter today came under increasing pressure to make a decision on possible wheatproduction cutbacks next year, while Administration officials remained sharply divided on the issue.

title: Early Suffragette Exhorts Feminists to Fight Harder
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)Hazel Nunkins Hallinan, who once chained herself to the White House fence to dramatize the fight for women's suffrage, says she doesn't understand why women don't make more noise for the eaual rights amendment

title: The New York Times/D. Gorton Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, at Young Americans for Freedom convention
Ethiopia Concedes It Is Losing Ground On Two War Fronts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 25 (UPI)Ethiopia has conceded that it is losing ground in the fighting in Eritrea and Ogaden and is in a race against time to reverse the situation.

title: Jacob M. Arvey, Democratic Boss Of Chicago in 1940's, Dead at 81
description: Col. Jacob M. Arvey, the Democratic toss of Chicago in the late 1940's who started the political careers of Paul H. Douglas and Adlai E. Stevenson Jr. and I was instrumental in Harry S. Truman's narrow Presidential victory in 1948, died I of heart failure yesterday in Weiss Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 81 years old.

title: CARTER ORDERS STEPS TO MEET WAR THREATS
Deaths
Horse Shows
description: NASSAU COUNTY SHOW

title: Chapin Says A.M.C. Will End 77 in Black
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., Aug, 25Roy D. Chapin Jr., chairman of the American Motors Corporation, said today that the company would break even or show a small profit when its fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, ending two straight years of losses for the nation's smallest automaker.

title: Art: Oils by George Grosz
description: ONE OF THE most hurtful things ever said to an artist of real stature by a dealer was said to George Grosz by Alfred Flechtheim at a time when Flechtheim's word was law in Berlin and Grosz wanted above all things to be accepted as a painter. The trouble with you, Grosz. said Flechtheim, is that you can draw a bit, but you just aren't a painter at all.

title: Oktoberfest in Queens at Victory Field
description: There will be an Oktoberfest in Queens this weekend, with oompah bands, rides and games, craft exhibitions and international foods. Sponsored by the Greater Ridgewood Historical Society, the fair will be held in Victory Field, at Woodhaven Boulevard and Myrtle Avenue in Woodhaven.

title: END OF DRILLING BAN WON'T ENRICH REGION QUICKLY, OILMEN SAY
