description: The oil industry was elated by the surprise court decision yesterday to lift the injunction on Atlantic offshore drilling, but the ruling will not mean a sudden influx of oil dollars to the Northeast, industry sources said.

title: Flushing Airport Opens Briefly Before the City Closes It Again
description: Defying a directive from Mayor Beame, the management of Flushing Airport in Queens reopened for business yesterday morning, but three hours later the Mayor sent a team of police officers and city officials to shut down the 52yearold facility permanently.

title: Abandoning the Moon
description: NASA administrators announced the other day that they plan shortly to halt the monitoring here on earth of the remaining Project Apollo instruments operating on the moon. The motive is budgetary, though the amount of money that will be saveda few hundred thousand dollarsis minuscule in NASA's multibilliondollar budget. We believe the decision is unfortunate.

title: Strike Over Union Shop Raising Issue of British Press Freedom
description: DARLINGTON, EnglandA newspaper strike in this quiet city of 80,000 in northeastern England has raised serious questions about freedom of the press in Britain and contributed to passionate arguments over whether tradeunion militancy is endangering British liberties.

title: E.R.A. Walkathon Tomorrow
description: A march, a rally and a walkathon will be held in New York City tomorrow to focus attention on a national campaign to ratify the equal rights amendment and to commemorate the victory of women's suffrage 57 years ago today.

title: James R. Caldwell, A Retired Executive Of Rubbermaid, Inc.
description: WOOSTER, Ohio, Aug. 25 (UPI)James R. Caldwell, who developed the first Rubbermaid housewares in the 1930's, died yesterday at Boca Raton Community Hospital, Boca Raton, Fla., following long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Futures of Soybeans Decline 7c a Bushel; Corn and W heat Up
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)Soybean futures prices fell as much as 7 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today after being firmly higher for most of the session.

title: Young Opposes Force by Africans
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 25 (UPI)Amdrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, today rejected armed struggle as a means to end South Africa's racial segregation policies saying: It is not necessary to kill the patient to cure the disease.

title: LOUIS L. FELDMAN, PIONEER IN PREPAID MEDICAL PLANS
description: Louis L. Feldman, an executive in the public health field for the last 48 years and a pioneer in the development of prepaid medical programs, died yesterday in his home at 2500 Johnson Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 66 years old.

title: Some Movies Born to Be Revived
description: Even the most cursory glance at this weekend's film schedule is enough to prove that American revivalhouse movies have recently changed. In the 1960's and early 70's. when theaters featuring American revivals especially flourished, the fare was homogeneous in certain ways. These days, though, revival movies aren't necessarily lively, nostalgic or classically entertaining. They aren't even necessarily old.

title: For Some New Reasons, Many. Old Marrieds
description: LOS ANGELESAn increasing number of couples who have been married for 20 or more years are getting divorced these days.

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Topics
description: DIVINE LIGHT  Consolidated Edison has come full circle on theology. It was just 42 days ago that the company attributed to an act of God, the lightning that disabled huge power lines and caused the New York City blackout. Now Con Ed concedes the blackout had a good deal more to do with an act of manthe July 13 failure of its system controller to cut off power to some areas and thus keep the whole system from collapsing. Con Ed, saying it is not interested in doing any fingerpointing, declines to identify the controller. In short, to err human, to forgive divine.

title: RHODESIA UNLIKELY TO ACCEPT PROPOSAL
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 25Authoritative sources said today that there was no prospect whatever that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Government would accept a BritishAmerican proposal providing for a United Nations peacekeeping force to maintain order during a transition to black majority rule.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 26, 1977

title: Out of Doors
description: YOU CAN SPEND thousands of dollars to rent a house for weekend retreats on Fire Island, or you can enjoy the same beautiful surf and sand freeif you have a tent.

title: Women Marking Equality Day With Assessment of Their Voting Impact
description: TRENTON, Aug. 25At tomorrow's celebration of Women's Equality Day, day that honors women's suffrage, women of both parties and uncommitted women voters will be taking a hard look at what their votes will mean in the forthcoming elections.

title: Hnueilings
description: SPIERERThe unveiling of a monument in memory at Frieda Splerer will take place on Sunday, August 28th. 1977 at 11 A.M., at Monlollore Cemetery, Sprinolleid, I.. I. Society is Progressive Horodenker, Block 15. Anounced by her bereaved husband, Leon Splerer.

title: Connors Extended
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.. Aug. 25 (AP)Jimmy Connors narrowly escaped defeat today in the $125,000 United States Pro tennis championships, beating young John McEnroe, 57, 6.2, 75, in the second round.

title: Tiny Carp Is Big Fish In a Youth Tourney
description: Kirk Boykin, a 12yearold Manhattan boy, pulled a 13ounce carp out of the Lake in Central Park yesterday to win top prize in the New York City Housing Authority's annual fishing contest.

title: Vernon
description: ATLANTAPoor Vernon Jordan. He had the nerve to criticize President Carter's domestic policy, and now has been called everything from a power grabber and an ungrateful wretch to a disgruntled office seeker.

title: Nadjari Indictment of Judge Is Dismissed
description: A 12count indictment brought against Judge Adolph C. Orlando of the Bronx Court of Claims by Maurice N. Nadjari, the former special prosecutor, was dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Of 11 indictments brought against judges by Mr. Nadjari, all 11 ended without a conviction.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Registered nurses at Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn have overwhelmingly accepted their first union contract, ending a twoday strike at the hospital. The nurses voted 286 to 35 to accept the 14month agreement, which grants a 5 percent acrosstheboard wage raise.

title: Pop Music: Country Faithful
description: THE COUNTRYMUSIC concert held Wednesday evening in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center must have been one or the wettest outdoor events of the season. It was broadcast live on WHN, New York's fulltime country radio station, and one suspects that most of the people who heard it were warm and dry. But in the park, a tenacious crowd huddled under unbrellas through the entire evening. Manhattan's countrymusic audience may not be very large, but on the basis of Wednesday's showing it is dedicated.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: A Family Plays in Brooklyn
description: From prison to Broadway to Europe and now on the Brooklyn waterfront. This Is not a riseandfall narrative, but a scanty account of the fiveyear journey of the Family, an urban repertory theater company.

title: Ledger Mentioning Names Lansky and Vesco
description: MIAMI, Aug. 25More than a dozen Federal, state and local law enforcement officials with jurisdiction in southern Florida met in Fort Lauderdale today with Rhode Island police officials investigating a recent seizure of about six tons of marijuana in Rhode Island. Notebooks seized with the marijuana contained the names Vesco and Lansky,  presumably referring to Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld figure who lives in Miami Beach, and Robert A. Vesco, the fugitive financier who is in Costa Rica.

title: The New Diplomacy
description: OTIS AIR FORCE BASE, Aug. 25Diplomacy, which appears in Stevenson's Book of Quotations between Dining and Disappointment, is changing fast these days. Increasingly it deals, not with manners or abstractions, but with serious economic disputes between nations over, among other things the future control of the resources of the oceans.

title: 18 Jurors and Alternates Seated In Bolles Murder Trial in Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Aug. 25 (AP)Seven women and 11 men have been selected to serve as jurors and alternates in the trial of two men charged wih the carbomb death of Don Bolles, a newspaper reporter, in June 1976.

title: The Poll:
description: Mayor Beame

title: Rare Company At the Jean Cocteau
description: While preparing for his role as Davies, the destitute parasite in Harold Pinter's The Caretaker, the actor Craig Smith found he could study for the part at close hand simply by walking around the Bouwerie Lane Theater's East Village neighborhood.

title: Squabbles in Paris Mar a Celebration
description: PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP)Parisians celebrated the 33d anniversary of their liberation from German occupation today, but much of the festivity was clouded by leftright squabbles over who should get the glory.

title: Stocks Decline on Bearish News, With Dow Falling 8.75 to 854.12
description: Bearish economic news sent the stock market down sharply yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

title: Loeb Is Again Taking Reins Of Investment Banking Firm
description: John L. Loeb, who at 74 years of age is one of the titans of Wall Street, is again taking charge at Loeb Rhoades & Company, the investment banking house he helped found nearly half century ago.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON. Aug. 25A brief sickout by nurses and other union members that began last midnight at Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital appeared to have ended late today after a day of negotiations over work schedules and staffing arrangements.

title: Publishing: Inside Idi Aminland
description: THERE ARE books that are written at great personal risk. An author or his family and friends can be threatened if spoken words are committed to writing. A State of Blood by Henry Kyemba, to be published in the United States early next month, is such a book.

title: Awarding of Gold Shield to Police Without Detective Duties Scored
description: A program established to recognize and reward oustanding New York City police officers by giving them detectives gold shieldsand higher payeven though they are not assigned to work as detectives, is generating new controversy within the Police Department.

title: They Only Serve, but Hard
description: It started with twoplatoon football, that sternly segregated pastime where offensive players ride in the front of the bus, and defensive players in the back, and never the twain. From there it was a short step to the Garo Yepremians who kick field goals and extra points and do nothing else, the punters who only punt for a living, the specialists who run back punts and kickoffs and the specialists who try to tackle them. Then the American League adopted the abomination called the designated hitter. For

title: J. Edgar
description: Alan F. Westin: From these papers, can we pinpoint when the F.B.I. first started compiling dossiers on A.C.L.U. leaders and activities?

title: Museums Just Waiting To Be Discovered
description: SOMEWHAT CONTRARILY, New York, a city credited with rarely looking back, is along with its environs, one of the greatest collection terminals of the world. Although its major museums are famous in all civilized centers of the globe, it has scores of others that are less well knowneven to the people who live herebut are well worth a weekend visit.

title: Warming Up to the Islands in the Sun
description: Andrew Young's whirlwind visit to 10 Caribbean countries in just 12 days before his departure for Africa last weekend demonstrates both a personal commitment and a welcome shift in American policy. The personal commitment was to many of the leaders of the countries he visitedleaders of poor developing countries who (excepting JeanClaude Duvalier in Haiti, with whom Mr. Young expressed his disagreement) have held fairly firmly to democratic roads and who have respected the rights of their citizens. The shift in American policy is a recognition of special responsibilities in the Caribbean region.

title: Bridge:
description: Littleknown players carried off the honors in the first day of play at the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships at McAfee, N.J., Wednesday.

title: Rain Aids Firefighters Battling Huge Blaze in Northern California
description: EUREKA, Calif., Aug. 25 (UPI)An offseason downpour today came to the aid of 5,000 firefighters baffling a huge forest fire in Northern California, and officials said it could bring a quick end to a conflagration that has blackened more than 50,000 acres in tie last two weeks.

title: Goodman Impugns Farber Ethics, Citing Sex and Pornography Views
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday assailed Barry Farber's judgment and integrity, charging that his opponent in the Republican primary for Mayor was the originator and producer of sex show who was now taking a strong stand against pornography.

title: Enterprise Fails
description: NEWPORT, R. L, Aug. 25Malin Burnham, appointed this week to save the Enterprise, could not halt today Ted Turner's inexorable drive toward selection of the Turner ship, Courageous, as defender of the America's Cup. The two American 12Meter yachts, Courageous and Enterprise, clashed today for the 18th and 19th times this summer, for the fourth and fifth times in the current final selection trials, and Courageous won both races.

title: Commodity Price Index Climbed To 201.2 From 200.2 Last Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 201.2 from 200.2 last week.

title: Chinese Mission to Seek U.S. Technology
description: Whatever the outcome of this week's delicate diplomatic maneuvers in Peking with Secretary of State Cyrus Vance, China is eager to acquire at least one American dimensiontechnology.

title: ALASKA WILL GUARANTEE LOAN FOR GAS PIPELINE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)  The State of Alaska is willing to guarantee up to $900 million in loans for construction and materials for the El Paso Alaska Company's proposed natural gas pipeline, it was learned today. The pipeline is one of two alternatives under consideration for bringing Alaska North Slope natural gas to American consumers.

title: CARTER ORDERS STEPS TO INCREASE ABILITY TO MEET WAR THREATS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25After months of preparation and study, President Carter has issued a secret directive on national strategy that commits the United States to modest increases in defense spending, seeks to improve the combat ability of American forces in Europe to absorb an initial shock and calls for light, mobile and flexible forces to meet threats in such areas as the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and East Asia.

title: INTERNS FOR US. JOBS APPROVED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 25  President Carter today signed an executive order creating a Presidential Management Internship Program of twoear Federal internships for graduates of public management schools.

title: Analysts Expect Prices toRemain Stable
description: Uranium market analysts reacted calmly to Australia's announcement that it would lift a fouryear ban on the mining and export of its uranium reserves. They forecast that prices of uranium oxide would remain relatively stable and that the Government's policy contained enough safeguards to prevent undesirable proliferation.

title: Berkshire Festival Ending 49th Stage Season
description: The Berkshire Theater Festival in Stockbridge, Mass., winds up its 49th season this weekend. In the Berkshire Playhouse, Come Back, Little Sheba will be performed tonight at 8:30 P.M., tomorrow at 5 and 9 P.M., and Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets are $7.50 and $8.95.

title: Killanin Going to China
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 25 (UPI)The international Olympic Committee said today that Lord Killanin, the group's president, would visit China during the week of Sept. 12. Lord Killanin is to conic]. with Chinese officials on whether Peking would be willing to become a member. China has repeatedly told the I.O.C. it would become a member only if the committee would expel Taiwan.

title: Race Among HighPerforming Oils Is Heating Up as the Field Widens
description: Suddenly the motor oil business is bubbling with activity. The Exxon Corporation this week announced a new motor oil that, the company asserts, will in crease gasoline mileage by an averageI of 4.5 percent. In July, the Atlantic Richfield Company introduced a premium oil that promises similar gains, as well as less engine wear. And, last year, the Mobil Corporation came out with a motor oil that also raises gasoline mileage.

title: Survey Shows New Yorkers Link Lootings to Thievery, Not Protest
description: New Yorkers strongly condeinned the looting during last month's blackout as common thievery, rather than a protest against ghetto living conditions, in a New York Times/Channel 2 News survey of the mayoral primary race.

title: NOMINEE TO F.B.I. JOB UNDERGOES SURGERY
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 26Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., the directordesignate of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, underwent surgery here today to correct a weakened and ballooning wall in his main abdominal artery.

title: Beame Assails Vicious Document; Reactions of Primary Rivals Vary
description: Mayor Beanie lashed out yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's report as a shameless, vicious political document and a hatchet job, while his opponents in the Democratic mayoral primary took viewz ranging from condemnatory to sympathetic.

title: Economic Research Group Calls on Britain For the Adoption of a Policy of Reflation
description: LONDON. Aug. 26 (Reuters)An independent economic research group today called on the British Government to adopt a policy of reflation as a means of reducing unemployment and said it should repay its suge loan from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Flight Cancellations Ease Impact Of Strike by British Control Aides
description: LONDON, Aug. 26A strike by air traffic control assistants played havoc with tray plans throughout Britain today but numerous flight cancellations helped prevent congestion at airports.

title: Horse Shows
description: AT WESTBURY U.

title: Not Quite a Requiem
description: ALTOONA, Pa.Johnstown, Pa., was the only city I could see, smell and touch at the age of six.

title: Israelis Are Reported Satisfied By Palestinian HardLine Position
description: TE AVIV, Aug. 2G (Reuters)An apparent hard line on peace with Israel adonted by Palestian leaders meeting in Damascus today was viewed with tacit official satisfaction here.

title: BERKOWITZ SLATED FOR A COURT HEARING
description: Justice Leonard E. Yoswein of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn reversed himself yesterday and ordered that David R. Berkowitz, the accused 44caliber killer, be present in court on Tuesday, when the results of his psychiatric examination will be formally disclosed.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: Incoming

title: Personal Investing On Future of Small Growth Companies
description: Are the earnings of small growth companies likely to do better than those of bigger, better established cornpahies if the economy begins to show signs of fatigue in the months ahead?

title: Mets
Four Marx Movies On WNEWTV
description: In a tribute to Groucho Marx, who died last week, WNEWTV, Channel 5, will preempt most of its afternoon and evening schedule tomorrow to telecast, in their entirety, four feature films starring the Marx Brothers.

title: LOFTUS EUGENE BECKER, FORMER C.I.A. AIDE, 66
description: Loftus Eugene Becker, a former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency and legal adviser to the Department of State, died yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: For Many, TV Tape Means Watching More and Loving It
description: Last week, like thousands of other New Yorkers, an advertising executive and a woman companion saw the hit movie Star Wars. Unlike other New Yorkers, however, they did not watch the film in a crowded theater, but in the comfort of his apartment.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Aug. 26, 1977

title: Bridge:
description: Experts from the metropolitan area collected both major titles in the second day of play at the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships at the Playboy Resort and Country Club McAfee. NJ., Thursday.

title: Burger and Wife to Viiit Russia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and his wife will visit the Soviet Union at the invitation of the Soviet Government, the Supreme Court announced today. A Court spokesman said that Chief Justice and Mrs. Burger would be in the Soviet Union about a week and a half, returning to the United States in the second week of September. The Burgers will stay at the residence of the United States counselgeneral in Leningrad and at the United States Embassy in Moscow, the spokessaid.

title: Italy Is Pressing West Germany To Confine Escaped War Criminal
description: ROME, Aug. 26The Italian Government today appealed publicly to West Germany to take measures against Lieut Col. Herbert Kappler, the Nazi war criminal who escaped from a Rome military hospital last week, that would express condemnation of a past that cannot be, forgotten.

title: Women's Equality Day Proclaimed
description: Mayor Beame declared yesterday Women's Equality Day in New York. He told members of the National Organization for Women that he had sent telegrams to many of his colleagues in the United State Conference of Mayors, representing4 the major cities in the 15 states that have not yet ratified the proposed equal rights amendment, to marshal support for its passage.

title: LUCE AGREES TO MEET WITH BLACKOUT PANEL
description: Charles F. Luce, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company, has reversed his field and has decided to appear voluntarily at next week's hearings by a special New York City commission looking into the blackout of July 1314.

title: Vietnamese Admit That They Made Mistakes
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 26 (UPI)The Central Committee of Vietnam's Communist Party, facing serious nationwide food shortages and admitting big mistakes in leadership, has begun a program to speed up agricultural development.

title: Langella in Title Role Of Dracula
description: Frank Langella, who was last on Broadway in Edward Albee's Seascape, will return in the title role of Dracula, the John BalderstonHamilton Dean dramatization of Bram Stoker's vampire story. When first produced on Broadway in 1927, Dracula starred Bela Lugosi, who went on to make a classic film version in 1931.

title: Baby Survives 8Story Fall
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 26 (AP) A 28monthold boy narrowly escaped death this morning after plunging eight stories from an apartment house here, the police said. The youngster, Stefano Zanetti, landed gently on the ground after his fall apparently was cushioned by tree branches.

title: UNDERWRITERS CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The Securities and Exchange Commission's staff report that today charged New York City's underwriters with misleading the investing public, said some of them were reducing or eliminating their own holdings of the city's securities at the same time they were urging small investors to purchase the city's. debt.

title: Naughton and Son to Renew Rivalry in 2 States Today
description: The Indianapolis Fairgrounds and Yonkers Raceway are 732 miles apart, but Billy Haughton, his son Peter and Joe O'Brien will be at both harness racing sites today, hunting for prestige and money.

title: Yanks Beat Rangers, 65, and Lead by 3
description: Mickey Rivers and Graig Nettles, left handed hitters both, drove in the tying and winning runs in the eighth inning last night against Rogelio Moret, a lefthanded pitcher, as the Yankees continued to murder the myth that says they have trouble beating lefthanders.

title: NEW PREMIER IN BERMUDA PICKED BY MAJORITY PARTY
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 26 (UPI)J. David Gibbons was elected leader of the United Bermuda Party today, automatically making him the new Prime Minister of Bermuda.

title: Britain Is Shaken by FV Film of Woman Urging. Suicide on Her Mother
description: LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP)A British televison documentary in which a hidden police camera recorded a woman urging her aged mother to commit suicide has touched off a widespread row over the right to privacy and ethics in television and criminal justice.

title: Georgia Judge Quits Blacks
description: DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 26The presiding judge in the case of five black youths charged with the murder of a white man withdrew from the case today, citing ill health.

title: Fire Hits U.S. Moscow Embassy, Forcing Evacuation
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 27A fire swept through the top floors of the American Embassy here last night, forcing evacuation of the ninestory building and causing what appeared to be extensive damage to the chancery offices.

title: Most Banks Deny Charges
description: Most of the major banks accused of unloading their own New York City securities while continuing to sell the city's notes to the public denied the charges yesterday, although several had no comment.

title: Bald Eagle Found at Lake Ontario Died of Pesticides, Autopsy Finds
description: ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP)An American bald eagle found last month on the shore of Lake Ontario died of a virtual potpourii of pesticides, according to a preliminary autopsy.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY'PROCEEDINGS

title: Cape Town Dealer Held in Gem Theft
description: CAPE TOWN. Aug. 26 (UPI)  A diamond dealer who suffered acid burns in the face and told the police last week that he had been robbed of $3.5 million wort hof diamonds, has been arrested as a suspect in the their, the police said today.

title: Children of Mother Killed by
description: Three children of a woman killed by elfstyled Bishop DeVernon LeGrand were removed yesterday by the police from his former Brooklyn church and put into the custody of their maternal grandmother, police officials reported.

title: Sounders
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 26Coach Eddie Firmani of the Cosmos was a preoccupied man today, just a few hours after it had been determined that the Seattle Sounders would be his team's opponents in Sunday's North American Soccer League championship game.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (UPI)Lillian Gobert, wanted in Texas on charges of imprisoning mentally deficient and disabled persons in a rest home and cashing their pension checks, was arrested today by sheriff's deputies.

title: Powell Confirms Lance's Double Use of Collateral
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26A White House spokesman today confirmed a disclosure that Budget Director Bert Lance used a single block of bank shares as collateral for two separate loans from two different banks at the same time. The spokesman called the action an innocent mistake.

title: Allegations Over Valuable Foreign Gifts Irk Nixon, Aides Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon was described today as angry and his vire, Pat, as deeply hurt by implications that they intentionally kept some valuable foreign gifts that belong to the Government.

title: Mets Lose, 53, as Rain Halts Game in 7th
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 26A heavy rainstorm ended the BravesMets game tonight after six and a half innings and a delay of 1 hour 24 minutes, with Atlanta winning the battle of the cellar dwellers. 53.

title: Monmouth
description: RESULTS

title: PROGRAMS TO FIGHT CRIMEAGAINST ELDERLY BEGUN
description: The start of two federally financed programs to combat crime against the elderly was announced yesterday by Mayor Beame. Each program was given a $250,000 grant, the Senior Citizens Anticrime Network for two years and Senior Citizens Crime Assistance and Prevention Program for one year.

title: P.L.O. Leadership Rules Out a Dialogue With the Carter Administration
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 26The Palestine Liberation Organization today closed the door on a possible dialogue with the Carter Administration, issuing in the name of its Central Council a hardline, statement that attacked American and Zionist maneuvers.

title: Controlling Custodial Nepotism
description: The Board of Education has taken a long overdue first step against the flagrant nepotism that plagues the school system. It has issued welcome new regulations to govern the hiring and supervision of relatives on the board's payroll and to create a special committee on conflicts of interest. It is by now well established that many custodians have enriched themselves by placing wives, children, nephews and cousins on the payroll. But they have not been alone in this lucrative game of All in the Family. Local community boards and the headquarters bureaucracy have also mastered the rules. They, too, are to be scrutinized under Chancellor Anker's new regulations.

title: Moslem Mayor, 3 Christians Die In Fighting in Southern Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 26Four reople were killed overnight in renewed fighting in southern Leh, non between Palestinian guerrillas and rightwing militiamen.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 27, 1977

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FACE TO FACE Masked Rituals, an exhibition of 75 masks on loan from various museums and galleries, is today's new show, extending through Nov. 13, in the main gallery of the Queens Museum in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, on the grounds of the old New York World's Fair. Representing tribal groups of Africa and Oceania, the exotic pieces are functional objects used in ritual ceremonies. The mask display also includes photographic enlargements illustrating social and cultural aspects of tribal life, and a slide show.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Witness Tells of Vending Scheme As Goldman's Fraud Trial Opens
description: Testimony began yesterday in the trial of Irving Goldman, a former Cultural Affairs. Commissioner for New York City who was charged with conspiracy and fraud in the sale of candy supplies for vending machines in the city's subways.

title: Man and Machine Match Minds at M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 25 A popular theory holds that we use only ten percent of the brain, and that wonders would follow if we could learn to use the rest.

title: NEW TEAMSTERS'FUND IS UNDER U.S. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)An upstate New York teamsters union fund is under fire for allegedly losing more than $500,000 in investments since 1970.

title: Powell Confirms Lance's Double Use of Collateral
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26A White House spokesman today confirmed a disclosure that Budget Director Bert Lance used a single block of bank shares as collateral for two separate loans from two different banks at the same time. The spokesman called the action an innocent mistake.

title: Television
Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee

title: Stocks, in Late Rally, Forge Ahead 1.30 to 855.42 for a Mixed Closing
description: The stock market made a late recovery yesterday and finished mixed in slower trading.

title: Nudists Arrested in Spain
description: MADRID, Aug. 26 (UPI)Members of the paramilitary Civil Guard have arrested about 50 nudists on the beadles of the island of Ibiza and have turned them over to authorities to be charged with., immorality and creating a public scandal, Spanish news agency reports said today. Authorities also ordered the Civil Guards to mount a permanent guard on those beaches that have attracted nudists, the reports said.

title: Survey Shows New Yorkers Link Lootings to Thievery, Not Protest
description: New Yorkers strongly condemned the looting during last month's blackout as common thievery, rather than a protest against ghetto living conditions, in a New York Times/Channel 2 News survey of the mayoral primary race.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
Excerpts From Report by S.E.C. Staff on Transactions in New York City Securities
description: The last offer of securities by the City of New York to the general puoiic was made in March 1975. Since that time, the public debt market has been closed to the city. On Nov. 15, 1975. the New York State Legislature enacted the Moratorium Act, which suspended the enforcement of the city's shortterm debt, because the city was unable to meet its maturing obligations. Thr_.usands of small investors had purchased a substantial part of the approximately $4 billion of shortterm securities sold during the six months preceding March 31,1975.

title: AIR FORCE IS USING MIG'S IN WAR DRILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)The Air force said today that it obtained and flew foreign military aircraft, and informed sources said that included four to five MIGs.

title: WinnDixie's Net Fell 6.4% in Quarter But Rose 11.7% for the Full Fiscal Year
description: WinnDixie Stores Inc., the nation's fourth largest supermarket chain, yesterday reported a 6.4 percent drop M earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter ended June 25. but an 11.7 percent gain for the full year. The quarterly earnings decline was the first since the fourth quarter a year ago.

title: Surplus in Trading for Canada In July Reported at $328 Million
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Canada had a seasonally adjusted trade surplus of $328 million in July after recording a revised $91 million surplus in June, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: AUSTRALIAN VOTE SOUGHT ON MINING OF URANIUM
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 26 (Reuters) The Australian trade unions leader, Bob Hawke today called for a referendum on the Government's decision to allow resumption of uranium mining after a fouryear ban.

title: Public Service of New Hampshire Wins Approval for Sale of Stock
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 26 (AP) Stockholders of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire have approved the sale of 180,000 new shares of preferred stock to help pay for construction of the Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: Fiscal Crisis And Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission report issued today produced few revelations about New York City's financial practices, but it offered something much more significant. It reached an enormously damaging conclusion about the behavior of both Mayor Beame and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin in the fiscal turmoil of 1974 and 1975, and offered stunning new information about the behavior of the major banks and underwriters as they struggled with city officials to keep New York City solvent.

title: Bridgeport, Conn., Welfare Aide Tries to Mandate English Study
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 26This city's welfare director plans to require ablebodied nonEnglishspeaking welfare recipients to take English classes cr lose their welfare checks, even thcugh the state's Social Services Commissioner has doubts about the project's legality.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA New Jersey pediatrician has found a method of treating a class of infections called herpes virus hominis that afflict many persons, young and old. Dr. S. Harvey Sklar, who Is on the staff of the Englewood Hospital, was granted Patent 4044122 this week for treatment that comprises administering an alkaly metal salt of adenylic acid.

title: Regional Exchanges Approve Tie
description: After months of discussions, four regional stock exchangesthe Boston, Cincinnati, Midwest, and Pacific Coast Stock Exchangeagreed today to establish a common electronic linkup and trading system. The announcement follows by two days an agreement between the New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock. Exchange to link their trading floors electronically.

title: Portuguese Escudo Holds Steady
description: LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The Portuguese escudo held steady at overnight levels as Portuguese banks here opened this morning. The rate was quoted at a middle of 38.70 to the dollar, compared with last night's close of 38.60.

title: Fair Housing Ordinance in Texas Omits Protection of Homosexuals
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 26 (AP)The City Council has passed, by a 4 to 3 vote, a fair housing ordinance that does not prohibit discrimination against homosexuals in renting or selling apartments or houses.

title: Notes on People
description: Vanessa Redgrave, the British actresss who styles herself a Trotskyist, was to have addressed likeminded Spaniards at two meetings in Madrid this weekend, but the police have banned them. Miss Redgrave, in Spain as a guest of the Communist Workers League, met earlier in the week with the chief of the party in Spain, Santiago Carillo, to discuss the background of Ramon Mercader, the Spanish Communist who assassinated Leon Trotsky in Mexico in 1940. The weekend meetings planned by the Workers League, a Trotskyist group, were to have been supported demands that the Government legalize some groups, like the league, that are still banned.

title: From Wells to Orwell
description: VAN, TurkeyThis area of Turkish Kurdistan once had its great moments in history but now it is a nowhere place and therefore eminently suited as a point from which to write about Cambodia.

title: U.S. Leads Britain, 93, In Cup Golf
description: Southampton, L.I., Aug. 26Golf was a wonderland of green beauty and tradition spread over 18 magnificent holes in perfect weather at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club today as the 26th biennial Walker Cup matches opened with unexpectedly onesided success for the United States.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala

title: U.S. Steel Plans A Curtailm'ent In Work Force
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26The United States Steel Corporation announced today an austerity program under which it is not filling jobs caused by retirement and keeping new employment of administrative personnel at an absolute minimum.

title: THEATER DIRECTORY
LEHIGH CEMENT SAYS OFFER MAY BE MADE
description: The Lehigh Portland Cement Company of Allentown, Pa said yesterday that a company, which it declined to identify, is seriously considering recommending to its board that a proposal be made to acquire Lehigh.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
Companies List Earnings Reports
LABOR DEPT. SETS RULES ON JOBS FOR VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)The Labor Department proposed indicators today to measure the compliance of state agencies in giving veterans preference in public service jobs.

title: Hyland Asks Tighter State Controls On Business Permits in Atlantic City
description: TRENTON, Aug. 26William F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, announced recommendations today for tightening state controls over mercantile and alcoholicbeverage licensing in Atlantic City in a further effort to bar undesirable elements attracted by the advent of legalized gambling there.

title: Smith Would Reject Proposal
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. Aug. 26 (ReuPrime Minister Ian D. Smith said today he would reject the latest BritishAmerican peace proposals for Rhodesia if they included his own resignation and the dismantling of Rhodesian security forces.

title: An Imaginary Arrierican Indian Reminds French to Drive Safely
description: PARIS. Aug. 25The trail of an imaginary American Indian called Sly Bison has been laid out for the four million French drivers expected to clog the roads throughout France this weekend.

title: Playing Royally, Kansas City Wins, 32
description: The Kansas City Royals, who won the American League's Western Division title a year ago, are making a run at the top, again, however belatedly.

title: Carter Gives Support as Women March in Capital for the E.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 26  Feminists got a pledge of support today from President Carter and a lesson in endurance from an 87yearold suffragette as she led some 3.000 supporters of the equal rights amendment down Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Golf's Old Man of the Hills Is 96
description: SOUTHAMPTON. L.I., Aug. 26Out on the sunny Shinnecock Hills golf course today, amateur golfers representing the United States and Britain were competing for the Walker Cup, a reminder of a gentler time. But the living link to that era sat in his small brownshingled cottage behind a high hedge above the 18th green. Tell them, said Charley Thom, the burr of Scotland still firm in his voice, that the Old Man of the Hills is still here. The Old Man of the Hills is 96 years old now, the club pro emeritus here. Retired since 1961, he doesn't leave his cottage much anymore. But he had attended the opening ceremony. Wearing a tweed cap and a tweed jacket, it was as if he had stepped out a sepiatoned photo from the turn of the century. He came to the United States in 1899, one of many Scottish pros who were golf's missionaries in those years of the guttapercha ball.

title: Miss Ackerman Betters Mark
description: BERLIN, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Rose marie Ackerman of East Germany seta world record tonight of 6 feet 6 inches in the women's high jump at arr international track meet in West Berlin. Miss Ackerman, the 1976 Olympic champion, bettered her previous world. mark set in the European championships at Helsinki two weeks ago.

title: Events Today
New Jersey Briefs
description: Byrne Again Vetoes Port Authority Actions

title: Dollar Drops to Low Against Swiss Franc
description: The dollar had a generally mixed day against world currencies in foreign exchange markets yesterday, but fell to a low against the Swiss franc in Zurich for the second time in a week, the Associated Press Reported.

title: Personal Investing
description: A Boston mutual fund analyst thinks earnings of small growth companies are likely to do better than those of bigger companies if the economy shows signs of fatigue in the months ahead. Page 29.

title: Spaniel Wins Top Award at Taconic Hills
description: SHRUB OAK, N.Y., Aug. 26Ch. Telltale Author, a liver and white English springer spaniel affectionately known as Lumpy, won his first bestinshow award in a field of 1,056 dogs tonight at the Taconic Hills Kennel Club's allbreed event on the grounds of Lakeland High School.

title: Top Women Aides Tell President Why They Oppose Him on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26We shall abort the issue, said Margaret Costanza, President Carter's assistant for public liaison.

title: Sniper Slays 6 in Jersey And Then Takes Own Life
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N. J.. Aug. 26A sniper with a rifle killed six persons here today, firing Into backyards as he walked along a railroad track, the police said.

title: Letter &
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Fives Gain Finals In Bulgaria
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 26 (AP)The United States men's and women's basketball teams won their semifinals in the World University Games today. The men defeated Czechoslovakia, 8569, and the women rallied to upset Bulgaria, 8784. Both will face the Soviet. Union in the finals tomorrow.

title: People and Business
description: Peter Van Nort, 41 years old and second in command of the Clinch River Breeder Reactor Project at Oak Ridge, Tenn., has resigned to become a senior vice president division and system operations, of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company, of Madison.

title: Voyager Boom Reported in Place
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 6 (AP)A science boom aboard Voyager 2 is pretty much where it ought to be, scientists say. but they are not sure it will stay there. Photographs taken and transmitted by the Jupiterhound spacecraft showed that the troublesome hocm was essentially deployed but may not he locked in place. said a spokesman at Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Voyager 2 never sent back to Earth a signal that the arm had been deployed, so its status had been a mystery almost since last Saturday's launching.

title: UNDERWRITERS CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The Securities and Exchange Commission's staff report that today charged New York City's underwriters with misleading the investing public, said some of them were reducing or eliminating their own holdings of the city's securities at the same time they were urging small investors to purchase the city's debt.

title: Festivities Open 2d Stage of Renovated Boston Market
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26Swordswallowers, clowns, office workers, mimes, families, tourists, area residents, marching bands, street musicians and a local dignitary or two turned out here today to celebrate the opening of the South Market in the Faneuil Hall Marketplace.

title: FRENCHLABORLEADER IS GRANTED U.S. VISA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26In the first case to be acted on since the law on visa applications was recently liberalized, an official of France's General Confederation of Labor, often described as Communistrun, has been granted a visa to attend an American union convention, State Department officials said today.

title: Chief Lifeguard at Wildwood Quits
description: WILDWOOR, Aug. 26 (AP)John Capacio has been a lifeguard here for 34 years. Now, at 51 years of age, he is out of work.

title: Young and Owen in Zambia to See Black Leaders on Rhodesian Plan
description: LUSAKA. Zambia. Aug. 26The British Foreign Secretary, Dr. David Owen, and Andrew Young arrived here tonight to present a BritishAmerican plan for settling the conflict in Rhodesiabefore a skeptical assembly of Rhodesian black nationalists and key leaders of black African nations.

title: Vegetables Fight to Flourish In City's Sidewalk Gardens
description: The corn isn't as high as an elephant's eye, but then the sidewalks of New York aren't Oklahoma. Despite the havoc caused by vandals and pollution, a number of New Yorkers are trying valiantly to enjoy a few ears of corn or some tomatoes or peppers of their own nurturing.

title: Small Steps Against Smog
description: An encouraging armistice has been reached in the battle over plans to control automobile pollution in New York City. There will be no tolls on the East River bridges. There will be no ban on parking so draconian as to destroy the city's economy. There will be some modest steps taken to improve traffic flow and mass transit.

title: Hughes's Former Key Aide Loses His Post as Summa's Chief Counsel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26Probate of the estate of Howard R. Hughes inched forward in courts in three states today while it was disclosed in a related development that Chester C. Davis had been dismissed as chief counsel of the Sununa Corporation, the Hughes holding company.

title: Turner Has Courageous Revved Up
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug 26Who won. today? a docksider at Newport Yacht Club asked early this evening when the press boat returned to port from its America's Cuo patrol.

title: Yankees
Soviet Says Voyage to North Pole, Was Hunt for Sea Lanes Not Stunt
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26The historic voyage of the nuclear icebreaker Arktika to the North Pole last week was part of a continuing effort to develop a shorter shipping route across the northern Soviet coastline, the expedition's leader said today.

title: Abraham Koppleman, Distributor Of Publications in Hartford, 87
description: Abraham Koppleman, the president of H. P. Koppleman, wholesale distributors of magazines, books and newspapers in Hartford, died yesterday at Hartford Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Hartford.

title: VANCE AND JAPANESE DISCUSS PEKING TRIP
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance briefed Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda on his China trip today, and Japanese sources said Mr. Fukuda extended an invitation to President Carter to pay an official visit to Japan.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Port Atuhority of New York and New Jersey asserted in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that it should be granted more time to assess he noise impact of the BritishFrench Concorde before the supersonic jetliner is to be given landing rights at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Fight Poverty by Fighting Fraud
description: The Community Services Administration, like the Office of Economic Opportunity which preceded it, represents an innovation in Federal efforts to help the poor. Most of its money$800 million this yeargoes to 850 local organizations where the poor or their representatives are to some extent entrusted with the responsibility of using it as they see fit. Houses have been renovated, minority businesses assisted, poor people involved in local politics.

title: JERSEY SAYS THANKS WITH QUEBEC DAY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26From the morning raising of the blue and white Quebec flag with its graceful fleur de lis until long after the sun had set last night, Quebec Day here celebrated a growing love affair between La Belle Province and the Jersey Shore.

title: Airlines in Heated Dispute Over Traffic Within Texas
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 26  A Chicago businessman boards a Braniff Airways flight at Chicago's O'Hare Field late one afternoon and arrives at the sprawling DallasFort Worth Airport two hours later. He rides a bus to downtown Dallas, meets clients for dinner, then takes a taxicab to Love Field, the smaller and older Dallas airport that is closer to the city's center.

title: Consumer Notes
description: NEWARK, Aug 26Thousands of consumers who heat their homes with natural gas supplied by the New Jersey Natural Gas Company or who use gas for cooking purposes will get a onetime credit of about $32.50 as a result of an order by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

title: SEVEN LOCAL BOARDS SUPERSEDED BY ANKER
description: Chancellor Irving Anker yesterday superseded seven local school boards that had sought to set their own school calendar and announced that all elementary schools would open, as scheduled, on Sept. 8.

title: H. U. D. Chief Seeks a Lumber Study
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Patricia Roberts Harris, said today that she had asked the Council of Wage and Price Stability to investigate an inexplicable but dramatic rise in lumber prices, which have increased as much as 28 percent since July 1.

title: Vikings Dominate, Beat Dolphins, 337
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 26 (AP) Tommy Kramer threw his first touch. down pass as a pro, and Duck White and Sammy White each scored touclt, downs as the Minnesota Vikings overwhelmed Miami, 337, in a Nationat Football League exhibition game to night.

title: Books of The Times
description: Seventy years from now, will anyone remember Mick Jagger and Paul McCartney? It is more likely that Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov will evoke the same recognition then as Anna Pavlova and Vaslav Nijinsky do today, nearly 70 years after their own debuts outside Russia. What entertainer of Nijinsky's and Pavlova's time, for instance, can match their legend?

title: Exploration in Peking
description: PEKING, Aug. 26When Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance concluded four days of talks here yesterday on the normalization of United StatesChinese relations, he pronounced himself satisfied that his mission had been very useful, for it had succeeded in fulfilling its exploratory purpose and enhanced mutual understanding. Hua Kuofeng, the chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who met with Mr. Vance yesterday, declared that exploration was a good thing. In fact, he used the word four times in a few sentences.

title: Court Crowd Jeers and Jostles Sanjay Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 (AP)Sanjay Gandhi, son of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi wad jostled and jeered by a crowd of several hundred people today when he made a brief court appearance here.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Edward Hausner

title: Connors Ousts Stan Smith in U.S. Pro Tennis
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug, 26 (UPI) Topseeded Jimmy Connors, hitting deep the whole match, advanced to the quarterfinals of the 5125,000 United States Pro tennis championship tonight with a 6.4, 63, victory over Stan Smith, seeded 10th.

title: Now That El's Gone, Bronx Hub Sees A Brighter Future
description: It was 1888, an auspicious year by any standard, when a dark sky closed in over Third Avenue and 149th Street in the Bronx with the extension of the elevated transit line to Manhattan.

title: Security Surrounds Release of the Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 26 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said that its report on New York City's finances was one of its most complex ever. It was also one of its most closely guarded. me report was released to the public at I P.M. after it was distributed to reporters at noon. The reporters were required to remain in a briefing room at S.E.C. headquarters for one hour. That gave them some time to review its contents without permitting any immediate disclosure of the findings.

title: Julie Andr ews in Suburbia: She Is Prim but She Can Sing
description: How many young people squirmed through The Sound of Music in the 1960's, making faces as their dates or parents watched and listened in rapture? How many endured Mary Poppins dreaming of the Rolling Stones? One thing is certain. Those who loved these movies have not forgotten. One could sense their expectations this week at the Westchester Premiere Theater, where Julie Andrews, the star of both films, has been performing.

title: Andretti Breaks Lap Record
description: ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Aug. 26 (AP)With lastminute steering adjustments to his JPSLotus, Mario Andretti shattered the lap record today in the first day of trials for Sunday's Dutch Grand Prix. The 37yearold Formula 1 driver from Nazareth, Pa., clocked 1 minute 18.85 seconds at 119 miles an hour on the winding 21/2mile Zandvoort circuit, surpassing the previous best of 1:20.31 set in 1973 by Ronnie Peterson of Sweden.

title: Quebec Assembly Approves Law Promoting the Primacy of French
description: QUEBEC, AUG. 26A law to promote the primacy of French in Quebec was approved by the Assembly today against the bitter opposition of an economically dominant Englishspeaking community.

title: 3 Airlines in Dispute Over Texas Traffic
description: Continued From Page 27

title: Johnson Is Focus of Timely Book
description: Call it coincidence, or call it prescience or perhaps call it a little of both, bbut the first book that is likely to appear about President Carter's surprise nominee for director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, United States District Court Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., will be written by a surprising authorRobert F. Kennedy Jr., son and namesake of the late Attorney General and Senator from New York.

title: Irwin Leads With a 62 For 127, Near Record
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 26 (AP)Grimly determined Hale Irwin responded today to what he called a mustwin situation with a spectacular nineunderpar 62 in the second round of the $250.000 Hall of Fame Classic. That gave him the lead by five strokes,

title: Seattle Times to Drop XRated Ads
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 26 (UPI)  John A. Blethen, publisher of The Seattle Times, announced today that he was taking steps to exclude from the newspaper all advertisements of Xrated films and socalled adult entertainment. He said I restrictions on such advertising would begin next week and that after existing contracts with theaters were terminated in 1978. no advertising of Xrated movies and adult entertainment would he accepted.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Carter's Bertlanced Budget
description: As the clock struck 11 P.M. on Dec.. 31, 1981, President Carter's telephone rang in the Oval Office. Patrick Caddell, his polling authority, gave him the great news. At precisely 10:32 P.M., the American people had undergone a complete recovery of faith in their government.

title: Dying Mexican Silver Town Still Foresees Shiny Future
description: REAL DE CATORCE, MexicoWe used to have thick carpets and fine furniture, the Mayor's secretary said as he unlocked the door to the crumbling municipal palace, but outsiders came and bought up everything they could find. Diego Sanchez waved sadly toward threadbare curtains and faded pictures of former Mexican presidents. This was the main reception room, he said. So many important things happened here. In an old cupboard dusty piles of manuscripts provided mute evidence of an era that someone once thought worth recording in this community 9,000 feet up in the Sierra Madre in northcentral Mexico.

title: Sherry Peppers Wins Spinaway At Saratoga in Only Her 2d Start
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Angel Cordero, the meeting's leading jockey, was more ebullient than usual this afternoon after bringing home Townsend B. Martin's Sherry Peppers as the winner of the $53,900 Spinaway at Saratoga.

title: Washington Commuters Delayed By Flooding in a Subway Project
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)Thousands of commuters had to be switched from one route of Washington's new Metrorail subway system to buses today after dams at a subway construction project collapsed, flooding a partly completed station.

title: Legion Aide Says Blacks
description: DENVER, Aug. 26 (UPI)The threat of a Communist takeover in South Africa is more important than the rights of the black majority there, according to an American Legion official.

title: Sports Today
A Choreographer of Vanguard Leads New England Dinosaur
description: The. New Yorker's implicit belief that vanguard choreographers are rarely found outside the city limits was shaken by New England Dinosaur's appearance at American Theater Laboratory Thursday evening. Its artistic director, Toby Armour, was part of the Judson Memorial Church revolution of the early 1960's, and she has continued to work steadily in Boston for the last decade.

title: EXSOLDIER SUIT ASSERTS HE WAS AN LSD TEST VICTIM
description: NEWARK, Aug. 26A $15 million damage suit has been filed against the Federal Government on behalf of a former soldier who contends he was the unwitting victim of LSD tests 20 years ago and that he has suffered irreparable damage since then.

title: Results in World University Games
description: AT SOFIA, BULGARIA

title: Prices for Futures Drop In Grains and Soybeans; Weekend Hedging Cited
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)Soybean and grain futures prices fell a shade lower on the Chicago Board of Trade today in a session of relatively minor price movements.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Union Dispute Delays Conference for Beame
description: A union dispute among television camera crews delayed Mayor Beame's news conference for 45 minutes yesterday.

title: 8 DIRECTORS RESIGN COMMONWEALTH OIL
description: Eight of the 14 directors of the troubled Commonwealth Oil Refining company resigned after a board meeting in New York yesterday. Norman C. Keith also stepped down as chairman, although he will remain a member of the board.

title: The Standings
description: Saturday, August 27, 1977

title: Saratoga Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Fiscal Crisis And Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission report issued today produced few revelations about New York City's financial practices, but it offered something much more significant: It reached an enormously damaging conclusion about the behavior of both Mayor Beame and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin in the fiscal turmoil of 1974 and 1975, and offered stunning new information about the behavior of the major banks and underwriters as they struggled with city officials to keep New York City solvent.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Lawyers for the Crane Company said the company was prepared to divest itself of its welding fittings business in St. Louis in order to allay objections by the Chemetron Corporation to a proposed tender offer.

title: Esquire Magazine Sold to Felker With the Help of British Publisher
description: Clay Felker, who founded New York and New West magazines and then lost them to Rupert Murdoch in a financial imbroglio last winter, bought Esquire magazine yesterday with the help of one of Mr. Murdoch's British newspaper competitors.

title: Youth Electrocuted in Troy
description: TROY, N.Y. Aug. 26 (AP)A 17yeartold boy was electrocuted here today when he stepped backward on scaffolding against his home, on which he was scraping paint, and came into contact with a Niagara Mohawk Power Company line, police said. The youth, Paul Miller, was the son of Sgt. William Miller of the Troy Police Department.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Aug. 26 (Reuters)France will open a drive for world disarmament with a personal approach by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing to the leaders of the major nuclear powers, French Government officials said today.

title: Crime Ring Suspected In Japanese Forgeries
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26, (Reuters)Japanese police said tody they suspected a large international crime syndicate of passing forged Bank of Tokyo travelerscheck's: totaling $127,347 in 15 countries in the last year.

title: PHYLLIS GLEITSMAN GROSS
description: Phyllis Gleitsman Gross, coowner of Hayes Registry Inc., the city's largest theatrical telephoneanswering service, died Tuesday of cancer at New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital. She was 44 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: NO FRAUD IS ALLEGED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  Mayor Beame, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, six New York City banks and Merrill Lynch, the country's largest brokerage, all knowingly misled investors in city securities in 197475 by failing to disclose the city's perilous financial condition, the Securities and Exchange Cornmission said today.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 27, 1977

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Goldwater Warns. On Taiwan Treaty
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 26 (Renters)Senator Barry Goldwater said today that President Carter would be risking impeachment if he unilaterally tried to break off the defense treaty with Taiwan.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: TAMPA, Fla.Milton Owens, 1581/2 pounds, knocked out Major Lambert, 164, Pensacola, Fla., 4 rounds.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times during the last week.

title: Major League Box Scores
Carter to Name 2 Lawyers in West For the Federal Appeals Bench
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)President Carter announced today that he would nominate Procter R. Hug Jr., of Reno, Nev., and Thomas Tang, of Scottsdale, Ariz., to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

title: Radio
State U. Contract Awarded
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 26 (AP)The State awarded $10 million in contracts yesterday for construction at the new State University at Buffalo campus in suburban Amherst, ending a twoyear freeze on work. About $300 million of work has been done at the new campus so far.

title: Communists in Portugal Say New Austerity Plan Is Unfair to the Workers
description: LISBON, Aug. 26 (Reuters)  A Portuguese Government proposal of an austerity package that includes a fluctuating exchange rate for the escudo, higher prices for gasoline and cuts in public spending was attacked today by the Communist Party and others as a serious blow to workers.

title: Ohioan Is Called Nazi War Criminal
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) John Deinjanjuk, a resident of the United Stales since 1952, has been accused by Federal officials of participating in the commission of World War II atrocities while he served as a guard at a German concentration camp in Poland.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article from St. Louis in The New York Times on Aug. 12 inadvertently identified Kenneth L. Worley, director of the United Automobile Workers Region V, as head of the local Chamber of Commerce. The reference should have been to Harry T. Morley Jr., president of the St. Louis Regional Commerce and Growth Association.

title: RUMANIAN GOOD OFFICES ARE ACCEPTED BY BEGIN
description: TEL AVIV. Aug. 26 (Reuters)Prime Minister Menahem Begin has accepted an offer by President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania to extend his good offices to further a Middle East peace settlement, the Israeli radio reported tonight.

title: 2 District Mine Union Leaders Call For Miller to Resign as President
description: CHARLESTON. W. VA.. Aug. 26The two highest officials of the United Mine Workers largest regional unit called today for the resignation of Arnold R. Miller as union president.

description: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala

title: INFORMATION SOUGHT ON URANIUM CARTEL
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 26Six prominent opposition position members of the Canadian Parliment have filed an action in the Ontario Supreme Court challenging the legality of a Government order prohibiting the disclosure of information on an international uranium cartel sponsored by Canada.

Goldin six New York City banks and Merrill Lynch, the country's largest brok. erage, all knowingly misled investors in city securities in 197475 by failing to disclose the city's perilous financial con. dition the Securities and Exchange Com. mission said today.

title: BLACK MAYORS ARRIVE TO AID SUTTON EFFORT
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan began collecting more than a decade's worth of political debts yesterday when a stream of black elected officials, including more than a dozen mayors, arrived in New York City to spend the weekend in a getoutthevote Primary drive in black neighborhoods.

description: The New York Times

title: WILLIAM WARD
description: William Ward, a prominent fashion photographer in the 1940's and 50's, died yesterday in Calvary Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Remsenburg, L. I., and in Cannes, France.

description: The New York Times/Edward Hausner

description: Following is the statement by Mayor Beanie on the Securities and Exchange Commission Report

title: Now That El's Gone, Bronx Hub Sees A Brighter Future

title: Gas Pipeline in Indiana Town Explodes
description: COLUMBUS, Ind., Aug. 26 (AP)A natural gas pipeline exploded and spewed gas into the air with tornadic force today, uprooting trees, tossing rocks and driving hundreds of people from their homes.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Casts About in Effort To Rescue Goldfish Castaways
description: One theory is that someone two years ago threw two or three goldfish into the stagnant water inside a vacant lot at 71st Street and First Avenue and that the fish reproduced over the years.

title: S.E.C. in Poll Finds Investors Knew Little
description: As part of its investigation into the securities transactions of New York City, the Securities and Exchange Commission polled investors about how much they knew about the city's financial condition when they bought city notes. Of the more than 160,000 individual investors who owned the major portion of the city's outstanding longterm bonds, more than 500 of them were polled to determine the adeauacv of city's disclosure.

title: Florida Newspaper Ending
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP)The Osceola Sun will cease publication Sept. 9, according to The Sentinel Star Company, the Sun's parent corporation. The Sun suffered losses each year after being founded in 1969, an announcement yesterday said. The estimated daily circulation of the afternoon newspaper was under 6,000.

title: Martine Pred'homme Wed to Federick Dulles
description: Martine Pred'homme and Frederick Hendrik Dulles, a New York lawyer, were married yesterday at the American Cathedral in Paris. The Rev. Frederick B. Northup performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article from St. Louis in The New York Times on Aug. 12 inadvertently identified Kenneth L. Worley, director of the United Automobile Workers Region V, as head of the local Chamber of Commerce. The reference should have been to Harry T. Morley Jr., president of the St. Louis Regional Commerce and Growth Association.

title: Sniper Slays 6 in Jersey And Then Takes Own Life
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Saturday, Aug. 27A sniper shot six persons to death yesterday as he wandered along the railroad tracks that run through this country town in North Jersey.

title: About New York
description: Carol Bellamy must go begging for attention, trailing the Philharmonic on its summer park tour and working the crowds with her politician's fugue, looking for voters hands in all sorts of groups, from the naked on Fire Island to the wizened in the city's sunset warrens.

title: Chekhov's First, Platonov,
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass Platonov is Chekhov's first extant fulllength play, written when he, was in his early 20's and discarded by the author. An untitled manuscript discovered after his death, the work has been infrequently produced (although one version, entitled A Country Scandal, had a long run Off Broadway in 1960). Any production, such as the one currently at the Williamstown Theater Festival, is necessarily an interpretation; performed in its entirety, Platonov would probably last about seven hours.

title: Puppeteers to Give Masanielle
description: The Bread and Puppet Theater, headed by Peter Schumann, will return to the New York scene from its home base in Glover, Vt., with a new production, Masanielio. It is based on the exploits of a 17thcentury Italian folk hero and will have its premiere Sept. 6, and play through Sept. 10 at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Alaska Base Will Get 12 F4E Jet Fighters
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)The Air Force will send 12 additional E4E jet fighters to. Alaska over the next year to strengthen United States air defenses there.

title: Las Vegas Five Gets TwoYear Probation
description: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 26 (AP)After four years of rumors, there was almost a sigh of relief today as officials at the University of NevadaLas Vegas formally acknowledged that the school's basketball program had been placed on a twoyear probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The N.C.A.A. issued the suspension yesterday.

title: Judge Acts on Court's Patronage
description: A Brooklyn administrative judge yesterday announced changes in the selection of receivers, guardians and other courtappointed officials to remove any appearance of impropriety as well as any unjustifiable criticism of court appointments.

title: East German Oarsmen Reach Finals in Five More Events
description: AMSTERDAM, Aug. 26In weather that sent the spectators running for shelter from torrential downpours and reappearing to gaze at rainbows, the semifinal rounds of the men's elite, or heavyweight, world championship races were rowed today on the Bosbaan course.

title: Why Some Soviet Sociologists Are Alarmed
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.In a recent interview, Leonid L Brezhnev was asked if he foresaw any structural changes in the Soviet system in connection with the rapid growth of indigenous nationalities in the Soviet Union. He replied that this development only gladdened him, because would strengthen that new and unique historical community, the Soviet people.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON Aug. 27 (UPI)Airplanes taking off despite predictions of chaos as a result of a strike by assistant controliers.

title: Few Favored Bonds Even Before Report
description: Even before the release of the Securities and Exchange Commission's report criticizing New York City and New York banks and brokers for allegedly having knowingly misled investors in city securities, a majority of New York City residents said they would not buy a New York bond anyway.

title: MUSIC
description: THE summer is still with us, but the cultural fur of fall is already starting to fly as orchestras and chambermusic societies firm up plans for the new season and put their subscription campaigns into high gear. Next week some of the intriguing orchestral concerts in store for Westchesterites will be covered, but for now here is news of an impressive vocal and instrumental series in Bronxville. It is called Chamber Music at Sarah Lawrence, and when Michael Rudiakov, the noted cellist who has been its artistic director since the program was begun nine years ago, was interviewed about it, he was positively exuberant.

title: From London, With the Natives: Exploring the Heartland
description: We had stayed in town on our first visit to London, taking in Parliament, Buckingham Palace, West End theaters all London has to offer at close range. That was when we first heard mention of Merrymakers, excursions out of London combining rail and bus travel, and last spring, planning a second visit, we remembered.

title: Temporary Jobs On a Steady Basis
description: ALTHOUGH steady work has become a cultural watchword in our society, there are people who cannot find it, cannot do it or do not want it. For them, there is the option of a temporary job, which can be found through the 20 or so employment services in the county that specialize in temporary positions.

title: Judith F. Kozlowski Wed to Eliot Clauss
description: Judith F. Kozlowski, who is in her third year at New York Law School, was Married yesterday to Eliot R. Clauss, who received his law degree there. Msgr. James G. Waders performed the ceremony in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Dog Shows
Barbara Foley Bride Of Jeffrey Alan Smith
description: Barbara Mary Foley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Foley of Smoke Rise, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Alan Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frederick Smith of Rockville Centre, L. I.

title: New Terminals of 15 Years Ago Made Port Containership Capital
description: Fifteen years ago this month the port opened its first specially designed containership terminal and observed the first commercial voyage of a nuclearpowered merchant ship. Of the two anniversaries, the container terminal inauguration is by far the more important for the port since commercial service by a nuclear merchant ship has ceased in the interval and was nothing more than an experiment to begin with.

title: Jersey Suspect Termed Troubled
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 27 Twentyyearold Emile Pierre Benoist was troubled.

title: Tall Tale of Success On a City Terrace
description: Being a midwesterner at heart, I was determined that our terrace garden should duplicate as much as possible my native environment. I wanted to grow corn, but had noticed in my readings on vegetables suitable for the city terrace that most of them warned the prospective farmer against planting ittakes up space, small yield for the space required, etc.

title: Look what's cooking at A&S
description: The Brooklyn Tomato Races. Tomato fever is spreading in Brooklyn backyards as resident farmers cultivate their best tomatoes for the A&S Great Tomato Sweepstakes. To enter you must be a Brooklyn. resident with your own tomato garden. Award winning categories include pint size, plum size, full size and biggest.Y

title: The Reckoning
description: For weeks, Mayor Beame had suspected the Securities and Exchange Commission was about to issue a report on New York City's finances that could threaten, if not eliminate, his chances for reelection. Over a period of days he mounted a preemptive strike, hoping that if he could portray the report as politically inspired, he could minimize the damage.

title: Penn Central on New Tracks Without a Railroad
description: The Penn Central Company has a taste for superlatives  in 1968 it was formed from what was then the largest merger in United States history and less than two and a half years later on June 21, 1970, its railroad plunged into the nation's biggest corporate bankruptcy.

title: A Time for Women in State Politics
description: IF I WERE to retire from the House of Representatives, which I am not contemplating, the race for my seat would probably be between two women. I think the strongest condidates from both parties would be women.

title: The Stormy Summer of Controversy at Forest Hills
description: It should be a time for nostalgia, for savoring Grand Slams and classic fivesetters. The farewell at Forest Hills. C'mon, baby, let the good times roll.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
White Rhodesia, Its Time Running Out, Is Set to Vote
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 27The jacaranda blossoms are flowering across Rhodesia, heralding another spring in the Southern Hemisphere. But politically, for whites, it is late autumn going on winter in the life of the territory that has been theirs to rule since Cecil Rhodes' pioneers raised the British standard here on a spring evening in 1890.

title: This Season's New Series
description: This year 22 new weekly series will make their debut on the networks, spread out over the next couple of months. They are:
