title: S.D. Mueller Weds Cynthia E. Bonomo At Connecticut Club
description: Cynthia Ellen Bonomo and Stephen Douglas Mueller, who graduated in June from Colorado College, were married yesterday at the Woodway Country Club in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Edgar A. Brammer of the College Hill Lutheran Church in Cedar Falls, Iowa, performed the ceremony.

title: Carlota Geyer Is Bride Of Dr. Neil L. Schechter
description: Carlota Patricia Geyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Geyer of Darien, Conn., was married last evening to Dr. Neil Lawrence Schechter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schechter of Jericho, L. I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at Waveny House, a community meeting place in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Phyllis Salkaln, C. Blake Munro Have Nuptials
description: The marriage of Phyllis H. Salkaln, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Bradford Harwood Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., to C. Blake Munro took place yesterday in Boulder, Colo. The Rev. George A. Berlin performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church. Mr. Munro the son of Mrs. Louis W. Munro of Syosset, L.I., and the late Mr. Munro, former president of Doremus & Company an international advertising and public relations agency.

title: An Explorer Investigates State Caves
description: NEWTON IN THE LAND of handy turnpikes and bustling boardwalks and, soon, freespending casinos, there are probably better ways to spend a weekend than to descend through dark, narrow passages into the earth.

title: Resentment Of High Rise Amid Homes Is Still High
description: During last month's blackout, the lights blazed on in the 1,700 apartments of North Shore Towers in Floral Park, Queens. The complex has its own power plant, which is just one more example of the highly visible presence it has maintained in the two and a half years since its completion.

title: U.S. Bid for Greenland Reported by Historian
description: COPENHAGEN, Aug. 27 (AP)A Danish historian says in a new book that his Government turned down a bid by the United States in 1946 to buy Greenland.

title: GARDENING
description: THE NEXT time you nibble on those delicious salted mixed nuts that came out of a can, remember that they grow on trees, and that it takes a dandy big grove of nut trees to fill all those cans on the store shelf, and that with some tender loving care and intelligent choices, some of those crunchy goodies can be grown in the backyard.

title: STAMPS
description: With their independence declared, but yet far from won, the former Thirteen Colonies began their first attempt at united gov ernment with the Articles of Confederation, which took shape in the early dark days of the Revolution. This became the foundation for the Constitution that is one of the great strengths of American democracy.

title: Article 6  No Title

description: ...on Merrymaker tours, remember that they are booked only in Brita:n and cannot be arranged in this country. Reservations must be made in person, either at the railroad stations from which they originate or at the following British Rail offices in London: 4 Regent Street; 14 Kingsgate Parade, Victoria Street; 407 Oxford Street; 170B Strand; and 87 King William Street.

title: Brooklyn Postal Guard Is Shot In a Clash With Two Gunmen
description: A 49yearold postal guard was shot yesterday in an exchange of fire with two holdup men near the rear entrance of the main Brooklyn Post Office at Cadman Plaza in the downtown section of the borough.

title: IN BRIEF
description: THE TAKEOVER BATTLE for the Babcock & Wilcox Company seemed to come to an end after five months as the United Technologies Corporation withdrew its offer for Babcock shares, leaving J. Roy McDermott & Company the apparent winner. McDermott's final offer amounted, in effect, to $65 a share.

title: A Designer's Inside Story
description: Ellen Lehman McCluskey remembers the day, years ago, when she received a phone call from the manager of the Barclay Hotel in New York:

title: Klein's Path in a Field of Scandal
description: SUFFOLK County Executive John V.N. Klein has led a charmed political life. He has risen from Smithtown Justice of the Peace to the county's highest office during a decade or so when the Republican Party has been continually racked by scandals that would make a bigcity boss cringe. In fact, some of Mr. Klein's best friends have been deeply involved in the scandals.

description: Countries which appear technically capable of detonating a nuclear bomb within a decade

title: Whippet Earns Top Award at Danbury Show
description: DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 27The Butt family from Honey Brook, Pa., has had the top whippets in the nation for the last five years, and Ch. Sporting Fields Clansman, the Butt's latest whippet to campaign, is making quite an impact. He took his second bestinshow in the last six days when he won over 1,570 dogs tonight at the Newtown Kennel Club's 27thd og show at the Danbury Fair Grounds.

title: Mrs. Abzug Spoils a Sutton Party
description: The Democratic primary campaign yesterday intruded unexpectedly on the third annual Harlem Day festivities when Bella S. Abzug, a mayoral candidate, and a number of her black supporters appeared at an event where another mayoral candidate, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan. had expected to have the stage pretty much to himself.

title: Westbury
description: No trace of Indian lives Can be found here among the houses. Not an arrow has been uncovered Even while digging for suburbia. Of course there are no headstones But neither are there tools or bones Worthy of consideration. Many crossed the Sound, Fished the waters, Trapped small game in the woods North of here. At this spot, All trees are developers' creations. What did the Indians know about The greatest plains west of the Mississippi? If they crossed this country, They took their traces with them, Holding their lives in their quivers, Packing their shadows as they went. On this earth we grow berries and asparagus; Now beans and grapes grow full. Massapequa, look for me in my dreams. Tell the secret of this forbidden place.

title: City Hall Fete Will Recognize McDonnell Exit
description: After 14 years at the center of labormanagement disputes, Vincent D. McDonnell is preparing to leave his post as chairman of the New York State Mediation Board and join the law firm of Shea, Gould, Climenko, Kramer & Casey and also head the Graduate School of Industrial Relations at Pace University.

title: A New Book for Mr. Felker
description: One press lord taketh away from Clay S. Felker, but another helpeth to restore. Last January, unable to stop a takeover by Australian newspaper magnate Rupert Murdoch, Mr. Felker resigned as president of New York Magazine Company. Now Mr. Felker is to be president of a new company formed to buy Esquire magazine; its chairman will be Vere Harmsworth, head of Britain's Associated Newspapers Group. Before founding New York, where he created its influential style of trendy service articles for the upper middle class. Mr. Felker had been an editor at Esquire from 1957 to 1962, helping to develop Esquire's irreverent tone of the 1960's and attracting a number of writers whose personal involvement with their subjects came to be called the New Journalism.

title: Rebecca Fowle Wed to Arthur Lafave 3d
description: Rebecca Fowle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fowle of Providence, R.L, was married yesterday to Arthur J. Lafave 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lafave Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Edward J. Tyler, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents in Thetford Hill, Vt.

title: English Laughter
description: J . B. PRIESTLEY once complimented life for having such an easy time creating superior comic characters and situations. Novelists must strain to do this: We hear a sneering little voice whispering, Absurd ... overdrawn ... unconvincing Dickensian ... and so out they go, these glorious extravagances. In 71 novels, plays and collections of essays, Mr. Priestley, now 82, has made a career of sneering back at that little voice. An unrepentantly public figure, he wants his own extravagances to be heard and immediately understood: No matter what the subject in hand might be, I want to write something that at a pinch I could read aloud in a barparlor.

title: Miss Hickey Is Wed To Thomas J. Lavin, A Business Student
description: Elizabeth Hickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Hickey of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas J. Lavin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Lavin of Baldwin. L.I. The Very Rev. George G. Maley performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: REAGAN EXPECTS SUPPORT IN CANAL TREATY BATTLE
description: WAYNE, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP)Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said yesterday that his stand against the proposed Panama Canal treaties would not be a lonely one and would not split the Republican Party.

title: Connors Out With Bad Back; Gottfried Bows
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 27 (Reuters)Jimmy Connors, the topseeded player, withdrew from the 50th United States Pro tennis championships tonight because of a wrenched back, and the No. 2 player, Brian Gottfried, was upset earlier in the day.

title: A Montage of Highlights
description: SEPTEMBER

title: Wendy Oshinsky Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Myron Oshinsky of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Sue Oshinsky, to Dennis Coren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Coren of Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Ann Louise Engelland Wed To Harry Taranto, Analyst
description: Ann Louise Engelland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren H. Engelland of Cos Cob, Conn., was married yesterday to Harry Vitali Taranto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dario Taranto of So Paulo, Brazil.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Last summer. after Onondaga County Republicans received subpoenas from the Manhattan District Attorney's office, it was repotred that a Manhattan grand jury was investigating Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's 1974 reelection campaign.

title: Elaine Pettebone Wed to H. L. Armstrong
description: The Princeton University Chapel was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elaine Ann Pettebone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Major Pettebone of Whitehouse Station, N. J., to Howard Low Armstrong. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Irwin Armstrong of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Lynnwood Andrews, Therapist, Fiancee Of John Cushman Jr.
description: Lynnwood Byrd Andrews, a recreational therapist at Babies Hospital, plans to be married Sept. 24 to John H. Cushman Jr., a reporter for The American Metal Market, a trade daily Published by Fairchild publications.

title: Camp in Warren Aids Retarded
description: AT CAMP JOTONI in Warren Township, 80 mentally retarded youngsters planted a garden this summer. They picked beans, blanched and froze them to eat on a picnic, and pickled the cucumbers and onions they had carefully weeded and watered.

title: Gas Station Operator Foils Robber
description: REDWOOD FALLS, Minn., Aug. 27 (UPI)A masked gunman went into the service station of John Towler early today and demanded money, just as a car pulled up for gasoline. Mr. Towler, who is in his 70's, told the gunman he had to go out and take care of his customer. Mr. Towler walked out to the car, whispered to the customer, jumped in and rode off. The wouldbe robber fled on foot.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayLong Island Doberman Pinscher Club match show and obedience trial. Second Sight Dog Guide Foundation. Smithtown, L.I.; entries from 9 A.M.; information: (516) 8227267.

title: Voyager 1 Launching Is, Postponed Again
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP)The launching of a second Voyager space probe was postponed for the second time today as scientists labored over problems with the first one.

title: 345,000 Volts Under the Sound
description: IN a trailer office on the shore of Long Island Sound one wet and sloppy day, three construction engineers leaned back in their seats and gazed at a map showing an electric cable snaking its way four miles across the bottom of the Sound.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Ideas &Trends
description: If the Interior Department prevails, agribusiness in 17 Western states may have to give way to family farming.

title: James Norris, Elizabeth Miller Have Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Beebe Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Q. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y., became the bride yesterday afternoon of James Norris son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Norris of Buffalo. The Rev. Dudley J. Stroup performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale.

title: MARKETS
description: The stock market continued last week to do what it has been doing best this year: It declined.

title: People Mover At a Standstill
description: THREE years ago, the state decided not to let anybody play with its brandnew $4.5 million toy, the peoplemover at Bradley International Airport.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH few homes in this area have flat or shedtype roofs over the entire house, many do have this type of roof over an attached garage, family room or extra room that has been added. These flat roofs are usually covered with builtup or rolltype roofing, rather than shingles, and they may or may not have gravel on top.

title: Maryalice Phillips Wed To Frederick Hoogland
description: Maryalice Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Phillips of Hamden and Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick W. T. Hoogland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick V. Hoogland of Martinsburg, W.V., formerly of Brooklyn.

title: CRITIC'S VIEW
description: It is probably bad form to bring it up this week, just as the new season arrives radiating good hope, but the separation of blacks and whites in the arts has reached the point where it may be said that cultural apartheid exists in this promised land. Although the longrange effects of this division are likely to be devastating to the arts in America, few of the people who control the arts seem concerned. In spite of a bright spot or two, such as the weeklong Celebration of Black Composers that the New York Philharmonic begins tomorrow night, substantial change in this ominous picture seems unlikely soon, certainly not in the 197778 season.

title: Elizabeth Williams Wed to Thomas Lipscomb
description: Elizabeth Townsend Williams and Thomas Phillips Lipscomb, graduates of the University of the South, were married yesterday in Richmond. The Rev. Marshall T. Ware performed the ceremony in All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: News Summary
description: China, which under Mao Tsetung scorned Yugoslavia as revisionist because of its stress on profits, is looking to that country for guidance in motivting dissatisfied factory workers and aiding economic growth. A source in Peking said that a Chinese delegation headed by an alternate member of the Politburo had visited Yugoslavia and examined its system of worker selfmanagement, in which workers share responsibility for running an enterprise and the distribution of profits. Relations between the two countries have warmed to the point where President Tito will visit China for the first time. He is expected in Peking this week. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: DINING OUT
description: NO gift is more precious than good advice, read my fortune. My gift is to suggest that you try Hunan in the Smith Haven Mall (next to Pathmark). The food is consistently excellent, from appetizers to dessert (yes, dessert).

title: Grand Jury on the Line
description: NEW HAVEN THE Connecticut grand jury system has come under a renewed attack over the last couple of weeks, this time because of its apparent failings in a case in which I am involved. Lorne Acquin, accused of committing nine murders in midJuly, sits unindicted in the New Haven jail and state grand jury will not even begin to consider his case until Sept. 7.

title: Jane Elling Zacharias Wed to Harvey Baker
description: Jane Elling Zacharias and Harvey Baker, graduates of Union College, were married yesterday afternoon in Hew Gardens, Queens. Criminal Court Judge Melvin Berger performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: U.S. Open Tennis Draw
description: (SEEDINGS IN PARENYHESES)

title: BEAME CHARGES BANKS DECEIVED INVESTORS; SEES COVERUP BY S.E.C.
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday angrily assailed a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission and charged that it was New York City's major banks  and not he  that had misled investors in city securities.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT'S ABOUT time, I say, that something pleasant was said about the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is often called the Port Authority, the Pee Ay or just (to its bondholders) PA.

title: Well Contamination Is Causing Concern In Nassau County
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 27Two more water wells in Nassau County were closed this week by the county's Department of Health bringing to 42 the number of wells throughout the county that have been banned for human consumption because of some sort of nitrate or organicagent contamination.

title: RollsRoyce Owners Honor Car's Builder
description: MONMOUTH, Wales, Aug. 27 (Reuters)More than 80 RollsRoyce limousines drove in procession through this Welsh border town today in a centenary tribute to Charles Rolls, cofounder of RollsRoyce.

title: Are Reports of Pelham's Decline Premature?
description: PELHAM DESPITE what may have been read here recently, there is a rumbling being heard from a usually quiet village in Westchester. It is a sound of rebirth, renewal and camaraderie. Witness the renaissance of Pelham.

title: A First Look at Fall
description: NEVER mind last season. Last season is never any good. How many last seasons can you think of in which more than one absolute masterpiece was published? No, it's next season that always looks good, especially compared with last season, and this fall is nn exception. New fiction by John Fowles, Philip Roth, Irwin Shaw, John le Carre, John Hersey, Jerzy Kosinski, Margaret Drabble, Toni Morrison, John Gnegory Dunne and Pete Hamill. A new collection of poetry by John Ashbery. Diaries and letters by Edmund Wilson, Flannery O'Connor, Virginia Woolf, Evelyn Waugh and Anne Sexton. Autobiographies and memoirs by Jessica Mitford, Eleanor Clark, Bennett Cerf and Agatha Christie.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: Harlem Has Its (Third Annual) Dayand Shows the Proud Side
description: Heralding a second renaissance for Harlem, sponsors of the third annual Harlem Day yesterday climaxed a week of water ballets, tennis competitions, elderly citizen lunches, cocktail parties and soul food buffets with live jazz and other activities.

title: Shaping Economic Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Practically every administration since World War II has faced the same early problem in economic policymakingthe diffusion of authority among too many agencies and officials.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Republic of Panama has been much in the news lately, bringing to the attention of many Americans that Panama is more than just a canal area.

title: TV Movie on Dr. King Rekindles Rancor Between Widow and Aides
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 27The production of a television movie about the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has stirred an acrimonious debate about the slain civil rights leader's character and his place in history.

title: A Capital InvestmentDominican Tourist Gamble
description: Atop the crest of the west bank of Santo Domingo's Ozama River, along Calle Coln, is the Fortaleza Ozama. Within its walls stands an angular, limestoneandcoral edifice called the Torre del Homenaje, the Tower of Homage, dedicated to Queen Isabella of Spain in 1507.

title: Around the Nation
description: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 27 (UPI)William Shaheen, United States Attorney, said today that the Justice Department had concluded an investigation into allegations that the administration of Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. of New Hampshire misused Federal funds. He said that no further action would be taken.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% Municipal surtax.)

title: Affirmed Spa Victor; Alydar 2d
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 It was obvious from the way most fans wagered on the 73d running of the Hopeful today that they were convinced the chief contenders would be Calumet's Alydar and Harbor View's Affirmed.

title: Australia Outsails Sverige Again; Enterprise Sets Back Independence
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27Gambling with a lead in yacht racing is a bit like playing Russian roulette. It can raise the mortality rate. But the yacht Australia got away with unnecessary risk early in its race against Sverige here today and beat the Swedish boat by 25 seconds in the final challenger series of the America's Cup competition.

title: Revival Outlook for the Old Mill
description: THE Carter Administration's proposals on hydroelectric power may affect the future of Connecticut's old textile mills, but their fascinating past and uncertain present are already of concern to preservationists, environmentalists and developers.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Every so often a family of wasps decide to set up housekeeping somewhere in the garden. At this time of year, they can make life miserable. There seems to be something about the August summer days that try waspand ourtempers.

title: A Serious Little Border Dispute
description: In rural Delaware County in upstate New York. troubles run as deep as the soil. In fact, troubles are the soil, specifically a 1,000acre sliver of land that is the focus of a border dispute between the neighboring towns of Andes and Bovina.

title: Westbound Amtrak Train Collides With Derailed Freight in Illinois
description: LA GRANGE, Ill., Aug. 27 (AP)At least 30 persons were injured today when an Amtrack passenger train collided with an oncoming freight train, knocking more than 20 cars off an overpass, the authorities said. No passenger cars were reported off the tracks.

title: The World
description: When the Soviet Union said this month that South Africa was about to carry out an atomic test, the report was not taken too seriously in the West. It was taken very seriously last week when France repeated the charge. The French Foreign Minister, Louis de Guiringaud, warned that such a step would imperil all of southern Africa. The United States agreed.

title: Diana Vreeland Defines the 70's Style
description: It's a very natural thing, style, you see. It's not at all invented or for sale in a store. It's not like canned soup. You can have any kind of soup in the world, but you can't buy style  because it is personality, interest, education, and a sense of pleasure in society.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NOW that her twoweek run in the principal role of Diana Morales in A Chorus Line at the Shubert Theater on Broadway has come to an end, Patti D'Beck isn't worried about lapsing into idleness.

title: The New Season in the ArtsA Special Preview
Report's Significance Lies in Damaging Interpretation of Events
description: The limousines that pulled up to Gracie Mansion on the wintry dawn of Dec. 17, 1974, may not have seemed special to anyone watching nearby. But the message being carried by the men inside was critical. The arrivals that morningbreakfast guests of both Mayor Beame and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldinwere senior executives of the major banks and brokerage firms in New York City. And they were there to lay before their hosts a warning that they were encountering enormous difficulty in marketing city securities to the investing public.

title: Michigan Lineman Injured
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 27 (AP)Bill Dufek, the University of Michigan's allBig Ten offensive tackle, will be lost to the Wolverines for at least the first half of the 1977 season because of a leg injury. Xrays revealed Dufek has cracked fibula. The senior allAmerica candidate received the injury in a passblocking drill, university officials said.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE ISLAND'S man in South America this month was Representative Lester L. Wolff of Great Neck, on a sixcountry trip to check into the traffic in cocaine.

title: Inside Five Famous Women's Closets
description: Successful, famous, highpowered women need closets that work for, not against them. Their closets must hold day clothes, evening clothes, resort clothes  clothes for all seasons. Organizing this wardrobe is no easy matter. Liv Ullman doesn't even try. Bella Abzug keeps her entire hat collection on an antique hat rack. Lee Radzwill doesn't believe in huge, roomsize closets. She thinks they lead to keeping too many clothes and are, therefore, dangerous by being confusing. And Marisa Berenson just sails into her huge walkin closet where everything's visible at a single glance. Nobody handles closets in the same way. Here, then, a glimpse inside the closets of five famous women  Sue Mengers, Dolly Parton, Betty Friedan, Regine, and Bianca Jagger. They reveal their secrets, their tricks on how they make their closets work for them.

title: A Con Edison Flotilla Is Snaking a Power Line Across L.I. Sound That Could Light Up a City of a Million
description: In a trailer office on the shore of Long Island Sound one wet and sloppy day, three construction engineers leaned back. in their seats and gazed at a map showing an electric cable snaking its way four miles across the bottom of the Sound.

title: MUSIC
description: THE SUMMER is still with us, but musical wheels are starting to turn as orchestras and chamber music societies firm up plans for the new season and put their subscription campaigns into high gear. In Connecticut curiosity and expectation are running equally high as America's fourth oldest orchestra, the New Haven Symphony, puts out the welcome mat for its young new music director, Murray Sidlin.

title: Wilton Unplugs Microwave Plan
description: WILTON WHEN the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation applied recently to the Town of Wilton's Planning and Zoning Commission for a special permit to construct a 370foot microwave radio tower in the area as part of a planned chain of relay facilities stretching from New York City to Hartford, more than 50 local residents turned up at a public hearing to oppose it.

title: TENNIS MAGAZINE'S GUIDE TO THE 1977 U.S. OPEN
description: When CBS cut back on its schedule of tennis telecasts early this year, it promised to make up for it with expanded coverage of remaining eventsincluding especially the U.S. Open. Making good in a big way, CBS scheduled a record 27 hours of air time for Forest Hills action between August 31 and September 11, more than double the previous mark of 13 hours set last year. (For a complete schedule, see page 8 in this section.)

title: RELIGIOUS PAPER ENDING PUBLICATION; LOSSES CITED
description: The National Courier, a semiweekly religious newspaper circulated from Plainfield, N. J., is ceasing publication this week after two years and $2 million in losses, its publisher, Dan Malachuk, announced yesterday.

title: Lebanese Christians Issue Warning
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 27Lebanese Christian leaders, in a joint manifesto expressing deep concern over the situation in this country, called today for withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from the area near the border with Israel, expressed disenchantment with the role of Syrian peacekeeping troops here and warned that they would reconsider their support for President Elias Sarkis if security conditions continued to deteriorate.

title: Yarborough Fined $500 For Fuel Tank Violation
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., Aug. 27 (UPI)The Cale YarboroughJunior Johnson Holly Farms Chevrolet team was fined by NASCAR for the second time in less than a month todaythis time $500for having an oversized fuel tank.

title: BETTY R. SHEFFER, ACTIVE IN WESTPORT CIVIC AFFAIRS
description: Betty R. Sheffer, a 30year resident of Westport, Conn., who was active in local cultural and civic affairs, died Friday in Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn., after a long illness. She was 54 years old.

title: The U.S. Open Title: One Man's Dream
description: It has been nearly two months since Bjorn Borg's exciting victory over Jimmy Connors for the Wimbledon championship. In the interim, the interest of tennis fans has been centered on either World Team Tennis or the outdoor summer circuit.

title: Beame's Six Opponents in Primary Are Taking Different Stances in Response to S.E.C. Charges
description: With the stinging Securities and Exchange Commission report on the actions of Mayor Beanie and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin bound to have an impact on a close Democratic mayoral primary, six primary opponents of the Mayor began yesterday taking different tacks in an effort to turn the report into votes.

title: Bellamy for Council President
description: The president of the New York City Council is a title more honored than understood. In usual times, the council president is, in effect, the city's vice president and would succeed to the mayor's job in event of a vacancy. The council president occupies the eastern end of City Hall and can use it as a rallying ground for opposition to the mayor. The council president casts as many votes on the city's governing body, the Board of Estimate, as the mayor. And the council president, of course, chairs the council.

title: In the Months Ahead, The Arts Debate Will Center on Populism
description: The new season in the arts opens with a traditional fever of anticipation about the new, and pleasure at revisiting the tested and true. Yet this particular season also opens with some graphic imagery of another, newer, traditionthe funding crisis.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: A New YorkBred Country Star
description: Eddie Rabbitt, whose performance at the Lone Star Cafe on Friday night was broadcast live over radio station WHN, is a New Yorker who went to Nashville to make his reputation. Now, after several country music hits, he is firmly established and can return home in triumph, or something like it. But the fact that he had to launch his career from Nashville says something about country music stereotypes, especially as they relate to New Yorkbred talent.

title: The Region
description: New York City's Democratic mayoral primary is entering its final stages, almost certain to amount only to a qualifying heat. None of the seven candidates is likely to capture the 40 percent of the vote needed for the nomination. As a result, winning isn't everything and may not even be a sign of ultimate strength. Second place, and with it qualification for a runoff, may be as important.

title: Walker Cup Is Retained By U.S., 168
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug, 27The United States retained the most highly prized international amateur golf trophy today as its team completed a twoday domination of Britain's golfers and won the Walker Cup for the 23d time.

title: Frank Vincent Floriani Marries Carol L. Reo
description: Carol Louise Reo, daughter of Mrs. John Trainor of Wyckoff, N.Y., and the late Joseph J. Reo, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank Vincent Floriani, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Floriani of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. Giles Bello performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Elizabeth in Wyckoff. The bride had her cousin, Joan Avignone, as maid of honor. Frank V. Floriani Jr. was his brother's best man.

title: Hanging Out And Hanging In
description: THE summer of 1977 has been loaded with deadly surprises. One has been Son of Sam, stalking victims on the sidewalks of New York. Another, the blackout, which touched off massive looting and a breakdown in services and took a big bite out of the Big Apple's morale.

title: Pop: A Mixed Bag of Treats For a Mixed Audience
description: Predicting the future in popular music is a quirky business. Nobody, from artists to executives to critics, really has any idea what is likely to happen. Record release schedules and tour plans are either tightly guarded secrets or meaningless speculations, vague at best and downright misleading at worst. And in terms of trends, the music is so volatile, at least when looked at up close, that little of significance can be said.

title: Runners Poised for Fall Races
description: WESTPORT WHEN the Roadrunners program began here 16 summers ago, organizers were happy to attract even 15 athletes to a weekly race. This summer 99 runners of all ages, shapes and sexes showed up for a 3.25mile jaunt at 8 A.M. on a Saturday. Last year Westport's Labor Day 10miler, now one of the top road races in the East, drew 260 runners, more than three times the total of a decade before.

title: Women Executives Speak Up
description: FARMINGDALE TO THE casual observer, the existence of Faculty Wives' Clubs, Ladies' Day programs at professional society meetings or even Secretary Days, when male bosses are expected to honor their female secretaries, may not be offensive. But to 10 Long Island women executives, such institutions are indicative of a prevailing climate in the local business and professional community.

title: Look Who's Waiting In the Wings
description: Hair, Biltmore, Sept. 14.

title: The FourDay Work Week: A MuchPraised Idea That Few Want to Hire
description: The fourday week, the most discussed work innovation of the decade, is getting nowhere, despite the fact that the idea has caught the imagination of workers and theorists.

title: Sexual Bias In Medicine
description: DURING a protracted wait in my gynecolo. gist's inner office not long ago, I picked up a book from his desk called Search the Scriptures: Modem Medicine and Biblical Personages, by Dr. Robert B. Greenblatt (Lippincott). Noting that the first edition (1963) had sold 100,000 copies, and that this was the sixth printing of the second edition (1968), I was curious to see what new doors to the Bible can be flung open in the light of modern scientific knowledge and curious to see what my own doctor reads in his spare time. Here are a few of the passages I jotted down:

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Although instant cameras have been around for years, they suddenly seem omnipresent. Perhaps it was the impetus given them when Kodak introduced their models to compete with the Polaroids that originally had the field to themselves, or perhaps it is because television and magazine advertising seems to be currently saturating the photographic market. At any rate, the cameras look so simple and seem to provide what everybody wants: instant gratification for their efforts.

title: Article 4  No Title
Follow The Lieder
description: SCHUBERT'S SONGS

title: Three Novels
description: YOU worry a little at the start of this book, with its rapidfire chatter about a magazine executive who suffers an embolism while returning from an alcoholic brawl of a sales meeting. But once Pete Gilliam is his own man, having resigned from his job and settled down in the woods to write a novel, the flip tone fades out almost completely and we end up feeling more involved with him.

title: U.S. Checking Report Of Missing Tourists
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (Reuters)Reports that three American tourists are missing in Uganda and may have been beheaded are being urgently checked out through diplomatic channels, the State Department said today.

title: LI. BUSINESSWOMEN FORM AN ASSOCIATION
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I. To the casual observer, the existence of Faculty Wives' Clusbs, Ladies' Day programs at professional society meetings or even Secretary Days, when male bosses are expected to honor their female secretaries, may not be offensive. But to 10 Long Island women executives, such institutions are indicative of a prevailing climate in the local business and professional community

title: Sports: Very Big League Economically
description: Julius Erving, the basketball player, calls it the toytrainsinthebasement syndrome. It is a wellknown phenomenon, the seemingly irresistible urge of the rich and powerful to dabble in the business of sports. That urge has been particularly insistent in the region lately and it has raised questions about the importance of sports to the area's economic wellbeing.

title: Backers of Socialist Suit Say U.S. Is Withholding Documents
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)Financial backers of the Socialist Workers Party lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation say that the Carter Administration is using every available means to avoid disclosing files that may show F.B.I. wrongdoing.

title: Special Paris Report
description: Walk around Paris and look at the way people look. This is the French fashion magazine of today. Sit in a cafe in St.GermaindesPrs, Avenue Victor Hugo, Les Halles or Avenue Montaigne. In each place, you might as well be on a different planet, so different are the fashion points of view. And each is right. Fashion, that ever downgraded commodity, has become the fastest form of communication since Morse code. Each person's way of dressing tells you exactly what his or her convictions are. No words are necessary.

title: Scientists Have Had Recent Success With a Drug Derived From Sponge
description: WASHINGTONBecause of the incredible scientific sophistication of modern medicine, allusions to folk cures and herbal nostrums are generally relegated to the exaggeration of the snake oil pitchman. But the derivation of potent drugs from natural substances such as the leaves of plants has a long and impressive record of success.

title: 8 in Family Die in Headon Crash
description: SCIPIO, Utah, Aug. 27 (UPI)Eight members of a vacationing California family were killed yesterday when a tractortrailer ran headon into their van on rainslick U.S. 91 near this westcentral Utah town. They were identified as Farrel A. Lee Jr., 34 years old, of Newbury Park, Calif.; his wife, Elaine, 30; and their children, John, 7; Mark, 6; Suzane, 5; Patricia, 3; Scott, 2, and Mike, eight months.

title: Campuses Humming Into the Night
description: DOBBS FERRY IT was a familiar suburban campus scene: busy parking lots, the cafeteria a focus of activity, knots of students comparing notes or chat ting between classes and the classrooms in full session. The one difference at Mercy College was that it was all taking place at night.

title: FRESH AIR FUND HAS A RECORD 100TH YEAR
description: Modest acts of giving by individual contributors to the Fresh Air Fund have multiplied into a record of $1,005,000 this fiscal year, providing the best sort of birthday present for the fund on its centennial.

title: Drought Imperils SubSahara Area
description: PARIS, Aug, 27 (AP)Extraordinarily low rainfall in nations near the Sahara in West Africa is beginning to create conditions reminiscent of the early days of the great drought that ended in 1974.

title: Vilas Keeps Up Streak
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 27Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, playing well enough to win, scored his second victory in the $25,000 Lionel Tennis Week open roundrobin tournament today. He beat Matt Mitchell of Palo Alto, Calif., the National Collegiate champion, 6.2, 6.2, at the Westchester Country Club.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE LARDNERS, by Ring Lardner Jr. (Harper/Colophon, $4.95.) One aspect of this family memoir is a portrait of Ring Lardner (18551933), author of some of the best writing about the American scene since Mark Twain, as a young newspaperman in love, as a straitlaced yet loving father of four sons who all grew up to be writers, as a celebrity losing a long battle with alcohol. Another aspect shows Ring Jr., a successful screenwriter, bitter over his imprisonment as one of the Hollywood Ten.

title: LETTERS
description: It was good to see the point made in Grace Lichtenstein's article on The Battle Over the Mighty Colorado (July 31) that Easterners are more dependent upon the waters of the West than many realize.

title: Why Don's You Really Come Home?
description: EVER since he settled in a hilltop town on Mount Carmel a reN years ago, Hillel Halkin, a young American, immigrant to Israel, has cast wry but loving looks at the human scene unfolding daily before his eyes. His choice of Zichron Ya'akov as a place to live and work (he is a wellknown translator of modern Hebrew novels into English) and as an observation point from which to view a society maddeningly, obscured by media stereotype and patriotic clichs, was unusual. It neither a kibbutz nor one of the other main centers of attraction for American settlers in Israel. Most Americans choose to settle in the concrete helterskelter of Tel Aviv, or in the concave mirror land of Jerusalem, where the living have always been disenfranchised by the dead and the overwhelming tyranny of the past periodically breeds illusionist politics.

title: Article 1  No Title
Half of 1976 Murder Victims Had Police Records
description: A new profile of murder victims in New York Citydisclosing, for the first time, that half of all victims had prior arrest recordshas emerged from a Police Department analysis of homicides committed here last year.

title: Vintage Baseball Without Frills
description: WEST HAVEN CERTAINLY the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Indians wouldn't dare venture out under these lights, particularly against a fastball pitcher with a penchant for wildness. Yet, out on the dimly lit field, as big as life to the 500 or so fans (who can all see the players closeup no matter where they're sitting), there they are  the Yankees in their pin stripes and the Indians in their black doubleknit uniforms that make them look like a neighborhood tavern team in a slowpitch softball league.

title: Alice Bradford Griswold Is Wed To Basil Stetson Jr., Denver '76
description: Alice Bradford Griswold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Griswold Jr. of Litchfield and Norfolk, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday in Litchfield to Basil Wise Stetson Jr., son of Mrs. Stetson of Princeton, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mr. Stetson. The Rev. David Gurniak performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Episcopal Church.

title: Education
description: Last April, the United States Supreme Court ruled that the use of corporal punishmentin this case, paddlingby a Miami junior high school did not violate the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishments.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Tomorrow the New York Yankees meet the Kansas City Royals at the Stadium at 2 P.M. The game is a makeup of one postponed July 25. The teams are battling for the flag in the Eastern and Western Divisions, respectively. Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M. the Yankees face the Seattle Mariners before opening a road trip in Bloomington, Minn., against the Twins on Friday. The New York Mets open a threegame stand Friday night at 8 P.M. at Shea Stadium against the Atlanta Braves. The teams will also meet Saturday and Sunday afternoons at 2 P.M.

title: BERMUDA BERMUDA BERMUDA
Letters: Riders Rate European Train Trips
description: To the Editor:

title: Carla J. Splittorf Married to Dennis J. Kutney
description: In the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Carla Jean Splittorf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Splittorf of Greenwich, became the bride of Dennis John Kutney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Kutney of Langhorne, Pa.

title: Governor to Head History Study
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27 (AP)Mills Godwin, the Governor of Virginia, has been named chairman of a major educational conference that will mark the start of a 13year study of events that followed the American Revolution. The conference, to be held Nov. 13 to 15 in York, Pa., is to include some 200 local, state and national leaders. Similar conferences will be held in each of the ensuing 12 years. Mr. Godwin's selection as conference chairman was announced Wednesday.

title: Cosmos Going for Title No. 2 Today
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 27In the 11year history of the North American Soccer League no team has won the championship twice. The Cosmos and Dol have an opportunity, to change that tomorrow when they meet the Seattle Sounders here for the league tide.

title: $100,000 BAIL SET ON MAN SUSPECTED AS ARSONIST
description: A Queens man who officials say they suspect had set 1,000 fires in the borough in the last 15 years was arrested early yesterday by fire marshals, according to Frank D. Doyle, special assistant to the Fire Commissioner.

title: Overdose of Salt Blamed in Death Of a 6yearOld Boy in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP)An overdose of salt has been blamed for the death of a 6yearold boy who always salted his water, milk, pop, Koolaid and every other liquid, as well as his food, according to his foster parents.

title: ART
description: NEWARK THIS CITY is not often without a cultural event of estimable stature. Even when there is no concert or art show or other cultural diversion, there is the city, which has architecture of extraordinary variety and of dignified historical importance.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON THERE is a weirdly uncanny kinship between the photographs of Lilo Raymond and Mike Disfarmer at the Port Washington Public Library. Although Mr. Disfarmer's pictures were taken during the 30's and 40's and Miss Raymond's in this decade, they both exhibit a related formality that easily spans their age difference.

title: Cheever, at 19, Is Making His Debut in U.S. Today
description: By the time the Grand Prix circus comes to Watkins Glen, N. Y., in early October, another American driver may he a regular in the Formula I machines. Some of his countrymen may not recognize him as an American, however. The driver is Eddie Cheever who was born in Phoenix, but has lived in Italy since he was 2 years old. He is a hot property in European road racing, and he says he is close to a deal with a major Grand Prix team for the remainder of the season.

title: THE HACKER WHO WON AT FOREST HILLS
description: I won at Forest Hills last year. You thought Jimmy Connors won. Yes, he won the U.S. Open. I won the minitournament for travel writers. Well, actually I tied for first with two other players. And actually, there were only four players altogether.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs.

title: The Nation
description: President Carter has evidently decided that it was not Bert Lance who was at fault in the Bert Lance affair but the banking system in which he operated. In a strong defense of his friend and Budget Director, the President said last week that Mr. Lance had done nothing illegal or even unethical when he headed a bank in Georgia and that there was no reason why he should not stay on in the Administration, But Mr. Carter suggested that some of the common loan practices among bank officers that Mr. Lance followed should be restricted by tighter Federal supervision.

title: Tennis at Forest Hills: Hail and Farewell
description: Forest Hills, we are very old friends. When I was 15 in 1959, game and money a decade away, I suffer?? my first match on your grass. Justina Bricka beat me in the first round. From that initial experience, each year I have returned to you. More often than not, the experience has ended much like the first encounterwith a loss instead of a victory. All the same, I return each year like the prodigal son, because you are the mecca of American tennis.

title: The Fence at Point O'Woods
description: POINT O'WOODS A SIXor sevenfoot fence separates this area from the Fire Island communities to the west, but it is more a symbol than a barrier. Just about anyone can ask a Point O'Woods resident to unlock the gate near Ocean Bay Park, and the resident more times than not will comply with the request.

title: Revolving Doors Are Whirling in Executive Suites
description: Recent days have seen a lot of toplevel job shuffling in executive suites. Perhaps firings and promotions are easier to accomplish when the principals are away on vacation.

title: DINING OUT
description: RAGS always seems to have a lively, bustling hum of activity, a sense of enjoyment that is obvious and infectious. Its popularity stems first of all from the wellplanned menu, which has burgers at $2.50 and runs on up through some imaginatively conceived entries designed to catch the hungry eye.

title: Home Styles
description: Brick is a hot ticket these days, in many areas of construction and design.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH few homes in this area have flat or shedtype roofs over the entire house, many do have this type of roof over an attached garage, family room or extra room that has been added. These flat roofs are usually covered with builtup or rolltype roofing, rather than shingles, and they may or may not have gravel on top.

title: Births
description: Berk

title: Politics And the F. E. C.
description: When public financing of elections was being discussed in the 1960's, I asked Robert Kennedy, then a Senator from New York, what he thought of the idea.

title: Swan Banding Stirs Protests
description: ORIENT ARESEARCH project by a graduate student that involves the neckbanding and legbanding of mute swans in Suffolk County may be halted if legal action planned by a humane organization is successful.

title: FatherandSon Tennis: Love Game
description: Manhasset IT can be exasperating and aggravating, with clashes of temperament. Yet it can also be gratifying and rewarding. Sometimes there is the gnashing of teeth in rage; other times, a warm glow of togetherness.

title: FULL SOCIAL SECURITY AT 65 IS NEEDED, CALIFANO SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, says the Federal Government would be breaking a promise to Americans if it decided to withhold full Social Security benefits until recipients reach age 68 years.

title: FLORIDA
HONE CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH few homes in this area have flat or shedtype roofs over the entire house, many do have this type of roof over an attached garage, family room or extra room that has been added. These flat roofs are usually covered with builtup or rolltype roofing, rather than shingles, and they may or may not have gravel on top.

title: Robinson Paces Jets' 2014 Victory
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 27  A reserve quarterback, Matt Robinson, hit Richard Osborne on a 57yard scoring pass to rally the New York Jets to a 2014 victory over the New Orleans Saints in a National Football League exhibition game tonight.

title: Thousands Rally for Equal Rights
description: Thousands of women of different ethnic, economic and cultural backgrounds who had pledged themselves to obtain passage of the Equal Rights Amendment held marches yesterday in New York and other major cities across the nation.

title: Jeffrey Holsapple Weds Debra Sistare
description: Debra Graham Sistare and Jeffrey Best Holsapple, 1972 graduates of St. Paul's School in Concord, N. H., were married there yesterday in the school's Chapel of SS. Peter and Paul by the chaplain, the Rev. Theodore Yardley.

title: WATCH THE JUNIORS! THEY'RE TOMORROW'S CHAMPS
description: As you may have noticed, tennis' top players seem to be getting younger and younger. The average age of the semifinalists in the Wimbledon men's singles this year was 21.5, for example, while the top three winners in women's tennis at midyear (see page 152) averaged an even 21 years of age. So obviously, the place to look for next year'smaybe next month'schampions is in the ranks of today's teenage stars.

title: A Musical ForecastUnsettled But Lively
description: As of this writing, the 197778 music season in New York has a slightly unsettled look. The labor negotiations between the Metropolitan Opera and its many unions are unresolved, and at least once in the past this has resulted in a threemonth delay in the opening of the season. Town Hall has booked several series of events, but the muchloved auditorium is in danger of being transferred by its owner, New York University, to an outfit that would close it to concert activity.

title: POLITICS
description: MAYOR THOMAS F. X. SMITH of Jersey City talked with both major gubernatorial candidates during the last few days to remind them of his hopes for his city and how that might affect their hopes for winning, the November election.

title: THEATER
description: THE Red BlueGrass Western Flyer Show by Conn Fleming and Clint Ballard Jr. will be at the Goodspeed Opera House until Oct. 16. The musical marks John Cullum's fourth association with the Goodspeed. In 1966 he appeared in Engaged; in 1973 El Capitan; and in 1974 he created the role he took to Broadway in Shenandoah.

title: Carter Family Peanut Business To Be Managed by a Cooperative
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 27 (UPI)Gold Kist Inc., an Atlantabased farmers' cooperative, has agreed to take over management of the Carter family's peanut warehousing business and put President Carter's son, Chip on the Payroll.

title: Roslyn: Readers Respond
description: IT'S hard to know where to start a comment on Ken Rawson's analysis. As in a caricature, the subject is recognizable. One or two salient features (the most unattractive ones) are exaggerated, and a host of others are omitted.

title: WHAT'S WHERE IN FOREST HILLS
description: From the air, it resembles nothing so much as a classic case of urban sprawl. The community of Forest Hills (left) in New York City's Borough of Queens is hemmed in by major highways; it's bisected by subway and rail lines; it's a hostage to growing noise and air pollution; and its landscape is increasingly dominated by highrise, highdensity housing. Indeed, it appears at first glance to be typical of the contrasting mix of city and suburb that characterizes the fringes of big cities throughout the U.S.

title: A Mayoralty Enlivens Primary
description: WHITE PLAINS A BATTLE between two Democrats for their party's nomination for Mayor of this city in the Sept. 8 primary has turned out to be about the liveliest primary contest in Westchester, where the lineup in the November election for countywide offices was decided sometime ago at party conventions.

title: Surprising Disks From Familiar Musicians
description: Most musicians dislike being typecast as specialists. and often they will take on a surprising assignment to prove their versatility in repertory not usually associated with them. Frequently, the results are unexpectedly successful, but sometimes it rapidly becomes clear that a firstrate talent has gone astray. The following artistsfour conductors and two singershave all made recent recordings in their fields of proven expertise as well at least one exploration into fresh territory. The blessings, as we shall see, are decidedly mixed.

title: Letters
description: Two Critiques

title: Feminism's Effect on Fashion
description: If a woman came to my office 15 years ago wearing pants, says Dr. Mildred Newman, a wellknown psychoanalyst, I regarded if, in true Freudian tradition , as behavior to be analyzed. In those faraway, prefeminist clays, a woman walking around in pants was considered to be unfeminine, and the psychoanalyst's couch could he the setting for an examination of her identity problems.

title: Miss Chwals Wed To Mark Milligan
description: St. Michael Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Katharine Cecilia Chwals, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Chwals of Greenwich. to Mark Fairbanks Milligan, son of Melvin L. Milligan, also of Greenwich and Kuwait, and Nancy Crandell of Houston. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Thomas P. Guinan. The Rev. Mark Connolly assisted.

title: LANCE'S DISCLOSURE OF ASSETS TO SENATE FOUND INCOMPLETE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  Budget Director Bert Lance apparently failed to disclose all of his financial holdings and debts in a net worth statement submitted to the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee before his confirmation hearings in January, according to a check of records and interviews with Mr. Lance's business associates.

title: VOTERS CITE CONCERN OVER PANAMA CANAL
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., Aug. 27No public issue has more voters in more parts of the country irate than the Panama Canal, at least as far as the questions and speeches they throw at senators and representatives show.

title: Events Today
description: HARLEM WATER BALLET: Ballet performed in the water by boys and girls, ages 6 to 21; 10 A.M. to noon, Lasker Pool, 110th Street off Lenox Avenue.

title: Stamford Is Angel at Sterling Barn
description: Stamford WHENEVER theater folk gather, the same topic inevitably is raised: Should the Government subsidize the performing arts as European Governments do? And the question is examined once again, with neither side convincing the other.

title: Food
description: Cheese, Clifton Fadiman has written. is milk's leap toward immortality. True, perhaps; and more. The transformation that results in cheese is the natural way of keeping excess milk in edible form for years on end. Skillfully mature, and properly protected from atmospheric erosion by airtight wrapping, cheese is a nearperfect food and one that can, and should, be consumed to the last morsel, without any waste whatsoever. The trouble. however, is that too often cheese is discarded when it becomes dry, or because pieces left from the cheese course have been ineptly cut and look unappetizing. Indeed, remnants of Camembert and Brie, once their fluent interiors slip away, do seem to lose all their charm. And firm cheeses, like Cheddar and Colby, are so easily reduced w scatterings of crumbs. Other types, like Port du Salut, end as dried crusts in the refrigerator. But they needn't be cast aside.

title: A Classical Start to an Eclectic Year of Dance Activity
description: Just when it looked as if the dance worldor ballet, at leastwould have its first year in sometime without those glamorous foreign seasons and star appearances so dear to the hearts of all true fans, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C., and our own Metropolitan Opera House have rescued the upcoming dance year by giving New Yorkers two weeks with the Ballet Nacional de Cuba. It promises to be a highlight of the dance year.

title: Major League Averages
description: Records Include Games Played Friday Night

title: THE SELLING OF SOCCERMANIA
description: On the soccer field, your light cleated shoes are really the only piece of equipment. The wind blows through your shirt and around your legs as you run. And you're running all the time, constantly moving, constantly alert. There's an open space. You run into it, creating an outlet for a pass. The ball comes to you. You control it, keep it close, using only your feet, perhaps your chest, never your hands. Hardrunning defenders rush upon you and the field becomes a mass of enemy jerseys. You spot a free teammate off to one side, pass to him, run to him, take a return pass behind the defender, pass it back to your man as he comes running by. The motion is fluid, quick, sudden. One moment a serious attack threatens, in the next everyone is running backward, trying to catch up with a reversal of the play. It's a tense game, a game of configurations forming and reforming, of pressures that build and dissolve, electric instants and fantastic feats of physical agility. There are no timeouts.

title: Food Sales at Sea Provide Bargains For West Germans
description: FLENSBURG, West Germany, Aug. 27 (Reuters)About 200 excursion boats that are really floating grocery stores are doing a brisk trade around the northern coast of West Germany. Millions of West Germans save money on highpriced food and drink on the high seas these days because tariffs make them cheaper than they would be in town.

title: Carol Rivera Bride Of John H. Lawrence
description: The marriage of Carol Aviva Rivera, a 1977 alumna of Vassar College, to John Hilliard Lawrence, who graduated from Vassar in 1975, took place yesterday in Metairie, La, Msgr. Henry C. Bezou performed the ceremony in St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

title: Albany's Mayor Is in a Primary Fight His First in 36 Years in Office
description: ALBANYErastus Corning 2d is running for Mayor.

title: Talk With David Storey, Playwright and Novelist
description: IN England David Storey is commonly regarded as a novelist who also writes plays, in America as a playwright who also writes novels. Actually, in terms of productivity and reputation, he could be considered fulltime in both professions. Nine of his plays have been produced, including In Celebration, Home, The Contractor and The Changing Room (the last three of which were each named Best Play of the Year by the New York Drama Critics' Circle). He has two new plays scheduled for production this season, one of them at Britain's National Theater. At 43, he is one of England's most important dramatists.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Poison Ivy: Scourge For All Seasons
description: POISON ivy, the scourge of the summer, is poisonous all year and it flourishes in New Jersey. The innocentlooking threeleafed plant is most often a trailing vine in this state, but it can also be a small shrub.

title: Dance Theater In Street Games
description: Up From the Streets sought out the dance elements in a dutch of city kids' games and alernated them with mime representations of those very same games. The adults of the Judith Scott Dance Theater did the dancing and a group of children staged the street games at Lincoln Center Plaza early Friday evening as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors.

title: Water Use Restricted For Bay Area Family
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 (AP)A Bay Area couple who gave their flowers and lawn two hours of water a day while their neighbors' lawns turned brown in the prolonged drought have become the first family in the Bay Area to have flow restricters installed on their water line .

title: Schools to Reopen With More Money
description: THE state's publicschool pupils will return to classes next week with more money available for new programs than in recent years. The full effect of revenue from the income tax adopted in July 1976 will be felt for the first time as diverse phases of the thorough and efficient education law passed in 1975 are adopted.

title: Hard Times
description: Another summer camp romance. The starryeyed young couple walks hand in hand in the moonlight and the clean country air of Camp Monroe, 50 miles upstate in the rolling Hudson Highlands. The crickets chirp. The pines rustle. The owls hoot. And the bass guitar thunders. These young lovers are 11 years old, and they are going to the camp's disco.

title: Engagements
description: GussBraxmayer SummerBraxmayer

title: THE SELLING OF THE U.S. OPEN
description: To those who complained last year that Forest Hills had lost its heart, that it had fallen into the hands of impersonal, superefficient businessmen, a word of warning: hold tight because you ain't seen nothin' yet.

title: U.S. Asserts It Headed Off ATest By Pretoria After Soviet Warning
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27The Carter Administration is convinced that it headed off imminent detonation of an atomic device by South Africa through application of concerted diplomatic pressure, after a warning by the Soviet Union, topranking White House officials said today.

title: New Law Stiffens Tests for Drivers
description: TRENTON A NEW driver'slicense law goes into effect Thursday, and each of New Jersey's 4.6 million licensed drivers will be affected. One of the most significant changes will be the requirement that all New Jersey drivers pass eye tests to keep their licenses.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: COLUMBIA, Md.Ten years ago, midway between Washington and Baltimore, people began moving into James W. Rouse's new town of Columbia. It was heralded as an innovative approach by the real estate developer toward providing a selfcontained racially and economically mixed community. Columbia has partly lived up to expectations, Its racial mix has been maintained, for example, with a black population exceeding 20 percent. By comparison, the rest of Maryland's Howard County is only 6 percent black.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Some time ago the television show Kojak used as a plot device a murder in a company headed by a man with a secret identity. He had been a witness against an organizedcrime chief, and the Justice Department had provided him, and his family, with a new identity. Only the discovery that his family's Social Security numbers had been issued in sequential order gave the disguise away.

title: NEW YORK TOUGHENS SOLIDWASTE RULES
description: ALBANY, Aug. 27New, tough regulations governing the construction and operation of landfills, incinerators and other solidwaste disposal facilities throughout New York State, including New York City and the suburbs, will go into effect tomorrow.

title: F.B.I. Nominee in Surgery
description: Frank M. Johnson, who was chosen by President Carter only a week ago as the new head of the Federal Bureau of investigation, has undergone surgery to remove an aneurysm in his abdomen. An aneurysm is a ballooning of a blood vessel that can be serious, but its surgical removal is a relatively routine operation. An Administration spokesman said the operation might prompt a request for a delay in Mr. Johnson's confirmation hearings, though doctors were certain Mr. Johnson would be fully recovered within six weeks. If confirmed, Mr. Johnson will take office Jan. 1

title: Article 2  No Title
Golf
description: AT PINEHURST.N. C.

title: HANS A. REY, AUTHOR AND ILLUSTRATOR, DIES
description: Hans A. Rey, who with his wife wrote and illustrated the seven Curious George books and more than 20 other books for children, died Friday night at Beth Israel hospital in Boston. He was 78 years old.

title: Concert and Opera Events
description: The New York City Opera opens with Mefistofele, Aug. 31.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Dance Meet

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: RETAIL sales, which represent about a third of the nation's gross national product, are proving puzzling, if not enigmatic, for those trying to discern a clear trend line.

title: THE CONFESSIONS OF A FOREST HILLS BALLBOY
description: The red plastic geraniums across the court caught my eye. I looked to the right. Twelve thousand people and r watched Jimmy Connors bounce a yellow tennis ball and twist to serve. Thwop! The ball smacked the tape and dropped to the gritty HarTru surface. Milliseconds passed. Then it clicked: it was my job to pick up that ball.

title: China Studying Yugoslav System In Effort to Motivate Its Workers
description: PEKING, Aug. 27China's practical new leaders are studying the Yugoslav system of worker selfmanagement in an effort, evidently, to find a new way to motivate the country's dissatisfied factory workers and speed economic growth, a knowledgable source here disclosed today.

title: Everybody's Polish as 50,000 Attend Annual Festival in Riverhead
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.If they weren't working saucersize Kiss me, I'm Polish buttons, their red and white Tshirts read Polish Power, or some varlant. Some young people sprayed Polish eagle designs on their long, shiny hair. It was the third annual Polish Town Fair here, and families came from as far ad, well, Staten Island, to affirm their ethnic heritage.

title: Reagan On Panama
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27There is nothing more depressing in politics than old men crying for a world that is gone and risking wars young men would have to fight. Yet this is what Ronald Reagan did in his Panama Canal speech to the Young Americans for Freedom the other day in New York.

title: Being Queen Wasn't Enough
description: THERE are few things more tranquil, more graceful and more enigmatic than the royal effigies of the Middle Ages. Yet nowhere is the contrast more marked between the sweet grace of the effigy and the turbulent course of the life than with Eleanor, Duchess of Aquitaine, the intriguing subject of this new biography by Marion Meade, author of a biography of Victoria Woodhull, who became in 1872, the first woman candidate for President.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The written histories of wars and revolutions are clear and unambiguous. Since they are written the winners, the losers are always wrong. Photographs, however, even when taken by the winners, preserve something of the contemporary reality that comes directly to the modern viewer without passing through the mind of the photographer. Old photographs often say things about the past that were neither seen nor intended by the photographer.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The railroad problem will not go away. It is still here, despite massive efforts by Congress in the last four years to revitalize the industry and reform its economic regulation.

title: Ion Grumeza,Writer, Weds Lynn Barrett
description: In the Grafton (Vt.) Community Church yesterday, Lynn Scarlett Barrett of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Robinson Barrett Jr. of Grafton and Westfield, NJ., was married to Ion Grumeza, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Grumeza of Muscel, Rumania.

title: Stenmark Takes Skiing
description: THREDBO, Australia, Aug. 27 (UPI) Sweden won the Thredbo Cup today when the reigning World Cup ski champion, Ingemar Stenmark, beat a teammate, Torsten Jakobssen, to take honors in the International Skiing Federation international slalom.

title: Yale Chooses Two New Trustees
description: Yale University has chosen two new trustees, Barbara Scott Preiskel. a New York City lawyer, and Joseph Hill Williams, an Oklahoma industrial leader. Both of the new trustees for the 17member Yale Corporation were selected to serve 12year terms. Mrs. Preiskel, a black Yale Law School graduate and a member of the directors of the American Civil Liberties Union. will become the second woman currently acting as a trustee for Yale. Mr. Williams. also a Yale graduate, is president of a firm that specializes in agricultural chemicals in addition to being an independent pipeline operator and a producer and a marketer of oil and gas.

title: Beanie's Statement on the S.E.C. Report
description: The S.E.C. report has made charges which are wholly inconsistent with the voluminous facts as presented or with the lengthy sworn testimony given at its hearings.

title: TV: The Networks Slug It Out
description: On the night of Labor Day, ABC, CBS and NBC together will unleash a fusillade of weekly series, floating series, rotating series, backup series, crosspollinating series, blockbuster movies, ersatz movies, serialized novels, docudramas, pageants, sports spectaculars, championship ballgames and a miscellany labeled events.

title: Miss Cooper, H. S. Sherrill Have Nuptials
description: Alexandra Vaughan Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Kirkland Cooper of Pembroke, Bermuda, was married there yesterday to H. Sinclair Sherrill, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Henry W. Sherrill of Lancaster, N.H. Canon Maurice Wheatley performed the ceremony in St. John's Anglican Church.

title: SHOPTALK
description: ARE you searching desperately for a goosefeather baster to glaze your duck a l'orange? And with strawberries still in season, don't you wish you had a strawberry huller? Don't you want bamboo barbecue sticks?

title: Questions/Answers
description: POPLAR TREE ROOTS

title: THEATER
description: THE Red BlueGrass Western Flyer Show by Conn Fleming and Clint Ballard Jr. will be at the Goodspeed Opera House until Oct. 16. The musical marks John Cullum's fourth association with the Goodspeed. In 1966 he appeared in Engaged; in 1973 El Capitan; and in 1974 he created the role he took to Broadway in Shenandoah.

title: FISHING
description: SCHOOLS of giant bluefin tuna are creating spectacular scenes off Block Island. breaking water in feeding frenzies behind trawlers dragging for ling and whiting. This is some of the finest and biggest action to be found anywhere in the world's oceans.

title: Jazz: Serenading The Rock Fans
description: For the first time in almost 20 years, jazz is riding a wave of popularity. The audience for jazz, it is generally agreed, is getting bigger.

title: Banding Of Swans Is Fought
description: ORIENT, L.I.A research project by a graduate student that involves the neckbanding and legbanding of mute swans in Suffolk County may be halted if legal action planned by a humane organization is successful.

title: SIX WOMEN TESTIFY IN TEXAS PHONE SUIT
description: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 27 The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, under attack for discharging one executive and allegedly driving another to suicide, hasdefended itself in court with the testimony of six women who told of sexual encounters with the two men.

title: Article 5  No Title
Gozzi Wins Class Honors at Nassau Show
description: WESTBURY, LI., Aug. 27The script was a familiar one when the regular workinghunter championship results were announced at the Nassau County horse show today. Gozzi was the champion and Riot Free was the reserve champion.

title: GARDENING
description: IN May, a great variety of lilacs put on such a display at Skylands Botanical Garden in Ringwood Park that I have had lilacs on my mind all summer, particularly those comparatively small, seldomseen lilacs that extend the bloom season.

title: Changes in the System Are Under Serious Consideration
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee calls back Budget Director Bert Lance for a third round of questioning on Sept. 7, not only his personal finances and his banks but the Senate confirmation process itself will be under review.

title: Toma, Miniature Pinscher, Treated Royally on Riviera
description: Ch. Repeage's Toma is probably the only American dog to receive flowers from a princess or dine on a cushion in a plush Riviera restaurant. The sleek eightpounder has been setting records in this country and abroad as one of the outstanding black and tan miniature pinschers in the history of the breed. His toy group victory this month at Sand and Sea capped an eventful summer highlighted by consecutive successes at the Monaco, San Remo and Nice allbreed shows. Toma was the only dog brought over from the United States especially for the European competitions.

title: Whether for Love Or Money, Demand For Ivory Soars
description: Wealthy Sudanese tribesmen bequeath it to their loved ones. Canny Hong Kong financiers hoard it against hard times. Trendy East Side boutique people prize it for, among other things, its sensuously slippery feel.

title: MONSOON GIVES INDIA A GOOD CROP OUTLOOK
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 27For the third year in a row, India has had a good monsoon. Normal to heavy rains have been reported in almost all areas, assuring good crops.

title: Young Conservatives Elect a Buckley as Leader
description: After three days of conventioneering in New York City, the country's largest conservative youth group yesterday elected a young cousin of former Senator James L. Buckley as its national chairman.

title: Classified Material Believed Safe In U.S. Embassy Fire in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 27Ambassador Malcolm Toon said today that he did not beieve any classified material had been compromised as a result of a fire that ravaged the uppermost floors of the United States Embassy building here for more than nine hours last night and this morning.

title: INTERVIEW
description: HARTFORD WHAT you really need for this job is the widom of Solomon and Kissinger's training in shuttle diplomacy, Howard Klebanoff said as he shook his head and reviewed what he sees as the hurdles and obligations before him in his new job as chairman of the State Board of Higher Education.

title: The Standings
description: Sunday, August 28, 1977

title: Vincent C. Duffy, a Retired Judge And Police Recorder in Paterson
description: Vincent C. Duffy, a retired Passaic County judge, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Paterson.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine A. Savage, Nurse, Is Bride of James D. Crandell
description: Catherine Ann Savage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Savage of Westfield, N. J., was married yesterday to James David Crandell, son of Mrs. James L. Crandell of Westhampton, L. L, and the late Mr. Crandell. The Rev. Richard Smith performed the ceremony in Westfield Presbyterian Church.

title: Notes: Tourism Under Attack
description: The worldwide tourist industry should end its dangerous overexploitation of the environment and assume increasing responsibility for guarding each country's resources instead of being the great spoliator, the International Association of Scientific Tourism Experts was told at a recent meeting in Athens.

title: Depressing Trade Statistics
description: This country's trade accounts have been written in red ink for more than a year, and last week the Commerce Department released figures showing that the deficit in July was the fourth worst on record.

title: Bakke Reverse Bias Case Backed By Young Americans for Freedom
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 27 (AP)The young Americans for Freedom has filed a friend of the court brief supporting a white applicant for medical school whose reverse discrimination case is before the United States Supreme Court.

title: DINING OUT
description: HAD anyone proclaimed, two years ago, that there would soon be a handsome new restaurant on the banks of the Hackensack River in Secaucus, he would have been considered to have been playing without a full deck. Yet that is exactly what has happened.

title: Newport Jews Want Delay in Election That Falls on Rosh haShanah
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27  Jewish voters in this home of the nation's oldest synagogue are counting on a civil rights action by the State Attorney General to force postponement of the Sept. 13 municipal election, which falls on Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year.

title: New Orleans District Elects Republican to Congress
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 27Robert L. Livingston Jr. tonight became the first Republican elected to the House from the First Congressional District here since Reconstruction, easily winning a special election called to choose a successor to former Representative Richard A. Tonry.

title: A Winner Needs to Put Together Artfully a Combination of Jewish, Irish, Italian, Black and Puerto Rican Voters
description: New York City, unlike most other cities, has a broad blend of religious, racial and ethnic groups that make up its electorate. To win an election in the city, a candidate has to put together the best combination of these diverse and politically powerful groups  Jews, Irish and Italian Catholics, blacks and Puerto Ricans. In the Democratic mayoral campaign this year, one of the important reasons none of the candidates has a substantial advantage at this stage is that the vote still seems to be fragmented among these groups.

title: PINOCHET AND VIDELA TO VISIT WASHINGTON
