description: State Senator Joseph Galiber and Robert Munoz, the former director of a Bronx drug rehabilitation program, along with three other persons, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States through a realestate scheme financed by antipoverty funds.

title: Eight Years of Hanks Charm Proved a Boon to All the Arts
description: Nancy Hanks, retiring as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts after eight productive years, is not herself a practitioner of any of the arts. But there is one thing on which all are agreed. Miss Hanks has carried the techniques of political persuasion to a level that is itself high art.

title: Texas Woman Fights Extradition In Imprisoning of Mental Cases
description: LOS ANGELES. Aug. 29 (UPI)Lillian Gobert, 42 years old, told a judge today that she would fight extradition to Texas, where she is wanted for allegedly imprisoning 12 mentally deficient persons in a small roachinfested house in an alleged plot to steal their pension checks.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Tuesday. Aug. 30 (Reuters)President Tito of Yugoslavia was given a huge reception when he arrived here today on his first visit to Poking.

title: 2 SUITS IN DETROIT AREA ASSAIL BANNING OF SIGNS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 29Federal and state courts were asked in two lawsuits today to strike down as unconstitutional a zoning ordinance in suburban Oak Park that bans posting of all signs on residential properties, on the ground that the ordinance violates the First Amendment's right to freedom of speech.

title: Carter to Seek Wheat Acreage Cut
People in Sports
description: The Mets recalled Jackson Todd from their Tidewater farm club in the International League yesterday. The rookie righthander, who had won his first two games before losing his next three, was sent to Tidewater on July 29 after the Mets had reactivated Bob Myrick. Todd had a 23 wonlost record in nine games with the Tides.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Notes on People
description: G. Gordon Liddy's Sept. 7 parole will not be held up even though he led a recent prison farm cafeteria strike and, it was disclosed yesterday, concealed a club and a lead pipe in his cell, apparently for protection against other inmates at the farm in Allenwood, Pa. Joseph A. Nardoza, regional parole commissioner for the Federal prison system in Philadelphia, said that Allenwood officials who reported the pipe and club did not recommend a penalty against Mr. Liddy, the last of the Watergate burglars still in jail. His 20year sentence was commuted to eight years by President Carter; he has been in jail for narly four and a half years. Mr. Liddy was transferred out of the Allenwood facility after the food boycott, and officials found the weapons in his cell. The same officials also said that Mr. Liddy's transfer to the medium security prison at Danbury, Conn., was sufficient punishment for his part in the cafeteria strike. I think he has served long enough, said Mr. Nardoza.

title: Chief Spokesman for the Port Authority Suspended For Submitting False Entries on Expense Accounts
description: John Tillman, chief spokesman for the Port Authroity of New York and New Jersey, was suspended from his $55,000 ayearjob yesterday after he conceded that he had been padding his expense accounts since he took the post three years ago, billing for fictitious dinners and drinks with public officials and news reporters and their families.

title: Chase Denies S.E.C.'s Charge That It Dumped City's Securities
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, making its first comment on a critical Securities and Exchange Commission report issued Friday, denied yesterday that it had dumped New York City securities in late 1974 and early 1975.

title: Experts Says Carter Land SetAside Plan Could Stabilize Grain Prices
description: President Carter's decision yesterday to reimpose the old soil bank programnow termed a setaside plancame as no surprise to the grain trade.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR THE RECORD For nearly a century Grove's Dictionary in its various editions has been tile standard reference work on music in English. The sixth edition is forthcoming next yearhence something different in the way of admissionfree lectures today at 4 P.M. at Lincoln Center.

title: EDITH MAAS LINCOLN, DOCTOR, DIES AT 86
description: Dr. Edith Maas Lincoln, who as head of the chest clinic of the children's medical service at Bellevue Hospital Center pioneered in using drugs to treat tuberculosis, died Sunday at her home in North Salem, N.Y. The widow of Dr. Asa L. Lincoln, a physician who died in 1974, she was 86 years old.

title: U.S. INVESTMENT ABROAD INCREASED 10% LAST YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)Direct investment abroad by United States concerns rose 10 percent last year to $137.2 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTEY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Westchester Plans to Act
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 29The Westchester County District Attorney said today he would move within the next month to seek indictments against Mr. Berkowitz on charges of illegal possession of weapons and attempted arson.

title: More Cases in South
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 29 (AP)The national Center for Disease Control says that there are so many reported cases of Rocky Mountain spotted fever in the South that the infecton seems to be misnamed.

title: People and Business
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits warned yesterday of a worldwide depression in two or three years unless steps were quickly taken to shore up the international economic system.

title: Mamaroneck's Cat Burglar Case Closed as Suspect Dies of Wounds
description: The police in Mamaroneck, N. Y., closed the books on their yearlong investigation of a cat burglar after the suspect died Saturday night. Gilbert Phillips, 39 years old, of New Rochelle, an employee of the LarchmontMamaroneck Joint Sanitation Commission, had been shot two weeks ago, after he stabbed a police officer who was trying to arrest him on trespassing charges.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAUSALITO, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI) This picturesque community on the bay north of San Francisco was blacked out early today when a series of explosions. apparently touched off by terrorist saboteurs, blew up an electrical substation.

title: AUSTRALIA INVESTIGATES CHARGES ON SALMONELLA
description: CANBERRA, Australia. Aug. 29 (AP)The Australian Government has ordered a thorough investigation into the allegation that Australian beef may have been responsible for an outbreak of salmonella food poisoning in the Northeastern United States.

title: Strife in Sri Lanka Abates, but the Tensions Persist
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 29Ethnic violence has shattered the tropical tranquillity of this lush and lazy island republic, bringing to a boil a longsimmering hostility, In 10 days, 100 peoplemostly members of the Tamil minorityhave been killed and thousands driven from their homes, vowing never to return.

title: They're Making Their Own Pitch And Loving It
description: Victor Potamkin isn't an expert on models, but he figures that most of them don't look like Cadillacs. Maybe Volkswagens or Toyotas, he said. Mr. Potamkin is the largest Cadillac dealer in the country.

title: An East German Poet Goes to West Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP)Sarah Kirsch, one of East Germany's most popular poets has arrived in West Berlin as a selfexile, a spokesman for the Association of German Writers said today.

title: Todd XRays Show Thumb Not Broken
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 29Xravs of Richard Todd's jammed right thumb were negative, the Jets announced today, and Coach Walt Michaels had a ready answer on the quarterback's availability against the Giants next Sunday.

title: European Currency Pact Wanes as Mark Gains
description: Paris, Aug. 29The European currency snake is getting thinner and thinner, largely because West Germany's economy is getting fatter and fatter.

title: DEMAND OVER FORCES SNAGS RHODESIA PLAN
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 29  A proposal to suspend and eventually deactivate the forces opposing each other in the Rhodesian guerrilla war continued to be the main sticking point today as British and American diplomats presented their settlement package to Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, who holds the key to Rhodesian acceptance of the plan.

title: U. N. BEGINS A PARLEY ON SPREAD OF DESERTS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 29The battle to protect and possibly enlarge the world's dwindling supply of fertile land reached a key stage today as politicians and scientists from more than 90 countries met here for the opening session of the United Nations Conference on Desertification.

title: Peter Altmeier, 79, Helped Draft Postwar Charter for West Germany
description: COBLENZ, West Germany, Aug. 28 (AP) Peter Altmeier, former president of the West German state of RhinelandPalatinate and one of the drafters of the West German Constitution, died today. He was 79.

title: Market Place
description: It is a problem faced by thousands of investors who have losses in shares of companies that are no longer traded. In some cases, the companies in question are bankrupt. In other instances, there may be substantial assets but, for one reason or another, market makers are not active in the shares.

title: A Soviet Scientist Sees Official Drive To Discredit Him
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29The most prominent Soviet scientist to apply to emigrate to Israel said today he feared that a recent newspaper article denouncing him might be only the beginning of an officially sanctioned campaign to discredit his reputation.

title: Court Bars Use of Confessions In Georgia Black's Murder Trial
description: DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 29Confessions and statements allegedly implicating five black youths in the murder of an elderly white ranch foreman were ruled inadmissible as evidence today by a judge who cited a technical error in procedure.

title: RICHARD C. ROBEY
description: Dr. Richard C. Robey, since 1976 a professor of American studies and high education at Newark College of Rutgers University, died Sunday in Clara Mass Hospital, Belleville, N. J., of a massive brain hemorrhage suffered 10 days earlier. He was 42 years old and lived at 417 Riverside Drive.

title: Man Pleads No Contest to Charge Of Transporting Money in Murder
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Aug. 29 (AP)The man accused of masterminding the murder and multimilliondollar robbery of Marjorie V. Jackson, a wealthy widow, pleaded no contest today to Federal charges stemming from the case.

title: Yanks Win on Pinch Clout, 53
description: Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, didn't want Whitey Herzog, the Kansas City manager, to go fishing in the pond they share in Kansas City. He would have gotten ahead of me, Martin said, explaining why the Yankees made the Royals pay a oneday visit to Yankee Stadium yesterday to play a makeup game.

title: Meany, in a Gain for Carter, Endorses New Treaty on Panama Canal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  George Means, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O. and usually a hardliner on international affairs, said today he supported President Carter's treaty ceding the Panama Canal to the Panamanian Government at the end of the century.

title: Quake Kills 2 in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug 29 (Reuters) A strong earthquake killed two persons and injured 25 on tiny Atauro Island off the Indonesian province of East Timor on Saturday, the meteorological office here said today.

title: PENALTIES WILL BE HIGHER FOR ILLEGAL DISMISSALS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)The National Labor Relations Board is making it costlier for employers and unions to discharge workers illegally or otherwise discriminate against them.

title: Csonka Seems Worried
description: Larry Csonka played little more than a quarter and gained only 6 yards on four carries. He said his left knee, which underwent surgery last year, did not pain him, but he seemed worried that he might have lost a step because of it. I was so bad, he said...Kotar, playing for the first time since suffering a mild concussion two weeks ago, was the Giants leading rusher and passcatcher with 18 carries for 60 yards and five receptions for 54.

title: For Flushing Airport
description: It could be argued that Flushing Airport in Queens doesn't make enough money for New York City and that by turning the 80acre site over to property developers more revenue could be generated. But there are other less easily measured benefits derived from this piece of land that in more than 52 years of operation has cost nary one cent of taxpayer money.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: W. R. Grace & Company announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Energy Research and Development Administration for a program aimed at developing commercial manufacture of ammonia from coal.

title: Lawsuit Speeds H.E.W. Audit of Harvard Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Department of Health, Education and Welfare disclosed today that Federal auditors had begun checking the way Harvard University spent about $200 million in Government grants and contracts over the last three years.

title: Wildwood Lifeguards Snub Offer
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, Aug. 29The Wildwood Beach Patrol, which was dismissed after ignoring a backtowork order after a oneday sickout, rejected today an offer by the state to drop charges against 58 of the lifeguards if four others would plead guilty to contempt of court.

title: GIGANTE HOLDS FIRM TO CLERIC'S PRIVILEGE
description: The Rev. Louis R. Gigante, after testifying yesterday for several hours before a special grand jury investigating his relationship to organized crime figures, said he would go to prison rather than violate the right of priestly confidentiality. The jury is looking into reports of bribery, official misconduct and conspiracy relating to favored treatment for prisoners in the custody of the New York City Department of Correction.

title: Elderly Women: Myths, Stereotypes and Positive Predictions for the Future
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29The stereotype of the old woman in this country depicts her as unintelligent, incompetent and unattractive. But at a symposium of the American Psychological Association being held here this week, the panelists  while recognizing her present plight  found themselves irrepressibly hopeful about her future.

title: Carter Not Noticeably Disturbed By Lance Controversy, Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29A White House spokesman said today that President Carter was taking an equanimous view of the controversy over his old friend, Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: STEEL OUTPUT ROSE 2.5% TO 2.4 MILLION TONS IN WEEK
description: With industry vacations ended, steel production rose in the week ended Aug. 27 by 2.5 percent and reached 2.4 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Pisarcik Stars As Giants Win In Overtime
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 29Joe Pisarcik, a 25yearold National Football League rookie with a bad cold, was the unlikely hero tonight as the Giants returned to their home of champions and registered their first victory of the year and their first ever in an overtime game.

title: CUOMO PLEDGES USE OF COMMUNITY AID
description: Mario M. Cuomo, carrying his campaign to the problemridden Red Hook section of Brooklyn, said that if he were elected Mayor, New York City would make more efficient use of Federal communitydevelopment funds than it has under Mayor Beanie's administration.

title: CARTER TO SEEK CUT IN '78 WHEAT CROP; FOOD RESERVE ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29In the face of mounting surpluses, President Carter has decided to curb the nation's 1978 wheat crop and give the Federal Government a bigger role in the grain stockpile business. The cost of the new program was estimated at $4.4 billion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Wildwood (N.J.) Beach Patrol, which was dismissed after ignoring a backtowork order after a oneday sickout, rejected an offer by the state to drop charges against 58 of the lifeguards if four others would plead guilty to contempt of court.

title: Argentine Wins, 62, 60, Extends Streak to 39
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 29Bring on Borg and Connors. Bring on the United States Open. Guillermo Vilas is ready.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: South Africa Reports Foiling Invasion Plot
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug 29 (Reuters) Justice Minister James Kruger said today that the police had smashed a guerrilla network plotting an invasion of South Africa.

title: Advertising
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the nation's largest apparel manufacturer and largest apparel advertiser, has a widelyknown brand name in Levi's. It probably would rank among the dozen most recognizable brands in America and its worldwide recognition may be almost as strong.

title: Byrne Campaign Expects Carter To Be in State 5 Hours Sept. 10
description: President Carter is expected to spend about five hours in New Jersey on Sept. 10 campaigning with Governor Byrne, officials of the Byrne campaign said yesterday. The tentative schedule, which must still be confirmed by the White House, is for the President to arrive at Newark International Airport at 9 A.M. and to leave at about 2 P.M. from Mercer County Airport near Trenton.

title: GAINS BY BLUE CHIPS AID BROAD RECOVERY ON LIGHT TURNOVER
description: Buoyed by strength in many of the depressed bluechip issues, the stock market posted a broad advance yesterday in the second slowest trading of the year.

title: The Battle of the Wine Bottle Labels: Maker Leaves His Mark After All
description: Walter Taylor can stop inking out his name on his wine bottlesfor the time being.

title: DEMAND OVER FORCES SNAGS RHODESIA PLAN
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 29A proposal to suspend and eventually deactivate the forces opposing each other in the Rhodesian guerrilla war continued to be the main sticking point today as British and American diplomats presented their settlement package to Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, who holds the key to Rhodesian acceptance of the plan.

title: Family of Slain Texas Surgeon Sues ExFatherinLaw for $7.6 Million
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 29Dr. John Hill and his wife, Joan Robinson Hill, ranked among Houston's social leaders in the 1960's. He was a prominent plastic surgeon, she was a noted horsewoman. They lived in River Oaks. Houston's most exclusive neighborhood.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Pickin' and Strummin' Reunite At Philadelphia Folk Festival
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 29Midway between putting down his guitar and picking up his violin during last night's concert at the Philadelphia Folk Festival, Norman Blake paused to editorialize.

title: Monmouth
description: ENTRIES

title: Waldheim Urges a 20% Increase In U.N. Budget for Next 2 Years
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that he would ask the General Assembly to approve a $942 million budget for the United Nations for the next two years, up 20.1 percent from the 197677 figure.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 29  Patricia Q. Sheehan, State Commissioner of Community Affairs, will be among 10 representatives chosen by the National Governors Conference who will meet tomorrow at the White House with urban and domestic affairs officials of the Carter Administration.

title: Events/Sports
description: 7:55 P.M., WMCA: Baseball. Yankees vs. Seattle.

title: Detroit Is Adding Hoopla, Long Absent, to '78 Lines
description: DETROIT, Aug. 29There had been a quick look at the star of the show the night before. After the news conferences were over, and the outoftown visitors and local television personalities had eaten cocktailparty hush puppies and quiche Lorraine, after, dinner was over, but before the dancing girls came onstage, someone flipped back a white sheet that covered one of the American Motors Corporation's new 1978 Concord automobiles.

title: Article 1  No Title
Jean Barrere, 59, Stage Manager For Many Hit Shows on Broadway
description: Jean Barrere, a stage manager whose career of more than 35 years brought him into association with some of Broadway's most illustrious and complicated shows, among them Life with Father and South Pacific, died over the weekend at his apartment in CrotononHudson, N.Y. He was 59 years old.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: What Abe Beame Did
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission staff report on the city's financial legerdemain has incited controversy over Mayor Beame's conduct before the 1975 financial crisis. Mr. Beame's detractors see the report as a flat indictment; his supporters view it as irrelevant to the issue of the Mayor's fitness to govern. Neither conclusion seems adequate.

title: INEZ KELLER FUITE
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 29 (AP)Inez Keller Fuite, who was in the first group of airline stewardesses to fly 47 years ago, died Friday. She was 71 years old.

title: Federal Panel Urges More Public and Private Help for Epileptics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29A Federal panel that investigated the problems of epilepsy concluded today that increased governmental and private efforts were needed to help several hundred thousand Americans epileptics to lead more productive and meaningful lives.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 30, 1977

title: 15 Key Black Leaders Plan a Coordinated Attack on Callous Neglect
Olympic Assistant Named
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Aug. 29 (UPI) Roger Tubby, a deputy commissioner of parks and recreation, was named today as special assistant to Governor Carey for the Winter Olympics.

title: Largest Advertisers Spent 20% More in '76
description: The 100 biggest national advertisers spent $7.7 billion for advertising and promotion last year, up 20 percent from 1975. This increase to a new record was the largest in the last 22 years, according to an annual tabulation made by Advertising Age.

title: Giants' Scoring, Statistics
description: Giants  Kotar, 16, pass from Pisarcik (Danelo, kick).

title: 4 Accused of a Plot To Take Presley Body
description: MEMPHIS. Aug. 29 (AP)Four men who the police say were plotting to steal Elvis Presley's body and hold it for ransom were arrested early today outside the cemetery where the singer is entombed.

title: Kuwait's Total Gas Output Up in '76
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 29 (AP)Kuwait's total gas production in 1976 amounted to 395.8 million cubic feet compared from 382.4 million cubic feet in 1975, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: Two Justices in Brooklyn Receive Sealed Report on 44Caliber Killer
description: Two justices in New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday received, but said they did not open, a sealed, handdelivered report containing the psychiatric evaluations of David R. Berkowitz's mental fitness to stand trial for murder.

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR CENSURES SIX AGENTS IN LAS VEGAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Clarence M. Kelley, censured six Las Vegas agents and placed five of them on probation today for violating bureau rules but said he had found no evidence of criminality or serious misconduct in the Las Vegas office.

title: CARTER TO SEEK CUT IN '78 WHEAT CROP; FOOD RESERVE ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29In the face of mounting surpluses, President Carter has decided to curb the nation's 1978 wheat crop and give the Federal Government a bigger role in the grain stockpile business. The cost of the new program was estimated at 84.4 billion.

title: Detective Slain on Brooklyn Call; Partner Kills Man, Shoots Another
description: A 34yearold policeman, responding to a 911 emergency call about a man with a gun was killed by a shotgun blast yesterday as he and his partner tried to enter a room in a shabby brownstone house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The partner killed one man in the room and wounded another.

title: Recession Possible, Canada Warns
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 29The Government's economicstatistics bureau referred today to the possibility of a Canadian recession.

title: For Wagner, Golden, Biondolillo
description: Borough presidents were invented when old New York and the City of Brooklyn merged in 1899. They were responsible for many public works until reformers wearied of reports of featherbedding and took away the last of those powers hi 1961. But subsequent incumbents found new responsibilities.

title: Miami Gets U.S. Transit Grant
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)A $15million grant for 110 new buses and transit facilities in the Miami, Fla., area was announced today by the Urban Mass Transit Administration. The grant provides for airconditioned, 50passenger buses, funds for purchasing land for a new Coral Gables 300bus light maintenance and storage facility and expansion of the present maintenance facility. The grant was made to Dade County (Miami) for the Metropolitan Dade County Transit Agency.

title: CLIFFORD D. CARLSON
description: GENEVA, Ill., Aug. 29 (UPI)Former Representative Clifford D. Carlson, Republican of Illinois, died at his family's farm in Dixon yesterday. He was 61 years old.

title: Bayi Discloses Invitation To Race Walker in Mile
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)Filbert Bayi of Tanzania, hte worldrecord holder in the 1,500meter run, was beaten at a mile today, and then disclosed he might run a mile against the Olympic 1,500meter champion John Walker of New Zealand in Vancouver, British Columbia, Sept. 17. Walker holds the mile world record of 3 minutes 49.4 seconds. Bayi's 1,500 record is 3:32.2.

title: Cemetery Now a Historic Place
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)The burial place of the Chippewa Chief Great Buffalo has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Chief Great Buffalo died in 1855 at the age of 96. The LaPointe Indian Cemetery is on Madeline Island in Lake Superior off the coast of Wisconsin. The United States holds the property in trust for the Bad River Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians. National register status means that the property is eligible for Federal funds for maintenance and upkeep.

title: Pressure Against Soap TV Ads Dismays Agency and ABC Aides
description: With the increasing loss of advertisers for ABCTV's controversial new comedy, Soap, officials of leading advertising agencies in New York have expressed concern about the effectiveness of recent campaigns by pressure groups to prevent companies from advertising on television programs.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY. AUGUST 29. 1977

title: A Dieter's Dream: Playing Tricks on the Digestion
description: Another treatment for obesity is about to join the weighty list of painless remedies for shedding excess poundage. This treatment, while not yet tested on humans, appears to be the dieter's dream: It offers weight loss without a drastic reduction in food consumption. All this may someday be accomplished by simply swallowing a tablespoon or two of a colorless, tasteless liquid after each meal.

title: Voyager 2 Reports Trouble Clear; Twin Set for Labor Day Launching
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI) Scientists of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory received information today from Voyager 2, bound for Jupiter, that a dust cover had finally been removed from the spacecraft's science instrument package and had been discarded.

title: More, the Review of Journalism, Being Sold to Washington Group
description: More magazine, a monthly review of journalism that started in 1971, is to be sold today to James Adler, president of Congressional Information Services Inc of Washington, according to Michael S. Kramer. its publisher and editor.

title: About New York
description: As a priest and a politician, Louis R. Gigante operates in two realms where substance and appearances can crosshatch and mystify. He handles water and wine and bread and claims there actually is a God somewhere. He also pockets and delivers the worldliest clubhouse contracts for City Hall disposition, hustling eyeonthesparrow favors and backslapped fealties for his followers in the impoverished South Bronx.

title: East Hartford Sniper Holds Off Police
description: A 34yearold man of East Hartford, Conn. who told the police he had killed his wife and son, barricaded himself inside his house last night and fired a rifle at police cars, warning that he would kill himself if the police tried to capture him.

title: The Real Canal Giveaway
description: It's now evident, if anyone ever doubted it, that deep and emotional hostility to the giveaway of the Panama Canal presents the Carter Administration and the Senate with a powerful challenge. Perhaps even more so than in the case of the Vietnam War, the test is whether the American people, governed as they are, can adapt themselves sensibly to a changing international order.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: MACHINE TOOLS ORDERS FOR JULY FELL BY 14.4%
description: July orders for new machine tools fell 14.4 percent below the June level but ran 20.1 percent higher than in July 1976, according to monthly statistics released by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. However, orders for the first seven months reached $1.65 billion, which represented a gain of 51.7 percent over the 1976 period.

title: Four Years After Airline Employee Was Forced to Retire, His Protest Goes Before Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)It didn't seem right to Harris McMann when United Airlines, his employer for nearly three decades, insisted in 1973 that he retire.

title: Companies Issue Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended July 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates slack Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American. Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Agency and Beame Talking About Different Points
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission report on New York City's financial dealings has set off a debate between the commission and city officials over who is telling the truth about what occurred in late 1974 and early 1975, just before the fiscal crisis became public knowledge.

title: BUSHWICK MAY GET A HOUSING PROJECT
description: Plans were approved yesterday for a S14.2 million housing development in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, an area of spreading blight and burnedout build ings where almost no housing has been built in decades.

title: Navy Giving Up Carrier Roosevelt; Vessel May Head for Scrap Yard
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 30 (AP)The aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt will be decommissioned Oct. 1 and stricken from the Navy's roll of ships, the Navy confirmed today.

title: People in Sports
description: Ted Turner is marketing his mouth. The outspoken, flamboyant Atlanta Braves' owner and America's Cup trials skipper has hired Ed Keating to negotiate with several companies considering Turner as a spokesman for their products. Keating is the man who negotiated a contract for the exfree agent Gary Matthews, now a Braves' outfielder, whose case led to Turner's suspension from baseball.

title: Controversial Pitfalls Avoided
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 30 (AP)The leader of Northern Ireland's nondenominational Alliance Party, Oliver Napier, welcomed the tenor of President Carter's statement.

title: Courageous Picked As Defender of Cup
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30Thunder, rain and lightning provided the appropriate background on Bannister's Wharf late today for the anointment and appointment of Robert E. (Ted) Turner, skipper of Courageous, as the next defender of the America's Cup starting Sept. 13 against the yacht Australia.

title: Harlem Wasn't There
description: I turn the corner at St. Nicholas Avenue and 125th Street, the damp, gray day covering my brow with sweat. Around me the streets are teeming with shoppers  people sifting through racks of clothes, vendors haggling over vegetables, children pressing their faces to windows. Blocks away I can see the gutted rooms of tenements, trash toppling from door fronts, cats circling warily from burnedout foyers.

title: Technology
description: An electrical power source using plutonium 238 is one of the mainstays of the nation's space exploration program. The steady output of the heatproducing capsule containing the plutonium has turned out to be preferable to solar cells in some parts of outer space, and the system can withstand fiery reentry. Page D5.

title: About Education
description: Three Harvard researchers have found evidence of a reversal of the longterm trend to water down the reading levels of textbooks used in American elementary and secondary schools.

title: Private Lives
description: THERE ARE more kittens. Don't ask how. According to the Yiddish apothegm, Shoulders are from God, and burdens, too. These kittens look like white rats, but it seems unlikely that the black cat would have littered the clothes closet in the front hall with white rats. Why, when there are clothes closets, suitcases, bureau drawers and plastic trash bags, should anyone have bothered to line a maternity box with newspaper and carpet remnants? How cunning of the black cat to have disdained this box in favor of an old rainboot and one's tennis racquet. Perhaps the catgut in the tennis racquet overwhelmed her with nostalgia, although we have been reliably informed that catgut is actually the dried intestines of a sheep. Still, sheepgut sounds wrong.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: James Jones Gives Robeson Part Life
description: LOS ANGELES IN A SECONDFLOOR rehearsal studio on the edge of the San Fernando Valley, James Earl Jones, the actor, is bringing life these days to the character of Paul Robeson, a black man with a curiously paradoxical place in American history.

title: Columbus, Ohio, Busing Plans Vex Even Those Favoring Integration
description: COLUMBUS, OhioJanice H. Butts has vivid memories of the days when schools in this city were really segregated.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: Incoming

title: The Labor Scene
description: Organized labor plans nationwide rallies next week to focus Congressional attention on its call for a decent job at a decent wage for every American willing and able to work. Page D3.

title: Article 1  No Title
What's in a Number? Ask 35 (or 42) Pine St.
description: Tenants at 35 Pine Street in Yonkerswhere the alleged Son of Sam killer, David R. Berkowitz, residedhave been asked to tell everybody they live at 42 Pine Street.

title: South's Governors Fear the Region May Lose Out on Aid and Energy
description: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 30Southern governors charged today that wellorganized efforts were under way to shortchange their region in the distribution of Federal funds and the formulation of a national energy policy.

title: Selma Robinson, a Writer, 78; Contributing Editor of McCall's
description: Selma Robinson, a contributing editor of McCall's magazine, died in New York City Monday. She was 78 years old.

title: Carter Vows to Aid Recovery of Ulster If Peace Is Reached
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  President Carter promised today that if Roman Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland settled their differences peacefully, the United States would help to encourage new financial investments in that strifetorn British province.

title: Hearings Scheduled by S.E.C. On Shareholder Participation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 30 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a schedule of hearings on shareholder participation in the corporate lectoral process.

title: Portrait ofa Soviet Artist: Enigmatic Style Reflects Equally Enigmatic Man
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30The brooding canvas, 10 feet high and 20 feet wide, dominates Ilya Glazunov's spacious studio just off Moscow's Kalinin Prospect. Its celebrated subjectsfrom Czar Nicholas II and Lenin to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn and the Beatlespeer out past stacks of smaller paintings, a worn easel, a palette bright with dried wisps of paint, but they find no audience.

title: Wheat Futures Prices Up About 1c
description: Wheat futures traders, as expected, shrugged off President Carter's move to reduce wheat acreage by 20 percent on the 1978 crop. Prices of wheat futures in Chicago closed up less than a cent a bushel.

title: Celeste W. Cheatham Is Dead at 74
description: Celeste Wickliffe Cheatham, a patron of the arts and former owner of the Fenwick Court, a Madison Avenue shop that specialized in antiques, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a short illness. She was 74 years old and lived in Riverhouse, at 435 East 52nd Street and in Palm Beach.

title: Syria Is Buffeted by Corruption, Violence and Economic Problems
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 27The Government of President Hafez alAssad is plagued by sectarian tensions, corruption, economic difficulties and a series of assassinations and explosions.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW. Aug. 30 (AP)Soviet dissidents have asked the World Psychiatric Association's current meeting in Honolulu to support their colleagues who have allegedly been placed in Soviet psychiatric hospitals because of their political views.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Moscow Steps Up Its Diplomatic Efforts on Mideast
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30The Soviet Union has undertaken a flurry of mysterious diplomatic activity on the Middle East in advance of a meeting next week in Vienna between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Letters
description: Those Chicago Alleys

title: Police Check Report That Sniper Tried to Buy Bullets for .44 Gun
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J. Aug. 30Four men who were ambushed and killed by a sniper here last Friday were buried today in this hilly, pastoral area where crimes of violence had been virtually unknown.

title: Dr. William H. Resnick, 80, Is Dead; Retired Yale Professor of Medicine
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30Dr. William H. Resnik, heart specialist and retired professor of medicine and professor emeritus at Yale, died today at his home in Stamford. He was SO years old and lived at 27 Fox Hill Road.

title: 2 PATROLMEN GIVEN YONKERS PROMOTION
description: YONKERS, Aug. 30Two Yonkers patrolmen who alerted the New York City police to their suspicions that David R. Berkowitz might be the Son of Sam were promoted to detective tonight in. a ceremony presided over by Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli. For Patrolmen Peter Intervallo and Thomas Chamberlain the promotion will mean a raise of $742 a year for each.

title: OutofCourt Environment
description: A proposal to settle environmental disputes whenever possible by mediation rather than through the courts is as invulnerable to argument as virtue itself. The cost of ??gation, the endless time it consumes and the antagonism that it generatesall speak in favor of the faster, simpler and more social approach of mediation, most recently advocated by Secretary of the Interior Andrus. Yet there is good reason to doubt that the proposal will become a reality on any major scale.

title: C. A. B. May Study LowFare Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)The Justice Department announced today that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to investigate a transAtlantic lowfare cartel agreement by the major airlines that might drive out competition by charter and specialized carriers.

title: Portrait ofaSovietArtist: Enigmatic Style Reflects Equally Enigmatic Man
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30The brooding canvas, 10 feet high and 20 feet wide, dominates Ilya Glazunov's spacious studio just off Moscow's Kalinin Prospect. Its celebrated subjectsfrom Czar Nicholas II and Lenin to Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn and the Beatlespeer out past stacks of smaller paintings, a worn easel, a palette bright with dried wisps of paint, but they find no audience.

title: Four Shore Counties in Jersey Press for Offshore Oil Controls
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 30 (UPI)Officials of four shore counties say they will continue to fight for strict controls over offshore oil development in the Atlantic Ocean to protect the environment.

title: Tanzanian Support On Rhodesia Asked By Young and Owen
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 30(AP)  Andrew Young, the American delegate to the United Nations, and Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain arrived here today after a stop in Dar es Salaam to seek support of their Rhodesia peace plan from Tanzania's influential President, Julius K. Nverere.

title: Tito Gets Huge Welcome as He Begins Visit to China
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 30President Tito of Yugoslavia received a huge official welcome when he arrived in Peking today for his first visit to China. The warmth of his reception reflected the importance China places on supporting allies against the Soviet Union and the new mood in Peking following the death last year of Mao Tsetung.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX AID TO CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets took the Federal Reserve's discount rate in stride yesterday. Shortterm interest rates rose moderately; intermediate issues held steady as the Treasury sold $2.5 billion of notes at an average rate of 6.84 percent, and corporate and taxexempt bond yields declined.

title: Councilman Gigante's Privilege To Silence as a Priest Is Upheld
description: The right of the Rev. Louis R. Gigante, a New York City Councilman and a Roman Catholic priest, not to divulge to a grand jury the nature of a conversation with a reputed Mafia chief was upheld yesterday.

title: Renee Richards Serving
description: The Virginia WadeRenee Richards women's match at the United S:ates Open tennis championships will be played tomorrow afternoon. . . . Chris Evert's biorhythms, which were way down the day she lost to Miss Wade at. Wimbledon, appear fine for the Open until the semifinals. Her diagnosis for the day of the semifinals: Your sensitivity is high. but yew should control emotional desires and stick with routine tasks. . . . Can Manuel Orantes or Eddie Dibbs win Forest Hills after reaching the finals of the United States Pro? History is against it. . . . the Nastase had his first racquetthrowing argument at Forest Hills. but it came with Kelly the Chimp during a comic routine in the onehour television special.. Super night at Forest Hills, taped Monday night by CBS for airing, Sept, 9. . . . CBS (Channel 2) will have nightly reviews (11:3011:45) of the tournament action. . . . Fastest route to Forest Hills: E or F express subway from Manhattan.

title: F.T.C. Official Urges Curb On Hearing Aid Dealers And Time to Try Devices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)Hearing aid dealers should be required to offer moneyback 30day trials, and doortodoor sales without written permission should be barred, a Federal Trade Commission official proposed today.

title: Manufacturers' Capital Budgets Up
description: Capital appropriations by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers totaled $15.19 billion in the second quarter of 1977, the second highest amount in 24 years, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: The Corporate Pitch: Play Ball!
description: FEW MINUTES before 5 P.M. on most Tuesdays, Ellen Saracino leaves her desk at J. Walter Thompson, puts on the scruffiest jeans I can find, sneakers, and a blue Tshirt emblazone'd with the JWT logo. She joins several similarly dressed coworkers in the lobby and after a brief taxi ride emerges at Central Park's Sheep Meadow, transformed from a Kodak account secretary into Shins, the short center of the advertising agency's softball team.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Most recipes that call for a roux specify cooking butter and flour together briefly before adding a liquid such as milk or chicken broth. I have a friend from Louisiana who keeps insiding that a proper roux should always be browned before it is used. Is this true?

title: Silk Flowers Blossom In a West Side Loft
description: From their loft on West 30th Street, 31yearold Laura Gottwald and her husband, Jansuz, did nearly $250,000 worth of business last year making and selling silk flowers under the label of Laura Paprika, Mrs. Gottwald's maiden name.

title: Port Rivalry Stalling Dock Worker Talks
description: The heightened competition for shipping business among the Atlantic ports from Boston to Hampton Roads, Va., has stymied contract negotiations with the longshoremen, whose current contract expires on Sept. 30.

title: THE EXPERT SHOPPER
description: PLUMP, RIPE, sweetlyjuicy red tomatoes are one of midsummer's most succulent gastronomic delights. A pungent, winey boon to stews, soups and sauces, this crimson vegetable (technically, botanically, a fruit), is best appreciated when eaten raw.

title: PENTAGON ASKS SALE OFF15'S TO SAUDIS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The Pentagon has quietly urged the Carter Administration to sell 60 F15 supersonic fighters to Saudi Arabia, according to Government sources.

title: WHTE HOUSE ORDERS URBAN POLICY REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Stung by the recent criticism by black leaders and disturbed by the looting at the time of the New York City blackout, President Carter has ordered an urgent review of Federal urban policy.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 30, 1977

title: Con Ed Controller, Citing Ill Health, Not at Hearing; Investigator Calls His PreBlackout Action Panicky
description: The man who ran Consolidated Edison's control center just before the blackout of July 1314 declined to testify yesterday at a hearing held by a speical mayoral panel investigating the power failure.

title: Pisarcik's Passing Puts Punch in Giants' Offense
description: On the kind of hot, sticky August day when poets wonder why they remain in New York pent, Joe Pisarcik arrived like a cool breeze from the Canadian Football League and reminded themexcitement.

title: Private Air Force Used by Port Aides, Assembly Unit Says
description: Dr. William J. Ronan and other officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey turned the agency's three helicopters into a private air force for their own commuting, shopping, entertainment and personal business trips, a New York State legislative committee charged yesterday.

title: SOL WORTH, PROFESSOR AT ANNENBERG SCHOOL
description: Sol Worth, a scholar in the field that combined anthropology and visual communications and a professor of communications at the Annenberg School of the University of Pennsylvania, died in Boston on Monday. He was 55 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: British Ponder a Ban on ViolenceRidden Carnival
description: LONDON, Aug. 30A debate got under way today on whether to ban the annual Notting Hill Carnival after it had ended in violence for the second year in a row.

title: Record Japanese Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, Aug. 30 (Reuters)Japan's high trade surplus soared to a record $2.05 billion in July, when exports rose by 23 percent over the corresponding month last year, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Bridge:
description: The best autobiography ever written by a bridgeplayer is certainly The Strange Lives of One Man, by Ely Culbertson, who had the autobiographical luck to have been a hobo, a cosmopolitan, a political reformer and a revolutionary under sentence of death as well as Mr. Bridge of the 1930's.

title: VANCE MAY CANCEL VISIT WITH GROMYKO NEXT WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The State Department today raised the possibility that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would cancel his talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, in Vienna next week in order to join in Washington activities attending the signing of the new Panama Canal treaties.

title: Begin Rejects Arab League As Geneva Proxy for P.L.O.
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 30Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that the recent Syrian suggestion that the Arab League might represent the Palestine Liberation Organization in any reconvened Geneva conference would be completely unacceptable to Israel.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal judge in Newark approved a request to subpoena news reporters for questioning about the sources of stories involving a twoyear investigation of Henry Helstoski, a former member of the House of Representatives.

title: Lance Is Forfeiting Important Backing In Southern Press
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30In a significant reversal of opinion, the South's most outspoken editorial supporter of Bert Lance is now suggesting that he should consider resigning if f for no other reason, than to save himself. The suggestion, by Bill Shipp, editorial page columnist for The Atlanta Constitution, comes in the wake of previous strong support for Mr. Lance.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: stantine Trypanis, who pointed out numerous difficulties but promised to look into the matter.

title: Careers
description: Algebra, trigonometry and physics are becoming standard summer fare for increasing numbers of young men and women.

title: Nationwide Rallies for Decent Jobs at Decent Wages
description: Organized labor, already embroiled in bitter battles on Capitol Hill over laborlaw reform and the minimum wage, plans nationwide rallies next week to move an equally controversial proposal onto the front burner of Congressional attention: its call for a decent job at a decent wage for every American willing and able to work. Governors and mayors in many areas have joined the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in proclaiming the week ushered in by Labor Day as Full Employment Week.

title: The Iowa State Fair: Baking Up A Batch of Blue Ribbons
description: DES MOINES They came from all over Iowa and beyond last week, carting their homemade jams and jellies, breads and cookies, canned fruits and picklesand high hopes.

title: Carter Vows to Aid Recovery of Ulster If Peace Is Reached
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  President Carter promised today that if Roman Catholics and Protestants in Northern ireland settled their differences peacefully, the United States would help to encourage new financial investments in that strifetorn British province.

title: Personal Health
description: THE WATER diet, the grapefruit diet, the Atkins diet, the drinking man's diet, the Air Force diet, the Mayo diet, the sex diet, the ice cream diet, the rice diet, the lowcalorie diet, the caloriesdon'tcount diet, the Weight Watcher's diet, the macrobiotic diet....

title: Dublin Welcomes Statement
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 30The Irish Government welcomed President Carter's statemeat as a constructive development in American relations with Ireland and Britain.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: PERFECT START: Women sprinters getting off the mark at Iron Bound Stadium in Newark. Event was part of SPEDY (Summer Program for Economically Disadvantaged Youth) program that included basketball and field events.

title: Again, The Whole Earth Museum
description: SPETSAIS, GreeceAccording to Webster's Third New International Dictionary (1965), a museum is an institution devoted to the procurement, care and display of objects of lasting interest or value.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT ISN'T necessary to be a wine enthusiast to know about the white wine explosion. There isn't a bar in New York where white wine sales haven't approached or passed the sale of gin and vodka. Hardbitten martini drinkers by the score switch every day to white wine, and many a hostess has saved a fortune on her liquor bills because so many guests now ask for white wine rather than mixed drinks.

title: Advice on Cooking Beef
description: As a result of 140 cases of salmonellosis food poisoning found in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, the National Center for Disease Control, in Atlanta is recommending that all beef be cooked to an internal temperature of 145 degrees, which is medium.

title: Pop: Roberta Flack Shows a New Magic
description: ROBERTA FLACK may not be quite the commercial success she was a few years ago. But she remains a considerable artist, nonetheless. Thus her appearance for two shows Monday night at Smucker's, the club near the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was a noteworthy event. Miss Flack did it partly to encourage Smucker's, which is filling a valuable role in giving musicians a place to play and Brooklyn audiences a place to hear good music. She also did it as a benefit for the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation.

title: DePerryMasonization
description: The time has come to put our courts on television. This may seem like a drastic remedy for our enfeebled criminal justice system, but it isn't. Television cameras have been allowed in Colorado state courtrooms under carefully regulated conditions for 20 years. Whether the dispensation of justice has improved is a matter of opinion, but Alabama, Florida and Washington have been impressed enough to try it for themselves.

title: Blue Line Triumphs In 4Horse Jumpoff
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30More than two decades ago, the Southampton Horse Show was one of the leading outdoor equestrian events in the East.

title: Southern Leaders Briefed by Carter On Canal Treaties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  President Carter today described the task of gaining public acceptance for the new Panama Canal treaties as one of those items that falls on the shoulders of leaders that is not popular.

title: Betting Against Famine
description: President Carter's decision to seek a 20 percent cut in wheat acreage represents a victory for the Agriculture Department and wheat farmers, a loss for the Treasury Department and the Council of Economic Advisers and a bet against world hunger next year. It's a risky bet and a regrettable decision.

title: HOSPITAL OFFICIALS ADOPT PLAN ON HEALTH INSURANCE
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 (AP)More than 12,000 hospital administrators and other officials adopted a universal health insurance plan today at the annual convention of the house of delegates of the American Hospital Association.

title: CARTER ORDER TO CUT WHEAT ACREAGE GETS WIDE FARM SUPPORT
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30Farmers and their leading spokesmen gave wide support today to President Carter's decision to cut wheat acreage, saying it was a step in the right direction, but most said they, feared it was too limited in scope to alleviate rural distress caused by falling prices.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
12Meter Australia to Be Challenger
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 30Half an hour after Courageous was selected today to defend the America's Cup, the yacht Australia earned the right to challenge for it by completing a 40 rout of Sverige.

title: Last Copper Producer Settles
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 30 (AP)Asarco Inc. has reached a tentative agreement to end a twomonth walkout by 3,500 workers, an official of the United Steelworkers of America said today. Asarco is the last of six major copper producers to reach a new contract agreement. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

title: Couple Accused in Loan Scheme
description: MIAMI, Aug, 30 (AP)A Fort Lauderdale couple today faced trial in Federal District Court on charges of bilking churches and developers in Alabama. Minnesota, Indiana and New York of more than $600,000. James G. Fish and his wife, Pauline, are accused of operating a bogus international financial corporation. According to a Federal grand jury indictment, the couple created the Consortium Funding Corporation to han dle loans to churches and other institutions having trouble securing development money.

title: Black Leaders Agree Full Employment Is Overriding Issue of the 1970's
description: Black leaders who met here two days ago to plan a strategy for dealing with what they perceive as this country's widening racial gap agreed that the solution must begin with a full employment policy.

title: Korean Party Chief Urges Inquiry on Scandal in U.S.
description: SEOUL. South Korea, Aug. 30A ranking opposition party member called on the South Korean Parliament today to investigate charges of Korea's allegedly illegal influence buying scheme in Washington.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Arrogance, Egos and Beards
description: I don't care if Streinbrenner likes beards, began a letter from a fan in last Sunday's New York Times. I don't care if Jackson's ego is bigger than Munson's ego. I don't care who likes whom, who makes what, who stands where in relation to who stands there....I've cared for most of my life about the Yankees. I've opened the paper in the morning to discover what happened the night before, and until this year I've found out. But I don't get any baseball information anymore. I get the latest psychiatric report, the last philosophy of a catcher, the musings of a pitcher, the wanderings of the right fielder, the latent aggressiveness of this one, the basic unhappiness of that one. The poor man is mistaken if he thinks that change came about this year. Night baseball started it ever so long ago and the situation became acute when the major leagues put franchises in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Oakland, Anaheim, San Diego and Seattle. When the Yankees are on the road playing the A's, Angels or Mariners, the man can't discover in his morning paper what has happened the night before, because when the paper went to press, nothing had happened. He didn't find out last year, either.

title: U.S. Relay Team Scores An Easy Victory in 400
description: LUEDENSHEID, West Germany. Aug 30 (UPI)An American 400meter relay team raced to an easy victory in 38.81 seconds today at a warmup track and field meet for the first World Cup, which starts Friday in Dusseldorf.

title: How to Give Silks Tender Loving Care
description: Silk, the queen of the fibers, dethroned in recent years by the less expensive, easiertocarefor synthetics, is making a comeback.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: In Memoriam
description: SILVERMANMarc Barry. Our hearts still ache & our tears still flow because we miss you so. Love forever, Mother, Dad & brother Bruce

title: Issue and Debate
description: Everyone wants the best possible deal when it comes to money. This probably explains the builtin appeal of current legislation that would end a 44yearold Federal law prohibiting the payment of interest on checking accounts. But as with many good ideas, the situation is more complicated than it first appears.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30Faced by a growing no smoking movement in a state whose citizens last year smoked 18 billion cigarettes, a committee of the State Public Health Council proposed today sharp restrictions today on the use of tobacco in a wide varlety of public places.

title: Bomb Suspect Arrested
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)A local Man has been arrested on charges of placing a bomb at the front door of a bank near his home. The suspect, Eugene Storley, 28 years old, was apprehended yesterday by Federal agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms following his indictment on charges of planting the bomb at the National State Bank on South Broad Street. The blast on Aug. 16 shattered three glass doors.

title: WHITE HOUSE ORDERS URBAN POLICY REVIEW; FUND PLAN DRAWN UP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Stung by the recent criticism by black leaders and disturbed by the looting at the time of the New York City blackout. President Carter has ordered an urgent review of Federal urban policy.

title: India to Honor U.S. Commitments Despite Problems With CocaCola
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Reuters)India will honor all agreements with foreign investors despite the Government's present problems with the Americanowned CocaCola Company, Commerce Minister Mohen Dharia said here today.

title: SexSegregated Schools Boycotted
description: LIBERTY, Miss., Aug, 30Black students have overwhelmingly joined a boycott of Amite County's four public schools to protest a sevenyearold Federal court desegregation order that separated the schools by sex.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: ERice, Gross, Burleson. DPBoston 3. LOBOakland 5, Boston 6. 28Gross. Doyle 2, Hobson, Ystrzmski. HRLynn (15). SBYStrzmskl. SFBurleson, Lynn.

title: Executives of Ford Predict Record Sales For Its 1978 Autos
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30Executives of the Ford Motor Company predicted today record sales for the 1978 model year, but they declined to join General Motors in forecasting record combined sales of cars and trucks for the auto industry as a whole.

title: Berkowitz Is Found Unfit for Trial, But Gold Will Get Own Evaluation
description: David R. Berkowitz. the man accused of being the .44caliber killer, was reported by two courtappointed psychiatrists yesterday to be mentally unfit to stand trial and to be suffering at present from paranoia.

title: CARTER AIDES FAVOR SHIFT IN PRIMARY RULE
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 30White House political aides are trying to smooth the way for President Carter's renomination in 1980 by making it harder for minor candidates to win delegates, and Democratic Party liberals today accused them of trying to stifle opposition.

title: It's Not Nice to be Fooled by Mother Nature
description: The first two times I was pregnant, my Greek inlaws used traditional methods from the village to determine the sex of the unborn child. My husband's aunt, for example. would throw a lamb's kidney into the fire. If it popped, the child would be a girl; if it remained whole, it was a boy. Or if I picked an acorn from a tree and it had a worm in it, I would have a girl, whereas if the acorn was perfect, it was a boy. Or if the mother's face broke out during pregnancy she was clearly carrying a girl, while if her skin stayed smoothbut you get the idea.

title: Books of The Times
description: EVIDENCE abounds that for more than a million Cambodians the wake of the 197075 war in their country was worse than the fighting. Refugees have provided nightmarish accounts of harshness under Communism: starvation, forced movement of hundreds of thousands of people. and mass slaughter, much of it indiscriminate and with little, if any, provocation.

title: O'NEILL DENIES A REPORT THAT PARK USED HIS OFFICE
description: WATERTOWN, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP)Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, said today that he had only social contacts with Tongsun Park and labeled ridiculous a report in The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Park had used his office.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 (AP)Hurricane Anita whipped the Gulf of Mexico into froth and headed west today, prompting thousands of Texans and Louisianans to move inland.

title: A Pianist With a Touch of the Poet
description: THE NEW YORK Philharmonic chose, inexplicably, to present the first concert of its fiveday Celebration of Black Composers in the confined space known as the Auditorium of the Lincoln Center Library of the Performing Arts, which normally seats about 250 persons. However, the program on Monday night, an admissionfree piano recital by Leon Bates, attracted several hundred more than could be accommodated. Folding chairs were set up in the aisles for some, while others stood at the rear or milled about in frustration in the lobby.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN STIRS NEW AARMS FLURRY
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 30The controversy over South Africa's potential to develop nuclear weapons was revived today when Finance Minister Owen Norwood said at a political gathering in Durban that the Government reserved the right to depart from its assurances last week that its nuclear program was for peaceful purposes only.

title: U.S. AND SOUTH KOREA IN 5YEAR TEXTILE PACT
description: SEOUL, Aug. 30 (Reuters)The United States and South Korea have agreed on a new fiveyear agreement slowing down Korean textile exports to the United States, Government sources said here today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Dunne and Landes in Nassau County
description: For 25 years after World War II, Nassau County was one of the fastestgrowing areas in the nation. Since 1969, however, growth has stopped; indeed, population has dropped. People in Nassau are now concerned about the loss of industry and jobs, about the departure younger families, about inadequate transportation and high taxes. Dealing with the present and longrange problems of this county of 1.5 million people requires an administrator who is capable of intelligent analysis and fruitful innovation.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Badillo Asks an End to Many RealEstate Exemptions
description: Representative Herman Badillo and his new running mate in the Democratic primary election, Abraham Hirschfeld, called yesterday for the abolition of exemptions from city property taxes enjoyed by owners of certain commercial buildings.

title: Lance and the Georgians
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30In the last few days, there has been a definite change in the White House attitude, not toward Bert Lance personally but toward the Lance problem. Publicly, his Georgia colleagues are still supporting him, but privately and sadly they are now conceding that he is embarrassing the President and will probably have to go.

title: Smith Ends Campaign in Rhodesia By Promising Positive Proposals
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 30 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia closed his election campaign tonight with a speech promising some very positive proposals when British and American mediators arrive here later this week but expressing little hope for the success of the mission.

title: PENTAGON ASKS SALE OFF15'5 TO SAUDIS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The Pentagon has quietly urged the Carter Administration to sell 60 F15 supersonic fighters to Saudi Arabia, according to Government sources.

title: Guarterback for Blacks
description: For Vernon Eulion Jordan Jr., executive director of the National. Urban League, it took a bit of doing to quarterback the first meeting of the nation's principal black leaders in more than a decade.

title: Teng's New Power: Rehabilitated Leader Seems to Have Become China's Guiding Force
description: PEKING, Aug. 27Teng Hsiaoping, the pragmatic Deputy Prime Minister who was rehabilitated only last month, has emerged as China's guiding force from the recently concluded 11th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, analysts who have been examining the results of the meeting now believe. But Hua Kuofeng, the 56yearold party chairman, is still being carefully accorded the honor due his position and it seems to be the intention that he serve as China's leader for the coming decades.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Won't Oppose Plan by Banks For Review of Consumer Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)The Justice Department announced today it does not opose a plan by commercial banks in New York State to establish a voluntary consumermortgage review program.

title: Companies Issue Sales and Earnings Reports
description: Forperiod ended July 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: F.B.I. AGENT TO SUE U.S. FOR BACK LEGAL FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was the subject of a Justice Department investigation into breakins, wiretaps and mail openings in New York but was never indicted intends to sue the Government for reimbursement of legal fees he incurred in the investigation, a lawyer for the agent said today.

title: Callaghan Notes Human Concern
description: LONDON, Aug. 30Prime Minister James Callaghan tonight expressed warm appreciation of Mr. Carter's statement, especially the President's rejection of violence and his support for peaceful means to find a solution.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Tuesday, August 30, 1977

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus gave the goahead yesterday to Occidental Oil Shale Inc. and Ashland Oil Inc, to start a prototype program for producing oil from shale on Federal land in Colorado.

title: ExConvict in Connecticut Slays His Wife and Son, Then Kills Himself After a 16Hour Siege by Police
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 30A convicted murderer, apparently distressed over his inability to find work after being released from prison, killed his wife and 4yearold son and then fatally shot himself here this morning after holding 50 policemen at bay for more than 16 hours.

title: Belmont Offers Food and Favorites
description: Belmont Park's lawns took on a picniclike atmosphere yesterday. Nine gailycolored concession stands, each offering different types of food and drink, came in for considerable play from the 16,287 fans who braved the afternoon's heat and humidity.

title: News Summary
description: Sale of 60 advanced F15 fighters to Saudi Arabia has been recommended to President Carter by Defense Secretary Harold Brown. Supporters of the $1.5 billion deal say it would cement ties with a major oil producer certain to play a key role in Middle East peace negotiations. Israeli officials say the sale would destabilize the military balance in the region. Opponents in Congress say the plane is too advanced for Saudi pilots. [Page A1, Column 3.]

title: Mets Drop Sixth Straight as Astros' Niekro Wins, 62
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 30Lenny Randle looked up from his dressing cubicle and asked, Are there any more Niekros in the National League?

title: REAL NONALIGNMENT PLEDGED IN SRI LANKA
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 30The new Prime Minister of Sri Lanka said today that his Government would follow a more genuinely nonaligned course in foreign policy than that of the previous government.

title: Music: Irresistible Junkanoo Drums
description: JUNKANOO DRUMS, A Bahamian musical that is being presented nightly through Saturday at the band shell in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park, has no plot or overall theme. Essentially it consists of a series of original songs by the Bahamian singer, songwriter and guitarist Exuma, but the songs have been elaborated into theatrical sketches, with 40 dancers, singers and musicians participating.

title: Article 4  No Title
GOING OUT Guide
description: DOLLARS AND SINCE The New York Stock Exchange has a colorful past. This is reflected in a new display of etchings, engravings and lithographs, along with views of Wall and Broad Streets, at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. The venerable Stock Exchange is shown in successive bases, from Tontine Coffee House where postRevolutionary era merchants gathered to its present site completed in 1903, with an office skyscraper on Wall Street added in 1922. Museum hours are Tuesday through Friday and on Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M., and from 10 A.M. on Saturday.

title: Carter Officials Said to Weigh PayPrice Code
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Carter Administration officials are considering a new program for wage and price restraint in an effort to reduce inflation and expect it could be announced within the next six months, a qualified source said today.

title: A.A.U. to Consider Reinstatement Appeals
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 30 (UPI)The Amateur Athletic Union said today it would begin processing applications for United States track and field athletes who competed as professionals but now seek reinstatement of their amateur status.

title: Billy Carter Pushes Peanut Liqueur on Big Apple
description: While President Carter campaigned for the Pananma Canal treaty yesterday, his brother, Billy, campaigned in the Hunt room of the 21 Club for what was billed as America's first peanut Honour.

title: Fugitive and Hostage Sought
description: ANTIGO, Wis., Aug. 30 (UPIAgents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, backed by local law enforcement agencies, concentrated on a scenic resort area around this northern Wisconsin town today in the search for an escaped Michigan prison trusty and his woman hostage. The authorities said they had received a number of tips from the public, particularly citizens' band radio operators, reporting sightings of Douglas Henry, 22 years old, of Lansing, Mich., and his captive, Evelyn VanTassel, 58, of Marquette, Mich.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Chinese Report Success in Effort To Turn Deserts Into Vineyards
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 30 (Reuters)China has turned its masses loose in the desert, and the masses are winning the battle to turn the sand into productive land, according to papers presented at a United Nations conference aimed at enlarging the world's simply of fertile land.

title: Eagles Acquire Osborne of Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 30The Jets, who obtained Richard Osborne from Philadelphia last year for the $100 waiver price, traded the tight end to the Eagles today for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Child's World
description: SHOES are something special to a child. Until boys and girls are 10 or so, they take more interest in them than in anything else they wear. Maybe it's the subliminal influence of fairy tales in which shoes are always carrying someone off to a magical place: Dorothy to the Land of Oz... the Seven League Roots... and don't forget what a glass slipper did for Cinderella.

title: Notes on People
description: Apungently phrased editorial in the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano yesterday labeled uncivil printed reports that Pope Paul VI would resign when he turns 80 on Sept. 8 and said such reports were unfounded. Departing from the usually staid language of the Vatican newspaper, the editorial said: How can one be so superficial, so vulgar as to want to alarm public opinion at any price with appraisals and forecasts that have no factual base? As for printed rumors about the Pontiff's health, the editorial said, The Pope is well and with alacrity is preparing to preside at the international synod of bishops that will be opened in the Vatican on Sept. 30. It condemned what it called the dogged insistence in which a large part of the Italian newspapers has swooped on the coming birthday to spread imaginary and eccentric news.

title: Mail to White House 2 to 1 Against Lance
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)The White House said today that letters critical of Bert Lance, the budget director, held a 2to1 margin over those supporting him.

title: Dance: Too Uneven
description: WOMEN'S STATES of Mind was a very uneven concert of works by Micki Goodman and Irene O'Brien that was modestly successful at its high point and embarrassingly poor at its worst. The two presented their theater/dance works at the Eden's Expressway loft, 537 Broadway. Monday evenine.

title: Technology
description: The launching this month of a Voyager craft bound for Jupiter, Saturn and beyond is the latest adventure for a littlenoted power technology that has made possible much of the last decade's dramatic extension of knowledge of the solar system.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Connor Is Victor Again In World Title Star Sail
description: KIEL, West Germany, Aug. 30 (AP) Dennis Connor outdueled a fellow American James Schoonmaker. for his second straight victory in the world Star Class sailing championship today. Connor held first place in the overall standing.

title: Mets' Box Score
description: DPMats 2. Houston 1. LOBMats 10, Houston 6. 2BHoward, Cabell, Boisclair, SBFerguson. SNiekro.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Shipboard Cooking: Chartered Meals, With Flexibility
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA. Years ago someone wrote in praise of Ana Bolderson's galley caprices while aboard the Nymph Errant II, a charter boat that plies Bahamian and Caribbean waters during the seasoa and, sometimes, between seasons.

title: Woman Named to State Casino Control Commission
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30Governor Byrne announced today the appointment of the fifth and final member to the state's Casino Control Commission, which will regulate gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Advertising
description: When the Joseph Jacobs Organiza tion, a marketing company for the Jewish media, makes sales pitches to advertisers these days, it has a new weapon in its arsenal: the revelation that President Carter is interested enough in what appears in these publications that he receives a weekly news roundup of their contents.

title: Giants Obtain Gravelle
description: Gordon Gravelle, the Pittsburgh Steelers' starting right tackle in both of their Super Bowl victories and one of pro football's best blockers on pass plays, was obtained by the Giants yesterday for a 1978 draft choice believed to he a secondround one.

title: Chess:
description: CORDOBA, SpainSvetozar Gligoric, a 54yearold Yugoslav grandmaster, has won the Torneo del Vino here in the Don Gonzalo Hotel with an imposing 72 score, thus matching the record set in last year's event by the world champion, Anatoly Karpov.

title: Union Chief Accuses Wagner Sr. of Threats
description: A municipal labor leader charged yesterday that former Mayor Robert F. Wagner had berated and threatened him for refusing to endorse his son, Robert F. Wagner Jr., for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Borough President.

title: Foster Smashes No. 44 As Reds Top Expos, 43
description: Sparky Anderson has changed George Foster's nickname.

title: Meany Supports Blacks' Charges Of Neglect by the Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  George Meany today resumed his feuding with the Carter Administration by associating organized labor with charges made by black leaders yesterday that the Administration was callously neglecting blacks, the poor and American cities.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Aug. 30, 1977

title: Werblin Planning $70 Million Gambling CasinoHotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30David A. (Sonny) Werblin, chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority that. controls the Meadowlands Racetrack and. Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, and four others were named today as principal partners in a group that plans to build a $70 million gambling casinohotel on the Boardwalk.

title: BIRTHDAY OF DR KING AGAIN SCHOOL HOLIDAY
description: Responding to protests from several community leaders, the Central Board of Education yesterday agreed to restore as a school holiday the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Carter to Support Federal Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)President Carter announced today that he would go along with a proposed pay increase for about three million Federal whitecollar workers and military personnel effective Oct. 1, but the amount of the rise was undecided.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Watt Safe?

title: Police Now Admit Producing Film In Investigation of Pornography
description: The New York City Police Department admitted yesterday that, contrary to its earlier denial, it paid $2,500 to have a pornographic film made as part of its efforts to infiltrate the pornography industry.

title: Flower Market Is a Hardy Perennial
